Ihesus.

The flower of the commandments of god with many examples and auctorytees
extracte and drawn as well of holy scryptures as of other doctors and good
ancient faders / the which is much vtyle and prouffytable unto all people.

The.x. commandments of the law.
Thou shall worship one god only. And love him with thy heart perfytely God in
vain swear not wylfully Ne by nothing that he made verily The sunday keep and
halow holyly Hery^ge gods service on them devoutly Fader and mother honor thou
lowly And in their need help them gladly Slay thou no man malycyously Nor to
his death consent wytyngly Thou ne shalt commyt lechery But with thy wife in
wedlock only Thy neighbors goods stele not falsely. Nor nothing withholde
untruly Falls witness bear thou not slyly Nor falls record for none envy Other
men's wives take not flesshely Ne other women to know carnally Other men's
gods coueyt not lightly Nor hold from them vnryghtfully




The five commandments of the church.
The sondayes here thou mass and the festes of commandment. Of thy sins
thou the confess at the leest one time of the year. And thy creator thou
shalt receive / at Eester humbly. These feestes thou shalt halowe / that been
given the in commandment. The four ymbres vigyles thou shall fast / and the
lent entyerly.




INRI

depiction of the crucifixion of Jesus

The prologue of the translatour.
IN the beginning of this little work
Almighty god be my speed
Indewe me lord with some little sperke
Of grace and conning / my pen to lead
So that in nothing I excede
Following mine auctour / truly to endyght
To thy laud and praise in doing this deed.
And of thy blyssed mod / lord most of might
O maris stella / o sterre most bright
Shynynge in the fyrmament or sky
The which do guide ye maryners by night
And where thy help / should perysshe and deye
As thou in heaven / syttest right hye
Pray for those / unto thy blyssed son
That this to read will them apply
For their reward / may have salvation
Upon the pain / of eternal dampnacyon
To learn and know / ye commandments ten
We all be bound / without excusacyon
And in especyall / we christian men
The day shall come / we know not when
That unto account / called we shall be
For fere and dread / tremble shall we then
And know not for help whyder to fle
Wherefore in this world / blyssed is he
That in heart lives pure and clean
The devil / ye world / our conscience these three
Will cause our sins / to be known and seen
And what soever our life has been
Good of ill / it shall appear
Will we or nyll we / sooner than we wene
Before god / his saints / and his mother dear
Wherefore whiles we ben living here
Having time / oportunyte / and space
Serve we god / with heart entere
Making petycyon unto his grace
In humble wise / that in that place
Where he is we may ever dwell
Having the fruycyon of his blyssed face
And to be delivered from the pains of hell
These doctors dyuyne / done preche and tell
That ydlenes is a right peryllous vice
By the which our forne faders fell
Example we have of Salamon the wise
That when he was besyed / about the deuyse.
Of gods temple / and good operacyon
And in other virtues him did excercyse
He was never overcome by temptacyon
But as soon as he had delectacyon
In ydlenes / slouthe / and woman's company.
Of will dysposed / by delyberacyon
Renouncinge his faith / commyted ydolatry
Dauyd also lived in aduoutry
With Vryes wife / and caused to be slain
And ydlenes the rote / and cause of all their folly /
This story the bible reherceth plain
Right many in no^bre has be known and seyen
That ydlenes has brought unto perdycyon
By law and Justice / demed unto pain
For their demerytes / and transgressyon
And to avoid / the peryllous infeccyon
Of ydlenes slouthe / and other occasyo^s of sin
Has bo^ded me / under correccyon
Out of frensshe / this matter to begin
Entendynge thereby / no silver for to win
Ne yet none other temporal gain
But welthe of souls / escapynge the engyn
Of the devil of hell / his snares / and his chain
Who ever is besy / glad / and feign
Souls to dystroye / whom god has elect
Who give us grace / heaven to attain
Of my hole mind / this is theffecte
Explicit.
Tabula.
Here follows the table of this book.
MAn reasonable call the aid of god and of the vyrgyn Mary for to enlumyne
thin ente^dement to know thy self. That is to know what thou art / what
sins reygne in the / and how thou have dysobeyed unto god in brekynge his
commandments. Saint Bernarde says that thou shall be better and more to
allow if thou know thy self than if thou knew the course of the sterres / the
foundementes of ye earth the strengthes of herbs / the complexyons of men and
that thou had knowledge of the things celestyalles and infernalles. Vnde
bernardus. Studo cognoscere teipsum qr multo melior et laudabilior eris si
teiprem cognoscas / quam si teiplum negleto cognosceris cursus syderum /
fundamenta terraru^ / vires herbarum / complexiones hominum / et haberos
noticiam celestum et infernorum. Many persons there ben throughout ye world
the which will not believe of simple word that they the which transgress the
commandments of god gone unto dampnacion and pardycyon. And they the which
will not believe it / study they and seek they by this table their sins as
they ben declared in this book / and they shall find by the holy scripture
witness of certain by auctorytees yt they lose paradyse and desce^de in to
hell in the which they shall be eternally without ever to have aid ne
socoures in any manner. And for to find lightly the matters whereof this book
speaks him behooves to look what nombre and lettre is marketh and gooth and in
the nombre in the heyght of ye margen / and in those nombres and lettres shall
be found that yt a man demau^deth.

A notable.

FOr to know / read / or write ye allegacyons of auctorytees of this book a
man should know that ouerall where he fyndeth math. that is mathei / and where
he fyndeth mar. yt is marci / and luc that is luce / and ioh. that is iohannis
/ also he shall find ad rom^. that is roma in epistola ad romanos. Et.i. ad
cori^. yt is in prima epla ad cori^theos / et primo ad thy. yt is in prima epla
ad thymotheum / et ad gal. yt is ad gallathas / et ephe. is ad epheseos / et
phyl. is ad philipe^ses / et thessal. is ad thessalonice^ses / et col. is ad
collocenses / et hebre. is hebreos. Also he shall find gen^. yt is genesis /
etexo. is exodi / et leui. is leuitici. et nu. is numeri. et deuteronomy. is deutonomi
/ and.i. vl. ii. re. is primi libri regu^l secundi libri regu^. ps. vel psalm.
that psalteru vel plalmi. et eccle. yt is ecclesiastes. et eccli. that is
ecclesiastici. et sapi^e. is sapientie. et prouer. is prouerbiorum. et ysa. is
Ysaie. et the. is iheremye. et ezchi. is ezechielis. and dan^. is danielis. etc.

Here follows the table of the examplary of this book.

MAn reasonable know thou yt god has given unto the ten commandments / the
which you sholdest put in thy heart and keep them and accomplisshe upon pain
of dampnacyon eternal. If thou have broken any of them / take heed of the
examples semblables unto yt by this table for to se how it shall happen the if
you put not in the correccyon and amendment. And for to fy^de those examples it
behooves to seche through the book on hye in the margen the nombre of the leaves
that it marketh gooth on / and after the nombres of the matters with the a / b /
c / and in that nombre and lettre ye shall fy^de every example. First the
examples of obedyence shall be written Secondy those of inobedyence. After to
here the word of god. Morouer ye examples of every commandment in partyculer
shall come afterward. etc.

The perambule and dyuysyon of this book.
Here begins the perambule and dyuysion of this present book called the
flower of the commandments of god.


GOd the fader / the sone / and the holy ghost ye which is one seul god in
trynyte whom it will like to give unto us, his love / his grace and his mercy.
And ye it would please hy^ to enlumyne the hertes and the thoughts of sinners
the which wyllen repent them / correct / and amend. And who so shall study
this book (ye which is named the flower of the commandments of god) / for
that it has been gadered among the books as the fair vyolettes ben gadered
among the rude and vile herbs through out ye feldes: in likewise as a man may
se by auctorytees and holy scryptures alleged and assembled for to know that /
that god wylleth and commands to the end for to go in to life eternal. And
in likewise as the honey flies gadren the swetenes of the little flowers for to
make ye wax or honey / or in likewise as men gadren the cream and the swetenes
of the milk for to have the fat and butter for to nourysshe ye body. Even so
has been gadered the flowers and swetnesses of the holy scryptures for to
nourysshe spyrytually the souls with virtues and goods spyrytualles in
accomplysshynge ye will of god for to have salvation / and to escape
dampnacyon. This book treats pryncypally three things. The first declares
that all the ten commandments and all the holy scryptures tenden and hangen
to love god and his neighbor / and how god defends in these two things
here all sin / and all evil words / thoughts / and operacyons / and he
commands al virtues and goods espyritualles. The second thing whereof this
book treats is of the.x. commandments / the which ben declared one after
another by chapitres as they ben here before in the table. The third declares
some things moeuynge for to keep the commandments of god / and many things
noysauntes unto them the which breketh them. Moreover the condycyons of the
pilgrim of paradyse / and of the reward eternal of them the which well or
ill have accomplysshed these commandments. Creatures reasonable study ye
this book / for it is much profitable unto all people as well clerks as
seculyers / and plant ye and rote the commandments in your hertes as if
they were written in a book and god shall give unto you paradyse the which is a
place replenysshed with Joys more sweet than any milk or honey Legitur in
libri moysi. Audi israel precepta domini et eain cord quasi in libro scribe /
et dabo tibi terram effluentem lac et mel. etc.

B. Here follows the first chapter the which treats in general that it is
commanded to love god with all his heart / and his neighbor as himself. i. c.
IF thou wylt do thy salvation benygnely thou shall obey unto god and unto his
commandments / as here after thou shall here. God gives unto the two
commandments so generalles that they comprehend under them all that / yt
thou sholdest do and fle for thy salvation. In likewise as sayen ye holy
scryptures in many places. Vn^ Mathei.xxii. Marci.xii. Luce.x. Et
deuteronomii.vi. Diliges dominum deum tuu^ ex toto cord tuo / et ex tota anima
tua / et ex tota me^te tua / and ex tota virtute tua / and hoc estmaximum
primum mandatum. Secundu^ autem simile est huic. Diliges proximum tuum sicut
teipsum. In hus duobus mandatis vniuersa lex pendet et prophet. That is to
say. It is commanded the that thou love thy lord god with all thy heart /
with all thy soul / with all thy thought / and with al thy strength / that is to
understand more than all things / and above al things This here is the
gretest commandment and the first. For it is of the dyleccyon unto god the
which comprehends the three first commandments: and the three virtues
theologalles / the which ben faith / hope / and charity The second
commandment is semblable unto that / for is dylection the which gives them
charge that thou love thy neighbor as thy self. This dyleccyon comprehends
under it the seven last commandments / all ye works of mercy / and the
four virtues cardynalles the which ben Prudence / attempraunce / Justice /
and force. In these two commau^dements before said to love god and his
neighbor all the law hangs and ye prophets. For to understand right
shortly all the faith / all the.x. commandments of god / and all the
scryptures of ye ancient testament and of the new / and all that / that the
prophets and saints of paradyse has spoken unto us and written for the health
of our souls / it is a thing certain that all tends and hangs in ye end
and co^clusyon for to love god and his neighbor as it is said. Saint Poule
says ad romanos.xiii. Dilectio proximi malum non operatur / plenitudo legis
est dilectio. The dylecco^n of thy neighbor does none ill / the fulfyllynge
of the law is dyleccyon. And therefore retain well in thy mind these two
commandments and them accomplysshe from point to point / in operacyon / in
word / and in thought / and thou shalt do none ill / but thou shall
accomplysshe all goodness / and thou shall be saved.

C. The second chapter assygneth.v. reasons wherefore a man should love god with
all his heart above all things.
IT is written in the.xiiii. chapter of the gospelles of saint John yt our
savior and redemptour Ihesus said unto his dysciples Qui habz mandata mea and
seruat ea^le est qui diligit me. That is to say after the exposytoure. He the
which has my commandments in the ere to here them and in the heart for to
think them / and in the mouth for to teache them / and in the mind and
volunte to keep them and to accomplysshe in operacion / he it is which loves
me. Many (...) should moeue us to love god with all our hertes and obey unto his
commandments more sooner tha^ to all things. D. First it is good reason to
love him with all our heart for the goodness infynyte the which is in him and
the which of him proceeds / the which is so great that it is innombrable.
That is say that he has so many that a man can find the end. Also it is
good reason to love him / for he has loved us more than all ye creatures that
he has made and create in this world / the which he has all create for to
serve us. When god made and create the heaven and the earth / the son and the
moon / the sterres / the fyrmament: the elements / and all the beestes each
of them in his kind / and all the birds every of the^ in his gree / he them
made for his honor and for to serve us and to govern / and without them wene
may live. Albeit of all the creatures that he has create in this world hene
has made none unto his semblau^ce and unto his image to be in his company
eternally but man and woman and the aungelles. And for as much as he has
loved us more than all the operacyons that he has create and for the goodness
infynytethe which is in hy^ as it is said it is good reason that we love him
above all things with all our thought Example. We read that the son of a
rich man loved in his youth the vanytees of the world. He loved first a
dog much curyously the which deyed. Secondly he loved right much an hawk
that he bare upon his fyst / and she deyed. Thyrdly he loved a little horse ye
which lept and turned honestly the which also deyed / and he was much wroth
and showed it to his mother saying. Alas my dog / my hawk / and my horse that I
did love so much ben deed / whom may I more love that I ne shall lose that
love / and his mother said unto him. Mine own dear child love god and thou ne
shall lose that love go in to the church and put the in orayson and pray god
that he give unto the his love and his grace. He was obedyent / and as he
perseuered in orayson he herd preche the gospel. Mathei.xix. Qui relinquit
domum vel fratres vel sorores aut patre^ aut matrem aut vxorem aut filios aut
agros propter nomen meum centuplum accipiet et vitam eternam possidebit. He
that leueth all his parents and friends and all his possessions for the love
of god / he shall have an hundred double of retrybucyon and shall possede the
life eternal. Than ye sone came unto his mother and said that he would leave her
and go in to relygion for to love god parfytely / for the said gospel that he
had herd preche / and his modersayd unto him. It is that thing that I
desired / for this world ne is but vanyte and full of decepcyon / love god
therefore parfytely. Than the child was relygyous and parfyte in holy life. E.
Secondly we shall love god with all our heart and thought more than all the
world / and above ye gold and the silver and all the goods the which ben in
the world. That is to say to love more sooner to lose the gods temporalles of
this world than to break one of the commandments of god / and the reason is
right euydent / for a man should love hy^ more that gives than the thing
given. God the which is full of bounte infynyte us has given generally and
partyculerly and unto every of us the goods of grace / of nature / and of
fortune that we have / and all the goods proceeds of him / and estudy well the
scryptures in the chapytres the which folowen and thou shall find that it is
so. Vnde legitur Mathei.xxv. Dominus vocauit seruos suos et tradidit illis bona
sua: et vni dedit quinque talenta: alii autem duo: alii vere vnum vnicuique
secundum propriam virtutem That is to say yt the lord calls his servants
and gives unto them his goods / and gives five talentes unto one / unto an
other twain / unto an other one / unto every of them after his virtue. By the
lord is understand god that gives unto his servants / that is that he
gives unto every of us his goods unto the one more than unto an other after
his will and after the faculte of every of them. Et legitur ad Ephesi. iiii.
Vnicuique nostrum data est gratia secundum mensuram donationis xprei. Grace is
given unto every of us after the measure of the gift of Ihesu christ. Et legitur
ad roma.xii. Habentes donationes secundum gratiam que data est vobis
differentes sieve propheticam secundum rationem fidei sieve ministerium i^
ministrando. Et legitur.i. ad Corin. xii. Vuicuique autem datur manifestatio
spiritus ad vtilitatem / alii datur sermo sapientie / alii sermo scie^tie /
alii fides alii gratia sanitatum / alii operatio virtutum, etc. Manyfestacyon
of spyryte is given unto every man unto his vtylyte / the word of wisdom is
given unto one / and unto another the word of conning / unto another faith /
unto another grace of health / and unto another operacyon of virtue. Et David
in psalm. Cantabo domino qui bona tribuit michi. I shall sing unto the lord
the which gives me of his goods. Et Job. i. ca. Si bona suscipimus de manu
domini / maia autem quare no^ suscipiamus. If we have received the goods of
the hand of god wherefore may we not in likewise take ye euylles. And sith that
it appears that god has given us all the goods that we have. It is good
reason yt we love him more than these goods and above them. That is to say to
those more sooner to lose all the goods of the world than to break one of ye
commandments o^ god and to lose his love. For it is written John.xiiii. Si
quis diligit me sermonem meum seruabit. Siquitur. Qui non dilig^ me sermones
meos non seruat. That is to say. Who so loves me keeps my word and he that
loves me not keeps not my words. Verba gratia. If thou were in turkey and
that men set before the an. C. busshels of gold on the one side / and the
ydolles on the other and yt the king of turkey said unto the. I shall give unto
the all this gold and retain the to be the first of my palace and do
sacryfyce unto ye ydolles / thou sholdest love god above the gold and honor
of ye world. For it is written.i. corin. vi. Neque fornicarii neque ydollis
serue^tes regnu^ m^um possidebu^t. Also who should lay an. C crowns in thy
hand for to make a false oath in Judgment or to work one day of a feast
commanded / or for to sle a man unjustly / thou sholdest love god and thy
neighbor better than the gold and the silver / and rather wyn^e nothing than
to break his commandment. It written Job. xv. Manete in dilectione mea si
precepta measeruaueritis manebitis in dilectione mea. Dwell ye in my dyleccyon
/ if ye have kept my commandments ye shall dwell in my deleccyon. Also if
thou know well yt mean to stele the treasoure of thy neighbor or to have
his heritage iniustly / it is defended / take it not upon pain of dampnacyon
and to lose paradyse. Vnde.i. corint. vi. Neque fures neque auari regnu^ dei
possidebunt. Also who so should put five hundred crowns in the hand of a
woman for to have her company she should refuse them upon pain of dampnaco^n
and to lose paradyse. For to make short tale better it is to obey god and to
lose all the goods of ye world than to da^pne his soul. For if any love the
goods more than god: and to leave to obey unto god for to have the goods he
by^deth himself unto dampnacyon. Example of a rich man the which loved to
much the world and brye fly he fell in to hell and all his goods. It is
written in the life of saint Ambrose yt as he yode on a time unto Rome he came
to lodge in the town of tuscie wherein was a rich man: and when he saw so
much of goods and of servants he axed the said man of his estate. The man
answered I am happy and glorious in all manners. I habounde in rychesses. I have
great company of servants / all yt ever I desired is well comen to me / ne
there came never unto me aduersyte. When saint Ambrose herd these words he
was much abashed and said unto those that were of his company. Arise and fle
we for god is not in this place / haste you children and make none abiding
lest the vengeance comprehend us / and that they ne wrappe us in their sins
/ and when they were a little thens ye earth opened suddenly and swalowed the
said rich man and all his goods and those things which unto hy^ apperteyned
sanke into hell in such manner that there ne abode no thing apparaunt. Another
example how the cursed rich man the which was clothed with purple and lived
delycatyuely is buried in hell. Quere.lxxxiiii. A. Another example of a man the
which gave himself unto the devil to the end that he should enryche him / and
the devil gave to him treasours and baptized him in the name of all the
deuilles.lx. Another example of a rich usurer the which loved his gods more
than god of whom he demanded aid at his death.lxxxvi. f. Another example of
an usurer the which loved to much his goods commanded his soul unto the
devil at his death / after yt he might no more possede them.lxxxvi. g. F.
Thyrdly we should love god with all our heart more than our faders and moders and
above all our children / cosyns / parents and friends / and the reason is
good. For god is our pry^cipal fader celestyall the which has made us and
create unto his image and unto his symylytude. In like wise as it is written
Genesis nono. Ad ymaginem quippe dei factus est homo. And of as much as ye
soul that he has create is more dygne than the body / of as much more we
should love god and obey unto his commandment more sooner than unto our fader
carnal. Saint barnarde says. Ecce domine quia me fecisti debeo me amori tuo
totum. Thou lord by cause thou have made me and create I ought to give all in
thy love. And it is written eccle. xxxvii. de David. De om^i cord suo laudauit
deum et dilexit dominum qui fecit illum. David praised god withal his heart
and loved his lord the which has created him. We require god every day our
fader in saying ye pater noster. Pater noster qui es i^ celis. Of good right
we call him our fader in as much as he has us made and created / and for as
much as he nouryssheth us with his goods that he makes to grow. For he is a
good fader ye nouryssheth / and in as much as we hope to possede his heritage
that is paradyse as his propre children. For these things here and many other
we should love god above our pare^tes. We should love our faders carnalles
naturally and by the commandment of god / but we should love god above them.

love him better than our self as it is said. Example in the appostles the
which has loved god more than their own bodies / for some has endured for
to be flayne / as saint Barthylmewe / some other to be heeded as saint Poule /
the other crucified as saint Peter / and saint Andrewe. And for all the pains
that the tyrauntes might do unto them theyne left the love and ye
commandment of god. Vnde ad to.viii. Quis separabit nos a charitate christi
tribulatio / an angustia / an persecutio / an fames / an nuditas / an periculum
/ an gladius Saint Poule says what is it that may separe us from the love and
charity of god. Shall it be trybulacyon / anguysshe / persecucyon / or honger.
etc. I am certain that death / ne life / ne deuylles / ne sygnouryes ne may
depart us from the love of god. And it is written.i. ad cori^t. xvi. how saint
Poule says. Who so loves not Ihesu christ be he cursed. Si quis non amat
cristu^ anathema sit. Also he says in an other epistle that god has
prepayred unto the^ great reward the which loves him. Vnde.ii. ad corin. ii.
cap. Quod oculus non vidit nec aures audiuit nec i^ cor hominis asce^dit que
preparauit deus dilige^tibus se. This auctoryte is declared toward the end of
this treatise.xlvii. a. Example we read that the heart of a vyrgyn was cut in
her body for the great love that she had unto god. Quere in the examplary at
the nombre.lxxv. e. Another example that Susanne loved better to be slain and
dyffamed than to break the commandment of god when the two harlottes did say
unto her Of two things choice which thou wylt either that thou consent that
we have thy company at our pleasure / or that we make the to be stoned and put
to death. Quere.lxxxxvi. c. Another example written in ye life of faders of a
good young man ye which was bound all naked in a fair bed and there was
put unto him a fair woman impudyke all naked for to make him to do sin with
her / but for to resyste unto the sin and to keep the love of god and to obey
unto his commandment he bote and ete his own tongue and spette ye blood in
the vysage of the said harlot the which fled of horror. Example that mary
magdaleyne loved much god / wherefore god pardoned her all her sins. Vnde
Luce.vii. Remittuntur ei peccata multa quoniam diliexit multum. Another example
of a duchess the which loved over much her body and lived voluptuously and
she did stynke. The dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye that a certain duke
had a wife the which lived so tenderly and so dylycatyuely that she dysdeyned
to be bayned in comune waters of ryuers and fountaynes / but her servants
gadered the dew of the sky and prepayred unto to her a bayne. Her meets and
drynkes were so delycyously dressed and made that marvel it was. Her bed
also smelled odoryferously and sweet / and as she lived so / by ye Judgment of
god she was stryken with so great stynche in her living days that none ne
might abide the foul air of her Al her gentylmen and servants left her
except one chamberere or maiden only / that served her the which ne might
pass by her without having the air of some spyces well smelling / and also
as in reny^ge admynystred unto her / and in such stynke she deyed. H. Fyfthly
we should love god with all our heart / and put our trust and hope in him more
sooner and above all ye kings / dukes / earls / lords / and other men of the
world / and the reason is euydent / for there ne is in all the world so
great a lord that may defend us at the death from our enmyes and keep us from
dampnacyon and give to us paradyse / there ne is none alonely but god the
which is replenisshed with goodness infynyte. And therefore the psalmyst says.
Bonum est confidere in domino quam co^fidere in homine. Better thing it is to
put confydence in god than too put confydence in man. Iteru^ pres. Bonu^ est
sperare in domino quam sperare in principibus. Better it is to trust in god
tha^ to trust in princes. Example. Saint barbara the which put her love / her
affyau^ce and her esperaunce in god / and not unto the lords temporal she was
comforted at her death of god / and the aungelles baren her soul in to
paradyse / and her fader Dyascorus the which beheeded her was brent with fire
celestyal and ye deuylles bare his soul in to hell / his rychesses ne his
sygnouryes aided him not at need. So it is better to put co^fydence in god than
in princes and men in whom is no health. Vnde David in psalm. Nolite confidere
in principibus nec i^ filiis hominum / in quibus non est salus. And ye prophet
Iheremye says that the man is cursed the which puts his trust in men and
puts his flesh / his arm / and his heart / and departs himself from
god. Vnde Iheremye.xvii. Maledictus est homo qui confidit in homine / and ponit
carnem brachium suum and a domino recedit cor eius. Helyodorus was punysshed of
punycyon dyuyne for that / that he obeyed unto king Scelenius more sooner than
unto god wha^ he yode to take the treasours of ye church of Jerusalem.
Quere.lxxxii. b. Another example how king Ezechyas sent to seek counceyle of
his sekenes unto belzabub and he deyed myscheuously / and his messageres were
brent with fire celestyall. Quere.ix. g. For to know the deference when love
is good or ylle / or when it is mortal sin or venyall thou shalt find it
in the ix. commandment. Quere.xlii. c. Example in Moses ye which loved god
parfytely and obeyed unto his commandments more sooner and above the will of
king Pharaon / and therefore god loved him so much that he spoke unto him face
to face. In likewise as it is written in the three and thyrty chapter of Exodi.

A. How the commandment of god co^prehendeth under it the three first
commandments / and the three virtues theologalles / the which ben faith /
hope / and charity.ii.
IT is written in the.xxiiii. chapter of the gospelles of saint Johan that our
lord said unto his dyscyples. Si diligitis me mandata mea seruate. If ye love
me keep my commandments. If thou love god with all thyn heart above all
things thou shalt believe in him / thou shall worship him and shalt give
him honor. the which is due unto him / not unto ydolles / ne unto things
create / for it is unto the creator unto whom such honor is due. Thus thou
shalt accomplysshe the first commandment of our lord the which is written
Exodi viscesimo. Non assumes nomen dei tui in vanum. More over if thou love thy
lord god above al things thou shalt sanctyfye / honor / and keep the
feestes commanded. And in so doing thou shalt fulfill and totally
accomplysshe the third commandment of god the which is written Exo. xx.
Sabbata sanctifices. And therefore the dyleccyo^ of god comprehends the three
first commandments the which us ordeyneth well toward the blyssed trynyte.
The first us ordeyneth anenst the puissaunce of god the fader the which is of
the mageste incomprehensyble. The second anenst god the sone the which is
veryte and wysdom sovereign. The third anenst god the holy ghost the which is
bounte and love infynyte. If we ben well ordained anenst god the fader / the
sone / and the holy ghost the which is one only god in trynyte we shall love
him above all things / and we shall accomplysshe the three first
commandments the which tends unto his dyleccyon as it is said. Also the
dyleccyon of god comprehends the three dyuyne virtues theologalles the which
ben faith / hope / and charity with their branches and dependau^ces. They ben
said dyuynes for that / that they do ordeyne dyuynely the heart of man anenst
god. Saint Austyn says in eucheridon. Fide / spe / et caritate colitur optime
deus. God is right well honored by faith / hope / and charity. Faith keeps
soueraynly veryte. Hope sovereign hyghnes / and Charity sovereign love. And it
is said charity of chere / unity / and love in god. We se god but by faith /
and by faith we believe in him and love him / and we keep his first
commandment ye which is. Vnu^ credo de. Also we serve god to have the good
to come / and therefore we put our trust in him / and we abstain us to swear by
him vaynly / and so we keep ye second commandment. Ne iures va^a per ipsum.
Also by charity / faith / and hope we love / serve / and honor god / and we
keep ye third commandment. Sabbata sanctifices. Also we love god for three
things. The first is for the great and infynyte goodness the which we have
herd say the which is in him and proceeds of him / and thereto we put faith.
The second is for the great good that we hope to have of him after our death.
The third is for the great goodness that he has done to us in our creacyon and
redempcyon / and that he does cotydyally to us of goods that he makes to
increase / and therefore we put our charity within him. By these three things we
have faith / hope / and charity with god and love him with all heart above all
things. The faith is the foundement of all virtues / for without faith it is
impossyble to please god. Vn^ paulus ad hebreos.xi. Sine fide impossible est
placere deo. B. Also we ne may be saved by good operacions without having
faith Vnde ad galath. ii. No^ iustificatur homo ex operibus legis / nisi per
fidem jesus xprei. Et ad gallat. iii. Iustus ex fide viuit. The Just man lives
by faith. Also for to believe in god after the faith and by baptym man is
saved / and by defaute of faith and baptym man is dampened. Vn^ Marci. xvi. Qui
crediderit et baptizatus fuerit saluus erit / qui vero non crediderit
condempnabitur. How men ought to believe in god and in the artycles of the
faith it is written after in the first commandment / of faith comes
obedyence / good desire / and innocence / relygyon / mundycyte / confyaunce /
and chastyte.C. Also ye sinners ne may be saved without having esperaunce or
hope that god unto them pardons their sins after the article of the faith
ye which is. Remissionem peccatorum / and therefore they should put their hope
in god. Cain and Judas ben dampened by defaute of hope. Also we should hope yt
god shall deliver us from our enmyes vysybles and inuysybles in likewise he did
our forne faders. Vn^ pres In te sperauerunt patres nostri sperauerunt et
liberasti eos. Iteru^pres. Quoniam in me sperant liberabo eum: protegam eu^
quoniam cognouit nomen meum. He has trusted in me I shall deliver him / for he
has known my name. Example when Job was tourmented he said that if god would
sle him yet would he put his trust in him. Vnde Job.xiii. Example that Dauyd
had good hope when in the name of god he slew ye proud puyssaunt man
phylystyen. Quere.lxxviii. Also we should have hope that god shall give unto us
beatytude and life eternal. Vnde pres. Beat omnes qui sperant in te domine.
Esperaunce is a fair virtue of the Which comes pacyence / moderaunce /
contrycyon / co^fessyon / joy espyrytuall / and contemplacyon. D. Also without
having charity we ne may be saved / in likewise as saint poule says.i. ad
Corinthios.xiii. Sili^guis hominum loquar and angelorum: caritatem autem non
habuero factus sum sicut es sona^s aut cimbalum timiens. This matter of charity
is written here after.iiii. ca. Of charity proceeds love / pity / grace / peace
benygnyte / and debonayrte. Example of charity. Quere.lxxv. A.

E. Here follows the commandment to love thy neighbor.ii.
IT is written in ye gospel of saint Johan that our lord said unto his
dyscyples. I give unto you a commandment of new / that is that ye love other
in likewise as I have loved you / all men shall know in that thing that ye be
my dyscyples / if ye have dyleccyon togyders. Vnde John.xiii. Mandatum nouum do
vobis vt diligatis inuicem sicut dilexi vos / i^ hoc cognoscent omnes quia
discipuli mei estis si dilectionem habueritis ad inuicem. Also the gospel says
that to love his neighbor as himself is more greter things than sacryfyces.
Vnde Marci.xii. Diligere proximum tanquam seipsum maius est omnibus
olocaustimatibus et seruictis. For to have paradyse and to escape the pains of
hell it is requysyte that thou obey unto god / ye which commands ye thou
love thy neighbor. When a king temporal makes to proclaim any thing within
his realm his subgectes thereto obeys of dread to have damage. And god the
which is king of kings made to preche throughout al ye world that we should
love each other upon pain of dampnacyon and to lose paradyse. It is written
Iohannis.xv. Hec man do vobis vt diligatis inuicem. Et legitur Mathei.xix. Si
vis ad vitam ingredi serua mandata. If thou wylt enter in to the life eternal
keep the commandments If thou dread the furour of a king temporal ye
which is transytory / by a more greater reason thou ought to dread ye
furour of god ye which may send the in to damnacyon eternal. F. Many things
ought to moeue us to love our neighbor. The first the which is most
pryncypal and fynall is for to obey unto god / the which commands it us.
When a good fader gooth out of the town he commands unto his children and
unto his servants yt they love each other. In likewise did our lord Ihesus
before yt he was crucyfyed / and when he shall come to the Judgment the matter
shall be dyscuted of those the which have done ill unto their neighbors / and
shall be sent in to the fire of hell if they be found i^penytents. Vnd
Athanasius. Q^^mala egeru^t ibunt in igne^ eternum. The second thing yt should
move us to love our neighbor is the fraternity natural tha^ ought to be
between us in as much as we ben descended of one fader and or one mother / that
is of Adam and Eve and that naturally the generacyon proceeds the one of ye
other / so nature moeueth us to love each other. The third thing is the
fraternity espyrytuall the which is between us in as much as we ben broders
and systers crystyens baptized of one baptym in one god only. The.iiii. is in
as much as we ben se^blables the one unto the other / made and create unto the
image of god. Vnde. genesis.ix. Ad ymaginem quippe dei factus est homo. Also
the dombe beestes loves their semblables. Vnde eccl. asti.xiii. Omne animal
diligit simile sibi. Also ye birds of one self semblaunce slyeth / eteth /
and keeps company togyders / as pygeo^s / sparowes cranes. etc. Vide
eccle.xxvii. Volitalia ad sibi similia conueniunt. Sith that these bestes
irreasonables loves each other by mote strong reason we should love each other
the which ben reasonables. Three things pleased unto the sage Solomon ye
which ben approved before god and man / that is concordau^ce between bredren
and friends / love between neighbors / and comentement in mar^age / that is to
understand the man and the woman. Vnde eccle. xxv. In tribus beneplacitum est
spiritui meoque sunt probata coram deo et hominibus concordia fratrum / amor
proximorum / viret mulier sibi consentientes. The.v. thing ye which should
moeue us for to love our neighbor is that we entende to go together in to
paradyse / and thither to come there to enjoy us. Vnde scriptura. Proximum
diligimus vt cum ipso curramus et cu^ipreo ad gloriam perueniamus. Et ambrosius
dicit. Sicut sine via nullus peruerut quo tendit ita sine caritate que dicitur
via non possimus recte ire. In likewise without love and charity we ne may goo
right in to paradyse. Also the aungelles loves us and keeps for to obey unto
the commandments of god / and to the end that we may come in to paradyse with
them / and that we may enjoy us togyders. And therefore we should love each
other and that love should not be in syn^e in likewise as it is written.i. ad
corin.xiii. Dilectio proximi malum no^ operatur. The dyleccion of thy neighbor
ne does none harm.

G. To love his neighbor as himself comprehends the seven works of mercy /
the.vii. last commandments / and the.iiii. virtues cardynals.ii.
IT is written in the.xxii. chapter of the gospel of saint Mathewe and in
the.xiii chapter of ye epystles of saint Poule unto the Romans. Diliges
proximum tuum sicut teipsum. H. Thou shall love thy neighbor as thy self. To
love his neighbor as himself is understand and expounded in two manners. The
first is. All the good that thou would ye men should do to the as well unto
the body as unto ye soul if thou had necestyte) thou should do it to thy
neighbor if he had necessyte Vnde Mathei.vi. Omnia quecu^que vultis vt faciant
vobis homines and vos facite illis hec est enim lex et prophet. That is to
understand. If yt thou had honger and thyrste thou would well that men
should give unto the to drink and meet to ete. Or if thou were seek or sore
thou would well be vysyted. And if thou had not herborowe nor lodging as
the poor pilgrims thou would well that men should harborowe and lodge the.
Or if ye thou were a prisoner thou would be redeemed. And if thou were naked
thou would be clothed. Or also if you were deed you would be buried. Do in
likewise to thy neybour if he have necessyte as you would he did unto them
accomplysshynge the works of mercy the which ben corporelles / and well shall
come unto the. Example of a man the which was drouned in the accomplysshynge
the works of mercy and his soul went unto heaven before that his body was
cold.lv. B. Another example how freres gave a cluster of grapes and sent it
unto ye most of debilyte and weykenes.lxxv. A. Other example that a man should
do of good whiles that he lives without abiding unto his heriteres.lxxii. c.
d. e. f. Also if thou had necessyte of counceyle espyrytually or of
conforte / or to be chastysed and taught / or that men should pardon the thy
defautes / or that men pray for the or supporte the in thy perfeccyons. In the
things before said thou would have aid and socoures in thy necessyte. Do
thou in likewise to thy neighbor in his necessyte and thou shalt love him as
thy self / and thou shalt accomplysshe the works of mercy as he did ye
which drew again his brother the which fell into fornycacion. quere.lxxv. f.
Also you shall acco^plysshe the fourth commandment the which is written. exodi
xx. Honora patrem tuum and matrem tua^. I. The second exposycyon to love thy
neighbor as thy self is such. All the ill that thou would that men ne
should do unto the (as well unto body as unto soul) thou ne sholdest do it
unto thy neighbor Vnde thobie.iiii. Quod alio tibi odis fieri vide ne tu
aliquando alteri facias. Et Y so do. dicit. Quod non vis pati non facias quod
no^ vis tibi fieri alteri nunquam inferas. That is to understand. Thou would
not that men bette the: or slew the / ne do thou it to thy neighbor / and
thou shall accomplysshe the.v. commandment of god / ye which is written
Deutero. v. Nonoccides. Example that haynours that is hateful men slew a man
within the church were diuynely punysshed.lxxix. b. Another example of a man
the which bette his wife and she myscouraged herself and did much evil.lx.
I. Also thou would not yt men should stele thy goods / or rauysshe or take
it away by pyllage or otherwise. If you love thy neighbor ne take thou not his
goods iniustly / and thou shall accomplysshe the.vi. commandment the which
is written Exodi. xx. Non furtum facies. Also thou ne would that men should
commit lechery in thy wife / or with thy daughter If thou love thy neighbor as
thy self ne commyt thou it in his wife / and you shall accomplysshed the.vii.
commandment / ye which is written Exodi. xx. Non mechaberis. Also thou
would not that men should make the to lose thy goods or herytages / or thy
good reno^mee for false wytnes and report / ne do thou it to thy neighbor and
thou shall accomplysshe the.viii. commandment the which is written Deutero.
v. Non loquaris co^tra proximum tuum falsum testimoniu^. Example how three
persons the which forsware them for to impose a false crime unto a patryarche
were punysshed.lxxxxvi. A. Also thou would not that men should think ill
upon yt for to have thy goods iniustly / or for to deceive thy wife / ne do
thou it unto thy neighbor and love him as thy self / and thou shall
accomplysshe the two last commandments. Vnde deutero. v. Non concupisces
vxorem proximi tui. etc. Also if thou love thy neighbor thou ne shalt do him
none ill. Quia dilectio proximi malu^ non operatur. Vt dicitur ad romanos.xiii.
Two things ben requysyte for to keep the dylection of thy neighbor as says
Ysodore in his book of dyfference. Scz vt beneficii impensione foueatur et
nulla malicia ledetur. That is to say that a man do good unto his neighbor if
he have necessyte / and also that he hurt him not by any malice Do the things
beforesayd and thou shall accomplysshe the.vii. last commandments of god /
and the works of mercy ye which thou shalt find after in the nombre.xxiiii.
a. b. c.

K. Also for to love thy neighbor as thy self it behooves that thou have
prudence / attempraunce / justice / and force / they ben four virtues the
which ben said cardynalles for that / that they teache the man to govern him
in him self / and after his neighbor as ye pope governs holy church by the
counceyle of his cardynalles / and a man ne may love his neighbor without
these four virtues. For prudence keeps a man that he be not deceived of his
enemies by none engyn / and him counceyleth and ordeyneth that all that / that
he does and says be in the right line of reason after the ordenaunce of god
ye which all sees / iugeth / and knows. Also prudence counceyleth to weep
the sins committed and past / and that a man despise the prosperytees worldly
the which ben transytoryous / and that a man should coueyte to have the Joys
eternalles. Also prudence makes to ordeyne the things presents for to live
after god / and makes to provide for the things to come / and also to record
of the things past. Understand ye word of a wise poet the which says.
Prospice ve^tura / sic est prudens tua cura Cu^ quid vis agere / debes primo
bn^ videre An tibi conueniat / liceat simul vtile fiat. Om^a prude^ter / fac
finem cerne freque^ter Primo metire / que finis possit ante venire A prudent
man ought to be wyle or ware to look about on all parts that he ne be deceived
of his adversaries the which ben over all the world. Quia totus mundus in
maligno possitus est. It behooves to look about that a man be not deceived by
amyte carnal and socyall. Quia iam pater patrem iam filius fellit matrem: iam
socius socium: iam amicus decipit amicu^. Saint poule says take heed how ye
walk wisely. That is how ye live not as dombe fowls but as sages and redeem
ye time lost vnprouffytably spent and wasted for the days ben ylle / and
therefore be ye not imprudente but take ye head what is ye will of god. Vnde
Paulus ad Ephe. v. Videte quomodo caute ambuletis non quasi insipientes sed vt
sapientes redime^tis tempus quoniam dies mali sunt prorterea nolite fieri
imprudentes sed intellgentes que sit volu^tas dei. Attempraunce keeps a man
that he ne be corrupt by any cursed love / or for fere / or Joy / or swetnes.
For the man attemprate takes moderacyon to love that / that he ought to love /
how he should love / and as much as he ought to love. After he dredeth yt that
he should dread / how he should dread / and as much as he ought to dread.
Moreover he takes no Joy ne delight but in ye thing that he ought to have /
as he should have / and as much as he ought to have it. And also he ne takes
dolor but yt / that he ought to take / as he ought to take / and as much as
he ought to take. The man atte^prate ne coueyteth ne yet will do thing whereof
he may repent him in any manner ne passes the law without measure / and also
he puts himself under the yoke of reason and doubts all the coueytyses of
the world the which ben divided in.iii. things the which are / the
couetyses of ye desires of the body / the couetyse of auaryce / and of the
sin of pride. In these.iii. things there behooves to put attempraunce that a
man be not deceived. Of the which speaks saint John in the second chapter
of his first canonyque and says. Omne quod est in mundo aut est
concupiscentia oculoru^ aut superbia vite. Force makes the heart of the man to
be lift up on hye above the perils of the world and expels debylyte of
courage and makes him strong to resyste again the temptacyons and
aduersytees of the world / of ye body / and of the deuylles. Vnde Augusti.
Quod fortitudo est amor facile tollerans propter quod id amatur. Also the
virtue of force makes to dysprayse the felycitees and prosperytees wordely /
and not to dread any aduersytees. Facit prospera mundi despicere et nulla eius
aduersa formidare. Justice puts the man in order and right estate toward
his neighbor / for it yeldeth unto every man that ye which is his. after the
right line of reason. It wylleth prouffyte unto all and noyeth unto no man.
Justice is said of Just. Iusticia dicitur a iusto. For the Just man ne will do
but reason. Every virtue the which is well done in operaco^n is said Justice.
Also all right and reason is said justice / but all justice is not right. For
the cursed officers peruerteth justice / sometime by gifts / sometime by dread
of lords or by evil people / or by love or by hate. Prudence gives cou^ceyle
unto Justice for it aydeth it / and attemprau^ce amodereth it. Saint Austin
says that virtue is an equalyte of life soundinge unto reason. Virtus est
quedam equalitas vite vndique consonans rationi. Et ioha^nes crisostomus dicit
quod virtus animiest recte de deo sentire and recte inter homines agere. Et
hieromimus dicit. quod sola apud deumli bertas est non seruire peccatis et
summa a pud deum nobilitas est clarere virtutibus. For to love god and his
neighbor and for to live holyly in likewise as men should it behooves to take
the manners and condycions of men parfaytes the which here follows.
