A. It is commanded that we love each other in likewise as god has loved us
iii.

IT is written in the.v. chapitre of the gospelles of saint Johan yt god said to
his dyscyples. Hoc est preceptum meum vt diligatis inuicem licut dilexi vos.
That is to say. My commandment is that ye love each other in likewise as I
have loved you For to con expound this dyleccyon a man ought to know that god
has loved us in many manners / whereof we shall tell five. B. First god has
loved us ryghtfully before that we loved him / and not for his prouffyte ne for
to have our goods / but of his benygnyte for to socoure us and to save us. In
likewise should we love our neighbors before that they do us good / and not
for to have their goods / but for to socoure them in following god. Vnde.i.
Iohannis.iiii. In hoc apparuit caritas dei no^ quasi nos dilexerimus eu^ sed
quoniam ipse prior disexi nos / et misit filium suum propiciatorem pro peccatis
nostris.

C. Secondly god has loved us dyscretely. For he has loved the persons and
ye salvation of souls and has hated and persecuted the sins / and repreued
those the which did commytte them. In likewise should we do. For if our
neighbor be entached or spotted with any vice we should hate his sin and
reprehende him dyscretely. Vnde paulus ad galath. vi. Si preoccupatus fuerit
homo in aliquo delicto vos qui spirituales estis instruite in spu^lenitatis
considerans teipsum ne et tu temteris. Example that soft correccyon
prouffyteth more unto evil persons than sharp Quere in the
examplary.lxxiiii. a. Another example how saint Johan softly drew a thief from
sin. Quere.lxxii. e. Also dyleccyon ought to be without symulacion For who so
loves well chastyseth without fayntyse. Vnde paulus ad to. xii. Dilectione
sine simulatione odientes malum adherentes bono. Thou sholdest love thy
neighbors in god / and after the virtue of equity / and not in ill and sin.
These the which god loves he chastyseth discretely. Vnde apo. iii. Ego quos
amo arguo and castigo dicit dominus. Et pau. ii. ad thymo. iiii. Argue obsecra
increpa omni pacientia et doctrina. A questyon. Who so should demand if the
love of thieves and pyllars (were good) the which loves and susteyneth each
other / or of lechoures the which loves their folysshe lovers as them self.
The answer. Such love is nothy^ge worth / for they love not god / ne their
neighbor / ne their self. They love not god in brekynge his commandments /
ne they love not their neighbor ne themself / for they dampne them self.
Vnde psalmist. Qui diligit iniquitatem odit animam suam. He the which loves
iniquyte hates his soul. Et beatus iacobus dicit. Peccatum cum consummatu^
fuerit generat mortem. Incontynente that sin is consummed and done it
engenders the death. That is to understand that it mortyfyeth spyrytually the
goodness of the soul / by the death of gylte.

D. Thyrdly god us has loved fructuously / not only in voice but of word /
and of operacions. In likewise we should our neighbor in doing the operacyon.
For if a poor man the which has hunger and thyrst all to frosen demand the
alms. It shall not suffyse to say unto him. A poor man thou have hongre and
art frosen god help the. Saint James says in the.ii. chapter of his
epistle that faith without operacyon is deed and nothing worth. And saint
Johan says illud.i. Ioh. iii. Filioli: non diligamus verbo neque lingua sed
opere et veritate. Little children / sons and daughters / love not only by
tongue / and by word / but by operacyon and veryte. The tree the which ne
has but leaves and bears no good fruit is not good but for to brenne. In
likewise the person ye which ne has but words without operacyons is
nothing worth Our savior Ihesus first did and after showed it again by
word. Capit ihesus facere et docere. And in likewise should we do / for it is
written iacobi.i. Estote factores verbi and no^ auditores tm^ fallentes
vosmetipreos. Be ye ye doers of the will of god and not alonely ye herers
deceyuynge your self. The man yt is Iustyfyed by the operacyon of ye faith
and not alonely by faith. Some ben friends of the mouth / some of the table /
some of ye purse / and some of operacyon. The friends of the mouth promises
enough / but they do nothing in operacion. A fructibus coru^ cognoscetis eos.
The friends of the table loves each other whiles yt barell of drink and the
feast lasts / and says well one of the other / but when there is no more
meet nor drink the love defayleth and sayen / it is a myscheuous man yt has
all eten and wasted Vn^. eccle. vi Est amicus socius mense and no^ permanebit
in die necessitatis. He is friend and felawe of the table and he abides not in
the day of need. Et eccle. xxxvii. Est amicus solo noi^e. He is a friend
alonely by name Also the sage speaks of ye said friends. Ecclesi. vi. Est eni^
amicus scdm tempus suu^ and non in die tribulationis / et est amicus qui
conuertit ad inimicitia^ / et est amicus qui odiu^ et rixa^ et co^uitia
denudabit. The friends of the purse ben cosyns as to give or to lend / but
hate and the devil it is to yield again. The friends of operacyon fails not
at need and ben sorry of ye evil of their friend and glad of his welfare. In
need a man shall se what a friend is. Vnd eccle. vi. Amicus si permanserit /
fixus / erit tibi quasi coequalis / et in domesticis tuis fiducialiter aget /
sequitur amicus fidelis fortis protectio / qui autem i^uenit thesauru^ / amico
fideli nulla est comparatio. A faithful friend is a great and a strong
defense / he ye which fyndeth him fyndeth a treasour there is no comparyson
unto a faithful friend. Also the true friend ought to help and remember his
friend at his need as he should do unto himself. Vnde ligitur nono ethicoru^.
Amicus se debet habere ad amicum sicut ad semetipsum. God has us loved of
word and of operacyon togyders. And in likewise should we love our neighbors.

E. Fourthly god has us loved parfytely more than his own body as before it
is said. Quere. G. Also proarfyte men puts their bodies in danger of death
for to save their neighbors / as did a man named Sanctulus. Quere.lxxv. c.
Another example of two men that had so great charity and amyte together that the
one would have deyed for to save the other. Quere lxxv. b.

F. Fyfthly god has loved the salvation of all his enemies the which wronged
him / and bette him without that / that he defended himself nor that he
answered Injury against Injury he did not / but yielded the good against the ill
/ and he prayed for his enmyes Vnde luce.xxii. Pater dimitte illis non enim
sciunt quid faciu^t. Also perfect people should love their enmyes in following
god / and they shall have great reward in paradyse. Un. math. v. and. lu. vi.
Diligite inimicos vestros benefacite hus qui oderu^t vos et orate pro
persequentibus et calumniantibus vos vt sitis filii patris vestri qr benignus
est super ingratos and malos. That is to say. Love your enmyes / do good to
them that hates you / and pray for your persecutours and dyspysers to thend
that ye be the sons innytatoures of god your fader.

G. Questyon. How may I love those ye which has bette me or made me to lose
my goods or my good renown. The answer. Thou sholdest love the evil will of
thy neighbor: but for the love of god thou sholdest love the persons and
their salvation / and also if by Justice thou make them to yield to the thy
goods and to punysshe the sin of thy neighbor thou of tendest not. For
Justice is founded after god and unto god / and Justice appertains to do
punycyon and not unto ye. Wherefore thou ne sholdest venge the that god ne
wroth him against the. The great lords the which will not understand for to
do right and justice departs it with ye sword / and is suffered of god unto
those ye which has good right. Un. catho Pugna pro patria. The parfite people
bears al aduersytees pacyently and does good against ill for the love of god.
Example in saint Steven yt prayed for his enmyes yt god should pardon them the
sin that they did to stone him. And to the end yt his prayer were the sooner
exalted he set him on his knees Vn^ acti. vii. Positis au^t genibus clamauit
voce magna dice^s / dn^e ne statuas illis hoc petm^. Example yt Dauyd wept ye
death of his enmy Saul ye which persecuted hy^ Also he wept at the death of
his friend Ionathas in like wise as it is written in the first chapter of the
second book of kings Also we read in the.xviii. chapter of ye book of kings
that Ionathas the sone of Saul loved Dauyd as his own soul / and on a time he
dyspoyled him of his gown and gave it unto Dauyd Also Dauyd loved him as
himself. Also Dauyd wept at the death of his neighbor Abner. Vt habetur.ii.
regu^. iii. Also he wept at ye death of his sone Absolon yt did him war. Vt
habetur.ii. regu^.xviii. and.xix. Also Dauyd would do none evil to his enmye
Saul when he might have done it / in like wise as is written in the xxvi.
chapter of the first book of kings. This is an example here that we should
love our enmyes for the love of god. By these things aforesaid it apereth how
we should love our nyghboure.

H. Questyon. Who is my neighbor.
BY this that god commands to love his neighbor a man may demand. What is
it yt is my neighbor. The answer. That is every man and woman / for we should
love the salvation of souls and the well and vtylyte of all persons / and not
the ill. Saint Austyn says. Exte^de caritate^ per totum orbe^ quia me^bra
christi per orbem iacent. Extend charity over all the world / that is
dyleccion / for the members of Ihesu christ lies by the world. God will that
those of scotlond / of of france / and of spain be also well saved as them of
England if they deserve it: for all ben members of god tendynge to salvation.
He loves the little as ye great / he the^ has create and is their governor
and purueyour. Un. sapien. vi. Pusillu^ and magnu^ fecit dominus equaliter cura
est illi de omnibus. And therefore it behooves to understand that all ben our
neighbors / but for as much as we ne may do alms over all ye world it
suffyseth to do it unto those ye which ben among us after our power This
matter is given unto us by word. Luce.x. Homo quidem desce^debat ab iherusalem
in iherico qui incidit in latrones. And the euangelyst says that one of the
masters of the law demanded of Ihesu christ who was his neighbor / and he
answered unto him. A man descended from Iherusalem unto Iheryco the which fell
in to the hands of thieves the which dyspoyled him and bette him so much that
he was replenysshed with wounds and left him as half deed / and it befell
that a priest passed by and took none head. In likewise a deaken passed yt took
no head. After a Samarytane the which passed the country found him and had
pity and anointed his wounds with wine and oil and did bind him and after
yt put him on his mare and bare him in to a stable and gave two pens unto the
master of the stable and prayed him that he would heel him / and at his
return he should satysfye him at his will After these words Ihesus demanded
of ye master / which of them seems unto ye that has be most nere unto the
seek man of the three the which passed by him. He answered the Samarytan
estraunger. And god said unto him thou have said truly / go and do thou in
likewise. Saint Austy^ says. Omnem hominem oportet intellegi esse proximum
quia nemo est cu^ quo operandum sit male. A man should understand as it is
said yt every man is our neighbor. For to moralyse upon this eua^gelyst a man
should understand that when a person is baptized he is replenysshed with all
virtues and with goods espyrytuelles as if he descended from Iherusalem that
is paradyse in to Iheryco that is in to the field of battle in this world the
which is full of thieves those ben sins the which dyspoyleth him of his good
virtues and stryketh him with many mortal wounds yt which ledeth him unto
the death of hell / that is pride: auaryce / slouthe / envy / glotony / ire /
and lechery the which stryketh ye souls when they consent unto them / and by
the priest and deaken the which passed and took none head ben understand
those ye which have no pity ne compassyon of the pardycyon of souls / and by
the Samarytan myserycordyous ben understand these the which remedyeth unto
the health and salvation of sinners as after that Adam had sinned and was
fallen among the thieves god had mercy the which has so much done that he
has be heeled by the merit of his passion and by the holy sacraments. And
our lord as the Samaryta^ made to put wine and oil in his wou^des. Vinum qui
letificat cor hominis. That is by confession the which clarifyeth the
conscience of sinners / and the oil that is the last vnccyon the which
heeleth the sekenesses corporelles and espyrytuelles in likewise as says saint
James. And when the Samarytan put the seek man on the mare is Ihesu christ the
which bare our sins on his body at his passion / and said unto the master
of the stable that he should heel the said seek body. That is to understand
Ihesus gave unto saint Peter the keys of the realm of heaven and unto prelates
and pastures unto whom he said When I shall come again in Judgment I shall pay
you your salayres after as ye have labored. After the sense moral Ihesus has
be our neighbor / for he has heled our gostly sekenesses as the samarytan
did the corporelles. And those ye heleth ye sinners of their sin or
socoureth those yt have need ben said neighbors.

A. Of the virtue of charity ye which extends in all ye commandments of
god.iiii.
THe master of the sentences says in his third book yt charity is in such
wise dyffynyed. Caritas e^ dilectio qua diligitur deus propter se / et proximus
propter deum. Charity is dyleccyon by the which god is loved for the goodness
infynyte the which is in him / and the neighbor is loved for the love of god.
All the commandments of god tends for to love god and his neighbor as it
is said. And charity is none other thing but to love god and his neighbor.
So charity is commanded by all the.x. commandments and in every of them. If
thou wylt have of examples of charity ye shalt find in thexamplary.
Quere.lxxv. a. b Charity is so noble a virtue that it is cause and mother of all
good virtues / without it for nothing seche we other virtues. Un. aug. Caritas
est causa and matter oim virtutu^ q^ se disit frustra habentur cetera si au^t ad
sit habentur oi^a. Charity is cause of virtues / for when we fast / or when we
do alms / or wha^ we do any good operacion god is the cause and the same
good deed is done for the charity and love of him. in obeyenge unto his
commandments / to the end to be united and coniunct with him yt is that he dwell
with us and we with him. Vnde.j. john. iiij Deus caritas est: and qui manet in
caritate in deo manet: et deus in eo. Et john. xv. Qui manet in me et ego in eo
/ hic fert fructu^ multu^. qr sine me nichil potestas facere. Also when we love
our neighbor and yt we do hy^ good in his need god is the cause for it is for
his sake / and therefore charity is cause of virtues. The which charity is
contemned in all the commandments of god. Also charity is mother of virtues /
for in likewise as children proceeds of the mother and have their nourysshement
and and techynge / even in likewise ye virtues proceeds of charity and ben
done for ye love of god / wherefore it is said ye mother of virtues / and in ye
thing where charity lacks no goostly good is found / and where it is all
goodness there rests. Aug. Vbi est caricas quid est quoth possit obesse / vbi
au^t non est quoth est quoth possit prodesset. Without charity we ne may walk after
god. Vn^ amb. Si cut sine via nullus peruenit quo tendit / ita sine caritate q^
dicitur via no^ possimus recte ire. Also charity is ye fountayn of virtues.
Vn^fulge^tius epres dicit quod caritas est fo^s oi^m vtutu^et origo bonoru^
munime^ egregium via q^ ducit ad celu^ in caritate qui a^bulant nec errare
poterit nec timere / iprea dirigit / iprea protegit / ipsa perducit ad regnu^
eternum. Charity is the fou^tayne of all virtues for by it they ben aroused /
grow / fructyfy / and increase. It is the natyuyte of al goodness and the
garnysshy^ge of noblesse. For by it man is rich and full of goostly goods /
and lift up in noblesse fast by god / it is ye way yt ledeth unto heaven and
without it we ne may go thider He yt walks by charity can not go out of the way
ne dread. Charity adresseth / defends and ledeth ye right way. Also charity
is ye rote of al virtues. In likewise as says saint Austyn the words of the
appostle.j. ad thy.vj. Sicut radix oi^m maloru^ est cupiditas / ita radix oi^m
bonorum est caritas. The rote of the tree be it good or ill extend the humor /
her bounte / or malice by ye branches and boughs / and also makes them to
grow and to multyply after his nature. And in likewise as couetyse ye which
is rote of all evil extends her malice in all sins / in likewise charity
ye which is the rote of all goodness and virtues extends her bounte and
valor by all virtues and makes them to grow / to multeplye / and to bear
fair flowers / and good fruytes. For the beginning / the cause / and the rote
wherefore a person does good deeds as the works of mercy. It is by charity
for the love of god. And if any supporte the imperfeccyon and the pouerte of
his neighbor / yt is for the love of god by charity. Un ad gal. vi. Alter
alterius onera portate et sic ad i^plebitis legem christi. And if he counceyle
and conforte his neighbor that is by charity. Vn^.i. ad tessallo.v.
Co^solamini in inuicem et edificate alterutru^. And if he do justice in
yeldynge every man his own / and if he keep veryte without lyenge / and if he be
humble without pride / chaste without lechery / all is done for the love of
god in obeynge unto him. Vn^ gregorius. Amor dei nunquam estociosus / operatur
eni^ magna si est / si autem operari renuit amor non est. Every good deed ought
to be done in god / and for the love of him / for no virtue bears good fruit
before god if it be not done upon ye rote of charity. Vnge grego. Non habet
ramus aliquid viriditatis nisi maneat in radice caritatis. Et Iheronimus dicit
quod alia inter fructus spu^s debuit habere primatum nisi caritas sine qua
cetere virtutes non reputabuntur esse virtutes ex qua nascuntur omnia bona.

B. Charity is a tree that bears none ill fruit / but bears all fair flowers
and all fair fruytes so that it is much worthy to be praised / loved / and
hau^ted. That is to say He the which has charity declyneth from all evil and
does all good operacyons. Iuxta illud psalmus. Declina a malo and fac bonum.
We find no peers in an apple tree ne crabbes or medelers in a plomme tree.
for it is a good tree that bears good fruit. Vnde mathei.vi. Non potest arbor
bona malos fructus facere. Also there is no theft / lechery. etc. found in a
good person Also he the which has charity is not enuyous of the welthe of
his neighbor. For saint Poule says.i. ad corin. xiii. Caritas non emulatur.
Also he the which has the heart enroted in charity bears good fruit Vn^
luce.vi. Neque enim de spinis colligunt ficus / neque de rubo vindemiant vuam.
In a thorn men find no fygges / for it is a bitter tree / in likewise as is
envy. The fruit of a tree of envy is bitter and evil. For the enuyous ne
does but evil unto his neighbors. And the fruit of the tree of charity is
sweet and good / for he ye which has charity ne does but good / also he the
which has charity ne speaks none ill words / and the enuyous is to the
contrary. Vnde mathei.xii. et luce.vi. Bonus homo de bono thesauro cordis
profert bona and malus homo de malo thesauro profert mala. Also in likewise as
men know a tree by the fruit that it bears / in likewise does a man a
person by his operacyons. Vnde luce.vi. Vna queque arbor de fructo suo
cognoscitur. Et mathei duodecimo. Ex fructu enim arbor cognoscitur. Et mathei
septimo. A fructibus eorum cognoscetis eos. A man can not say that a person is
chaste when he is found in doing lechery. Vnde mathei duodecimo. Progenies
viperarum quomodo potestis bona loqui cum sitis mali. Also that man or woman
the which has charity enjoys and delyteth hy^ in all goodness / in all
welthe / in all beauty / and in all good operacyons and in veryte. Un.i.
corinthios decimotercio. Caritas concaudet veritati. Also he enjoys him for
to to se the goodness of his neighbor as humylyte / pacyence / chastyte /
devotion / sanctyte. etc. Also he is sorry and dyspleasaunt of the harm and
afflyccyon of his neighbors after the saying of the appostle ad to. xii.
Gaudere cu^ gaudentibus and flere cum flentibus. Also he the which has
charity has no Joy in him self that he have any sin: or if he go out of ye
way Vnde.i. corin. xiii. Caritas non gaudet super iniquitatem. And the enuyous
is unto the contrary. Also he the which has charity thinks non ill / for he
has good conscience. Vnde.i. corin. xiii. Caritas non cogitat malum. He loves
his neighbor as himself / and he ne wylleth evil unto hy^ no more than unto
himself. And therefore he ne does detraccyon ne mockery / and ye enuyous does
the contrary. Also charity ne may do none ill / for in it is nothing contrary.
Vnde.i. corin. xiii. Caritas no^ agit perperam / idest aliquid peruersum. For
it is all good as it is said. Non cogitat malum. Non est ambiciosa. He the
which has charity is not enuyous to have ye good of another / but yeldeth
unto every man yt the which is his. Also it has no dread seruyle ne worldly /
for he ne dredeth that ill come unto him for to sustain and to keep veryte and
bounte. He is not as the auarycyous that dredeth to lose his goods and to
offend the world. Vnde august. Perfecta caritas nec cupiditatem seculi nec
timorem Per istas duas ianuas intrat et regnat i^imicus. Et legitur.i. john.
iiii. Timor non est i^ caritate sed perfecta caritas for as mittit timorem: quia
au^t timet non est perfectus in caritate. Also he the which has charity
bears pacyently for the love of god aduersyte / sykenes / and pouerte. Vnde.i.
ad corin. xiii. Caritas non irritatur oi^a suffert / oi^a substinet paciens
benigna est. etc. Charity is benygne unto all in general / for it yield the
good against the evil. Secundum illud luce.vi. Diligite inimicos vestros
benefacite his qui oderu^t vos / benedicite maledicentibus vobis et orate pro
calumniantibus vos. Love your enemies / do good unto those the which hates
you / bliss them the which do curse you / pray for those the which
dyspyseth you. Et legitur ad to. xii. Benedicite persequentibus vos / bn^dicite
and nolite maledicere. Bliss ye those yt persecuteth you / bliss ye and curse
ye in no wise. Also he the which has charity is not proud for any good that
god unto him has given. Quia caritas non inflatur. The charitatyfe is humble /
sweet and replenysshed with all good virtues ye which ben kept by charity. And
therefore saint Poule says illud.i. ad corin. xvi. Vigilate state in fide
viriliter agite and confortamini et omnia opera vestra in caritate fiant. Wake
you and hold you in the faith / labor ye strongely and conforte you / and
all your operacyons ben done in charity. Et legitur ad ephe. iii. Caritate
radicati and fundati vt possitis comprehendere cu^ omnibus sanctis que sit
latitudo longitudo sublimitas et profundu^. Be ye enroted and founded in
charity to the end that ye may comprehe^de with all the saints what is the
longenes or length / or the largenes and bread / or the heyght and the depenes
of charity. The largenes of the tree of charity is to love not only god and
our friends but also our enmyes. Vnde pres. Tatum mandatu^ tuu^ custodire
nimis. The length of charity is perseueraunce in good operacions un the last
end. The hyghnes of charity is esperaunce to have remuneracyon in paradyse of
good deeds. The perfundyte and depenes is to believe that the goods that we
have comes of god occulte the which we ne may se.

C. Without charity no good espyrituel ne may prouffyte unto persons. For
saint Poule says.i. ad corinthi. xiii. Si linguis hominum loquar et angelorum
caritatem au^t no^ habuero factus sum velut es sona^s aut cymbalum timiens.
That is for to understand in english after ye exposytour, if that I should
speak as wisely as all the men in the world and the aungelles of heaven / and
that by my tongue I might convert all the nacyons of the Infydeles if charity
lack in me I may not be saved. My tongue is as he ye which stryketh upon an
here or on a clock / or as he that beteth the water / this prouffyteth
nothing as unto the salvation. The words that saint Poule speaks of himself
ben understand of every person. Sequitur. Et si habuero prophetiam. And if it
were so that I had the gift of prophecye as Balaam the which said. Orietur
stella ex jacob. Et si nouerim misteria omnia. And I knew all the mysteryes
and secrets of the new and of the old testament / and all the secrets of
god as did Lucyfer. Et si habuero omne^ scientiam et fide^. And if I had all
ye science of the books of the world / and all the faith of crystendome. Et
si distribuero in cibos pauperum oe^s facultates meas And if I should give unto
the poor all ye goods that I have from penny to penny and if I had an hundred.
M. pownde. Et si tradidero corpus meum ita vt ardea. And if I should give my
body to so many afflyccyons yt it should brenne as saint Laurence that was
roasted / and if I should fast breed and water every day. Caritate^ non habuero
nichil michi prodest. All these things beforesayd should nothing prouffyte as
to the salvation if I have not charity That is too know if the love of god or
of my neighbor defayled in me. That is to understand if I hated my neighbor
in desiring the loss of his goods / as to be stolen or rauysshed / or the
evil of his body as to be bette / slain / or other ill in brekynge any of the
commandments of god. If I should dye in such estate without correccion and
amendment I shall not be saved / for charity defayleth in me. Caritas non
cogitat malum. Charity thinks none ill. For it has an holy conscience. B^
these things aforesaid it appears that a^ the law and the commandments of
god depends of charity / the which is to love god and his neighbor.

A. How god defends in his commandments all evil words / thoughts and
operacyons. And there commands all good operacyons.v.
David the prophet says in h^ psalter. Declina a malo and fabonum. Declyne
from evil (...) is fro all evil words / thoug^tes / and operacions and do
goo^ that is all good operacyons. For god it the commands. If thou will
know vnd^^ What commandments all evil word^ ben defended. the answer. It
behooves (...) make dystynccyon if thy words be again ye dyleccyon of god /
or against yt of man If they ben spoken by delyberacyon aye^^ the dyleccyon of
god a man breketh one o^ the three first commandments. For y^ such words
ben blasphemynge or swer^ge vnprouffytably god them defends b^ words
express in the second commandment. Ne iures vana per ipsum. An^ if they
ben words berynge honor vnt^ ydolles god it defends in the first
commandment. No^ adorabis deos alienos And if they bear dyshonoure unto the
sanctyfycacyon of festes god them defende^ in the.iii. commandment. Sabbata
s^^fices. And if such words ben against ye d^lecco^n of thy neighbor. it
behooves to m^ke dystyncyon of them. If they ben of fals^ witness or lyenge
god them defends (...) viii. commandment. No^ loq^ris contra proximituu^
falsum testimoniu^. And if they dysh^nour fader or mother / god defe^deth the^
in (...) fourth commandment. Et venerare patres. And if they ben words of
thretenynge to beat or to sle his neighbor god them defends in the.v.
commandment. Non sis occisor. And if they ben of auaryce or pyllerye god them
defends in the.vi commandment. And if they ben lecherous words god them
defends in ye.vii. commandment. In likewise god defe^deth evil thoughts
in his commandments. For if they ben against the dyleccyon of god they ben
defended in one of ye three first commandments / in likewise as it is said of
ill words. And if they ben against his neyghour it behooves to make
dystyncco^n of such thoughts. For if they ben lecherous and that delectacion
and delyberacyon be therein of will for to accomplysshe the sin / god them
defends by words expres in the.ix. commandment Non concupisces vxore^
proximi tui. And if they ben of auaryce / theft / or couetyse god them
defends by words expres in the tenth commandment. Deutero. v. Non
concupisces rem proximi tui. And if such thoughts be against the honor of
fader and mother god them defends in ye iiii. commandment. And if they will
beat / slay / or do ill god them defends in the v. commandment. etc.
Morouer god defends all evil operacyo^s in his commandments. For in the
commandments where as he defends all evil thoughts and words / by a
greter reason he there defends the cursed operacyons / and by words expres
he them defends in four commandments. That is to understand in the first.
Non adorabis deos alienos. and in the.v. Non sis occisor / and in the.vi. No^
furtu^ faties / and in the.vii. No^ mechaberis. B. Also god commands all
good operacyons in his commandments / and by words expres in two
commandments yt is to understand in the third. Sabata setifices / and in
the.iiii. Et venerare patres And here a man should clearly understand and well
note that in all the commandments where god defends ne to de: ne to say ne
to think evil / he commands the opposyte / yt is to do / to say / and to
think good as men may se where he defends. Ne worship you no ydoles and
strange gods. Tha^ I commau^dethe yt thou worship one god only. Ne sle not
thy neighbor ne hate hy^ ne do him none ill. Than I command the to love him.
Ne do no lechery / than be you chaste. And be thou no thief: Than be you lawful.
Ne love not to much the goods of the world as done the auarycyous / and
keep not to much. Than be thou lyberall / and depart with them. Be thou no
liar / ne falls wytnes berer. Than be verytable. etc. Ne speak you none ill
words in swery^ge ne ne lyenge / than bring thou good words and true. Ne
think thou none ill by auaryce / or lechery / and than thy^ke well these good
things. Also thou sholdest note that where god commands the to do good
operacions he the defends the contrary / yt is to do evil operacyons. Verbi
gratia. Sanctifye and halowe the feestes commanded Than do thou no sins ne
operacyons whereby thou shall dishonor them / love thy faders and thy moders.
Than hate the^ them not / ne do them none ill. Honor the^ Than dishonor them
not. Socour them Than fail them not in their need. etc. By these things
aforesaid you sholdest understand than when you wylt not halowe the festes to go
to gods service / as even songs / matyns / and masses if it be feast
commanded or solempnel / or when you wylt not go to ye holy water / to the
sermons / and processyo^s or when you wylt not honor thy faders / or do
almesdedes and works of mercy to those the which have need / or when thou
will do ne say ne think ye good that thou sholdest do. Thou go against
some of the commandments of god / and offendest by the sin the which is
called obmyssy-yt is to leave a good deed undone by slouthe And therefore thou
shalt have correccyon and punycyon / and god shall demand of the account at
the day of Judgment / as it is written. Math. xxv. Esuriui et no^ dedisti michi
manducare. Sitiui et non dedistis michi potum. etc. Ite maledicti in ignem
eternum. I have had honger and thou ne have given me to ete. I have had thyrste
and thou ne have given me to dry^ke / and therefore accursed goo in to the fire
eternal. Those the which have not wylled to do the good operacyons / but unto
ye contrary have done the ill shall be punysshed as thou shall find by the
example of Cayn the which slew his brother Abell. Quere.lxxvi. a. Or of those
ye which has not wylled to bring forth good words but has blasphemed and
perjured shall be also punysshed as thou shalt find by example of the sone of
a woman of Israel ye which was stoned for his blaspheme. Quere.lxii. a. Or of
those the which have thought ill / as a woman the which was dampened for a
thought lecherous. Quere an ho^dred. a. For to abredge those the which
dysobeyeth unto god by operacyon / word / or thought shall be punysshed / in
likewise as thou may se by many examples ye which be written here after in
the examplary of the commandments of god.

C. Questyon under what commandments ben defended the.vii. deedly sy^nes:
and where ben commanded the virtues opposytes and contraryes.vi.
THe prophet Ysaye says in his first chapter. Quiescite agere perverse
discite benefacere. Cease you rest you to do peruersly and ouerthwartly the
sins and cursednesses / for god them defends. Learn to do well things
virtuous for god them commands. For to understand well the flower of that
thing that god wylleth and commands / a man should know that he defends
in his commandments the seven sins mortalles with all their branches and
dependaunces / and there commands the virtues opposytes and contraryes in
likewise as it shall be declared here afterward. And first for to know under
what commandment is defended every sin it needs to consider in bryef the
intencyon of god in gyuynge the said commandments / and the intencyon of
those the which go unto the contrary. First if thou demand where is defended
pride thou shall have answer general and after pertyculer. I answer ye
ge^rally that pride is defended in all and in every of the.x. commandments
of god / for when thou brekest any thou commytte^ inobedyence / and all
inobedyence is not (...) out pride. Also pride is defended generally in all
the.x. commandments of god. Ve^ba gracia. When thou worshyppest ye ydolles /
or when thou swerest vnprouffytably or when thou brekest the feestes / or any
of the.x. commandments thou show apertly that thou ne wylt so much low
the^ and humble the under god as to obey unto ye commandment that thou
brekest / so ye art inobedient and proud togyders / and therefore pride is
defended generally in all the commandments. Also all mortal sin and all
offense is committed by the sins of transgressyon or of obmyssyon And all the
sins of transgressyon or of obmyssyon be not without inobedyence /
inobedyence is not without pride as it is said. So every person the which
co^mytteth any mortal sin is proud and in likewise inobedyent and so
breketh some commandments / but specially pride the which is anenst god is
defended in the first commandment / and yt the which is anenst his
neighbor is defended in the iiij commandment. Secondely if thou demand
where auaryce is defended / it behooves to consider the entencyon and operacyon
of the auarycyous / for if he love ye goods more than god and above him he
ydolatryseth and breketh the first commandment. And if he work on the holy
day by couetyse in doing such operacyon he ne sanctyfyeth such holy day as
he ought to do and breketh the third commandment. And when he takes the
goods of another unjustly in any manner he breketh the syxte commandment. And
when he ne takes them in deed but by delyberacyon and consentement of reason
them would have he breketh the.x. commandment Thyrdly of slouthe is behooves
to consider that he the which is slothful to accomplysshe that / that god
commands / or delygent to do that that he defends he offe^deth in that
commandment where the said slouthe or contradyccion is made / as if he be
slothful to pray / to serve and to worship god after ye faith received in
baptysme he offends against ye first commandment / or if yt said slouthe be
a^enst god or his saints in the days of the feast commanded to sanctyfy the
said feestes he offends against the third commandment And if the said
slouthe were against the dyleccyon commanded anenst his faders and neighbors
he should offend against the fourth commandment. Fourthly ye sin of Ire and
yt of envy ben defended in the fyfth commandment / and all their branches
and dependences / as shall be declared in that commandment. Fyfthly of glotony
it is to consider the cause fynall of the excess / for when a gredy gloton
delyteth and loves his womb and body more than god and above him he
co^mytteth ydolatry and breketh the first commandment as in that shall be
declared / and if he break the fastes of the solempnytees / or that he excede
in drink or in meet in the feestes commanded he breketh the third
commandment. Sabbata sanctifices. And at all times that he nouryssheth his
body stro^gely in so much that it moeueth him to commit lechery he offends
against the seventh commandment / for glotoni and lechery ben systers.
Syxtely all ye sorts and manners of lechery the which ben committed in
operacyon ben defended in the seventh commandment / and those of the will in
the.ix. commaundment. And a man should note that in all the commandments
where god defends the sins he commands the virtues opposytes and
contraryes / as who would say. Be thou not proud / than be thou humble. Be
thou not slothful / than delygent. Be thou not to much holding ne
auarycyous / than yt thou be lyberall. Be thou not enuyous / tha^ charytable.
Ne yrefull / than pacyent. Ne gloton / than sobre. Ne lecherous / than chaste.
So it appears that god commands the virtues in his commandments and
defends the sins / the which sins ben too be blamed / and the condycyons
of those the which commytteth them that here follows.

D. Here after follows the.vii. mortal sins defended in the commandments
of god.
Who so will know the offenders
By the branches of the seven sins
I shall reherce them by orders
And first with pride that all ill begynnes
Of pride.
The proud man is dysobedyent
Ypocryte / and great in bostynge
Apt to every inconuenyent
Contemnynge and also presumynge
Of auaryce.
The auarycyous is a thief
Full of gyle / and great defrauder
Usury and symony to him is lefe
Sacrylege is he / and also rauyssher
Of slouthe.
The slothful man is also musing
Idle / neclygent / gyuynge no force
Vain / tydeous / delytynge inslepynge
Sluggysshe / unlusty / an unthrifty corce.
Of envy.
The enuyous is full of hate
A great detractour and full of ill
Dysposed ever to make debate
Full of malice and evil will
Of wrath.
The enuyous is a great thretener
Iniuryous and blasphematour
Also he is a murderer
Dysdaynous / crier / and full of murmour
Of glotony.
The gloton deliteth in drink and fedy^ge
Encombrynge his stomach with excess
Full seldon sobre / or yet fasting.
Putting his body to no dystresse
Of lechery.
The lecherous is a fornycatour
Aduoutrer / and defloratour
Sacrylege / and rauysshour
Sodomyte and incestour
The auctour.
Who so will do his salvation
Fle the mortal sins seven
In avoiding of dampnacyon
If he will enheryte heaven.
It is written ecclesiastici.xxj. Quasi a facie colubri fuge peccata si
accesseris ad illa suscipient te dentes leonis dentes illius interficientes
ai^as hominum. Fle the sins as from the face of a serpent / if thou approach
unto them they shall take the with lions tethe / ye which ben the tethe of that
serpent which is sin / the which tethe sleeth spyrytuall by death of gylt
the soul of man. There is not a worse heed than is the heed of a serpent as
says ye sage eccle. xxv. Non est caput nequius super caput colubri. For his
tethe / his tongue / and brethe ben venymous / the which enuenymeth and makes
the persons to deye. Also for to^ speak spyrytually there is nothing wor^
unto the soul than mortal sin / the company of it is nothing worth / for it
ledeth unto dampnacyon and perdycyon. Vnde Ezechielis.xviij. Anima que
peccauere ipsa morietur. The soul the which has committed mortal sin
shall deye spyrytually of death eternal without extynguysshement if it be not
medycyned by penance.

A. Here follows the first commandment of god.vi.
ONe only god thy creator
Thou shall serve / and in him believe
And love him best with all honor
As nere as grace will give the leave
Vno credo deu^. Believe in one god only and love him right parfytely. It is
evil taken to them that has done unto the contrary / in likewise as we may
find by examples. Quere.lvij. c. d. e. In this commandment many things ben
commanded and defended.

B. That it is commanded to believe in only god in trynyte and to worship
him.vi.
IT is written deutero.vi. Audi Israel / dominus deus vester deus vnus est. O
Israel your lord god is one god. Et legitur marci xii. Vnus est deus et non
alius preter eum. One god is / and there ne is none other but he. Of necessyte
of health it is requysyte to all persons for too put their faith and crede^ce
in god ye creature / and not in ydolles and things created. For it is written
that without faith it is Impossyble to please god. Vnde ad hebreos vndecimo
capitulo. Sine fide impossible est placere deo. And therefore he commands us
too believe in one only god in trynyte. That is to know in god the fader al
puyssaunt / in likewise as says saint Peter. Credo in vnum deum patrem
omnipote^tem. And in Ihesu christ his dear sone / in likewise as says saint
Andrewe. Et in iesum christum filium eius vnicum dominu^ nostrum. Also in the
holy ghost in likewise as says saint Barthylmewe. Credo i^ spiritum sanctum.
These three persons be^ one only god in one unity and symplycyte / and not
many gods / for they ben in one self substance and nature / in one self
might / dyuynyte / and glory. Anathase says. Fides autem catholica hec est /
vt vnum deum in trinitate / et trinitatem in vnitate veneremur. The faith
catholyke is that we honor one god in trynyte and the trynyte in unity. And it
behooves not to confound the persons ne to separate ye substance. Neque
confunde^tes personas neque substantiam separantes For they ben three persons
devised and dystyngued ye which ben in one substance and nature / in one
unity and symplycyte as it is said the which ben one only god. And therefore
it is here commanded to believe in him to worship / honor / and serve him /
and to give the dyuyne honor the which apperteyneth unto him and not to
ydolles. Our blyssed savior and redemptour Jesus gives it clearly by words
to understand the which ben written Mathei.iiij. Dominum deum tuum adorabis et
illi so li seruies. Thou shalt worship thy lord god and him alonely serve.
Also it is written deuterono.vi. Dominum deum tuum timebis et ipsi so li
seruies. Thou shall dread thy lord god and him all only serve. Examples to
worship one only god in trynyte and not many It is written in the xviij.
chapitre of Genese that as Abraham was at the door of his tabnacle he lift up
his eyes and saw dyuynely three angels in semblaunce of three persons the
which de notes the fader / the sone / and the holy ghost / he ran against
them and worshipped them in earth and said. Domine sun ueni gratiam in oculis
tuis ne tra^seas seruum tuum sed afferam pauxillum aque et laue^tur pedes
vestri. etc. Tres vidit and vnu^ adorauit. He saw three persons and worshypped
one only god in trynyte. Unto the example of Abraham we shall adoure and
worship one only god in trynyte. Another example written in ye.xxiiij.
chapter of Exody that our lord said vn-Moyses. Mount in too the mountain
thou and Aaron / and Madab / and Abyn / and three score ancient men of Israel
and ye shall worship a far of. Another example in Exody that the children of
Israel understood that god them vesited and regarded the tourmentes that
Pharaon did unto them / than they fell prostrate on the earth and worshypped
him. Vnde exodi. iii^. Audie^tes filij israel quod deus eos visitaret et
respiceret afflictionem eorum et adorauerunt prom in terram. etc. An other
example written in the first chapter of the first book of kings that a man
named Helcana departed from his cite on the days establysshed too the end that
he should worship and do sacryfyce unto god. Another example written in the.ix.
chapter of Neemie that after that ye children of Israel came again from the
captyuyte of Babylon they separated themself from people strangers / and also
put them in fastings / they cladde them in sackes / they put earth upon their
heedes and worshypped their lord god. Another example written in the first
chapter of Job yt when the said Job had herd the words of the messengers the
which came to tell him that his goods were lost and his sons slain / he
lift him up and fell prostrate unto the earth and worshypped god and said.
Nudus egressus su^ de vtero matris me / and nudus reuer^ar illuc. Another
example written in the.vi. chapter of Danyell the which was commanded of
king Dayre that none ne should demand any thing of god ne of man by.xxx.
days / but alonely of the said king Dayre. And Danyell ne did nothing and
bowed his knees three times on a day and worshypped his lord god. Another
example written in the second chapter of ye euangelyst saint Mathewe that when
the kings that came fro the oryent entered in to the house and found the child
and the vyrgyn Mary his mother they yode on their knees and worshypped him.
Another example in the.x chapter of the gospel of saint John that a man yt
had be blind from his natyuy^ was enlumyed of Ihesus and after wo^shypped him.
Another example write Mathei.viij. and marci.j. that when Jesus descended from
the mountain a mesel^ a lepre came to him and worshypped him and said. Domine
si vis potest me mundare. My lord if thou will thou may^^ heel me. Another
example written M^thei.xxviij. that when the appostles cam^ to our lord after
yt he was risen they wo^shypped him. Another example written in the.iiij.
chapitre of the gospelles of sayn^ Mathewe that our lord said unto Satan as
he tempted him. Thou shall wo^shyppe thy lord god. Dn^m deum tuu^ adorabis et
illi soli seruies. Another example written in the.xxij. chapter of the
Apocalypse that after that saint Johan ha^ seen the reuelacyons of god he fell
before fete of the angel that had showed their to him to the end that he might
worship him. And the angel said / keep the from doing yt. And afterward
follows wo^shyp god. Thou shall be right vnnatura^ to dysknowlege thy god the
which is t^^ creator of the heaven and of the earth / g^uerneth all the world
and purueyeth unto all creatures all things as to them be necessary. Also
thou sholdest be ydolat^ to give unto the ydolles and strange go^des the
honor the which apperteyne^ unto the fourmer and creatoure of us all The
scryptures says that the name (...) god is louable from the oryent till unto
occydent. Vnde psalmus. Asolis ortu vs^ ad occasum laudabile nome^ domini. A so
thou sholdest be without entendemen^ and natural reason for too think that
stone or a symulacre has puyssaunce f^ to give the health in thy sickness or
paradyse at the end of thy life. Also force or p^yssaunce proceeds of the
creator as it is written Iohannis.j. Omnia per ipsum fata sunt / et sine ipso
factum est nichil. And therefore believe in one only god in trinyte and if thou
therein be ferme and steadfast you shalt be worthy to do miracles as did a
priest the which entered within the fire for to approve the faith and was not
bre^t Quere.lxi. B. Another example how a good man steadfast in god required him
that a mountain might be remoeued and changed from one place in to another
for to conferme the faith / and his request was herd. Quere.lxj. a. Unto this
purpose it is written Mathei.xxj. Amen dico vobis si habueritis fidem et non
hesitaueritis et si monti huic dixeritis toll et iactare te i^ mare fiet.
Certainly I say you if it be so that ye have had faith without doubting / and
that have said unto this mountain take the away and cast the in to the sea /
it shall be done.

C. Secondly it is defended to believe in ydolles and strange gods / in
errors / and folysshe credences.vj.
IT is written in the ancient testament that god defends al ill operacions /
thoughts / and words of infydelyte the which these ydolatres speaks / and
thinks against the faith. Vnde exodi.xx. c. No^ habebis deos alienos coram
me. No^ facies tibi sculpile neque omnem similitudinem que est in celo desuper
/ et que in terra / nec oi^a eorum que sunt in aquis sub terra non adorabis ea
neque colles. That is to lay. Thou shall not have strange gods before me
Thou ne shall make ydoldes ne statues ne symylytudes what so ever it be in the
sky on hye as the son and the moon that many have worshypped unfaithfully /
nor in other things the which ben on the earth of the things the which ben
in / waters / ne under the earth. Thou ne shall worship those things ne give
unto them the dyuyne honor / that is that ye which is written before. One
only god with all thyn heart thou shalt serve / and in him believe. Thou
shalt love him with all thyn heart and also thou shall honor him. Maledyccyon
comes on those the which will not believe in god / and the which makes
ydolles unto whom they adiust and put their faith. Vnde deuteronomie.xxvij.
Maledictus homo qui facit scultilie et conflatile abhominationem domini opus
manuum artificium. And it is written Leuitici.xix. Nolite conuerti ad ydola nec
deos conflatiles facietis vobis: ego dominus deus vester. Convert you not unto
ydolles / conflatyles and sculptures / that is that ye make no gods by
blowynges and grauynges as did the children of Israel when Moses yode to
fetch ye commandments in the mountain / they wend to have made a god of
gold and of silver and they made a calfe the which they worshypped and
daunced about. Than Moses was wroth of the said ydolatryse and of the daunces
/ and he kest down the tables wherein was written the commandments and brake
the^ he made to cease the said daunces and called on his party all those the
which were not there to consenting unto whom he said that they should put
unto death al the^ the which had ydolatrised and daunced and that the son
ne should spare the fader ne other parent / for in so doing they should
consacre their hands in obeyenge unto god / and so it was done. For of the
people of god the which had so ydolatrysed and daunced there were.xxx.
thousand slain / and by the will of god as thou shall find. Exodi.xxxij.
Vocem cantantium ego audio dicit moses. Et cum appropinquasset ad castra vidit
vitulum and choreas Iratusque valde proiecit de manu tabulas et confregit eas.
Questyon. To know if that it be offense to make and worship the images of the
saints of paradyse for that before it has be said. Non facies tibi scultile /
nec omnem similitudinem que est in celo de super. etc. The answer. We should
not worship the images in like wise as the thing that we adoure / for that
should be ydlatrye / but we worship other thing that the image represents /
as so me saint. The image is alonely the token of the thing that we worship
/ wherefore we offend not. Many folks have broken this commandment and yet
does / as ben the ydolatres the which worshyppeth and serves unto ydolles
and gives unto them ye dyuine honor / their faith / esperaunce / and love
that they should give unto the creatoure. These ydolatres be^ excommunycate by
the sentence of right. It appears also by many examples that they deyed of an
evil death / as Egeas the which made to crucyfye saint Andrewe. Quere.lvij.
c. And Dyascorus the which beheded his daughter saint barbara.lvij. e Also the
prouoste Tarquyn / the king of Perse. Cosydore. Quyncyen. Maxymyen. etc. In
likewise as men shall find in ye examplary in the first commandment.lvij. f.

A. Thyrdly all the artycles of the faith ben here commanded to believe in
likewise as the church believes and holds.vii.
ANathasius says. Quicunque vult saluus esse ante om^ia opus est vt teneat
catholicam fidem Quam nisi quisque integram inuiolata^que seruauerit absque
dubio ineternum peribit. Every person the which will be saved it is requysyte
before all things that he hold the faith catholyke / the which if every one
ne keep hole without doubt he shall perysshe in perdurabylyte. Al good
catholykes should believe in one only god in trynyte as it is said before. And
who so believes in god steadfastly it behooves that he believe in all his
operacions / as in ye creacyon of heaven and of ertth and in his sanctyfycacyons
/ as in the holy church. Wherefore ye artycles of the faith ben here
commanded the which does follow.

Saint Peter says. Credo in vnum deum.

Who so will believe steadfastly
In the faith of crystyente
Believe in one god alonely
Three persons in unity.

Et in iesum christum filium eius vn^^^ dominum nostrum. And saint Barthylmewe

pater natus neuma sacer deus vnus.

That is in the fader all puyssaunt
And in the holy ghost also
And in Jesus his dear infaunt
As christian men should do
Also saint Andrewe says Creatore^ celi et terre.

And this only god in trynyte
The heaven the earth and the sea
And all other things made has he
For the conforte of our humanyte
Saint Mathewe says. Sanctam ecclesiam catholicam.

In holy church also believe
By steadfast faith and devotion
As nere as god grace the shall give
If thou entende to have salvation
Again saint Thomas says Scto^ru^ co^munionem. And saint Simon. Remissiomem
peccatorum.

And believe that all good crystyens
Have with the saints communyon
Of all good deeds by the sacraments
And of their sins remyssyon
Saint jude says. Carnis resurreccione^
And when ye angel his horn shall blow
All that been deed shall appear
Lie they in earth never so low
In body and soul enrere
Saint Mathewe says. Vita^ eternam

In to paradyse shall ascend
The evil also great pain shall feel
In hell ever withouten end
Saint James the more says. Qui co^ceptus est de spiritu sa^c to natus ex

Believe also by great veryte
In Ihesu crystes humanyte
Conceived of the spyryte holy

Straight in to the helles he yood

He has promised as we read
On domes day to come again
To Judge the quycke and the deed
Some to bliss and some to pain
Hec est fides catholica quam nisi quisque fideliter firmiterque crediderit /
saluus esse non poterit.

Who so his soul thinks to save
Entendynge here after to come to bliss.
Parfyte faith must he have
In one article he may not mysse
THe person the which will be saved ought to be steadfast / stable / and
immouable in ye faith for it is the foundement upon the which men edifye ye
other virtues for to multyply them in goods espyrytuelles and for to mount in
to paradyse. Vnd ad collocenses.i. In fide sitis fundati stabiles et immobiles.
Be ye founded in the faith stable and immouable. Also we read of a wise man
the which edyfyed his house upon a steadfast stone / and the rain descended
and the winds and the waters struck against it and it fell not / for it was so
well founded. Vnde mathei.vij. Desce^dit pluuia et venerunt flumina / et
flauerunt venti et irruerunt in domum illam et non cecidit / fundamenta enim
erant super petra^. The raynes descended / that is ye tourmentes and
aduersitees the which descends from the heyght of the air. By ye waters the
which comes ben understand ye persecucyons of the rich puyssauntes. And by
the wyndes the which blows ben understand the favors of the world / or ye
Iniuryes / thretenynges / and unjust languages ye which stryketh against ye
house belonging to the Just by diverse temptacyons. And it fell not from good
purpose by delectacion / consentement ne good operacyon / for it was founded
upon a stone / yt is ye faith of god. Saint Poule says in his epystles. In
oibus sume^tes scutu^ fidei i^ quo possites oi^a tela neqissimi ignea
exti^guere. For to resyst against ye temptacyons of ye devil it behooves to
have steadfast faith And a man should note ye faith without operacyon is deed
and of no value / and as the body is deed when ye soul is departed. Vn^. Job
ii. Sicut corpus sine ai^a mortuu^ est ita and fides sine operibus mortua est.
Example of some yt has been sure in ye faith. q^re.lxi. a. b B. Much people
gooth to da^pnacion and perdyco^n for lack of faith as lollers and heretykes
that holds and believes some thing against ye artycles of the faith / and
instruteth ye sy^ple folk so to believe / such people ben excommunycate by
sentence of right. Vt habetur extra de hereticis. Exco^municamus. And is a case
reserved unto the bysshoppes. Also all those the which has put faith and
credence unto the said heretykes in reputing them to be good and to have good
faith / and all those the which defends them of deed and of word ben also
excommunycate. Also many heretykes have been ill reproved for that yt they have
erred against the artycles of ye faith First Manycheus erred the which said yt
there were two gods / the one good and the other badde / and that the good
had created the things inuysybles and the ill the things vysibles. Against
this error saint Peter says. Credo in vnum deum patrem omnipotentem creatore^
celi et terre. Secondely Arryanus erred the which said that Ihesu christ was a
creature created less after the dyuynyte than god ye fader. Against this error
Anathasius says. Filius a patre solo est no^ factus nec creatus / sed genitus.
Equalis patri secundum diuinitatem: minor patre secundum humanitatem. Thyrdly
some greeks have erred the which said that the holy ghoost was creature and
not god. Against this error was made in the symbol. Qui cum patre et filio
simul adoratur et conglorificatur. Fourthly Sabellius erred the which put the
confusyon of the persons without to dystyngue them and said that the fader
was sometime the sone and sometime the holy ghost. Against this error Anathasius
does say. Alia est enim persona patris alia filii / alia spiritussa^cti vna
est diuinitas. Fyfthly the Jews and sarazyns erred ye which believed not in
Ihesu christ and gooth against the artycles of the faith. Sextly Iacobyte and
Nycolayte erreth / for they believe otherwise in the sacrament than ne does ye
holy church Romayne: Seue^thly the Greeks erreth the which denies that the
holy church Romayne ne is the chyefe and the maystresse of al chyrches.
Against this error was put in the symbol. Apostolicam ecclesiam. Many other
heretykes have erred against the faith the which I leave by cause of shortness.
Examples of heretykes. And first example that ye deuylles kept an heretyke
from brennynge: but when the body of Ihesu christ was brought they ne might
keep him.lix. a.

Another example that a cautelous heretyke was brent of a fool.lix. c.

A. Fourthly of the effect of the.vii. sacraments the which ben comprehended
under the artycles of the faith.viij.
IT is written that our lord said unto his dyssyples that they should go
through out the world to preche ye gospel yt is all holy after our faith. He
the which has believed in god after the faith and has accomplysshed that the
which is written in the gospel and has been baptized shall be saved. And he
the which has not believed shall be condampned. Un. mar. xvi. Euntes in mundum
vniuersum predicate eua^gelium omni creature. Qui crediderit and baptisatus
fuerit saluus erit / qui vero no^ crediderit condempnabitur. After the law
catholyke and the holy scryptures we believe that these sinners have remyssyon
and pardon of all their sins by the grace and mercy that god has given and
instytued unto those the which worthily and holyly receives the holy
sacraments instytued and ordained in his church / the which holy sacraments
ben contained and hole comprehended under these artycles. Credo sanctam
ecclesiam catholicam / sanctorum communionem remissionem peccatorum. And they
ben seven the which folowen. That is to know Baptysme / penance /
confyrmacion / vnccyon / order of prestehode / eucarystie / and marriage. After
the scryptures these sacraments ben Instytued for to hele those yt ben seek by
the Infeccyon of sin. The church is an apotycary or as the house of a prudent
phesycyen the which is furnysshed with all good medycynes against all
sekenesses for to give health. The seek man is the sinner / the phesycyen is
Ihesu christ / the mynyster of the medycyne is the priest / the entrayte the
lectuary / and apotecareryes is the virtues of the sacraments. The sy^ner has
many sekenesses / the first that comes in to this world is sin orygynall /
against ye which is the sacrament of baptysme for to hele it. The second
sekenes is venyall sin against the which is instytued the oil of ye last
vnccyon. The third sekenes is mortal sin / against the which is instytued
the sacrament of penance. The.iiii. sekenes is debylyte or weykenes of faith
/ against the which is instytued confyrmacion. The fyfthe sekenes is
ygnouraunce of things verytables / against the which is instytued the
sacrament of the order of prestehode / for he the which receives it ought to
be a clerk and sage for to instruct. The syxte is the concupyscence carnal
of voluptuous people / against the which is instytute the sacrament of
marriage. The seventh is affection dysordynate in things blind and defaylynge
/ against the which is the sacrament of eucharystye. or body of our lord.
Also the seven sacraments gives great grace unto sinners / for they do bear
effect. By the great grace that almighty god has given within the effect of
the sacrament of baptysme well received all gylte is effaced and put away.
that is orygynall and all sin actual mortal / and venyall. And this
sacrament gives grace and also all virtues as well theologalles as moralles /
and if it ne gives them as unto the usage / yet it gives the^ as unto the
habyte. Si non dat quantum and vsum ad minus dat quantum ad habitum. Ista est
sentencia consilii generalis Vt habetur in constitutionibus domini clementis
extra de su^ma trinitate et fide. ca. c Fidei catholice. Also the effect of
the holy sacrament of baptysme gives an affynyte espyrytuall the which is so
right parfytely great that it lets marriage / so that the baptysant and the
godfaders and god moders and gosseppes ne may have in marriage ye baptized. Also
baptysme opens the gates of paradyse and makes him to possede / and makes
him to be perteyner in the passion of our savior and redemtour Ihesu christ.
Quia omnes qui in christo baptizati sunt christum induunt. Vt dicit paulus in
suis epistolis. This sacrament of baptysme is requysyte of ye necessyte of
health. For it is written Iohannis tercio. Nisi quis renatus fuerit ex aqua and
spiritu sancto non potest introire in regnum dei. Who so has not be gotten
again / or newly borne / regenerate / or washed from sin orygynall by water
and by the holy ghost ne may enter in to the realm of god. Also as says the
holy euangelyst saint Mark It is requysyte that we be all baptized in likewise
as it has been said and declared here tofore.

B. The effect of the sacrament of penance well taken in contrycyon /
confession / satysfaccyon and purpose no more to return unto sin does many
goodnesses unto ye soul of every man and woman contryte for their sin. The
first is that it wassheth / puryfyeth / and makes clean the soul from the
fylthe of sin. The second that it effaceth / adnychylleth / and makes to
put in forgetfulness all venyall and mortal sins. The third that unbinds
and lowseth the lines of the devil and of sin / and takes ye soul from her
vile servitude. The fourth goodness that the sacrament of penance does is that
it makes the appoyntement of the dyscorde ye which was between god and man by
sin. The fyfthe that it makes man to be the sone of god and of grace that
was by syne the sone of ire and of the devil by Imytacion. The syxte goodness
yt penance does is that it recouereth and makes to come again the good
virtues and operacions ye which had been done in thestate of grace ye which
were put in forgetynge and lost by mortal sin. The seventh goodness that
penance does is that it makes a man to be the membre of god and of the
church and makes him to be pertener and gadred in the good deeds of saints /
for by mortal sin the man is separate from god and from his saints.
The.viij. goodness that the sacrament of penance does is that it unbinds and
dyschargeth man from da^pnacyon and perdycyon. The nynth goodness is that it
opens paradyse unto ye sinner and makes him to have the life eternal and to
reygne with god. All sinners should receive this sacrament in great faith /
humylyte / and reverence / for by ye great grace that is in it all sins ben
pardoned / in likewise as says holy scryptures in many places. It is written
Mathei.iij. Facite fructum dignum penitentie. Make ye fruit dygne of penance.
Et legitur Ezechielis.xviij. Si autem impius egerit penitenciam ab omnibus
peccatis suis que operatus est et custodierit vniuersa precepta mea et fecerit
iudicium et iusticiam vita viuet / et non morietur / omnium iniqu^tatum eius
quas operatus est non recordabor. That is to say. If the sinner will do penance
of all his sins that he has committed / and after that he has kept all my
commandments / and that he has done Judgment and Justice which is to
yield unto every man that the which unto him apperteyneth he shall live in
life eternal and shall not deye in dampnacyon / nor I shall never record ne
remember none of ye sins that he has committed. And it is written
Eyechyelis.xxxiij. Nolo mortem impii sed vt conuertatur a via sua and viuat.
Sequitur post iusticia iusti non liberabit ei^ in quacunque die peccauerit /
and impietas i^p^ non nocebit ei in quacunque die conuersus fuerit ab impietate
sua. That is to say. I will not the death of the evil sinner / bu^ that he be
converted from his cursed way and yt he live / and it follows. The Iust^ce of
the just shall not deliver him in o^^ day that he has sinned / and the sin
of the wicked man shall not noye him in on^ day that he co^uerteth him from his
euylnes: and therefore the sinners ben not to be despised. For such one shall
be this day evil the which peruauenture shall be t^morowe a good penytent and
of the nombre of the saved. Example in of the sinner publycan ye which in
short time was Iustyfyed and better than the pharasee which despised him / in
like wise as it is written in the.xviij. chapter of the gospeles of saint Luke.
Another example (...) the thief zacheus the which at the beginning was evil
and in short time wa^ converted and a good man in likewise as it is written in
the gospelles of saint Lu^ Also Theophyle. Thais. Mary magdalene in short time
converted them / and many other examples semblables shall be fo^de by the table
of the examplary in the ty^tre of penance. It is written in the.xviij. chapter
of ye gospelles of saint Mathewe that if a man had an hundred sheep and that
one of them were lacking / he would leave the.lxxxxix. too seche that one / and
if he may find him he will enjoy more of that sheep than of the other which
has not gone out of the way. Also Joy shall be made in heaven upon a sinner
the which has done penance. Vn^ Luce.xv. Gaudium erit in celo super vno
peccatore penitentiam agent quam super nonaginta nouem iustus qui non indigent
penitentiam. Also the publyke sinners and the manifest harlottes the which
comes unto penance and reknowlege their defautes shall be more sooner saved
than ye devout people that Iustyfyeth themself and reknowlege not their
sins. Vnde. Math xxi. Amen dico vobis quia publicani et meretrices precedent
vos in regno dei / venit enim ad vos johannes in via iusticie et non
credidistis ei / publicam autem et meretrices crediderunt ei. etc. By theffect
of the sacrament of confyrmacyon well taken the venyall sins ben pardoned.
The holy ghost fortyfyeth the person in the faith and assures him from fere.
Grace newly therein is given / and the ancient therein is augmented. By theffect
of the sacrament of vnccyon well taken the venyall sins ben forgoten / and
the mortalles ben pardoned. This sacrament gives medycine and health unto the
body and unto the soul / and perseueraunce in good operacyons / it multyplyeth
and augmenteth grace gotten and gives grace of new / also it defends from
the enemy. Of this sacrament it is wryte^ Iacobi.v. Infirmatur quis ex vobis
inducat presbiteros ecclesie vt orent super eum vnguentes cum oleo sancto and
alleuiabir eu^ dominus a languoribus suis et si in peccatis sit dimittentur ei.
If any of you be seek call for the prestes of the church to the end that they
pray over him in anoytinge hy^ with the holy oil and our lord shall light
him of his la^goures / that is of his sekenes And if he be in sins they ben
forgyuen him. And the psalmyst in the person of ye sinners says. Miserere mei
domine quoniam infirmus sum sana me domine quoniam conturbata sunt ossa mea.
Lord have mercy upon me which am dyseased heleme / for all my bones ben
troubled. The sacrament of order is of purete / clennes / science / prudence
given unto priests for to Instruct the people / for admynystre the sacraments
/ to bind and to unbind ye sy^ners. The sacrament of eucaristie that is ye
sacrament of the auter is god in form of breed and of wine the which gives
grace unto all folk and life eternal in likewise as it is requysyte. Vnde
john.vi. Hec est panis de celo descendens / vt si quis ex ipso manducauerit non
morietur. Here is ye bread descendynge from heaven to the end that who so eteth
of it shall not deye. Iterum legitur in eodem capitulo. Ego sum panis viuus qui
de celo descendi / si quis manducauerit ex hoc pane viuet in eternum / and
panis quem ego dabo caro mea est pro mundi vita. That is to say. I am the breed
of life that am descended from heaven / who so eteth of this breed worthily and
in such wise deyeth shall live in pardurabylite / and the breed that I give is
my flesh for the life of the world. Example that a vyrgin saw a priest
clear / fair / and shynynge in great glory as he song mass. que^.lxxxxiiij
a. Another example that a bishop saw upon an ester day some men confessed the
which were meruaylously white / and ye other black.lxxxxiiij. c. It is a

C. It is written in the end of the first book of the dialogue of saint
Gregory that a fader of an household was seek nygh unto the death and he sent
to fetch the rectour of ye parysshe a worshypfull priest named Seuerus the
which was found occupied in cuttynge his vine. And the messengers said to him
yt their master prayed hi^ yt he would come right hastily to him to ye end
that he might pray for him / that he might confess him / and that he might do

before I will come after you / and he tarried a while or he departed to make an
end of a little thing the which was left of his operacyon when he had ended
he put him on ye wa^ to goo unto the said seek man / and in the way he found
the said messengers ye wh^che ran toward him: and unto hy^ say* A priest why
haste thou tarried so long travail the no more for he is departed: when he
herd them say so he was much sorry / and so all weeping he came to ye say^ body
that was deed and there he fell prostrate unto the earth in weeping and
wa^lynge and saying that he was homycyd^ of the said deed body. And as he wept
the soul of ye said deed man came again unto the said body. And when they the
wh^che were present saw that of great Joy and admyracyon that they had they
t^ke them to weep / the which him demanded where he had been and how he wa^
comen again. He answered the deuyll^ led me the which were as men right
^^deous and black from whom issued o^ of their mouth and nosethrylles fire
an flambe so that might not endure / and a they led me by derke places
suddenly fair vysyon an angel as a fair you^ man came against them the

has be wepth our lord has given him unto him (...) his teeres. Than ye said
man reuyued ar^se up suddenly from the earth / confess him / did penance by
seven days / a^ on the.viii. day Ioyously he departed o^ of this world.
After this example a pre^ should never deffer too admynyster the s^cramentes of
the church to any person^ that them needs. Also a person sho^^ not tarry to

aeged / and when he may no longer prolouge ne delay. Audi scripture Legitur
ecclesiastici quinto. Non tardes conuerti ad dominum et ne differas de die in
diem subito enim veniet ira illius and in te^pore vindicte disperdet te. Et

A. Fyfthly it is commanded here to love god above all things / and defended
to love other things more than him.ix.
IT is written in the.xiiij. chapitre of the gospelles of saint Johan Si quis
diligit me sermonem meum seruabit. etc. Sequitur. Qui no^ diligit me sermones
meos no^ seruat. Who so loves me he keeps my word: and he the which loves
me not keeps not my words. It is a thing right reasonable to love god the
creator and to obey unto him above all things created in like wise as it is
declared before. Quere i. d. e. f. For to understand this dyleccyon saint
Thomas of Aquin gives a rule general saying in this wise. In the thought of
man there is ever some thing that he loves soueraynly above all things / and
in it he ordeyneth his life. And that / that he loves in such wise is the
last end and intencion. If it be god he is in thestate of grace / and if he
deye in such wise he shall be saved. If it be a creature he is in thestate of
dampnacyon. Saint Austyn says. Peccatum mortale est libido sieve amor
voluptatis supra deu^ vel equaliter ei. Mortal sy^ne is lechery or love of
volupte above god / or egall unto him. Et peccatum veniale est libido sieve amor
voluptatis citra deum. Venyal sin is lechery or love of volupte under god.

B. Many sorts of people there be^ that loves other things better than god.
First these auarycyous men the which loves ye gold and the silver and the
other goods of ye world above god / and puts their love / fyaunce / and
hope more in the help of goods than in the aid of god / they break this
commandment and synneth mortally. Quia proponunt ceeaturam creaturi. They
love the thing created above the creator / the which is ydolatry. Vnde ad
ephe. v. Auaricia est ydoloru^ seruitus. Vn^ augustinus dicit. Hoc est homine
colitur / quod preceteris diligitur. That thing is honored of man the which
he loves above all things. Et psalm. di. Simulachra ge^tium argentum et aurum
opera manuum hominum. The ydolles of people is silver and gold / the
operacions of the hands of man. For to win an halfpeny the auarycyous
swereth and forswereth himself / breketh the feestes and leueth to serve god
and to say his service / for his heart is on the goods more than on god. And
he may not serve unto god and unto the devil. Vnde mathei quinto capitulo.
Nemo potest duobus dominis seruire. etc. Sequitur Non potest deo seruire et
mammone.

Example of an auarycyous usurer the which axed help of his gold and silver
wha^ he should dye. Quere.lxxxvi. F. Another example of an auarycyous man ye
which commanded his soul unto the devil at his gate for that / that it
would no longer abide with his treasoures and goods. Quere. lxxxvi. G.

C. Secondely these glotons the which loves their wombes more than god and
the which serves unto the preparacyons of meets for to nouryshe the belly
more sooner than to do service unto god in his church / or the which obeys
unto their wo^bes when they will ete more sooner than unto god when he is
commanded to fast and to abstain him / they break this commandment / and
make their god of their wombes the which is a manner of ydolatri whereof speaks
saint Poule ad philippe^.iij. Quorum deus venture est and gloria in co^fusione
eorum. Of the which glotons the belly is their god and glory unto their
confusyon / unto ye which belly or womb they make their oblacions and
sacryfyces. Their church is the kechyn where they say their matyns and
deuiseth of their service. Their priest is the coke the which makes the
sacryfyce for to give to the belly the which is the god / and the sacryfyce ben
the meases of the metes / the awter is the platter / the ensence is the odor
of wynes and metes. the lauds of the matyns that been said at the table where
the wyles / mockeryes / and detracco^ns ben reherced. For to make short that /
that a person loves and honors most is his ydoll or god. Vnde Isodorus.
Cuique quoth magis colit vel diligit hoc ydolum vel deus est illi. This sin of
glotony draws a man gloton unto apostasy. Vn^ ecclesiasti.xix. Vinum et
mulieres apostatare faciu^t sapientes et arguent sensatos. The wine and
lecherous women: bry^geth in apostasy the wise men / and repreueth ye wytty.
Also it ledeth in to dampnacyon. Vnde paulus and roma. viij. Si enim secundum
carnem vixeritis moriemini. If ye live after ye body or the flesh ye shall
dye. that is ye shall be dampened. Example of a woman dampened the which used
her life in glotonyes / dronkenesses / and lecheryes.lxxxxij. A. Another
example of (...) gloton named Vodo the which yode vnt^ the tauernes when he
should go unto the church.lxvij. E. The ydolatry of the paynyms is evil / for
they honor the ydolls and gives unto them the dyuyne honor the which
apperteyneth unto god. The ydolatrye of the auarycyous is wors / for they love
and worship gold and silver more than god. The ydolatrye of glotons (...) yet
wors and worst of all the which hono^reth their womb and makes it their g^^
as it is said. Thyrdly the lechours louet^ their folysshe lover more than god /
and obeyth more sooner unto her than unto go^ that is to say / they love better
to break the that god commands than to do ayen^ the will of their said love
/ and by yt the dampne their soul / and they neither lo^^ god ne themself.
Vn^ pres. Qui diligit in^tatem odit animam suam. He the which loves inyquyte
hates his soul. Example by that Sychen loved Dygne ye doug^ter of Jacob by
love lecherous he was slane and his fader also. Que. lxxxxi. d. Fourthly those
the which loves faders and ^^ders more than god breketh this commandment

D. Syxtely those the which loves to rich people and great lords / as
