E. Syxtely the pride ye which is against the dyleccyon of god is defended in
this first commandment / and that which Gayenst the dyleccion of his
neighbor is defended in the fourth / and humylyte is commanded.ix.
IT is written in the.iiij. chapter of the epistle of saint James ye god
resysteth against the proud men and women. Deus super bis resistit. For they
dysobey unto his commau^deme^tes and unto his will A man is much proud when
he gives or will have the honor the which apperteyneth unto god / or when he
says that the goods of nature comes of him / as is youth / beauty. etc. Or
the goods of fortune as gold / silver. etc. Or ye goods of grace as wit /
reason / memory / engyn / devotion. etc. Saint Poule says.i. ad cori^. iiij.
Quid habes quod non accepisti. What gods have thou in this world that you ne
have taken them of another. When thou was borne thou brought nothing with the
/ and all the goods that thou have comes of god and all the evil that thou
have proceeds of thy self. Also thou art proud and breketh this
commandment if thou love ye honors of the world more than god or if thou
take heed more gretely to have the^ and to get them than the love of god. Or
when dysordonatly you gloryfyest thy self of the deeds that you do / or of
the goods that thou have of god in saying that they come of the or by thy
merytes / or yt there is none but thou that is worthy too have it. By such
pride a man becomes appostate. Vn^ eccle. x. Initium superbie hoi^s est
apostatare a deo. Also a proud man appeteth to have the honors worldly / the
precious clothynges or orname^tes. He wylleth that every man praise him and
honor / bow under him / call him lord / and that he trede other underfoot /
and yt he be superyoure. Example how Dauyd slew the proud Golias. Que.
lxxviij. C. Another example how the devil drew the soul from ye body of a
cursed rich man with a hoke. Que. c. v. A. Also a proud man will not obey /
but wylleth that men obey unto him / he will not serve but he will be served /
he dredeth nothing and will be dredde / he will be reputed a good man and holy
and yet will he not do the operacions. etc. For to know a proud person a man
shall wete when he has an appetyte dysordonate to have honor / excellence /
dygnyte / noblesse / lordshyppe / domynacyon over and above the good that god
has him given and ordained / but a man should know that the noblesse of
abyllementes is not defended unto every man after his estate. It is the
superfluyte of the pride the which may be taken in those abyllementes the
which is defended. Also a man shall know a proud man when he will not put
him under god and his superyoures in obedyence / dread / service / and
reverence. Pride has many cursed branches the which ben / bosty^ge
inobedyence / ypocrysy / contempcyon / pertynacyte / dyscorde / presu^pcyon /
arrogaunce in pride / exceeding elaco^n. etc. The which branches shall not be
here declared because of shortenes / but note well that the sin of pride
noyeth in many manners unto those the which commytteth it. Quere post ad
numeum.xliiij. b / c / d / e / f / g. and cete. Example in the bible of some ye
which has been proud / and first Adam and Eve committed pride in as much as
they appetyted to be semblable unto god in knowinge the good and the evil.
Eritis sicut du scie^tes bonum et malu^. Alsoo in as much as they brake the
commandment of god in bytynge the apple. Quere in thexamplary liiij. A.
Another example of those of Babylon that committed pride willing to edyfye a
toure to reche unto heaven / and god resysted against them and changed their
languages. etc. as it is written. G. xi. Agar was proud and despised her
maystresse / but the angel of god meked her as it is written. Genesis.xvj.
Another example that Pharao was proud the which would not obey unto god and
unto his servant Moses / and he was drowned as it is written in Exode.
Quere.liiij. F. Another example that Chore. Dathan / and Abyron were punysshed
for their pride / inobedyence and murmr. Quere in thexampl.liiij. H. Another
example that ye king Anthyogus was proud over puyssau^ce humayne Quere.lxxxv.
D. Another example yt a man was so proud that he would that all men should
bow the knee before him and he was hanged on a gybet as it written /
Hester.vij. ca.

F. God alsoo does command humylyte in all his commandments where he
defends pride. Men knows a person humble when voluntaryly he obeys unto
god and unto his superyours / and yt he put himself under to serve / to dread
/ and to honor another. Of humylyte is somewhat spoken in the.iiij.
commandment in the first manner how children should honor their faders.
Quere.xxj. B. Humylyte does many good deeds. Primo^ makes to exalte the
oraysons of the meke folk. Vnde psalmus. Respexit in orationem humilium et non
spreuit precem eorum Secundo it makes god to abide with the humble folk. Vnde
Ysaie. penultimo. Super quem requiescet spiritus men's nisi super humilem et
quietum et trementem sermones meos. Et bernardus. Si maria humilis non esset
super eam spiritussanctus non requiesceret. Tertio humylyte delyuereth him from
his enmyes. Vnde psalmus. Humiliatus sum et liberauit me. Iterum psalm. In
humilitate nostra memor fuit nostri. Quarto humilyte makes to have grace.
Vnde.j. petri.v. Oi^s enim inuicem humilitatem insinuate qr dominus superb^
resistit humilibus autem dat gratiam. Example in the glorious vyrgyn Mary.
Luce.j. Aue gratia plena. Quinto humylyte lyfteth the person unto god / and in

qui se humiliat e^altabitur. Example of the sinner publ^can the which humbled
him was lift v^ and Iustyfyed. Luce.xviij. Descendit h^ iustificatus ab illo
scilicet phariseo. Sext^ humylyte makes to possede paradyse. V^
prouerbioru^.xxix. Humilem spiritu sus^piet gloria. Et Job.xxiij. Qui enim
humiliatus fuerit erit in gloria et qui inclinau^rit oculos suos ipse
saluabitur. et psalm. H^miles spiritu saluabit. Examples of humylyte / and first
of a nonne the which washed the pottes / wyped the disshes / and d^de all
humble things. Quere in thexamplary.lxj. C. Another example that t^ prince the
which humbled him before H^lye and prayed hy^ mekely was not bren^ with the
fire celestyall as the other were ye which spoke proudly. Quere in
thexa^plary.lx. G. Another example in the glorious vyrgyn Mary the which made

A. Here follows the second commandment of god the which treats of
swerynges and blaspheminges.x.
The name of god thou shall not swear by
Nor yet by his saints in vain
For if thou do so certainly
Thou shall suffer eternal pain.
This commandment is written Exodi xx. ca. Non assumes nomen dei tui in vanum.
Thou shall not take the name of god in vain. And it is wryte^ deuterono. v.
ca. Non vsurpabis nomen dei tui frustra qr non erit impunitus qui super re vana
nomen eius assumpserit. Thou shall not usurp the name of thy god for naught.
For he the which has taken his name upon a vain thing shall not abide
unpunished Examples of them the which has been punysshed for their swerynge
cursedly. Quere in the examplary.xlij. A.B. And it is written Leuitici.xix.
capitulo. Non per iurabis in nomine meo nec pollues nomen dei tui ego dominus.
Thou shalt not forswere the in my name / and thou shall not soil the name of
thy god by cursed and vyolent words. etc. In this commandment many chapytres
ben written.

B. And first that god defends all swerynges vain and vnprouffytable under
this word / vanum.x.
NEiures vana per ipsum. Swear thou not without need and in vain of a thing
whereof thou art not certain. For to understand all this commandment in
few words it behooves to hold for a rule general that as many times and as
often as a man does make oaths / sermentes / and swerynges the which ben vain
and vnprouffytable / without necessyte / without cause good and vtylyte so
often takes he the name of god in vain. Or when a man makes lyenge oaths /
and vows without truth the which be^ evil or deceytfull / or execrables /
and detestables he takes also the name of god in vain and breketh this
commandment Or when a man makes Just vows and accomplyssheth them not
according to his promysse he takes the name of god in vain. And for because
that men do swear in so many of wise manners that it is meruaylous: and that
these generalytees suffyseth not unto the people of little entendement it
behooves here afterward to goo more largely to recyte and declare the manners
therein to offend. This word here vanum is said in scripture in three manners.
Vanum aliqua^do dicitur falsum: aliqua^do inutile / aliquando peccatum
iniustum. Primo this foresaid word vanum is taken for a false thing. Thou
shalt not take the name of thy god in vain / that is to know berynge record
in wytnessynge and testyfyenge for a false thing against thy neighbor whereof
speaks the psalmyst* Vana locuti sunt homines vnusquisque a proximu^suum.
These men speaks vain things every of them unto his neighbor when any will
deceive his neighbor by any falsenes / fraud or malice he makes serment and
oath in cally^ge god unto wytnes for to conferme his malice the which is to
take the name of god in vain / so he does Injury unto god. For forswerynge is
none other thing but to call him unto wytnes for to afferme and conferme that
that a man swereth / as swore saint poule Testis est michi deus. And to call god
unto wytnes for to conferme any false thing is a great injury done unto him /
for in yt manner there it is to believe that god ne knows the veryte ne the
falsenes of the thing that a man swereth / so man apposeth on him ygnouraunce
the which is against the holyscrypture. Vnde paulus ad hebreos.iiij. Omnia nuda
et apperta sunt ante oculos eius. Al things that been open and and naked ben
openly seen before the eyes of god. Et legitur ecclesia. Oculi dn^i multo plus
lucidores super solemn circu^spicie^tes om^es vias hominum et profundum abyssi
and hominum corda intuentes in absconditas parts terre. etc. The eyes of our
lord ben much more clerer than the son beholdy^ge all the ways of men and
the profundyte and depnes of the hertes of men beholdynge in the parties hyden
of ye earth. etc. Also when in swerynge any calls god to wytnes he imposes
on him that he loves lesynges / or that he is a liar the which is a thing
that he hates. Vn^ psalm. Dilexisti iusticiam et odisti iniquitatem. Thou have
loved Justice and have hated sin / also you have loved veryte. Vnde psalm. Ecce
enim veritatem dilexisti. So to impose unto god that he loves lesynge / or
that he is a liar is a thing yt much dysprayseth his bounte and imposes on
him great injury. And therefore a forsworn person is worthy of punycyon.
Secundo / this word vanu^ is taken sometime in ye scripture for a thyge vain
and inutyle. Vnde psalm. Dominus scit cogitaciones hominum quonia^ vane sunt.
Our lord knows the thoughts of men / for they ben vain and unprofitable /
as when a man confermeth a thing vain and vnprouffytable the which is
against the thought. God the which knows the thoughts as it is written prim^
regum.xvj. sees well that man takes his name in vain. In the ancient
testame^^ it was defended that men should not swear false. But Ihesu christ
defends in the new law that men ne swear but in necesyte for a thing
vtyle. And the reason (...) such / for that / yt the tongue is the memb^ and
party of the man or of the woman^ is most frail / tender / and light
applyege for to swear and to vttre language n^yenge unto his neighbor. Et qui
iura de minimo de leui cadit. He the which s^reth for a little thing falls
lightly / an^ who so lightly falls ryseth not again when he will. And
therefore swear not vanely against thy conscience in saying o^ thing and
thinking another for to deceive thy neighbor / and leave the accus^maunce of
swerynge by god and his say^tes that punycyon do not come upon the Example of
two young men the which forswore them and the one of them becam^ lepre / and
the other seek of the fire of sayn^ Anthony. Que. lxxxxvij. d. Tertio / the
word vanum is taken sometime for sin^ and for thing inutyle the which is
magnyte / or inequalyte or Iniustyce / where speaks the psalmyst. Hilij
hominum d^gitis vanitatem et queritis mendatiu^. S^nes of men wherefore love ye
vanyte and ^che lesynges. Those the which swereth they shall do evil and
sin unto the^ neighbors / as homycyde / robberyes. and for to venge them
they love vanyte the is sin / and seeks lesynges and swereth the name of god
in vain. Saint Austyn assygneth two parties of Justice / that is to declyne
from ill and to do good. And those the which swereth that they shall do evil
as homycide swereth against the commandment of god and against Justice / so
they take ye name of god in vain. In likewise he the which swereth that he
shall do no good / as not to do alms deeds he gooth against the
commandment of god and against Justice / so he takes the name of god in
vain / and he should not acco^plysshe such an oath as it is wryte^ here
after. God commands that all the words yt men speak of him or of his
saints be in his dyleccyon / in his honor and reverence / and that he ne be
called but in all veryte bounte loyalte / and vtylyte / or punycyon shall come
upon them the which does unto the contrary. Example that evil came unto
Chore. Dathan: and Abyron the which took the name of god in vain in speky^ge
ill words against the commandment of god / and sanke in to hell all quycke.
Quere liiij. H. Another example of a relygyous that spoke words murmuring
against the dyleccyon / loyalte / and reverence of god / and evil came to him.
Quere.liiij. I.

A. The manners of forswerynge by the oath affermynge / and by the oath
promettynge.xi.
THe wise man says. Let not thy mouth be accustomed for to swear / many
cases ben in yt accustomaunce / for who so often swereth often is forsworn
And who so lies often / often sy^neth mortally. The name of god ne be
accustomed in thy mouth as he the which says often by god I shall do thus /
or by god I shall not do thus. And entremet the not to swear often by the
saints of paradyse / for if thou swear by them in vain thou ne shall be quyte
toward them / they shall have matter to accuse the before god. Vnde.
ecclesiasti.xxiii. ca. Iurationi non assuescat os tuum multi eni^ casus su^t in
illa / nomi^atio vero dei non sit assidua in ore tuo et in nominibus sanctorum
non admiscearis: quonia^ no^ eris i^munis ab eis. This is that which is written
before. The name of god nor his saints for naught ne in vain thou shall not
swear by / thou dampnest thy self be thou in certain if thou in swerynge
forswere the. We find in scripture two general kinds of perjury or
forswerynge by the which men sin in contempnynge or despysynge wetyngly the
dyuyne veryte. The first kind is by the serment or oath affermynge. The
second is by the serment or oath promising. Nam aliud est iuramentum
assertorium vt quando iuratur de presenti vel preterito sic esse vel non esse
fuisse vel non fuisse. Aliud est promissorium vt cum jurat aliquis se daturum
vel facturum aliquid in tempore futuro. etc.

B. First a man forswereth him by the serment or oath affermynge when he
knows or believes steadfastly that any thing is false / evil / and dysloyall
/ and that by delyberacyon he swereth affermatyuely with intencyon to deceive
that it is good / he the which in such wise swereth synneth mortally and
right grievously as it is written.xxii. q. ij. Homines. Right grievously he
synneth for he affermeth his lesynge by oath. Quia periurium est mendatium
iuramen to firmatum. Et dicitur periurium quasi peruersu^ iuramentu^.
Periurement or forswery^ge is as to afferme a lesy^ge by oath. And it is said
periurynge also as peruers oath. Et scotus in tercio suo. d. xxxix. Quicu^que
scienter jurat falsum sieve iocose: sieve seriose peccat mortaliter. Also who so
should demand what it is of the servant the which swereth a false thing
unto his knowledge by the admonycyon of his master as if the said master had
cause or quarrel against any man and for to win that he makes the servant to
forswere him. Raymonde says that they ben both forsworn and synneth
mortally. Dominus quia precepit seruus: quia plus dominum temporalem quam deum
vel animam dilexit.xxii. q. v. Qui compulsus. The master is forsworn for that
he commanded / and the servant is also for that he loves his lord te^porall
more than god or his soul. In likewise if the fader and mother make their
children to be forsworn wyttyngly both twain shall be forsworn / if the said
children were capables of the commandments of god. That is if they
understood well that they should dysobey unto god / and that they should sin.
And if the said children were not capables of the commandments of god they
do not commit sin / but the fader and the mother the which commands them
synneth double / and double penance and punycyon unto them apperteyneth. Alsoo
a man may make a questyon to know if he ye which constreyneth a person too
swear synneth or not. Saint Austyn says that it behooves for to make
dystynccion if he know or understand if he should be forsworn or not. If he
knows nothing and he him co^strayne for to have certyfycacyon of the doubt
it is no sin / but it is humayne temptacyo^. But if he know well that he
shall be forsworn and he him co^streyn to swear. The answer after saint
Austyn and after a doctor named Galazius. Quod talis vi^cit homicidam. That
such a person vaynquyssheth and surmounteth an homycyde For an homycyde de
sleeth the body. And he the which constreyneth a man too swear sleeth the
soul of the death of gylte. Moreover it sleeth two souls / that is the soul
(...) him that is forsworn / and the soul of h^^ the which constrained him
to swear. As it is written.xxij. q. v. Ille qui prouocat hominem ad iurationem.
Et.xxii. q. v. qui e^git. And that the which is said that he surmounteth an
homycyde is to understand in the damage given. For it is greter damage of the
loss of one soul than of bodies Infynyte Magis damnum est in a^^^sione vnius
anime quam corpora infinita.xxxii. q. ij. Si habes. And so an homycyde synneth
not so grievously.xiij. di. Duo mala Example of a man the which constrained
another to forswere him / and ill cam^ unto him.lxxxxij. g. Also if a march
a^^swere affyrmatyuely unto any person yt he shall sell unto him his ware at
such (...) price / and if he have Intencyon too gy^^ it unto him for a less
price and swereth (...) in lyenge against his thought. Quia motire est contra
mentem ire. And afferm^^ his lie by delyberacyon he synneth mortaly by as many
times as he so swereth / ^^rehe an hundred times on the day. And he the which
byeth if he swear by god I ne shall give more than so much for the thing /
or I will give no more and if ye he have Intencyon to give more and the he speak
against his thought and swear i^ in lyenge by delyberacyon he synneth als^
mortally by as many times as ye case happens. Also after that the merchant
has sworn affyrmatyuely that he shall sell his ware for so much if he bye it
/ and after that the other withholdeth it and e^presseth him so much that he
makes him forsworn they sin both two. For in likewise as we ne would lose
paradyse and be dampened we ne should desire that our neighbor be harmed.
Mathei. xxij. D^peccat mortaliter. Also who so should ^^ges proximum tuu^ sicut
te ip su^. Thou shall love thy neighbor as thy self. Example that two
merchants said unto their curate that they could not sell without lyenge and
swerynge.lxxxxix. K. Also who so should demand if they yt swereth covertly by
words deceyuable synneth or not. The master of the sentences answers in
tertio libro. d. xxxviij. q. xv. when any person swereth by art or cautele of
words not ente^dables for to deceive that god ye which is witness in the
conscience takes in such wise the oath as he it entendeth or understands
unto whom a man swereth by such wise he is doubly culpable for he takes the
name of god in vain / and he deceyueth his neighbor by cautele ye which is
contra illd thobie.iiij. Quod ab alio tibi odis fieri / vide ne tu aliquando
alteri facias. The thing that thou hate to be done unto these that thou ne
do it at any time unto another. Such people that in such wise forswereth
them abides not unpunished as we may se by example of a christian man the
which swear cautelously upon the auter of saint Nycholas for ye silver yt a
Jew had lent to him.lxxxxvi. a Also what is it of him that hereth any swear
falls / and is certain that he shall be forsworn and holds his peace) to
understand if he synneth or not. Raymonde says that ye / and allegeth illud
Leuitici.

Amma que aud^erit voce^ iurantis fallum et testis fuerit quod aut ipse vidit
aut conscius est nisi indicauerit portabit i^iquitatem sua^. The soul the
which hereth the voice of one swerynge falls and has be wytnes yt he has seen
or that he is culpable he shall bear his sin if he show it not. But that is
to understand yt he him should reprehe^de they two being al alone without to
publysshe it and manifest unto all folk / or he it should tell secretly to hy^
yt is his sovereign for to correcke him if the sin be secret. Quia qui
crime^ occultum manifestat no^ est corrector erroris: sed proditor / sicut
dicit augustinus.ij. q. j. Si peccauerit. He ye which manyfesteth the sin
secret or hid he ne is correctour of the error but he is a waster or
proditor. Also if he manifest the perjury openly peradventure he should be
punisshed corporally or slain by the Judge or by the pare^tes of him against
whom he is so forsworn: or peradventure he ye which should publysshe yt said
case lightly might be slain. So it appears that he ye which hereth another
to be forsworn should hold his peace / and also he ne should publisshe it.
Also a man forswereth him by the affermynge when he swereth of a thing
doubtous / that is to say when he knows not if it be true or not / or if
such things apperteneth unto such one or unto such one / and so by
delyberacyon swereth affyrmatyuely yt it appertains unto such one he synneth
mortally. In such a case a man should speak of credence and not of certain
science. But if by lyghtnes of tongue without delyberacion he swereth / it
should be venyall sin / so that anon he repent him and be sorry. etc. Also
men forswere them by the serment or oath affermynge when they believe that any
such thing is true / and that it apperteyneth unto such one / and swereth
affyrmatyuely for true without intencyon to deceive / and al be it they ben
deceived for it is false. I put the case he the which so swereth and
incontyne^t after the oath made enquyreth of the deed and repents after that
he knows and apperceyueth the falsenes he synneth but venyally / but if he
were slow and give no force to inquire of his ygnouraunce how he has sworn
he synneth mortally / as it is written.xxij. q. v. qi periurat. Also a man
forswereth him by oath affermynge wha^ any swereth affermatyuely that any
thing is true and that it apperteyneth unto such one / the which thing
really is true / but he that swereth believes steadfastly that it is false and
swereth it for true upon intencyon to deceive / in such manner he sins
mortally as it is written.xxij. q^. ii. homines Periurium est ergo vel iurando
loqui fall sum cum intention fallendi / vel iurando loqui falsum sine
intention fallendi: vel iurandi loqui verum cum intention falle^di. Than
forswerynge is too speak false in swerynge with intencyon to deceive / or to
speak false in swerynge without intencion to deceive / or to speak true in
swerynge with intencion to deceive. It is written primo regum.xvi. ca. Homo videt
ea que parent dominus autem intuetur cor. A man sees and knows the things
the which appears / but the savior and redemptour beholds the heart and
the thought.

C. Secondly a man forswereth him by ye oath promising in many manners. And
first when any promyseth by oath voluntary that he shall give or pay unto
such a person such a thing at such a term / or within such a term / if
after yt he change his purpose or yt he pass the said term by reason
dysposed he synneth mortally and is forsworn. But if he change not his
purpose and that before the said term he fall in to pouerte or necessyte in so
much that he has not whereof to fournisshe and acco^plysshe the said oath /
and that he is dyspleasaunt that he may not accomplysshe it / in such wise
shall he be of forswerynge excused. Quia necessitas non habet legem. The
nedenes has no law. Also when any promyseth by oath that he shall pay within
such a term / and that in swerynge he has intencyon not for to pay for
peradventure he knows well yt he can pay for he has not whereof / so he is
forsworn. But if he swear I shall pay if I may he shall be excused of the
perjury. Also of reason natural it is too understand that as often times as a
man swereth that he shall do our thing if he purpose in that hour that he
swereth that he will not do it ne acco^plyshe / incontinent that he makes the
say^ oath he is perjured. Example of a man the which would forswere him for
mone^lent and he lost his speech.lxxxxvij. c. Also it is clearly to understand
that those and they the which gives their faith solempnely in the sacrament
of marriage yt the^ shall do loyalte of body and of goods the one unto the
other / If in making ye say^ oath / or after yt their will is changed and
they defayle unto their promise they be^ perjured and synneth mortally. Also
wha^ any swereth that he shall say or do any thing dampnable as theft /
sacrylege / ^^chery / to beat or slay / or when he swereth yt he ne shall do
thing the which is lefull^ prouffytable / as not to give alms / or n^^ to
love his neighbor / or never to pardon him / or that he shall never fast the
four times that is the ymbringe days or such things semblables lefull and
good. He^ those the which swereth against chary^ synneth mortally and in
swerynge and (...) accomplysshynge the deed / but if they repent them and that
they accomplisshe no^ the operacyon it shall be well done / for such oaths ne
should be accomplysshed as it is written.xxii. q. iiij. Isido. Quod inca^te
vouisti non facias impia est promissio^ scelere ad impletur. Example that He^de
sinned to slay saint Johan baptyst f^^ to accomplysshe his oath.lxxvi. E. Also
y^ a woman made an oath unto her lemma^ in gyuynge him her faith for to lie
wit^ him when he will / that should be an oth^^ full of sin the which she
should not hold. And if she should swear that she should swear that she should
not go unto another she should hold that oath / for if she should go unto
another harlot or ribaude she should be forsworn and that should be wors. Also
if a thief swear unto his felawes yt he shall depart lawfully the theft done
among them / if he depart it lawfully it is an evil oath and full of sin /
and if he depart it not lawfully it is yet wors. Also if any has sworn that
he shall never be bishop or that he shall never e^tre in to relygyon / if
after it befall that it were prouffytable unto the church that he were bishop
or to enter in to relygyon he should not be bound unto the first oath. Also I
put the case that some be seized and taken of his enmyes or robbers the which
by great fere makes him to swear or to promise to pay a thousand pound the
which he ne can pay / or to give or deliver a town or a castle / to know
if he be bound to acco^plysshe yt said serment or oath. Unto that says
Raymonde says nay / and takes ye words of saint Austyn the which says quod
iuramentum non potest esse vinculu^ iniquitatis. An oath ne may be the line and
bond of iniquyte as it is written.xxii. q. iiij. inter cetera. and.xv. q. vi.
c. Si sacerdotibus. etc. Et dominus per Ysaiam. Dissolve colligationes
impietatis. Unbind ensemblementes or gadrynges together of cursed impyete that
is wickedness. Howbeit these doctors make dystynccion between the oath
promised and ye oath affermed / and says that the feere excuses the oath
promised / and excuses not the oath affermed. For a person should more sooner
suffer all euylles than to afferme a false thing / as it is written.xii. q. v.
Iuramenti. Some other doctors says when he consents him unto an oath what
dread so ever he have if it be an oath the which may be done without mortal
sin and without losing of paradyse he is bound to accomplisshe ye said
oath. Also a man forswereth him by yt oath promising when he swereth that he
shall do or say any thing lefull the which is with solempnyte / albeit that he
do indyscretely and without necessyte yet ought he to keep it / or else he
synneth mortally if there be none excusacyon the which him excuses right
lefully as it is written.xxii. q. iiij. Si aliquod. Example that a doctor
accomplysshed not a vow like as he had made it lost his sight: lxiii. G. Also
a man forswereth him when he makes any oath that he shall do a thing lefull
the which is without solempnyte / as to swear by god I shall go to morrow unto
the church / or I shall fast / or I shall give atmesse / or to do any
semblable things. If such of propre delyberacyon do unto the contrary of his
promise when it is so that he may do it he is forsworn and sins mortally.
But if he has sworn to give alms and sone after he falls in to pouerte he
should be excused of perjury for ye necessyte. Also it behooves to make
dystynccyon of oaths quotydyens the which they make without solempnyte of
thing lefull by hastynes and lyghtnes of tongue and evil custom as many done
when they do swear they know not if they have sworn or not / when such oaths
ben made without delyberacion or dylectacyon / or consentement of reason they
venyall sins.xxv. di. c. Criminis. But when in swery^ge they apperceyue well
that they fail and repents them not and take pleasure therein such oaths
torneth them in to mortal sins. Vnde Augustinus.xxii. q. ij. Nequis. Nullum
peccatum a deo veniale quod non fiat criminale dum placet and ide^ si scientes
ducit in consuetudine^. No sin is venyell unto god but that it may be mortal
when it pleases him / and the same if if it be done wyllyngly in custom.

D. Four manners ben found in scripture that a sin the which of ye nature
is venyall may be transmuted and changed to be mortal. The first is when the
conscience Iugeth yt the oath is cursedly made and repents him not of the
said ill. Vn^ scriptura. Quicquid sit contra co^scie^tiam edificat in gehenna^.
What thing so ever be that is done against the conscience edyfyeth in the fire
of hell. The second is wha^ the conscience delyteth in it and takes pleasure
in the oath evil made as before is alleged. Nullu^ pctm^ a deo veniale. etc.
The third is by that / yt a man is fallen in delectacyon of venyall sins he
dysposeth hy^ often times to come unto mortal sins / whereof speaks saint
Gregory the which says. Vitasti gaudia / vide ne ebruaris arena. He says so
for that often times fro small sins men come in to great. In likewise as by a
little sparkle of fire there ryseth a great flambe. Whereof ye sage speaks in
his proverbs saying. Qui minima negligit paulatim decidit in maiora. He that
dyspreaseth the small things falls in to great. The fourth when yt venyall
sins ben not repelled comynly proceeds after the sins mortal. As it
appears in the first mouementes the which ben deputed among the venyall
sins when the delectacyon has conualescence in so much that the
consentement also approaches / so sourdeth incontinent mortal sin. Also the
accustomaunce to swear is dangerous for who so swereth often often him for
swereth / and who so often lies often synneth mortally. Therefore says the
holy Ysodore Vsus iurandi periuru^ ducit. The usage to swear makes
forswerynge. Et legitur hie remie.xiij. Si ethiops mutare po^t pellem suam et
pardus varietates suas: and vos poteritis benefacere cu^ didiceritis malu^. If
ye ethyopyen that is black might change his skyn^e / and the leoparde her
varyete^ yt is white and black / and ye may do well (...) likewise as ye have
learned and accustom ill. Also of little corns men may make^ great sum or
burden and lade an horse so much that he ne may bear it. Also of little venyall
sins men make great mortal sines the which ladeth and dampneth the pesones.
Vn^ mgr^ alanus. De minimis granis fit maxima su^ma cabali / de breuibus m^dis
non veniale malu^. So it appears th^^ the venyall sins and the accustomau^^
to swear ben to fle as it is said before.

A. The manners to blaspheme god / and that the blasphematours ben right cursed
and evil.xij.
IT is written eclesiastice.xxiij. ca. Vir multum iurans implebitur iniquitate
and non discedet a domo illius plaga. A man much swerynge as he the which
blasphemeth god / or the which forswereth him shall be replenysshed with
inyquyte and ye plage shall not depart from his house. To blaspheme god is a
right great sin and detestable the which a man commytteth in many manners.
First in gyuinge unto god any thing that apperteyneth not unto hy^ as to say
that god is a liar. Secondly wha^ a man takes from god that thing ye whi
apperteyneth unto him / as to say that he is not Just and good. Thyrdly when
man grants or gives unto any creature yt thing the which apperteyneth
unto god the creator / as to say such a man or such an ydoll is god. Or as
did ye servants of the king of Assyryens the which granted unto their
king that the which apperteyned unto god / for they said unto the king
Ezechyas. Which ben the gods of all the earth the which have power to
deliver their regyons from the hands of our king / there is none. And which
is the god that may deliver Iherusalem from his hand. etc. This blaspheme
dyspleased so much unto god that the angel of our lord stroke ye people of
the army of ye said king and slew an.C. lxxxv. M. as it is written in the.xix.
chapter of ye.iiij. book of kings. Fourthly when a man brings forth toward
god contumelous moeuynges to debate or strife. Vnde mathei.xii. Hic no^ ei cit
demones / nisi in beelzebub principe de monioru^. Et luce.xi. In beelzebub
principe demoniorum ei cit demonia. Some Jews said that they had found him
subuerty sy^ge the people / and defending to give the trybute unto caesar / and
they lied. Vn^ luce xxiij. Hunc inuenimus subuertante^ gente^ nostram et
prohibente^ tributa dari cesari. Also some wend for to have said Injury unto
him that he received the sinners and that he eat and drank with them. Vnde
luce.xv. Hic peccatores recipit et manducat and bibit cum illis. Also some said
that he was good / and other said that he was not good but that he seduced the
people in ill. Vnde John.vii. Quidam dicebant bonus est / alu dicebant non /
sed seducit turbas. Fyfthly in the swerynge cursedly / execrably / and
irreuerently as when any cursed crystyens ben angry anenst god / and by yt
manner of Injury and of vengeance swear by the virtue of god / by the blood /
by the guts / by the lunges / by the heart / by the fete / by the heed / the
eyes / the tethe / or any of his members. The person yt so swereth by
delectacyon and delyberacyon obstynatly if he be a clerk he ought to be
deposed / and if it be a lay man he ought to be excommunyed as it is
written.xxij. q. i. Si quis per capillum. We read that saint Poule thappostle
cursed some blasphemers. Of who^ were Hymeneus and Alexander whom he betoke
unto Satan to the end yt they should learn no more to blaspheme / as it is
written. thymo.i. ca. Also them the which swereth by the five wounds of Ihesu
christ / or by his death / his passion / and his blood / such oaths and
swerynges ben to fle and to defend / for they often blaspheme / and do
irreuerence unto god and unto his passion of whom is proceeded our health. Vnde
crysostomus super matheu^. Oi^s salus hominum in christi morte posita est. All
ye health of men is put in the death of Ihesu christ. Also to blaspheme god is a
sin much to dread / for it makes the blasphemers ill in many manners.

B. First they ben wors than the Jews for the Jews crucyfyed our lord but
one time / but a christian man blasphemer crucyfyeth him and beteth him with his
tongue as many times as he swereth. Vnde apostolus ad heb. vi. Rursum
crucifigentes semet ipreos filium dei. Et aug. dicit super john. Flagellatus
est christus flagellis iudeorum / flagellatur blasphemijs falsorum

now sore scorged by ye blasphemes of false crystyens. Also saint Austyn says

Vnde august. illud mathei.xxii. Blasphemauit. Non minus peccant qui deum

terris. Also in as much as they sin of very malice and science they offend

corint. Si cognouissent nunquam rege^ glory crucifixisse^t If the Jews had

xxi^ Pater dimitte illis non ei^ sciunt quid fac unt. But he prayed not for the

autem seruus qui cogn^uit voluntatem dn^i sui / and non se prepara^^ et non

A. Questyon if a man commytte sin at every time that he swereth.xiii.
NOn assumes nomen dei tui in vanu^. Upon this commandment a man may demand
if any may swear without committing sin. The answer A man may swear without
sin when necessyte is / the which is verytable / Just / lefull / and for
good end / as when a man swereth for to afferme Innocence when any cursed
crime is brought up / or for to conferme ye alyaunces of peace / or for to show
or persuade unto ye herers that the which is vtyle for ye health of their
souls. To swear for these things it is none evil sin. for it is necessary
and lefull. Albeit that the swerynge of it self is not good / and nevertheless
it is not ill when it is necessary / and yet it is not to appetyte as is the
good. More over it is not to fle as an ill thing wha^ it is lefull / but he
defends the appetyte / ye dylectacyon / and the accustomau^ce to swear
vaynely and vnlefully / as a thing idle / vain / and peruers. Saint Poule the
appostle knew the commandments of god / and nevertheless he swear as it is
written in his epystles. Vestis est michi deus. By that it is to understand
that swerynge is lefull and necessary when by the same a man thinks unto yt
welfare of his neighbor after the commandment of god the which says.
Diliges proximu^ tuu^ sicut teiprem. And the psalm. Dn^e quis habitabit in
tabernaculo tuo aut quis requiescat in monte sancto tuo. Lord who shall dwell
in thy tabernacle / or who shall rest in holy mountain. The answer. Qui jurat
proximo suo et non decepit eum. He ye which swereth unto his neighbor and
deceyueth him not shall mount in to heaven. etc. Also the angel yt saint Johan
saw standinge on the sea as it is written in the appocalyps. Teuauit manum sua^
ad celum and iurauit per viuente^ in secula seculorum. He lift up his hand and
swear by the lyuy^ge in ye worlds. Also our lord says in ye gospel Amen /
amen / dico vobis. Also we read yt our lord swear in the old testament.
Iurauit dn^o et no^ penitebit eu^. and again. Iurauit dn^s vitate^. etc. Our
lord swear true yet he commanded in ye old law. Read dn^o iurame^ta tua.
etc. Yield thyn oaths to our lord. By these foresaid auctorytees a man may
swear without syn^e at a need. And for yt god says in the gospel that our word
should be / it is so / it is not so. Math^. v. Sit au^t sermo vr^ est / est /
no^ / no^ / quoth autem his abunda^tius malo est. The answer yt ye affyrmacyon or
negacyon yt is in the heart ought to be in ye mouth / but for yt malice is so
grown yt they will not believe by sy^ple word / and therefore god has put to
prudently. Quod amplius est malo est. That the which is more than enough is
ill / not evil unto those the which swereth for the welfare of their
neighbor / but ill unto those the which ne will believe without swerynge / their
incrudylyte is sometime of pain and of culpe / and therefore he says not
malum. Ill unto him the which hy^ uses much in swerynge. But he says a malo
/ from the evil of him the which otherwise believes not / that is of his
syn^e ne departs from him the which is sometime pain / and sometime pain and
gylte / tha^ god defends the oath the which is ill. He commands to speak
well in saying. Sit sermo vester est / est / non / non. It is so / it is not
so / and he grants the swerynge the which is necessary. Also when a man will
not believe the truth but by swerynge / he the which swereth in good and Just
cause syn^eth not / but he should offend if he swear not. For it should befall
sometime yt a good man should lose his good and Just cause if veryte were not
approved by good men. And therefore says saint Austin. Quisqis meru cuiuscu^que
potestatis veritatem ocultatiram dei super se prouocat: quia magis timet
hominem quam deum. If any hyde veryte by the dread of puyssau^ce he provoke
the ire of god upon him / for he dredeth ye men more than god. In such wise to
swear by necessyte is no sin as it is said. Also albeit that god has
defended oaths inutyles / nevertheless by especyall he defe^deth the swerynges
the which ben made by the creatures to the^de that man ne do honor unto
creatures the which apperteyneth unto the creator. Ne honorifice^tia
creatoris transferetur ad creaturas. Or yt man believe not that any dyuyne
thing be in hy^ whereby reverence unto ought to be done. And therefore after yt
god had said in ye gos. ( tild). Mat. v. No^ iurare oi^no. Hastily (...)
puts after. Neque per celu^ qr thronus d^ est / neque per terra^ qr
scabellum pedu^ eius (...). neque per hiero solimam qr ciuitas est reg^magni
neque per caput tuu^ quia non pot^^vnum capillum tuu^ facere albu^ vel nigri.
Swear thou never above all thing / neither by the heaven for it is the throne
of g^^ne by the earth for it is the stole of his fe^ne by Iherusalem for it is
the cite of ye gr^te king / ne by thy heed for you can not ma^^ one of thy
heeres white ne black. Also (...) read yt saint James defended that no^ should
swear. An^ oi^a fr^es mei nolite ^^^re The gloss says yt he defends not sy^
swery^ge / but he defends the will to ^^re. And therefore he said vygyla^tly
(no^^ for the affection and will should not dra^^ us to swear / but the

terra^ / nec per quodcu^que aliud iuram^tu^iurare vetat. When need is to swear
