B. What is requysyte for to swear lefully without any sin.xiij.
Three things ben requysyte or yt a man swear without committing any sin.
That is to understand / veryte / judgment / and justice. Vnde Hieremye.iiij.
Iurabis viuit dominus in veritate et in iudicio and in iusticia. Et
habetur.xxii. q. i. Et iura bunt. If these these three things defayle or any of
them it is perjury / as it is written.xxii. q. ii. Animaduertendum. The first
thing the which is requysyte or yt a man may swear without sin is veryte in
the conscience / that is that a man know the thing steadfastly for to be so
as he it swereth. For who so should think one thing and swear another should
be perjured. Or who so should believe that any thing were true / and knows it
not too be all true for certain: he should swear of credence and not of veryte
/ for that should be against yt the which is said (iurabis viuit dn^s in
veritate). The second thing requysyte to swear well without any sin is that a
man should swear by dyscrete delyberacyon / ye which is in the party of reason
/ that is that a man should dyscerne if there were any necessyte to swear or
not. For albeit that a thing be true yet he should not swear if there ne were
necessyte. As who so should swear by our lady I am in the church. etc. Howbeit
that the oath be verytable yet is there sin / for there is no necessyte to
swear yt. Iurabis in iudicio. When a man swereth it behooves that he there have
good Judgment / that is dyscrete delyberacion as it is said / to dyscerne and
advise if the thing be requysyte and necessary for to swear / as when a man
warns or counceyleth to believe some good thing the which is expedyent and
prouffytable unto some slothful and peruers persons the which would not
believe by simple words and speech he may swear in calling god to witness
that in such wise he should be without offense in swerynge. Iurabis i^
iudicio. Also when a man swereth by good dyscrecyon it behooves to regard.vi.
things / that is qua^do / quale / cui / quomodo / vbi / et de quo. First it
behooves too regard (quando) in what time it is that a man swereth / for in
seculer causes nor in other a man ne should swear / ne constreyne to swear in
the solemn feestes / ne to hold Iurysdyccyon. Secondly (quale iuramentu^) /
what oath it is that a man swereth / for some of them or one of them ben
greter than another and more to dread. Thyrdly (cui): to whom it is yt a man
swereth / for a person of the church should not be coarted to swear to
seculer / ne in court seculer but in some case / for there might follow
irregalyte / as in case of crime. Fourthly (quomodo) how it is yt a man swereth
/ by what manner / by what delyberacyon / by what constraynte / and by what
hastynes / or necessyte. Fyfthly (vbi) where it is that a man swereth / in what
place / in holy place / or in place not holy / as in the church or church
yard. Syxtly (de quo) / of whom / of what thing it is that a man swereth /
of a thing good or ill / if it be of an ill thing a man should not swear. The
third thing the which is requysyte to swear lefull is to regard yt the
thing wherefore a man swereth be just lefull and to do good and accomplysshe /
for the oath the which is not just should not be acco^plysshed. And for yt
offended Herod for the oath yt he had made unto his daughter when he made
saint Johan baptyst to be heded. Vn^ Ysodo. Impia est promissio q^ scelere
adi^pletur. The promys is ill ye which is accomplysshed by syn^e / if the oath
have these three things before said a man may swear without sin.

C. That a man should accomplysshe ye vows Justly made. xiij
DAuyd ye prophet says. Vow ye lefully by devotion. And after that ye have
vowed so yield ye and accomplysshe ye said vow to your lord god. Vnde daujd
in psalmo. Vouete and reddite dn^o deo vestro. And note well that after yt he
has said (vouete) there follows incontinent reddite). In this second
commandment god defends that a man ne break the vows the which has be
made Justly / and lefully by delyberacyon and by Just cause. They ye which
accomplyssheth them not and leueth them / and the which does unto the
contrary of that / yt they have vowed and promised / or the which them despise
takes the name of god in vain and does unto him irreuerence and unto his
saints. And they should understand that they be^ charged and bound to
accomplysshe the^ / or else they commyt mortal sin. Ysodorus dicit. Multum
deo reus eris si no^ reddas quid voueris / deo displicent qui vota sua non
i^plent. That is to say. Thou shall be much culpable unto god if thou yield
not / that is if thou accomplysshe not that yt thou have vowed. Those the
which acco^plysshe not their vows dyspleaseth unto god. Example of a woman
the which vowed chastyte and after would be married. Quere in thexamplarye of
the second commandment.lxiij. E. Also it is better done not to vow than
not to hold ye promysses after yt the vow is made. Vn^ eccl. v. Multoque
melius est no^ vouere quam post votu^ promissa no^ reddere. Et Ysodo. dicit.
Melius est eni^ non promittere quam fide promissio^is non soluere. That is to
say. Better is not to promise than not to pay the faith of ye promise. Also
it is great Ieopardy to tarry to accomplysshe the vow after it is made if a man
has time and space to accomplysshe it. Vnde deuteron^.xxiij. Cu^ votu^ voueris
dn^o deo tuo non tardabis reddere: qua requiret illud dn^s deus tuus et si
moratus fueris reputabitur tibi in peccatu^. That is to say thou ne shalt
tarry to yield unto thy lord god when thou have vowed a vow for thy lord god
shall require it of the / and if thou have made taryenge to accomplysshe it
unto the it shall be reputed in sin. And it is wryte^ ecclesiastes.v. Si quid
deo vouisti ne moreris reddere displicet enim i^fidelis et stulta promisso. If
you haste vowed any thing unto god ne tarry thou to yield promise / unfaithful
and folysshe promise him dyspleaseth. Example that it is a great peril to
deffer to acco^plysshe his vow. Quere in ye examplary.lxiij. H. Many other
examples of vows there shall be found and cete. Also a man should note that
those the which accomplyssheth their vow ben in the love and grace of god.
For they shows them self loyal and faithful in there promysses / and god
unto them accords in there prayers and oraisons. Example that Anne vowed unto
god that if he would send her a sone that she should give hy^ unto the service
of god all his life / she conceived Samuel the which was a prophet and
acco^plysshed her vow as it is written.i. regu^.i. ca. Another example yt the
king Aza acco^plysshed ye vow yt he made of his fader and bare him to gods
house: as it is written.ii. paral.xv. Another example yt after that ye children
of Ysrael had vyctory of Holofernes they yede to worship god in Iherusalem /
and al they kept their vows and promesses / as it is written. Judith.xvi. ca.

D. What thing is a vow how is it dyffynyed. Vow is concepcyon of ye best
purpose of delyberacion of steadfast courage to god or unto his saints with
ente^cyon him to oblege. Vnde secundu^ magistru^ in quarto di.xxxviii. and tho.
et alios theologos. Quoth votum est co^ceptio spontanea melioris propositi animi
deliberatione deo vel sa^ctis eius firmita cum intention se obligandi. And it
is to be noted that many things ben requysyte unto lefull vow and
accomplysshed the which ben touched in the said dyffynicion. First it is
requysyte concepcyon of some made in the entendement by the holy ghost.
Secondly it is requysyte that the vow be not ill. And therefore the dyffynycyon
says (melioris). Ill and sin desordoneth us toward god. Vnde legitur. Quoth
votum non est vinculu^ iniquitatis. Vow is not the lain and bond of inyquyte.
And therefore it is written. Dissolve vinculu^ iniquitatis. Unbind or louse the
lain of inyquyte. Et legitur.xxxij. q.iiij. Ysodo. In malis promissis resci^de
fide^ / in turpi voto mutu decretum / quod incaute vouisti no^ facias / impia
est promissio que scelere adimpletur. In cursed words rescyndeth ye faith
change thy will in that vow the which is foul and evil / do not the thing
ye which you have vowed unwisely. The promysse is evil the which is done and
accomplysshed by sin. Example written in the.xxiij. chapter of the deeds of
the appostles that.xl. Jews vowed that they should neither eete ne drink till
they had slain saint Poule / their vow was evil and in sin / and they
might not accomplysshe it. etc. Thyrdly it is requysyte yt he there have
concepcyon fre in as much as ye dyffynycyon says (spontanea) / that is that
every man may vow the things ye which ben in his lyberte and in his right
and not otherwise / and therefore servants / children / relygyous prisoners.
etc. in some things may not vow. Quia non sunt sui iuris. Fourthly it is
requisyte that he there have delyberacyon and therefore the dyffynycyon says /
animi deliberatione) unto the dyfference of those the which voweth suddenly
without delyberacyon and consentement of reason. Fyfthly vow ought to be made
unto god or to his saints and not unto men for many things the which abides
because of shortenes. Syxtely with entencyon to bind him for love bears
oblygacyon to do some thing or to love it. etc.

E. Vow the which is lefully made of right ought too be accomplysshed as it
is said / but in.ix. manners a man is not bound to accomplysshe his vow. The
first is when any has vowed under condycycyon as to say. I shall do such a
thing if such one have his health / or if he live not or if he deye not of
such a sekenes / when the condycyon has none effect a man is not bound to
accomplysshe ye said vow. The second is when it has be made suddenly and
without delyberacyon. The third is ye vow of them the which has lost their
wit / or ye which ben furyous. The fourth is when by infyrmyte / pouerte /
or other lefull lettynge a man may accomplysshe the said vow. The fyfth is
wha^ a man voweth by ire / or other passion so great yt they leave true
delyberacyon. The.vi. when it should be to the hurt of any great good or common
welfare. The vij. is when ye vower is subgect to another as young people / a
maid under.xiij. year / a man child under.xv. years / a relygious a wedded
woman / a servant if the vow should be lettynge of the service that he owes
when the souerayns beforesayd ben not so content / or gaynsayeth there unto ye
subgectes ben not bound to their vows

of saint Johan in the floode of Iourdayn Nono / on the sunday our lord made
his first miracle to change the water in to wine at the wedding. etc. Decimo
/ on ye sunday our lord Ihesu christ fed five thousand men with five loves
of breed / and with two fysshes. Vndecimo / on the sunday our lord Ihesu was
honored with palms the which is the sunday before Eester day. Duodecimo /
on the sunday the redemptoure of the world rose from death to life.
Terciodecimo / on the sunday the holy ghost descended upon the appostles the
day of penthecost or whyt-sonday. Quartodecimo / the clerks presupposes that
god shall hold his Judgment on the sunday / but for certain no person
knows any thing but all mighty god only. By these things beforesayd it
appears that the sunday is establysshed for to be kept / sanctyfyed /
honored / and laudably feested among all the pryncypall festes. Vnde
secundumius canonicum. Co^stat diem dominicu^ inter summas et precipuas
festiuitates contineri. and dicitur in decreto. In dominica die nichil est
agendum nisi soli deo vocandum. de consecratione distinctione. tercie. Ieiunia.
No thing is to be done on the sunday / but to be besyed toward god / him
for to honor and his glorious saints. And by this the which is before
written. Sabbata sanctifes). A man should understand that in the ancient
testament men kept and sanctified the saterdaye. But for the mysteryes
beforesayd the which has been done on the sunday / and to the end that we do
not as the Jews does the which keeps the sa-saterday we shall keep and
solempnyse the solempnyte the day of the sunday. Examples of diverse people
the which has wrought on the sunday. And first of a man the which wrought
on the sunday and his hands claue unto the wood. Quere in the
examplary.lxiiij. C. Another example of a man the which led hay on the
sunday and he was thretened dyuinely to be brent Quere in thexa^plary.lxiiij.
D. Another example of two women the which baked on the saturday after ye son
going down / and one of them became dry / and the pele of the oven cloue to
the hands of the other. Quere.lxiiij. G. Another example of a mowyer the
which left work on the saterdaye / and his felawes would not do so: and he
found some gold. Quere in the examplary.liiij. M. Secondly it is good reason
to sanctyfy the festes of god and of the glorious vyrgyn Mary for the mysteries
of their solempnytees the which should be long for to declare by the which
our redempcyon has been made. Thyrdly master Wyllyam of Anserre techeth.vi.
reasons in the sum of the office wherefore it was establysshed that we make
solempnyte of the saints of paradyse. The first is for the honor of the
dyuyne mageste / for when we do honor unto saints we honor god in his
saints / and we say yt he is meruaylous in them. He the which does honor
unto saints he honors specially him the which them has sanctyfyed. The
second for to have aid in our humayne fragylyte / for we ben so frail unto
sin that by our self we may not have health / and for as much as we have
need of the help and prayers of saints we do them honor in their feestes to
the end yt we may deserve their help. The third is for the encreasynge of our
suerte / for by the honor that is done unto saints in their solempnytees
our hope and suerte is increased so yt the mortal men semblable to us may be
in such wise raised in so great honor by their merytes / it is certain yt
so it it may be of us / for the power of god is not lessed. The fourth is for
the example of our following / for when ye feestes of the saints is recorded
every year we be^ called to follow them / so that by thexample of them we
dysprayse the things erthly and desire the celestyalles. The fyfth is for that
that the aungelles and saints of paradyse have Joy and exaltacyon when we the
which ben sinners convert us unto god. Vnde luce.xv. Gaudiu^ erit in celo
super vno peccatore penitentia^ agente. etc. And therefore it is reason sith yt
they make feast of us in heaven yt we make feast of the^ in earth. The syxte is
for the procuracyon of our honor / for when we honor ye saints we procure
our honor / their sole^pnyte is our dygnyte / when we honor our brother we
honor our self. Charity makes all thing to be common / and our things ben
celestyalles / erthly / and pardurables.

C. Questyon / who so should demand at what hour a man should begin to
celebre the feestes. The answer / regulerly men say that from the one
euensonge unto ye other euensonge the church makes solempnyte. It is written
extra de ferus and de consecratione distinctione.i. capitulo. Missas. Om^es
dies dominicos a vespera in vesperam cum omni veneratione decreuimus obseruari.
We have decrete to keep in all honor all the days of the sondayes from ye one
euensonge unto the other euensonge. For to cease on them for to do any work
and for to make holy ye feestes a man should consider the qualyte / and the
quantyte of the feast / what ye custom is of the regyon / and of the place
where a man is. And after the gretenes of the feast and custom of the place a
man should more sooner begin / and the more late for to make an end In
likewise as says the scripture in many places. Vnde quamuis scriptu^ sit a
vespera in vesperam celebrabitis sabbata vestra verumtamen initium festorum and
finis iuxta eorum qualitatem et regionum consuetudines seruari debent / and
sicut magnitudo eorum exigit prios incipere / et tardius terminati extra.e.
quoniam. This scripture repreueth the folly of some simple men the which
reputeth not to be sin to labor and work late on the saturday at night /
and weneth that it is sin to work erly on the monday in the morning. Of
this matter thou shall find many examples in the examplary.

D. Questyon / who so should demand wherefore is it that men make holy / and
honor some feestes more solempnely in some countrees than they of other
countrees done / or that some feestes in some bishop riches ben kept of whom
no mencyon is made in other countrees. Unto that it behooves to answer that a
man ought for to do after the custom of the regyon where as he is. For it is
written extra de ferrijs Quoth in festis celebrandis vel non / vel quis dicatur
esse festiuus vel non consuetudo regionis debet obseruare. Dicendum est etiam
cum hieronymo quod vnaqueque proui^cia abu^dat in suo sensu.
distinctione.lxxvii. Vtinam in omni tempore ieiunare possemus. Et augustinus
interroganti. Respo^. Ambrosius. Cum romam venio ieiuno sabbato / cum
mediolanum sum non ieiunio sabbato / sic et tu quamcunque forte ecclesiam
veneris eius mora serua si cuiquam no^ vis esse in sca^dalum nec quemquam tibi.
One and every prince haboundeth in his being. And therefore if thou come to
Rome and that they fast there on the saterdaye fast thou also in like wise as
they done. And if they have in custom to keep or sanctyfy any feast keep it
with them. And if thou aryue in any church keep their customs the which ben
not against god / or else they shall sclaunder the.

A. How in six manners men sanctyfye the feestes commanded / the which manners
shall be put by psalms / and some ben necessaryes for the sanctyfycacyon of
those feestes / and the other ben cerymonyalles for the augmentacion of god and
of virtues.xv.
First men sanctyfy the feestes commanded by abstynence / and to cease to do
operacions erthly and seculers / as to goo to the plough. Exodi vicesimo Non
facies omne opus in eo. And it is to the end that we cease and refrain the
auaryce and couetyse of the world / and for to take heed and entende unto the
vtylyte and prouffyte of the souls. If on the workinge days we take heed for
the labor of the bodies god will that on the holy days commanded we entende
unto the vtylyte of the souls. At the beginning of the world god created
spyrytuall things as aungelles / and corporal things as ye beestes and the
birds / and of these two things together he made man / that is of a thing
spyrytuall as the soul / and of a thing corporal as the body. In likewise we
have need of two refeccyons. That is of the refeccyon of the body the which we
do get on the werkynge days / and of the refeccyon of the soul the which we
seche on the holy days. How be it that every day we ought for to give
refeccyon unto the soul. For it is written in the gospelles how that a man
lives not only by etynge of breed for to mayntene ye body / but in every
word the which proceeds from the mouth of god / whereby the soul is
refeccyoned. Vnde Mathei. iiii. capitulo. Non i^ solo pane viuit homo / sed in
omni verbo quod procedit ab ore dei. And therefore god has ordained werkynge
days to labor on all holy to nourysshe the body. And also commands to
cease of operacyons worldly on the holy days for to sanctyfy them and for to
nouryssh the soul as before is said. Deuteronomie.v. Obserua diem sabbati vt
sanctifices deum / sex diebus operaberis et facies omnia opera tua / septimus
dies non facies in eo quicquam operis. etc.

B. A questyon to understand if a man may work on the holy day without
committing mortal sin. The answer. We find in writing that in four manners
some may do work on the holy day without committing mortal sin. Prima est
propter operis vel laboris modicitatem Secunda est propter temporis
necessitate^. Tercia propter cordis pietatem. Quarta est propter publicam
vtilitatem. The first is when a man does so little thing that the rest of the
thought ne may be let toward god / that is anenst the sanctyfycacyon of the
solempnyte it be not dymynysshed or lessed / as to hew a logge ye which is in
the court for to dress the dinner and not to lose the service. But who that
should do so great operacyon that the rest the which is commanded in the
said feast. Sabbati sanctifices were pertourbed and let should do mortal
sin / in likewise as says the gloss upon this word ye which is. Exodi
xxxi. Qui polluerit sabbatu^. Glosa. Turba^do quietem anime morte moriatur /
scilicet anime and corporis. Ex quo patet quod solum ille labor qui turbat
quietem and spiritus libertatem causat peccatum mortale. The second is for the
necessyte of labor ye which is in way of perdycion in such manner that a man
ne may defer it / or provide for the impetuosyte of ye rain time of August /
or for the great cold in ye time of winter. etc. When a man presupposes of
the perdycyon of the said labor the necessyte may be so great that a man
should be excused of mortal sin. Quia necessitas no^ habet legem / si malum
sequitur potestea de. con. distinc. i. Sicut etiam patet extra de
consuetudine.ca. iiii. A sure thing it should be to do by thexample of his
curate or prelate of the church. For it is written prouerbioru^.xi. and.xxiiij.
Quoth salus erit vbi sunt multa consilia. Health shall be where as ben many
counceyles or counceylers. To the which thing a man should understand that
the church may dyspence in these things here by one reason ye which is that
the church ne uses alonely of the puyssaunce humayne also as the reason
supposes / but also of the puyssaunce dyuyne. And therefore the church
dyspenceth by that puyssaunce in the commandment dyuyne that god has given.
Of the which thing it appears that who so dyspyseth the puyssaunce of the
church or the keys of the church he dyspyseth the puyssaunce of god. Vnde
luce.x. Qui vos audit me audit / et qui vos spernit me spernit. He ye which
hereth you hereth me / and he ye which dysprayseth you dysprayseth me. The
third is for pity / for in some feestes determined the church promytteth
without mortal sin that men labor for the love of god to help unto the
poor people / but so that it be the after mass and without hope of
retrybucyon. etc. The fourth is for to think and to aid on the necessyte of
the common welthe / as after the mass to help or repair a bridge / or an
evil passage / or a church dystroyed / and semblable things / so that a man
do it without coueryse of lucre or winning. Also it is well for to be noted
that it is extra de ferijs / that al be it that the sunday and many feestes
that been under ben commanded for to be kept How be it when the herynges also
enclyne them toward the lands in ye season that they ought to be fysshed a
man may fysshe for them on the sondayes and other holy days for the necessyte
of the common wealth So that they of that thing that they take they dystribute
and give unto ye poor chyrches and other good places by and over the dysme.

C. How a man should take heed to here the service and predycacyons on the
festes commanded.xv.
SEcondly for to sanctyfy the festes a man should go by devotion unto the
church to here the service the which therein is done. As mass / matyns / and
euensonge. etc. And for to here to deuyse of the feestes / of the fastings and
command me^tes the which there ben made. Also for to here ye predycacyons
and words of salvation / of the which proceeds all benedyccyon as it is
written Luce.xi. Beati qi audiuut verbum dei / et custodiunt illud. Blyssed be
they the which hereth the word of god and keeps it. In likewise as it is
declared more largely in the fyfth condycyon that the pilgrim of paradyse
should have.xlv. F. Many sorts of peope there be the which sanctyfyeth not
the feestes for that they take no head to here the dyuyne service the which is
done in the church / and the predycacyons. Some there ben ye occupies them in
the mondanytees and pleasaunces temporalles when they should take heed to the
service of the church / such people does break this commandment. Example of
a rich man ye which fled the service and the predycacyons / and lepte on horse
back and yede unto the mondanitees when men ronge to mass on the holy days
commanded / and the devil took him and bare him away Quere in
thexa^plary.lxv. A. Also some will not cease them of worldly operacions the
which werketh when they should take heed unto the service / such people
synneth mortally. Example how that a woman was dyuynely punysshed for that that
she cercled and closed her field on the day of saint Johan baptyst when the
other were at mass. Quere lxiiij. B. Also some there ben the which takes
head to drink and to ete during ye masses and the seruyces of the church /
and such people sanctyfye not the feast commanded but if they have excusacyon
lefull Example that evil came unto a smyth the which took head to ete and to
drink when the other people besyed them unto ye service of the church.. Quere
in the examplary.lxvii. C. Another example of a man the which went to play
and to drink at ye tavern with his felawes when he should have be at the
service of the church / and at last he was dampened. Quere.lxvii. D. Another
example that evil came unto a man named Vado the which went unto the tauernes
to drink and to ete when he should goo unto the church / and after his death
he had a foul drynk. Quere in thex. lxvii. E. Also some there ben the which
takes head to play on the feestes commanded when they should be at the
service / such people offends gretely. For they sanctyfy not the feestes and
dysobeyeth unto god. And also many times they commytte many sins in playenge
/ the which ben operacyons / not of sanctyfycacyon / but of dampnacyon.
Example that the heed of a sweter was found that that was before was behind /
and the cattes cried upon his grave. Quere in thexamplarye.lxiii. C. Other
examples there ben written in thexamplary of the second commandment of people
unto whom there came evil in playenge and blasphemyng. etc. Also some there
be the which slepeth in their beds or in the church when the dyuyne service
and predycacions ben in doing on the feestes commanded / such people
sanctyfyeth not the feestes. For the commandment of god says. Thou ought for
to dyspose ye to serve god all the sondayes and the feestes. Example how the
devil gave hot pytche unto a monk for to drink as he slept in doing the
service of the church. Quere in thexamplary.lxvi. C. Another example how the
devil smote a monk with the knotte of a straw as he slept in the service
time.lxvi. b. Other examples of these matters ben written in the examplary of ye
third commandment. Also some gone not to here the service and predycacyons
by slouthe / neclygence / and indeuocyon / and such people sanctyfyeth not
well the feestes. The realm of heaven is not promised unto iedeous / neglyge^t
/ and slouthful persons / but unto them the which wy^^eth to take heed upon
commandments of god / and the which them accomplyssheth virtuously. Vnde
scriptura. Non enim te pidis and negligentibus promittitur regnum celorum / sed
in mandaris domini vigilantibus atque strennue opera^tibus. Also note well in
especyall of the heedes of an house the which leseth the mass on the sunday
or on a feast solempnell by slouthe without excusacyon leful.. If reason were
dysposed to it such slouthe should be mortal sin / and breketh this
commandment / whereof it is written de consecratione distinctione.i. capitu.
Missas. And if a person that is chyefe of an house were three days without
going unto his mass perochial of his church and if he had not excusacyon
lefull he should be excomunycate in lykewyas he puts in a decretall. And
they the which keeps the house and the children that they perysshe not while
the other ben at the mass on the sunday and feast solemnell / if they ben
excused in serving god ye day of ye said solemn feast. The answer is such
/ that if they have excusacyon not for to be at the church corporally for to
serve god / where if they ben not they ben excused so that they serve god
within ye house in saying the good things that they can For the commandment
of god speaks unto every man and woman. And to serve god you sholdest dyspose
ye every sunday and the other holy days commanded in what place so ever it
be. Example of a maiden servant the which desired for to goo unto the mass
and unto the prechy^ge and her maystresse would not suffer her but our lord
appeared unto her unto whom he showed her health. Quere in the
examplary.lxxxxix. B.

D. And they the which ben enoyed to do well / and dyspyseth to say well and
to here it. As they the which leueth the congregacyon of the church / the
service / the mass / and the sermon without lefull excusacion for to go unto
the vanytees / as dau^ces / plays / tolyes / and dysportes / they ought for
to be excommunyed / as it is written De consecratione distictione.i. capitu. Qui
die solempni pretermisse ecclesie conuentu ad spectacula vadit exco^municetur.
etc. Of the which thing it follows that they sin mortally / for
excommunycacyon should not be given but for mortal sin Quia excommunicatio
non nisi pro mortali culpa infligi debet. Vt habetur.xi. question.iii. capi.
Nemo episcoporum. Those ye which ben of the party of god with good will they
here his service / and his word / and the opposytes it dyspyseth. Vnde
ioha^nis.x. Oues me vocem meam audiunt and ego cognosco eos / et cognosco me
me / et ego vitam eternal do eis et non peribunt in eternum / et non rapiet
eas quisquam de manu mea. My sheep those ben the good persons herynge my voice
/ and I know them and mine know me / and I unto them shall give the life
eternal / and they shall not perysshe / and none shall take them fro my hand.
Example that it has well taken unto many for herynge the word of god.
Quere.lv. A. B. C. And it follows after. Alias oues habeo qui non sunt ex hoc
ouili. etc. Other sheep I have the which ben not of this flock / those ben
the cursed persons the which have not wylled to here the word of god. And it
is written in an other gospel that on the day of Judgment god shall put his
sheep on the right hand Vnde Mathei.xxv. Oues suas statuet a dextris / hedos
autem et sinistris. And he shall put the kyddes or gotes on the lift hand the
which have despised his word he them has compared unto a kydde or got the
which is a be stynkynge / foul and unclean / whereof the company is
nothing worth. Also they ben compared to an ape the which sleeth the church
and loves gladly the tavern / for to go unto the church he halteth / and
toward the tavern he renneth. Also he loves better a quarte of wine than a
potell of holy water. Also these people the which ben enoyed to do well
resembles unto the devil in three propryetees. Primo the devil will never do
no good deed. Secundo he will never here no good. Tercio he perturbeth and
lets them the which would do any good deed. Example how the devil enemy
unto mankind gave in charge to a woman four things / of the the which the
one was that she should trouble and let those the which were in devotion and
prayers in the church / ye second was that she should not confess her. etc.
Quere in thexa^.lxv. F In likewise does these cursed people the which ben
slouthful to serve our lord god on the holy days and to do good ye which
gooth from the mass and will here no good thing and bring other in to
vanytees and out of the church / the which is a token of evil. Quia sicut
signum euidentissimum electorum est audire verbum dei ita signum euide^tissimum
reproborum est nole audire. etc. And also it is a token right euydent of the
chosen to here the word of god. In likewise it is a token right euydent of the
reproved to have no will to here it. Example of a monk that the devil drew
out of the church when the other waked in prayer. Quere in the examplary.lxv.
g. The good servants of god hereth with good will his service / his word /
and his commandments: and takes the co^dycyon of the pilgrim of paradyse.
Quere post.xlv. A. B. And god them shall reward in the Joys of paradyse in
likewise as it is written after.lvii. A. The cursed servants the which will
not go to here the service and to sanctyfy the feestes in likewise as it unto
them is commanded should dread to be sent unto the fire of hell the which is
a tourment right cruel. Quere.xlix. B.

A. How a man should take heed to serve god and his saints on the feestes
commanded.xvi.
THyrdly for to sanctyfye the feestes a man should serve god and his saints
with heart / with mouth / and operacyon. Saint Poule says in the.xvi. chapter
of ye second epistle to the corynthyens. In oi^bus exhibeamus nosmetipsos
sicut dei ministros. Show we our self in all things as the mynysters of god.
Et alibi seruire deo regnare est. To serve god it is too reygne with him. Every
good christian man should enforce him to serve god on the holy days after his
science and faculte / and should put him in devotion and orayson for to give
praysynges unto god and unto his saints / as Dauyd the which said. Semper
laus eius more meo. The clerks should sy^ge with heart / with mouth / and
operacyon for to serve god. Vnde ecclesiast. xxxix. In omni cord et ore
collaudate et benedicite nomen domini. Praise ye and bliss ye the name of our
lord in all your heart and mouth Also a man should serve humbly and reverently
unto the priest in things ye which unto him ben necessaryes / as to give him
the water / to torn the book / to bear ye paxe to light and to put out the
candell. etc. Dauyd says. Seruite domino in timore and exultate ei cu^
trimore. Serve ye unto god and unto his vycars in dread. To serve god in dread
is the beginning of wisdom. Vnde prouerbiorum.i. Initium sapientie timor
domini. Also the good and diligent servants have evermore the advantage /
and of good as well in this world as in the other / and they ben beloved of god
and of great lords before the slothful. Whereof speaks the wise man.
Prouerbiorum.xxii Vidisti virum velocem coram regibus stabit / nec erit coram
ignobiles. Et prouerbio rum.xxi. Cogitationes robusti su^t semper in abundancia
/ omnis autem piger in egestate est. The thoughts of a man boystous and
coueytous ben ever in habundaunce of goods / and all slothful people ben in
need and in pouerte. All the good servants shall be in paradyse with god
much honored and praised. Vnde in euangelium. Si quis michi ministrauerit
honorificabit eum pater meus qui est in celis.

Item euangilium. Volo pater vt vbi ego su^ illic sit et minister meus. Ihesu
christ says I will fader where as I am that my mynister be / that is that his
servants be with him parteners in his realm and his glory. Of the
servants the which ben good and faithful / and of those ye which ben evil
and unfaithful is somewhat spoken in the chapter of Sacrylege. Quere.xxx. C.
Also god called the good persons swetely his servants. Vnde Mathei.xi.
Venite me ad oe^s qui laboratis et onerati estis et ego reficiam vos. Also god
unto them shall give a great reward. Vn^ mat. xxv. Euge serve bone et fidelis
/ quia super pauca fuisti fidelis / supra multa te constitua^ intra i^ gauduim
domini tui. Good servant and faithful enjoy the / for that thou have ben
faithful upon a little thing I shall ordeyne the upon a great thing / enter
in to the Joy of thy lord. For to make short every person should enforce
him to serve and honor god and his saints each after as his science and
faculte is. And also should take heed unto the vtylyte of their friends and
they shall have great reward in the realm of paradyse. Of the which is
written toward the end of this present treatise.xlvii. A.

B. How a man should besy him in prayer on the feestes commanded.xvi.
FOurthly for to sanctyfye the feestes or holy days we should pray to god in
orayson and say all the good things that we can more besyly than on ye
werkynge days. Saint Austyn says quod oration est oranti presidium aduersario
ince^dium / angelis solacium / deo gratum sacrificium. Orayson or prayer is
defense unto him that prays against all evil / unto the devil aduersarye.
Joy and solace unto aungelles. sacryfyce unto god much agreeable. That orayson
keeps a person from all evil it appeared by thexample of a woman the which
would have hanged her self by dyspayre / and as she apparayled ye cord in
herynge a bell ring unto the sacrynge she went on her knees in orayson and
incontinent the temptacyo^ ceased and she was delivered. Also on ye feestes
commanded we should think on the euylles yt we have done on the werkyng days
/ and we should repent us and hertely cry god mercy / and put our self in
orayson for to require of him myserycorde. etc. Wherefore is it that god will
that we require him orayson. For four things pryncypally. First to the end
that we reknowlege him to be our god / lord / and master / creatoure / and
benefactour / the which for us has made and created all things. Vnde.
iohannis.i. appoc. Adorate eum qui fecit celum and terram mare et omnia que in
eis su^t. Et psalm. Quoniam deus magnus dominus et rex magnus super om^es deos.
It is good reason that a person worship and pray unto his god / lord / and
benefactour in reknowlegynge the good that he unto us has done. Secondly god
will that we him require in orayson to the end that we repute us to be his
servants and obedyentes unto hy^ It is reason that a servant obey unto his
master / serve / honor / and pray him. For as much as Lucyfer would not be
as a servant in praynge god but enpryded hy^ of the good yt his god unto him
had given in so much that he would have sytten by him and have been semblable
unto him. Vn^ ysaie xiiij. Sedebo in mo^ te testame^ti in lateribus aquilonis
ascenda^ super altitudine^ nubiu^ similis ero altissimo. And for yt he would
not pray god / ne reknowlege to obey unto him but would show himself as
master / so he lost all the good that he had and is now the foulest devil in
hell. And therefore we should pray unto god and confound the sin of pride
in us / in showing us to be his servants obedyent unto him. Thyrdly our
lord will that we require him in orayson in knowlegynge our poor fraylte as
of our self we may nothing do / and that all comes and proceeds of god.
Vnde iohannis primo. Omnia per ipsum facta sunt et sine ipso factum est nichil.
Item Iohannis.xv. Sine me nichil potestis facere. For to understand well when
we require one of the saints of paradyse that we may have health of our
sickness / it is not the saint of him self that heleth us / but it is god /
and the saint that ye do require prays unto god for you / and god heleth you
in exalting the request and intercessyon of the said saint. In likewise all
the good puyssau^ce that all the saints of paradyse have god it unto them
has given. And therefore we should pray god in orayson in reknowlegynge our
fragylyte that of our self we may nothing do / and that all proceeds of
him. Fourthely god will that we him require in orayson for too do him honor.
For orayson is a sacryfyce the which is much agreeable unto god. Also the
encense the which is put within the fire casts a good odor and a smoke the
which mounteth on heyght unto god. In like manner orayson enbrased upon the
coals of devotion casts a smoke and a sweet odoure the which mounteth up
before god / the which unto him is much agreeable. And therefore says the
psalmyst. Dirigatur domine oration mea sicut incensum in conspectu tuo. We read
thobie duodecimo. That Thobye was much devout the which occupied him self to
do the works of mercy. And on a time the angel of god appeared unto him unto
whom he said. When thou prayest god in orayson with teeres / and when thou
buryest the deed bodies I present thyn orayson before god. Also we read. Actuum
decimo / how Cornelius was on a time about the hour of noone in orayson the
which made his request unto god. And incontinent an angel of god in lykenes
of a fair young man clothed in white appeared unto hy^ unto whom he said. Thyn
orayson is exalted / and thyn almesdedes ben remembered before god. We ought for
to serve god in orayson for to do him honor and sacryfyce the which unto
hy^ is agreabled / and unto us vtyle and prouffytable. Also as a noble man
should do honor unto the king on his knees the which is called homage / in
reknowlegynge that he holds his sygnourye of him / and that he is servant
obeyssaunte unto him. In likewise we ought to do to god in orayson. Or in
likewise as the servant is bound for to serve his master / in semblable
manner ben we bound unto god the which is our master. Or in likewise as every
man should bear and pay his rent and his trybute unto the lord of whom he
holds. In like manner should we do honor unto god of our bodies and of our
goods unto our power.

C. A questyon / how should a man make orayson unto god for to have that the
which is necessary. Answer. Him behooves to say his pater noster / for he
requires of god that all euylles and sins ben put away and that he have
unto body and unto soul al goods temporalles and spyrytualles the which ben
necessaryes and vtyles / Our lord made the pater noster and said unto his
dyscyples that they should say it when they would pray unto almighty god In
likewise as it is written in ye gospelles Mathey sexto / et Luce vndecimo.

Here after follows the orayson domynycall or pater noster the which our
lord taught to his dyscyples / and the requests and fruytfull petycyons
contained in the same.
Our fader that art in heaven sanctified be thy name thy kingdom come to us /
thy will be done in earth as in heaven / our daily bread give us to day and
forgive us our debt as we forgive our detts. and led us not in to te^ptaco^n.
but deliver us from evil. ame^

The requests that a man makes unto god in saying the pater noster.
THe petycyon of Sanctificetur nomen tuum takes away pride and puts in us
the virtue of humylyte / and requires the gift of dread / and the beatytude of
the gospel. Beati pauperes spu^. And the reward follows. Quoniam ipreo rum
est regnum celorum. The petycyon of Adueniat regnum tuu^ takes away envy / and
puts in us the virtue of charity / and it requires the gift of pity / and
the beatytude of the gospel. Beati mites. And the reward follows. Quoniam
ipsi possidebunt terram. The petycyon of Fiat voluntas tua sicut in celo and in
terra takes away ire and puts in us the virtue of pacyence / and requires
the gift of science / and the beatytude of the gospel. Beati pacifici. And
the reward follows. Quoniam filij dei vocabuntur. The petycyon of Panem
nostrum cotidianum da nobis hodie takes away slouthe / and puts in us ye
virtue of dylygence / and requires the gift of strength and the beatytude of
the gospel Beati qui esuriunt et sitiunt iusticia^. And the reward follows.
Quoniam ipsi saturabuntur. The petycyon of Et dimitte nobis debita nostra sicut
et nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris takes away auaryce / and puts in us
the virtue of largess / and requires the gift of counceyle / and the
beatytude of the gospel. Beati misericordes And the reward follows. Quoniam
ipsi misericordiam consequentur. The petycyon of Et ne nos inducas in
temptatione^ takes away glotony / and puts in us the virtue of abstynence
/ and requires ye gift of entendement / and the beatytude of the gospel.
Beati mundo cord. And the reward follows. Quoniam ipsi deum videbunt. The
petycyon of sed libera nos a malo takes away lechery / and puts in us the
virtue of chastyte / and requires ye gift of sapyence / and the beatytude of
the gospel. Beati qui lugent. And the reward follows. Quoniam ipsi
conselabu^tur.

A. How a man should yield graces and thanks unto god of the good and welthe
the which he unto us has done with out being unkind.xvii.
FYfthly for to sanctyfy the feestes we should goo unto the church on the said
days of ye feestes for to yield thanks and praysynges unto god for the great
goodnesses that he unto has done the which ben so many and great that it is
so Impossyble as unto us that we ne may yield nor give them again in any
thing that we may do. And every man ought for too understand that god unto
him has done more good and benefayte than he is worthy / ne than he has
deserved. Saint Barnarde says. Agamus fratres gratias factori nostro /
benefactori nostro / redemptori nostro. My brother yield we graces unto him the
which has made us / that is unto god our fader celestyall Vnde mathei.
xxiii. Vnus est pater vester qui est in celis. The which has created our
souls of nothing unto his symytude. Vnde gene.ix. Ad ymaginem quippe dei
factus est homo. And the psalmyst. Ipse fecit nos and no^ ipse nos. Yield we
graces unto our benefactour that is unto god the which makes the corns and
the fruytes to grow and to come / and all that whereof we live. Vnde johan.i.
Omni per ipsum facta sunt / et sine ipso factum est nichil. Yield we graces
unto our redemptour / that is unto the sone of god the which is borne of the
vyrgyn Mary the which has suffered death and passion for too redeem us from
hell where we should have descended Vnde ad gal.ii. Dilexit me tradidit semet
ipsu^ pro me nesim ingratus de gratie. God has given the thy body with all thy
members. He gives the thyn eyes to see / thyn eeres to here / thy fete to go.
etc. If thou had not sight ne herynge thou should not know what good it is
to here and too se. And if he give the light thou should thank him all thy
life / he the grants now sight and heringe and al thy members for nothing
without thy merytes. Moreover he gives the nourysshement / vestement house /
field / corns / oxen / kyen / sheep / and bestyall. Vnde paulus in epistola
and co. Quid habes quod non accepisti. What good have you of thyn own that
thou ne have first taken of another: when thou was borne thou brought nothing
with the / ye goods comes not of the / thou reknowlegest not the goods here
/ and so thou thankest not god. Saint Austyn says in the book de ciuitate
dei. Quisquis beneficia dei non vidit cecus est / nec laudat ingratus est /
qisquis in lauda^do reluctatur insanus est. He the which sees not the
benefaytes yt god unto him has done he is blind / and if he praise not god
he is unkind / and the which is worse he is not hole. He is seek ye which
impugneth god with his gifts / and uses of those gifts against the honor
of god and against his propre health / that is to understand wha^ he makes
folysshe lokes with his eyes / when he brings forth cursed words with his
mouth / and so of other members / or when he mysuseth the goods / that is to
understand when he takes clothes proud and pompous / when he eteth
excessyuely / when he drynketh unto dronkenesse / and so of other. And as often
times as any abuses in such wise ye gifts of god after true Justice / he
should be put from that gift / that is to understand from the sight or the
herynge. etc. And it is all for his unkindness. Vnde Bernardus super canti.
Ingratitudo inimica est anime / exmanictio meritorium virtutu^ dispersio /
benefactoru^ perditio. Such a man ye which is so unkind is indygne and
unworthy to take many gifts of god. Vnde bernardus. Non est dignus da^dis qui
no^ agit gratias de datis. That man is not worthy to have things given unto
him the which yeldeth no thanks of the things given / a man may know it in
him self. If thou had done good unto a person by three or four times /
and that at every time he were to the unkind thou would cease to do any more
good unto him. What shall thou than say of god the which has done good unto
the more than a thousand times / and thou unto have be evermore unkind
without reknowlegynge ye good that he to the has done. Example that the.ix.
lazers that our lord heled were unkind for they went not to yield him thanks
after that they had health. He had heled x. but there was but one the which
reknoweleged the good that he unto him had done / the which returned him to
yield thanks. Vnde. luce.xvii. Nonne dece^ mu^dati sunt / et nouem vbi sunt /
non est inue^tus qui reddiret et daret gloriam dei / nisi hic alienigena.
Another example how ye man unto whom the lord pardoned ten thousa^de talentes
was unkind for he ne would pardon the small debte / and for his unkindness he
was betaken to the hangman and put in prysone. Quere.xxvii. H. Another example
contrary of a knight the which pardoned him that had slain his fader / and
god pardoned him all his sins. Quere.xxvii. I. The scryptures us warns to
yield graces and praysynges unto god for to fle unkindness. Vn^ pau. i. ad
thessal. v. In omnibus gratias agite. Yield thanks unto god in all the things
yt ye do. Et ad colloscenses.iij. Omne quod cu^que facitis in verbo aut in
opere oi^a in nomine dn^i nostri jesus christi facite gratias agentes deo et
patri periprem. In every thing what so ever ye do in word or in operacyon /
do all things in the name of our lord Ihesu christ in yeldynge thanks unto
god. etc. Et legitur.i. ad corin.x. Sieve manducatis / sieve aliquid aliud
facitis omi^a in gloriam dei facite. Do ye all things in the glory of god if
ye ete or if ye drink / or if ye do any other thing. All the aungelles and
saints of heaven loves god / and yeldeth him graces of his benefaytes / and so
should we do. Vnde apo. vii. Vide hostium appertum in celo / dicit btu^s
ioha^nes ecce turba magna qua^ dinumerare vt nemo poterat. etc. Saint Johan
says in the apocalypse that he saw the door open in heaven / and so great
turbes of holy persons that no man might nombre them / and they cried with hye
voice. Salute unto our lord god the which sytteth upon the throne /
benedyccion / clerenes / and sapyence and accion of graces / honor / virtue /
and force unto our lord god in secula seculoru^. Ame^ Also all the creatures
gives praise unto the creatoure. That is to understand the beestes and the
serpents / the birds ye kings / the princes / the Iuges / the vyrgyns / the
ancient with the young prayseth the name of our lord / for his only name is
exalted. Vnde psalm. Bestie et vniuersa pecora: serpents et volucres pennate.
Reges terre et omnes populi: principes et om^es iudices terre. Iuuenes et
virgins senes cu^ innioribus laudent nomen dn^i: quia exalta tum est nomen
eius solius. Iteru^ psalmus. A solis ortu vsque ad occasum laudabile nomen
domini.

B. Example of a good child the which yielded graces and praysynges unto god in
all aduersytees that came to him. We find by writing that a child was so
perfyte that he said deo gracias in all things. And it be befell so that
after that his fader and his mother were departed men of war came unto his
house / the which tasted of a tonne of eygre sydre / the which a none they
brake and shed the said sydre / and when the child saw that he said. I yield
graces unto god I drank eygresydre / and now I shall well drink good water.
After that the men of arms brake his house and warmed them with the tymbre.
And when the foresaid child saw that he said Deo gracias. I yield graces unto
god. I was wont in fore times to be lodged in this great house: and now I
shall make me a little lodge and therein I shall abide. And the said men of war
yode in to his gardyn and brake and pulled up all the herbs as cooles / lekes /
borage / onyons / percely / letuse. etc. Than the child said again deo
gracias / ye have broken ye lekes and other herbs I yield graces unto god / it
me behooves to take wild leaves of the feldes / and to go and frye them with a
little pot of butter yt ye have left in such a corner. And when ye men of
war saw that they had done so much harm unto the said children said
unto themself / we ben right cursed the which have done so much harm to
this child the which is not wroth ne never evil word unto us he has said
/ and unto us does the best that he may in doing good against evil. For to
make short they repented them and converted them unto good by his example.

E. To wake in contemplacyon and to do the works of mercy at the feestes
commanded.xvii.
SYxtely to keep the feestes gardables or that been to be kept a man should
employe the time waking in operacyons spyrytualles / as to occupye himself in
the life contemplatyue the which belongs unto the dyseccyon of god / that is
to serve / to honor / and to worship him as it is said. And to think on
things celestyalles and spyrytualles to mount on heyght with god and his
saints / and to reygne with them eternally in the Joys of paradysethe which
ben so great yt they ben infynyte and inenarrables. This life contemplatyue
unto us is given in figure of the blyssed Mawdeleyne the which set her often
at the foot of our savior and redemptour Ihesus and herd his word as it is
written. Luce.xi. Sedens secus pedes domini audiebat verba illius. Another
example of the contemplacion of two relygyouses the which were fro crystmas
till mydsomer speaking of god without enoyenge them / and they wend to have been
there but two hours. Quere.lxxxxiiii. b. And after that the soul has taken
her refeccyon and the body his nourysshement it is good after dinner on the said
days of the feestes to take heed also to ye dyleccyon of his neighbors
indygentes and nedy / as to give alms to vesyte the seek / to counceyle the^
that lack counceyle / to comfort them that been heavy / sorrowful and seek /
and also to do all other works of mercy. This life actyue is given unto us by
figure in Mary marthe hostess of our blyssed savior and redemptour Ihesu
christ the which prepared him his meet and took head unto ye works of mercy
the which is the life actyue Also by this Marthe is understand ye devotion by
the which we ben acco^panyed by charity with our neighbor. And by Mary
magdaleyne is understand the intencyon relygyous of ye thought. The life
actyue gives the breed corporell unto hy^ the which has ho^gre / and
doctrine unto the ygnouraunt and unlearned. It correcketh the sinner errant /
and calls again the proud man unto humylyte. Also it mynystreth unto every
one yt the which is unto him expedyent. The life contemplatyue reteyneth the
charity of god and of his neighbor / but it rests it of the accyon
wtoutforth / and at the only desire of the conductour to Join so unto him.
And all hertes erthly fouled and put under foot is embraced to se the face of
the creator and desires to meddle / that is to be with the cytezyns of the hye
regyon enioyenge them in the beholdynge of god of the incorrupcyon eternal.
The life actyue unto the perturbacions of the world. The life contemplatyue
the which extends to god is most sure. And therefore our lord said to
Martha. Illud luce.x. Martha martha solicita es et turbaris erga plurima: maria
optima^ parte^ elegit que non auferetur ab ea.

D. How the reverence and sanctyfycacion of al holy things is brought in this
third commandment.xvii.
Saint Ysodore says in his book. Secundum dignitate^ read cuique honore^.
Yield honor unto every man after his dygnyte. Many things ben holy whereunto
we owe honor / for their sanctyfycacyon is contained under this
commandment. Sabbata sanctifices. Of yt which holy things we shall tell
four. First the time of the days of the feestes commanded should be
sanctyfyed in likewise as is before declared. Secondly a man should bear honor
and reverence unto the holy places / as unto the chyrches. Vn^ psalm. Domu^ tua^
decet sanctitudo. And of good right a man should honor the chyrches / for they
ben the places the which ben blyssed / the holy service is done therein / the
body of our savior is therein consecrate / the which there rests night and
day in the custode. Also in the church we ben baptized / confessed / purged /
and made clean of al our sins. Also we ben thither borne after yt we ben
dysceased and deed. It is the house of orayson in the which we make our prayers
and oraysons / and there ben made the good predycacyons. Also the church is
the saufgarde of the crymynalles and for banysshed people. It is the place
whereto they run the which them keeps from death / from evil and punycyon.
Also in ye church and in ye chyrcheyarde ben the holy bodies of our faders /
and moders / and friends departed and deed. And for these things here with
that / that god it will the holy places ought to be honored. Example of
hateful men the which slew a man in ye church were punysshed dyuynely.
Quere.lxxix. B. Another example how heliodorus was punysshed dyuynely in ye
church as he took the treasours.lxxxii. B. Many other examples ben written in
the third commandment of ye examplary how evil came unto them the which
have not borne honor unto the holy places / as unto the church and
chyrcheyarde / and how people accursed should not be buried there lxii. G. Our
blyssed sauyoure and redemer Ihesu christ showed right clearly yt he would that
the church be honored and reverenced when he put out the sellers and buyers
the which there made their marchau^dyses and seculer occupacyons / he showed
that it dyspleased him / for he did make a whyppe with the which he chased
them out rygorously / them and their oxen and kyen / and marchaundyse / and
kest and over threw their stalles unto the earth / and unto them he said. My
house shall be called ye house of prayer / and ye have made it a pyt or den
of thieves. Vnde mathei.i. Domus mea domus orationis vocabitur / vos autem
fecistis illam speluncam latronum. Sith that our lord said that they made a
den unto thieves / it follows well ye thieves were there within. Also a man
may say that those the which there makes such marchaundyse and negocyacyons
seculers ben thieves / or the which is wors they ben sacryleges / in as much
as they soil and hurt the place sanctyfyed and holy / the which is a
dependence the which proceeds of sacrylege. Sacrum ledens: sacru^ violans et
deturpans. This thing here was the most gretest rygoure that ever our lord
showed in this world / wherefore it behouth to say that it is great sin and
that there a man should not speak of taxes of process of detraccyon / of laws
and exaccyons / nor of any thing seculer. Again many persons the which does
the contrary / and the which gooth unto the church on the days of the said
holy feestes for to speak and to treat of such things more than for to pray
unto almighty god. The blyssed saint Austyn them repreueth the which says. In
oratorie nemo aliqid agat nisi ad quod factum est vnde and nome^ accepit. No
man ne does any thing in ye oratory but that thing whereunto it is made /
whereof it bears his name. The oratory is not made to do ne say the seculer
things beforesayd / but it is made to pray unto god / and for to do and to
say things salutaryes / the which ben of sanctyfycacyon. The collectours of
taxes and sergeauntes or other the which ben charged to puruey unto the
things seculers should go in to place profane not hallowed out of ye church
and chyrcheyarde / and there to provoke and to bring those with whom they
have besynes when they have long matters seculers to treat / for euyte sin
and offense of the holy place. For in spekyng of such matters there aryseth
sometime noyses and cursed words in aggreuaunt the sin for because of the
holy place / and it in less sin in unhallowed ground than in holy ground.
Also the gospel says that when two or three persons ben assembled in the name
of god for too speak good words yt god is in the myddle of them. Vnde
mathe.xviii. Vbi sunt duo vel tres congregatim nomine meo ibi sum in medio
eorum. Also a man may say that when two or three persons be^ assembled at the
church for to speak there evil words that the devil is in the myddle of
them / the which writes that / yt they speak. Example how saint Bryce saw
the devil the which wrote ye evil words that was spoken in the church.
Quere.lxv. E. Of this matter it is written in the decrete. Nemo debet in loco
orationis intendere fabulis ociosus. disti^ctio^e.xxv. Qui in aliud. No man
ought to take heed unto idle fables in the place of orayson. Et poeta dicit. Ve
vobis gentes in te^plo vana loquentes. Demone scribuntur / que in templo vana
loquntur. Maledyccyon unto you people speaking vain things in the temple /
the vain things ye which ben spoken in the church ben written by the devil
/ and those the which talks of vain things fableth with the devil. Vnde
poeta. In templo fari / diccum demone fabulari. Also after the right writing
men put out of the church people excommunyed the which ben not buried till yt
they ben assoyled and reabled. Also people the which ben homycydes and
manquellers of themself ne ben buried in holy ground / for that / that is
appears that they ben dampened. Also men find in scripture many examples how
the deuylles have unburied many cursed people out of the church and
chyrcheyarde. Quere in the examplary.lxix. B. By these things above said it
appears that every man and woman should bear honor and reverence unto the
holy places. Thyrdly a man should give honor and worship unto the bones and
relykes of the saints of paradyse. For since that god commands that their
feestes be sanctyfyed honored and kept for their holy and deuoutenes yt they
have led in this present life / it follows that he will that their bodies
the which have done ye good operacyons for his love be honored. The which
bodies shall be at the dredeful day of Judgment assembled and come again with
their souls / and shall live eternally in the Joys of paradyse with almighty
god. Legitur ecclesias.xliiij. Corpora sanctorum in pace sepulta sunt / et
viuent nomina eorum in generatione and generationem. Fourthly the
sanctyfycacyon of the seven holy sacraments is brought in this third
commandment / for we should bear unto them honor and reverence for yt they
ben holy. And for as much that the sy^ners by them ben purged and made clean
of the stynkynge ordure and fylth of sin and ben sanctyfyed and of the nombre
of saints of paradyse. In likewise as the time and places ben sanctyfyed /
also should the seven sacraments the which unto us be^ right necessaryes for
our health. Of these sacraments is spoken in the first commandment of god.
Quere.viij. B. And therefore it suffyseth of that the which is spoken unto
people of good entendeme^t and reason.

A. The manners how men break the feestes commanded.xviii.
IT is written Exodi.xxxi. ca. Qui polluerit sabbatum morte moriatur. Qui
fecerit in eo opus petibit anima illius de medio populi sui. Who polluteth or
soyleth the sunday / the feast commanded shall deye of death. The soul of
him the which thereon has wrought shall perysshe. The feestes ben evil kept
in many manners of ye which we shall say three generalles. The first is for to
do thereon operacyons worldly / manually / and by hand. And this also is
devised in many branches after the diverse sorts of people the which on the
days of ye feestes there done many operacions. First for to goo unto the
plough / or to mow / or to sow / or to make great works. Also the mysterys
of the persons the which does ye operacyons is defended as it is said.
exodi.xx. Non facies in eo opus. The feestes keep and honor / be thereon devout
and labor not. Evil comes unto them the which on them werketh. Example of
carle the which yode unto the plough on ye day of the feast commanded / and
ye wood claue unto his hand / and two years after was heled.lxiiij. F. Another
example of a woman the which wrought on ye day of saint Johan baptyst and she
was punysshed dyuynely Quere in the exampl. lxiiij. B. Secondly men break the
feast to carry on it / and to bear burdens in carts / or upon horses / for the
commandment of god says. From labor thou sholdest rest the / thy self /
thy household / and thy bestes. Vnde the remie.xvii. capitulo. Nolite pondera
portare in die sabbati et nolite eicere de domibus vestris in die sabbati et
omne opus no^ facietis in eo dicit dominus. Example of one of ye children of

the examplary.lxiiij. A. A questyon / if those the which bears corns unto
their lords on the days of the feestes offenden. A doctoure answers that
they ben not excused if other necessyte ne cause and constrayne them thereunto.
And more over the lords the which them commands or gives occasyon that to
do ben parteyners of their sins. And says afterward that they the which
bears lyuynges or vytayles far in to the country or marchaundyses and may
not do otherwise without great damage or hurt / such people ben excused as he
believes / so that they be first at the mass and at the service. And semblable
thing it is of pilgrims and vyagers. Example of a man the which bare wheet
in to his graunge or barn upon the day of the feast / and the said graunge
and wheet were brent. Quere in ye examplary.lxiiij. E. Thyrdly forgers or
smyths the which shoeth horse on the feast commanded by couetyse of winning
breketh the commandment of god. And if it be for to think on the necessyte
of pilgrims or vyagers they ben excused. Fourthly men break the feeste
commanded for to make thereon marchaundyses by auaryce and coueytyse of gain
without going to here mass and the service the church for to serve god and
to sanctyfy the feestes as done many merchants the which ben more waking
and erlyer risen on ye said festes for too run unto fayres and markettes than
they ne done on the workynge days Such people the which ne thinks but on
the goods temporal and leueth the gods spyrytuell sanctyfyeth not ne keeps
ye feast commanded / by ye which they syn^e mortally / and gone unto
da^pnacyon. But those the which after the mass and after the service bears
vytayles or other things necessaries for to sell / and the other the which
gooth thither for to bye their prouysyon of vytayles or other things
necessaryes may be excused. Quia necessitas no^ habet legem / nisi malu^ inde
sequeretur. de co^. di.i. Sicut. Necessite has no law / if evil should follow
after. Example of the bible how it is offense to do marchaundyse on the holy

cessandum est ab opere servile neque placitum fieri ad mortam vel penam
sanguinis. etc. Syxtely the feestes ben broken for to do operacyons on the
vygylles of the the said feestes / as those the which work the saterdaye at

examples in the examplary. Also all sorts of people of what vacacyon yt they
ben also should cease to do worldly operacyons the days of the feestes for to
restreyne avarice / for to take heed unto their sanctyfycacyon / and also for
to obey unto god And it seems yt those the which them breketh have lost the
mind of them / and therefore techyngly it is written. Meme^to vt diem sabbati
sa^ctifices. Remember the. etc. All beestes appetiteth ye rest after their
labor. Also after that all things vegetables have borne flower and fruit and
labored in somer they rest them in winter. Also after that god had labored to
co^pose and make the world he rested him on ye seventh day. But ye auarycyous
forgeteth the rest / they labor.vi. days for to nouryssh etheyr bodies /
and they labor the seventh day for the dampnacyon of their souls / and so
remembers of it. Also many people dare not work on the holy day for ye
sclaunder and language of people: but if they have in some places to work / or
with some persons to speak / or if they will borowe corn or silver. etc. Or
they will find to to win in marchau^dyse / to sell or to bye or if they will
find means for to aduau^tage them. Such people puts their term on the

the feestes / but breketh it. Also those the which does unto the contrary of
that thing that god the^ commands that is the which does operacyons on ye
said feestes by reason dysposed synneth mortally / and puts them from
paradyse as a man may se by many examples written in thexamplary. Quere.lxiiij.
A. B. C. Also these logycyens it preueth by reasons in form and arguments
thus. All they the which on the sondayes or feestes commanded go to ye
plough. etc to work dysobey this. Sabbata seti^fices / om^e opus. etc. The
sin mortally and by consequence they put them fro paradyse. For it is written
Mathei.xix. Si vis ad vitam ingredi serua mandata. Et psalm. dicit. Tu mandasti
mandata tua custodiri nimis. Vel sic. All mortal syn^e puts a man or a
woman from paradyse. For it is written Ezechiel. xviij. Anima que peccauerit
ipsa morietur. And they the which done ye great works on the feestes
commanded synneth mortally / for they dysobeye unto god / than they put
themself from paradyse. The solucyon is such. True it is that al mortal
sin / and al inobedyence puts from paradyse those the which in such
wise it trespasseth without penance. For it is written luce.xiij. Nisi
penite^ciam egeritis omnes simul peribitis. But those the which does penance
in their life and the which cease them of sin in obeyenge unto god. Iuxta
illd ysaie. Lauamini mu^di estote auferte malum cogitationum vestrarum ab
oculis meis quiescite agere perverse discite bn^facere. They shall have grace
and mercy and their sins shall be put in forgetfulness. Vnde ezechie.xviij. Si
autem impius egerit penitentiam ab omnibus peccatis suis. etc. Vita viuet et
non morietur omnium iniquitatum eius non recordabor etc. The second manner how
men breketh the feestes / is for to despise to go unto the service and to here
it / and the predycacio^s also as not to put him in devotion / and as not
taking head unto the health of his soul as is before declared. The third
manner general how men break the feestes is for to commytte the mortal sins
/ as dronkennesses / glotonyes / blasphemynges / lesy^ges / iniuryes / noyses /
stryues / murdres and so of other mortal sins. That is to say that at every
time that a man co^mytteth mortal sin on the feast commanded. It is not in
such wise sanctyfyed / but unto the contrary to dishonor by yt which it is
broken. Also the feestes ben often times broken by daunces unduly done / as
by pride / vanyte / or concupyscence carnal / or in the time of the service of
ye church / or in a place not conuenable / as ye church or the chyrcheyarde /
or with persons sclaundred / or when a person has not oportunyte to dance /
or when a man makes dyshonest signs / as to kiss / to wringe the fyngers /
to trede upon the foot. etc. Example of this matter of a maiden the which was
rauysshed in the dau^ce and after vyoled and hanged herself. Que. lviii. F.
Another example how the devil would have borne away a maid the which dau^ced
on the sunday. Quere.lxviij. C. Sith yt god defends on the feast to do none
operacyon vtyle as unto the body as to go unto the ploughe it follows well by
a more stronger reason that he defends operacyon evil and vnprouffytable as
to do lechery. If yt any went unto the plough on the sunday he should be
reputed ill / by more stronger reason he the which does lechery / for the
plough is a good operacyon of it self / ye which lechery is not: and therefore
men break the feast for to commyt on it deedly sin. They yt them have
offended let the^ be repentaunt in such wise to have offended god yt is full
of all goodness / and for fere to be sent to the fire of hell which a cruel
tourment as shall be declared here after.

A How those yt break the feestes ben punysshed ofttimes in this-worlde / and
they apperceyue not fro whens such punycyon proceeds. xix
THe prophet Ysaye says in the xvii. chapter of his book. Vniuersa mala
venerunt super te propter mltitudine^ malificioru^ tuoru^. All euyls shall come
on the for the multitude of thyn evil deeds. If you break any of the sondayes
or of the feestes commanded for to do any operacyons the which takes away
the sanctyfycacyons / or if thou dysobey unto any of the commandments of god
/ or if thou committee any mortal sin / be thou all in certain that thou
art bound unto pain and punycyon be it in this world or in the other. For
the psalmyst says. Iniusti punientur et alibi dicitur quia nullum malum
remanebit impunitum. The unjust shall be punysshed. Also all evil shall be
punysshed. And often times god punyssheth in this world those the which
breketh the feestes commanded by the same self operacyo^s that they do make
on the days of ye festes but they perceive not whereof the said punycyon
comes. Vnde Ysaie.xlvii.c. Veni et super te malum et nescies ortum eius et
irruet super te calamitas quam non poteris expirare / veniet super te repent
miseria quam nescies. etc. Evil shall come upon the / and thou shalt not can
tell whereof it shall proceed / and pouerte shall fall upon ye the which thou
may not avoid: and mysery that thou know not shall hastily come upon the.
etc. For to understand this matter it behooves to pertycularyse upon ye cases
the which happens. There ben some laborers the which gooth unto the
ploughe on the days of the feestes commanded for advance them and to enryche
in habundaunce of corns / and it dries sometime / when August comes their
corns ben full of drake / of deruell / and of myldewede / of stynkynge corn
or of other infeccyons. Who so should demand of ye said laborers whereof such
mysfortune or punycion comes / for their feldes has been well composted / well
sown with good sede / harowed and done in good season and fair wether. The
prophet Yasaie before alleged gives the answer in saying. Vniuersa mala
veneru^t super te. etc. vtsu. The said punycyon proceeds to you by adventure.
Nescio / deus scit. I can not tell / god knows for yt / yt ye made your said
corns on the feestes commanded. etc. Example of a punycyon the which came
upon ye corns of flies ye which devoured them / and in one of the wings of
the said flies there was written (ira) / and in the other wynge was written
(dei). That is to say the Ire of god the which was upon the people for their
sins.lxiiij. K. Vel sic. Thou labourer thou have in august good corns in thy
field / and do great dylygence the day of saint savior / or of saint
Laurence for to repe them / bind / and carry in to thy barn or peradventure
thou tythest evil ye said corn. etc. And for to punysshe ye of thy syn god
suffers that idle people as souldyers and hunters come upon thy ground and
devour and wast thy breed and thy corns with their hounds and horses. etc. Or
god shall send baylyfs / sheryfs / or comyssaryes yt which shall arest / take
/ or sell thy corn the which shall be given for naught / be it for taxes /
debtes / fortune or loss / and after thou shalt have honger or indygence.
Thou haste the eyes of thy soul blinded. Legitur in libro sapientie. Malicia
eorum excecauit eos. For thou co^syderest not that god the punyssheth for that
thou werkest and labourest to repe the said corn on the day of the feast
commanded. Vel sic. Or after that the said corn shall be ripe / reped /
bound / and engrau^ged the fire shall take within it / and enbrase it with
flambe and smoke till it be all burnt and consumed in to ashes. Veniet super
te maium et nescies ortum eius. vt supra. Example of a man the which carried
his corn on ye day of the feast / and the fire burnt all up. Quere in the

the feast there shall come so great drought that thy said corn ne may grow /

vestrum et recedatis a dn^o ira tusque dominus claudat celum et pluuie non

and if ye have despised my laws I shall vesyte you hastily in pouerte and

be devoured of enemies / I shall set my face against you. etc. Thou merchant

sanctifices) he shall permette that an evil thief or a knave shall by thy
marchau^dyse the which shall deceive and begyle ye and also shall not pay the

the in process and debate ye value of the debt / where god the would have sent
a good merchant the which should bye well and pay well / but he will not do
that unto the / but he will do it unto hy^ the which has sanctyfyed the
feestes. Also he the which will bye marchaundyse and leave the sanctyfycacyon
of the feast for to run thither is often times begyled and deceived by fraud
and falshede. For if he bye oxen / kyen / sheep / or horse they shall be
peradventure seek or deye of moreyne. etc. by the which he shall lose all
such thy^g and he shall not apperceyue that it unto him proceeds for the
evil sanctyfycacion of ye feast. Veniet super te malu^ and nescies ortu^ eius.
vt supra. Example in the bible how the sellers on the feast day were reproved
and made cease. Quere.lxiiii. n. Also crafty people and werkers with their

And also god unto them sends some sekenes / for the which they muse and may

B. Of slouthe that god defends.xix.
THe wise man says in his proverbs. O ye slothful people go unto the ampte
or pysmyre and consider his ways and learn wisdom / the which ampte
prepares his meet in somer / and assembleth in heruest that that he will eat
in winter. How be it that he ne has leder / ne co^maunder / ne prince. Vnde
prouerbioru^.vi. Vade ad formicam o piger and co^sidera vias eius: et disce
sapientiam que cum non habeat ducem / nec preceptorem: nec principem parat in
estate cibum sibi / et congregat in miss quod comedat. etc. That is to
understand Labor ye in somer / that is do good operacyons whiles that thou
art living / and that thou have the time / the place / and the oportunyte /
and assemble in the fair virtues to the end that in winter that is after thy
death thou have to eete / that is to be refeccyoned in the glory of god. Vnde
psalmista. Saciabor cu^ apparuerit gloria tua. The prophet Ysaie says that
the servants of god the which have well labored in this world shall have
to drink and to ete. That is they shall be refeccyoned with the glory of god /
and the cursed slothful persons shall have hongre and thyrste. Vnde
Ysaie.lxv. Ecce serui mei comedent et vos esurietis / ecce serui mei bibent et
vos sitietis. etc. Also the dampened shall cry. Illud Iheremie.viii. capitu.
Transsijt messis sinita est estas et nos saluati non sumus. The heruestis past
somer is ended and wene ben saved. Man reasonable it is defended the by this
commandment that thou be not slothful to go unto the service of the church
/ and to sanctyfy and keep ye festes in likewise as they ben commanded If thou
have ben heavy to sanctyfy them / or to do the good espyrytual the which is
dyuyne what good deed so ever it be unto the which thou were holden of
necessyte / that is to understand if by consenting of reason thy body has
domynacyon and lord ship of thy soul in such manner that it has in hate
and in dyspleasaunce the dyuyne goods / and that he has eschewed and left to
do it and to accomplysshe it in such wise as it was commanded. It is here
against charity and mortal sin. Quia accidia secundum sanctum thomam est
tristicia de spirituali bono in quantum est diuinum ad quod quis de necessitate
tenetur Slouthe is to have trystesse of spyrytuall goodness in as much as it is
dyuyne whereunto some is holden of necessyte. To tarry / to withdraw or to fle
the going to euensonge / mass / matyns / predycacyons / processyons and all
other seruyces. If he sancyfy not well and honor god and his saints in their
solempnitees. And by this ben reproved the slothful late comers / neglygentes
/ people not carynge / forgetefull / idle / weyke in spyryte / soft / tender /
ennoyfull / sluggardes / and dyffaylers / in so much that they ne will obey to
serve god and his saints after the commandment ye which unto them is
given. Example how that god reproved the idle people the which ne did no good
operacyon. Vnde mathei.xx. Quid hic statis tota die ociosi: ite in vineam meam.
Also those the which ben idle and slothful to go unto service of the
solempnytees ben to be reproved as these beforesayd. Legitur luc.xii. Ille
seruus qi cognouit voluntate^ dn^i sui / et no^ se preparauit: et non facit
scdm voluntate^ eius vapulabit mltis. That servant yt knows the will of his
master or lord and prepares not himself / ne does after his will shall be
much beten. Also they shall be sent in to the fire of hell. Whereof it is
written luce. iii et math. vii. Oi^s arbor que no^ facit fructu^ bonu^ excidetur
and in ignem mittetur. That is to say. Every tree / that is every person the
which ne makes good fruit that is good operacyons shall be cut and sent
into the fire of hell / whereof it is spoken after Quere.xlix. b. A tree the
which bears no fruit ne does but occupye ye earth wherein it is / and
therefore men cutteth it and brenneth it. In likewise shall the slothful be
the which does no good deed shall be taken out of this world and sent unto
the fire of hell / in the which they shall be co^streyned to abide eternally /
and so to hold the^ will they or not without ever to have aid ne socoures.

C. Example of a relygyous that would do no goodnesses. It is written in ye
dyalogue of saint Gregory of a friar the which came unto a relygyon more by
necessyte tha^ by will unto whom it was grefe wha^ men spoke unto him of his
