health / he ne would do ne here ye good / and to all goodness flouthfull he was
to do it. When he was seek and at ye death all his brethren came thither / and
as he labored at the last end he cried and said unto his bredren. Depart
you / go you he^s for I am given to a dragon for to devour me / yt which ne
may englout me for your presence / my heed is now plunged in his mouth / give
him place to swalowe me / and that he tourment me no more / and yt he do that
thing that he should do. If I be given unto him for to be devoured / wherefore
shall I suffer to tarry for you. Than ye bredren unto him said. Brother what
thing is that / yt thou spekest / make the token of the cross. He answered I
would make it but I may not for the scales of this dragon. Than his said
brethren fell flat unto the earth in orayson and weeping for ye aid and
delyueraunce of him / and by their prayers he was delivered. He thanked the^
and correcked himself / for he was no more slouthful but prompte and dylygent
unto all goodness / and after ended well his days / and if he had not
correcked himself he had be dampened and put from paradyse. Another example of
a man yt which was dampened for that he would do no good deed.

D. We find by writing how a holy man being in devotion herd by the
permyssyon dyuine the voice of a soul ye which cried horrybly alas / alas /
alas / and yt said holy man him demanded what he was / he answered I am a
soul dampened and he again demanded / what have thou done wherefore thou art
dampened. He answered for that / yt I was slothful to do good operacions /
said not the good that I knew / nor I yode not unto the church in time and
place / and and did not the good that I was holden to do / and therefore I am
dampened. By this example men should understand that it suffyseth not to
declyne from evil for to be saved / but with that it behooves to do good
deeds. Vnde psalmista. Declina a malo et fac bonum. The said man was not
dampened for the theftes / ne fornycacyons. etc. but for that yt he lost the
time of grace without doing of good deeds / and without confessyng hy^ and
after his death he might never confess him ne do good operacyons / for he
had lost ye time of grace / and also he was not in the place where he might
do it. Nichil preciosus tempore / sed heu hodie nichil vilius. Another example
of a priest the which tarried too mynyster the sacraments unto his parysshen
the which departed and deyed. This example is written here before in the first
commandment / quere.viii. c Dylygence is against the sin of slouthe for
good servants should be prompt and dylygent to serve god and his saints in
likewise as it is declared here before.xvi. A and they shall be praised / and
shall have great reward in likewise as it is written in the chapter of
sacrylege. Quere in ye.vi commandment.xxx. C.

A. Here follows the fourth commandment of god the which treats that we
should love our faders.xx.
Faders and moders thou shall honor
And them socoure in necessyte
To help thy neighbor in every hour
Be thou dylygent in all equity
THis commandment is written / Exo. xx. ca. Math. xix. and Marc. vii. Honora
patrem tuum et matrem tuam. Honor thy fader and thy mother or evil shall come
unto the / in likewise as it is comen unto many. Quere in thexam.lxx. b, d. And
it is written. Math. xxii. Et adroma. xiii. Diliges proximum tuum sicut teiprem
Thou shall love thy neighbor as thy self. in likewise as it is written here
before. quere.ii. f. g. h. For to declare this commandment it behooves to se
and know many things. And first.

B. Which ben the faders that we should honor.xx.
VEnerare patris. Honor thy faders. Four pryncypall faders there ben unto
whom honor is due. That is to understand. Our fader creator / he the which
has engendered us / the fader spyrytuall / and the fader temporal. The fader
first that we should honor is god the creator that we require every day in
our orayson domynycall. Pater noster qui. etc He is said our fader for he has
created our soul unto his likeness. Also he loves us as a good fader does
his children / and nouryssheth us with his gods that he makes to grow. He is
the fader the which nouryssheth / he purueyeth us to that the which is
necessary. Moreover he wylleth that we have heritage and possession in his
realm that is paradyse / and therefore we should love him fylyally / that is to
say chyldely / for we ben his children in likewise as says the holy
scripture. Vnde dd in psalm. Dn^s dixit ad me filius meus es tu. Et paulus dicit
ad thessal.v. Om^es enim vos filii lucis estis et filii dei non simus noctis
neque tene braru^. Et ad roma.viii. Quicu^que enim spu^ dei aguntur hi sunt
filij dei. Et. i. ioh. iii. ca. Videte qualem caritatem dedit nobis pater vt
filij dei nominemur et simus. etc. Et math. xxii. Simile est regnum celorum
hoi^ regi qui fecit nuptias filio suo. etc. God so much loves his children
that obeys unto him / and unto them gives so much goods in paradyse that
they ben decored as gods. Vnde legitur in biblia. Ego dixi dii estis et filij
excel si om^es. The second faders that we should honor ben the fader and
mother that us has engendered / borne loved / given souke / nourisshed / and
socoured / or they ben those the which has not engendered us but have the
charge to nourysshe us / to clothe and to hose and sho us / and to puruey
temporally and spyrytually / wherefore men say in common language / he is a fader
that nourissheth. Unto these faders here we ne may yield the good that they
unto us have done / whereof speaks the phylosophre in (nono ethicorum) where he
says. Magistris dominis et parentibus non potest reddi equiualens. After that
thou were borne thy fader and mother have borne yt tenderly between both their
arms / for thou was feeble without any strength for to help thy self. When
thou cried and yt thou unto them did harm and anoye they supported thyn
vnwysenesse and shrewednesse / and voluntaryly pardoned the. When thou befyled
the in thyn own ordure and sylthe they made the clean and served unto thy
necessyte. When thou had honger they gave the souke / and the good morcelle^
out of their own mouths for to nourysshe and feed the. They have taken much
pain and travail / and thought for the as well by night as by day / and have
put themself in great danger for too get the goods and herytages. etc. For
to make short thou can not restore to them the good the which they have
unto the done. And therefore says the sage. Ecclesiastice. vii. Honora patrem
tuum et gemitum matris tue non obliuiscaris memento qm^ nisi per ipsos non
fuisses. That is to say. Honor thy fader and forgete not the way lynge of thy
mother / remember that thou had not ben if they ne had been. Example of the
daughter the which forgate not her mother in necessyte / and nourisshed her in
a toure with the milk of her breasts Quere in the exampl.lxxi. C. By this
present commandment god wylleth and commands unto children that they do in
likewise unto their faders and moders with heart and mind / and with operacyo^
wha^ time and place it shall require / as the said faders unto them has done at
the beginning of their chyldehode as before is declared. Example how the two
sons of Noe Sem and Iaphet mocked not their fader as did Cham / and they ben
praised. Quere in thexamplary.lxx. C. Another example of sone the which would
not shote at his fader as his bredren did. Quere.lxxi. A. By the which a man
should understand that a good child loves his fader and may not endure that
a man unto him do any evil / neither at death nor at life. Another example of
the sone of Abraham. Quere.li. A. The third be^ our faders espyrytualles or
goostly the which have the puyssaunce of god to regenerate and to reform our
souls spyrytually by the admynystracyon of the holy sacraments of the holy
baptysme and penance. etc The which unto us ben necessaryes and prouffytables
as it is written in the before in the first commandment. Quere.viii. a. b. Of
the which the pope is heed and sovereign fader of all christian people / ye
which has the puyssaunce that god gave unto saint Peter. The which is
written. mathei. xvi. Tibi dabo claues regni celorum et quodcu^que ligaueris
super terram erit ligatu^ et in celis / et quodcu^que solueris super terram
erit solutum et in celis. After our holy fader the pope our spyrytuall faders
be^vycares the which have prelacion and puyssaunce under god and under him /
every of them in pertyculer in the country lymytted where his said prelacyon
exte^deth and not in other countrees. As every bishop is the fader spyrytuall
unto them of his bysshopryche / every curate unto his parysshens. etc. As men
say / here is my fader of confession / or goostly fader / or god fader etc.
Also every master of the scole is a fader of doctrine unto his scolers. And
every precher of them unto whom he precheth for to do things salutaryes.
Whereof saint Poule makes compte the which says. Illud. i. ad. corinth. v.
Ego per euangeliu^ genui vos. Unto every of these faders here we should bear
honor and reverence after his dygnyte / as says saint Ysodore Secu^dum
dignitatem read cuique honore^. And unto them we ought to obey in that / that
we have promised in baptysme. Also in yt / that god and the church us
commands and in things the which ben after god / for the health and salute
of our souls touching good manners / and to fle and eschew sin. The fourth
faders the which we should honor / ben the mighty prynces-lordes chyeftaynes
and masters ye which have domynacyon and puyssaunce seculer upon other. As a
king in his realm is fader / heed / and master of them of his said realm as
unto the secularyte / and he and hye officers have the government as unto the
Justice seculer. Also every duke and lord in his duchy and sygnourye. Also
every man the which is master of his house is the fader of the household of
those of his said house / as well children as servants and is called in
scripture (pater familias) fader of the household. Whereof we read in the
ancient testament that the servants of a lord named Naaman said unto their
master. Fader if the prophet has told the great thing certes thou sholdest
do it. Vnde.iiij. regum. v. Pater si re^ gra^dem dixisset tibi propheta: certe
facere debueras. He murmured against ye prophet He liscus. etc. Unto these
faders seculers here every man should bear honor and reverence by this
commandment when ye time the place / and the oportunyte it gives / and after
the dygnyte of every man. Vnde.i. petri. ii. Omnes honorate fraternitatem
diligite deu^ timete / regem honorificate. That is to say / honor all folk /
love fraternite / dread god / honor the king. And it behooves them to obey
unto things ye which touches the government of their realm or sygnourye in
god and after him for the health of souls / and not otherwise. Legitur mathei.
xxii. Reddite que sunt cesaris cesari / et que sunt dei deo. Yield unto caesar
the things the which ben due unto caesar and yield unto god that the which
apperteyneth unto him. That is to understand that men should yield unto the
temporal lord such honor and the thing the which unto him apperteyneth.
And for to yield unto god ye dute and magnyfycence ye which belongs unto his
soueraynte. And saint Peter says. Be ye subgectes unto all humayne creatures
for the love of god or unto the king also as unto the superlatyfe the which
is above the other / or unto the dukes as sent of the king unto the vengeance
of the evil / and unto the praysynge and laudacyon of the good. Vnde.i. petri.
ii. Subiecti estote om^i humane creature propter deum / sine regi quasi
precelenti: sieve ducibus tanquam ab eo missis ad vi^dictam malefactorum /
laudem vero bonorum. And how be it that our lord commands that a man
honor / serve / and love his faders it behooves for to understand as it is
said that god is the sovereign fader. Vnde mathei. xxiii. Vnus est pater vester
qui est in celis. Unto god apperteyne the sovereign honor / for what person
that honors / prayseth / loves / serves / or puts his hope or trust in
persons / as in princes more than in god he offends in likewise as it is
declared before in the first commandment. Quere.i. H. Moreover ye scryptures
says yt ye auncyente people ben our faders in aege. Vnde paul.i. ad thimo. v.
Seniore^ ne in crepaueris: sed obsecra vt patrem. Thou shalt not blaspheme the
ancient / but praise hy^ also as fader. And it is written. Leuiti. xix. Coram
cano capite surge et honora personam senis / et time dominum deum tuum. That is
to say. Arise thou before the balde heed / and honor the ancient person /
and dread thy lord god. The ancient has seen passed / and can / and knows
/ wherefore a man unto him should bear honor and reverence. And when the young
presumes to speak / to know / or to do any thing before the ancient men
they ben proud presumptuous / and ought gretely to be reproved. Also it is
written. Ecclesiastice.xxxii. In medio magnatorum loqui non presumas / et vbi
sunt senes non multa loquaris. Glosa. Si vis interrogatus fueris habeat caput
tuum responsum / et multis esto quasi inscius et auditacens simul et loquens /
et pro reuerentia accedet tibi bona gratia. That is to say. Presume not to
speak among the great / and where the auncientes ben speak but little. If thou
be questyoned two times than answer. And be thou in many things as not
knowing and harken in scylence. And sometime speak / and good grace shall come
to the for to do reverence. Also this word here (pater) the which is here of
the masculyne gendre is taken in.iiii. manners after Grecisme. Est pater hic
cura / pater est alius genitura. Est pater etate / pater ille vocatur honor.
Ad summum regem facit illa creatio patrem. The first after Grecisme is he the
which has the cure to baptyse / to confess / and to admynyster the
sacraments. The second fader is he the which has engendered. The third fader
is the ancient of aege ye which is called the fader of honor. The.iiii.
fader the which ought to be the first is ye creator sovereign king. Of these
faders before said many examples shall be found in the fourth commandment of
the examplary. Quere ad numerum.lxxi. A. B. C.

A. The manners how these children should love their faders. xxi
HOnora patrem tuum et matrem tuam. Honor thy fader and thy mother. After the
commandment of god a man should bear reverence unto his faders in many manners
/ of the which we shall tell.vii.

B. First a man should do honor unto his faders when he passes before them
/ or that he speaks unto them / or that he bow the knee / and uncover and
bow his heed in humylyte / dread / and love. This manner of doing is comune in
all honest persons and much praised. For it is written luce.xiiii. and
mathei.xxiii. Omnis qui se humiliat exaltabitur. All men the which hu^bleth
them and boweth down shall be exalted. The more that a tree is charged with
fruit / or an ere with corn / the more they bow down and enclyne toward ye
earth Also a person the more that he is replenisshed with virtues and with
grace / ye more gretely he humbles him. Vnde iacobi iiii. ca. Deus superbis
resistit / humilibus autem dat gratiam. God resists unto ye proud people /
and to ye humble he gives grace. Also the person the which boweth down and
humbles him more low than he ne should he offends not as to pass in at a
door. And if he raise himself higher than he should he hurts him self and
offends. Our lord had humylyte in all manners. That is to understand in his
natyuyte / and when he washed the fete of his dyscyples / and when he put
himself under saint Johan for to be baptized. etc. Vnde mathei.xi. Discite a
me quia mitis sum et humilis cord. Learn of me / that is take ye example of me
for I am soft and humble of heart. If our lord has so much bowed down and
humylyed him under his dyscyples as to wasshe to their fete / by a more greter
reason we should humble us and bow under our fader and mother. Also it is
written that every man dread his fader and mother. Vnde leuitice.xix. Vnusquisque
patrem suum et matrem suam t^meat. And when that any ne humbles hy^ and boweth
down before his faders when time and place it requires it is pride and gooth
against thiq commandment. Secondly a man does honor and pleasure unto his
faders when that a man speaks unto them sweet words / good and curteys /
simple and amyable unto god and unto them. Whereof speaks the sage
Ecclesiastice.xx. capitul. Sapiens i^ verbis amabilem se facit. And the sage
makes him amyable in words. Et legitur ecclesia.vi. Verbum dulce multiplicat
amicos / et inimicos mitigat. That is to say / swear words multyplyeth friends
/ and asswageth or lesseth ye enemies. And the phylosophre says in the.ix.
book of ethyques. The amyte of the good folk shall be increased by ye good
languages. Et legitur prouerbiorum xxv. Lingua mollis confringet duriciam
cordis. The soft tongue breketh the hardness of the heart Et legitur
prouerbiorum. xv. Respo^sio mollis trangit iram: sermoduris suscitat furorem.
Soft answer breketh ire / and hard words reyseth furour If thou speak sweet
words unto thy parents they ne may be wroth against the and also thou do
unto them honor. Example how Ysaac the sone of Abraham spoke sweet words
unto his fader when he would have made sacryfyce of hy^ and slain him.
Quere.li. A. Unto the contrary if thou blame them or speak rigorously thou
do unto them dishonor. Also to curse them thereof follows terryble
punycyon. Whereof it is written. Marci. vii. Honora patrem tuum et matrem tuam /
et qui maledixerit patri aut matri morte moriatur. Honor thy fader and thy
mother and he that has cursed his fader shall deye of death / and his light
shall be put out in ye myddle of derkenesses. Vnde prouerbioru^.xx. Qui
maledixerit patri suo vl matri sue extinguetur lumen eius in medus tenebris. We
read genesis.ix. capitul. that one of the sons of Noe named Cham mocked his
fader as he lay and slepte uncovered / and therefore his sone was cursed and is
reproved evil / he and all ye lygnage of him. etc. Example how.x. children
trembled by punycyon dyuyne for that they had offended their mother. Quere in
thexampl.lxxiii. E. Another example of a child yt ye devil bare away. Quere
in thexamplary.lxx. G.

B. Thyrdly men do unto them pleasure and honor when men love them naturally
in seeking and desiring their health and prosperyte corporal and spyrytuall.
Valerian says. Quod prima lex nature est amare parents. The first law of
nature is to love his kynnesmen and parents. And god commands illud.
Mathei.xxii. Diliges proximum tuum sicut te ipsum. Thou shall love thy
neighbor as thy self. The most nerest neighbor that thou have is thy fader
and thy mother / for thou art proceeded and comen of them. Love them than as thy
self in god / and after him and not otherwise. Example of a daughter that
nourysshed her mother in a prison with ye milk of her breasts / and by her
charity and love her mother was delivered the which should have deyed. Basilius
dicit / pare^tes nostros vt propria viscera diligamus si accedere nos ad
seruitutem christi non prohibuerint / si autem prohibueri^t ne sepulchra
illorum a nobis debentur aspici. Love we our pare^tes as our own bowelles if
they defend us not approach unto the seruytude of Ihesu christ / and if they
defend it us we should not behold their sepultures. Our lord Ihesus loved so
much his mother that he forgate her not at the hour of his death and
recommaunded her unto saint Johan ye euangelyst. Vnde john. xix. Dixit
discipulo / ecce matter tua. etc. And in deed the contrary when a child hates
his fader or his mother in requyrynge that they have an evil death or aduersyte
for to have their goods / honors / and herytages they ben right unnatural /
peruers / and evil wors than a be. Quia legitur ecclesiastice.xiii. Quod
omne animal diliget sibi simile. Eueri be loves his semblable. And of those
the which them tourmenteth it is written in this manner. Prouerbio.xxviii Qui
subtrahit aliquid a patre suo vel a matre et dicit hoc non est peccatum
particeps homicide est. And of those ye which them beteth it is written:
Exodi.xxi. Qui percusserit patrem suum aut matrem suam morte moriatur. He the
which smyteth his fader or his mother shall deye of death. Example of two sons
the which slew their fader. Quere.lxxii. D. Another example of a sone the
which dishonored his mother / and his children deyed shortly.lxx. E

E. Fourthly men do honor unto their parents when that wyllyngly and
benygnely they submyt them in their subieccyon and service to socour them in
their needs and necessytees corporalles and spyrytualles / whereof speaks saint
Peter.i. petri. ii. Serui subiecti estote in omni tempore dominis / non tantum
bonis and modestis sed etiam discolis hec est enim gratia. Be ye subgectes that been servants unto your lords and masters in all dread / and not alonely
unto the good and moderate / but unto the evil. And the sage says.
Ecclesiastice.iii. Qui timet deum honorat parents / et quasi dominus seruiret
his qui se genuerunt. etc. And here those that been proud should well
understand that their fader and mother them served swetely after that they
were borne / wherefore the children should humble them to serve them and honor
them. Also god them commands it. We read yt the good holy man Thobye
taught his sone that he should do service unto him / not alonely in his life /
but with that when he should be deed / and unto hy^ said. Illud thobie.iiij. Cum
acceperit deus animam meam corpus meum sepeli / et honorem prebebis matri tue
omnibus diebus tuis. When god has taken my soul bury my body / and thou shall
give honor unto thy mother al thy life. Also we read that our savior and
redemptour Ihesu christ humbled himself and put him under Joseph / and unto his
glorious mother the blyssed vyrgyn Mary / as it is written. Luce.ii Erat subditus
illis. Thou child wherefore seruest thou not thy fader and mother / and wherefore
shall thou not be in their subgeccyon. Art thou greter master than god the
which put himself under his parents and friends. Those the which ne will
serve and appetyteth that men them serve or those the which ne will be in
subgeccyen but appetyteth that other be subgectes unto them ben proud and
inobedyentes unto god their creator / wherefore it can not be well with them.
Example how a woman was blind for that she failed to goo to serve in the place
where the body of saint Martyn rested in likewise as she had vowed.
Quere.lxiii. H. Another example of a man the which served and did humble
things and fled vain glory.lxi. c.

F. Fyfthly a man does honor to his faders when that a man obeys unto the^
in things vtyles and lefull after god and good manners / and it is right
straytly commanded to obey unto fader and mother in the thing famylyer
prouffytable unto ye body or unto the soul. Whereof saint Poule speaks Ad
ephesi.vi. Filii obedite pare^tibus vestris in domino / hoc enim iustum est /
sequitur patres nolite ad iracundiam prouocare filios vestros. Faders provoke
ye not unto ire your children that they ne ben stryken of little courage. Sed
educate illos in disciplina et correctione domum. But led ye them in
dyscyplyne and in the correccyon of god. Also in eodem capitulo ad ephesi.vi.
Serui obedite dominis carnalibus cum timore et tremore et in simplicitate
cordis vestri sicut christo non ad oculum seruientes quasi hominibus place^tes
sed vt serui christi facientes voluntate^ dei. sequitur. and vos domini eadem
facite illis remitte^tes minas scientes quia illorum et vester dominus est in
celis et personarum acceptio non est apud deum. That is to say Ye that been
servants obey unto your lords carnalles with dread and fere and in ye
symplenes of your hertes in likewise as unto Ihesu christ / not as servants
with the eye also as pleasynge unto men / but also as the servants of Ihesu
christ in doing the will of god. And ye lords do ye unto them in likewise
forgyuynge al thretenynges in knowlegynge that your god and theyrs is in ye
heuens / and accepcyon of persons is not anenst god. Et legitur ad collos.iii.
Serui obedite per om^ia dominis carnalibus non adoculum seruientes / qua si
hominibus placentes sed in simplicitate cordis timentes dominum. A questyon
that is to understand if a man should obey unto his fader in all things. The
answer is that nay. A man should not obey unto them in things the which ben
against god as said the holy appostles when they were reproved for that / that
they kept not the commandments of the princes of the paynyms. They answered
to such reproues. Illud actuum.v. Obedire oportet magis deo quam hominibus. It
behooves to obey unto god more than unto men. In some things a man should
accomplysshe and obey unto his faders. Unto the prelate a man should obey in as
much as the right of his prelacyon thereto extends. The fader carnal has
prelacyon upon his children as in conseruacyon and keeping of ye house. The
fader of the household is in his house as the king in his realm. The subgectes
of the king owes unto him obedience in things the which apperteyneth unto
the government of the realm. Also in likewise the sons and the servants of
the household ben holden to obey unto ye fader of the house in things the
which apperteyneth unto the dyspences and costs of the household. The fader
owes unto his child correccyon and techynge / and ye children thereto should
obey humbly. As in other things the which should be against god they should
not obey. And when they unto them dysobey in such case they ne do unto them
none irreuerence: how be it that the appostle says. Ad colloscenses.iii. capi.
Obedite parentibus vestris per omnia / hoc est enim placitum domino. This word
here (omnia) intelligitur ad que se ius prelationis extendit et non aliter.
etc. That is to understand that a man should obey unto his parents in all
things where as ye right of their prelacyon extends / and not otherwise. For
if they commanded any thing the which were against god or good manners a man
should not obey as it is said. God wylleth and ordeyneth that we live in this
present world under obedyence / and we should clearly understand it. For as
soon as he had created and fourmed Adam he gave him commandment the which
he trespassed and transgressed and therefore he was punisshed / as it is written.
Genesis.ii. and.iii. Also we read in the book of Moses that if a child had be
stoborne and inobedyent unto his fader and mother that his said fader and mother
should led him unto the ancient men of the cite and that they wytnessed and
told unto them the sins of their said child and that he would not be
corrected by them ne by their admonycyon here follows ye punycyon of the said
child so inobedyent as it is written. Deuter.xxi. Tapidibus eu^ obruit pplus
ciuitatis and morietur vt auferatur malum de medio populi vestri / et vniuersus
israel audie^s pertimescat. Let the people of the cite cast stones at him and
let him be slain to the end that the evil be taken away from the mids of
the people and that all the people of Ysraell that shall here it be in dread.
Also we read that Absalon the ione of Dauyd made war and persecuted his said
fader and by punycion dyuyne he was hanged by ye here of his heed and had his
heart perced with four speres and was slain. Also relygyous people ought to
obey unto their prelates after the vow that they have made to keep relygyon
touching the rule and constytucyons of their monasterye / where if they go
unto the contrary they should be grievously punysshed. In things the which ben
not after god and good manners they should not obey. Saint Poule says ad
hebreos vltimo capitul. Obedite prepositis vestris vt subiacete eis / ipsi enim
peruigilant quasi ratione pro animabus vestris reddituri / vt cum gaudio hoc
faciunt et non gementes. Obey ye unto your prouostes / that is unto prelates
and be ye under them. Certainly they wake also as too yield reason for your
souls / to the end that they do that with Joy and not in wayly^ges. Also saint
Poule says / if there be any that will not obey unto our word by ye epystole
mark ye him and accompany ye not with him / to the end that he be confounded
Vnde.ii. ad thesall. iii. Si quis non obedierit verbo vestro per epistolam hunc
notate / and non co^misciamini cum eo vt confundatur. Also when these prelates
shows the health of souls as good doctrine a man should here them and learn
the good that they say / in likewise as if god it commanded from heaven. Vnde
luce decimo. Qui vos audit me audit / et qui vos spernit me spernit. He the
which hereth you hereth me / and he the which dyspreyseth you dispreyseth me
says our lord god. Also our lord says that a man should do that the
which the prelates ypocrites commands / and not to do their cursed sins
and operacyons Vnd mathei. xxiii. Super cathedram moi si sederunt scribe et
pharisei omnia quecu^que dixerunt vobis seruate et facite / secundum autem
opera eorum nolite racere / dicunt enim et non faciunt. Obedyence is the ladder
for to ascend in to heaven / and it is requysyte of necessyte of health. In
likewise as it is written in the beginning of the examplary where the examples
of obedyence ben written. Quere.li. A.

G. Syxtely a man does honor unto his parents and fader when a man helps
them by operacyon of body and of gods in their necessyte after their abylyte
and puyssaunce. Also it is written primo to hannes tercio. Filioli mei non
diligamus verbo neque lingua / sed opere et veritate. My children love we not
by word ne by tongue / but in wecke and in truth. Do unto thy fader and
unto thy mother in semblable manner as the have done unto the in thyn infancy
and chyldhode as it is said before. Quere before in this said commandment.xx.
B. And saint Ambrose recounteth in his book exameron in the fyfth chapter that
the birds the which ben called storkes puts their parents as fader and
mother when they ben fallen in aege into a nest and in deed them nouryssheth
and keeps duly and dylygently there / and if any of the said old fowls have
lost their feders by aege or otherwise / favorably and kyndely they cover
them and fail them not unto the time that they be deed. In ye the same manner
by greter reason naturally and of the commandment of almighty god we should
help / socour / and conforte our faders and moders and other pare^tes Be ye
not as the enfantes of serpents ye which byteth and renteth the womb of
their moders / and sleeth them. Example of a sone the which defaylled unto
fader and unto mother / and he bare a tode three years in his vysage. Que. lxx.
B. Another example of two daughters the which put out their fader in his age.
lxxiii.

H Seventhly men does honor unto their faders wha^ they the^ supporte in age
feebleness / in sekenes / and have no wit / and if they excede somewhat to
pardonne them. Whereof speaks saint poule ad gal. vi. Alter alterius onera
portate: et sic ad implebitis legem christi. Bear ye the burdens or deeds one
of another. And so shall ye accomplysshe the law of Ihesu christ Et legitur
eccle. tertio. ca. Fili suscipe senectam patris tui et non contristes eum i^
vita illius: et si defecerit sen^us veniam da illi. Sone receive the auncyente
of thy fader / and be not wroth with him in his life / and if his wit
defayle pardon him / Et legitur ad ephe. iiii. Estote autem inuicem benigni:
misericordes donantes inuicem sicut er deus in christo donauit vobis. Be ye
togyders benygne mercyful gyuynge togyders in like wise as god has given unto
you in Ihesu christ. Examples how a man should bear honor unto his fader and
mother and first. Example how the wise salamon honored his mother. It is written
in the second chapter of the third book of kings how the king Salamon
saw one time his mother Barsabe come unto him / and he rose up and came to mete
her and worshipped her / and set him upon his throne / and made his mother to
sytte on his right side by him / in doing her honor in like wise as a good
child should do unto his mother Again tho children the which sets fader
and mother when they ne may nothing more do / not at the hye end in doing
them honor / but at the corner of ye ch^neye. And if there be a boon it is
given unto the fair fader the which has no mo tethe. Another example written
in the fourth chapitre of the book of thobie / how the auncyente thobye said
unto his sone / When god has taken my soul bery my body / and bear honor
unto thy mother all ye days of thy life. And in like wise should good children
do. Another example. It is written that when the vyrgyn Marye departed Ihesus
forgate her not / and theder made to come and be borne all the appostles. And
he himself came theder for to do her honor and service. etc. And also set
her on his right hand in paradyse in doing her honor. Whereof speaks ye
psalmyst the which says. Astitit regina a dextris tuis in vestitu deaurato
circumdata varietate. Another example of a man the which was fell and hard
unto his auncyente and his sone him repreued and of good right. For a man
should bear honor unto his faders by commandment of god. Quere.lxxi. F.

I The things mouyng for to honor their faders. Ca. xxi.
IT is written ecclesia. tertio. Sicut qui thesaueim at / ita qui honorificat
patrem suum. In likewise as is he ye which wexeth rich In like wise is he the
which honors his fader and his mother with due reverence. Many things there
is ye which should cause and stere the persons of this world to honor
their faders and moders / of the which we shall tell. iiii. The first is to
have honor and preyse as well before god as the world and for to fle
dishonor. For the wise Salamon says in ye ecclesiastes. Gloria enim hominis
ex honor patris sui et dedecus filij pater sine honor. The glory of the man
is of the honor of his fader / and unto the dyshonoure of ye sone when the
fader is without honor / if the fader have honor or dishonor in likewise
has the sone / and the good or the evil of the fader redoundeth upon ye sone
It was none honor unto Absolon for to make war against his fader Dauyd.
Also evil came unto him. Quere.lxx. A. The second thing the which moeueth
us to honor our faders is to the end to have benedyccyon or blyssynge. Whereof
speaks the sage. Ecclesiastic. iii. Honora patrem tuum et subueniet tibi
benedictio a deo / and benedictio illius in nouissimo manet That is to say /
honor thy fader that benedyccyon come upon the from god. And the benedyccyon
of him abides in the last end. Example in Ysaac the sone of Abraham the
which had benedyccyon. Quere.li. A. The two sons of Noe Sem and Iaphet the
which honored their fader had benedyccyon. As it is written. Genesis. ix. c
Benedictus dominus deus sem sit chanaan seruus eius / dilatet deus iaphet et
habitet in tabernaculis sem: sitque chanaan seruus eius. The third is of dread
to have maledyccyon / for it does dyscende upon the children the which will
not honor their faders. Whereof it is written. Deuteronomie. xxvii. Maledictus
qui no^ honorat patrem suum et matrem suam / et dicet om^is populus. Amen. He
the which honors not his fader and mother shall be accursed / and all the
people shall say. Amen. Example of Cham the sone of Noe the which mocked his
fader / and called his two bredren Sem and Iaphet for to mock him also / for
that that his natural things were uncovered and he had maledyccyon in his
lygnage. Quere in thexamplary.lxx. C Another example of children the which
had the maledyccyon of their mother. Quere in the example.lxxiii. E. Another
example of a fader and of a sone the which cursed each other in hell.
Quere.lxxi. G. Another example of a child that the devil bare away.
Quere.lxx. G. The fourth is to the end to live the more longely / and of dread
to shorten the life and to deye cursedly. Whereof it is written. Exodi. xx. et ad
ephesios. vi. Honora patrem tuum et matrem tuam vt sis longeuus super terram
qua^ dominus deus tuus dabit tibi. Et deuterono. v. Honora patrem tuum et
matre^ tuam sicut precepit tibi dominus deus tuus vt longo viuas tempore et
been sit tibi. Et eccclesiastic. iii. Qui honorat patrem suum et matrem suam
vita viuet longiore. For as much as Asolon honored not his fader he abreged
his life. Quere in thexamplari. lxx. A. Many other examples shall be found in
thexamplary of the commandments of god. As of a man whose berde grew long
after that he was hanged. Quere.lxxi. E.

A. The things that a fader owes unto his child. xxii.
IT is written prouerbiorum vice simoseptimo capitulo. Diligenter agnosce vultum
pecoris tui: tuosque greges considera / non ei habebis iugiter potestatem. etc.
Know thou dylygently the face / the manners / and condycyons of thy people /
and consider the defautes of thy subgectes / for thou shalt not have evermore
puyssaunce upon them. A good fader owes duly unto the child four things /
the which ben nourysshynge correccyon / techynge and good examples showing.

B. First the fader should nourysshe his child / for god him commands to
love his neighbor as him self / and the nerest neighbor that a man may have
is his child the which he should love and it puruey after his puyssaunce or
else he should be unnatural and inobedyent unto god. Example of a good mother
the which loved naturally her child and might not endure yt he were slain ne
that he had evil. Quere. lxxiii. D. The birds nouryssheth their young ones
/ and them purueyth till that they may purchase for them self / as the hen
her chekyns / and the other every of them in their degree. In likewise should
the fader do unto his children / for if they de fail to give them drink and
meet in their necessytees / or if he let them deye of honger / of cold / of
pouerte / or of other thing by defaute of keeping / he should be deputed
mankyller / as it is declared in the fyfth commandment where as is spoken the
manners of manslaughter. Quere post.xxiiii. D.

C. Secondly the fader owes unto his child correccyon / for if he se that he
be inobedyent and rebel against god and good manners / or that he habandon him
to commytte sins and cursednesses he him should reprove and correcke and
punysshe wisely and dyscretely in taking example at god our fader celestyall
the which loves ye persons and reproves the vices. This thing is declared
before in the first commandment. Quere.iii. C. Also take example at the fader
spyrytual the which reproves and correcketh the vices and sinners in
predycacyon and confession / and in gyuynge penance for punycion after ye
counceyle of the appostle.i. ad thessal.v. c. Corripite inquietos / consolamini
pusillanimes suscipite infirmos / pacientes estote ad oe^s. Correcke ye them
the which have no rest / comfort ye them the which have little courage /
receive ye the seek be ye pacyent unto all. And a man should well note that
correccyon is one of the works of mercy that god commanded. And sometime he
defends that men beat not. Quere.xxv. B. Also correccyon is one of the parts
of Justice that the Just should ever have in them and do it unto other. Iustus
dicitur a iusticia. The Just is said of Justice. Thou fader thou sholdest
desire the health of thy child / and he shall not be saved if he ne be
correked of his sins. The sage says. Illud. prouerbiorum. xxiiii. Noli
subtrahere a puero disciplinam si enim percusseris eu^ virga non morietur. Tu
virga percuties cum et animam eius de inferne liberabis. Keep the from
withdrawynge dyscyplyne from thy child / if thou stryke him with the rod he
shall not deye. Thou shall stryke him with the rod and thou shalt deliver his
soul from hell. And saint Poule says. ad titum.ii. Loquere et exhortare and
argue cum om^i imperio. Speak and exhort and reprove with all sygnoury. Example
of two relygyous of the which the abbot corrected one incontinent that he
failed / and ye other he spared. When they were departed and deed he that was
corrected yede into the Joys of paradyse / and ye other unto the pains of
purgatory. Quere in thexa^plary.lxxiiii. C. Also thou fader if thou love thy
child if he be in sin you sholdest threten him / and thou sholdest afferme
unto him that he shall be beten if he correcke not him self. Vnde
ecclesiastice. xxx. Qui diligit filium assiduat illa stagella. Also it is
written in the said chapter Curua ceruice^ filii tui iniuue^tute et re^de
latera eius du^ infans est ne forte induret and non credat tibi et erit tibi
dolor anime. Bow down the heed of thy child in youth and smite his sides
whiles that he is a child that he wax not hard unto the / and yt he believe
the not when he shall be great. The wande boweth and wryeth when it is young /
and when it is old a man may not twyne it / no more may men the children
Wherefore they must be plied and daunted in youth. Example by the good
correccion that was done unto a young child he yode in to paradyse
incontinent yt he was deed / as it is written in thexamplary.lxxiiii b. Also the
fader that loves that his child be wise / prudent / and fulfilled with good
manners him beteth and chastyseth / for ye rod gives wisdom. Vnde prouer.
xxix Virga atque correctio tribuit sapientiam. Alibi legitur. Sepe facit pueros
aspera virga bonos. A sharp rod makes often times good children. And
master Alayne says. Currere cogit equum sub milite calcar actum. Et puerum
studio virga vacare suo. That is to say. The sharp sporre constreyneth ye
horse to run under yt knight And the rod constreyneth the child for to
take heed unto his study. And it is wryte^ prouer. xxii. Stulticia colligata
est i^ cord pueri / et virga discipline fugabit eu^. Folly is in the heart of
the child / and the rod of dyscypline chaseth it away. Example of a monk
that the devil drew out of ye church and led him unto vanytees wha^ the
other waked in orayson / but incontinent that saint Benet had beten him and
chastysed the devil fled / and after the said monk was devout. Quere.lxv.
G. Also when the fader is not curyous of the salvation of his child and to
correcke hy^ of his sins and defautes it is a token that he loves him not.
Vnde prouerbioru^.xv. Qui abijcit disciplinam despicit anima^ suam. He that
puts away dyscyplyne dyspreyseth the salvation of his soul. Also if by
defaute of correccion the child commytteth sins the fader is deputed an
homycyde spyrytuall of the soul of his child of death of gylte as says saint
Gregory / and in likewise as it is wryte^ distin. xliii. Pastor qi non corrigit
ouem occidit. The herdman ye which does not correcke his sheep: that is his
subgect / sleeth him spyrytually. Example of a child blasphematour of the aege
of.v. years that the fader ne corrected and the deuylles slew him in his fader
lap, Quere in the examplary.lxii. B. Also in ye house where defaute of
correccion is ye children and the servants behave them ill / for every of
them will be master / and between them aryseth noyses / and dyuysyo^s by the
defaute of the superlatyfe. Vnde seneca. Iudex qui dubitat vlcisci multos
improbos facit. The Judge the which douteth or draws back to venge or to
punysshe the malefactor does many cursednesses And here should be noted by
the fader of the household that he shall yield account before god of all his
children / servants / and subgectes the which ben remaining in his house /
if he teache them not / correcke / and think on their health. In likewise as
wrote saint Austyn unto an earl his friend. Vnde augustinus. Que somi frater
omnibus tibi subiectis in domo tua a maiore vsque minimum amorem et dulcedinem
regni celestis amaritudinem and timorem gehenne annuncies et de eorum salute
sollicitus ac vigil existas / quia pro omnibus tibi subiectis qui i^ domo tua
sunt rationem reddes. Example of Hely the which corrected not well his
children of their sins and therefore he is blamed in scripture and in doubt of
perdycyo^. Quere in thexamplary.lxx. F. Some children ben wise ye which loves
the fader that them correcketh / and the other ben foles proud and inobedyent
the which will not be corrected ne reproved / and they ben wroth when men
them correct. Vnde scriptura. Corripe sapientem et amabat te / stultus si
corripitur irascitur. Example of a woman dampened the which dyspraysed those
that reproved her of her sins and defautes. Quere in the examplary.lxxj. H.
The wise man says in his proverbs. Qui diligit disciplinam diligit scientiam
/ qui autem odit increpationes insipiens est. That is to say. He the which
loves dyscyplyne loves science / and he the which hates blames is a fool.
Also the wise man says in ye xxviii. chapter of his proverbs / that he the
which corrects any man shall find grace and love toward him more sooner
than he the which him deceyueth by flaterynges. Also the fader and the mother
ye which corrects not their children in yongthe shall find them in aege
rebel / stoborne / proud and inobedyent / and also shall confound fader and
mother in language or otherwise. Vnde prouerbioru^. xix. Puer qui dimittitur
voluntati sue confundit matrem suam. Et seneca dicit. Qui nutrit puerum suum in
inuentute nimis dilicate indubitanter in senectute ipsum inueniet contumacem et
superbum. Example of a child the which bote of the nose of his fader at the
galowes as men would have hanged him. And for as much as they yt were present
blamed he answered. I have well done / for if my fader had corrected me in my
yongth I had not ben hanged now. Quere in thexamplary.lxxi. D. Also the wise
man says that he the which nouryssheth his servant dylycatyuely in yongthe
shall apperceyue him afterward stoborne and boystous. Vnde prouerbiorum.xxix.
Qui dilicate a puericia nutrit seruum suum.i. corpus vel seruum postea
sentieteu^ contumacem. Example it is written in the bible that Helye suffered his
sons to live dylycatyuely / and he apperceyued afterward that they were
sinners. Moreover evil came unto them for they were slain in battle. Quere
in thexamplary.lxx. G. Other examples shall be found in ye fourth
commandment of thexa^plary. Quere.lxx. G.

D. Thyrdly the fader owes unto the child techynge / for he ought to
instruct him in ye faith / in scyences / and good manners. Also he should learn
him the commandments of god. Vnde ecclesiasti. vii. Si filij tibi sint erudi
illos / et curua illos a puericia illorum. If thou have children teache them /
and bow them down in their infancy and chyldehode. Et legitur prouerbioru^
xxix. Erudi filium tuum and refrigerabit te et dabit delicias anime tue. Teache
thy child and he shall refresshe and give dayntyes unto thy soul. Et legitur
ecclesiastice. xxx. Qui docet filium suum laudabitur in illo et in medio
domesticorum in illo laudabitur. He the which techeth his sone shall be
praised in him of his household and shall say this is a good child / also he
has a good fader and patron. If thou learn him science and good manners thou
shalt be Joyous in this world and in the other / And to the contrary if thou
learn him nothing thou shall be sorrowful and dolent therefore. Example of a
sone the which cursed his fader in hell for that yt he had taught him
nothing but evil. And of an other sone the which was saved and praised and
blyssed his fader for the good that he had him learned. Quere.lxxi. G. Another
example how Cathon gave good instruccyon unto his sone. Also Thobye taught his
children that they should obey unto him. The poet says. Disce puer du^
tempus habes euo iuuenili. Ne doleas si pauca scias etate seuili. Child learn
whiles that thou have time in the aege of yongthe that thou repent the not in
aege wha^ thou shalt conne but little thing. etc. Also the faders
spyrytualles as prelates / curates / and prechers should instruct their
subgectes. Vnde.ii. ad Thymotheum.iiij. Predica verbum / iusta oportune /
importune argue / obsecra / increpa in omni patie^tia et doctrina / erit enim
tempus cum sanam doctrinam no^ sustinebunt / sed ad sua desideria conceruabunt
sibi magistros prurientes auribus et a veritate quidem auditum auertent ad
fabulas autem conuertentur. That is to say. Preche unto sinners and maynteyne
thou it opportunatly / unportunately repreue / pray / blame in all pacyence and
doctrine / the time shall come that they ne shall sustain / that is they ne
will have wholesome doctrine. They shall assemble prechours and masters for to
tell them pleasant things for to here / they shall take away the herynge
when a man shall speak of the truth / and they shall approach to here fables
/ toys / and mockeryes. It is a great thing unto a fader curate or precher to
show the word of god and to convert a sinner / and to put him from the error
of his way / for he saves his soul and covers the multitude of his sins.
Vnde iacobi. v. Scire debet quoniam qui conuerti facerit percatorem ab errore
vie sue / saluabit animam eius a morte / et cooperit multitudinem peccatorum.
Examples of many the which have been saved for their word of god. Quere in
thexamplary. And unto the contrary it is a great danger unto curates and
superlatiues to let the souls of their subgectes be lost by defaute of their
showing of good doctyne / for they ben deputed as homycydes of their souls.
Vnde Ezechielis.iii. Si no^ annunciaueritis impio neque locutus fueris vt
auertatur a via sua impia / et ipse impius in iniquitate sua morietur sanguinem
aute^ eius de manu tua requiram. etc. Et legitur prouerb^. xi. Vbi non est
gubernator populus curruet. The people falls where as is no governor / that
is of capytayne or of master. Also the curates the which precheth not ne
corrects their parysshens shall answer before god of all their synes Vnde
johannes chrisostomus dicit. Vnusquisque enim christianus pro suo peccatored
det rationem / sacerdos autem non tantum pro suis sed et pro omnium subditorum
peccatis. Also they ben called dombe dogs the which can not bark ne baye /
that is they can not preche ne show the word of god. Vnde Ysaie.lvi. Canes
muti non valatrare videntes vana dormientes et ama^tes somnia. etc. Example
that he yt precheth the word of god shall have great reward in paradise / and
that many curates gooth unto dampnacyon for that they govern them evil.
Quere.lxvi. g.

E. Fourthly the fader should show good example unto his children. Saint Poule
says. Ad titum.ii. capi. Inomnibus teipsu^ prebe exemplum bonorum operum / in
doctrina / in integritate / in grauitate verbum sanum irreprehensibile vt is
qui ex aduerso est vereatur nichil habens malum dicere de nobis. Give thyselfe
example of good operacyons in all things / in doctrine / in integryte / in
grauyte / thy word be hole with out reprofe to the end that he the which is unto
the contrary have shame / and have not any evil thing to say of us. A man
should note that the fader is deputed homicyde of his child spyrytually of
death of gylte when he does operacyons of sy^nes before him / and that by his
example he habandon him unto evil and syntull works. The blyssed man saint
gregory says in his pastoryall. Scire debent prelati quoth tot mortibus sunt
digni / quot perditionis exempla ad subditos transmittunt. Et legitur mathei.
xviii. Ve homini per quem scandalum venit. Woe unto that man by whom sclaunder
comes. Example of a man and of his child the which cursed each other in
hell / and said by the I am dampened. etc. Quere in the examplary.lxxi. G. Also
in this fourth commandment a man should understand that god there
commands that a man love his neighbor as him self. This dyleccyon is
declared largely in the beginning of this present book. Quere.ii. e. f. g.

A. Here follows the works of mercy the which ben here commanded to
accomplysshe ane^st our faders and neighbors indygentes and nedy. xxii.
Who so with god will make his accord
When he shall come unto the Judgment
The works of mercy commands our lord
The to accomplysshe unto the Indygent.
Saint Poule says in his epistle that he writes.i. ad Thymotheum.iiij. capi.
Pietas ab omnia vtilis est promissionem habens vite: que nunc est et future.
Pity is prouffytable in all things having promise of the life the which now
is and of that for to come. Also these scryptures says. If thou wylt be in
the love and in ye grace of god / and that thy case be well borne unto the
Judgment partyculer and general the which shall be done of the it behooves
that thou be merciful to give and to lend unto the poor indygent. That is to
understand. If any of thy bredren christian men be comen to pouerte thou shalt
not harden thyn heart ne withdraw thyn hand / but thou shalt labor and give
unto him the lone in the thing the which you see that he has necessyte.
Vnde deuteronomie.xv. Si vnus de fratribus tuis ad paupertatem venerit non
obdurabis cortuum nec contrahes manuum sed apecies eam pauperi et dabis mutuum
quo eum in digeri prospexeris. And if thou do unto hy^ any alms and charity
thou shalt have way and ouerture for to come surely before god. For the gate
of paradyse shall be opened unto him the which has done mercy and alms /
in likewise as men open ye gates and make way unto hy^ the which brings a
fair present or gift unto a lord / and if he bring nothing men shytte the
gates against him. Vnde ecclesiastice. xvi. Omnis misericordia faciet vnicuique
locum secundum meritum operum suorum et secundum intellectum peregrinationis
illius. All almesdedes and good operacyo^s that the Just has done shall
appear upon him before al at the Judgment. Vnde Ezechielis.xviii. Iusticia
iusti erit super eum. The Justice of the Just shall be upon him And the sage
says that in the end of the man his operacyons shall be made open. Vnde
eccle. xi. In fine hominis denudatio operum illius. Et legitur Ysaie.xxix. Erit
vobis visio omnium sicut verba libri signati. The vysyon of all things shall
be unto you in likewise as the words of the book written / and god shall call
with him the good people the which bears upon them the works of mercy that
they have acco^plysshed / the which he shall put on his right hand / and
shall led them with him into paradyse. And the evil shall be put on the lift
hand and sent unto the fire of hell. It is written prouerbiorum.xxi. Qui
obturat aurem suam ad clamorem pauperis clamabit ipse et non exaudietur. He ye
which stops his eeres unto the clamours of ye poor / he shall cry and he
shall not be herd. Item sequitur prouerbiorum. xxi. Qui sequitur iusticiam et
misericordiam inueniet vitam et gloriam. Alibi vincit cuncta dare / da si vis
superare. Per dare regnare poteris / celosque valere.

B. To give breed and drink.
Unto the poor look that thou give.
Both breed and drink in time of need
If thou so do / verily believe
Thou shalt be saved / be out of dread
GOd will that thou break and give thy breed unto the poor / not the breed the
which is moulde / infecte / or corrupt / ne breed the which is comen of
theft or of pyllery / but of breed the which is thine / and of that the
which thou etest. Vnde Ysaie. lviii. Frange esurienti panem tuum. Et legitur
prouerbiorum. xxii. Qui pronus est ad misericordiam benedicetur de panibus enim
suis dedit pauperi. He the which is enclyned unto mercy shall be blyssed / of
his breed he has given unto the poor. Et legitur prouerbiorum. xxviii. Qui
dat pauperi non indigebit / qui dispicit deprecante^ sustinebit penuriam. He
the which gives unto the poor shall have no need / he that dysprayseth the
besecher shall sustain pouerte. Et legitur prouerbiorum. xi. Qui abscondat
frumenta maledicetur in populis He the which hydeth his whete in time of
famyne shall be cursed among the people And note well that it is unto the poor
and indygent people that thou sholdest give and not unto the rich. Vnde Luce.
xiiii. Cum facis conuiuium voca pauperes debiles claudos. etc. et non diuites
ne faciat tibi retributio. etc. Example by this how saint Eustace was an
almesman / god would not that he were dampened / and him converted. Quere.xliii.
b. Another example how that a barley lofe prouffyted much unto a rich man the
which keste it unto a poor man by furoure. Que^. xliii. c. Another example
that the cursed Dyues brenneth and broyleth in the fire of hell / for he had
no pity of the poor lazare. Quere.lxxxiiij. A. Another example of a rich man
merciful. Quere in the examplary. lxxxiiij. C. And of duke Durande.lxxxiiij. b
Also god will that thou give drink unto poor folk that been thyrsty / and
thou shalt have reward in paradyse / and if thou ne give but one dysshe with
cold water. Vnde mathei. x. Quicunque potum diderit vini ex minimis istis
calicem aque frigide ta^tum in nomine discipuli. Amen dico vobis non perdet
mercidem suam Example of a man merciful the which was drowned as he wend to
take the water for to give it unto a poor man / and he yede in to paradyse or
his body was cold. Quere in the examplary.lv. B.

C. To lodge and to clothe.
The poor people that lodging want
In to thy house receive them gladly
If they of clothes have verey scante
Provide that needs as seems the sadly.
GOd will that the poor pilgrims and people passing by the way the which
have not where to lie ne to lodge / that thou gader them and bring them in to
thy house. Vnde Ysaie.lviii. Egenos vagosque induc in domum tuam. Et paulus ad
hebreos. xiii. Hospitalitatem nolite obliuisci. Example by that / yt Abraham
kept hospytalyte / and that he lodged the aungelles / he had a sone the which
had benedyccyon. Genesis. xviii. Sara sterilis erat conceptret et peperit
Ysaac. Sara the wife of Abraham was barayne and ancient the which conceived
and chylded ysaac. Quere. li. A. Another example. Saint Gregory shows in his
omelye of the monday in Ester weke that there was a fader of an household the
which served by great study unto hospytalyte with them of his house / and he
received every day at his table the pilgrims / and on a day thither came many
pilgrims the which he received / among the which there was one whom he
would have washed as he was accustomed to serve them in humylyte / and as he
ne did but take the lauer he ne wist where ye said pilgrim became whom he
would have served. And as he meruayled him of ye deed in that night god unto
him said by vysyon. Thou haste received me these other days in my members and
yesterday thou received me in my propre person. Unto this purpose it is written
Mathei. xxv. how god shall say at the Judgment. Quod vni ex minimis meis
fecistis michi fecistes. That that ye have done for the love of me unto one of
my leest ye have done it unto myself. And god will that if thou find any
naked person frosen for cold that thou cover him / and if thou be of power
that thou give him a vestyment. Vnde ysaie.lxviii. Cum videris nudum operi eum.
Et legitur luce. iii. Qui habet duas tunicas det vnam non habenti. Example
saint Gregory shows in his first book of his dyalogue yt saint Bonyface was
so merciful that from his chyldehode he gave oftentimes unto ye poor his
gown and his sherte. And on a time in ye absence of his mother when there was a
derthe he gave and dystrybuted unto the poor people all the corns of the
garners. And for as much as the said mother was wroth he prayed unto god / and
the said garners were replenysshed with corns. Another example how saint
Martyn gave the half of his mantell unto a poor man. And the night following
he saw god among the aungelles covered with the said mantell the which said
in this wise. Martinus ad huc cathecuminus hac me vest contexit. Martyn yet
cathecumyn that is not baptized but in will to be has covered me in this
vestement.

D. Of the seek and prisoners.
The seek and poor thou shalt vysyte
And with good heart also them aid
The prisoners eke as is requysyte
That lie in chains shrewdly arayde
AFter ye scryptures thou ne sholdest be slouthefull / ne take for thing in
grefe too vysyte the seek. For as to aid and conforte them a man is confermed
in the dyleccyon of god and of his neighbor Vnde ecclesiastice. vii. Non te
pigeat visitare infirmum ex hijs enim in dilectione firmaberis. Example of a
Samaritan the which vysyted and made to heel a man the which was in the
hands of thieves. Quere in the first commandment.iii. H God shall say at the
Judgment. I have be seek and in prison and thou haste vysyted me.

E. Example how saint Gregory shows in the omelye of this gospel. Vide^s
ciuitatem fleuit super illam. There was a worshypfull man a monk named Martyr
the which by grace of vysytacyon parted from his monastery in the which
preceded a fader spyrytual. And as he yede his way he found a mesyll or lepre
in the way the which was so deformed and replenysshed with wounds and sores
of the sekenes elephantyne as he might be / he would go in to his hospytall /
but he ne might so much do / he was so weary / and intended to go the way of
ye said Martyr monk. And the man of god had pity and compassyon of the said
weary mesyll and thought to help and socoure him in his need / he took his own
mantell and spredde it on the earth and wrapped the said lepre in it and lift
him upon his sholders and bare him. and when he approached nygh to the gates of
the said monastery the fader spyrytuall of the said monastery began to cry
with an high voice unto his servants. Run ye run ye and open the gates of
the church for brother Martyr is comen the which bears god on his sholdres.
And when he aryued at the gate he the which he had thought to be a lepre
lepte from his back in the form of our savior and redemptour Ihesu christ
the which was god and man mounted in to heaven before the said friar Martyr in
saying. Martyr thou have had no shame of me upon the earth / and I shall have
no shame in heaven of the. And when the holy man was entered in to ye church the
fader of the monastery him demanded saying. Brother Martyr where is he that
thou barest right now. He answered If I had known him I should have holden him
by the fete. Than Martyr told ye case / and said that as he bare him he felt
no weight. etc.

F. Another example how saint Elyzabeth served a mesyll four days. Men find
in writing that in an hospytall the which saint Elyzabeth had do to be made
there came a mesyll or lepre so foul / horrible and lothely to behold that
the chamberers and servants of the said hospytall had horror and ne would
mynyster and serve him of such necessytes as were requysyte. And when saint
Elyzabeth saw that he was in such wise dyspised of other she came unto him
for to mynyster his necessytees in all humylyte and dylygence. She washed his
heed / bathed him / and bare him upon her sholdres / and made him to rest in
her lap / and she did him this service four days. and than the said seek
man departed. The fyfth day as saint Elyzabeth was making her devout oraysons
our savior Ihesu christ appeared unto her and said. I am Ihesu christ the sone of
the vyrgyn Mary / unto whom thou have mynystred at such days. And for as
much as thou haste purueyed me in form of a lepre thou shall have with me
eternal life and Joy. etc.

G. Another example of a seek body the which was vysyted of an angel. It is
written in the life of the faders that an ancyent man solytary was seek by the
space of thyrty days the which had never a person that him vysyted / nor
the which unto him did any service in his sickness the which he bare
patiently. And after the said.xxx. days god unto him sent an angel the
which unto him admynystred by seven days his necessytees / for no person him
vysyted. And after that some freres remembered them of the said man ye wh^^
said togyders. Such one our brother comes no more forth let us god vysyte
hy^ lest peradventure he be seek / and they arose incontinent and went toward
him. And when they came to knock at the door the angel of god departed from
him / and the said seek man began to cry with an hye voice in the said house.
Go hens bredren / goo hens / and in weeping they yode and took the door of the
hokes and entered unto him / and than they demanded him wherefore he had in
such wise cried / and he unto them answered. For I have labored by.xxx. days
in sickness and no manner of person has vysyted me / and here these seven
days god has sent an angel the which has minystred unto me my necessytees
/ and when ye were comen unto the door he departed fro me. And when he had
said these words he deyed / and all they praised our lord god. etc. Another
example how many freres gave a clustre of grapes unto the most weykest. Quere
in the examplarye.lxxv. A. Another example of a curate the which vysyted a
rich man at his death / and would not vesyte a poor woman wydowe the which
deyed.cv. A. Another example of a curate ye which tarried to long or went to
mynyster the sacraments to his parysshen the which deyed. Quere before.viii.
C. Another example how two men became lepres for that / that they had
horroure and despised lepres. Quere in the examplarye. lxxxiiij. E.

H. To bury the deed.
The deed bodies yt lie above ye ground
Having not whereof in earth to be brought
To bury them all christian men ben bound
Specially those yt of themself have naught
IN scriptures we read yt the good man Thobye left his dinner and ran for to
have the bodies of them that had been slain and by night entered and buried
them against the will of the king / for he fered and loved more god than the
king. etc. Also we read. Eccclesiastice.xliii. Corpora sa^ctorum in pace
sepulta sunt / et viuent noi^a eorum in eternum. That is to say. The bodies of
those that been holy ben buried in peace / and the names of them lives in
perdurabylyte.

I. To counceyle and to conforte.
Confort them that been confortlesse
And counceyle them yt no counceyle have
Of such good deeds thou do not cesse
If thou think thy soul to save.
A Great work of mercy it is as too give good counceyle unto those the which
have sinned folyed / or gone out of the way or the which have many doubts and
dyffycultees. The wise man says that health shall be in the thing where as
ben many counceyles. Vnde prouerbiorum.xi. and.xxiiii. Salus erit vbi sunt
multa consilia. A man should take the counceyle of god and of the good men and
not of the evil. Vnde thobie quarto. Consilium semper a sapientie perquire. The
evil people ne counceyleth but evil and sin / and therefore take not their
counceyle. Vnde ecclesiastice.xxxvii. A consiliario malo serua animam tuam.
Example / evil came unto Theophyle to take the counceyle of a sorcyer / for he
made him to renounce unto god and unto the vyrgyn Mary. Quere.lviii. b Also
evil came unto Amon the which defloured and had to do flesshely with his
sister Thamar by the counceyle of Ionadab for he was slain after. Quere in
thexamplary.lxxxxi. C. Another example how evil came unto the king Ochozyas
for sendynge too seek counceyle at the devil / for he deyed myscheuously / and
his messengers were burnt with the fire celestyall. Quere in thexamplary ad
numerum.lx. g An other example also how by the cursed counceyle of
Balaam.xxiii. thousand men of the children of Ysraell were burnt for
committing fornycacyon. Quere in thexamplary ad numerum.lxxxx. d. Also it is a
great relygyous work as too conforte those the which ben seek and in
trybulacyon. Vnde iacobi. i. Religio munda et immaculata apud deum et patrem
hec est visitare pupillos et viduas in tribulatione eorum. Example in god the
which conforted the three children the which were in ye fornayse. Quere.lviii.
B. Also god conforted Susanne in her trybulacyon. Quere in the
examplary.lxxxxvi. Also it is written in the first chapter of Thobye that the
said Thobye yede by all those of his knowledge for to conforte them. And he gave
mete unto them that had honger and clothed them that were naked / and those
that were frosen of cold. etc.

K. To chastyse and to teache
Chastyse those right wisely
That thou have in governance and kepinge
With soft words also swetely
Teache all those of simple understanding
THe matter of chastysement and techy^ge is written here before. Quere.xxii. C. D.

L. To pardon and to pray
Of charity and pity pardon all those
That the has offended in word and deed
For his love that deyed and arose
Pray for thyn enemies quycke and deed
HOw those the which hates should pardon and pacyfye to gyders the Iniuryes
and offenses done and spoken if yt they will that almighty god pardon them
their sins. Quere hanc materiam. xx. G. Example in eodem loco. Also it is an
holy thing and saluable as to pray for them that been deed the which have
honger and thyrste to se god / the which ben seek in the prison of purgatory /
naked and unpurveyed of all goods. Vnde ii. Machabeorum. xii. Sancta et
salubris est cogitacio pro defunctis exorare / vt ea peccatis soluantur. Also
great reward follows to pray for the quycke the which has necessyte. Vnde
mathei. v. et luce. vi. Orate pro persecutoribus et calumnianti antibus vos /
et erit merces vestra multa et eritis filij altissimi. etc.

M. To supporte.
Thou sholdest sagely the sy^ple supporte
And help to ease them of their charges
The folysshe folk advise and exhort
Than each will praise thy bou^tees larges
AFter the law of god thou sholdest supporte and help thin au^cyent faders
and the imperfeccyon and pouerte of thy neighbors / in likewise as it is
written here before. Quere.xxi. H.

Thus leueth to speak of the works of mercy.
It is a thing right according
And much it pleases god almighty
Unto the soul also great helping
To excercyse the works of mercy
AFter the holy euangelyst god shall say to the good at the day of Judgment.
Come ye blyssed of my fader / and possede you the eternal realm the which
unto you is apparayled and made ready from the beginning of the world. I have
had honger and thyrst / and ye have given me to ete and to drink. I have been
seek and in prison / and ye have vysyted me. Vnde mathei. xxv. Venite benedicti
patris mei possidete paratum vobis regnum a constitutione mu^di. Esuriui et
dedistis michi man ducare / situi et dedistis michi potum. and cetur. This
sentence conteyneth.vi. clauses. The first is understand by this word (venite
the which denotes a Joyous calling in an assocyacyon amyable. The second
clause is understand by this word (benedicti) the which denotes dyuyne
benedyccyon. That is that the good shall receive the benedyccyon of god / and
they shall be of the nombre of the blyssed saints of paradyse. The third
clause is understand by these two words (patris mei) the which denotes
dyleccyon paternall / that is that they shall have the dyleccyon and
benedyccyon of god the fader as of god the sone. The fourth is understand by
(possidite) ye which denotes that the good shall be put in possessyon and
saysme of the Joys and of the good deeds that they have deserved. The fyfth is
understand by (paratum vobis regnum) the which is the assygnacion of the
place and of the heritage the which is apparaylled unto ye good the which
unto them shall be denounced and given at ye day of Judgment. The syxte clause
is understand by (constitutione mundi) that is predestynacyon the which is
that god were predestynate to be saved. By the which the said Joys of
paradyse unto them were made ready. And unto the contrary ye ill people the
which have not wylled to excercyse mercy / as the cursed Dyues: and to do good
operacyons shall have this sentence upon them the which our lord shall cast
at the dredefull day of Judgment. Discedite a me maledicti in ignem eternum
qui paratus est diabolo et angelis eius. Esuriui et non dedistis michi
manducare. etc. Vt legitur mathei. xxv. That the pride the which is against
the dyleccyon of his faders and neighbors is here defended / and humylyte is
here commanded: Quere ante.ix. E. F.

Here leueth of the.iiij. commandment.
A. Here follows the fyfthe commandment of god the which defends homycyde
unjust. xxiiij.
God the defends to beet and to kill
Ire / hastynes / and wrath intyerly
All malice / rancour / and evil will
Punysshed shall be full bytterly
THis commandment is written. Deuteronomie. v. ca. No^ occides. Thou shalt
not kill ne slay. Alibi dicitur. Non sis occisor. By the of will ne of deed be
none homycyde / or evil shall come unto ye in likewise as it has done unto
many. Quere in thexamplary.lxxvi. A. B. C. For to understand right shortly
this commandment in general / a man should understand that god in it
defends all man slaughter unjust of will and of deed as unto ye body and as
unto the soul / and all ire / furour / vengeance / strife / envy / and hate.
And therein commands for to love his neighbor by charity / and to do him
no harm against right and Justice. In like wise as shall be found here after
by ye chapytres.

B. And first that god defends death corporal and spyrytuall. xxiiij.
NOn sis occisor. Ne slay not the soul of thy self ne of thy neighbor for
too grieve him by sword. And slay not thy soul ne that of thy neighbor by
mortal sin. In this commandment two sorts of dethes be^ defended. The one
is corporal and the other is spyrytuall. A man sleeth the soul spyrytually of
ye death of gylte by mortal sin / the which is a dysobeysaunce so venymous
/ full of infeccyon and of sekenes mortal that it mortyfyeth and quenches
charity and the virtues and separeth god / his love: and his grace the which
gives life unto the soul. Vnde augustinus. Sicut corpus moritur recedente
anima a qua est eius vita / ita anima recedente a deo a quo est eius vita
mortua est. That is to understand. In likewise as the body deyeth when the
soul departs / in semblable manner the soul is deed of deeth of gylte when
god is departed by sin. For god is ye life the which makes the soul to
live. Vnde. John. xiiij. Ego su^ via veritas et vita. And a man should not
understand that the soul defayled is deed and quenched / for it is immortal.
But a man should understand that the soul is deed spyrytually of the death of
gylte as it is said / and deputed for to descend in to ye tourmentes
infernalles of hell with all the deuyls / the which is ye second death /
where as the dampened has death without dyenge / and life without living.
Saint Bernarde says. Non viuit qui superbia inflatur / qui luxuria sordidatur
/ qui ceteris peccatis inficitur / quoniam non est hoc viuere / sed vitam
confundere et appropinquare vsque ad portas mortis. That is too say. He the
which is blown with pride the which is soyled by lechery / and ye which is
infecte by other sins he lives not For it is no life to live so. It is to
confound his life and to approach unto the gates of death. Et paulus dicit.i.
ad thymotheum v. Vidua que in delici^s est viuens / mortua est. Glosa. Quia si
viuat natura / mortua est culpa / vel si viuat mundo mortua est deo. The wydowe
the which is living in delytes of sins is deed spyrytually for all be it
that ye nature lives she is deed by gylte. Or if she live to the world she is
deed unto god. Et legitur appocalipsis. iii. Scio opera tua qui nomen habes
quod viuas et mortuus es. etc. The beginning of corporal death and spyrytuall
proceeds by ye sin of our first fader Adam the which brake the
commandment of almighty god. Our lord him defended that he should not ete
of the truyte and unto him said In what hour that thou etest of it thou shalt
deye. That is for to understand of double death / for thou shalt be mortal
as unto the body to deye one day the which shall come / and also thou shalt
deye spyrytually of death of culpe or gylte / for grace and virtues shall
depart them from the And the devil came after the which is ye great
murderer and enuyous hangeman of the soul and insacyable enemy of humayne
creatures the which counceyled and provoked unto our first mother Eve that she
should ete of the fruit. And he tempted her first for that the woman is more
frail and apt to convert than the man by fair language and flateryes. And
she answered / god has said unto us that in what hour that we ete of it we
shall deye. no the devil said unto her. It is not so ye shall not deye. God
has said so for that that he knows that in what hour that ye ete of this
said fruit your cyen shall be opened and ye shall be as gods knowing the
good and the evil. So Eve consented her unto the devil and did ete of the
apple / and made Adam to ete against the commandment of god / and anon they
were bound unto the death corporal and spyrytuall. God had created their
souls fair / and clear / shynynge in innocence / full of charity / of virtues
/ and of spyrytual gods / and hadd put them in a place delectable that is
paradyse terrestre / and they were immortalles / but after that they had
sinned they were bound unto death as it is said and were adnychyllate / and
their spyrytuall goods forgoten. Quia legitur ezechielis. xxxiii. In quacunque
die peccauerit iustus omnes iusticies eius obliuioni tradentur. Before sin
the soul was fair / but after it was vile and foul and pryued from grace and
from virtues and taken out of paradyse terrestre and put in this present
world the which is the land of labor and of mysery / and deputed to
descend in to the regyon infernal that is hell. etc. Who so should well
consider th^s example he should keep him from commyttyng of mortal sins the
which mortefyeth the life of the soul and his spyrytuall goods as it is
said. A man should note here that all the good operacyons that a man does in
mortal sin ben deed and of none effect for they ben done without grace and
charity. Quere post.xlv. B. And therefore he ye which commytteth mortal sin
is culpable of a great crime worthy of punycion to slay in such wise his soul
and his virtues by the death of gylte. Example how filius prodigus was deed of
death of gylte by sin when his fader said unto his ancient sone. Illud Luce.
xv. Gaudere oportebat quia frater tuus hic mortuus fuerat et reuixit / perierat
et iuuentus est. Another example of a thief the which saint Johan converted
when he him demanded of the bishop the which should have kept him. He
answered. Parer mortuus est deo. That is to say. Fader he is deed unto god of
death of gylte / he is prince of the thieves. Another example how Susan^e said
that death was in her if she committed the lechery that the two ancient men
would have had her commyt. Vnde Damelis. xiii. Si enim hoc egero mors michi
est. si autem non egero non effugiam manus vestras sed melius est absque opere
incidere in manus vestras quam peccare in conspectu domini. For a good cause
Susanne would not commytte sin / for incontinent that it is consummed and
done it engenders the death / as says saint James in his epistle. Peccatum
cum consummatum fuerit generat mortem. And the soul the which has sinned
shall deye of death. Vnde ezechielis. xviii. Anima que peccauerit ipsa
morietur. For too understand well the scriptures god defends the death
corporal / and death spyrytuall as it is said. It is a thing clear sith that
god defends yt thou sle not the body / by a more greter reason he defends
that thou slay not the soul spyrytually. For it is nothing as of the body the
which is transytoryous as to ye regard of the soul the which is perdurable
and eternal. etc.

C. The manners how a man commytteth homycyde. xxiiii.
NOn occides. Thou shalt not slay. Homycyde is committed corporally and
spyrytually in many manners. First a man commytteth homicide spu^ally by evil
thoughts when a man consents him by delyberacyon to do any mortal sin. In
likewise as it is written indepenitentie disti^ctione.l. c. Siquis volu^tarie.
If by delyberacyon thou desyrest the death of any of thy kynnesmen and friends
for to have their goods and herytages. Or if thou have hate with any of thy
neighbors in desyryng to beat him or to kill him / or to do him any evil in
his person or in his goods or herytages thou art deputed homycyde of thy
soul spyrytually. Vnde.i. iohannis.iiii. Qui odit fratre^ suum homicida est.
etc. This matter shall be declared hereafter in the chapter of the sin of
hate. Quere post.xxvii. c. And in the two last commandments of god.
Secondly a man commytteth homycyde spyrytually when a man gives so evil
example unto his subgectes that they habandon them to sin as it is declared
here before in the fourth commandment Quere.xxii. E. Or when the subgectes
go unto perdycyon by defaute of correccyon. Quere.xx. C. Or by defaute to show
and to teache the word of god. Quere.xxii. D. Versus. Exemplum / men's / lingua
/ manus / substractio victus. Corporis ac anime dici possunt homicide. Thyrdly
a man commytteth homycyde spyrytually by the tongue when a man makes lesynges
