for to noye his neighbor. Vnde sapientie.i. Os quod mentitur occidit animam.
Also when a man blasphemeth or when a man swereth vaynely against the dyleccyon
of god a man sleeth the soul of the death of gylte. The wise man says that
the death and the life ben in the hands of ye tongue Vnde prouerbiorum.xviii.
Morset vita sunt i^ manibus lingue. Examples how the deuylles did slay the
child of a rich man in blasphemynge god. Quere in the examplary ad
numerum.lxii. B. Also a man does homycyde by the tongue when a man accuses
falsely any person for too make him to deye / as the Jews when they accused
falsely the Just lamb that is our savior and redemptour Ihesu christ unto
Pylate the Judge crymynall by lesynges and after cried as unreasonable beestes.
Crucifige / crucifige eum. They were homycydes and culpables of his death. And
Pylate the which him Iuged and condamned wrongfully / they committed homycyde
how be it that they stroke not the nails. Another example how Judas yt which
sold our lord for.xxx. pence sayng. Quid vultis michi dare. etc. was homycyde
/ traytre / and thief too deliver his master / and evil came unto him for he
lost the dygnyte to be an appostle and another was elect and put in his place /
as it is written in the deeds of the appostles. Hiat habitacio erus deserta / et
episcopatum eius accipiat alter Also he was accursed of god / and he had been
better never to have been borne. Vnde mathei.xxvi. Ve homini illi per quem
filius hominis tradetur / melius esset illi si natus no^ fuisset homo ille. And
at the last he hanged himself and is dampened. Also a man does homycyde by the
tongue when a man commands unjustly for to do homycyde. In likewise as it is
written distinctione.i. Si quis viduam. Et de peniten. disti. i. capitul.
Periculose. Example in Herod the which commanded that saint Johan baptyst
should be beheeded / he was homycide albeit that he gave not the stroke Other
examples there ben of them that has committed semblable homycydes as of Egeas
the which made saint Andrew to be crucyfyed. And Tarquyn made Thymothee to be
slain. And Hyrace yt which made to kill saint Matthew. And Quyncyen saint
Agathe. And Neron saint Peter and Poule. They were homycydes of the^ how be it
that they ne deden the operacyons. Quere ista exempla.lvii. f. g. h. i. Also
they the which counsaylleth or commands to excercyse wars ye which be
not just after god / or ye which that to do ben moved / by auaryce or
vengeance more than for the love of Justice ben homycydes and culpables of the
murdres the which thereof comen. Also those ye which cou^saylleth to do any
homycyde breketh this commandment / as it is written. di. i. cap. Si quis
vidua^ and de pe. di. i. c. hominum. and ca. Omnis iniquitas. These baudes the
which counsaylleth to do lechery / or these ill knaves theft ben homycydes of
ye souls spyrytuelly. etc. Also those ye which susteyneth the quarrel of
war unjust puts themself in danger. Quia agentes et conscientes pare
pena punientur. That is to understand those ye which makes war / the
which it susteyneth / and the which also consents shall be punysshed of
semblable pain. etc. Fourthly a man does homycyde by the hand and by cursed
operacyon. If it be will dysposed unjustly that is a great sin much enorme
and reserved unto the bishop or unto the pope after the person slain. Vt
habetur. di l. ca. Si quis voluntary. It is that ye which is spoken before.
Christian / man / and christian woman to hate / to beat / and to kylle unto the is
defended entyerly. If thou hold rancoure thou shall be punysshed bytterly This
sin bydeth unto great punycyon Example how the angel showed unto tongdalus
in hell a valee replenysshed with coals of fire in the which were put these
homycydes. Quere.lxxvii. g. Another example how leueresse made saint beatryce
to be slain. And the devil posseded her and slew her.lxxvii. a. Another
example how iesabell made Naboth to be slain / and she was slain and the
hounds eat her.lxxvi. b. They shall be sent unto the fire of hell the which
is a torment right cruel. Quere.xlix. b. Also when by charnalite or other
cursed government a man is cause that the fruit of a woman perysshe before
the baptysme or after / he is homycyde and case reuersed. Also empoysonners /
and enuenimers / or women the which drynketh herbs for to make the fruit of
them to deye such people ben homycydes and transgressors of this
commandment. Also a man homycyde by the hand / and of that it behooves to
make dystyncyon. When the judge makes any person to deye for his demerytes by
right justice. And that he and the hangman done execusyon for to punysshe
alonely the sinner by justice / the judge ne synneth in co^maundynge it / ne ye
hang man in doing execusyon / but it may be merytorye for the conseruacyon of
the comune wealth / and of the thing publyke / as approves saint poule in a
pystle where he says ad romanos.xiii. Omnis anima potestatibus / sublimoribus
subdita sit Sequitur si malum feceris time non eni^line causa portat gladiu^
minister dei. vindex est in iram ei qui malum agit. That is to understand.
Every soul is subject to the haulte puyssau^ces. Certes the mynyster of god
bears no sword without cause he is venger in ire unto him ye which does
ill. And if the judge or ye hangman make the sinner to deye / not upon entencyon
to accomplysshe justice / but upon entencyon dysordynate to shed the blood
humayne of the christian people and creatures of god / or by vengeance or
cursydnes / they ben deputed homycydes for the entencion was corrupt and
enfecte with malice and cruelte / all be it that the sinner had well and
justly deserved it. In like wise as it is written in the droit. Also when a man
sleeth by necessyte it behooves to make dystyncyon of the necessyte / if it may
be avoided or nay / as here ben people the which will slay me unjustly / it
behooves that I slay them / or that they slay me. If that I may escape so that
they slay me not / nor I them I should avoid For if I go to slay them and that
I may escape I should be homycyde and transgressoure of this commandment.
But if I may not avoid but that I must go through them and that I do homycyde
without hate ne will to slay. I shall not be deputed homycyde ne transgressour
of this commandment. How be it good thing it is to make conscience to be
comen unto such necessyte. Bonarum enim mention est timere culpam vbi culpa
non est. Vt habetur in decreto extra de homicidio. Interfe cisti. Also when a
man sleeth by case of fortune it behooves to make dystyncyon wha^ the fortune
happens if a man do operacyon lefull or not lefull. If it were operacyon
lefull as to cut a tree / or that he cast ye sheuys from the carte. etc. And
that he take heed to behold about and to cry hye and clear / and the hour.
In such wise ye if there were person and that he might well avoid ne should
be deputed homycyde. Vt probatur. di. l. ca. Sepe cotingit: et extra de
homicidio capitu. Quidam. But if he did operacyon unlawful as to cast stones
where as the people have of custom to pass. etc. he should be homycide and
transgressour of this commandment. Also if a man lay to slay any in just
batayl he is not deputed homycyde as it is written. xxiii. q. Quid culpatur.

D Fyfthly a man does homycyde for to withdraw the living of any person as
when faders and moders ne gives no meat unto their little children / or that
ye mother gives them no souke / when a bird ne bears meat unto her little
birds they deye. In like wise faders and moders ben homycydes. Also when the
syege is before a town it behooves to make dystyncyon if ye war be just or
not / if they be just for to famysshe them and to make the^ deye for hongre
if they yield not the place I trow to punysshe them it is no homycyde / how be
it yt the thing is dangerous For many bears punycyon the which have
nothing to do. And if ye war be not just / it is homycyde to make them dye
of hongre Also when rauisshers takes away the substance of the poor people
unjustly they take away their life / and therefore they ben deputed homycydes.
Vnde eccle. xxxiiii. Panis egentiu^ vita pauperis est qui defrauldat illum homo
sanguinis est: qui aufert in sudore pane^ quasi qui occidit proximu^ suum. That
is to understand / the bread of the hongrye and nedy is the life of the poor
/ he ye which takes it from him or begyleth is a man of blood he the which
takes away in sweet the bread is also as he ye which sleeth his neighbor.
But people of arms the which gothe against their adversaries in just war
for to defend the country and the comune welthe ye which have no wages may
take of lyuynges curteysly without exces ne to grieve the poor it is suffered of
the king / and the law suffers it for the great necessyte of the comune
wealth. Necessytas non habet legem: si malum inde sequeretur postea. Vt habetur
de consecradi.i. Sicut etiam patet extra de consuetudine. ca. iiii. But those
ye which have wages and takes unjustly the goods of an other by force
openly without mocyon of war breketh the commandment of god the which is
written exodi. xx. Non furtum facies. et deutero. v. Non concupisces rem proximi
tui. Also god commands yt thou love thy neighbor as thy self. and that thou
do unto him none ill no more than thou would that he did unto ye Vn^ thob.
iiii. Quod ab alio odis tibi fieri vide ne tu aliquando alteri facias. Also
after the scripture pyllerye is more great sin than the theft. For he that
steleth takes secretly with dread. And he the which pylleth takes apertely
before all gredely and without dread. unto both tway^ it behooves to make
restytucyon. Quia non dimittitur peccatum nisi restituatur ablatu^. xiiii. q.
vi. ca. Sires. Example how a knight was beten of the deuylles for yt that he
took away the cow of a woman wedowe. Quere.c. ix. e. Another example of a
rauyssher in pains for that / that he took the got of a woman wedowe. Quere.
c. ix. f. Another example how one monyer saw in hell a rauyssher in pains.
quere. c. x. a. Also those the which have habou^daunce of goods and by
auaryce lets their pore neighbors to deye for hongre be it by scarsete /
syknes / or other necessyte ben deputed homycydes and transgressors of this
commandment. Vt habetur. de. pe. di. lxxxvi. ca. Pasce fame morie^tem et si
non pauisti occidisti. Example how ye cursed dives was dampened and sent in to
the fire of hell / for he had no pite of the pure lazar the which coueyted to
have of ye cro^mys the which fell from the table. Quere lxxxiiii. c. Another
example.lxxxiiii. b.

How homycyde is a sin ye which asks vengeance of god. ca. xxv
NOn scis occisor. Be thou no murderer. It is great horror and cruelte to
committee homycyde / to undo that yt god has made to his own semblaunce to
murdre and slay his semblable and brother crystyen. Among other sins it is a
vice the which demau^deth of god vengeance that homycide. We have by example
in Cayn after that he had slain his brother abell god came unto him and him
demanded where his brother abel was / he answerde am I the keeper of my brother.
And god said unto him. Here is ye voice of the blood of thy brother Abell the
which cries unto me from the earth and demau^deth vengeance. vn^ge. iiii.
Ecce vox sanguinis fratris tui abel clamat ad me de terra. This matter shall be
declared in the examples where he speaks of ye homycyde of Cayn. Quere.lxxvi.
a. Also after that the cursed massacre herodes had slain the innocents / the
voice of ye said innocents cried for vengeance unto god as it is written in
the legende. Sub altar audiui voce ociosorum clamatiu et dicencium vindica
sanguine^ nostru^ deus noster. And god them answerde. Abide ye yet a little
while till unto ye time that ye nombre of your brederne be acco^plysshed.
Expectate ad huc modicu^ te^puis donec i^pleatur numerus fratrum vestrorum.
Than ye syn of homycyde demands vengeance / and in the end the innocents
were venged / And the said herodes deyed myscheuously In like wise as it is
written in the examplayre. Que. lxxvi. d. Every person be he king / prince or
labourer should fere to do homycyde unjust. For incontinent that it is
committed / the said person is bound unto pain and punycion in such wise
that he ne may escape but that he have punycyon in this world or in the other.
The said king herodes which slew the innocents was punysshed by little
worms that slew and ete him. etc. Also Pylate ye which made wrongfully our
lord Ihesus to dye / he slew himself with his own knife And the jews by
whom he was slain / god was venged / for some deyed by famyne / the other by
sword / and all deyed myscheuously. By the which it appears that by the
sin of hate and homycyde there follows punycion and vengeance. And therefore
said god unto saint peter when that he cut of malcus ere in his passion.
Illud mat. xxvi. Convert gladium i^locum suum: omnes qui acceperint gladium
gladio peribunt. Who so sleeth with the sword shall deye of a sword. That is
to say of the sword corporelly or spyrytuelly if he ne do great penance.
Item legitur gene. ix. Sanguinem enim animaru^ vetraru^ requiram de manu
hominis / de manu viri / and de manu fratris eius requiram animam hominis.
Quicu^que affuderit humanum sanguinem fu^detur sanguinis illius. Certainly I
shall demand of ye hand of man the blood of our souls. That is to
understand how god shall demand of the hand of the murderer the blood of
his brother crystyen that he has slain. It is so great sin that by the right
of Justice the said murderer ought to be slain and therefore of good right god
says / what so ever person has shed the blood humayn of the man his
blood shall be shed Et legitur apoca. xiii. Qui gladio occiderit oportet eum
in gladio occidi. etc.

B When it is lefull to beat / and when it is defended. Ca. xxv.
DAuyd the prophet says in ye psalter. Irascumini et nolite peccare. Wrath
ye or be ye wroth again your sins / and again those of your neighbors and
children and keep you from syne That is to trouble your entendement by passion
of ire to the end that thou ne do correccyon unjust. Nolite peccare / that is
to say if there come the a sudden ire / ne give thy consentement to do
vengeance without the bounds of justice. Ne strike thou not / ne murdre thy
neighbor unjustly / god it defends and so commands the to love him /
and that thou ne hate him. It is that thing the which is spoken in the
beginning of this commandment. Christian man or christian woman / to hate / beat
/ or kylle to ye is defended entyerly / if thou will hold rancour thou shall
be punysshed bytterly. To beat his neighbor is sometime commanded of god and
sometime defended. God commands that a man beat by charity and fair
correccyo^ the children sinners mobedyentes unto god and unto good manners. It
is a great work of mercy to save a soul / to correct an ill person ye
which gothe unto dampnacyon / more great than to give great alms. The sage
says sapien. i. Probata virtus corripit insipientes. That is to say the
virtues prouued corrects the fools unlearned / unwise / and sinners. Those ye
which have subgectes in their correccion them should correct and instruct in
good manners. And if they ben rebels inobedyent and sinners they should beat
them / punysshe and correct saigely and dyscretely by love and charity without
hate ne vengeance. This matere is declared in the fourth commandment. Quere.
xxii. c. Example how saint benet bette a monk by fair correccyo^. Quere. lxv.
g. In another manner god defends by this commandment that a man ne beat nor
murdre unjustly his neighbor by ire / furoure / courage moved / and by cursed
will. In the ancient testament the child that bette his fader / or his mother
by ill will / was put to death. Vn^. exodi. xxi. Qui percusserit patrem suu^ and
matre^ sua^ morte moriatur. Also in ye same chapter it is written. Qui percus
serit hoi^em vole^s eu^ occidere morte moriatur Also when any beat a person if
he deyed he was slain. exodi. xxi. Si mors fuerit subsecuta reddet ai^am pro
ai^a. And if he put out the eye of his neighbor / men should a put out his
eye. And if he had broken his neighbors tothe / men should a plucked out one
of his / if he had cut an hand / his hand should a be cut / or foot for
foot / or brennynge for brennynge wound for wound. etc. Vn^. ex. xxi. Beddet
oculu^ pro oculo / dente^ prodente / manu^ pro manu / pede^ pro pede / etc.
when any beat his neighbor again the commandment of god It is a thing
reasonable that he be beten Vn^. psalm. Scdm^ opera manuu^ eorumtribue illis.
God commands unto every person that he ne do unto another more than he would
another did unto him / and none ne would be beten ergo. etc. It is written
thobie. iiii. Quod ab alio tibi odis fieri vide ne tu aliquando alterifacias.
The syn of betyng is more great in some persons than in some other / for to
beat a clerk or a priest / it is a case reserved to the pope / to beat fader
or mother is case reserved unto ye bishop. Also to beat his parents of each
degree by ill / ye nerer they be the gretter is the sy^ne. Also those the
which beat their wives and children / or ye scolemayster his clerks by ire
and furour and not by correccyon offends this commandment / and if they do
it by fair correccyon / it is the work of charity. Also those the which
defend them in betynge and killing more by ire than to defend them justly
offends against this commandment. Example how a knight was gretely
tormented in purgatory for yt that he fyled the church yerde / and hurt one
wtin it. Que.lxxvii. f Another example of a man the which ^^te and tormented
his wife so often y^ she renyed the faith / slew her child / and consented
unto the will and temptacyon of the devil.lx.i.

A How god defends all ire unjust a yenst his neighbor. xxvi.
Saint James says in his epystyl l. Be every man swyfte to here / late to
speak / and late unto ire. Certainly the ire of the man ne does the justice of
god Vn^. iacobi. i.c. Si au^t oi^s homo velox ad audiendu^ / tardus aute^ ad
loquendu^ / and tardus ad iram. Ia eni^ viri iustitia^ dei operatur. Ire
furoure / noise / hate / dyuysyons they committee and reyse among neighbors
brederne and friends for many things. The first is to gain or to have to
gods or herytages the one of the other. The second is for the loss of the
goods or herytages the which is done for the one or for the other. The third
is for ye dimynucyon of the reno^mee of any / and iniuryes spoken between
them. The fourth is when any smyteth or sleeth any of them The.v. is when any
ymaginacion true or false that any hurt him in any thing or if that his
person be despised or full little praised. For to understand shortly: ire
spryngeth up when any has do^mage of another in his body / or has reno^med
hy^ or in his goods or herytages. And such ire is sometime kept and enclosed
in the heart without apperynge it without forth sometime it is showed in word /
and sometime in operacyon. The first is ill. The second is wors. The third is
worste of al.

B The first ire the which is in heart makes a man sorye / dyspleasau^t
again his neighbor in awaytynge the opportunyte when he may be avenged on
him and to do him dyspleasure and do^mage. If it be by delyberacyon /
delectacyon and conse^tement of reason there follows dampnacyon and putting
from paradyse. Vn^. ma. v.c. Oi^s qi irascitur fratri suo reus erit iudicio.
Every man ye which is wroth with his brother shall be culpable of judgment and
shall be cyted unto the judgment of god / and it behooves will he or not yt he
there appear after his death. Where he shall be demanded how he has kept
this commandment ye which is to love his neighbor as himself. What may he
answer when he has hated him and desired his ill and would do vengeance.
Every person the which is in such estate if he dye in such wise he is sent
unto dampnacyon. The prophet says quod in tempora vindicte disperdet te deus.
Example of a woman dampened the which kept her ire in her heart without will
to pardon.lxxviii.d.

C The second ire ye which is showed by sign or token is when any man has
the heart so full of ire and wrath again his neighbor that he shows the
said ire without forth by any ways / or by any tokens or manners. Of whom
speaks the euangelyst of him the which says racha the which is an
interieccyon showing ire and indygnacyon without being interpretee / or as he
ye which enclyneth his eyes having no will to behold him / or ye which
makes clean his mouth and make the spyttynge / or the which ne will speak in
metynge one with another / or ye which gothe by another way for dread to mete
him that he hates and semblable things / If thou therein have offended by
reason disposed in willing him ill thou art culpable of cou^sayl dygne of
punycion. Vn^. ma. v.. Qui dixerit fratri suo racha: reus erit consilio. The
counsayll of the blyssed trinite is that in such mesure and manner of ire as
thou have had against thy neighbor that thou shalt find it and have it in
such manner against god / the vyrgyn marye and the saints of paradise. Vn^
super illud lu. vi. Eade^ me^sura qua me^si fueritis remecitur vobis vbidicit
basilius: q^ me^sura vnus qisque peccat: aut been agit eade^ premi^a: aut pena^
sumet. God shall show the his ire in such wise that thou shalt never se him
ioyously by joyous face / and that he shall never have mercy on the / and shall
never deliver the from pains and torments if you depart or deye in such ire.
And prayers and oraysons yt men done for ye shall never serve the of nothing.
Whereof it is written hie. vii. Tu noli orare pro populo hoc nec assumas laude^
and or^em et no^ obsistas michi qia no^ exaudia^ te. God said unto saint
Hiereme / pray you not for this people for I shall not gracyously here the. The
token of ire of ye virgyn marye and of the saints of paradyse is yt they shall
never make prayers ne suffrages for a man dampened. Example of cursed dyues the
which demanded a drop of water / he was not herd. The token of ire of the
angels shall be yt they shall sever and depart the good from the ill / and
shall send them in to the chemyne of the fire. In the which they shall weep
and grynde their tethe of rage and of anguysshe / and they shall be put from
glory. vn^ math. xiii. Exibu^t angeli et seperabunt malos de medio iustoru^
and mitte^t eos i^ caminu^ ignis: ibierit fletus et stridor de^tium And ye
prophet Ysaye says. Tollatur impius ne videat gloria^ dei.

D The third ire the which is showed in word is when any has ye heart so
furyous heavy and angry against his neighbor that he ne can hold it wtin but yt
it must nedely forth in words / sygnyfyenge iniuryes / blames / shames /
noyses: reproaches / as to say that thou art a thief / pyller / or murdrer etc
/ or a liar / to dyspyte / to menace / as to say I shall beat the / or I shall
sle or I shall do such a thing and such / such people ben culpables of the
fire of hell as says the gospel math. v. Qui dixerit fratri suo fatue: reus
erit gehenne ignis. This matere shall be declared in the.viii. commandment of
god.

E The fourth ire is showed in ill operacyons / for the furoure and ire ye
which is in the heart oftymes makes vengeau^ces by the hand leyed and of
deed / as to beat to slay / to murdre beestes / or people / or to do^mage by
process / iuges / sergentes / men of law / officers / men of war / or by other
false things unjust / ill / and unlawful. Such vengences and operacyons ben
defended in this.v. commandment and ben right ill. For they put from paradyse
and makes to have dampnacyon. legitur math. v. Dictum est antiqis no^ occides:
qi eni^ occiderit reus erit iuditio. etc. You have in your law Slay thou not
thy neighbor / he the which has slain shall be culpable of judgment. That
is to be iuged unto semblable pain yt which is death corporell. But I tell you
every person yt is wroth or angry in his heart agay^st his brother in
willing him ill unjustly by delyberacyon / he is culpable of judgment / that
is to be accused before god unto dampnacyon and perdicio^. And that ye god
says after / qui dixerit racha / yt is when the hatered appears without forth
as it is said that the sin is the more great / and to say / fatue / it is
yet more great sin and to do the operacion It is the sin unto the which
apperteyneth more great punycyon and dampnacyon. Example of diascorus the
which by great ire and furoure beat iniustely saint barbara / and after
beheded her / and he was burnt with the fire celestyall. Que. lvii. e. Many
other examples ben written in the first commandment of the exemplayre of
princes and tyrauntes the which have made to slay and martyr the crystyeus by
great ires and furours. And they shall deye of ill death.lvii.d. f. And after
ye scryptures all men and women shall yield account at the day of judgment of
one and every of them and of all the ill operacyons that they have done in this
world if they dye impenytentes without contrycion / confession and
satysfaccion unto god and unto their neighbor after the offense done. If thou
will not believe that it be true by simple word than put to faith unto the
wytnes of the holy scripture yt which varyeth not Vn^. athanasius in psalm.
Quicu^que dicit quod ad aduentu^ christi oe^s hoi^es reddituri su^t de factis
propriis / rationem and qui bona egeru^t ibu^t in vitam eternal: qui vero mala
in ignem eternu^. At the coming of Ihesu christ al men shall yield reason of
their own deeds / and those the which have well done and wrought shall goo in
to the joy eternal. And those the which have ill done shall go in to ye fire
eternell. Et paul.ii. ad. co. v. Oe^s eni^ nos manifestari oportet ante
tribunal christi vt referat vnusquisque propria opera corporis prout gessit
sieve bonum sieve malum. It behooves us al to appear before the charity of Ihesu
crist where every man shall report his own operacyons of the body as he them
has dode ben they good or ill. Et. hie. xxv. Redda^ eis secu^dum opera little
and secundu^ facta manuum suaru^. I shall yield unto them says god after their
works / and after ye deeds of their hands. Also they shall goo in to the
place that they have deserved after their operacyons and works / the which
they shall bear with them. Et psalm. Secundum opera manuum eoru^ tribue illis
read retributionem eorum ipsis et cetera. Et apo. xiiii. Opera eni^ illorum
sequu^tur illos. Thou irous or wrathful man ye which haste had thy thoughts
ill to avenge the on thy neighbor / or the which haste wronged / and menaced
/ or beten / or slain if thou will be saved repent the and take the
condycyons of the pilgrim of paradyse the which ben written here after q^re
xlv. a. Also obey unto god and unto his commandments to the end that thou
possede the Joys of paradyse ye which ben great in like wise as they shall be
declared here after.xlvii. a. Also leave ire / furour / repent the and obey
unto god of dread / to be sent in to the fire of hell the which is a torment
right cruel in like wise as it is declared afterward. Quere. xlix. b. Vn^
legitur apoca. xxi. De homicidis / fornicatoribus / beneficis / ydolatris / and
oi^bus men dacibus / pars illorum erit in stagno arde^ti igne et sulphur quod
est mors secunda In the said chapter he speaks of homycydes / fornycatours /
enuenymours / ydolatryes / and also liars / the which deye impenytentes / the
place and the party of those shall be in a ponde of fire brynninge in hell
the which is the second death where the dampened shall be and shall have death
without deyenge and without ending and default without defayllynge. Example
of a man dampened the which spoke of ye fire wherein the dampened ben. Quere.
lvii. a.

F How god defends ire again himself. Ca. xxvi.
NOn contristabit iustum quicquid acciderit ei. prouer. xii. c. What fortune /
loss of gods aduersyte / pouerte / that comes unto a Just man / he should
not be wroth / for the good person bears pacyently all aduersytees for the
love of god as did ye good man job / a man is wroth again himself in many
manners. whereof one is right ill and worste of al when by ire a man fails to
dyspayre / and yt man is homycyde of himself. For thereof follows dampnacion
and perdycyon for the brekynge of the commandment of god Non sis occisor. By
thyselfe of will ne of deed be thou no homycyde / ne in thyselfe ne in thy
neighbor. Those the which be ire ben homycydes of themself should be put
from the prayers oraysons and from sepulture ecclesiastycall / and should be
buried in ground unhallowed if the end of them appear without any repentance
ye which may be so great that as unto god / that such homycyde shall be in
the way of salvation / but such thing is unknown as unto us. Also a man is
wroth against himself when a man accomplyssheth not his will / or when yt he
leseth or wynneth any thing by his folly / or when a man leseth or geteth any
good / or when a man falls in to any inconuenyente by deffaulte of takynghede
to himself. For these things here and for many other a man is wroth sometime
so outrageously that a man stryketh himself / or his wife his children / and
servants / and that a man breketh pottes and pa^nes in doing many ylles. And
oftymes a man falls in to sykenes the which grieve the body / the which
takes head to get of goods also well spyrytuell as corporell / and the
which dampneth the souls of them the which ben obstynate and persevering
unto the death without penance. By this Ire yt person is all troubled. ^n^.
david i^ psalm. Turbatus est in ira ocuius meus anima mea and ve^ter meus. Et
socrates dicit quod iracu^dis cu^ aliis irasci desierit sibi irascitur. etc
After the cause wherefore any is wroth and the ill the which follows and he
it appetyteth to avenge him and to do ill / ye syn of ire is more great or more
little the which is known as unto god ye which shall do the judgment and the
punycyon.

G Of ire ye which is again god. xxvi
ITem infer cave cu^ quo gracia tibi iuncta est. Chaton says unto his child
/ keep the from bringing in of strife or noise / with god / thy friend / or
thy neighbor with whom grace is joined unto the A man wratheth him against
god for many things / pryncypally for the flagellacions / aduersytees /
fortunes / sykenesses / and mortalytees / losses / punycyons / famyne / war
and ill time. etc. that he sends. For these things here a man murmureth
ayenste god in blasphemynge him yllynge him / dyspytynge / renyenge him and his
saints. And if a man may venge him / men do venge them the which is a haulte
folly to have will to resyste / or to go against the will of god ye which
sleeth or makes lively / the which makes to go in to paradyse or in to
hell. Vn^. psalm. Dn^s mortificat et viuificat deducit ad inferos and reducit /
dn^s pauperem faciat et ditat humiliat et subleuat. Also it is folly to be in
will to resyste against god the creatoure ye which is the judge that punyssheth
all malefactors. Vnde deutero. xxxii. Reddam vltionem hostibus meis et his qui
oderu^t me retribuam / inebriabo sagittas meas sanguine / et gladius meus
deuorabit carnes etc. Thou sholdest not be wroth against god / for he sends of
aduersytees and flagellacions for five consyderacyons. The first is unto the
sinners to the end yt they confess them / amend and purge them from sin /
and it is a token of love. For god wylleth not that they ben dampened / Vnde
appo. iii. Ego quos amo arguo et castigo Et alibi: ad hoc tendunt mala que
vobis infero vt reconsiliam me vobis dicit dn^s: ego cogito cogitationes pacis
and no^ afflictionis. Example in saint eustace unto whom god sent of
tribulacyons for to convert him and save him. etc. The second is unto sinners
obstynate in sin to the end that they begin their hell in this world as
herodes the which was eaten with hand worms and other worms. etc. The
third is to the good and just. For god them sends of trybulacyons to the end
yt they enpryde them not of the good deeds that they done / and for to keep
their virtues as god did unto saint poule. Vnde ii. ad corin. xii. Ne
magnitudo reuelationum extollat me / datus est michi stimulus carnis me

H Of the vengeance that god defends. Ca. xxvi.
THe sage says that he the which will venge him on his neighbor he shall
find vengeance of god. And also as he keeps his hate for to venge him wha^
he has oppertunyte. In like wise shall god do to avenge him on him for his
sins. Vn^. eccle. xxviii. Qui vindicari vult a dn^o inueniet vindictam / et
peccata illius seruans seruabit. When any person is offended / hurt / or

First for god has with holden and reserved to him and unto his vycayres to

when any is venged of himself he takes the office of god / as if he were god
and judge. Also he him makes judge and party in his own cause the which is
again right and reason Nullus debet ee^ iudex i^ sua propria causa: regula
iuris. Also justice ought to be done by counsayll. pro. xi. et. xxiiii. Salus
erit vbi multa sunt consilia. Health shall be where many counsaylles ben. Also
it ought to be done by great and meure delyberacyon / and all in peace
withouten have. The which thing ne does he the which him auengeth /
incontinent / but where a person has offended god he punyssheth him not ne
his officers / they abyden the time and the place to punysshe and to do
Justice. Legitur luce. xviii. Deus autem non faciet vindictam electorum suoru^
clamancium ad se die ac nocte: sed pacienciam habebit in illis. Example how a

after. quere lxxx. b. Another example how the jews ne weren in contynent

xviii. Descendam et videbo vterum clamorem qui venit ad me opere compleuerint:

A man should note that the vengeance the which is done by ire is unjust and
ill in four maneres. The first is when any punyssheth / or woide punysshe him
the which has not deserved it. The second is wha^ he him brings or would
bring to gretter pain than he has deserved. The.iii is when he infere / or
would inferer asmoche of pain egally as he has deserved / but not after the
order of justice as when he will punysshe any of himself without calling
justice and superyores / unto whom it apperteyneth for to do it. The fourth is
when any brings in or would bring in any just / and after the order of
justice but not by good and just entencyon / and for good end. The entencyon
of him yt which punissheth should other for the wealth and salvation of him the

called a good iusticier / in sechinge the preyse of the world / or to the end

K A questyon when it is that ire is good or when it is venyell sin or
mortal. Capitulo. xxvi.
DEsine ab ira et derelinque furorem / noli emulari vt maligneris dicit psalm.
That is to say cesse the of ire and leave furoure / ne have thou none envy
upon another that thou become not a curste. Men find in scripture that ire is
sometime good and leful / and sometime it is mean and veniel sin / and sometime
right ill and mortal sy^ne. Ire is good when it is again his own sins / or
again those of his neighbor without passion of his troblement. For a man
ought to have dyspleasau^ce to have offended god by sin or to se him
offended. And that dule or sorrow yt is taken for the said sins ben called in

again the sinners whereof Moses spoke unto the children of Israel / illud

it is declared before. / Quere ad numerum.xxii. c. and.xxv. b. Men make a
question. That is to understand whether it be lefull for to speak any foul

conuensieuses be not to speak if there be not necessyte. And not to the end that
they serve unto us / but unto our lord. In speaking such words a man should
have right great dyscrecyon and attempraunce / for he may speak such wyce that
he should dyshonoure the person. And that himself should sin mortally as

suddenly in ire and that forth with by reason he repents him / resystethe
and puts out such ire without will to venge him he ne synneth but venyally
Vnde cassiodorius dicit quod venialis ira est que non couritur ad effectum.
Also ye scripture says that when any feleth him hurt there sourdeth suddenly
a mouynge of courage impetuous yt which appetyteth vengeance is ire for as
much as he suffers. Vnde super illud mathei. v. Om^is qui irascitur fratri

L Of the remedies against the syn of ire. Ca. xxvi.
