those that curse you / and pray for your persecutoures the which wrongeth you
and dyspyseth you. And your reward shall be great in heaven. Vnde mathei. v. et
luce.vi. Diligite inimicos vestros benefacite his qui oderu^t vos benedicite
maledicentibus vobis / et orate pro persecut^ribus et calunniantibus vos et
erit merces vestra multa in celo. A man should note here yt the virtue of
pacyence is again the sin of ire / and therefore in all aduersytees /
iniuryes / sekenesses / and fortunes It is the very and sovereign remedy as to
bear pacyently.

A Of hate the which god defends. Ca. xxvii.
IT is written leui. xix. Non oderis fratrem tuum in cord. God made to tell unto
the children of Israhell by his servant Moses. Thou shall not hate thy
brother in thy heart. That is to understand by envy in thinking ill upon him
/ or in desiring the loss of his goods / or herytages / or the ill and
dyshonoure of his body / or the dampnacyon of his soul. It is written in the
same chapter leuitici. xix. Non facies calunniam proximo tuo: nec vi opprimes
eum. Thou ne shalt do no dyspyte unto thy neighbor / and thou ne shalt
chase him by force. Sith that god the commands that thou love thy neighbor
as thyselfe it follows well that he the defends that thou hate him not / and
that thou do unto him none ill / no more than thou would a man did unto the
/ love thy neighbor / than thou hate him not. It is written zach. viii.
Vnusquisque malum contra amicum suum ne cogitetis in cordibus vestris: et
iuramentu^ men dax ne diligatis omnia sunt que odi / dicit dominus. Every of
you or none of you ye thy^ke none ill again your friend in your hertes / and
love ye not the oath of a liar / god hates these things. Every man the which
dysobeyeth unto god synneth mortally. And every man yt which hates his
neighbor dysobeyeth unto god / than he sins mortally by the consequent he
puts himself from paradyse and byndeth him unto dampnacyon.

B The sin of hate is to dread and to fle for many things whereof we shall
tell five. The first is that for to hate his neighbor in desiring his ill a
man dysobeyeth unto god the which is so great sin / venim / and syknes unto
the soul that it chaseth from the hater charity and these other virtues and
lets all his gods spyrytuall that it ne may unto him proffyte as by
symylytude saying that sekenes corporell chaseth the health of the body. And
lets to drink and to ete / And other good that it ne may unto him profit.
And also as sykenes is contrary unto health and that thou ne may be hole /
and seek togyders. In like manner hate is contrary unto dyleccyon. And envy
unto charity the which ne may be togyders. For the logycyans says that two
things the which ben contraryes and opposytes the one unto the other ne may
be ne abide togyders but that ye one chaseth the other. Vnde duo opposita
nunquam possunt simul esse in eodem subiecto. Yt thou hate than thy neighbor
thou love him not. If thou have envy or wrath against thy neighbor or
even christian thou art out of charity. And if thou be out of the love and of
the charity of thy neighbor Thou art out of the love and of the grace of
god / thou ne love neither god nor thy neighbor. Vnde.i. iohannis.iiii. Si
quis dixerit quoniam diligo deum et tratrem suum oderit mendax est. That is to
understand if any will say yt he loves god and hates his even christian he is
a false liar. Iterum in eodem capitulo. Qui no^ diligit fratrem suum quem
videt: deum quem non videt quomodo potest diligere He the which loves not his
brother even christian that he sees / how may he love god ye which he sees not
/ hene may do it. for to give you in knowledge and to understand clearly / if
thou hate thy neighbor and even christian / thou love not our lord ihesu
christ / and thou art clean out of grace and charity / and thy virtues and thy
gods spyrytualles ben departed from the. Quia virtutes cum viciis remanere
vel parmanere non possunt. Then no good spyrytuell rests in the. And by the
consequent thou ne may be in such wise saved / but dampened with all the
deuylles of hell. Also saint Ambrose says. Qui caritatem non habet amyttit
omne bonum quod habet. He the which has no charity leseth all his spyrytuell
goods. And he the which hates his neighbor has no charity. For charity
is to love god and his neighbor / and it behooves that there be the one love
and the other / or charity is lost. For unto the dystruccyon of all one
diffynycyon or proposycyon it suffyseth that the one party be false / thus
says ye logyciens. Ad destructionem totius diffinitio^is vel prepositionis
sufficit vna pars esse falsa. And master Nycole de lyre says that by an ill
cyrcu^staunce all the deed is ill. Malum consistit in singulis defectibus: ita
quam vna circunstantia mala: facit totum actum mala. And the holy and blessed
saint poule says. Illud.i. ad corinth. xiii. Si linguis hominum loquar et
angelorum: caritatem aute^ non habuero factus sum velut es sonans aut cymbalum
tinniens. This auctoryte is expounded in the end of the chapter of charity
Quere.iiii. c. Example how a woman auoutres was dampened for the keeping of hate
without being in will to pardon. lxxviii. d. Another example how that a woman
aduoutres was dampened ye which trusted in the almesdedes that she had given.
Quere.lxxxxii. d. It is written eze chie.xxxiiii. that the justice of the just
and his almesdedes and good operacyons ne shall deliver him in any hour that
he has sinned. Also it is written in the said chapter as here after ensues.
Iustus non poterit viuere in iustitia sua in quacu^que die peccauerit. The
just ne may live in his Justice in any day that he synneth mortally / as to
hate his neighbor and even christian be it man or woman. Al manner of goods
spyrytual and temporal grows there as is peace / concord / and perfyte love /
and they less and dymynysshe where as is dyscorde / malice / wrath / Ire and
envy. Vnde ambrosius. Parue res concordia crescunt: magne vero res discordia
dilabuntur. Also every royalme the which is divided shall be desolate. Vnde
mathei. xii. Omne regnum in se ipsum diuisum desolabitur et domus supra domum
cadet.

C The second cause wherefore hate is to dread / is for that / that it is so
great a glayue and sword and offense that it sleeth spyrytuelly of death of
gylte the souls of haynours or hateful people the which hates their
neighbors and even christian by envy or malice desiring their vnfortune and
loss both in their bodies and goods vniustelye.i. vnde iohannis tertio
Oninis qui odit fratrem suum homicida est: et scitis quoniam omnis homicida no^
habet vitam eternam in se manentem. That is as much for to say. Every man the
which hates his neighbor in his heart is a man kyller and know ye that
every homycyde has not eternal life abiding in him. For by his hate he
departs froo god / his love / and his grace / the which is the life of his
soul. In like wise as it is declared in the commandment of homycyde and
murdre. Also by hate and cursed malice a man sleeth his soul spyrytuelly / in
like wise as a man may se by symylitude that a stroke with a swer defieeth a
man corporelly. For hate rancouce and envy and all mortal sins / is by
symylytude as a sword cuttynge of does sy^es the which stryketh the soul
for to dampne it. And if that remedy be not had therein in this world by
penance there is no health after the death. Vnde eccle. xxi. Quasi rumphea bis
acuta omnis iniquitas plage illius non est sanitas Also the sins be to flee
as from the face of a serpent. For they slay spyrytuelly the souls of men.
Vnde ecclesi. xxi. Quasi a facie colubrifuge peccata si accesseris ad illa
suscipient te dentes illius dentes leonis interficientes animas hominum. Note
well that a man should not understand that the souls ben deed / slain / and
that they defaylleth above al by sin / for they ben mortelles / but a man
should understand that they ben deed spyrytuelly / of death of gylte / and
dyscendeth in to the death eternel / the which is death without deyenge as it
is said before. For to avoid the said death it behooves to love our lord
Ihesu christ and his neighbors / and to flee hate. Saint Austyn says. Vita
mea dilectio est et mors odium. My life is dileccyon / and my death is hate. Et
legitur. de. peni. di. i. Omnis qui non diligit: manet in morte. Every man the
which loves not dwells in death. Et poeta dicit. Si quis odit fratrem suum
censetur ob hoc homicida. He is iuged for homycyde. etc. Example how a boy was
dampened for hate and that he would be venged Quere.lxxix. a. Another example
how the devil slew a man for the keeping of hate and would not pardon
him.lxxix. c.

D The third thing wherefore ye sin of hate is for to be dredde is for that
/ that it blyndeth the soul of the haynoure / that is to put out the inward
eyes of his understanding. Vnde.i.x.ii. Qui diligit fratrem suum in lumine
manet: qui autem odit fratrem suum in tenebris est et in tenebris ambulat: et
nescit quo eat quoniam obcecauerunt oculos cius. That is to say in our
maternall tongue of English to you the which understands not the laten. He
the which loves affectuously his even christian brother he dwells in light
And he the which hates him is in derkenes and walks in derkenes. And he ne
knows where he gothe. For derkenes has put out his eyes. His entendemente
is made derke / his light is lenyne / that is charity the which gives light
and shyneth is put out / charity is adnychylate and lost. Also in like wise
as the eyes of ye body of a person wexeth dy^me and derke for to behold
sharply the beaumes of the son. In like wise the eyes of ye soul ben put
out and made derke for to se ye wealth of their neighbor. Vnde gregorius Men's
inuidi tam de alieno bono affligitur quam de radio solis excecatur. By the
great light is understand here the haboundau^ce of the good operacyons of thy
neighbor / by the which good operacyons the enuyous haynoure is blinded of
duyl that he has to se them. Also thou hateful thy soul is in derkenes. In
likewise as a man may se by symylytude that the body of a blind man is in
derkenesse when his eyes ben put out. Thou seyth not the ylle that is in the
ne that that thou have for thy sin. And therefore thou may say. Iliud psalm.
Comprehenderunt me iniqiatates me et non potui vt viderem. Under stand well
when a blind man has lost his conductoure and leder he ne sees when he
falls in a dytche or in any danger / no more does the hateful when he
has lost his conductoure and leder the which is god / his lantern is put
out / that is charity as it is said. And therefore he sees not ne understands
ye inconuenyents wherein he falls and tombleth. Vnde prouer. iiii. Via
imptoru^ tenebrosa nesciunt vbi corruu^t. Et psalm. Via impiorum tenebre et
lubricum. Et eccle. xxi. Via peccantium complantata lapidibus / et infinem
illoru^ inferi et tenebre pene Also these hateful and enuyous ne may see the
goodness of their neighbor. For their malice and syn blyndeth their eyes. Vnde
legitur in libro sapientie. Eccecauit illos malitia illorum Also these hateful
ye which deyeth impenipente / they shall be sent into the land of myserye
and of derkenes. job. x. Verram misery et tenebrarum etc. As it was of him the
which entered at the weddynges without being clothed of the vestement
nupcyall or wedding garmente / yt is of charity. Vnde mathei. xxii. Amice
quomodo huc intrasti non habens vestem nuptialem: ligatis manibus et pedibus
eius proiicite eum in tenebras exteriores. / Bind ye him hands and fete / not
with cords but with the dyuyne justice / and cast him in to derkenesse / that
is in to hell. etc. Example. It is written in the.xi. chapter of exode / that
the king pharaon and his people had the.xi. plage of derkenes thycke by
punycyon / and the children of Israhell had light. etc.

E The fourth thing wherefore hate is to dread / it is for that / yt it puts
from paradyse. Quia deus non saluat impios vt dicitur job. xxxvi. of this
matter. Quere xliiii. b. c. d. e. f. g.

F The fyfte is for that that it byndeth unto punycyon and dampnacyon: Quia
iniusti punientur: et semen impiorum peribit. vt dicit psalm. Examples of people
hateful. Quere. lxxix. a. b. c.

G How hateful people should pardon / and pacyfye togyders the iniuryes and
offenses done and spoken if they will that god them pardon their sins.
Capitulo. xxvii.
IT is written mathei. v. ca. Vade reconsiliari fratri tuo. Thou hateful man go
to reconsile the with thy brother. The most sovereign remedy that the hateful
should do for to be in the love and in the grace of god / and for to have
paradyse when he shall depart out of this world is that he should put away
his hate and to go to pacyfye him with his neighbor And to pardon and forgive
him benygnely his trespass. For it is the right way for to make his peace
with god / and for to have salvation. Saint Gregorye says that by the love
that we have in god the love of our neighbor is engendered. And by the love
that we have unto our neighbor the love of our neighbor is noury^shed Vnde
gregorius in moralibus. Per amorem dei amor proximi gignitur / et per amorem
proximi dei amor nutritur. It is the most great thing and most pleasant
unto god to love his neighbor as himself / as all the sacrefyces and
oblacyons that we may do unto him. Vnde marci. xii. Diligere deum ex toto
cord and proximum tanquam seipsum / maius est omnibus olocaustimatibus and
sacrifiis. And therefore the holy euangelyst says that if thou do oblacyon unto
god at the alter and that thou record or remember ye that thy brother or thy
neighbor has any hate or thing against the leave thy gift before the alter
go first to pacyfye the with thy said brother / and afterward come offer thy
gift. Vnde mathei. v. Si offers munus tuum ad altar et ibi recordatis fueris
quoniam frater tuus habet aliquid aduersum te: relinque ibi munus ante altar /
et vade prius reconsiliari fratri tuo. The gloss and the expositours says
upon this paas there. Si frater tuus habet aliquid aduersum te. For that that
thou have him offended and wronged or hurt. That is yt thou sholdest leave thy
gift for to go pacyfye ye with him. And if he has offended the he should
come to the / thou ne sholdest go unto him / but thou art to pardon him In like
as thou would that god pardonned ye thy sins. And when thou ne will pardon
him he shall goo again the / and god ne shall pardone the thy sins as you
shalt here herafter. Saint peter demau^deth of our lord / if my brother sin
in me seven times will thou that I pardon him till unto the seventh. And our
lord him answered. I say not alonely till unto the seventh time / but I say
unto the if he repent him / and that he demand the pardon / that thou him
pardon till unto four hundred.lxxxx. times. Vnde mat xviii. Non dico tibi vsque
septies sed vsque septuagesies septies. Et luce. xvii. Si septies in die
peccauerit inte frafer tuus et septies in die conuersus fuerit ad te dice^s
penitet me dimitte illi. If thy brother has sinned in the by seven times in a
day and that he be converted unto ye seven times in a day saying I repent me
/ pardon him. Our lord Ihesu crystis so pypeous / merciful / and so full of
charity / yt all those the which him has offended / if they will repent them
/ amend / and demand grace and pardon in doing penance that he pardonneth
all benygnely and with good heart. Vnde Ezechie. xviii. Si autem impius egerit
penitentiam. etc Vita viuet and non mortetur: ominum iniquitatum eius non
recordabor. He gave pardon and forgyuenes unto Longis the which perced his
side with a spear / and is sauyd in the realm of paradyse with all the blessed
seyntes. He gave pardon also unto the good thief Dysmas the which hanged on
his right side on good friday. And if he be so merciful to give pardon He
wylleth also that in like wise we do unto them the which us has offended /
And if we so do we shall be his children / imitatours regynynge and parteyners
in his realm / and we shall pardon our sins if men us requires. Vnde
mathei. vi Si dimiseritis hominibus peccata eorum dimittet et vobis pater
vester celestis peccata vestra. That is to say / if ye have left or forgiven
unto men their sy^nes / your fader celestyall shall forgive you your sins. Et
legitur ecclesias. xxviii. Belinque proximo tuo nocenti te: et tunc deprecanti
tibi peccata soluentur. And if thou will not pardon unto thy neighbor his
offenses that he has done unto the and if he the require / god shall not
pardon ye offenses that thou unto him haste done. Vnde mathei. vi. Si non
dimiseritis hominibus peccata eorum: nec pater vester dimittet vobis peccata
vestra. Et augustinus dicit quod vnusquisque talem indulgentiam accepturus est
a dn^o qualem ipse dederit proximo. Every man and woman shall have such
indulgence of god as he has given unto his neighbor. Also if god pardon the
many sins in confession and that you be so unkind that thou wylt not pardon
unto thy neighbor / god shall redemaunde and axe the that / that he unto the
has pardonned for thyn unkindness / you should be merciful unto another as
thou would that a man should be unto the.

H Example in the euangelyst. mathei. xviii. of him the which owed unto his
lord. x. M. talentz the which had not therwt to pay it / he asked mercy of
the lord and he quyted him and gave him al his debt And incontinent that
servant made to put in captyuyte a servant of his the which ought him but an
hundred pens / and for any prayer that he could make / he ne would have mercy
ne pardon him his det And when the lord herd it / the which had pardonned
him the great det he was right wroth and angrye of the unkindness and of the
hardness of ye said servant that he ne pardonned the little debt / and
incontinent made him for to come before him and said unto him. Illud mathei
xviii. Serve nequam omne debitum dimisi tibi: quoniam rogasti me / no^ne
oportuit and tu misereri conserui sicut and ego tui misertus sum. Cursed
servant I had for given the all thy debt / for thou have prayed me / was it
not conuenyent unto the yt thou had mercy on thy servant in likewise as I
have had mercy of the. The said lord made to take him / and to put him in
prison / and him demanded al yt that he had him pardonned. And in like wise
shall god do unto them the which ne wyllen pardon unto their neighbors as
says the said euangelyst. Upon this matter there are many oppynyons. For so me
says that as before is written / that god shall redemaunde the sins that he
had pardonned for the unkindness. The other says that it behooves not to
understand that in the said word there is totale symylytude. For that that
god has one time pardonned / hene shall redemau^de it ne yet punysshe it more.
Quia non punit deus bis inidipsum: et quia deus est pronior ad miserandum quam
ad puniendum ita quia est imitabilis. And it should seem that he were muable if
he demanded yt / that he before had pardonned and forgyuen unto the wretchyd
sinner in this world / as did the beforsayd lord of whom is made mencyon in
the said euangelyst. But there is symylytude in that that where the foresaid
lord reproved his servant of unkindness done unto ye other man and punysshed
and put him in prison. In likewise shall god unto those that been unkind the
which ne will pardon their even christian as the said servant did / and unto
them shall say. Serve ne quam. etc. And them shall send in to ye prison of
hell / there for to remain for evermore in pain and dystresse / not for
their sins that before he had pardonned / but for their unkindness to their
even christian Also some say that the said unkindness is so great sin and
grievous that it may not be like in grauyte unto ye sins pardonned or forgyuen
before. And therefore the haynoures and hateful people should pardon or they
shall be punysshed eternally without any remyssyon. Also he ye which ne will
pardon / prays unto god yt he ne pardonne him his sins when he says his
pater noster in saying dimitte nobis debita nostra sicut et nos dimittimus
debitoribus nostris. That is to say Pardon us our sins in like wise as we
them pardon unto them the which has us offended. Men find that the emperor
Theodosyen held unto great bou^te when a man him required and prayed
faithfully that he would pardon him and forgive him. And the more that he was
wroth and angrye / ye more sooner he pardonned. In like wise should we do by
charity. etc. And in as much as the said gospel of saint mathieu says illud
mathei v. Relinque ibi munus tuum ante altar. Leave thy gift before the alter
/ that is to understand yt god refuse not thy gift And so ne wylleth yt thou
it bring again for thou sholdest give it / but he wylleth yt thou defferre and
that thou it offer in charity without the which it is not meritorious till
that thou haste taken away thy hate. Quia sanctus thomas dicit. Nullus homo
potest mereri nisi media^te gratia. No man ne may do thing merytoryous but
only by ye mean of grace. And in as much as he says vade / not alonely
with fete / but with that in humble courage for to bow the down and to humble
the to demand pardon and forgyuenes And to pacyfye the with thy said brother /
And afterward come for to offer thy said gift / and it shall be unto god
agreeable and unto the good and merytoryous / vtyle and prouffytable. The manner
to reconsyle him with our lord Ihesu christ and with his neighbor after that
as says master Johan crysostome upon the said euangelyst. Si offers munus
tuum. etc. Si cogitatu offendisti cogitatu reconsiliare / si verbis / verbis /
sifactis / factis. etc If thou have hated thy neighbor alonely in thyn heart
without speaking ne doing ill / take away thy hate / pardon hy^ with thyn
heart without vengeance and reconsyle the with god and with thyselfe / without
speaking unto him / and if thou have offended by words / also reconsyle ye by
words. And if thou have offended by deed reconsyle the by deed / for so
sholdest thou do.

I Epample. It is written in some places and reherced in the book of the
dyscyple how a knight slew the fader of another knight / the which would
venge him of the death of his fader / but he ne might find the said homycyde
unarmed and vnpuruayed for to kill him. And one time on the good frydaye that
god was crucyfyed the said knight yode barfote unarmed for to require pardon of
the other knight the which knight also soon as he saw him he drew out his
sword for to have taken vengeance on him / and came toward him. Than the
other knight fell prostrate at his fete and said unto him. I beseech you and
require you for the love of him the which on this day has been crucyfyed for
us on the mount of caluary yt ye pardon me that yt I have offended again you to
have slain your fader. And yt knight took him up and pardonned him al for the
love of our sauyoure Ihesus. And in token of pardon and reconsylyacyon he him
embraced and kyssed. And when it came to the offrynge that the said knight
yode to kiss the cross as he was accustomed than Ihesus on the cross
embraced the said knight with his arms and kyst him before all ye people / and
a voice was herd of all that was there. Thou the which have pardonned on this
day him the which has slain thy fader for the love of me. And I pardon the
this day al thy sins. And in that knight was accomplysshed that the which
is written. Luce. vi. dimitte et dimittimini. Forgive and me^ shall forgive you
/ pardon and men shall pardon you. And those that been obstynate the which will
not pardon as it is said shall have no pardon what so ever confession that
they make. Vnde ysodorus de su^mo bono. Erustra deum sibi propitiari querit qui
cito in proximo placari negligit. He ye which dysprayseth to pacyfye with his
neighbor / for nothing secheth he to endebonayre god in him. Example of a
man yt the devil slew for keeping of hate and ne would pardon. lxxix. c.
Another example of a woman dampened for the keeping of her ire without being in
will to pardon. lxxviii. d. Another example how the devil wend to let saint
Thybault to concord the barons of the company the which were in diuysyo^n.
Another example. cxii.l

K How envy and all her branches and dependences ben defended by this
commandment. Ca. xxviii
Saint Austyn says quam inuidia est dolor aliene felicitatis. Ennye the which
god defends is to have doloure / heaviness and bytternes to se that his
neighbor abounds in temporell goods / or spyrytuell. Also he reioyseth him
to se the ill / the do^mage / the ruin / dampnacyon / and perdycyon of his
neighbor is envy that god defends. Vnde prouerbi. xxiiii. Cum ceciderit
inimicus tuus ne gaudeas / et in ruina eius ne exaltet cor tuu^. Thou shalt
not enjoy the when thine enemy shall be fallen. And thyn heart shall not
exalte in his ruin. Et legitur prouer. xviii. Qui in ruina letatur alterius:
non erit i^punitus. He the which enjoys him in ye ruin of another shall not
abide vnponysshed. Envy is a cursed tree / his rote is he uynes / his stroke
is malice / his branches ben rancoure and hate / his flowers ben palenes / and
lenenes / the fruit is worth nothing / it is but bytternes. wherefore ye tree
is not good but to brenne in the fire of hell Vnde ma. vii. Omnis arbor q^ non
facit fructum bonum excidetur / et in igne^ mittetur. Every tree / that is
every person ye which ne does good fruit / that is good operacyons shall be
cut / yt is taken from this world and sent in to the fire of hell Also by
envy for to noye his neighbor the enuyous says of him many ill words by
detraccyon / susurracyon / and mockerye for to put him from his good reno^me /
and to menysshe his good. This matter is declared in the.viii. commandment
Also by envy many process / noyses / hates iniuryes / wars / bataylles / and
occysyo^s ben done / ye which to have dampnacyon and perdycyon. Also by envy
of the devil death dampnacyon and perdycyon ben comen in to this world. And
those the which ben enuyous follows the said devil and shall go with him in
to hell in perdycyon if they deye impenytentes. Vnde sapientie. ii. Inuidia
diaboli mors intrauit i^ orbem terrarum / mittatur autem illum qi sunt ex patre
illius. Also by envy Cayn slew his brother Abell / as it is written in the
examplary. Quere. lxxvi. Also by envy Joseph was sold of his own bredren ye
which said unto their fader that they had found his gown all blody and
that he was deed. And their said fader said illud genesis. xxxvii. Hera pessima
deuorauit filiu^ meum joseph. A cursed be has devoured my sone joseph /
that is envy. etc. Charity the which is again the sin of envy is here
commanded / the which is ye mother and the cause of all virtues in like wise
as it is declared before. Quere iiii. a.

A. Of the virtue of pacyence the which is again the sin of ire. Ca. xxviii.
IT is written prouerbiorum. xii. Non contristabit iustum quidquid acciderit ei.
The sage says that the just wratheth him not by passion of ire ne of
trobleme^t for pain ne aduersyte yt to him comes / For he bears all
pacyently for the love of god. Patience in aduersyte is a virtue / by the
which the bounte of ye man is proved in like wise as men shall here hereafter
/ And it is to be noted that pacyence in trybulacyon makes the man pacyent to
ha^^ ^any goods spyrytuelles. First pa^^^nce in trybulacyon enlumyneth the
en^endement of the man and it makes for to know himself. Vnde ysaie. xxviii.
Tantummodo sola vexatio dabit intellectum auditui. Secondly pacyence in
tribulacyon makes the man sage and governs by great prudence / and he ye
which is impacyent lyfteth up himself and shows his folly. Vnde
prouerbioru^. xiiii Qui paciens est multa gubernatur prudentia / qui autem
impaciens est exaltat iustitiam suam. Et legitur prouerbiorum xix. Doctrina
viri per pacientiam eius noscitur. The doctrine of the man is known by his
wisdom. Example how the sone of Abraham Ysaac sustained pacyentely when his
said fader would a made sacryfyce of him. Quere in the exemplayre li. a.
Thyrdly pacyence in aduersyte keeps the virtues and ye spyrytuell goods of
the soul as the coffre and the purse keeps the money and the treasoure of
the man. Vnde. lii. xxi. In pacientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras.
Example how David was much pacyent again the wars and torments that Saul
did unto him and would not slay him / where he might well have done it many
times if he had would as it is written.i. regum xxiiii. Also when he cut one
part of his mauntell and when he found him a sleep. Vt habetur.i. regum.
xxvi. And if the theuys breketh the coffre lightly they take the treasoure.
Also if a man be broken in trybulacyon by impacyence lightly the devil takes
and deceyueth the soul. Legitur ecclesiastici. xxi. Cor fatui quasi / vas
confractum et omnem sapientiam non tenebit. Fourthly pacyence in trybulacyon
and sweet words in answer appeseth the ire of his enemies. Vnde prouerbioru^
xv. Vir iracu^dus prouocat rixas qui autem paciens est mitigat suscitatas. In
eodem capitulo. Responsio mollis frangit iram: sermo durus suscitat furorem. Et
ecclesiastici. vi. Verbum dulce multiplicat a micos: et inimicos mittigat.
Sweet words multiplieth friends / and makes soft the enemies. Example in
Ihesu christ ye which never proffered ill word against them the which
wronged him / persecuted and put unto death / but bare all pacyently. Fyftely
pacyence in trybulacyon makes god to enhabyte with the pacient Vnde psalm.
Iuxta est dominus his qui tribulato sunt cord. Iterum psalmi. Cum ipso sum in
tribulatione. Example in the life of faders how as these deuylles in the gyse
of beestes bette and tormented saint Anthony / god them chased and him aided
in his trybulacyon. Than saint Anthony said unto god / where were thou my lord
Ihesus / wherefore ne had thou comen at the beginning. And god said unto
him. Anthony I was here / but I abode thy strife to se how thou would resyst
And for as much as thou haste well resysted in pacyence. I shall make to be
renommed of the through out all the world. Syxtely pacyence in trybulacyon
makes man vyctoryous and knight before the king celestyall dygne of more
great reward and praise than he the which has vaynquysshed his enemies /
breketh ye battle and wynneth the iourneye. Vnde prouerbiorum. xvi. Melior est
paciens viro forti and qui dominatur animo suo expugnatore vrbum. Example how
job was pacyent when he lost his goods and his children and he wrathed him
not but blessed god. Vnde job. i. Dominus dedit dominus abstulit: sicut domino
placuit ita factum est sit nomen domini benedictum Another example how ye three
children were pacyente in the furneys and therein blyssed god / as it is written
danielis. iii. And they ben dygne of praise and of reward eternell. It is
written in the third chapter of the appocalypse. He the which has
vay^quysshed shall be clothed in white clothes / and I shall not put out his
name of the book of life. And I shall confess his name before my fader and
before his aungelles. Also it is written. He ye which has vaynquysshed in
this wretchyd valeye of myserye I shall give unto him in my kingdom of heaven
that he shall be with me in my throne. And it is written in the second chapter
of the appocalypse. Be faithful and true till unto ye death and I shall give
the the crown of life / He the which has vaynquysshed shall not be hurt of
the second death. And it is written in the first chapter of the epystles of
saint Iamys. Blissed be that man the which suffers temptacyon / for when he
has be approved he shall take ye crown of life that god has promised unto
those the which loves him. And if it be so that the person be vaynquysshed
by tribulacyon he leseth the reward and ye glory of the good knight pacyent.
Vnde prouerbiorum. xix. Qui impatiens est sustinebit damnum. He the which is
impacyent shall sustain dommage and hurt. Seventhly the man pacyente the
which is among his enemies wronged and tormented deserves to have a crown
of glory as the martyrs. And ye man or woman the which is impacyent in
trybulacyon leseth the crown the which was retained for him or her if they
had well foughten against the temptacyon of the devil. Vnde. ii. ad
thimoteum. ii. Qui certat in agone non coronabitur: nisi qui legi time
certauerit. Eyghtely the man the which bears and takes pacyently the
sekenesses and trybulacyons here byneth in this wretched valeye of mysery for
his own sins and trangressyons after confession it shall serve him of
penance and of medecynes for to purge him and make him clean of his iniquytes
and trespasses The wise man says in the ecclesiastice. Altissimus de terra
creauit medicinam: et vir prudens non abhorrebit illi. Also the virtues ben
better and parfayte in sekenes when the man it bears patiently. vnde.ii. ad
corin. xii. Virtus in infirmitate perficitur. And those the which endures the
death wylfully for their own sins / and defautes after confession. When they
ben seek in their beds or when they ben hanged and made to deye as the good
the fethe which was put to death when that our lord suffered his passion. It
is right great penance much merytoryous wha^ it is borne pacyently. And
therefore god said of good right unto the said thief. thou shalt this day be
with me in paradyse. / Hodie mecu^ eris in paradiso. Vnde apo. xiiii. Beati
mortui qui in domino moriu^tur. Blessed be those that been deed ye which deyeth
in our lord / their death is much precious before god. Vnde psalm. Preciosa
est inconspectu domini mors sanctorum eius. And unto the contrari the death of
sinners impacyent is right ill. Eccles. xli. O mors quam amara est memoria tua
homini iniusto. Nynethly pacyence in trybulacyon makes to god in to paradyse.
/ Vnde actuum. xiiii. Per multas tribulationes oportet nos intrare in regnum
dei Also of those the which have had of tribulacyons in this world it is
written in the apocalypse that saint Johan saw one time so great a hepe of
people that a man ne might nombre them the which praised god. And he demanded
of one of the auncyentes what these people were that were there. Vnde apo. vii.
Niqui amitti sunt stolis et albis qui sunt: et vnde venerunt. R. Hi sunt qui
venerunt de tribulatione magna et lauauerunt stolas suas and dealbaueru^t eas
in sanguine agni ideo su^t ante thronum dei: et seruiunt ei in templo eius: et
qui sedet in throno eius habitat super illos. Without pacyence none ne comes
unto perfeccyon / none ne has vyctorye / for who so leseth patience he is
vay^quysshed / and if he have pacyence he is glorious. The cup of gold
suffers many strokes and of fire before that he come unto the kings table.
And the chalyce before that it be lift up and set on the auiter for to sing
mass. Many great strokes suffers the tonne before that the wine be put
therein. Much is the robe of scarlet de foylled before that it be worn. And
unto this may a man find as many of examples as there are of crafts within
London. In like manner before that thou goo before god thou ought to be well
puryfyed and made clean from sin. And to be precious as the gold / hard as
ye iron it behooves to have pacyence in trybulacyon / that is the yate whereby
the just persons enters in to paradyse. Hec porta domini iusti intrabunt in
ea^. vt dicit psalmista.

B Also pacyence in trybulacyon makethe a man to have six vtylytees after. vi
propretees that the fire has. Primo the fire shyneth and gives light / too
does trybulacyon as says Ysaye. xxviii. Tantummodo sola vexatio dabit
intellectum auditui. Secundo. The fire bre^neth the wodde and the things
combustibles so does tribulacyons the delectacyons of the body and of the
world. Tertio. The fire makes soft the led / ye iron and the things hard.
In like wise trybulacyon and loss of goods makes sort hertes / and makes
them to cease and to hold rygoure. Quarto. The fire purges and makes clean
the ruste of ye iron and of metal. In like wise trybulacyon purges the man
from the ordure and fylth of sin / and him makes to confess and to require
god. Mala q^ nos hic premiu^t ad deum nos ire compellunt. Quinto. the fire
prouueth the gold in the furneyse for to understand if it be good / pure /
and clean In like wise god sends of trybulacyo^s unto man to the end that he
be prouued manyfestly if he be good or ill for to have trybulacyon in good or
ill / how be it that god him knows well. Vnde psalm. Probasti nos deus igne
nos examinasti sicut examinatur argentum. Iteru^ psalm. Domine probasti cor meum
and vesitasti nocte igne me examinasti. Et legitur eccle. xxvii Vasa figuli
probat fornax and homines multos temptatio tribulationis. Also for to know
that that is within a person him behooves to speak some iniurye that prycketh
him / and his courage shall appyere without forth. Vnde hugo de sancto victore.
Qualis vnusquisque aput se lateat: illa ta iniuria probat. Sexto. The hete of
the fire goes upward. In like wise tribulacyons makes the persons to take heed unto god to the end that they possede paradyse / unto the which we may go
cum illo qui est benedictus in secula. Amen.

A Here follows the syxte commandment of god / the which treat of theft
and avarice. Capitulo. xxix.
Nothing of other men's you shalt take
By theft / extorcyon / ne gyle
A full strayte account must thou make
Live thou long or little while
IN the old testament is written this commandment deuteroum. v. ca. and leui.
xix. Non facies furtum. Thou shalt do no theft in manner what so it be / or
ill shall come unto the if thou deye without correccyon and amendment / in
like wise as thou shall find by many examples Quere. lxxx. a.b. This word
here theft to take it generally comprehends under it all auaryce / ye which
is defended by this commandment and all sacryleges / all pylleryes / symonyes
/ vsuryes / treasons / trecheryes / frauds / begylynges / decepcyons / and all
other cautelles / branches and dependauntes that a man may recompte by the
which the esperyte dyabolyke may bring in mind unto the auarycyous of what
estate that he be to take and to draw unto him the goods of another unjustly
And here is commanded the virtue of justice as well dystrybutyue as
coniunctyue the which us adresseth to yield unto every man that that unto him
apperteyneth Vnde math. xxii.c. Reddite que sunt cesaris cesari: and que sunt
dei deo. And for as much as couetyse is the rote of all ill. In like wise as
says saint pouie. i. ad this motheum. vi. Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas.
And how yt rote extends her savor and humor in all the persons of the
world. For from the least till unto ye most great all estudyeth and takes
head unto auaryce and does trycherye / frande and decepcyon the one unto the
other. In like wise as says the prophet Hieremy. vi. A minore qippevsque
maiore^ oe^s auaritie stude^t and a propheta vsque ad sacerdote^ cu^cti faciu^t
doiu^. Wherefore it follows yt this commandment is oftymes broken and that
theft and auaryce brings many to dampnacyon / as it is delared here after by
chapytres. B. And first.

Of theft that god defends. xxix.
NOn furtum facies. Thou shalt do not theft / the which is committed when a
man takes ye goods of another unjustly / fraudelently / and secretly against
the will of the master unto whom they belong / and without right and reason.
Many sorts of thieves reygneth in the world in likewise as the experyence
techeth it us. There ben some the which ben covered the which steleth
secretly the goods of another unjustly / the which breketh this
commandment / and ben hanged when they ben known. The good man Thobie feered
this sin. For on a time his wife brought a kydde in to his house / When the
good blind man herd it cry he said. Beware yt it be not comen of theft for
it behooves us not to ete / ne to touch any thing that is comen of theft /
yield it again unto the owner. Vn^ thobie. ii. No^ licet nobis aut edere de
furto aliqui dant contigere. etc. Some there ben the which ben pryue and of
those there be^ two sorts For the one does the great theftes / as the balyfs
/ sheryfs / and receyuers / the which steleth the amends and fynes and many
other things from their lords. The other does the little theftes as the
children and servants of an house the which steleth the breed / the meet /
the wine / bear / or ale / and the capons / and hens. etc. The thieves
companyons ben they the which ben parteyners unto the theft in partynge it /
or the which have of gifts / or ye which them byeth / or the which
cou^ceyleth that it be done / or the which them commands to do it / or
those the which defends the thieves / or those the which the^ lodges and
receleth / or the which ben present when they ben done / it sees /
understands / and knows / and accuses them not ne repreueth / nor them
correcketh unto their power. Qui tacet consentire videtur. et in decre. Agentes
/ pacientes / consentientes / pari pena pumentur. xvii. q. iiii. Omnes. As
much is he worth that holds as he that fleyeth. Also those ye which have
not accomplisshed the testamentes and ye bequestes of those yt ben deed
wtholdynge the goods ben thieves / and shall have punycyon if they deye
impenytentes without correccyon and restytucyon. Example how the deuylles bare
away the soul of a man the which had withholden ye horse of a deed knight
/ the which had given it unto the poor people. Quere in the examplary. lxxx.
C.

C. A questyon. For to understand if a man commyt theft in taking of a
lytelll thing as of a great thing. The answer is / ye. For theft is taken
where a man takes unjustly the thing of any person be it great or little.
And in theft god takes head unto the heart of the thief and not unto the
thing that he takes. Vnde primi regum. xvi. capitulo. Homo videt eaque parent
dominus autem intuetur cor. Et indecre. Hurtum est iniusta ablatio rei quamtu^
cunque parua sit. xiiij. q. vi. ca. vltimo Quia in furtu non quod ablatum: sed
meus fure^ it is atte^ditur. xiiij. q. vi. capitu. vltimo. And this is to be
understand when ye thought is such that he would take also with good will a
great thing if he might / or as of yt little thing taken the lord entendeth
to be grieved. And saint Thomas secunda secunde questione. lxvi. If any take a
little thing theuysshely / and that he unto whom apperteyneth the said thing
ne repute that a man do unto him noysaunce / and also that he the which takes
presumes yt that thing the which he takes is not against the will of the
lord or owner unto whom it apperteyneth and belongs / and when that it is
in such manner committed he is excused of theft. Otherwise it is mortal
sin / for it is again the dyleccyon of his neighbor unto whom a man does
nuysaunce. Also saint Thomas says that in such little things if any have
courage to stele or to do nuysau^ce unto his neighbor that he sy^neth
mortally. And therefore little theft is to dread as great / for if any do unto
his wyttynge do^mage with his beestes in the meadows or labors of his
neighbors / or if he take the fruytes of trees / as appylles / peris benes /
pesen / or hunters the which does do^mage in the corns with their hounds
etc. such people ne should be assoylled if yt they ne will make restytucyon of
the dommages that they have done. Vnde dicitur in decre. Inferens damnum
proximo no^ est absoluaundus: nisi prius damno secundum arbitrium lesi
restituo. xiiii. q. vi. co^petimus. It is that that before is written Nothing
of other men's thou shall take by theft ne by deceyte / if thou haste you
must yield it or thou shalt never se god in the face. The sin of theft
noyeth unto the soul of the thief in many maneres First theft puts the
soul unto pouerte of goods spyrytuelles / for it chaseth and makes to put in
forgetefulnes his virtues and good operacyons lately gotten. Quere ad numerum.
lxiiii. b. Secundo. Theft lets to get of virtues and goods spyrytuelles in
as many of manners as a man will get. Quere post. xliiii. c. Example how that a
servant ne might receive his creator of the hand of saint Thomas / till that
he had confessed that he had stolen of fygges from his master. Quere in the
examplayr four score and one. b. Tertio The theft dyffameth the thieves in
this world when they ben known and hanged. Quere post ad numerum. xliiii. d.
Example of a thief the which was arrested dyuynely with his theft upon the
grave of a deed body. Quere in the exemplayre. lxxx. b. Quarto. The theft
blind the ye soul of the thief in such manner yt he sees not the good that
he leseth / and ye line and bond in the which he puts him. Quere ibi post
ad numerum. xliiii. e. etiam. Quere. xxvii. d. Quinto. The syn of theft is a
place by the which the thief is taken by justice and hanged on the galowes. Or
it is a place by the which ye great hangman the devil hangs the thief on
the gybet of hell / and keeps him from rysynge and mountynge in to paradyse
/ in like wise as it is declared here after.: / Quere ad numerum. xliiii. f.
Example how a monk saw by permyssyon dyuyne of rich men hanged in the fire
of hell Quere in the examplayre. lxxxiiii. d. Another example how that a thief
usurer was tormented in hell / out of whom proceeded a dry tree on the
which was hanged those of his lygnage the which had not wylled to resyste
when they lived in this world. Quere. lxxxvi. a. Another example how four men
of a lygnage were damned and hanged one after another for yt / that they did
possede falsely an heritage Quere. lxxxi. g. For that that a little bird
takes a little grain of corn fast by the grynne / he is happed by ye neck
and put unto death and perdycyon. Also for a little of another man's goods
that a thief takes he is gretely in do^mage / for ye fraccyon / and brekynge
of the commandment of our lord Ihesu christ is the cord the offense the
halter / whereby he is taken by the hangman the devil for to hang and strangle
him as it is said before. And for a little thing the which endommageth
another he endommageth himself gretely. For he leseth his goods / his body
and his soul etc. Sexto. Theft sleeth the soul of the thief spyrytually of
death of gylt In like wise as it is declared in the begy^nynge of the sin of
homycyde. Quere. xxiiii. b. and in ye chapter of hatred. Quere. xxvii.
Septimo. By theft the theuys be cursed and excommuned every sunday in the

is declared herafter. Quere. xlviii. b.

Octauo. The theuys should dread the judgment partyculer and general the

A Of sacrylege that god defends. capitulo. xxx.
AFter these masters. Sacrilege is in such wise dyffyned. Sacrilegium est
sacre rei violatio et eiusde^ vsurpatio. Sacrylege is vyolacyon of holly thing
and vsurpacyon of the same thing. Et dicitur sacrilegium quasi sacrum ledens
vel violans vel depurpans. And it is said sacrylege also as hurtyng holy thing
/ or vyllynge / or deturpynge. Sacrylege is committed sometime by reason of the
person / sometime by reason of the place / and sometime by reason of the thing.
It is committee by reason of the person when that any beteth a clerk or a
person relygyous. xvii. q. Quisquis. And it is a case reserved unto the pope
after the manner as the deed is committee. By the reason of the place as when
the chircheyarde or the church be violed / deturped / broken or burnt / or
such other semblables. Such people ben excommunyed and cursed of sentence de
droit ipso facto. By the reason of the thing as when that it is consecrate and
deputed unto holly usage of the church / and that it be usurped / rauysshed /
taken / or when of that thing a man abuses or uses vnlefully. This last
membre is dyuysed in three parties. For sacrylege is committed when a man
steleth or rauyssheth the holy thing within holy place / or wha^ a man takes
the thing not holy in holy place / or the holy thing in place not hallowed. In
like wise as it is written. xliii. q. iii. Quisquis. Sacrylege is a great sy^ne
much comune. for many ne makes charge for to take the goods of the church /
as rentes / revenues / oblacyons / dysmes / or other goods the which has been offered and given unto god and unto his church or unto any saint. etc.
Acurate has no power to absoyle of sacrylege / for it is a case reserved
unto the bishop. etc. For to speak of those the which handeleth ye money of
the church / a man should understand that if the receyuours or tresorers of
the goods of the church has been unfaithful in their charges and co^myssyons
/ that is to understand if they have comptes ye which be not good verytables
/ and loyalles or if they have compted more hye thanne they should in iourneys
put and dyspens. They ben thieves and yet wors than sacrileges to defraude and
to pylle the church Yet shall they compte one time before god in judgment where
they shall have ye payment after their desert. Vnde. psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique
iuxta opera sua. God is their party and Judge with whom they have to do. And
therefore if they have offended in any manner make in such wise their
appoyntement by penance and satysfaccyon or they shall have dampnacyon. / It
is written marci. x. Ne fraudem feceris. A person the which fraudeth ye
church fraudeth first of all his own propre soul / and he shall find no
prouffyte / but do^mage in the end of the causes. Vnde prouerbiorum. xii. Non
inueniet fraudulentus lucrum. The begyler ne shall find of gain unto his
soul. Also the sage says that in like wise as he ye which stryketh with a
spear or arowe for to slay another / him noyeth much / so does also he ye
which fraudulously noyeth unto his friend. Vnde prouerbiorum.xxvi. Sicut
noxius est qui mittit lanceas et sagittas in mortem / ita vir qui fraudulenter
/ nocet amico suo. Our friend that is god and his church and he the which
fraudeth the chirch of god noyeth him much / and therefore god shall punysshe
him. Vnde psalm. Vultus domini super facientes mala / vt perdat de terra memoria
eorum. The vysage of god looks upon them the which done ill to the end that
he lose from ye earth their memory. Also these unjust shall be punysshed and
the sede of the cursed shall perysshe. Vnde psalm. Iniusti punientur / et semen
impiorum peribit. Also some people ben infydeles unto the church the which
byeth the bread from the mother of god / or the appelles from the chircheyarde /
or other things the which have be given or the which apperteyneth unto god
or unto his saints / and afterward ne will pay them without being cyted or
adiourned or so long dyffereth to yield it that ye church has necessyte.
Such people knows that it is great offense and that they ben bound to
great satysfaccion / for they goo again the will of god. mathei. xxii. Reddite
que su^t cesaris cesari: et que su^t dei deo. Some men makes no conscience /
and says that they ben of those ye which has given the said bread unto the
mother of god / or that the appelles of the chirchyarde unto them apperteyneth.
Unto that I answer them that they have nothing therein / and that incontinent
that they have made any gift or any oblacion vnto^ god / unto the vyrgyn marye
/ or unto the saints of paradyse / they have no more nothing in the gift
that they have made the seygneurye and domynacyo^ that they had therein is
gone unto god / or unto his saints / they ne may do more nor dyspose
afterward unto their pleasure but that they have offended. And so it should
not return unto the usage seculers after the rule of right the which says.
Quod semel dedicatu^ est deo amplius ad humanos vsus reduci non debet.

B. Also some tresorers ben infydeles and dysloyall unto the church the which
takes the goods of it and gothe and aydeth unto their occupacyons seculers as
they should do of their own. And also they ne demand license ecclesyastyce.
A man should say unto such people that they open their vnderstondynges and
know yt they offend in many manners. First they defraude thentencyon of those
the which have given or founded the goods. Secu^do they retarye the
spyrytuell good / for parauenture the church has had thereof need. Tertio if
they them steleth from the church they shall be sacryleges. Quarto they go
again the droit written and again the will of god. The thing the which is
given or dedicate unto god / or unto his saints ne should return unto the
secularytees vsayges / so a man should not abuse it / it should incontinent and
without taryenge go in the usage of the said church or of the servants of
god in like wise as it has be establysshed. And if the people of the church
betake unto ferme muable their dysmes and revenues unto the seculers it is none
abuse / it is suffered / to the end to put them unto prouffyte and for to make
them the better in valor. Also to ye end that the people of the church may
ye more better take heed unto prayer / study and contemplacyon. Thou tresorer
answer me. Haste thou puyssaunce without leave to take the goods of thy
neighbor and for to aid the in thy necessyte: vel sic. have thou puyssaunce
to take them either unto thyselfe or unto another without ye will of them unto
whom they apperteyne / you sholdest answer me that nay. And also I sygnyfye
the that thou haste no power to take the goods of ye church / thou haste but
the hands as servant to put unto ye prouffyte of the church. And the
servant of a temporal lord has no power to go take the money of his
master and to aid hy^ in his necessyte / or to lend it at his pleasure / no
more have thou the goods of the church / and therefore in so doing thou
offendest god. Also thou tresorer when thy neighbor has given of his gods
unto the virgin marie or unto saint peter thou ne sholdest take them or put
them to ye building of saint poule. For thou sholdest defraude ye entencyon of
thy said neighbor the which is to give or to found Also thou take away
from the vyrgyn marye that thing that apperteyneth unto her. Also thou ne
accomplysshest justice the which is to yield unto every man the good that
apperteyneth unto him. Also saint poule is content of the good that he has
and that god him has given / the which will not yt thou take away from
another his good for to bring it unto hy^ and therefore in doing such thing you
sholdest go against god and of his justice / and sholdest be unfaithful unto
thy neighbor and unto the vyrgyn marye to defraude the^ Men say in commune
langayge that ye thing the which is given unto saint peter ne should be given
unto saint poule. etc. C.. Unto a man unfaithful a man ne should betake ye
gods of the church to keep / to receive / to dystrybute / ne office / cause
to judge / to appoint / to plede / to keep and to demene. For in him dare not a
man trust. The psalm. says. Deleantur de libro viuentium et cum justice non
scribantur etc. The people unfaithful shall not be written in the book among
them that be good / for they ne do the operacyons. The good and faithful
servants ben praised of god and of the world / and them should a man love as
himself. And the unfaithful ben dyffamed and put out. Audi scripturas.
legitur prouer. xxviii. Vir fidelis multum laudabitur. Et in eccle. Si est tibi
seruus fidelis sit tibi quasi anima tua. / If thou have a faithful servant
take hy^ unto the as dear as thy soul. Also a faithful friend is great
defense / he the which fyndeth him has found a treasour / no comparyson is
there unto a feythfull friend. Vnde eccle. vi. Amicus fidelis fortis protectio:
qui inuenit eum inuenit thesauru^ amico fideli nulla est comparatio. God shall
reward well his servants ye which ben faithful. Audi scripturas. legitur
apoca. Esto fidelis vsque ad mortem and dabo tibi coronam vite. Be thou
faithful till unto the death / and I shall give the / the crown of life. Also
god said unto Abraham the which was faithful. Illud genesis.xv. Merces tua
magna mecum nimis. Thy reward is right great with me Also god said unto Moses
that he was right faithful. Illud deutero. viii. Rerum omnium perfrueris
abundantia. Also he said unto his appostylles. Illud mathei. v. Gaudete et
exaltate ^m^ merces vr^a copiosa e^ in celis. Et luce. vi. Ecce eni^ merces
vr^a: multa est in celo. Enjoy ye and lift up your hertes for your reward is
haboundaunt in the heuens. God shall not say so unto the unfaithful people /
but he shall shyt ye yates of paradyse unto them And shall say unto them that
he knows them not. Nescio vos vn^ sitis descedittame. By these things
beforsayd ben understand that every tresorer should well examyne his
conscience if he have taken any thing / borne away / nor lend as it is said
ne done thing that is dysloyall in his said co^myssyon / for it is a charge
much to dread as to handle the money of ye church unto those ye which done
their deuoyr. For they ben bound unto restitucyon and unto great penance if
they will be saved / in like wise as thou shall find in the chapter of
restytucyon. Also those the which takes unjustly the good of ye church
should dread maledyccyon and excommunycacyon. For every person that has the
maledyccyon of god and of the church is gretely acurst. And those ye which
takes the goods of the church unjustly have their maledyccyon / than is he
much accursed. Also those the which have the maledyccyon of god and of the
church ben pryued from masses / prayers and oraysons of the church. And those
the which takes the goods as theuys sacryleges have the maledyccyon of the
church / Than they ben put from the said prayers and benefaytes of the
church. And by the consequente they ben acursed. Also these dysloyalles should
dread to lose paradyse When that a servant robs his master he puts him
out of his house and from his office and service. In like wise shall god unto
those yt takes his gods as it is said Example in judas yt which was put from
paradyse / and from ye nombre of the appostles and servants of god. Vnde ps.
E^tant dies pauci and episcopat si eius accipiat alter His days were abredged
and how another took his dygnyte and his office / he was appostle and
purseberer / he murmured of the precious oil yt Maudeleyne shed upon our
lord / and said yt it had been well sold for three hundred pens. And he said
those words because he was a thief / sacrylege and accursed. Also those yt
takes the goods of the church unjustly dread punycyon and dampnacyon. And
if they will not believe it by simple word or by these scriptures / yet put to
faith in the examples yt follows. First. Example how Heliodorus was terrybly
punysshed of punycyon dyuyne in taking the tresours of the church of
Iherusalem as thou shall find in the exemplayre.lxxxii. b Another example of
theuys sacryleges the which were punysshed because they had stolen the cross
and the goods of the church.lxxxii. d Another example in iulyen the apostat
ye which persecuted the church and he was slain myraculously.lviii. a.
Another example how relygyous people should dread ye syn of theft and
sacrylege for gyuynge the gods of the church to their parents. lxxxii f.g.
Another example how that an earl and many of his lygnage were dampened because
he posseded an heritage unjustly the which had be taken away from the
church.lxxxii. a. Another example how ye friar of doyen of Coleyn was dombe
and arested dyuynely / for that yt he denied the money of the church the
which had be lent him / and he ne would yield it again. lxxxii. c.

A. The examplayre and theleccyon of those yt well or ill pay their dysmes.
xxxi
IT is written deuteronomii.xiiii. ca. Decima^ parte^ seperabis de cuntis
fructibus tuis qi nascu^tur i^ terra per amos si^gulos decima^ frumenti tui et
vini et olei and primogenita de apme^tis et ouibus tuis: vt discas timere dn^m
deu^ tuu^ i^ oi^ te^pore. Thou shall depart ye tenth party of all thy fruytes
yt ben borne in ye earth every year. The tenth of thy whete and of thy wine /
and of thin oil. The first borne of thy beestes and of thy sheep to the end yt
thou learn to dread thy lord god in all times. The dysmes should be paid unto
god and unto his servants of right. And therefore those the which have stolen
or the which have nothing paid of dysmes of goods yt god unto them has
made to grow upon ye earth or the which has witholden any party or the
which has paid and given of the worste / or paid with ill will / or
suffered to lose the said dysmes without putting them unto prouffyte / and
sauete / or dyffer to long to pay them. This is here a great sin much to
dread / for it is again the will of god the which commands to pay the
dysmes cerymonyally in like wise as thou shalt here hereafter by scryptures.
And first thou shalt know yt god is the creatoure the which makes to grow
and to come thy corns / thy labors thy fruytes / thy bestyall and all thy
gods that the earth bears. And also thou sholdest know that god has
witholden and retained for himself the tenth party of al those fruytes and
goods growing in ye said earth. If thou will not believe it by simple word /
let him go study the scryptures in the chapytres the which shall be hereafter
alleged. And first it is written deutero. xii. Decimas et primitias manuum
vestrarum and vota atque deuorta primogenita bonum et ouium reddere precipit
dominus. That is to say. Our lord has commanded to yield the dysmes and
first fruytes / ye labors of your hands and your vows and gifts / ye first
borne of kyen and of sheep. And it is written deuto. xviii Ab his qi offeru^t
victimas sieve bouem sieve oue^ i^molauerint dabu^t sacerdoti premicias frume^ti
vini: et olei and lauarum partem ex duium tonsione: ipsum enim elegit dominus
deus tuus de cuntis tribubus tuis vt stet et ministret nomini dei tui. etc. Of
those the which offreth sacryfyces or the which have sacryfyced ox or sheep
they shall give unto the priests the first fruit of whete / wine / and of
oil / and ye part of the wolles of the clepynge of sheryng of the sheep. Thy
lord god has chosen that priest of all thy lygnees to the end yt he it
hold of the and admynystre in ye name of our lord. Also our lord sent unto
the children of Israhell when they should offer in deserte the words the
which ben written leuitici. xxiiii. Cum ingressi fueritis terram quam ego dabo
vobis et messueritis sagetes feretis manipulosspi carum messis vestre ad
sacerdotem. etc. When ye shall be entered in to the land that I shall give you
/ ye shall bear your hands full of ye erys of your corn unto ye priest. etc.
Et legitur leuitici. xxvii. Omnis decime terre sieve de fructibus sieve de pomis
arborum dn^i sunt: et illi sanctifica^tur. All the dysmes of the earth / be it
of corns / or fruytes / or of apples of the trees / they ben of our lords and
they ben sanctyfyed unto him. Et legitur numeru^. xviii. Vniuersas frugu^
primicias quas gignit humus domino deportantur. The vniuerselles first fruytes
and corns the which the earth engenders be borne unto god / If thou will
understand what it is to say primicias. Catholycon says that primicia
primicie dicitur a primis pluraliter he primicie prumiciarum. vulgo dicitur
quod primicie sunt proprie que primo de fructibus percipiuntur: vel que deo
offeruntur. Primicie they ben the new the first fruytes and corns that the
earth bears. Also primicia est prima pars frigum dn^o offerenda. And it is
written in the.vii. chapter of the epystylles saint poule unto the hebrews how
the priests the sons of leui taking the commandment had to receive the
dysmes of the people after ye law. Example of this matere of a lord the
which withelde the tennethe of ye gods that he gave unto his servant. Quere.
lxxxiiii. a. Augustinus dicit decime et debito requiruntur et qui eas dare
noluerit res alienas inuadit. That is to say yt the dysmes ben demanded of
right. For they ben due / and he the which ne has wylled to give them he
witholdeth things strange the which apperteyneth not unto him. And god
says in the gospel / mathei. xxii. Reddite que sunt cesarus cesari et que
sunt dei deo. Sith that it is so found in the scryptures that god has
wtholden for himself the tenth party of ye fruytes and corns the which
comes from year to year upon the earth as it is said / and that he wylleth and
commands cerymonyally that in such wise it be done. Those that dysmeth ill
understand they that they committee sin and that it is unkindness unto them
for to mysknowe their benefactour. Also those that ill dysmeth that may well
they shall answer at judgment partyculere / or general the which shall be
made of them before god in the court celestyall. For god shall be there judge
and party. Also they shall have so many of accusatours the which shall accuse
them of their sins that they shall see / and know themself that they ben
culpables Also those the which pays unto the.xi. or unto the.xiii. or unto
the.xxx. should understand that it is no dysme. It is an ill custom the
which has be bego^ne of covetous people / auarycyous and unkind the which
dysknoweth the good that god unto them has given. Those the which follows
such custom should dread that couetyse and auaryce ne put out their inward
eyes. Whereof it is written in ye book of sapyence. Malitia eorum eccecauit eos.
Their malice that is their sin has blinded them that they may not see
their ill. It is great peril and danger for the soul to follow the custom
and will of people auarycyous. For they goo unto dampnacyon if that they deye
impenite^tes etc.

B. The condycyons to pay well the dysmes. Many condycyons should those have
ye which will pay well the dysmes of the which we shall tell four. The first
is that a man should pay entyerly / again those the which pay nothing in
rekeny^ge five or six sheuys of corn and begyleth god of the half shefe / or
again those ye which pay nothing of the new fruytz eten in somer / as
peers / plo^mes / benes / and pesen. etc.. It is written eccle. xxxv. Bono animo
read gloriam deo et minuas primicias manuum tuaru^. Yield glory unto god by
courage and mynysshe not ye first fruit of the labors of thy hands. The
second is that a man should pay ioyousli without heaviness ne without having
grutche therein again those unto whom it seems that they lose that that they
give to the dysme / as if they should cast it down the water they offends
gretely. Audi scrypturas. eccle. xxxv. In omni dato hylarem fac vultum tuum et
in exultatione sanctifica decimas tuas. Make thy vysage joyous in every gift /
and sanctyfye thy dysmes in exultacyon. Et legitur. ii. ad co. ix. Hilarem enim
datorem diligit deus. / That is to say yt god loves the gyuer joyous. and
ysodorus says. Qui cu^ tristitia largitur remuneratio^is no^ percipit
fructu^. He the which gives and enlarges with heuines ne apperceyueth the
fruit of remuneracyon. Also a man ne should let lose the dysmes nor the thing
that apperteyneth to god. For it is written exo. xiii. Pru^^^ (...) trugu^ tree
tue deteres i^ domu^ dei tui. (...) first corns and fruytes of the earth y^
(...) bear them in to the house of thy lord (...) The third condycyon that a
man she (...) have for to pay well his dysmes is that a man should pay of the
best and not o^ ye worste / or that the which falls unto the tenth again
those the which given the corn eten trodden or full of drake / or agay^ those
the which takes for themself the good appelles and gives the ill / they
offend gretely. Audi scripturas. Legitur numeri. xviii. Oi^a que aftertis ex
decimis and in donaria separabitis optima: et electa erunt. All those things
the which ye offer in dismes and in gifts ye shall depart the best and they
shall be chose and agreables unto god. et legitur leui. xxvii. Quicqid decimum
venerit sanctificabitur dn^o no^ elegitur bonu^ nec malu^ nec altero
commutabitur. Si quis mutauerit quod mutatum est et pro quo mutatu^ est
sanctifica domino. Hec precepit dn^s moysi. What thing so ever it be that
comes the tenth shall be sanctyfyed unto the lord / the good nor the ill be
not chosen and it shall not be changed in to another. If any change it ye
thing the which is changed / and wherefore it is changed / santefye it unto
our lord Our lord has commanded these things here unto moyse. Et legitur
eccle. xxxv. Noli afferre munera praua non enim suscipi et illa deus. Offer
thou not ill gifts god ne shall take them. Et legitur iuce.xi. Ve vobis
phariseis qui decimatis mentam and ruta^ et oe^ olus preteritis iuditiu^ et
caritate^ dei. Woo be to you pharysyens the which dysme the little and ill
herbs and trespass ye charity of god. The fourth condycyon is yt a man should
pay without taryenge / nor to draw back till that a man be somoned / cyted
or warned. It is offense to tarry to give unto god yt which apperteyneth unto
him / or lend unto himself his dysmes till unto another year without spekyng
unto the curate. It is written exodi. xxii. Decimas tuas and premitias no^
tardabis of terre. Thou sholdest not tarry to offer thy dysmes / and thy first
corns and fruit. C.. We have example in Cayn and Abell of those that well or
ill pay their dysmes. From the beginning of the world god commanded unto
our forne faders yt they should pay ye tenth of their fruytes. And for as
much as they had not unto whom to pay it god commanded yt they should brenne
it and that they should make smoke ye which should mount in to heaven for to
do unto god honor and sacryfyce by obedyence / and in reknowlegynge yt the
said goods comes of god. Cayn and Abel yt were Adams sons made it. But Abels
was good for he dysmed well / and there his smoke mounted in to the heaven and
pleased god. Cayn was wicked and dysmed ylle / wherefore his smoke yede
downewarde toward ye earth and it pleased not to god. Also his land fructefyed
not well in fruytes and labors and bare thystylles / drake / and darnell / and
thorns. etc. And for asmoche as Abell was good and obedyent and loved of god /
and that his land fructefyed well and that al goods came unto him / cayn had
envy upon hy^ and slew him and was accursed. Vnde ge. iiii. Respexit dn^s ad
abelle et ad munera eius: ad cayn autem et ad munera eius no^ respexit.
Sequitur. Nunc maledictus eris super terram cu^ operatus fueris eam no^ dabit
fructus suos: vagus et profugus eris super terram. God looked upon Abell and
upon his gifts / for he made them well / And he looked not upon Cayn / nor upon
his goods / for he gave of the worste / and god said unto him. Thou shalt be
now accursed above the earth when thou shall labor it ne shall give her
fruit. Also ye be cursed in dysmes and first corns and fruytes. For ye have
frauded me of my part that I have witholden for myself Vnde. michee. iii. In
dicimis and primitus vos maledicti estis. etc. Glosa. Quia fran dastis me part
mea. The gifts of god for to pay well the dysmes. Those the which pay well
the dysmes have pryncypally.iiii. gifts of god. The first habou^daunce of
fruytes / labors and worldly goods as says the scryptures in many places.
Vnde malachie.iii. Inferet omne^ decimam in horeu^ meum: et sit cibus i^ domo
mea: and probate me super hoc dicit dn^s si non aparuero vobis catharactas celi
et effundero vobis benedictione^ vsque ad abu^ dantiam: et increpabo pro vobis
deuorantem. Glosa. Vermen vel virium aeris sequitur: et non corrumpet fructu^
terre vestre nec erit sterilis vinea in agro dicit dominus. That is to say
bear al dysme into my garnier and that that is to ete in my house / and prouue
me of this thing says god If I open not to you ye things of heaven and if I
shed not benedyccyon till unto haboundaunce. And I shall blame for you the
devouring worm and vice of ye air And he shall not corrupt ye fruit of your
land. And the vine shall not be barayne in the field says our lord. Example
of a lord the which paid well his dysmes and his vine bare of fruit two
times in one year quere in the exemplayre.lxxxiii. b. Et legitur leuitici.xxvi.
Dabo vobis pluuias temporibus suis: et terra gignet getmen suum / et pomis
arbores / replebuntur. et cetera. I shall give you of raynes in their times and
when they have need says our lord Ihesu christ. And I shall make the earth
for to fructefye and engendre his buddes and his flowers. And also ye trees
shall be replenysshed with apples. etc Et legitur deuterono.xi. Dabit pluuias
terre vestre temporinam et serotinam vel colligatis frumentum et vinum et oleum
fenum ex agris ad pascenda iumenta / et vt ipsi comedatis et saturenimi. Moses
said unto ye children of Israhell. etc. God shall give raynes couenables in
time unto your land / to the end yt ye gadre whete wine and oil / hay from
the feldes to pasture with your marys / and to the end that ye ete and be
fed. Et legitur prouerbiorum.iii. Honora dn^m de tua substantia and de
primiciis omniu^ frugu^ tuaru^ da pauberi implebuntur horea tua saturitate et
vino torcularia redundabunt. That is to say. Honor god of thy substance and
of the news of all thy corns and fruytes / give unto the poor and thy
graynes shall be filled of haboundaunce / and the pressers shall redounde of
wine.

E. Example in job yt which was true / obedyente / pacyent / and beloved of
god / for he dysmed right faithfully. Also after that he had be prouued god
sent unto him haboundaunce of al goods. It is written job. xlii. yt he
posseded.xiiii. thousand sheep. syx thousand camellys / two thousan couple of
oxen / and a thousand of asses. etc. Also Ioachin and saint Anne yt paid well
their dysmes and departed their goods in three parties / habou^ded in goods as
it is written in the legende of saint Anne. and unto the contrary. Those yt pay
ill their dysmes ben punysshed by maledyccyon of famyne and pouerte / as it is
said of cayn Legitur deutero. xii. Cauete ne forte de cipiatur cor vestru^ and
recedatis a dn^o. etc. Sequitur iratusque dn^s claudat celu^ et pluuie no^
descenda^t: nec tra det germen^ suu^: pereatisque velocit de tra optima. etc.
Beware lest parauenture your heart be dysteyned / and that ye depart not from
god and that he be not wroth and close the heaven / and that ye raynes dyscende
not / and that ye earth ne give his sede / and that ye perysshe not hastily from
the land right good and best and for the defaute to dysme well and to obey
unto god. The second good that those have the which well pay their dysmes /
is health of body / whereof speaks saint Austyn saying. Si decima^ been dederis
non solu^ abonda^tia^ fructuu^: sed etia^ sanitatem corporis consequeris. If
thou have well paid thy dysme thou shalt not alonely have haboundau^ce of
fruytes / but with that health of body. Also when thou haste done an almesdede /
health the more sooner shall come to the. Vnde ysaie. lviii. Cu^ feceris
elunosina^ sanitas tua citius orietur. And unto the contrary those yt ill
dysmeth god unto them sends sickness / as of ye gout / of the heed / of ye
stomach / of the axes. etc. The third gift that those have that pay well
their dysmes / is that god unto them pardonneth their sins after true
confession. Legitur prouer. x. Vniuersa delicta operuit caritas. Charity
covers all sins. Et legitur.i. petri. iiii. Anteoi^a inutua^ in
vobismeipsis caritate^ continua^ habentes qia caritas cooperit multitudine^
peccatoru^. The.iiii. gift is to possede the realm of paradyse and the great
gods and joys that there ben. Of these two last gifts speaks saint Austyn
and says. Qui primu^ desiderat habere aut peccatoru^ indulgentia^ promereri
decimam et de nouem pertibus cla^ dare studeat pauperibus: qi vero non dat
punitur i^ oppositis. He the which desires to have reward or to deserve to
have pardon of his sins pay his dysme and study to give unto the poor of
the nynthe parties of thy goods that with him abides. And those yt give not
as it is said / god punyssheth them by the opposyte. That those which will not
pay well their dysmes have not haboundau^ce of goods / health of body / ne
remyssyon of their sins. And also they ne shall possede paradyse if they deye
impenytentes after ye remedy that unto it apperteyneth. Many examples of those
the which pay well their dysmes shall be found in the exemplayre Quere.
lxxxiii. a.

A. Of vsurye the which god defendethe. Ca. xxxii.
IT is written in the.xxv. chapitre of the book of leuytes. Pecunia^ tua^ no^
dabis ad vsura^ / and frugum superhabu^dantia^ no^ exiges ego do minus vester.
Our lord made tell to the children of Israhel by his servant Moses. Thou
shall not give thy money unto vsurye / and thou shall not axe superhabou^dau^ce
of corns. etc. For to understand well the matter of vsurye / a man should know
that vsurye is sometime manifest and sometime hid / wrapped / diverse contractz
yt is defended by this commandment For god will not that a man sell the time
yt he has given in co^munalte. That is to say ye when a man lends any
thing god defends that he take ought over for dylacyon of time. For in such
manner a man sells ye time / wherefore he is an usurer. For without labourynge
they will have prouffyte / which is again the will of god as he said by his
prophet Dauyd. Labores manuu^ tuaru^ qia ma^ducabis. Thou shalt labor with
thy hands / for thou shall ete. Sith it is true that god defends vsurye ye
scripture speaks in many places. First it is written deute.xxiii. Non
feueraberis fratri tuo ad vsura^ pecunia^ ne fruges nec qua^libet alia^ re^
Thou shalt not lend unto thy brother money to vsurye / ne of corns / ne of
any other thing. And it follows in the said chapter. / Fratri au^t tuo
absque vsura id quod indiget co^modabis vt benedicat tibi dn^s deus tuus in oi^
tempore. etc. Thou shalt lend unto thy brother without vsurye that thing whereof
he has need / to the end yt thy lord god bliss the in all times. God will yt
men lend each other by charity / and not for hope of any gain or retrybucyon.
Usury manifest is when a man lends corn / wine / gold or silver pry^cypally
for to have any prouffyte expressed by the parties or alonely in hope. Canon
dicit. quod vsura est vbi amplius requiritur qua^ datur quicqid illius sit: sed
si non recipit and spe^ habeat recipiendi vsura est. The droit canon says.
Vsurye is when a man demau^deth more tha^ a man ne gives what thing so ever
it be / and if he receive no more. And yt he has hope to receive it is usury.
For god regards the thought yt is reputed for the deed When any has lent
corn / wine / or sydre / the lender has no more seygnourye of yt thing
lend. The said lender gives the lone or pressed after the commandment of god.
Mutuu^ date. And if the said lender receive gift he thereof has the gayn not
of himself but of the dettour / ye said lender ne sells nothing unto ye
dettour the which is his / but if he should take gift he should sell the time
the which apperteyneth unto god. And when any sells the thing the which
apperteyneth not unto him / he ne should have the gain. In like wise he ne
should sell the time / for ye should be vsurye. The usurer will have gayn in
slepynge and waking without any labor yt which is again ye word of god
written. Gene. iii. ca. In sudore vultus tui vesceris pane tuo. In the sweet and
labor of thy vysage thou shalt get thy bread. / When any lends his horse /
or ox for to do any labourage lefull he may take price For it is his thing ye
which ne gothe unto the seygnourye of the lender as of money lend. Vbi est
mutuu^ ibi e^ dn^m. vn^ mutuum dicitur de meo tuum.

B. The kinds of vsurye hid that god defends. ca. xxxii.
IT is written luce. vi. Mutuu^ date nichil inde sperantes. God commands that
a man give the pressed without having hope to have any thing over the thing
lend. Vsurye hid ye which otherwhyles is said wrapped in seven kinds. The
first is done in receyuynge gage / or in making herandes. The second in
selling and in byenge. The third is made in lendynge. The fourth for to be
mean to lend. The.v. by assocyacyon. The.vi is under manner of pain The.vii.
for to take service without price / or for to make to lend unto another and in
taking gratuyte. As unto the first kind the which is done in receyuynge gayge
/ or in making erandes a man should understand that it is dyuysed in.v.
manners. The first is when by the lone a man receives any gayge for assurance
ye which of it self bears any fruit or prouffyte / as who should take a
gardin in morte gayge. A man ne should take the fruytes or prouffytes of the
said gage but in rebatynge upon ye pryncypall so^me lend / or it should be
vsurye / and it behooves to make restytuco^n. Moses says in deute. Non
accipies loco pignoris inferiorem et superiore^ mola^. Thou shall not take in
s^ede of gayge neither ye upper grindyng s^one nor the under. A man demands
what it is of co^munytes of any cytees the which betaketh money unto usury.
