The answer. All those cytezynes ben vsureres of whose auctoryte and cou^sayll
ye said pressed is made. Vnde raymondus dicit. Oe^s illiciues quorum auctorytate
and consilio fit: vsuraii su^t. And in yt manner if a communyte should receive
any gage / as cite castle or town / and that they ne compte the fruytes over
the pryncypall price. All those here ben usurers. ar. vii. q. i. Sicut vir.
and. xxiiii q. iii. Sihabes. Understand this matere and of one person / and
of many. For all those the which takes the fruytes and leueed of the said
castle or town without rebatynge upon the prxncypall price ben usurers as it
is said. The second manner is when the lender receives gayge that he uses /
or makes serve without any thing dyscomptynge of the pryncypall / as lynnen
clothe vestementes. Vnde amos propheta.ii. ca. Super vestimentis pigneratis
accubueru^t. etc. They ben couched upon ye vestimentes engayged. The third is
as the lender takes bestyall in gayge / and makes them more to dyspende and
ete than they ne should in such case. The fourth is when the usurer makes
erandes and messages / and at every erande or message he has a reward and
lives by it. The.v. is as the usurer renneth and that he ne will give dylacyon
till that a man unto him has given any thing. Of such people a man may
say. Illud psalmiste. Deuora^t plebem mea^ sicut esca^ panis. They devour my
people as the mete of bread.

C. The second kind of vsurye hid the which is made in selling or byenge
is dyuysed in four manner. The first is when any sells his marchaundyse
unto credence for much more than it is worth for asmoche as he gives term
of payment / he yt does so is an usurer. vt pz extra de vsu. c. Consuluit. The
second is when a man byethe the things that yet grows / as ye corn in
grass / ye appelles or vynes in flower much less than they be worth. For as
much as a man auau^ceth the payment / or yt a man them take in payenge
himself by such condycyon yt they shall have such case when it may happen
their catell safe / in this manner a man sells the time yt is not to be sold
/ and therein is vsurye. extra de vsu: co^suluit. But who so should by them of
so mean a price that a man should be uncertain whether they should be more
worth or less. For to put a way the peril of the vsurye it is better to do
and to say in this wise. I will not in no manner what so it be sell my corn /
nor mine appylles now: but I purpose to sell them on such a day / and if thou
will give me the price that they ben worth at ye said day or more / or less
thou shall have them / and I shall keep them for the. And if thou auau^ce money
now ye pryse shall be as they shall be worth at the said day as when the
apples are to be gadred and the corn after Auguste. The third is when a man
byeth any ware to be delivered at such a term much less than they ben
worth at the said term for asmoche as a man auaunceth the money / here is
vsurye. The.iiii. is when any rich man is required to lend or to engage unto
the poor people the which ben in necessyte / ye will not sell in perpetuyte
their rentes or herytages if they may find a lender / or an engayger. And the
said rich man in such wise knows it / but he has the heart in the
practyse / and wylleth that his fynaunce unto him be prouffyte and encreasy^ge
/ but for to fle ye name to be an open usurer he loves better to make the
contracte under the form of sale and byenge as of the priest / or of other
pryse to the end that his said fynaunce unto him do prouffyte / if in this
manner he by of the said indygens rent or heritage to requyte again that
these other call unto grace. That is to understand by such condycyon that as
many times and as often that within certay^ term / as of.vii. or.x. years / or
unto him or unto his heirs he shall yield the so^me given with the arrerages /
the said herytages or rentes shall come again unto ye said sellers / or unto
their heirs / here is vsurye hid the which is as silver lend contrary unto
charity / and here behooves restitucion of al yt that a man takes over the
first so^me given. Such people the which will increase their rychesses / and
fle contractes of winning and of lone / in hydynge their vsurye by form of
selly^ge and byenge / defrauldeth the entencion of the law of charity and of
justice unto their power / and deceyueth their soul by ye sin of such
vsurye hid. The which sin they wolden unto them to be lefull wtoute
reproach or without oblygacyon to make restytucyon the which thing may not be
done. But who so should bye the said herytakes the just price that they ben
worth in good entencyon without having the entencyon corrupt as it is said
of the rich the which takes head unto the practyse he may do it without
vsurye / how be it that there is time to require it. Quicqid agant hoi^es:
intentio indicat oe^s. The usure is wrapped in the thought yt god sees and
knows. The which shall make in dycacyon. Legitur primi regu^.xvi. Ho^ enim
videt ea que para^t: dn^s aute^ intuetur cor. Also it is to be noted that when
in any co^tracte has defaulte of justice and of good equity in such wise
that one of ye parties is endo^maged / he that does the do^mage is bound in
deed of conscience to quyte ye contracte or to supplye the defaute of justice
but specially when ye party it requires and is of necessyte.

D. The third kind of vsurye hid the which is done in lendynge is dyuysed
in many maneres The first is when ye usurer lends upon intencyon to have any
gift / gratuyte / or service over ye thing lend / how be it that in lendynge
it were not spoken. And if he thought not to have some prouffyte / he ne would
lend nothing. Here is vsurye as unto god for ye entencyon corrupt yt our
sauyoure defends. luce. vi. Mutuu^ date nichil inde sperantes. Et deutero.xv.
Si vnus de fratribus tuis ad paupertate^ venerit no^ obdurabis cor tuu^ nec
co^trahes manu^. sed aperies ea^ pauperi and dabis mutuu^ quo eu^ indigeri
prospexeris. When that any lends money under hope to receive any thing and
that it be so that he ne would lend nothing if he ne thought not to have
prouffyte / that that he receives afterward is vsurye / how be it that he axe
it not. And is holden to make restytucyon. The second is when the usurer
lends old corn sydre / or wine when it is at a vile price / to the end
that it be yielded unto him in the time that it shall be more dear / better or
renewed and not for ye necessyte of him yt boroweth / but upon entencyon to
gain it is vsurye. ext. de. v^u. ca. Nauiga^ti. E.

E. For to know many cas in generalyte it is to be noted yt when a man gives
money or other thing unto any indygent in.v. manners. The first is lyberally /
and without any gain of hope temporell / here is charity. The second is to
the end that the marchaunte of the said money under condycyon of loss and of
gain as well of the pryncypall so^me as of gain / and that may be lefull. The
third in such condycyon yt the so^me lend shall be evermore certain and
sure as unto ye lender / but the gain shall be under doubt of loss / or of
gain / and here is vsurye. The scripture gives a rule general and says ye
thing ye a man takes over ye pryncypal is vsurye. vt pz. xiiii. q. iii.
Plerique. The fourth by such condycyon that the lender adventure the so^me
lend in perils / and fortunes upon him / but the borower shall be bounden in
any so^me unto the lender / here is v^urye / and if he lost an. C. M. crounes
for to have in certain a little blanc. extra de vsuris. ca. nauiga^ti. The.v.
in putting gain and catell incertayne / as to lend an hundred crowns for to
receive at the end of the year an hondreth and ten / here is vsurye manifest.
If any man has lend lyberally and without hope to have retrybucyon temporell
/ and the borower would unto him give any thing lyberally he may take it
without peril of vsurye For in such case he is no more restraynte as not to
dare take gift after the priest as before. If a man had promised to yield the
so^me lend at a certain day / and by ye defaute of the which promise the
lender is endo^maged / for he should pay his rent or his tax. etc. he may
over the said so^me lend take justly his loss without v^urye. Also some
usurers there ben the which for ye pressed takes evermore some thing or
puts more over and above the thing lend. And for as much as ye borower ne
may furnysshe at every term ye said lender makes him to compte two or.iii.
times / and takes decretm away some thing as every time yt he compteth / and
makethe often of vsurye the pryncypall debt. / By the which they ben reputed
vyllains and cruel usurers.

F The.iiii. kind of vsurye hyd is when any receives any gift for to be ye
mean to make ought be lend unto the indigent G The.v. is made in assocyacyon
of bestyall ye which may be good or ill dyuersly The which they make in many
of maneres / but it behooves to take for a rule general the which is sothe
that as often that by the condycyons of the contracte ye one of the parties
abides subject unto the loss and adventures / and the other is sure nothing
to lose / it is vsurye / as a man may say that he the which betaketh his
beestes / yt is by such condicyon yt they shall be immortelz. That is if they
dye the fermer shall put as many of other / or shall pay the so^me yt they ben
worth when they were unto him betaken / if they increase the betaker will
part / and if they decrease he will nothing lose / the which is vsurye. Also
when one of the parties of ye ferme is notably assured / and the other
euydently grieved / the contracte is dampnable / but little excess in loss or
in gain is not in all again justice ne peril of damnacyon. A questyon for to
understand if it be v^urye if a man receive an.C. sheep to keep for one year /
and for the fruytes and keeping of the same he should have twenty shelinges or
more after that yt the gyuer and he couenau^ted togyders by such condycyon yt
in the end of the term ye gardyen him should restore as many of sheep and so
many good with the wo^les. To assoyll this questyon after the cou^sayll of good
experyment a man should consider if it be time of moreyne if the sheep ben seek
/ or if the pasture ben sekely and that it appear great peril and loss upon
the gardyen and not upon the gyuer / here is vsurye / but if the said pasture
and the sheep were hole without time of moreyne ne of peril and that a man
give pryse reasonable and that the said gardyen may well yield that ye said
gyuer demands / therein should be no vsurye. A more sure thing it should be
to marchaunde alonely for ye fruytes pains and keeping of the said sheep. And
that the perils of prouffytes were upon the gyuer and not upon the gardyen.

H. The syxte spyce or kind of vsurye hid is when a man lends unto a term
spoken to yield the thing lend upon pain to pay as much of advantage /
here may be vsurye after some cyrcumstaunces / but sometime he may well do it
justly for to punysshe the negligence of some as is beforsayd.

I. The.vii. kind of vsurye hid is when the usurer will nothing take over
the price given / but for the said pressed put in besynes.ii. or.iii. days of the
borower in his field / or when he ne will lend by his hand / but makes to
lend his servants or another his friend and keeps the gratuyte. For to be
short in this matter ye malice of worldly people auaricious is right great /
for they find so many of cautelles in betakynge their usury under ye shadow of
pity and in making passementes of oblygacions of bargayns of contractes that a
man ne may escrye nor determyne the hydynge of their vsurye / but every man
should understand that god commands that a man do charity unto his
neighbor and that a man lend him. And more over he defends that for the
priest a man ne sell the time as it is beforsayd. Those the which it sells
or the which have sold it remedy unto their conscyences if they will well
deye surely / and to be assured to go in to paradyse. For when they shall be in
judgment before god their cautelles no^ malice there shall make nothing. And
their vsuryes wrapped and hid under the shadow of pity shall be unfolded and
manifest. Quia nichil occultum est: quod non reueletur. And our lord Ihesu
christ shall judge them and condampne the^ after the truth of the thing / in
beholdynge what thoughts these vsureres had.

Also god sees and knows if any man has sold the time in hydynge his
vsurye / and if he has taken bounte and prouffyte over the thing lend
without taking therein pain ne labor for the dylacyon of the time termyned.
And for as much that such judgment is doubtous and that dampnacyon is to be
dredde it is beter to make restytucyon and penance for to have assurance of
salvation. T'ene certu^ et dimitte incertu^. Hold the thing certain and leave
that the which is not certain Dauyd makes a questyon in the psalter sainge.
Dn^s qis habitabit i^ tabernaculo tuo aut quis requiescet i^ mo^te scto^ tuo.
Seqitur Qui jurat prooximo suo et no^ decipit: qui pecunia^ sua^ no^ dedit ad
vsura^ et muneta super i^nocente^ non accepit. That is to say Lord who shall
enhabite or dwell in thy tabernacle / or who shall rest in thy holly
mountain. The answer. That shall be he the which swereth unto his neighbor /
and deceyueth him not. He the which has not given his goods unto vsurye /
and the which has not taken gifts of ye innocents he shall mount in to
paradyse. etc Examples of vsurye. And first of an usurer yt would not make
restytucyon for the amonycyon and warning of his priest / the which said that
he would prove if he might be saved without restytucyon. and so myscheuously he
deyed.lxxxvii. e. Another example how an usurer ye which would not restore
cried at his death yt he brent and broyled.lxxxvi. h.

K Of usury manifest and notable. xxxii.
IT is written math. xvi. Quid perdest hoi^ si mu^du^ vniuersu^ lucretur ai^e
vero sue detrime^tu^ patiatur what does it prouffyte unto a thief usurer to
assemble and wy^ne all the world / and that at his death his soul be sent
unto the torments of hell. Vsurye open and notoryous is much detestable / the
which a man should fle for many things: of the which I shall tell four. /
The first is for that yt these usurers be cursed by sentence of right / ipso
facto. The second is for yt that they ben pryued from the holy co^munyon / for
unto the usurers a man should deny the sacrament of the altar as well in the
death as in the life / if they have not true repentance and if they will not
make restytucyon. Example of an usurer the which would not restore
Quere.lxxxvii. a. The third is for that that their oblygacyon is not agreeable
unto god / and it ought not to be received. The iiii. is for that yt they
should be pryued from sepulture ecclesiastyke. Vt habetur extra devsuris. c.
quia i^ oi^bus. Example of an usurer the which would not restore that was
borne by an ass unto the gybet or galowes and there was buried. Quere. lxxxvii
a. Many other examples of usurers ben written in ye exemplayre of the
commandments. Quere. lxxxvi. a. b. c. d. An open usurer and known the
which should come at the necessyte of death ne should be assoylled / if he
did not yt were in him to restore plainly till unto the last penny all ye
vsurryes wherein he may be reproved and redeuable. And there unto he should
dyspose mouables and herytages / ne also it should not suffyse to ordeyne that
after his death they were restored. But it behooves that forthwith the party
endo^maged be contented / or in his absence the ordynayre / or the chapelayne
representynge the party endommaged / otherwise the testamente that he makes
is of no valor / ne the absolucyon that he receives. And if he deye so he
should be pryuate from ye holy ground / for he yt should bury him should be
cursed. extra de sepulturis eos libro.vii. Also the herytiers the which him
shall succeed in mouables and herytages shall be in like wise bound to restore
the dommages upon pain of dampnacyon. Example how iiii. men of one lygnage
were hanged in hell the one after another / because that they did possede fasly
an heritage without being in will to restore it.lxxxi. g. Another example how
that another Earl and many of his lygnage were dampened and put in to hell in
tormente upon a laddre / because they did possede an heritage unjustly
without being in will to restore it.lxxxii. a. Another example how that an
abbot sent again the money given and bequethed from his monasteri / because
that it was comen of vsurye / and ill begoten.lxxxviii. f.

A. Of symony that god defends.
AFter the masters symonye is in such wise dyffynyed. Simonia e^ studiosa
volu^tas eme^di vel veldendi spu^ale vel annexu^ spu^ali. A man commits
symonye for to selle / or to by a spyrytuall thing or a thing yt is annexed
unto the spyrytualyte by paccyon or gift / of promise / service / prayers /
supplicacyons undue / or by any other thing te^porell. God and nature
gaynsayeth yt a thing spyrytuell may be compared / or bought by thing
corporell and temporell of what pryse and dygnyte yt it be / as it shall be
declared here after. This sin is named somonye / for asmoche as in the time
of ye appostles the false and dysloyall simon magus offered a great so^me of
money unto ye appostles wenynge by yt to get the grace yt he saw in them /
and understood yt if he might have that geace yt he would selle it unto other /
and should recover much of fynau^ces. But in figure of all those yt sells or
byeth things spyrytuelles he and his money was cursed by the mouth of saint
peter / and because that he was the first in the new testament yt would by
thing spyrytuell / this espyce or kind of theft is named symonye in all holy
church because of ye cursed simon fygured of all the dampened symonyacques. For
to sell or to bye a thing spyrytuall a man should understand every paccyon or
contracte ye which is not made symply and purely for the love of god / but is
made pryncypally by gifts / prayers / seruyces / and for any other thing
temporel Also for to sell or to bye things spyrytuel it is here to understand
the grace of the holy ghost / and the virtues yt ben in the soul the spyryte
of prophecye / office of predycacyon / or to do the office dyuyne in the
church and to admynystre the holy sacraments. By things annexed unto the
spyrytualyte is to be understand sepultures / dismes / chalices / corporaces:
to welies / anbes / and other vessels / or vestementes hallowed the which may
be sold or changed unto other chirches not the more dete for as much as it
is hallowed other wise it should be symonye. Also cures / predendes / chanonryes
/ chapelles / right of patro^nayge in it self symply considered right to
receive dysmes / oblacyons because of benefyce of the church / auctoryte or
office to serve a cure or other predende of ye church / al these things have
annexacyon unto holy ordres and they ne may be boughtne sold after the form
beforsayd but yt there be symonye which is a crime capytall after the droitm
and compared unto heresye. vt habetur. i. can. q. i. Qui studet. Et thomas.
iii.iiii. By the which crime all holy ordeynaunce of ye church is perverted
and shall be from ill unto wors approchynge ye great and excessyue trybulacyon
of the chirch Thou shalt find many examples of symonye in the.vi.
commandment of the exemplayre.lxxxv. a. b. c. Quere. per tabula^.

B. Of ye manners of symonye that god defends. Ca. xxxiii.
IT is written actuu^.viii. ca. Pecunia tua tecu^sit in perditionem Saint peter
said unto Simon magus. Thy money be with ye in perdycyon. These words here
may be taken and also understand upon all symonyacques as it is before said.
but a man should understand that the sin of symonye is changed in to many
manners after the dyuersyte of the people the which entermell them unduly in
things in spyrytuell things / as hereafter so me in partyculer shall be
declared.

C. First a man the which receives ye holy ordres or the which enters in
any benefyce of the church in gyuynge or in promettynge by himself or by
other / gold or silver or any other thing is suspende by right written Extra
de symonia. tanta and. i. ca^. i. q. Reperiu^tur. And if in such estate he
mysbehaue him unto ye mysteres dyuynes he is irreguliere and may not be
assoylled if he ne resyne the benefyce / or if he have not dyspensacyon of the
pope. It is written iohannis.x. Quit non intrat per hostiu^ i^ ouile ouiu^ sed
ascendit aliunde: ille fur e^ and latro: qi aute^ intrat per hostiu^. i. xprem:
pastore e^ ouiu^. That is to understand / he which enters not by ye door /
yt is by Ihesu christ in to ye fold of sheep / yt is in ye church
ecclesiastical for to govern the people but enters by another place than by
ye doeyt is Ihesu christ he is a these secret or a watcher of the way.

D Secondly a clerk that makes paccyon with a man of the church or other for
to have his title in promising yt he shall never demand nothing for asmoche
as unto him suffyceth yt it may pass / he is pryued from the ordres yt he
receives in such manner yt none there may dyspence him but the pope after ye
droite. Extra de simonia per tuas.

E. Thyrdly two persons benefycyed ye which couuena^teth together under such
form (permute we benefyces) but for as much as your benefyce is better than
my ne I shall give you such a so^me of money This is here symonye. How be it yt
the one may make pensyon unto ye other without symonye. And if they make ye said
permutacyon symply without any thing demanding the one of the other / but they
make gifts or promesses unto ye patron for to grant his good will thereunto it
is also symonye. And if they say to each other in this wise for asmoche as we
may not permytte together without ye consent of ye bishop labor we both to
get his consent Such paccyon ne should be symonyacall if it were made symply
wtoute gift / and that ye said consentement were not gotten by manner of
symonye. Also to renounce unto any benefyce by such condycyon / and paccyon
made that it shall be given unto such a person it is symonye / when the
renouncyacyon is not made unto a person that is worthy to have it / and simply
and purely for the love of god. Legitur ioh. x. Ego sum ostium ouium per me si
quis introierit saluabitur et pascua inueniet. / Our lord Ihesus says. I am
the door of the sheep cote if any there enter by me he shall be saved and he
shall find pasture there within. Symonye is committed and done sometime as well
of the person that gives the benefyce as of him ye which receives it /
sometime of the one alonely / sometime ne by the one ne by the other / as if for
example some gives unto the famylyers of the bishop any thing for to moeue
him to give any benefyces. He the which knows nothing of that gift
nesemblably the bishop by the mean albeit of the which gift should be made
donnayson of the benefyce. Such donayson should be made symonyall / but
alonely he the which has made the donayson unto the famylyers of the bishop
shall be in mortal sin / and symonyer as unto that. And he that is benefyced
by such manner unknown should be bound when it should come unto his knowledge
to renounce unto ye said benefyce and to the other goods prese^tes of the same
/ but he is not bound to restore the goods dyspended during the time of the
poor conscience. For to know clearly when a man commytteth symonye in
permyttinge of benefyces / or when any renounceth unto his benefyce / or when
any gives a benefyce / or when any receives it. It behooves to se and to
consider the condycyons / the manners / and the causes / and if there ne be
gifts / ne promesses / ne prayers of lords or of friends. etc. Moreover it
behooves pryncypally to regard the fynall end to the which a man has
entencyon for to come. For if the condycyons and the fine be made purely for
the love of god he is well entered in the benefyce by the door. And if a man
enter otherwise in benefyce than by god / symonye is to be dredde For he is not
entered by the door.

F. Also for to know that it is great syn to sell a benefyce a man may it
clearly se in the example of hieroboam king / the which sold the
bysshopryches and dygnytes. And therefore god was wroth again him in so much
that he was degraded and unclothed him and his lygne / as it is w^^ten in
tertio regum.xiii. Quicunque vo^bat implebat manum hieroboam et fiebat sacerdos
excelsorum. etc. Quere. lxxxv. c.

G. Also men read in secundo machabeorum.iiii. how the king Anthyochus sold
unto Jason the dygnyte to be sovereign priest (that is bishop) and ill came
unto him. The prophet Ysaye says in his.v. chapter. Ve qui iustificatis
impium promuneribus et iustitiam iusti aufertis ab eo. Cursed be you the which
iustyfye ye ill by gifts / and take away the justice of the just. Those the
which enters in to benefyces unduly by the force and puyssaunce of princes
or great lords / or by menaces / murmures / or by their prayers and
supplycacyon / and not by the door the which is Ihesu christ ben thieves. For
for the dread puyssaunce or favor of ye said lords the good right is
corrupt / ye good ben expelled / and the unworthy beneficed and ill comes
unto them. We have an example in primo machabeoru^.vii. how cursed Alchymus was
constitute sovereign bishop of the king demetrius. The which did many of
ylles. Also the said Alchimus deyed cursedly / as it is written.i.
machabeoru^.ix. ca. This example is written after. Quere. lxxxv. h. Also some
enters in to benefyce unduly by flateryes / glosynges and decepcyons. And for
asmoche as they enter not by ye door / that is by Ihesu christ they ben theuys.
Also these bysshoppes and prelates the which pays their servants of their
salayres and seruyces by gyuynge unto them some benefyce or prebe^de / chapel
or dygnyte where it is so that the cause be for the payment / and not for the
love of god it is symonye. But it is written in droit canon / yt when a bishop
consydereth the prudence of his clerk / the dygnyte of his service / the
stremyte / holiness / and bo^unte of him / and yt he be of great merit. For the
goodness yt he sees and knows in him he should benefyce him in that church
and it is no symonye / but it is well done. For in the courts of prelates a
man should prouue the clerks. Also to ordeyne charity a man should give first
unto his famylyeres as unto strangers if they ben egally good.

H The people lay the which gives or prometteth or makes prayers and
supplicacyons indue for to benefyce their kynnesmen / servants or other their
friends / ben symonyackes and should be accursed / after that that saint Thomas
says and raymonde. Si quis auaritia ductus amore seruitio vel precibus
episcopalem vel sacerdotalem acceperit dignitatem: et i^ vita no^ relinquerit
eumque in asperam penitentiam mors no^ inuenerit ineternu^ peribit. i. q. i.
ca. Si quis. If any has taken ye dygnyte epyscopale or sacerdotale led by
auaryce / by love / service or prayers / and he ne has left it in his life /
and at ye death ne has found it in sharp penance he shall pay in
pardurablete. In gyuyng a benefyce unto one ye which is of his blood / albeit
there be no symonye for that / yt there is no sale / yet is there sin the
which is commit in three manners / or for asmoche that he loves tenderly his
flesh / or for that that he coueyteth to give a thing undue unto his
kynnesman / or for asmoche as he vylependeth the thing spyrytuell in gyuynge
it unto one indigne. And it seems that he should have therein symony if he
had the regard how his cosyn has the prouffyte temporal for the spyrytuall
/ in as much as cosyn / for he should receive a thing the which ne should be
due unto him. It is not the less symonye for to have the regard that his
kynnesman has the prouffite temporal but as if himself had it. When a man
gives a benefyce a man should behold whether the person unto whom ye gift
is made be worthy it. And that it be given symplye and purely tor the love of
god. We read math. x. How our lord said. Gratias date / the which is
expounded in two manners. Or when a man there puts no cause of sale / or when
a man has no regard in gyuynge but alonly god / or only grace. And therefore
he ye which gives unto his kinnesman ne gives in such wise / albeit yt god
has said / gratis date. Also who so will give unto his kynnesman without
symonye / it behooves that the person be worthy it. And that the gift be made
for the love of god purely / as it is said. Vt intret per ostium: id est
christum in ouile ouium. Our lord Ihesu christ gave the dygnyte and
government of the church unto saint peter and not unto saint Johan nor unto
his other parents / in gyuynge us example that in like wise should we do Also
when the appostles chose Mathyas and Joseph the just / to the end yt one of
them two were apostle in ye place of judas. Sors cecidit super mathiaz. For
Ioseth was of the parente of Ihesus. Legitur in secundo libro regum. quod
infidelis est episcopus qui nepotulo suo co^fert prelationem cum sciat enim
inabillem et sciat totum pondus prelii versum super prelatu^. That is to say.
The bisshoppe is unfaithful the which brings unto prelacyon / or dygnyte
his little neuewe when it is so that he knows that he is feeble to fight and
that he knows that all the country and the ruin of the battle tourneth on
the prelates. Example that a man ne should constytute any by prayers
charnelles. / Quere. lxxxv. f. Also god gives us example clearly that we ne
should lift up our parents in dygnyte spyrytuel if they be not worthy it.
Legitur mathei. xx. that when the wife of zebede aunt of Ihesus him prayed that
her two children / saint James and saint Johan cosyns of our lord that he
should make them sytte the one on his right hand and the other on his left
hand. The answer was. Nescitis quid petatis. They were unworthy to be set nere
by him. And therefore god said unto her ye wot not what ye demand. Marye ye
may well endure passion as I. But to set you on my right hand it is not unto
me to give it you: sed quibus paratu^ est a patre meo. That is unto them the
which ben dygne.

I. Fourthly those the which make paccyon to give certain so^me for to be
received in a monastery such wise rented yt it is suffycyent to sustain and
to puruaye as well those that there ben now as those yt they shall receive they
ben symonyacques And in like wise those ye which makes the said recepcyon /
or thereto give cou^sayl consentement / and there nys custom unto the contrary
the which may excuse ye sin.

K. Fyfthly the people of the church should admynystre the sacraments / and
the sepultures without making paccyon ne exaccyon of money / otherwise there
is symonye. But after yt they have done their deuoyre the lay people them
should content after the customs auncyentes or otherwise a man may make them
to come before the bishop after the droitz. Extra de symonia ad apostolicam.
The sacraments of the church ne should be sold / for that should be symonye.
Our lord it showed clearly unto his apostles when he said unto them Illud
math. x. Infirmos curate mortuos suscitate: leprosos: mundate: demones:
eiicite: gratis accepistis: gratis date. The gospel says. Hele ye the seek /
arayse ye the deed / hele ye the lepres chase away the deuylles / ye have
taken for nothing give you it for nothing. Also it is written. Administre ye
taking nothing for it the Eucharistie that is the sacrament of the altar
unto ye people / confess ye taking nothing / baptyse ye taking nothing /
give you unto all folk for nothing after the appostle. Vn^ augustinus dicit.
Gratis eucharistiam plebi ministrate: gratis: confitemini: gratis baptisate
secundum apostolum: cuntis gratis date.

L. When any priest sells or marchau^deth the masses or that he sing mass
for money and that the cause fynall of ye dylectacyon be to the end that he
have ye said money / it is symonye / and synneth mortally. Vnde augustinus.
Qui precise vna^ missam vel plures pro pecuniis celebrat da^nationem sibi
eternam preperat. He that syngeth a mass / or many for money he prepares
unto himself eternell dampnacyon. And it is here to be noted that ye things
temporelles ne should never be ye end of things spyrytuelles / but there ben
causes well mouynge. Vn^ hec est falsa: The priest is holden to give the
things spyrytuelles to the end that he have the things temporelles. Sed hec
est vera. The layeman is holden to give the things temporelles for the things
spyrytuelles / not in byenge them / for they should not be sold as it is said
in like wise as a man sells the flesh upon ye stalle. The grace of god the
which is in the sacrament is inapprecyable and it falls not under any price
/ For man has not thing whereof he it may bye / but for asmoche as the
servants of god ne may labor in things spyrytuelles without having their
living and sustentacyon / god will that a man unto them give some thing for to
live it hi^ they have done their deuoyre. Vnde pau. i. corinth. ix. Qui altario
deseruiu^t cum altario participa^t ita et dn^s ordinauit hiis qui euangelium
anunciant de euangelio viuere. They the which on the alter dysseruen shall be
parteyners of the altar / in such wise that god has ordained unto them the
which show the gospel / to live of the gospel / not that they shall selle
it / for that should be symonye as it is said

M. Syxtely mark well that no man lay ne should presume to do the office of
priests ye which ben in holy ordres / where if they do ill shall come unto
them as did unto the king ozyas. For after that he had coueyted and presumed
to do the office and that he had taken the ense^cer and encensed and menaced
the priests for ye that they gaynsayed him leperye him took in the vysage
within the house of god / etc. as it is written.ii. paralipo.xxvi. Quere. lxxxv.
g.

N. Seventhly a man ne should sell the yeftes of grace / ne the virtues the
which ben in ye soul / ne science / where that should be symonye. Augustinus
dicit. Spectat ad offirium vestre dignitatis gratie pete^tibus dona dare
gratis: sed si vnquam fidei munera vendatis incoursores giezi lepra^vos
sciatis. It belongs unto ye office of your dygnyte to give gifts for
nothing unto the demaundauntes of grace / but if ye sell in any wise the
gifts of faith knowledge you than unto the lepre of Gyezy. In likewise as
says saint austyn unto the mynystres of the church. Giezie was the dyscyple
of Helyseus / ye which took a great gift of the rich man Naaman for yt that
his master had heled him of his leprye: And therefore the said prophet
Helysyus said unto giezi. Lepram naaman adherat tibi et semini tuo. The leprye
of Naaman shall be brought unto the and unto thy sede. In like wise was it
done as it is written in quarto regum.v. ca. For he had received gift of the
grace of the holy ghost. Quere post.lxxxv. b.

O. A questyon to understand if an advocate may sell the science of the just
cause that he demeneth. The answer. He ne should selle the science / but he
may selle ye great labor and trauayll of his body yt he takes to study to
plede and to defend ye just cause. For god says in the gospel that ye
werkman is worthy of his mete and of his hyre. Mathei. x. Dignus est eni^
operarius cibo suo. Et luce. x. Dignus est enim operarius mercede sua. But if
ye said advocate sold the science by manner of sale / or that he had in his
thought the entencyon to selle it he should be symonyacke before god. It is
written prouerbiorum.xxiii. Veritatem eme et noli vendere sapientiam et
doctrinam et intelligenciam. etc. Be ye true and sell not wysdom doctrine and
intellygence. Also the science sold noyeth as it is said. and if it be given
it grows and also multeplyeth. / And if it be hid it serves of nothing /
Vnde scientia que data est crescit: crescere nescit si taceatur. Et legitur
ecclesi. xx. Sapientia absconsa est et thesaurus inuisus: que vtilitas in
vtrisque. Sequitur Melior est qui celat insapientiam suam / quam homo qui
abscondit sapientiam suam. Sapyence hid is a treasoure where a man sees not
what prouffyte is in ye one and in the other. Better is he the which hydeth
his vnwysdome than the man ye which hydeth his sapyence. Et legitur eccle.
iiii. Non abscondas sapientiam tuam in decore eius: in lingua enim agnoscitur
sapientia: et sensus et scientia et doctrina in verbo sensati. Thou shalt not
hyde thy wisdom in his honor / certainly wisdom is known in the tongue /
and the wit and the science and the doctrine in ye eloquence and word of
wisdom. An advocate ought be verytably and to sustain veryte. Also he ought
to keep and defend ye just cause that it perysshe not. And afterward he may
take gift for the trauayl of his body as it is said without to excede the
bounds of reason as many done ye which demand and take salayres and gifts
outrageously / more than they ne should / and that they ne have deserved to
have. And therefore they should dread damnacyon / for they ne ben just and
accomplysshe not justice in themself to be in will to have that thing yt they
have not wo^ne and the which ne apperteyneth unto the^ Also they should dread
if they have hated and broken Justice / judgment / ye good cause and ye good
right to receive yertes. For they sin mortally and run in maladyccyon. Vnde
ysaie.v. Vequi iusiti^icatis impium pro muneribus: et iustitiam iusti aufertis
abeo. Also they should dread if they have no will to lead / to cou^sayll to
keep the causes of the poores / as they done those of the rich / for that yt
they have no goods to give unto them. It is written eccle. In iudicando esto
pupulis / misericors vt pater et eris iu velut altissimi fi^ius obediens et
miserebitur tui. In judgment be thou merciful unto the orphelyns in like wise
as a fader and thou shall be obedyent. And also as the sone of the right hye
god / and he shall have mercy on the. Also if these advocates have made the
ylle causes good by their cautelles / malyces and subtyltees / and makes to
lose the good right they sin and ben unjust and corrupters of justice. And
if they have nourysshed / defended and sustained of certain science to be
good. It is great sin without doubt for to sustain dysloyalte / ill and
iniustyce. And in so doing the advocate yeldeth hyms^^^ culpable / and
brings himself in with malefactoure. By the which he is dyg^^ of punycyon
and synneth mortally. Vnde paulus ad roma. i Non solum qui fac^^ peccata: sed
qui consentiu^t facientibus d^gnisunt morte. Not alonely those the which do
the sins / but those the which also consents unto the doers / ben worth^
of death. Those synneth mortally / how be it that a man ne should understand
that ye said advocates co^mytteth symonye. etc Example how the devil bare away
in body and in soul a cursed coueytous these advocate. Quere.lxxxi. e. Another
examble of an advocate insacyable the which led a cause unto a man ye which
ne did bring unto him money unto his appetyte and he wronged him and took
the process and brake of the lectres / and trod upon it by dyspite in saying.
Vyllayn there is thy process the which ne broughte^^ me but this. The good
man in wepyng^ excused him by pouerte. But to be shor^^ anon after the
advocate deyed myscheuously. Also the master of a scole ne should sell the
science but the labor that he takes of his body. And in like wise of other
semblables. Quia omnis operarius dignus est mercede iua: vt dictum est. Also ye
prechers ne should selle the science that they speak in prechynge for the cause
fynall to have the gain temporal / or in like wise for to have favor
humayne or for vaynglorye / and not for charity and reconsylyacyon of the poor
sinners / commyt^^ symonye. But for as much as they have had pain corporal
for to study / to preche and to walk they may take that that men and women
unto them give for the sustentacyon of their living. Quia de^ ordinauit his
qui euangelium anuncta^ de euangelio viuere. Vt dicitur.i. corinth. Et augu.
dicit. Non debimus eua^gelizare vt vt uamus: sed viuere vt eua^gelizemus. We
should not preche the gospel to the end that we lyuen / but to live to the end
yt we preche. Also we should preche to the end that the reward of predicacyon
be not the mete the which is appetyted and desired / but the thing necessary
the which follows / that is sustentacion unto ye temporalytes the which is
requysyte unto a precher. Item augu. Euangelizare debemus vt non sit merces
predicationis cibus qi appetitur: sed necessariu^ quod seqitur id est
substantatio in temporalibus que necessaria est predicatori. Also those clerks
that lets to preche / to show / to reprehende / and to correct the vices
for any favors / or for false love / or for dread / or for any other thing
mutyle / and also hold their peace to se and to here ye ill. The prophet ysaye
them calls dogs not willing to bark / that is to preche. Vnde ysaie. lvi.
Caves muti non valentes letrare. Sequitur Oe^s in via^ sua^ declinaueru^t
vnusquisque ad auaritia^ sua^ a su^movsque ad nouissimu^ etc. A dog the
which bayeth not for to sustain his master is not good unto hy^ no more is a
precher unto god the which is dombe to sustain veryte. And therefore he is
called dog. Et legitur ihere.iiii. Sapientes sunt vt faciant mala / been
autem facere nescierunt. They ben wise to do ill but not to do good. Example in
the gospel of him the which hid ye talent he was called an ill servant and
a slothful / and was commanded that men should take away from him the
talente. Vnde math. xxv. Auferte ab ille talentu^. And for asmoche as the
haboundaunce of the derkenes of sin has ouerclouded the veryte of the
commandments of god in ye more part of the christian people living at this
day. No man ne should suffyse to write in partyculer the cautellous decepcyon
of this condampned sin of symonye. But these things spoken here shortly
justifies unto people of good conscience to make them inquire more plainly
after the occasyons and diverse maneres the which unto them may in this
thing come upon or happen. etc. More over people symony acques should dread
maledyccyon and excommunycacyon. Also they should dread irregularyte the which
shall not be declared because of shortenes. Also they should dread to be found
in ye judgment before god Also they should dread to lose the joys of paradyse.
Also they should dread punycyo^ and dampnacyon. Example of a man dampened ye
which had many benefyces. etc. Quere.lxxxv. e. Another example how few of
curates ben saved. Quere. lvi. g. Also they should dread to be sent for to
abide in the fire of hell perpetually. Those the which has offended by
symonye / run they unto penance and they shall have grace and mercy. etc.
Also do they of almesdedes for that is a good remedy.

A. Of restytucyon that god commands. Ca. xxxiiii.
IT is written in the.xxii. chapitre of the gospelles of saint matheu Reddite q^
su^t cesaris cesari: et que su^t dei deo. Yield those things the which ben of
caesar / the which ye have taken unjustly / yield the^ unto caesar / yt is to
understand to the lord temporal / unto whom they appertey^ and the things
ye appertain to god / yield them unto him. To make restytucyon it is necessary
for to come unto paradyse. and for to know clearly ye matter of restituco^n we
shall ordeyne it in five questyons. Prima wherefore a man ought to make
restytucyon. Secunda what he is yt ought to make restytucyon. Tertia unto
whom a man should make restitucyon. Quarta what thing a man should restore.
Qui^ta / when a man should make restytucyon as unto the first questyon the
which is.

B. Wherefore a man should make restitucyon. Ca. xxxiiii.
MAn reasonable know thou yt it is requysyte to make restytucyon. For asmoche
as it is so that to take from another again reason and justice it is mortal
sin. In like wise to have a steadfast will to witholde from another when a
man it may and ought to restore it is mortal sin / ne a man may not be
assoylled by any auctoryte during such ordinance of will. It is written in
droit. xiiii. q. vi. c. Sires. No^ dimittitur pectatu^ nisi restituatur
ablatu^. The syn is not forgyuen if ye thing taken away be not restored. And
saint Thomas says scda^ scde. q. lxii. ar. viii. Who so ever lets another
unjustly in the usage of the thing ye which unto him apperteyneth / he
trespasseth the commandment of charity / and is holden to restitucion.
Quilibet tenetur ad restitutione^ cuilibet rei subtracte. Every man is holden
unto restitucyon. Et i^ decre. Infereus da^nu^ prooxi^o no^ e^ absolua^dus nisi
da^no prius scdm^ arbitriu^ lesi restituto. He yt bry^geth in do^mage to his
neighbor ne should not be assoylled if ye do^mage were not restored to hy^.
Que. xiii. q. vi. c. Co^perimus. And saint thomas scda^ scde^. ii. q. dicit.
quod falsus testis peccat mortalitur: and tenetur ad restitutione^ da^ni quoth
alius i^currit. I falls wytnes sins mortally / and is holden unto
restitution. In like wise as you may se in many examples written in ye.vi.
commandment of thexemplayre q^. lxxxviii. a b. c. d.

C. The second question demanded.
WHat is he yt ought to restore. The answer. It is he that in cause by one or
many of manners ye which follows where any is put from his thing That is to
know either by commandment expres / or by counsayll given / or by fault
vycyous for to give it / or by consentement / or by adulacion. For to defend
or to sustain / ye endo^mages / or by hydynde or reteynynge in his keeping the
thing of another / or ye which gives effors / aid / or refuge unto ye wrong
doers / or will not say the truth in judgment / or in other place whereby
restytucyon might be made or the which ne gives unto the endo^mages / aid /
cou^sayll or defense yt apperteyneth to his office. All these manner of people
ben called generally / fauourables / parteners / or conse^ters. And when such
manner of favor or of conte^nement is such yt it is the cause of the do^mage
so happened / every of ye aforsayd is holden unto restytucyon / notwtstandynge
yt he has received but certain party or all holly any thing. But when they
ben many in cause of do^mage if one restore all holly as he is bound he
dyschargeth al ye other anen^^ the party endo^maged / but every of ye
parteners unto him is bounden prorata / yt is to understand in the so^me the
which unto him apperteyneth / where otherwise he shall not be dyscharged.

D. The third questyon demanded.
WHat thing should a man restore. The answer. The propre thing ill witholden
or his valor unto ye gre of the party. And with that ye fruytes of the same /
if it be a thing the which of it self dereth fruit. But costs myses and
dyspence made for to estyme the said fruytes should be first rebated and
compted unto the said restituant. Also a man should make satysfaccyon plainly
unto ye party endo^maged of the do^mages and lettynges / because of his thing
ylle witholden. For right reason it requires.

E. The.iiii. question demanded. xxxiiii.
Unto whom a man should make restytucyon. The answer. Unto him the which is
endo^maged if he be present / or unto his propre heir if he be deed or if he
were so far of that the dyspence should be more great for to go toward hy^
or in many places thanne the restytucyon should amount / or yt a man has not
the knowledge of them unto whom restytucyon should be made. Than a man should
give unto the poor for the spryrytuell well of him or of those unto whom may
apperteyne the said restytucyon. For as says saint thomas. These poor ben
very heirs in such case. Vn^ tho. i^. iiii. se^ten. Qn^ incertus est dn^s
rerum ablataru^ tu^c pauperes su^tillaru^ heredes. Some has wylled to say yt
such restytucyon should be made by the dysposycyon of ye bisshoppes diocesai^s
but reverence kept it is not found by words expres in any droit written. And
therefore in like wise as says the scot when dyuyne law or law of the
church ne binds us to do any thing determynetly / a man should follow
naturell reason ye which is in this matere present us tells yt by his good
and dyscrete confessor or other man of reason or by himself a man make the
said restytucyon anenst the poores The scripture says that the droit posytyf
in place there where it dyffreth not as in droit natural. Ibieni^ ius positiuu^
locu^ hm vbi nichil differt quamtum ad ius natural vnu^ sic vel aliter fiat.
Thomas scda^ sce^. q lx. articulo primo ad primu^.

F The.v. questyon demanded. xxxiiii.
When a man should make restytucyon unto onye. The answer. / It should be made
incontinent and without any taryenge as unto the will. For in like wise as he
the which is in sin mortal should repent him incontinent / and to purpose to
make confession when place and time. In like wise he ye which takes from
another should have a will pressed that as soon as he may goodly he it shall
restore entyerlye. A man may dyffer by some time the execucyon for to restore
that is to understand yt he unto whom he ought to make restytucyon will well
/ or should will by right and just reason that restitucyon were dyfferred for
a more great good. As for example. If a man of arms has dystressed a
merchant of the so^me of a thousand crowns / or gives commandment / aid
/ favor / counsayll / or comfort yt to do after the form before declared.
The which fynau^ce he ne may restore if he ne sell horse and harneys. Whereby he
shall be vnprouffytable unto the service of the king for the well of the
realm in such case or semblables. The merchant should more sooner be in will
that ye said man of arms dyfferre for a time restytucyon to be made unto him
than yt he should yield the man vnprouffytable so For as men say and it is very
true by the defaute of a nail a man leseth a sho / by a sho an horse / by a
horse a man / by a man a battle / by a battle a realm. And for as much as
the merchant will not content him but that restytucyon be unto him redely made
/ yet it shall not follow that the other were not absoylled / and in the estate
of grace by the dyspleasaunce of his sin and good purpose to restore in time
and place

G. By these things before spoken of restytucyon a man may well know that
lords and officers the which know to have servants and subgectes the
which pylleth the small people / whom men dare not to make them restore for
dread of ye said lords and officers / yet they ben bound to restore. Saint
Austyn says. When Justice is exclused and taken away great lords ben
excessyue pyllers. Remota iustitia qid su^t magna regna nisi magna latrocinia.
vn^ dicit augustinus in quarto libro de ciuitate dei. Those the which have
found any goods apperteynynge unto another also should curyouslye inquire
unto whom they may apperteyn / and if they ne may find him / they may retayn
such thing for a time and long enough with such conscience that always
when that they know unto whom it apperteyneth they it shall restore. Those the
which by things yt have been stolen / rauysshed / or else taken away where
unto ye seller has no right synneth mortally / if they have not entencyon to
bye them for to restore them unto whom they apperteyne / And notwithstondinge
that they have suffycyently given the valor also they ben bound to restore
them unto them to whom such things apperteyneth. Those ye which by hontynge
or haukynge endommage the corns ye vynes and other labourages / or that their
dogs strau^gle a sheep geese or other besty all be holden unto restytucyon if
the grefe be not so light that it should seem very semblable how the laborers
it bears gracyously. He the which malycyously hurts another in his body
whereby he leseth his iourneyes or is mutyle of any of his members he is holden
to pay the barbers / and also to save harmeles of iniurye and of the iourneys.
And he ye which should put to death any man which has to nourysshe or to
susteyn fader or mother / and children over the penance sacramental should be
bound to puruay al these beforsayd if it unto him be possible And for asmoche
as such restytucyon is right hard to estyme it should be expedyent for the
salvation of the soul of such homycyde to bear pacyently and wyllyngly in
justice the pain of tallyon that should be to endure death / or to go to
dyspose his life for him that he has slain / and for the law of Ihesu
christ. The scot reproves them the which absoylleth sometime more lightly an
homycyde than they ne should him ye which malycyously has slain his
neighbors dog. He the which malycyously lets any to come unto benefyce /
or office / or other good he is holden to restore not egally as much great
good as is the good in such wise let / but after the estymacyon of some of
good conscience or by himself. Four cas follows without gyuynge diffynyte.
The first is of them yt reysen in their herytages of new douuehouses / or
warennes / unto ye great preiudise of his neighbors. The second case is of
them the which wynneth great fynaunces in plays defended as of cards / dyse
/ and other plays of fortune. The third is of ye woman married the which
conceyueth lygnee of another than of her husband. The fourth is of them the
which by the vice of detraccyon takes away the good renomme of their brother
crystyen. Legitur prouerbiorum. xxiiii. Cum detractaribus non co^miscearis:
quoniam repent consurget perditio eorum vbi glosa dicit hoc vitio fore totum
humanum genus damnatur. These before said may in their conscyences by good
counsayll other than by ye shortness of this present treatise the which ne may
bear ye explycacyon than should be necessary in ye dyffyculte of such case and
of other ye which may come upon. Of the which is not here made mencyon.
Examples of restitucyon. And first of a man named Fredrycus tormented in
purgatory for that that he had not restored tho things ill
begoten.lxxxviii. a. Another example of a child in purgatory by defaute to
restore money borrowed.lxxxviii. b. Other examples of restytucyon in the.vi.
commandment of the exemplayre. Quere par tabulam.lxxxviii. c. d. e.

A. Here follows the.vii. commandment of god the which treats of lecherye
that a man co^mytteth in operacyon.
Keep the from lecherye and thoughts ill
Mysuse not thy body with wife ne maid
In this good mind be thou ever still
Be she never so nycely arayde
IN the ancient testament is written this commandment. exodi. xx. ca. And in
the new. math: v. et luce: xviii. Non mechaberis. Thou ne shalt do aduoutrye
/ or rybaudrye where if thou do ill shall come unto the if thou deye wtoute
correccyon and amendment. In like wise as thou shall find here after by many
examples. Quere.lxxxxii. a. b. All lecherye that a man co^mytteth in operacyon
is defended by this commandment. That is to understand fornycacyon /
aduoutrye / defloracyon / incest / sodomye. And al these other branches and
manners the which shameless people commytten. Whereof speaks ysydore the which
says. Nulla libidine poluaris si ne maculeris. Thou shalt not be polluted or
soylled by any lecherye. Et paulus dicit ad roma. xiii. Non incubilibus and
impudiciis non in contentione et emulatione: sed induamini dominu^ nostrum
thesum christum et carnis curam ne feceritis in desideriis. Not in beds and
shameful things / not in strife and in envy / but clothe ye our lord Ihesu
christ and make ye not the desires of the flesh.

B. Of fornycacyon that god defends ca. xxxv.
Saint poule says in ye.vi. chapitre of his first pystyl unto the
cori^thiens. Fugite fornicatione^. Fle fornycacyon / for god it defends.
Fornycacyon generally taken comprehends all these lecheryes that a man
co^mytteth in operacyon / and that the which is taken here in partyculer is
when those yt commit lecherye ne be in marriage / of affynyte / of gossiprede /
or under other line and enhabyteth vnlefully / It is great mortal sin to
know ye concubynes and the sclau^dre yt thereof proceeds It is a more great
sin to go unto wedowes / and they lose their honor / and the syn is right
great and infame to goo to those that been common / for they ben foul vile and
stynkynge which receive all people / and some are married which is aduoutrye.
etc The stewys or brodelhouse of the said co^munes ben taken from the laws
cyuyles in some co^munytes for to eschew and avoid a more great ill. But it
is not to be understand that god ne punyssheth the syn by eternell dampnacyon.
Vn^ psalm. Perdedisti omnes qui fornicator abs te. Thou haste lost from the al
those the which do fornycacyon. And a man should well know that the man the
which has company carnell of a woman is of affinite of all the consanguynes
that is of all the parents of the woman in that degree of affynite the which
apperteyneth unto the said woman in consanguynyte For the systers of the said
woman ben his systers / and the germayns his germayns / and so of other
degrees. And a like thing is it of the woman in regard of the parents of ye
man with whom she has committed lecherye And if that afterward the one or
ye other abandone them with any of the said parents and affynes under the.v.
degree he should committee inceste the which is a case reserved unto the
bishop. Legitur.i. corin. vi. Qui adheret meretricivnu^ corpus efficitur.
Sequitur eru^t duo in carne vna He the which draws unto a strompet is made
one body / two shall be in one flesh.

C. This fornycacyon is to fle for many things. The first is for that that
those yt committee it go again the commandment of god / whereof speaks ye
scryptures. Vn^. pau. i. co. vi. Fugite fornicatione^. seqitur. Qui aute^
fornicatur i^ corpus suu^ peccat. Fle fornication. He yt co^mytteth fornycacyon
/ synneth in his body. And again he says in the.v. chapitre of ye ephesyens.
Fornycacyon ne none immundycyte or auaryce be named in you / in likewise as it
apperteyneth unto saints. Et le. i. co. vii. Propter fornicatione^ euita^de^
vnusque vxore^ sua^ habeat and vna^quamque suum viru^. That is to say every
man has his wife for to fle fornycacyon / and every woman has her husband.
Also fornycacyon dyspleaseth unto god for those ye which it co^mytteth fyleth
his temple / yt is the conscyens of persons the which is the place yt he
has chose for hy^ to rest in. Vn^. i. ad co. iii. Te^plu^ dei estis and spu^s
dn^i habitat i^ vobis. That is to say ye be ye temple of god / and the spyryte
of our lord habyteth in you. and sequitur. Si qis au^t templu^ dei violauerit
disperdet illu^ deus. Empti estis precio magno: glorificate portate deu^ i^
corpore suo. If any has fyled ye temple of god / god shall destroy him / ye
be bought by a great price / gloryfye ye and bear ye god in your bodies.

D. Secondly fornycacyon is to flee for that yt it displeases unto ye
au^gelles of paradyse whereof we read. Example in ye life of the faders of an
angel yt as he walked with a man by the will of god when they met a lecherous
man well clothed / ye said angel stopped his nose / and he stopped it not
afterward when they met a great carayne so stynkynge yt a man ne might
approach unto it. And yielded ye cause and said yt for ye lecherye of ye said
young man he had stopped his nose. For lechery is more stynkynge before god
than all other infeccyons. Also lecherye dyspleaseth much unto the aungel the
which has the commyssyon of god to keep us and to counsayll as in his
presence the horror and abhomynacyon of sin is done in forsakynge his
counsayll and admonycyon. Legitur in psalm. Angelis suis deus mandauit de te vt
custodiant te in oi^bus viis tuis. God has sent his aungelles unto the that
they keep the in all thy ways. And therefore wha^ the judgment shall come of
the said lecherous man the said angel shall wytnes again him yt he would not
obey unto hy^

E. Thyrdly fornycacyon is to flee for yt that it pleases unto the devil. For
lecherye is so strong a line by the which ye devil holds these harlottes
that with great pain may they escape / whereof it is written osee.v. Non dabunt
cogitationes suas: vt reuertantur ad dn^m deu^ suu^: quia spiritus
fornicationu^ in medio eorum est. These lecherous people ne should give their
thoughts that they retornen unto their lord god / for the spyrytes of
fornicacyon ben in the myddle of them. Also a man bestyall apperceyueth not the
things the which ben of god. Vn^ legitur. i. co. ii. quod ai^alis ho^ non
percipit ea que sunt spiritus dei. Example of him yt excused him to goo to the
souper when he was boden. Vn^ luce.xiiii. Vxore^ duci et ideo no^ possu^
venire. The lechery the^ holds so strongli and byndeth yt they ne may think
on god ne leave yt sin / as afterward more play^ly shall be declared.
Quere.xliiii. f. Also lechery pleases unto the devil / for by it he wynneth
two persons at a time ye which thing he does not of other sins: it is a
stroke the which is worth two as ye hazardours he wynneth the man and the
woman by the said sin.

F. Fourthly fornycacyon is to flee for yt that it noyeth in many of maneres
unto those that it co^mytteth. First they lose the Joys of paradyse as says
the scriptures. Vn^. pau. i. co. vi. Nolita errare: qia neque fornicarii neque
ydolis seruie^tes: neque adulteri: neque moles: neque masculoru^ concubitores.
etc. regnu^ dei possidebu^t. Err ye not for the fornycatours / ne the
servants unto ydoles / ne these aduoultres / ne those the which commits
the sin of sodomye with masles. etc. ne shall possede the realm of god. And
he says.v. ca. ad gal. That the operacyons of ye flesh ben manifest the
which ben fornycacyon / uncleanness / vnchastyte / and lecherye / and it
follows / those yt do so shall not have paradyse and he says ad ephe. v.
Scitote i^telligentes qm^ oi^s fornicator: aut i^mundus: aut auarus quode^
ydolorum seruitus no^ habet hereditate^ in regno christi. That is to say
understand you that every fornycatoure / or unclean / or auarycyous the which
is seruytude of ydoles has not of heritage in ye realm of Ihesu christ. Also
these fornycatoures leseth god and the company of au^gelles / and all the
saints of heaven / and of all the things celestyall / and spyrytuall / they
lose their good reno^me their virtues and good operacyons / if they deye
impenytentes they lose the joy / the hele and the health of the soul. Also by
lecherye they feeble their bodies / engendre sekenes / corrupt the their blood
/ shorteth their life / they less their rychesses and their temporell gods
they chase away sapyence / science / and the gifts of the holy ghost / they
assocyate with deuylles with all maledyccyon / and with the dampened of perdicyon
/ they put their souls in great myserye and dystresse / they bind their
souls to death of dampnacyon eternell / and to be in the fire and in the
pains of hell without any remyssyon / if they in such wise deye without
contrycyon confession and satysfaccyon. Vn^ ysodorus. Ad penas tartari hominem
libido perducit. Lecherye bring a man unto the pains of hell. Example. It is
written in the second book of kings that Abner knew the concubynes of his
fader Hysboreth and within a little time after both twain were slain. Also
the prodygal man of whom it is written luce.xv. Who so dyspendeth and uses
his substance in lyuinge lecherously yeueth example that lecherye dymynyssheth
the richesse and the gods of the meschaunt fornycatoure / for it is given unto
harlottes and nouryture / And he lives delycyously while he has whereof. Also
the fornycatour makes gifts unto promoters / offycyalles / deanes / and
pays a great amends and loses to gain for the occasyons of his lechery.
etc.

A. Of aduoutrye that god defends. Capitulo. xxxvi.
NOn adulterabis. Thou shall not commit of rybauldyse. Aduoutrye is committed
when ye one of the parties / or both twain ben in ye line of marriage / and
they committee lecherye with another than with their party / and it is said
aduoutre quasi ad alterius thoru^ te^dere. vn^ marci. x. and math. xix.
Quicu^que dimiserit vxore^ sua^: and alia^ duxerit adulteriu^ co^mittit super
ea^. Et si vxor dimiserit viru^ suu^: and alii nupserit mechatur. It is to
know that men find by writing yt seven mortal sins may follow in
brekynge his marriage. The first sin is fraccyon of ye commandment of god in
two places. / That is coueyte not the wife of thy neighbor. exodi. xx. Non
concupisces vxorem proximi tui. And do thou not the sin in operacyon mathei.
v. Non machaberis. The second sin is pariurye / for those yt breketh their
marriage transgresses ye faith yt they have received in baptysme and promised
unto their party solemply in the face of the church before their priest and
friends / the which is a great sin as to break ye christian faith. For it is
written ad hebreos.xi. Quod sine fide i^possibile e^ placere deo. It is
impossyble to please god without faith. and ye faith of a person is nothy^ge
worth without doing ye operacyons as it is written iacobi.ii. Sicut eni^ corpus
sine spu^ mortuu^ e^: ita and fides sine operibus mor tua est i^ semetipsa. In
like wise as ye body is deed when it has no spyrite. In like wise the faith
is deed without operacyons. Those yt breketh ye faith given in marriage ne
believe well in god / by faith operant wherefore they shall be condampned in to
hell if they deye impenytentes The third is lyenge and infydelyte / for those
yt breketh their marriage show them to be liars and infydeles to break the
loyalte of the body and of the goods that they have promised to keep the one
with ye other the which is a great sin much to be blamed. For it is
written.iiii. ethicoru^ quodoe^ me^datiu^ prauu^ e^et fugie^du^ and sequitur.
Verax e^ laudandus / me^dax vero vituperandus Every lie or lesynge is ill and
to be fled / and it follows yt ye true man is to be praised and the liar to
be shamed. Et legitur pro.xxviii. Vir fidelis multu^ laudabitur. The man yt
keeps loyalte on his party shall be much lauded and praised before god and
the world / and shall have retrybucyon in like wise as it is written math.xxvi.
Euge serve bone et fidelis qia super pauca ^uisti fidelis supra multa te
constitua^ itra i^ gaudium di^u tui. O good and faithful servant enjoy ye
for thou haste ben faithful of a little thing. I shall ordeyne the above a
great thing / enter in to the joy of thy lord And unto the contrary the
person a liar and infydele shall be dyffamed before god and the world as we
read de villece. luce.xvi. Qui di^ famatus est apud dn^m suu^ quasi dissipasset
bona ipsius. And there follows damnacyon unto those which deye impenitentes.
The.iiii. sin is theft the which is when any man does unto his neighbor
theuysshely / fraud / nuysaunce / treson / and decepcyon secretly and
hydyngely again his will and it is done in such wise also when any is gyltye
on his party hydyngly and takes possessyon and saysyne of the body and of ye
flesh the which unto him is united by the sacrament of marriage / and the
which unto him is given and granted of god and of the church / whereof it is
written. gen^. ii. and math. xix. Proptur hoc relinquet homo patre^ et matre and
adherebit vxori sue and erunt duo in carne vna. That is to understand a man
shall leave fader and mother for marriage / and to draw him to his wife / and
they shall be two in one flesh / also they be not two / but one flesh. The
thing yt god has comoincte man shall not depart it. Vnde. marci. x. Itaque
ia^ non sunt duo: sed vna caro quos deus conuinxit homo non separet. Et legitur
primo. corinth. vii. Mulier non habet potestate^ sui corporis sed vir:
similiter virno^ habet potestate^ sui corporis sed mulier The woman has no
power of her body / but the man. In likewise the man has no puyssau^ce of his
body / but the woman For if the one or the other be prycked / or tempted of the
flesh they should obey ye one unto ye other for to fle sin. etc. Since that
the people married ne ben but one self flesh as it is said and that the one is
not master of his body / but it is the puysaunce of the other. It behooves to
say yt auoutrye is a great sin when the harlot steleth from him fraudelently
the thing the which unto him apperteyneth again ye commandment of god. Vnde
leui. xix. Non facies furtum. Thou ne shall do of theft ne of fraud unto thy
neighbor. vn^ mar. x. Ne fraude^ feceris proximo tuo. Also it is great sin
unto ye harlot to do unto his neighbor that thing yt he ne would unto
himself to be done. Vn^ ysodorus Quod no^ vis pati no^ facias: Saint poule
says: quod fures and latrones: regnu^ dei non possidebu^t. That is to say yt
convert theuys and watches of ways shall not possede the realm of god if they
deye impenytentes. etc. The.v. sin is sacrylege ye which is committee when
that a man hurts soylleth or violateth the holy things / or when a man them
steleth. In like wise does the harlot the which hurts / soylleth or
vyolateth marriage the which is a holy thing when he co^mytteth ye stenche and
fylth of lecherye in good and lawful marriage. Who so puts under ye fete of
hogs the sacrament of the altar / the corporaces or any holy thing to
the end yt they were soylled and hurt much he should sy^ne Legitur math. vii.
Nolite sanctu^ dare canibus: neque mittatis margaritas ante por. cos: ne forte
conculcent eas pedibus suis. Ne give you not holy things unto dogs / and put
ye not margaretes before the tete of the hogs yt they ne soylle them with
their fete. In like wise is it to hurt and to soil the holy sacrament of
marriage in the stynche of lecherye the which is more foul than donge ne
dyrte. Vn^ legitur eccle. ix. quod oi^s mulier q^ est fornicatoria q^si stercus
in via ab oi^bus pretereu^tibus conculcabitur. Every woman the which is a
fornycatoure shall be soylled in like wise as a torde in the way. Marriage is
an estate of great auctoryte the which should be treated and may^teyned
holyly / for god it establysshed in paradyse terrestre in the estate of
innocence before that man had ever sinned. And therefore a man it should holyly
keep for the reason of god ye which it establysshed and of the place where it
was establysshed. And after it is an estate of great dygnyte. For god would be
borne of a woman married / that was of ye blyssed vyrgyn Marye. etc. The.vi.
sin the which also may follow is incest ye which is a man to know his
kynneswoman / or a woman her kynnesman carnally as done these dogs. For if ye
harlot engendre a daughter on the wife of his neighbor it is possible that one
of his sons marye with ye daughter the which is his own sister ygnorantly /
for he knows nothing / or parauenture has her company as with a harlot
wenynge that she were nothing to him / so should it be inceste ye which is
the sin of a dog or hounde. The vii. sin is dysherytynge of their own
heirs when lygnee follows. For when the harlot engenders a child on the wife
of his neighbor / the said child shall possede the heritage wherein he has
nothing / and the true heirs shall be dysheryted and put out. The poor man
fraulded the which weneth to get for his children is spended and wasted. For
aduoutrers shall possede his goods and herytages ye which is so great a case
hard it is to find therein remedy and it to counsayll well that ye most sage
clerks therein ben excessyuely let. For all maladyccyon / dyffame /
dampnacion / and perdicion follows as well unto harlottes / rybauldes men and
women the which have committed the sin as unto the children aduoultres the
which be seized of the said goods and herytages wherein they have nothy^ge /
so nothing will they do for that / yt their mother was in lain of marriage when
they were begoten and born It is written eccle. xxiii. Mulier oi^s relinque^s
vitu^ suu^ and statue^s hereditate^ ex alieno matrimonio i^ lege altissimi
i^credebilis fuit viru^ suu^ dereli^quit i^ adulterio fornicata est et ex alio
viro filios statuit sibi. No^ trade^t filii eius radices / et rami eius non
dabunt fructu^ dereli^que^t i^ maledictu^ memoria^ eius and dedecus illius no^
delebitur. That is to say. Every woman leuynge her husband and establysshynge
ye heritage of a strange marriage has be incredyble in ye law of god / she
has left her husband / she has commit fornycacyon in aduoultre / and she
has taken a sone of another husband, her sons ne shall take rote and the
bow^s ne shall give of fruit. They shall leave the memory of her in malediccyon
and the dishonor of her shall not be es^aced. Et l^. pro vi. Qui au^t adultur
e^prodet ai^am sua^ turpuu dine and ignominia^ congregat sibi / and opprebrium
illius no^ delebitur. That is to say / he yt is a rybaulde shall lose his soul
/ his good fame and his reproach shall not be done away if he deye
impenytente. Also he yt co^mytteth aduoutre has maledyccyon in like wise as
it is written deute. xxvii. Maledictus q^ dormit cu^ vxore proximi sui: and
dicit oi^s populus ame^. Note well yt the sy^ne of aduoutre noyeth in.ix.
manners unto those yt it co^mytteth. Que. p. ad nu. b. c. d. e. f. g. h. i. k.

B. Examples we read tertu regum. xi. how salamon was a much harlot and loved
women strange ye which unto him were defended of god. And therefore his realm
was divided after his death in two parties / and his sone had much trouble for
hy^.

C. Also men find in writing in the ancient testamente of an aduouterer a
much harlot named judas / not he ye which sold our lord Ihesus / the which
as he yode to commit the said aduoutre in the presence of his wife / ye earth
opend under him and he fell in to depnes all clothed. Another example of a
woman married the which used her life in lecheryes and glotonyes / and therefore
was she dampened.xiii. a. Another example of a burge is aduoutrer / and of
another woman married / the which were dampened for their lecheryes lxxxxi. b.
Many other examples of aduoutrye shall be found in the exemplayre and by the
table the which is all alonge. The punycyon of those the which did break
their marriage and wedlock in the ancient and old testamente was that they
were stoned and put unto death incontinent the which should be a thing right
cruel if it should be used as now a days. For many should be punysshed ye
which ben a live. Legitur. leui. xx. and deutero. xxii. Si me chatus qis
fuerit cu^ vxore alterius et adulte riu^ propetrauerit cu^ co^iuge proximi sui
morte morientur and mechus and adultera. Those and they yt have broken their
maryages by lecherye should have contrycyon and make confession sacramentally
and do penance and they shall have grace and mercy. Example of a woman
aduoultres yt was saved by maky^ge co^fessyo^ sacramental. Que. lxxxxii. b
Another example how david ye prophet yt committed auoutrye with the wife of
vrie was sauid by repentance. He reknowleged his defaute and said peccaui. In
likewise as it is written in the.xii. cha. of the book of kings. etc.

Of things meritoryous and of offenses lecherous that a man co^mytteth with
his own wife. Ca. xxxvi.
Saint poule says in his epystylles. Satagitevt pro bona opera certa^
faciatis vocatione^ vestra^. Procure ye that ye make your vocacyon certain by
good operacyons. Marriage is certain vocacyon when it is kept holyly / clenly
/ and honestly. And it is dampnacyon when people the which ben knytte and united
in marriage ne keeps the honest and the chastyte the which apperteyneth unto
ye said holy sacrament. The deed of marriage may be merytoryous in.iii. manners.
First wha^ the pryncypall cause of yt is for to conceive lygnee. Secondly when
it is for to yield ye deuoyre of ye sacrament the one with the other. Thyrdly
when it is by good dyscrecyon to eschew sin in himself or in other. In this
last manner if they therein have no merit yet may he do it without sin. Some
time the deed of marriage is alonely venyel sin as when over the three manners
beforsayd a man secheth the pleasaunce of his sensualyte / how be it in such
conscience that the man ne will excede ye terms of honest of marriage. sometime
there is mortal sin and many manners. A metrifiour says. Qui^que modis
peccati^ vxore^ maritus: abutens. Te^pore: mente: loco / co^ditione / modo. The
husband abusing him with his wife synneth in five manners. That is to
understand by time / by mind / by place / by condycyo^ by the manner. By this
word here tempore is to understand yt in the time yt his wife is seek / feeble
/ and weyke / a man should absteyne from the operacyon of marriage / and the
woman should excuse her / for it should be great sy^ne in likewise as it is
written leui. xx. Also it is to absteyne him in the time of fastings for to
take away the pleasures of the body / and for to get anenst god more grace
and virtues. Also in ye time of the feestes solempnelles for to santyfye and
honor the said feestes the better Also in time that the woman is laid in
chyldbedde or ready to child. This word mente denotes yt when the thought and
concupyscence is carnal and lecherous / that it is out of the bounds of
marriage / yt is yt the man should accede also wyllyngly and promptly unto a
harlot if he hold her as he does his wife / the sin is great for ye thought
is ylle in all maneres where it is out of marriage. This word loco denotethe
when a man knows his party in place holy / as in the church / or
chircheyarde / it is sin for the holiness of the place. Also condition / for
to know it by condycyo^ of unhonest as openly before the people: or by
condycyon unlawful. It is a great offense. Also this word / modo / denotes yt
a man ne should know his party in other manner than nature it techeth: for it
is great sin. vn^. au. Vsus qi est contra naturam execrabiliter fit in
meritrice: sed execrabilius fit i^ vxore.xxx. q. v. adulteri. The usage yt is
again nature is done execrablye in ye harlot / but it is done more execrably
in his own wife.

E. Examples men read in thobye.vi. of the wife unto little thobye yt was
meruaylous fair and married unto.vii. husbands successyuely. The which the
devil strangled all seven the first night that they were laid together / for
that yt the said husbands acceded with her / not under ye entencyon of the
honest of marriage / but for to accomplysshe the voluptuolyte of their bodies
as they use somwhyle to do with a harlot. The little Thobye did not so by the
counsayll of the angel raphaell / and therefore the devil slew him not. vn^
tho. vi. Illa mulier tradita e^ septe^viris and mortui su^t: sed et hoc odiui
qia demon occidit illos. etc. F. Another example saint Gregorye shows in the
first book of ye dyalogue yt a woman in Catane of new married was conuayed
with other women to goo unto the dedycacyon of the church of saint Sebastian /
and the night yt she should go in the morning she was pricked with the flesh
that she ne might hold her from her husband. And in the morning she had
more great shame of men than of god and yode theder. And anon as she was
entered in to ye oratorye where the relyques of saint Sebastyan were / the
devil took her and began to tourmente her before all yt there were. Than the
priest of the church took the couerture from ye alter and couerde her / and
anon ye devil assaylled ye priest / and than the friends of yt woman said
unto ye enchauntours yt they should enchaunt the devil by their
enchau^tementes / but anon as they enchaunted by the judgment of god a legion
of enemies.vi.M.vi.C.lxvi deuylles entered in to ye woman and tormented her
asprely. And an holy man named Fortunate heled her by his prayers.

G. Another example saint gregorye tells in his dialogue how a woman lefully
was known of her own husband at saterdaye at night / and when she
accompanied with the other at the processyon of the sunday the devil entered
in to her and tourmented her strongly before all the people. By this example it
is to note that in holy times a man should absteyne him sometime from things
lefull. Also a man should understand yt marriage is one of ye.vii holy
sacraments / and for as much as it is holy he should draw him honestly and
holyly / and accede on his party in good entencyon. Those and they the which
done the contrary should dread to lose paradyse and ye reward yt the good
shall have the which have kept the sayncete of the said sacrament. Also they
should dread punycyon and dampnacyon / for all mortell sin byndeth unto
dampnacyon.

H. Example of a man married much devout / by the voluptuosyte of his flessh
yode unto his wife in other manner than nature ne techeth him / and therefore he
was dampened in the end of his days. As it was after showed by vysyon unto his
sone relygyous by his prayers and by the holy life that he was of.

I. Another example that men find in writing of a man married yt used his wife
dyshonestly as ye sodomytes / and much dyspleased unto his wife. and one time
