again her will commit in her the sin of sodomy and incontinent after that he
arose from his bed to goo in to the chambres in the which his bowelles fell
from him and dyscended by the foundement with great torment than he began to
cry / the people came and of the doloure yt he felt he told his said sin /
and that god him venged and punysshed / and my scheuously he deyed. Another
example of a man yt knew his wife on ester even. Que. lxxxxiii. a. Another
example how ye children of a man and of a woman ne might have baptysme for ye
sin that they committed in marriage / Que. lxxxxiii. b. Those yt have offended
in their maryages make they true confession and they shall have mercy. Que.
viii.c.

A. Of defloracion yt god defends. xxxvii
NOn mechaberis. keep ye from doing lecherye in any wise what so it be / he
yt does the work of nature out of marriage deceyueth himself. A man
co^mytteth defloracyon when one of the parties or both twain ben vyrgins and
they commit lecherye out of marriage. In the ancient testament she the which
suffered yt she were deflored was brent. vn^ le. xxi. Puella si depreheusa
fuerit in stupro et violauerit nome^ patris sui: fla^mis exuretur. For yt that
sychem deflored dine ye daughter of jacob / he and his fader with them of his
house were slain as it is written ge. xxxiiii. He yt defloreth a vyrgyne unto
her does do^mage inaprecyable / so yt there nys gold ne silver ne any thing
temporel of what valor so ever it be yt may be compared unto the valor of
one soul contynent as a vyrgyn maiden. Of whom it is written eccl. xxvi. Oi^s
po^deratio sclm cuiuslibet rei tpreoralis cuiuscu^que sit po^deris and valoris:
no^ e digna ai^e co^tine^ti. Saint jerome says yt unto these vyrgy^s is
promised fruit a. C. times / and when they be one time corrupt or bruised they
shall never recover the said fruit ne their vyrgynyte / no more than a man may
repair a lamp broken in pieces how be it it is to be understand but that they
may be saved in doing of penance / but they shall never be of the nombre of
vyrgyns in paradyse* they shall be of the nombre of those yt have done penao^ce.
Unto wedowes yt have well kept chastyte is promised fruit threscore times.
This says saint Iherome And unto women married fruit thyrtye times and every
one shall have after their deserte. Also the harlot the which corrupts a
vyrgyn is cause of all the payllardises and ylles yt the said vyrgyn does ever
after / as he the which makes a breche in ye corn well closed is cause yt
the said bestes entren in to the said corn and there done of do^mage / and for
to satyffye of the said ylle ye said harlot should close the breche unto his
power / yt is to withdraw ye said woman from sin. And after ye droitm he her
should marye with his goods / or to take her in marriage if she be not married:
or he should enter in to a monastery for to do penance perpetuell. Examples
how ylle is comen unto many the which have dyspoylled vyrgyns of their
maydenhede. First how a knight was dampened for that / yt he had deflored a
vyrgyn. Quere.lxxxxi b. Another example how a vyrgin was rauysshed in the
dance and fyled and after henge herself. Que. lxviii. f. Many other examples
ben written in the examplayre / Quere. lxxxxi. a. b. c.

B. Of inceste yt god defends. xxxvii.
NOn mechaberis. Fle al sin of lecherye and love clean life and pure / A man
co^mytteth inceste when ye parties the which accomplysshen lecherye ben of
lygnage / or of affynyte or under from the fyfte degree / or when there is
between the^ gossiprede by the mean of the sacrament of baptysme or of
confyrmacyon. After ye ancient law those the which committed this sin were
put unto death. vn^ leui. xx. Qui dormierit cu^ nouerca sua cum muru sua vterque
moriatur / quia scelus operati sunt sanguis eoru^ sit super eos. He ye which
has slepte with his stepmoder / or with his sister in law / the one / the
other shall deye / for they have done sin / their blood be upon them. Also he
the which has taken his sister the daughter of his fader or the daughter of
his mother ben they slain before ye people vn^ in dicto. ca. Qui acceperit
sorore^ suam filiam patris sui vel filiam matris sue. etc. Occidatur in
co^spectu populi sui. For this sin Ammon the sone of dauyd was slain by the
commandment of his brother Absalon / for he had deflored their sister Thamar
as it is wryte^ ii. regum. xiii. Also all malediccyon dyscendeth upon them the
which committee this sin as it is written deutero.xxviii. Maledictus qui
dormit cu^ vxore patris sui et cu^ sorore sua filia patris sui vel matris sue
et dicit omnis populus amen. That man is accursed the which slepeth with the
wife of his fader / and with his sister ye daughter of his mother. And all the
people shall say amen so be it. Also punycyon and dampnacyon follows unto
them ye which know their gossyppes men or women or god sons / or god
daughters as we read in the dyalogue of saint Gregorye that for the lecherye of
a curyal the which corrupt a fair daughter that he had holden on the font
of baptysme he deyed suddenly in the church before the people. Que. post ad
numerum.lxxxx. b. Another example of a woman dampened and terrybly tourmented
the which had committee lecherye with one of her kynnesmen. Quere. lxxx^ a. If
thou have offended in this vice goo unto penance. Quere.viii. b.

B. Of sacrylege as unto lecherye yt god defends. Ca. xxxvii.
Saint Bernarde says. Tangere qui gaudens meretricem qualiter audes. Palmis
pollutis: rege^ palpare salutis. Thou man of the church the which enioyest ye
to touch an harlot / how dare thou touch the king of health with thy
hands soylled. Thou art sacryleged the which soyllyst the holy sacrament of
ordres that thou haste received. Sacrylege is committee in many manners / but yt
which touches the sin of lecherye / is when a man hurts / soylleth / or
vyolateth ye holy things / as those the which ben in holy ordres hallowed unto
god / priest religious man or woman / and they co^mytteth ye sin of the
flesh. Such people synneth grievously they ben to punysshe. Example how a
priest fornycatour deyed suddenly in sy^ as he would have so^ge mass. lxxxxiii
d. Another example of the punycyon and dampnacyon of a no^ne the which
committed lecherye.lxxxiii. f.

Of things the which greueth ye sy^ne of ye flesh. in people of the
church. xxxvii
Saint Iherome says. In maiori gradu: mayor si^e dubio pena Of asmoche more as
lecherye is committee in great degree of a person / unto him there apperteyneth
the more great pain and punycyon. Many things aggreueth ye sy^ne of the
flesh in them of the church. The first thing is that they break the vow
of chastyce that they promised unto god in receyuynge the holy ordres. When any
them receives he renou^ceth unto marriage / and unto all copulacyon of woman.
And if ever after he go thereto he is a breker of his auowe the which is a
great case. The psalmyst says. Couete et reddite dn^o deo vestro. Vow ye and
yield ye unto our lord god. It is great sin unto lay people to committee
lecherye out of marriage / for they go against the law and commandment of
god / but the sin is more great unto the people of the church ye which
breketh their vow and the commandment of god. The second thing the which
aggreueth the sin unto ye people of ye church / is when dyrectly and
wyttynge they go again the will of god and again ye science and ye good that
they know. Their sin is greter than that of simple people the which ne
know ne yet understand the scryptures and synneth by ygnorau^ce Saint
gregorye says. Melius est via^ veritatis n^n cognoscere: quam eam cognita^
no^ seruare. It is better thing not to know the way of truth / than not to
keep it after that it is known. And saint peter says. Melius erat illis no^
cognoscere via^ iustitie quam post aguitione^ retrorsu^ co^uerti / It were
better unto those sinners not to know ye way of Justice than to convert them
unto ye contrary after the knowledge. And iaco. iii. Scie^ti bonu^ facere and
no^ facie^ti peccatu^ est illi. Sin it is to him knowing to do well and not
doing it The third thing ye which agreueth the sin in people of the
church is for yt / that they ben the example of all derkenes derysyon /
sclaundre / and sin. And they should be the light / the lantern / and ye
example of all chastyte / bounte and holiness and virtues after yt the which is
written mar. v. Vos estis lux mu^di. Sequi^ui. S^ luceat lux vestra cora^
hominibus vt videant opera vestra bona et glorificent patre^ vestrum qi est in
celis. You be the light of the world / your light shyneth in such wise /
before men that they se your good operacyons and yt they gloryfye your fader
the which is in heaven. And saint augu. says Quicqid vide^t laici vobis
displicere dicu^t procul dubio sibi no^ licere. Quicqid vos in opere vident ad
implere: credu^t esse licitu^ et culpa carere. What thing yt this lay people
se dysplease unto you / they se without doubt that it is not lefull unto them
and any thing that they se you to accomplysshe in operacyon they believe to be
lefull and without gylte. When the candyll or the light of a house is put out
it is occasyon that all those of the said house ben in derkenesse. Also when
the curates / chapelayns / clerks / and people of the church ben harlottes
the whi^^e should be the light of chastyte / of pureness / of clennes as it is
said / it is the occasyon that little people ben ill and harlottes. And by this
ye sin is ye more grievous unto pleople of ye church the which ben the
example of sclaundre and of sin / whereof follows maladyccion. Vnde mathei.
viii. Ve mundo a scandalis. Sequitur. Ve homini per que^ scandalum venit.
Maledyccyon unto the world for these sclaundres. Maledyccion unto him by whom
sclaundre comes. / When a priest is lecherous by him there proceeds great
sclaundre the which is a thing that pleases unto the devil and dyspleaseth
much unto our lord. Example how the devil charged a woman for to committee
lecherye with priests for the great ill the which thereof does proceed
Quere.lxvi. f. Also the wound or hurt is wors more vyllayne and apparent when
it is within the eye than in another membre / so is the sin of lecherye in
people of the church than in the lay people. Ihero. dicit. quod clericus aut
honestior e^ ceteris aut alus fabula. The clerk either he is more honest than
these other / or he is the tale unto other / yt is the example wors than ye
other. The fourth thing the which agreueth the sin is for yt that the
people of the church ben mynysters of god and of his household deputed unto
his service and live of his gods and have the great wages: benefyces and
revenues. When the household servant of the king of great lord governs
dyshonestly and dysobeyeth unto his master he is more to blame and to punysshe
than is another stranger / for that that he lives under him and has great
salayre / in like wise is it of the people of the church. Vn^ psalm. Verba
dn^i. Si inimicus meus maledisset mihi: sustinuisse^ vtique. and for asmoche as
the word of god is despised of his own household servants he is the more
ill content. etc. Also when fornycacyon is done in the church the syn is more
great than if it were done in other place. For the church is blyste and
deputed unto ye service of god. Also lecherye is more great sin in people of
the church the which ben blyste in receyuynge the holy ordres and deputed
unto service of god than in simple people. Au. Plus peccat clericus multere^
concupisce^do quam carnalitur laycus ipsam atti^ge^do. The clerk synneth more
in couueytynge the woman than ye lay man in touching her carnally. Also ye
barkynge of dogs is nuysyble unto ye ox. ye wayllynge of hogs pleases
more to god tha^ these lecherous clerks. Au. Plus placet deolatratus canu^ /
mugitus bouu^ / gemitus porcoru^ / quam vox clericoru^ luxuriantiu^. Also these
rich people have in hate and abhomynacion their servants when they ben foul
and vyllayns / and loves ye pure and clean. In like wise god has in hate his
servant foul / stynkynge / and soylled by lecherye. Le. eccle. xii. quod
altissimus odio habet pcto^res. The right great / yt is god ye which has in
hate the sinners. Also the sinner and his sin be in hate unto god. vn^.
sapien. xiiii. Odio sunt deo impius and impietas eius. The.v. thing the which
agreueth the sin is the dygnyte of the office wherein ben ordained these
priests the which is soylled in co^myttynge lecherye. The priests ben so
dygne that they excercyse the office of au^gelles / whereof it is written ma. ii.
Labia eni^ sacerdotis custodiu^t scie^tia^ and lege^ requirent ex ore eius qia
angelus diu^ excercituu^ est. The lyppes of the priest keeps science and these
other requires ye law of his mouth / for he is an angel / yt is to
understand messenger of our lord of the office of compaygnyes. The office and
ye excercyse that these aungelles have ye which keeps us to admynystre unto
us and to counsayll to live after the science and the law and the
commandments of god / and unto priests is betaken this office. And therefore
they should live chastely or their sin shall be right grievous. Also ye
priests have more great dygnyte than the au^gelles in as much as they have
the office to consecrate the body of Ihesus the which the aungelles have not.
For they have not received the ordres. And for asmoche as these priests have
so great dygnyte they should be full of great valor and bounte more than the
lay people / or their sy^ne shall be more great. Also a pyece of gold is
more worth and more dygne than a piece of led or metal / so is ye priest for
his dygnyte / than a seculer / whereby his sin is more great when he offends
against god Also no man ne here the mass of a priest the which he knows
vndoutfully to have concubyne. Vn^ lucius dicit. quod nullus audiat missa^
sacerdotis que^ scit idubitantur co^cubina^ habere. Also these priests /
curates and prelates ben vycayres and lieutenau^tes of god the which have
puyssaunce in many case to absoyle and to unbind ye sins from their
subgectes. And if any be defayllynge and inobedyentes for to bind them and to
exco^munycate as it is wryte^ mat. xvi. Quodcu^que ligaueris super terra^ erit
ligatu^ et i^ celis and quodcu^que solueris su per terram erit solutu^ et in
celis. et iho. xx. Quorum remiseritis pcta^ remittu^tur eis: and quoru^
retinueritis rete^ta su^t. when a lieu tenant governs him ylle in his
co^myssyon in dysobeynge unto his master his sin is more great than if he
had not the office. These prestes have the office beforsayd ye which ye
au^gelles have not / whereby their sin is the more grievous if they govern
them ylle. Example how two of the priests of the ancient law couueyted
vnshamefully and prayed Susanne of dishonor / and because she resysted again
them they thought to have made her deye but they themself were slain / their
syn was great for they were priests au^cyentes and iuges. Que. lxxxxvi. c.
The.vi. thing ye aggreueth the syn is when these prestes lodge and put to rest
their god and maker after ye celebracyon in their bodies ye which is vile / and
stynkinge / and in deed if he be polluted by lecherye. Vn^. i. corin. xi.
Quicu^que ma^ducauerit pane^ vel biberit calice^ dn^i i^digne reus erit

E Example how two prestes lecherous were punysshed. It is written in ye

F. Example for to keep chastyte / and for to flee the stynkynge sin of
lecherye the which is cause of so many euylles / It is written in ye life of
faders that a relygyous wrapped his hands in his mau^tell of dread to touch

so wrapped / he answered yt the body of a woman is fire / and at yt hour that I
touched yt it came to my remembrance of other women / wherefore if we will keep
chastyte it behooves to fle the look / the company / and the touching of the
woman. The pope innocent lays yt these clerks ne abyden with these women but
with those the which ben ancient without voluptuosyte carnal. And saint

su^t iuice^ puditia^ vestra^ custodite. etc. Those ye which have offended god

apostate and lecherous had mercy by penance. Quere. xlviii. e.

G. Of the sin again nature and of sodomye that god defends.
THe master of sentences says in his fourth book. Peius est eni^ cu^ matre
quam cu^ aliena vxore dormire: sed oi^m horum pessimum quoth co^tra natura^sit. It
is wors to sleep with his mother than with another woman / but worste of all above
all these other is that the which is done again nature. The sin again
nature is commit in many manners / the which sin is so horrible and
detestable yt men dare not write ne preche yt that the scriptures tells and
for cause / for many therein may offend. But in confession it should be
declared by the sinner if ye sinner will save his soul if he be fallen in to
such sy^ne by atouchy^ge upon himself / or with bestes / or in other manners
again the ordonnaunce yt god and nature has put in such case. Those yt
comyt this sin after ye faith should be put unto death. vn^ leui. xx. Qui
dormierit cu^ masculo coitu feminco vterque operatus est nefas morte moriatur
sit sa^guis eoru^ super eos seqitur. Qui cu^ tume^to et peccore coierit morte
moriatur: pecus quoque occidite. etc. Also they have maledyccyon as it is
written deutero. xxvii. Maledictus qi dormit cu^ oi^ iume^to et dicet oi^s
populus ame^. Sodomye was lost for this sin ye which dyspleaseth unto god
yt he made to fall.v. cytes. That is to understand Sodom / go more / segor /

A. Of ye virtue of chastyte ye which is again the sin of lecherye. Ca.
xxxviii.
IT is written luce. xii. Si^t lu^bi vestri preci^cti and lucerne arde^tes i^
manibus vestris. etc. Let your rayns be gyrde with the gyrdyl of chastyte and the
lyghtes brenne in your hands by good operacyons. God will that al persons men

clean / and loved of god. And of ye soul chaste and vyrgyn is written. can^.
ii. Sicut liliu^ int spinas: sic amica mea i^ter filias. The lely is a fair
flower ye which has.vi. leuys white the which sygnyfyeth the chastyte of ye

/ white pure / and clean without any spotte. Unto ye which estate a man may
say that there apperteyneth a white robe. Of this estate it is written how

melodyously a new long / and unto him it was said illud apocalipsis. xiiii.
Hi sunt qui cu^ mulieribus no^ sunt coinquitati virgins enim ^unt. Hi
sequu^tur agnum quocunque ierit. sequitur. Si ne macu^a sunt ante thronum dei.
A white robe is more clean than another / ye which ought to be kept from
soyllynge. For the spotte therein is more foul than in another robe. In like
wise chastyte vyrgynyte ought to be kept from the soyllerye of lecherye. Of ye
beauty of vyrgynyte is written can^. ii. T'ota pulchra is amica mea: et macula
non est in te. Example is the blyssed vyrgyn marye the which is the example of
virginite and of all chastyte the which was all fair without any spotte for
never origynal sin / venyel / ne mor tell ne entered in to her. Also chastyte
is a treasour inaprecyable. Whereof it is written ecclesa. xxvi. Omnis ponderatio
scz cuilibet rei: temporalis cuiuscunque sit ponderis and valoris non est digna
anime continenti. There is neither gold ne silver ne precious stone ne other
thing corporell / of what valor and price so ever it be / yt is to be
compared unto onesoule chaste and contynente as a vyrgyn and maiden. Example
men read in ye legende of saint bernarde that there was a fair man ye which
came to lodge in an ynne / and in the night he began to cry / a these thieves
these thieves / for his hostess came to him in the night for to have had his
company / and three times in such wise he cried / wherefore the people rose up
which found no thieves. And in the morning his dyscyples him demanded the
cause of his cry. He them answerde that his hostess would have stolen from
him his precious treasour of vyrgynyte. Of this treasour of chastity that a man
should love it is written math. xiii Simile est regnum celorum thesauro
abicondito in agro. Thesaurum in agro est castitas in cord. etc. A treasour ye
which is hid in a poor place / as the body ye which is frayll to sin
ought be kept ye thieves stele it not. A loule contynent as a vyrgyn ought well
to be kept it eme ylle thoughts / or she shall lose her said treasoure. Quia
augusimus dicit. Nichil prodest virginitas corporis vbi operatur corruption
mentis. Also to live chastely and to keep vyrgynyte in our corruptyble bodies
the which of it self is lecherous is not a life erthely nor terryenne / but
it is a life angelike. Vnde therono. In seimone de assumptione beat marie ait
sic. Been angelus ad virginem mittitur: quia angelis semper e^ cognata
virginitas profecto ait. Incarne preter carnem viuere non e^ terrena vita: sed
angelica. Wherefore you vyrgyns / and men and women the which loves chastyte
beware of exces of metes and drynkes for yt provoke lecheryes. / And for
asmoche as those and they ye which keeps vyrgynyte and chastyte ledeth a life
angelyke / they shall be semblables unto aungelles. Vn^ math. xxii. In
resurrectione no^ nubent neque nube^tur: sed eru^t sicut angeli dei in celo.
Also these au^gelles keeps the vyrgyns and the people chaste by great
curyosyte. In like wise as saint Cecyle said unto valeryan. Vnde legitur in
legenda cecile. Angelu^ dei habeo amatorem qui nimio zelo custodit corpus meu^
etc. Also the soul chaste and vyrgyn ye which has steadfast faith in god is
the espouse of Ihesu christ: whereof it is written.ii. ad. co. xi. Despo^di eni^
vos vni viro virgine^ casta^ exhibere christo. Et legitur can^. iiii. Veni de
libano spo^sa mea veni coronaberis. Et in vna antiphona. Veni spo^sa christi
accipe corona^ qua^ tibi dn^s preparauit ineternu^. The espouse of Ihesu christ
shall be crowned in paradyse for the resystence that she had made again her
body lecherous and again her other adversaries Example we read in ye legende
of saint Cecile that an angel bare two crowns of fair flowers well
smelling. And the said angel put one upon ye heed of saint Cecyle. And the
other upon the heed of her husband Valeryan. Vn^ legitur. quod valetianus
inuenit iuxta cecilia^ angelu^ dn^i stantem fla^meo aspectu radie^tem coronas
duas portante^ i^ manibus corusca^tes rosis et liliis albescentes qique vna^
dedit cecilie / et alter a^ valeriano dice^s. Has coronas nu^quam marcesce^tes:
nunquam aspectus suiflorem amitte^tes nunquam odoris sui suauitate^ minue^tes
de paradiso dei: vobis allatas mu^do cord and corpore cusiodite q^ ab alio
vide ii no^ poteru^t nisi ab eis qibus castitas placuerit sicut vobis probata
e^ placuisse. Unto the flower of virginite ben appropried the words of the
sayge. eccle. xxiiii. Flores mei fructus honoris and honestatis. That is to
say my flowers bears fruit of honor and of honest. Many flowers there ben
the which bears truyte of honor and of honest as the lylly / the rose /
the vyolet ye gyllofre. These flowers here have in the^ four things. The
first is beauty in beholding them. The second is good odor in smelling
them. The third is yt they worship the person ye which bears them
The.iiii. is yt they ben good to make medecynes and water. etc. In like manner a
person vyrgyn and chaste has these four propryetes here. First his soul is
fair / and so is the body oftymes. Sicut le. ge. xxiiii. Rebecca fuisse puella
decora nimis vgo que pulcherima and i^cognita viro. Another example ye saint
Barbara was fair of faith of body / and of soul. Pulchra facie: sed pulchrior
fide. For she vowed and kept virginite and refused to be married. And her fader
did make for her a toure for to hyde her beauty. O nimia^ pulchritudinem fecit
la pidcam in qua genitor iilam subliuius collocaret. etc. Secondly the person
the which keeps vyrgynyte and chastyte has the odoure of good reno^mee and
before god and the world as the vyrgyn married and these other vyrgyns. etc.
And unto the contrary lechery makes to have ill reno^mee unto those and them
that use it / and unto their lygnee. Thyrdly vyrgynyte and chastyte worshyppeth
and honors the vyrgyns / and ye place where they ben entered / and where
their image is / is worshypped and honored. Fourthly vyrginyte and chastyte is
of valcure / for ye vyrgyns do miracles and many good deeds Lecherye is unto
the contrary of the.iiii. things beforsayd / for she is not to be compared
unto the vile carcas and flesh roten the which leseth four things / that
is for to understand / beauty corporell / savor good and sweet odor / and
good reno^me. Chastyte is a fair virtue the which ought to be gretely
appetyted for the goodness the which thereof proceeds. Vn^ magister hugo de
sa^cto victore dicit. Magna est pudicitie virtus nam hominem a terreno subleuat
/ angelis sociat deo coniungit / et de terreno celestem de carnali spirituale^
facit. Chastyte is a great virtue celestyall and spyrytuall / it lyfteth up the
man from erthly things and felawshyppeth him with the aungelles / and conioyneth
him with god from erthly and makes him celestyall / and fro carnal espyrytual.
A questyon / who so should demand what vyrgynyte is / and what reward unto
it apperteyneth. The answer. Vyrgynyte is to have thought to keep perpetual
chastyte in his body corruptyble. And of the reward saint Iherom says that
unto the vyrgyns is promised fruit and ho^dred times. Unto wydowes lx. And
unto the married men and women xxx. For to be a vyrgyn and to have the reward
that thereunto apperteyneth it behooves to keep two things the which ben
chastyte of body and of thought. And a man should note here many things. First
that when a person has committed one only time lechery by delyberacyon and by
operacyon he loses the reward of vyrgynyte Howbeit that a man should not
understand but that he may be saved by penance. And when the thought of a
vyrgyn is corrupt and not the body if she be repaired by penance with purpose
for to keep her she loses not the reward the which apperteyneth unto
vyrgyns. And when any persons maryeth them and that they do the operacions of
marriage in likewise as god and the church has ordained / in such case they
do their salvation / but they have not the reward the which apperteyneth
unto vyrgins. And of those and them the which have their bodies entyer without
corrupcyon / and the which ne ben married but have their wylles steadfast to
mary them / they ben not worthy too have the reward the which aperteyneth
unto vyrgyns. Vnde hiero. Nichil prodest habere virginem si mentem quis
nupserat. Et augustinus in libro virginitate sic ait. Felici or michi videtur
esse mulier nupta quam virgo nuptura habet enim illa quam ista cupit. The
vyrgyns have the most gretest reward in paradyse / and of good right. For
their bodies have not ben soyled ne corrupt by lechery / and also they have
opteyned ye better party / that is to please and to serve god and not unto the
body and unto the world. Vnde hieronimus. Bona est castitas co^iugalis /
melior est vidualis / sed optimus virginalis. Et paulus.i. corinth. vii. Qui
sine vxore est sollicitus que domini sunt quomo do placeat deo. etc. sequitur.
Mulier innupta et virgo cogitat que domini sunt / vt sit sancta corpore and
spiritu. Qui cum vxore est sollicitus est que sunt mundi quomodo placeat vxori
and diuisus est. Alibi. Dico aute^ no^ nuptis et viduis bonum esse illis si
perman serint sic quod si se non continent nubent / melius est enim nubere quam
viri. And if a vyrgyn be corrupt by force she loses not the reward of
chastyte by such wise that afterward she be not unto the said deed agreeable /
and that she humble her toward god. Quia peccatum est actio voluntaria / and
no^ est peccatum nisi voluntarium. Et legitur primi regum.xvi. Homo enim videt
ea q^ parent deus autem intuetur cor. Example in saint Luce the which lied not
/ for ye holy ghost was in her / said unto the tyrau^t Si inuitam me violare
feceris castitas michi duplicabitur ad coronam. Et leo ^^^a dicit. Virgins dei
q^ oppressione barbarica integritatem carnis perdiderunt pudoris laudabilioris
erunt si se inco^taminatis non audeant comparare virginibus. etc.

B. The vyrgyns should dread many things for feere to lose paradyse and their
reward. The first thing that they should dread is pride espyrytuall and
vayneglory Vnde Augustinus in libro de virginitate sic ait. Non solum
predicanda est virginitas vt ametur verum et mouenda est ne i^fletur. The
second is slouthe / tedyousnes and ydlenes whereby the devil has entry^ge for
to tempt and deceive. When ye person is occupied the devil has none
entering / that is too understand folysshely to behold / to here / to speak /
to touch / and to goo in to evil companyes. etc. Who so will keep chastyte
ought to have good closure that cursed beestes and the venym of lechery enter
not in to the gardyn of their conscience. Vnde can^. iiii Ortus conclusus soror
mea sponsa / ortus conclusus fons signatus. When a gardin is well closed therein
enters no beestes. etc. The vyrgyns keep clennesse of heart and of conscience
to the end that they have beatytude. Vnd mathei. v. Beati mu^do cord quoniam
ipsi deo videbunt. And if their said heart be soyled by lechery they ne do
nothing. Vnde augustinus. Nichil prodest virginitas corporis vbi operatur
corruption mentis vt dictu^ est. Example how Iudyth kept well her five wits of
nature / for after that her husband was deed she made her secrets and her
bed in the heyght of her house for to euyte and fle companyes of people / and
lived solytaryly with her mayde^s without being in will to mary. She kept
chastely her wydowhede. Vnde judith vltimo. Erat judith virtuti castitas
adiuncto / ita vt non cogno sceret virum omnibus diebus vite sue ex quo
defunctus est manasses vir eius. and cetera. The fourth thing that these
vyrgins should dread is to much great nourysshement / for the good wine and
the delycyous meets draws the^ unto lechery And therefore these vyrgyns
should fle drinking of wine in likewise as venym. Vnde Hieronimus. Virga ipsa
vinum fugiat vt venenum. Example in Loath the which defloured his own
daughters when yt he was drunk / and he apperceyued it not in his dronkennes.
The fyfthe is imperseueraunce / for it suffyseth not too keep vyrgyte in
sometimes / but it behooves to persevere Vnde mathei. x. and.xxiiij. Qui
perseuerauerit vsque in finem hic saluus erit.

C. Examples of vyrgynyte. And first a man may say by figure and symylytude
that the soul the which is vyrgyn / chaste pure / and clean without sin is
loved of Ihesu christ and shall be crowned in paradise if he persevere in bou^te.
As Hester was beloved of king Assuerus / of whom it is written in the bible.
Quod hester erat pulchra nimis facieque decora and omnium oculis gratiosa / hec
enim dicta est ad cubiculum regis et adamauit eam rex super om^es mulieres et
posuit dyadema regis in capite eius. Another example how saint Agnes vyrgyn and
martyr was much loved of Ihesu crist. Also she reputed her to be his espouse
when she refused the sone of the prouo^ in marriage / her friend / and his
rychesses unto whom she said that she was prevented unto another lover better
than he of kind and of dygnyte the which unto her offered better ournementes
than he ne did. And that was Ihesu christ the which promised her paradyse and
the reward of vyrgynyte. Vnde legitur in legenda eius. Discede a me fomes
peccati nutrimentu^ facinoris pabulum mortis quia iam ab alio amatore preuenta
sum qui satis michi meliora ornamenta offerens fidei sue anulo s^^barrauit me /
long te melior et genere et dignitate po fuit signum in faciem meam vt nullum
preter eum amatorem admitta^. etc Another example that saint Luce was so chaste
of body of thought with the aid of the holy ghost that no strength of man ne
might led her unto the stews or bordelhous. The holy ghost her fastened and
held so strongely that no men ne might moeue her from thens where she was
rested / the which was steadfast as a mountain. And in likewise these women
should be so ferme and steadfast in good purpose to keep chastyte that no men
ne might draw them for to commytte lechery. etc. Another example how saint
Iustyne kept her chastyte and resysted against ye devil and against Cypryan
the which her tempted to commyte lechery in likewise as it is written in her
legende. Another example how three fair vyrgyns systers were kept of god in
such manner that the provost of Rome ne might defloure them / and as he wend
to dyspoyle them in his kechyn he did his sin in the pottes and caudrons.
Quere in the examplarye. lxxxxi. E. Other examples how saint Margaret and saint
Peronell kept their vyrginyte and resysted so well that they ben worthy to
have the reward eternal / to the which we may go. Amen.

A. Of dronkenes and glotony that god defends. xxxix.
IT is written eccle. xxi. Amaritudo anime vinum multum potatum. Wine drunk to
excess is bitter unto the soul / and also also it is contrary unto chastyte
For when the womb is replete lightly it is moeued unto lechery. Vnde
hieronimus. Venture mero repletus de facili spumat libidinem. And saint Poule
says ad ephesios.v. Nolite inebriari vino in quo est luxuria. Be ye not drunk
by wine / wherein is lechery. That is to wete yt the wine heteth and moeueth the
body to comytte lechery / and the man that so delyteth is not wise. Vnd
proverb. xx. Luxuriosa res vinu^ et timultuosa ebrietas: quicu^que hus
delectatur no^ erit sapie^s. The sin of glotony is defended when a man
breketh the fastings commanded in obeyenge unto the womb yt will ete when
god commands to fast or when men ete any things defended as Adam yt ete of
the apple against the commandment of god / or as those the which eteth
flesh on the frydayes or saterdayes or butter in lent when it is defended in
ye bysshopryche / or when some gloto^s loves their wombes more than god or
egally unto him the which is ydolatry / as it is declared in the first
commandment. Que. ix.c. Or when men take the hour as to ete on ye sondayes
and festes before mass or before yt they have served god / or when a man
secheth unto superfluyte and is to much lycorous or gredy of good wynes / and
of fatre and delycatyue meets / or prepayreth them over deyntely. To such
savor and delectacion unto superfluyte there is sin / but if any have honger
and yt he eteth and also delyteth in the meet it is no sin / for it is a
thing natural yt behooves unto al bestes If any also prepayre the meet in
such manner and intencyon yt he may ete it after the co^plexyon and faculte of
him / for otherwise he ne may ete it / he it also may do without sin. Vnde
au. Vtantur diuites co^suetudine i^firmitatis sue: sed dolea^t se aliter no^
posse melius ei^ facere^t si aliter possent. Also those the which has vowed
not to ete eggs on the friday / or flesh on the wednesday sy^neth as unto
the fraccyon of the vow: and as unto glotony. Also the excess of meet and
drink is defended that is to understand when a man eteth too much of breed
and of meet that nature be grieved / or that a man vomet / or when a man takes
so much of drink that a man becomes drunk and that the entendement be
troubled / or to excede in drink and mete togyders. A doctor named de
vrimaria says. Quicu^ que inebriatur vel excedit mensuram in commedendo vel
bibe^do et hoc facit preposito and intention / talis peccat mortaliter tociens
quotiens / sed si sit ignoranter et sieve preposito vel si causa euenerit aut ex
fragilitate sume^tis tunc peccat venialiter. That is to say. What soever man
that makes himself drunk or excedeth the measure in etinge or drinking and
does it with intency on and purpose synneth mortally by as many oftymes as it
happens. And if he do it ygnourantly and without purpose disposed or if it
happen by fraylte he synneth venyally. And another doctor named herma^num
believes that when any takes so much of drink and meet unto superfluyte and
from than forth that it grieve nature be it by vometynge or not / and that of
it yt which he has superfluyte and haboundaunce many poor people had been
sustained the which peradventure had thereof necessyte / he believes that it
is mortal sin. Qr contra caritatem proximi. This sin is called surfyt the
which is when men eteth of the meet eschauffed and warm before that it be
baked / soden / or roasted enough / the which does evil / or to ete so much
mete yt it ne may bake in the dygestyon natural the which causethe corporal
infyrmytees and spyrytualles / and makes men surfytous to deye as says ye
sage. Vnde eccle. xxxvii. Propter crapulam multi obierunt qui autem abstinens
est aduciet vitam. And the gospel says that these persons should keep their
hertes that they be not grieved in surfytes and dronkennes. Vnde luce. xxi.
Attendite autem vobis ne forte grauenter corda vestra in crapula et ebrietate.
Et psalm. dicit. Tanquam potens crapulatus a vino. A man surfyteth also by
ouermoche dry^ke / when he takes so much that his heart is drouned. Also the
excess of drink wastes the mind / breketh the wit and the thought /
confounds the entendement it moves unto lecherye / it noyeth too speak well
and implies the words / corrupts the blood / derketh the sight / perturbeth
ye veins / takes the strength from the synewes / makes the eeres deef /
troubles the guts / subuerteth the person / moysteth ye brain / lets the
sleep / weyketh all ye me^bres / shorteth the life / lets prayer / the
virtue and all good operacyons. Vnde legitur eccle. xxxi. Vinum multum potatu^
irrationem et iram et ruinas multas facit ebrietas animositas imprudentis
offensio minorans virtutem et faciens vulnera. etc Also the sage Salamon says
that the Joy of the body and of the soul is when a man drynketh of wine
moderately without excess / sobre drinking is health of the body and of the
soul. Vnde eccle. xxxi. Exultacio amime et corporis vinum modere potatum /
sanitas corporis et anime sobrius potus. And saint Poule says that these
dronken people shall not possede the realm of paradyse if they deye
impenytentes. Vnde.i. ad Corinth. vi. Neque fures / nequod auari / neque
ebriosi / regnu^ dei possidebunt. And of him the which constreyneth any to
dry^ke to excess saint Augustyn says. Qui alium cogit vt plus bibat quam
opus sit vt bibendo inebriet / melius esset illi vt carnem suam cum gladio
vulneraret quam animam eius per ebrietatem occideret. that is to say that he
the which constreyneth any to dry^ke more than he should to the end that in
dry^kinge he be dronken / better it were for him that he made a wound in his
body with a sword than he should sle his soul by drokennesse. Note well that
the sin of drunkenness noyeth and harmeth in many manners unto them the
which it commytteth Quere ad numerum.xliiii. b.c.d.e.f.g.h.i.k Examples how
mani ben come unto an evil conclusyon by glotony. First how great evil came
unto Adam for bytynge of the apple. etc. Quere in the examplarye. liiii. A.
Another example written in the.xii. chapytres of Iudyth the which with wine
made Holofernes drunk / and in his dronkennes smote of his heed. Another
example how punycyon dyuyne / sekenes / and death came unto the cursed king
Balthazar in a great dinner that he had made unto the great lords of his court
in likewise as it is written. Danielis.v. ca. Another example how Amon the sone
of Dauyd the which dyspoyled his sister Thamar was slain at a great dinner by
his brother Absalon / in likewise as it is written in the.xiii. chapter of the
second book of kings. Another example how the sons of Job and his daughters
were slain at a great dinner of their oldest brother / in likewise as it is
written in the.xvi. chapter of the said Job. Another example how ye princes of
the Phelystyns feested togiders and made a great dinner / and Sampson ye strong
pulled down the house upon them / and there were three thousand persons slain
in likewise as it is written in the.xvi. chapter of the book of Iuges. Another
example how saint Johan baptyst was beheeded and his heed was borne unto king
Herod as he was making a great dinner in likewise as it is written in
the.xiiii. chapter of the gospelles of saint Mathewe. Another example of
filius prodegus that wasted his substance in glotonyes and lecheryes / in
likewise as it is written in the xv. chapter of the gospels of saint Luke.
Another example of a pilgrim ye which sold his goune for to drink wine /
and evil came unto him. Quere in thexamplary.lxxxxiii. G. Another example that
ill came unto a man named Vodo the which yode to ete and drink at the tavern
wha^ he should have gone unto the church. Quere in thexamplary.lxvii. E. Many
other examples of glotons shall be found in the third commandment of
thexamplary. Quere per tabulam.lxvii. a.b.c.d.e.

B. Of fasting and abstinence that god commands. xxxix.
IT is written. Gen^. iii. ca. De ligno scie^tie boni et mali / ne comedas.
Incontinent that Adam was fourmed god him defended that he should not ete of
the fruit of the tree of science both good and evil. He dysobeyed unto the
said commandment and evil came unto him / in likewise as it is written in the
examplary. Quere liiii. a. Also god will that we fast and do abstynence in some
days that the church determyneth us. Fasting is instytued for ye health of
our souls / in likewise as says the scryptures. Vnde hiero. Ieiunio et
oratione sanande sunt passiones corporis et pestes mentis. The passions of the
body / and the pestelence of the thought ben heled by fasting and prayer. And
Ysodorus says Abstinentia enim carnem superat / luxuriam refrenat / et alia
vicia calcat. Abstyne^ce surmou^teth the flesh / refreyneth lechery / and
fouleth ye other vices. A man may not well overcome the temptacions but by
fastings and abstynences. Vnde. Ysidorus. Non potes te^ptationes vi^cere nisi
ieiunus insisteris. Also fasting lyfteth our thought up unto god in devotion
and contemplacyon / and also augmenteth the virtues and the reward eternal /
in likewise as says ye preface of lenten. Qui corporali ieiunio vicia
co^primis / mente^ eleuas / vtute^ largiaris and premia. etc. Also abstynence
and fasting ben much prouffytable in likewise as it appears by many stories
of the bible. It is written in the.xiii. chapter of the book of Iuges how the
angel of god appeared unto the wife of Ma^ne brehaigne unto whom he
commanded that she ne should drink wine ne sydre and yt she should not eete
any unclean thing and yt she should have a sone / and so it was done. And she
conceived Sampson the strong. Another hystory is written in the.xx. chapter of
the book of Iuges that after that the children of Ysrael had fasted and wept
they fought with the sons of Beniamyn and they had victory. Another hystory
how the prophet Helye did great abstyne^ces when he demanded of a woman
wydowe a little of water to drink and a shyuer of breed / the said wydowe gave
it him / and her mele or flower multyplyed / as it is written in the.xxii.
chapter of the third book of kings. And it it written in the.xix. chapter of
the said book how the aungel of god brought unto hy^ breed and water after that
he had much fasted and trauayled. Another history written in the.xxi. chapter
of the.iii. book of ky^ges that after that king Achab had made Naboth to be
slain he was manassed and thretened and knowleged his defaute / he cut his
vestementes / ware the hair / fasted / and slepte upon a sack / and god
atte^pred his pain and sentence. etc. Another hystory written in the third
chapter of ye prophet Jonas that when those of the cite of Nynyue herd that
their cite should be subverted and that they should be punysshed for their
sins / they fasted al great and little / and they clothed them with sackes /
and changed their cursed ways / and god had pity on them / and did not unto
them ye evil yt he would have done unto them. etc. Another hystory written in
ye fourth book of Iudyth that after yt the children of Ysraell had herd the
terryble puyssaunce of Holofernes they fasted and prayed god and they had
vyctory. Another hystory written in ye fourth chapter of Hester how before
that Hester made request unto the king for some people the which should be
slain she said unto a man Mardocheus that he should go unto the said people to
make them pray for her / and that by three days they ne should ete ne drink /
and yt she and her servants should fast / and so it was acco^plyshed and her
request unto her was granted. etc. Another hystory written in the first
chapyter of danyell how danyell and his company Ananias / azarias / and mysaell
also abstened them to ete of metes of the king and to drink of the wine / and
god gave unto the three children science in all books / and unto danyell he gave
entendement of visions and of dremes etc. Another example written in the third
chapter of the gospelles of saint Mathewe how the mete of saint Johan baptyst
was greshoppes and wild honey / and he neither drank wine ne sydre / and was
so full of great abstynences and holiness that it is written of hy^. Internatos
mulierum non surrexit mayor iohanne baptista. A question / who so demands
what fasting days the church commands to fast / and what people ben
bound to fast them. The answer. The church commands fasting unto all
those and them ye which may do it by health of their bodies / the fourtymes of
the year / yt is the ymbre days / and the vygylles of ye feestes the which
follows. That is to understand / the vygyll of crystmas / of whytsontyde
saint Johan baptyst / saint Laurence / the assumpcion of our lady / the vygyll
of saint Peter and saint poule / saint Andrew / saint Simon and saint Jude /
saint Matthew / and ye day of saint Mark / but it if come upon the sunday the
fasting and processyon shall be on the monday after. Also the custom is now to
fast all the vygylles of the feestes of our lady / and in many places the three
days of the cross. etc. Also the quarantyne of the lenten is of commandment
of the church to fast / in likewise as says these doctors. Alijs diebus
ieiunare remedium at premiu^ est / in quadragesima non ieiuna re peccatum est
alio tempore qui ieiunat accipiet indulgentia^ / i^ quadragesima qi potest et
non ieiunat sentiet pena^. A questyon / A man may demand in what aege a
person is bound to fast the lenten. Saint Thomas answers.ii.ii. q. xlvii.
Et dicit qua^diu aliquis stat in statu augmenti non tenetur ad oi^a ieiunia /
scilicet ad finem tercij septe^nij.i.xxi. years. And after the said saint
Thomas says / it is conuenable that every person under the said aege of.xxi.
years excercyse him to fast the most that he may do / as he of xiiii. years
should fast more than he of.x. years. And howbeit that a man ne may fast all /
yet he should enforce him to do every of them after his puyssaunce. We read in
the.xxiiij. chapter of Exodi how Moses fasted.xl. days when he received the
law and ye commandments of god. Also we read in the third book of kings in
the.xix chapter how the prophet Helye fasted.xl. days and.xl. nyghtes wha^
the aungel brought him meet. etc. Also we read in the.iiij. chapter of the
gospelles of saint Matthew that our blyssed savior and redemptoure Ihesu christ
fasted.xl days. Vnde mathei. iiij. Et cum ieiunasset quadraginta diebus et
quadraginta noctibus postea esurijt. etc. Also the said lenten should be fasted
/ and it is of the commandment of the church unto them yt have aege and that
may do it.

C. Many persons ben holly excused / as women with child for her fruit / and
also nouryces if they may not fast they should do after their power with the
nuryture of the child. A questyon of women yt ben strong and may well fast
it / but their husbondes defends it them. The answer is / scdm innocen. vbi
dicit. Licet dimittere debea^t mulieres vota voluntary suscepta propter
habitatione^ viroru^ / non tame^ ieiunia ab ecclesia precepta. Also the seek /
and the weyke ben excused. A questyon of pilgrims and people sore laboury^g.
The answer after saint Thomas. If ye pilgrimage or labor may be deferred or
taken away without inconuenyent fastings should not be broken. And if it be
necessyte to walk and to do the great Iourneyes or to labor much and that
they ne may do it with fasting they ben not bou^dede to fast. In such things
it should be surer to have recours to be dispensed of ye prelate. And a man
should not understand in common proverb how all the laborers ben excused to
fast it. For if any be rich and has suffycyent nourysshynge and wherewith to
keep the fasting day he ought to labor the less to the end yt he may fast and
satysfye unto the commandment of the church. But if he be poor and that
necessyte co^streyne him to labor strongly for yt he ne may have his
necessytees for his wife and children if he did not the said great labor he
synneth not mortally if he ete on the fasting day sygnauntly so that he have
his coura-and will that he would obey gladly unto ye commandment of the
church if he might have the said necessytees. Also it is to understand that
fasting is so grievous and so hard unto some persons that scantely and with
great pain they may fast one day in the weke in lenten for their labors
and trauayles that they aledge. Unto those a man should answer that they shall
have the more and greter merit in paradyse for the great labor yt they take
to fast / and that god shall reward unto every person the fastings and the
labors after ye operacyons that they do. Vnde psalm. Retribu et vnicuique scdm
opera sua. And if he will not fast do almesdedes or oraysons or good operacyons
in recompense and in showing token that he would obey gladly if he might.
Questyon of poor beggars if they ben holden to fast. The answer after
Thomas.ii.ii. q. cxlvii. where he says yt if they may have as much of alms
together as shall suffyce unto them to ete at dinner / they shall not be excused
of fasty^ge. And if they may not so much assemble for to suffyce them on that
day to feed they ben not bound to fast / or when they ben weyke for the
pouerte thereof procedynge they ben excused. Example of fasting Quere in the
examplarye.cv.C

A. The eight commandment of god defends all words the which ben against
the dyleccyon of thy neighbor. xl.
False witness look thou none bear
Ne yet lie in any wise
Dread thou also to speak or swear
Against thy neighbor by mine advise
THis commandment is wryte^ in the ancient testament. Deutero. v. ca. et
exodi. xx. Non loq^ris contra proximum tuu^ falsum testimonium. Thou shalt not
speak ne bear false witness against thy neighbor. And it written. Leuiti. xix.
ca. No^ mentiamini nec decepit vnusquisque proximum suum. Ye shall not lie and
neither of you shall deceive his neighbor. And it is written in ye new
testament. Mathei. xix. ca. et luce. xviii. Non falsu^ testimoniu^ dices. Thou
shall not say false in wytnessy^ge but that thou be punysshed as many have been
in likewise as thou may se by examples. Quere.lxxxxvii. a.b. In this
commandment god defends generally all falls and evil languages in all the
manners yt a man may bring them forth with the tongue the which ben against
ye dyleccyon of thy neighbor / in likewise as it shall be declared in
particular herafter / and us commands the virtue of veryte. For sith that he
defends in such wise al lesynges and evil languages it follows well that he
us commands that we bring forth good and verytable words. etc.

B. Of false wytnessynge that god defends. xl.
NOn falsu^ testimoniu^ dices. you not say falls in witnessy^ge. He yt makes
falls report in judgment of certain conscience for to noye unto neighbor
synneth right grievously in three manners. Primo / in as much as he forswereth
him and falseth his faith yt he takes upon ye font of baptysme and that he
renounceth god yt is full of veryte / and leueth his feaute and the oath that he
had made unto him for to draw hy^ unto the devil the fader of lyenge and the
hand that he lyfteth up in forsweringe hy^ apperteyneth unto the devil / and
when he blysseth and crosses him it is with ye deuilles hand. Scdo in as much
as he is the cause whereby ye right Justice is fyled and corrupt whereby falls
great inco^uenyent. Tercio / in as much as he is a liar / false / and
corrupter of veryte. Those the which forswereth them wytyngly in judgment ben
infamed as it is written in right. extra. q^rela^. Et. v^ q.i. Infames. Also
they ne should never be take in wytnes. extra de testi. Sicut. e. vii. q.i.
Quicunque. They deceive three persons that is the Judge / the innocent / and
themself. They deceive evil the Judge / wors the Innocent / and worst of al
themself. They deceive the Judge by that / that he believes that they say
veryte / and he makes false Judgment against right Justice the which is to
yield unto every man that thing the which is his. They deceive yet wors ye
Innocent / for by the false witnessynge sometime ye Innocent leseth his heritage
/ sometime his goods / his good renounce / or sometime is slain and put unto
death. They deceive worst of all themself / for they do dampne their souls /
and they bind them to make restytucyon of all the losses and domages in the
which the said Innocent re^neth by the said false wytnessynge. In likewise as
a thief or harlot the which takes and withdraws the goods of his neighbor
is holden to make restytucyon. In like manner a false witness the which
wtdraweth the goods of his neighbor by false wytnessynge is holden to
restytucyon as it is written in many places in the decrete. Tenetur autem falsis
testis ad restitutionem oi^m que per suum falsum testimoniu^ proximus eius
amisit. extra de elec. significati. vlter. med. and.xxviii. di. de syracusa ne.
extra de of. orde. ad reprime^dam. and.ii. q. c. presbiter. and non sane / et
non res aliena. and.ii. q. notu^. and ar. iii. q. ix. nichilominus. Sometime a
false witness or a false accusatoure is homycyde or thief. He is homycide of
his neighbor innocent when that he deyeth by his false accusynge or
witnessynge / as ye Jews the which made Jesus christ to deye And if he deye not
he takes from him and steleth his good renoune / and is holden to make
restytucyon / or else he ne may be saved nor he should not be absoyled. Qr no^
dimittitur pctm^ nisi restituatur ablatu^. xiii. q. vii ca. Sires. The sin is
not pardoned if ye thing taken away withdrawn / stolen / or alyened be not
restored. The good renoune of a person is better tha^ an hepe of gold. Vnde
proverb. Melius est nomen bonum quam diuitie multe super auru^ et arge^t u^
gratia bona. A good name is better than much richesse / good grace is above
gold and silver. If a man make restytucyon of gold nnd of silver / by more
greter reason a man should make restytucyon of ye good renoune the which is
more precious than gold or silver. Also they the which make false wytnessynge
and lesynge wytingly in Judgment in cause of crime for to noye unto their
neighbors synneth mortally and breketh this commandment. For they subvert
the truth of the Judgment ye which is unto the death of gylte of all
communyte present. Of the which thing it appears if the Judge speak false
thing wytyngly in vttrynge false sentence or wytnessy^ge it in reportynge unto
the procuroure or advocate in following and defendinge false cause they
transgress this commandment / and ben bounden toward him that suffers the
injury. Also ye false accusatoure or witness is a thief when he makes to lose
the goods or the heritage of his neybour unjustly by false wytnessynge and is
holden to restytucion as it is said. For his neighbor had not lost the thing
if he had been by reportinge falsely. Wha^ a witness is called to report of
a thing he should say for ye one and other the good and pure truth yt he
knows of it / without putting any wyle or lesynge.iii. q. xi. hortamur.

witness. Also a witness should not receive money to bear witness of any thy^g
For in likewise as the sentence ne should be sold no more should witness.

C. Of cursed language that god defends. xl.
DAuyd the prophet says in the psalter. Prohibe linguam tua^ a malo et labia
tua ne loquantur dolu^. Defend thy tongue from evil saying / and thy lyppes
that they ne speak treachery / fraud / ne fallace. It is that thing the which
is before written. Ne bear thou no false witness and lie not in no wise. Ne
mysse say thou by thy language any creature in no manner. In this eight
commandment god there defends all false reports / all lesynges / all
murmures unjustly made / and treasons brought forth for to deceive other Also
all detraccyons the which ben made in publysshynge the secret sins of his
neighbor / or showing them by encreasynge or Imposynge upon him false crimes
/ or in denyenge that he does good operacyons / or in demynysshynge his good
renown / or by chaungynge the good in to evil for to noye and harm him.
Such detractours the which takes away the good renown of their neighbor
takes from him life honorable / and therefore they ben false witnesses and
homycydes. Vnd bern^. Durior est li^gua detrahe^tis quam la^cea q^ perforauit
corpus xprei in cruce pe^de^tis. The tongue of the detractour is harder tha^ the
spear yt perced the body of christ hanging on the cross. Et legitur hiere. ix.
Sagitta vulneratis li^gua eorum dolu^ locutu^ est. The arowe making a wound
is ye tongue of them yt speaks ill. Et legitur sa. i. A detractione percite
lingue qm^ sermo obscurus in vacuu^ non ibit. Spare ye / cease ye of detraction
of the tongue / for a derke word shall not go in vain. Et legitur prouer.
xiii. Qui detrahit alicui ipree se in futuru^ obligat. He yt makes detraccyon
of any person he byndeth him in time to come / that is unto punycyon. Example
how a detractour had cruel Judgment before god for ye holy persons that he
had detracted rose against hy^ and demanded of the Judge vengeance / and he was
damned. Quere.lxxxxvii. D. Also god defends all flateryes as here after shall
be declared. Also he defends susurracyon the which is when any puts
dyuysyon between bredren / kynnesmen / and neighbors / or for to demynyssh

maledictus multos ei^ turbauit pace^ habentes. Example how a woman committed

defends all defames / iniuryes / and mokeryes. Example how a boucher was

defends all idle words and noyenges / and all bostynges / praysynges / and
shameful songs / and all evil counceyle / and to make short all words yt

reuyued said that incontinent that his soul parted from the body he was

Qui seminat iniquitatem metet mala. He ye which sows inyquyte gadereth

A. Of lyenge that god defends.
IT is written leuitici. xix. Non mentiemini nec decipiet vnusquisque proximum
suum. Ye shall not lie / ne none of you shall deceive your neighbor. The wise
Salamon required of god two things before that he deyed the which ben that
vanyte and lyenge words were far from him. Vnde proverb. xxx. Vanitate^ et
verba mendacia long fac a me. It behooves to se what lyenge is. Saint Austyn
says. Mendacium est falsa significatio vocis cu^ inte^tione fallendi. Lyenge
is a false sygnyfycacyon of voice with intencyon to deceive. In this
dystynccyon there ben two things. That is to understand a false thing and to
tell a lie. Dicere falsu^ est aliqid esse quod non est ita non distinccio vtru^
intendat dicere veru^ vel falsu^. To say a false thing is to say some thing
to be so the which is not / as when a man speaks it without regarding the
intencyon to speak true or false. Et mentiri est contra mentem iri. To lie is
to go against the thought after thethymologisement of the word. Is qui
mentitur co^tra id quod animo sentit loquitur voluntate falle^di. He the which
lies speaks against that / yt he has in his courage with intencyon to deceive.
In likewise in the dyffynycyon of lyenge is comprysed to speak a false thing /
and to tell a lesynge / and therefore there is dyffere^ce between lyenge and
saying a false thing. For every person yt lies speaks not a false thing.
Sometime he says troth albeit yt he wene to speak a false thing / and unto
the contrary every person ye speaks a false thing lies not. For he weneth
sometime to say all bet it yt he say false. So every person the which lies
deceyueth evermore by will / albeit yt he be deceived in the truth of the
deed / and therefore he the which lies sins always. For ye tongue culpable
ne makes / but ye thought culpable / as it is written.xxii. q. ii. Homines He
that speaks a false thing synneth not always mortally. Sometime he speaks a
false thing with intencyon to deceive ye which is mortal sin. And in lyenge
he speaks sometime a false thing yt he weneth to be true / and wha^ after his
saying he enquyreth dilygently of the deed / and repents hy^ when he has
apperceyued his falsenes it is but venyall sin / as it is written.xxii. q. ii.
Homines. For to have examples of liars it behooves to take them the which be^
perjured / for they ben liars and periurers toder. Example how a devil lied
unto a noble man and put him in error for to deceyueth him at his death.lx. B.
Another example how two merchants told unto their curate yt they ne could
sell any thing without lyenge. Quere. lxxxxix.

B. For to know the manners of lyenge a man should understand ye saint Austyn
assygneth.viii. kinds. The first kind of lyeng is when a man makes a lie
against the faith / or against ye doctrine of holy relygyon / as who should say
yt Ihesus is not borne of ye vyrgyn Mary / or yt he has not suffered death and
passion for to redeem us etc. To speak such words by reason disposed it is
mortal sin and case reserved / and it is the chief of all lyenges. The
second kind of lyenge yt is after the gretest sin / is when a man makes a
lie for to hurt or hy^der any person unjustly so yt such lyenge ne
prouffyteth unto no creature / but noyeth unto some / as too say evil of his
neighbor by detraccyon in forgynge false lesynges for to take from him his
goods / and his good renoune as it should be too accuse him or witness
against him unjustly of theft or of any crime. Those the which in such wise
lies synneth mortally and right gretely / and may be deputed homycydes / or
thieves after ye lie or lesynge as it is said before. The third kind after
most gretest sin / is when a man makes a lie for to aid unto some and to
noye unto another in cause of money / goods or herytages as to wytnes unjustly
with any for to make another too lose his money / such lesynge is mortal
sin. The fourth kind is when a man makes a lie by delyberaci for to deceive
any person in lechery or auaryce / it is also mortal sin. The fyfth is made
by couetyse for to please unto any person by flatery / and this flatery is
made in three manners. The first is granting unto any person some goodness that
he has not / as to say thou art wise / thou art fair thou art mighty / and
that he were not so The second is in approuynge the evil yt some cursed
person has done / as if he has beten / or pylled his neighbor. etc. to say
yt he has well done and to praise him of the said evil / these two flateryes
here ben.ii. mortal sins / but the last is wors and more great sin than the
first.xxii. q. ii. Primu^. xlvi. di. sunt no^ nulli. And ye prophet ysaie
saythin. v. ca. Ve qui dicitis malu^ bonum et bonum malu^ / ponentes tenebras
in luce^ et lucem in tenebras / ponentes amaru^ in dulce et dulce in amarum.
Maledyccion or woe be unto you the which say the ill to be good and the good to
be ill / putting derkenes to be light and light to be derkenes / putting sour
to be sweet and sweet to be sour / such flaterers ben called falls witnesses.
The third flatery is to praise any person to hyghly of any good deed for to
please hy^ / this last flatery is venyall sin The syxte kind of lyenge is
when the lesynge or lie noyeth not unto any and profyteth unto some for to
avoid the loss of his money / as if a pyller would take away thy money or
that of thy neighbors and he demands the where it is / and yt thou say I
know not. The seventh kind of lyenge is when the lie noyeth unto none and
prouffyteth unto some for to avoid yt he ne be slain / as if a murderer would
s^e unjustly a person hid in thy house / and demands the where he should
be / and ye answerest I wot not where he is. The eight kind of lyenge is when
the lie hyndreth not unto any and prouffyteth unto some for to keep him from
velany corporal as if an harlot demanded a vyrgyn for to corrupt her lies
unto her and says that he would mary her. etc. The five first kinds of lyenge
the which noyeth unto his neighbor ben mortal sins as it is said and as it
is written.xxii. q. ii. Primu^ ne quis. The three last the which noyeth not but
aydeth unto some ben venyall sins after all the doctors in person imparfayte
/ but unto persons parfayt as cloysterers / relygyous there are diverse
opynyons / for ye one says that it should be venyall sin and the other
mortal / howbeit that there is no venyall sin but yt it may torn in to
mortal when it pleases / and yt a man it does of custom in likewise as it
is written before in ye second commandment. There is doubt made what he
should answer the which has a person hid in his house whom a man secheth
to slay / if he show him he should dread of the crime of homycyde leest by him
he were slain in showing him. Also he should dread the sin of them the
which pursues for the slay him. Also he should dread if he the which a man
would sle were in mortal sin that if he deyed impenytent and that he were
dampened. Unto that saint Austin says yt how be it that he that lies does
good unto an other / nevertheless he does his own propre damage / and in no
manner he ne should lie for to redeem the life of another in especyall the
person perfayte. For it is said yt none ne shall be brought unto health
sempyternall by lye^ge / but he should hold his pease to the end that in such
wise he ne lose ne lie / ne sle his soul for to save the body of an other.
Vnde augustinus dicit / quod nullo modo debeat quis mentiri et maxim pro vita
alterius redimenda ait enim et sempiter nam salutem nullus est ducendus
opitula^ te mendatio. Idem augustinus. Ne quis arbitretur perfectu^ et
specialem pro ista te^porali vita morte cuius sua vel alterius no^ occidatur
anima debere mentiri / sed taceat vt sic neque perdat / neque mentiatur / neque
ocadat animam suam pro corpore alterius. xxii. q. ii. Primu^ ne quis. Item
Ysidorus diat. Omne genus mendatu summopere fuge nec casu / nec studio loquaris
falsum / nec qualibet fallacia vitam alterius deffendas xxii. q. ii. Omne. Fle
by sovereign work al kinds of lyenge and speak not false / ne by case / ne by
study / and defend not the life of another by any fallace. Ite^ au.
Periculosissime admittitur hec co^pensatio vt nos faciamus aliquod malu^ ne
alius grauius malu^ fauat disti. xxiiij. q. ait and ita dicu^t siplicitur
plurimi doctores. This compensacyon is taken right perillously yt we make any
ill ye other ne do more grievous evil. Some other doctors says yt in such
case men should lie but Raymond says yt sauy^ge better Judgment than his yt he
believes yt they should say nothing as says saint Austyn / or to transfer
his word in him questyonynge of other matters or to answer some word
equyuocall sygnyfyenge two things. We read ye Abraham descended ones in Egypt
with his wife and fered yt Pharaon ne slew him for her / and for this he said
to his wife / say yt thou art my sister and not my wife / and he said true /
but it was equyuokely for his wife was his sister for she was daughter of his
brother / thus men ought to answer equyuokely without lyenge. Also another
dysty^ccyon is made magystrally of lyenge of the words of saint Austin playner
and shorter the which ben devised in three manners. The first lyenge is aydynge
seruyable and pyteous the which co^pryseth the.iii. last kinds of the
dystynccyon beforsayd. The second is pleasant and joyous yt is the lyenge of
flaterers. The third is noyenge and full of cursednes the which compryseth
the kinds of the dystynccyon beforesayd. And in all these three manners there is
sin For every lie is either mortal sin or venyall. Vn^ au. Oe^ me^datiu^
est pctm^. xii. q. ii. Micht no^ absurd. I say than yt ye lesynges aydynges
ben sins / the pleasant lies be^ greter sins the which ben of bourdes /
flateryes / and scoffs / to speak and to flater there is syn^e without doubt /
and ye noyenge lies ben right great mortal sins when a man them speaks
wytyngly / and unto thynky^ge for to damage another. Unto this last lesy^ge all
these falsenesses / trecheryes / and fallaces yt a man does through ye world
for to deceive another in to damage either in soul or in body / or in goods
or in renoune / or in any thing what so ever it be / for every time yt a man
lies for to noye another as it is said unto his wytynge it is mortal syn^e
xxii. q. ii. Primu^ ne quis. Of this lyenge speaks the psalm. Perdes om^s qui
loquu^tur me^ daciu^. Et sa. i. Os quod me^titur occidit ai^am The mouth yt
lies sleeth the soul of death of gylte. Al ye falseth a man as a man falseth
the seal of a king or the popes bull / and for as much yt such a man bears
false lettres he shall be Iuged as felon or as falsary at the day of Judgment.
Vn^ au. No^ artificioso me^datio nec si^plici vbo oportet quam quam decipere qr
licet me^titur quis occidit ai^am sua^. It behooves not to deceive any person
by lyenge artyfycyall ne by sy^ple word. For how be it that any lie he sleeth
his soul as it is said. Also the liar is as a false coyner yt makes money
falls and naught. Also he is among the true people as ye falls penny among the
good. One good penny is better tha^.x tals / also does a true man than.x. liars
and falls. With great pain will a man take a falls penny wyty^gly / but will say
it is noumt it is false and coper. And he cares not of him self if he be a
liar or falls / whereby it appears yt he prayseth more a falls penny tha^ hy^
self which is great folly. Also lyenge is as veny^ mortal / for fro ye time yt
it is in ye mouth it enuenymeth and enfecteth all the person Vn^ psalm.
Accueru^t li^guas suas sicut serpe^tes venenu^ aspidu^ sub labiis eorum. They

enuenymed of the serpent of hell that told unto Eve the contrary of yt god

fader by imytacyon. Vn^ john.viii. Vos ex patre dyabolo estis et desideria ptis
vti vultis face ille homicida erat ab u^tio et i^ vitate no^ stetit qr no^ est

/ for he is a liar and also his fader. The devil is fader of liars / for the

C. How a man should fle lies and love truth xli.
IT is written ad eph^. iiii. Depone^tes me^daciu^ loquimini vitate^ vnusquisque
cu^ proximo suo. Take away lyenge / speak truly every man with his neighbor.
And saint Peter says in the second cha. of his first epistle. Put away all
malice / all treachery / symulacyons / enuyes / and all detraccyons as
reasonable children newly engendered. etc And it is written ad col. iii. Nolite
me^tiu i^uice^. Lie ye not togyders but speak ye true We should love veryte and
fle lyenge for many things. First in folowy^ge our fader celestyall. It is
written prouer. vi. how god hates.vii. things whereof lyenge is one / yt is to
understand / the eyes lift up in pride / the lyenge tongue / ye hands
shedynge blood yt noyeth not the heart ymagenynge ill thoughts / the fete ready
to run in to ylle the brynger forth of lies / the false witness and he ye
sows dyscorde between his bredre^. Also god loves veryte as says Dauyd.
Vn^ psalm. Ecce eni^ veritate^ delixisti. Alsoo god is veryce yt deceyueth not
ne lies. Vn^ john. xiiij. Ego su^ via vitas et vita. And by yt we should hate
to lie and love veryte in following our lord. Vn^ ma. viii. Veritate^ and
pace^ diligite. Love ye troth and peace: a good child should love the good
manners of his fader / than if we ben the children of god we ben also verytables
and not liars. It is written zacha. viii. Loqinum vitate^ vnusquisque cu^
proximo suo seqitur iurame^tu^ me^dar ne deligatis. Secondly we should fle
lye^ge and love veryte / for lyenge dyffameth the persons if their lesynges
ben dyscouered Vn^ eccle. xx. Opprobriu^ nequam in hoi^e me^daciu^ et i^ ore in
disciplinatorum assidue erit. Lyenge is an evil rebuke to a man / and it shall
be accustomed in the mouche of them not dysciplyned / and verite makes to have
good renoune before god and the world. Vn^. iiii. ^hi. Verax est lauda^dus /
me^dax vero vitupera^dus. That is to say. The veritable is to praise / and the
liar is to be shamed or hated When a person is verytable yt for one ne other /
for cousyn / kinnesman / ne friend ne swerueth on the one side ne on ye other /
but says ye pure veryte he is to praise and to love and holy thing habyteth
in hy^. Vn^. i. ethi. Ambobus exista^tibus amicis sctm^ est prehonorare
veritate^. Saint James says in his canons. Si quis in vbo no^ offe^dit his
perfectus est. Who so offends not in word he is perfyte. Et legitur eccle.
xxxvii. An^ oi^a opera verbu^ verax precedat / an^oe^m actu^ co^siliu^ stabile.
Thyrdly we should fle lyenge and love veryte / for lyenge puts man fro

sap. vi. Co^cupisce^tia id est amor sapie^tie and vitas ducit hoi^em ad regnu^
perpetuu^. Fourthly we should fle lyenge and love verite / for lyenge makes to
have perdycyon and da^pnacyon. Vn^ psalm. Perdes oe^s qui loquu^tur me^daciu^.
Thou shall lose all those the which speaks lesynges if they deye Impenytentes
/ and veryte delyuereth from evil and dampnacyon. Vn^ io. viii. Si ma^seritis
in sermon meo vere discipuli mei eritis et cognoscetis veritate^ et veritas
liberabit vos. If ye be abiding in my word ye shall verily be my dyscyples
and ye shall know veryte / and veryte shall deliver you / in likewise shall
