A. The.ix. commandment of god defends all lecherous thoughts and
commands clennesse of he^te.. xlii.
Man beware that thou ne desire
Thy neighbors wife / dought ne maid
In avoiding eternal fire
God to offend be thou afraid
THis commandment is wryte^ in the ancient testament. Deutero. v. ca. No^
co^cupisces vxorem proxum cui. That is to say. thou shall not coueyte thy
neighbors wife for to do sin. In this commandment god defe^deth all evil
thoughts disordonate of the sin of lechery and commands chastyte of
thought. For as nothing serves the chastyte of the body where the thought is
corrupt. Vn^ au. Nichil prodest vginitas corporis vbi operatur corruption
mentis. God defends in the seventh commandment the operacion of lechery and
in yt he defends the will the which comes of the thought. These two
lecheryes here ben to fle. Dauyd it required of god Vnd psalm. Ure renes meos
and cor meum. Brenne my raynes and my heart that they ne committee lechery. For
to have the heart blyssed / pure / and clean after the gospel. math v. Beati
mu^do cord qm^ iprei deu^ videbu^t. It behooves to shytte well the gates of ye
wits or nature that ye lecherous enemy mortal enter not / and that he soil
not ye said heart by evil thoughts. Master Hugues de saint victor says yt
lechery comes in to ye heart in.vi. manners. Sometime by sight / sometime by
herynge / or by touching / or by thought / or by word / or by operacyon / by
such things lechery is chauffed and nourysshed / ye soul is departed fro god
/ and chaftyte is fled from the manners / and lechery is excercysed in his
wits. And a man should note that incontinent yt the dylectacyon of lechery
comes unto the heart by sight or hery^ge / or by kissing. etc. suddenly than
resyst by pynchynge thy flesh / or byte thy tongue / pull thyn eere / think
on the tourmentes of hell. etc. And by such resystynges a man shall keep his
heart from soylynge and geteth a crown. In likewise as you shall find by the
examplary of ye.ix. commandment. Quere. C.ii. A.

B. The concupyscences of ye flesh how lechery is commyt in thought. xlii.
NOn concupisces vxore^ proximi tui. Thou shall not coueyt thy neighbors wife.
A man should understand ye concupysce^ce carnal is lechery without operacyon /
and it is said in.iii. manners. The first is without sin. The second is with
sin venyall. The third is with mortal sin. The first moeuynges of
concupyscence carnal the which ben sodaynes wtin the bo^des of nature and of
the sensualyte the which depends not upon the will ben not sin / for they
ben in ye puyssaunce of nature humayne. But more sooner is matter to purchase
virtues unto whom therein well resysteth by the mean and grace dyuyne / as unto
the foul thought without dylectacyon / and that it come against his will / yt
is no sin if reason thereto consent not. Vn^ greg. super ezech^.
Qua^tu^cu^que i^mu^da sit cogitatio me^te^ no^ polluit si ratio no^ co^sentit.
Et au. dicit quam pctm^ est actio volu^taria / nullu^ eni^ pctm^ nisi
volu^tariu^. It behooves sometime to be hold these women to speak to them / to
touch and to think on them / but after as the thought is ordynate or
dysordynate / there is sin or there is none. As it is of necessyte to ete and
drink / but after the ordonau^ce or dysordonaunce it may be well done or ill
done. Un de aug. in libro de nuptiis et concupisce^tus dicit. Co^cupisce^tia
no^ est pctm^ qn^ ad illicita opera no^ co^sentitur. Concupyscence is no sin
when the will ne consents unto the operacyons unlawful. Than those the which
lives chastely should not trouble the^ when there comes ill thoughts unto
them / for the devil tempts more the good than the badde. Bernar. dicit. No^
ei^ contristari debemus si in te^ptationibus inciderimus / sed si i^
te^ptationibus superatifuerimus. We should not be wroth if we be^ fallen in to
temptacyons / but if we therein have been overcome. When temptacyo^s comes a man
should stro^gely resyst and fight against them for to have reward and merit.
Vn^ bernar. Quotie^s resistis totie^s coronaberis / na^ quotiens resistimus
totiens ^yabolu^ superamus angelos letificamus deu^ honoramus. By as ofte^tymes
as you resystest as many times shall thou be crouned / and as oftentimes as we
resyst so many times we surmount the devil / we rejoice yt angels and we
honor god. The second concupysce^ce of the flesh is when the moeuynges
comes of the dylectacyon unto thing unlawful without propre will ne reason
dysposed to accomplysshe the operacyon / he is venyall sin. Also when an
evil thought comes unto any man with the dylectacyon all times without plain
consentement of reason than is it venyall sin. The devil begins to show
the temptacyon / and if a man consent not thereto but resysteth incontyne^t it
is no sin. And if dylectacyon come after the temptacyon it is venyal sin.
And understand well yt if the consentement of reason be not there / for if it
were there it were of the kind of mortal sin. The third concupyscence of
ye flesh is when yt delectacyon of evil is abyden and that reason and the
propre will ben dysposed it to accomplysshe here is mortal sin / albeit yt
afterward a man ne may come to do the operacyon / for the will is reputed for
the deed. In likewise is it of all other sins mortalles when the will is
dysposed the sin is as who says done. And a man should here understand yt
it behooves yt all men and women the which should enter in to ye realm of
paradyse have in their purpose yt if they lived eternally they ne would sin
mortally in any manner what so ever it be. Than of necessyte of health it
behooves that all those and they yt will have salvation should have in their
thought yt they ne will committee lechery in any manner but in good and lawful
marriage. If thou wylt not believe of simple word study the scryptures that
tells it in many places. Vn^ au. dicit quod voluntas reputatur pro facto. The
will is reputed for the deed. Iterum dicit. Co^se^sus i^ opus pcti^ mortalis
est pctm^ mortale and co^sensus in opus pcti^ venialis est pctm^ veniale.
Consentement in operacyon of sin mortal is mortal sin / and consentement in
work of sin venyall is venyall sin. Et greg. dicit. Qui co^sentit pcto^et
no^ arguit dignus est morte. He yt consents to sin and stryueth not to
resist unto the contrary is worthy to deye. And it is written in the gospel yt
our savior Ihesus said unto ye auncyentes. Do ye none aduoutry / and I say
unto you yt every man yt has seen a woman in desyry^ge to know her he has
committed sin in her in his heart. Vn^ math. v. Dictu^ antiqis Non mechaberis
/ ego au^t dico vobis qr oi^s qui viderit muliere^ ad concupisce^du^ ea^ me
chatus est in cord suo. God shows here yt the will is reputed for the deed /
unto ye dyfference of them the which weneth not to sin if they accomplysshe
the operacyon. It is written.i. regu^. xvi. No^ ei^ videt ea q^ pate^t / dn^s
au^t i^tuetur cor. The man sees those thing the which appears / and our
lord beholds ye heart and the will. Et pau. ad to. i Non solum qui faciu^t
peccata sed qi conse^tiunt facie^tibus digni su^t morte. After that saint Poule
had named many sins he said / not alonly they the which do the sin /
but also they the which consents to do them ben worthy of death. Example how
a woman was dampened for the conse^tynge of will to commytte lechery. Quere c.a.
Another example of a monk ye which lost the breed celestyal for having evil
lecherous thoughts. Quere. C.i. A.

C. For to understand clearly the dyfference of mortal syn^e and venyall it
behooves to take the words of saint Austin the which ben written in his book
of ye cite of god the which says. When a man loves a person is behooves yt
the said love be good or evil. It is good when it is for the love of god / and
therein is virtue And also such love is necessary as when the sone loves the
fader. etc. it is natural / the which is not louable ne vytuperable. Also
such love is voluptuous and lybydynous / it behooves to make dystynccyon / for
if the dylectacyon and will be above the love of god / or egally unto him / as
to say. I love better such operacyon of lechery than to obey unto god the
which it defends / or of as much as he endeuereth him to do it / albeit he
do it not here is mortal sin in two manners. And if the love be under god /
that is to say that a man loves better to obey unto god than to do it / it is
venyall sin. Vnde augustinus. Peccatum veniale est libido sieve amor voluptas
citra deum / mortale vero est libido sieve amor voluptatis. supra deum vel
equaliter ei. Mortal sin is lechery or love of volupte above almighty god or
egally unto him.

D. The euylles and domnges that the evil thoughts do. xlii.
EVyl thoughts ben to fle for many things. First for yt they separate the
persons from god. Vn^ sapi. i. Perverse ei^ cogitato^nes sepera^t a deo.
Secondly for that they make to have maledyccyo^. Vn^michee ii. Ve qi cogitatis
i^utile and operamini malu^m cubilibus vr^is. Maledyccion unto you ye which

egredie^ti duabus viis. Maledyccyo^ unto men of double heart / and unto ye

sinner entering in to ye earth by two ways Thyrdly ill thoughts ben to fle for
yt they chase away ye virtues and goods spyrytualles of ye soul and lets
all good espyrytuall yt it ne may profit. As a man may say by symylytude yt
sekenes corporal chaseth away the health and the welthe of the body / and to

likewise as it is declared afterward. Que ad numerum.xliiii. b. c. d. e. f. g.
etc. Fourthely evil thoughts ben to fle for yt they sle spyrytually the souls

is the life of the soul as it is declared in ye commandment of homycyde.
quere. xxiiii. b. Fyfthly evil thoughts ben to fle for yt they blind the
eyes wtinforth of ye soul and of the entendement and makes ye soul derke and
puts it in derkenes / as it is declared afterward. Quere. xliiii. Syxtly ill
thoughts ben to fle for yt they ben publysshed and showed at ye day of
Judgment before all the world / as it is written. Math^. x. et lu. xii. Nichil
au^t opertu^ e^ quoth no^ reueletur neque absco^ditu^ quoth no^ sciatur and i^ pala^
veniat. There is nothing so strongly covered but yt it shall be showed / ne hyd
but yt it be known and seen openly before all. Also it behooves to yield
account at the day of Judgment before god of all evil thoughts. Vn^ sapi. i.
In cogitationibus i^pu i^cogitatio erit. Interrogacyon or questyon shall be
made of the thoughts of the sinner. Et sapre. iii. Impuau^t scdm q^
cogitaueru^t correctione^ habebu^t qi neglexer a^t iustu^ and a dn^o
recesseru^t. The ill shall have correccyon after the things yt they have
thought. Example yt it behooves to yield account at the Judgment of ill
thoughts. Quere. cviii. D. Seventhly ill thoughts be^ to fle for dread to

unto those yt have pure hertes / and clear fro syn^e. Vn^ mat. v. Bti mu^do
cord qm^ iprei deu^ videbu^t. of this matter. Que. xliiii. and.xlvii. a.
Eyghtly ill thoughts byndeth unto punycyon and da^pnacyon eternal wtin the
fire of hell the which is a tourment much cruel in likewise as it is
declared hereafter. que. xlvii. b. Vn^ eccle. iii. Cor grauabitur in doloribus.
The evil heart shall be grieved in dolours. By these things beforesayd it
appears ye a man breketh the commandment of god by thought lecherous /
against the which a man should resyst for to go in to paradyse. Unto ye which
almighty god us conduyte the which is reygnynge and benedictus in secula
seculorum. Amen.

A. The tenthe commandment of god the which defends all evil thoughts of
theft / coueytyse / and auaryce the which ben against the dyleccyon of his
neighbor. xliii.
Coueyte thou not in any thing
Thy neighbors good ne heritage
Let not thy heart in it have liking
Lest thou be dampened for such outrage.
THis commandment is written in the old testament. Deuteronomy. v. ca. Et ^ro. xx.
No^ co^cupistes re^ proximi tui / no^ domu^ nec agru^ / nec seruu^ / nec
a^cilla^ / nec vniuersa q^ illis su^t. That is to say. Thou shall not coueyt
thy neighbors thy^g / his house his field / ne the servant / ne the maiden /
ne any thing yt unto him belongs. In this commandment god defends al
couetyse wtin forth / yt is to wit ye will dysposed to have the goods of
another unjustly against the will of him to whom they belong. Also god will
yt every man content him with the good yt he has / or yt to him shall come after
right / reason / and Justice / but a man should understand yt the first
mouinges coueytynge the goods of another yt be^ wtin the bonds of ye
sensualite / yt preue^teth all holly before the delyberacyon of reason they ne
ben dampnables / but al will dysposed and consenteme^t of reason being in will
to have them unjustly it is mortal sin and fraccyon of this commandment.
No^ co^cupisces re^ proximi tui. Some coueyteth ye thing of another in.iii.
manners. The first some there ben ye it coueyteth / but for yt / yt they know
well yt they can not have it they ne pursue it. And if they wist well yt they
should have it they should put it in effect / such synneth mortally. Secondly
some other coueyte the thing and enforce them in effect to have it / albeit yt
they ne may have it yet synnen they mortally and more grievously than ye first.
Thyrdly some other there ben to whom it suffyseth not to coueyte the thing /
but by falls enforcy^ge done so much yt they possede it / and such synneth
more grievously tha^ these beforesayd. They ben as those thieves and rauysshers
after yt they have coueyted comen to effe^^ to take it. It is written of these
manners here beforsayd.i. ad thym^.vi. Qui voluit diuites fieri i^cidu^t in
te^ptatione^ et laqueu^ dyaboli and desideria mlta i^utila and nociua q^
mergu^t hoi^es in i^teritu^ and perditione^. Saint Poule says yt they ye
which will be rich falls in to temptacyo^s and in to the deuyls gynnes in
many desires vnprouffytables and noyenges which plongeth these men in death
and perdycyon. Another exposycyon upon these said words. No^ co^cupisces re^
proximi tui. Thou shalt not coueyte ye thing of thy neighbor for to possede
it unjustly. It is against right / Justice / and reason / and for to ordeyne it
or too use it unto an ill end / as those yt appetyteth good for to lead great
pompes and estate in vaynglory / or for to use lechery / or to have dylycatyfe
metes / as ye cursed Dyues yt was daily served delycyously and rychely / or as
ye clerks yt appetyteth ye benefyces and dygnytees / not for to dystrybute ye
goods to ye poor as they should. Qr bona eccliarum su^t bona pauperum. But
for to live fatly and po^pously in superfluytees and sins. etc. vlsic. Thou
shall not coueyte to have ye thing of thy neighbor unjustly for to wtholde it
as these auarycyous yt keep and assemble without gyuynge and dystrybutinge.
Morouer a man should understand right clearly yt as many times as any is
disposed in his thought to go against any of the commandments of god he
synneth mortally and is a breker of this commandment against the which he
will go / albeit yt he ne come to do ye operacyon. Verbi gr^a. If you in thy
heart hate thy neighbor in desyringe his death or his damage you brekest yt.v.
commandment. Vn^. i. john. iii. Qui odit fr^rum suu^ homicida est. Also if you
be wroth in thy heart against thy neybour in desyringe to venge ye unjustly by
delyberacyon you brekest ye.v. commandment and synnest mortally. Vn^ math. v.
Oi^s qi irascetur fr^i suo scilicet i^ cord reus erit iudico^. This matter is
suffyciently declared in ye precedent commandment and in the things
beforesayd where it speaks yt the will is reputed for the deed. Here is the
end of the ten commandments of god ye a man should keep for to come unto the
glory celestyall / unto the which we may go cum illo qui est benedictus in
scla sclorum. Amen.

B. How those the which have broken ye commandments of god and the which
ben in mortal sin ne should not with draw to do always good deeds /
howbeit that they should be dampened. xliii.
Saint poule says in his epistle ad heb. iiij. ca. Oi^a nuda et apperta sunt
ante oculos dei. All things the which ben naked and hid ben before the eyes
of god. He sees and knows our thoughts and operacyons / and shall yield unto
every man that / yt he has deserved. Vnde psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta
opera sua. Et alibi scribitur. Nullum malu^ remanebit i^punitum et nullum bonu^
irremuneratu^. That is to say. that none evil shall abide unpunished / and no
good deed but that it shall be rewarded / be it in this world or in the other
And therefore ye person yt is in deedly syn^e should not withdraw to do well.
Vn^ versus Non amittuntur / q^ pro dn^o tribuuntur. Om^ia que fiunt / in
mortali bona pro sunt. Nam mu^di bona da^t demonijs arma refrena^t. Me^tes
u^lustrant / etia^ torme^ta minora^t. Ad maiora bona / da^t vsu^ facienda Non
tame^ eternal / possunt acquirere vita^ Vel sic. Versus. Co^dita peccato
mortal dant bona terre. Augme^tant vitam minuunt tormenta gehe^ne. These
metres or verses beforesayd has been made and taken upon the scripture the
which says yt they the which do good deeds in mortal sin be^ rewarded
in.v. manners / albeit yt if they deye impenytentes they shall not be saved. The
first reumneracyo^ yt they shall have ye which done good deeds yt god shall
send them the sooner erthly goods in this world / and greter haboundaunce
than if they ne did good deeds. The second remuneracion is yt by doing of
deeds they refrain / wtdrawen / and tarry the assautes of the devil that is to
say yt the devil has not so great puyssaunce and force upon them the which
does or says good as if they ne so did ne said / and also is wtdrawen.
Example how an holy man saw by the suffraunce of god at a great dinner how the
deuylles drew a back when those the which dyned spoke of god and good words
/ and the aungelles drew them nere. And when they spoke of detraccyon and of
evil ye deuyls came again. etc. Quere in thexamplary.lxxxxix. H. The third
remuneracyon is that the good deeds yt they do shyneth unto them / and
enlumyneth their entendementes to reknowlege their defautes / and to se the
good yt they lose / and the evil that they get. Also their entendementes ben
not enlumyned when they do no good deeds as when they do. The fourth
remuneraco^n is yt if these persons the which do good deeds in mortal sin
were dampened in hell they ne should be so grievously punysshed and tourmented
as if they ne had done no good deed / for the good deeds does quench the
sins as the water the fire. Vnde ecclesi. iii. Ignem ardentem extinguit aqua
and elemosma resistit peccatis. Example of a man deed the which fell in going
over a bryd^ for whom there was great strife for his al mesdedes and evil
deeds the which he had committed in likewise as it is written in the examplary.
C.x.C. A man should note here ye more that a person does of evil in this
world the more cruelly shall he be tormented in hell. Quere in
thexa^plary.xlix. c. And the more that he has done of good deeds and the less
of evil he shall endure and feel the less doloure if it were so that he were
dampened / and therefore a man should never draw back to do evermore good
deeds. The fyfth remuneracion that those have the which done good deeds in
mortal sin is that god them sends the more sooner grace to correct them
and amend them and to come unto salvation than if they ne did any good deeds
/ in likewise as a man shall find by many examples. First example by Cornelyus
the which was paynym / and for that yt he gave almesses he saw an angel the
which said unto him that he should go unto saint Peter the which should tell
him what he should do. Vnde actuu^. v. ca. Corneli mitte et excersi symonem qui
cognoi^atur petrus / hic dicet tibi quid te oporteat facere. And he did so
and was converted unto the faith of our lord Ihesu christ. Another example is
written in the legende of saint Syluester how the cause of the health and
salvation of ye emperor Constantyne was for yt he had pity on the children
that men would have slain to thentent that he were bathed in their blood for
to have remedi against his lepreheed. The said emperor would not that the said
children were slain for him and made to deliver them again unto their moders
the which wept / and morouer made to give unto them gifts. And the night
following he saw saint Peter the which said unto him that he should call ye
pope Syluester and that by him he should be converted / baptized and heled of
his lepry and meselry. And in likewise was it done as it appears in the said
legende. Another example. It is written in the legende of saint Eustace how the
cause of his conuercyon was for the almesdedes that he did. The begynny^ge of
the life of saint Eustace was that he was an ydolatre and sinner / but he was a
great gyuer of alms and full of pity and of mercy / and for the good deeds
that he did god would not that he were dampened / but gave hy^ grace to convert
him / to correct and to amend / and appeared unto him the which should be to
long to tell / and for an end and conclusyon he is holy and saved. etc.

C. Another example. It is written in ye legende of saint Johan thalmosyner of
ye conuersyon of the rich man chaunger and exposytour named Peter / the which
in ye beginning of his life was right cruel unto poor people and chased them
out of his house with great ire and Indygnacyon. And on a time the poor men
complained them togyders yt never in their life they might not have so much as
one only almesdede of him. The one of them said. What will ye give and I this
day may get any alms of him. Than they made covenant with him / and he
yode unto the house for to demand alms. And when the said rich man came
and saw the said poor man before his gate he could find no stones to cast at
him / so as one of his servants passed by the which bare barley loves to his
house he took one of those loves and smote ye said poor man by great wodenes.
Than ye poor man took up the lofe and so ran unto his neighbors unto whom
he showed ye alms that he had gotten of his hand. And two days after ye
said rich man was seek to ye death and saw in vysyon yt he was in Judgment
and black men put his ylles in balaunce / and on the other part of ye said
balaunce some other clad in white / and the one of them said. We have but one
barley lofe yt he gave unto god by constraynt two days passed. And when they
had put ye said bread within the said balaunce it seemed unto him that the
balaunces were egalles / tha^ they said unto the said rich man. Multyplye this
barley lofe or these black men shall take the and than he awoke and said. Alas
if one barlylofe that I kest by wodenes has so much auayled me / how much
avails the almesdedes the which ben given lyberally. etc. For to make short
ye said rich man converted him and was a right great gyuer of almesses after
and a very good man. Another example of another rich man the which served
the devil about.xl. years / and for going to here a predycacion he converted
him and was saved As it is written in the examplary. Quere. lvi. K. Another
example by that yt a man dyspayred had served saint Domynycke / he appeared unto
him / conforted him / and put him in the way of salvation / as it is written in
the Legende of the said saint. Another example of a man that was se^tencyed and
Iuged unto dampnacyon / and was delivered at the request of the vyrgin Marye /
as it is written in her miracles. Another example of a fair maiden po^peously
arrayed and cladde upon a sunday after that she was weary of daunsynge the
devil would have taken and borne her away in body and in soul / and she began
to cry for help of the vyrgyn Mary / for her mother had learned her to serve
her / and she was delivered from ye devil / as it is wry in thexamplary.
Quere. lxviii. c. d. A questyon. What deference is there between ye good deeds
the which ben done in deedly sin / and those the which ben done in ye
estate of grace. The answer. There is great deference / for the one is right
lively and merytoryous for to have the reward eternal in paradyse. It is that
the which is done in thestate of grace without sin. The other the which is
done in mortal sin is a good deed / deed and without reward eternal / for
it is done without grace and charity. Also sin is a venym so mortal unto the
soul that it mortyfyeth all goodness spyrytuall / and departs god his love
and his grace / whereby the sinner loses his reward eternal. But the good
deeds that he does in mortal sin serves hy^ / for there ben the.v.
retrybucions beforesayd. For to understand well this matter the persons the
which shall be saved at the day of Judgment shall have merit and reward
eternal that they have done in the world in thestate of grace. And if they
had committed any mortal sins and after do penance all those good deeds yt
they have done in thestate of grace in precedinge ye said sins come again
unto them in their good valor by the penance. And of those good deeds the
which ben comen again in conualescence ben saved and they shall have reward
eternalle in paradyse. And not of those the which they have done in mortal
sin / for that / yt when they were done they were deed by sin as it is said
/ and by that the merit eternal is lost. Vnde sctu^s thomas. Nullus po^t
mereri nisi mediante gratia vt dictu^ est. quere.xlv. b. Vn^ versus. Illa
remiscu^t que mortificata fuerunt. Viuere no^ possunt q^ mortua nata su^t That
is to say that those good deeds reuyueth in god co^ualescence by penance / the
which have been mortyfyed by sin. But those good deeds the which were done
in sin may not live / yt is reuerte in conualescence after penance to have
reward eternal. It follows than that the good deed yt is done in the estate
of grace is better than the other deed. And therefore those the which
dyfferreth to confess them in lente^ or in other times ben to be reprehended
to do a good deed in sin. Also a man should understand that no good deed is
lost / but the one good deed is much better than another. etc.

A The thing mouynge for to keep the commandments of god. Ca. xliiii.
Those that learn ne will.
The commandments and law to keep
And in every point them fulfill
In hell shall lie right deep
IN that aege that an enfant is capable of the commandments of god he is
holden to learn them / for that that he should keep him that he break them not
upon the pain of dampnacyon. Vn^ legitur in secundo libro sententiaru^.
disti^. xvii. Stati^ eni^ cu^ quis fit capax precepti dei tenetur ad eius
noticia^ et obseruantiam. Et david dicit in psalm. Tu mandasti ma^data tua
custodiri nimis. Thou haste command much to keep thy commandments. When
yt any temporell king makes to bane proclayme / or show any commandment
thorowoute his realm his subgectes move them to obey unto hy^ of dread to
run in pains and do^mages that they may have for their inobedye^ce. Also
many things should move us to keep the commandments that the king of heaven
and of earth has made to proclayme / and to cry over all the world. The
first thing the which should move us to keep the commandments of god is
for the great goodness in fynyte that is in him / that is to say that there is
so much of goodness in god that it is innumerable. For a man ne can find the
end so much there is of goodness in him. Of this matere is somewhat spoken in
the end of this treatise / and how the saints of heaven behold above them
the fair myrrour ye which is god. quere. xlvii. a. Example.xlvii. b. c The
second thing esmouynge to keep the commandments of god is for to obey to
his will / he is our fader celestyall the which has create our souls as it
is said before. Also it is he yt which nouryssheth us with his gods that he
makes to grow / and it is he the which has again us bought us by his
precious blood / and ye which will that we possede his heritage in paradyse as
his dear children. It is good reason yt the children obey unto the fader / and
by that yt we ben the children of god we should obey unto his commandments.
The third thing ye which moves us to keep the commandments of god is to
the end to be in his love and in his grace / for he loves those the which
keep them in like wise as it is written johannes.xv. Si precepta mea
seruaueritis manebit is i^ dilectione mea. If ye have kept my commandments
ye shall dwell in my love and dyleccion. Iteru^ in code^ capitulo. Vos amici
mei estis si feceritis que precipio vobis / Ye be my friends if ye do that
thing ye I commau^de you. Example by that / that abraham was obedient unto god
/ he was so parfytely in his love that he had his benediccion. Quere.lxi. a.
Another example by that that saint Mor was obedyent he did many miracles
among the which he ran one time upon the water wtoute synkynge or ylle
having. Que. lii. c. Another example by the obedyence of a relygyous / god
loved so much that a dry belet block that he arroused with water bare flower
and fruit. Quere in the exemplayre.lii. e. God said in the gospel / if ye
love me keep my commandments. He ye which loves me not / keeps not my
commandments. vnde iohannis.xiiii. Si diligitis me mandato mea seruate.
Sequitur Qui non diligit me sermones meos non seruat. Any lord or king ne
may love his servant when he dysobeyeth unto his commandments / no more
does god / how may he love ydolatres blasphematoures children unnatural /
inobedientes / murdrers / theuys / payllars / and false witnesses / when they
dysobeye unto his will and break his commandments he ne may love them.
Behold what hate and inconvenient that there came unto adam for a bit of an
apple that he did again the commandment of god. Quere.liiii. a. Also
behold how chore / dathan / and abyron / were punysshed for the inobedyence
and murmr that they made again god and Moses. Quere.liiii. God ne may love
hy^ the which dysobeyeth unto his commandments. But he loves him the
which obeys unto him. We read how god demanded of saint peter if he loved
him / Petre amas me. He answered thou know that I love the. Tu sis quia amo
te. And by that that saint peter loved god / and obeyed unto him / our lord
Ihesu christ said unto him in this manner of wise. pasce agnos meos: pasce oues
mea. I shall give the keys of the reame of heaven unto the / and that that thou
byndest in earth shall be bound in heaven etc. For that that he was obedyente
unto our lord Ihesu christ / god gave unto him the government of the church
and the keys of paradyse. Also we should keep the commandments of god to
the end that it would please him to abide with us / for to keep us and save
us. Vnde iohannis.xiiii. Si quis diligit me sermonem meum seruabit et pater
meus diliget cum et ad cum veniemus et mansionem apud cum faciemus. That is to
say / who so loves me keeps my words and my fader shall love him says
Ihesus / and unto him we shall come and we shall make with him our dwelling /
and it is written. ioha^nis.xv. Manete in me et ego in vobis. Dwell ye in me and
I shall dwell in you. Et legitur. ioh. iiii. Deus caritas est: et qui manet in
carytate in deo manet: et deus in eo. God is charity and love / and who so
dwells in charity / he dwells in god and god in hy^ We read that our lord
said unto the appostles that they should goo to preche and to convert the
infydeles. And that they ne should think what they should answer unto the
tyrauntes / and that it should be given unto them that that they should answer
of the holy ghost the which abodem them as says the gospel. Dabitur eni^
vobis in ti^la hora quid loquamini. Non enim vos estis quiloquimini: sed
spiritus patris vestri qui loquitur in vobis. So it appeared that god abode in
them. And who so does again the will of god he ne abides in him. etc. The
fourth thing yt should move us to keep the commandments of god / is to
the end that the good deeds that we done be unto him agreeable / and unto us
vtyle and prouffytable / For if we dysobeye unto him our operacyons pleases
him nothing. Three things ben requysyte before that we may do thing the
which is unto god agreeable / The first is the good deeds that we do be done
genere bonorum. That is that it proceed of a good kind or stock as to give
almesdedes of his own labor without doing it of theft or pyllery. The
second is: quod sit ad laudem dei non ad vanam gloriam. That is that it be
done unto the preyse of god / and not unto vain glory. The third thing is
that a man be in the estate of grace. For the good deeds that a man does in
sin is not merytoryous unto the eternyte unto the person the which does
it. Also it is not aggreable unto god: how be it yt a man should not draw back
to do evermore of good deeds as it is declared before. Quere.xliii. b. The
pope pius says de consecratione distinc.v. Nichil prodest ieiunare and orare
et alia religionis opera agere nisi men's ab iniquitate reuocatur. It
prouffyteth nothing as unto salvation to fast / and to pray / and to do
other good deeds of relygyon if the thought be not called again from sin /
that if a man cease him not to committee mortal sin. etc. And saint poule
says.i. corinth. xiii. Si linquis hominum loquar and angelorum. etc.
Caritatem autem no^ habuero nulis michi prodest vt dictum est ante: quere.iiii.
ca. After the scryptures it behooves to do the good deed in estate of grace /
in doing the pilgrimage of the world as it is said in ye first condycyon of
the pilgrim of paradyse. Quere ibi post. The.v. thing that should move us to
keep the commandments of god it is to the end that it would please him to here
and to understand our requests / prayers and oraisons / and that he them
grant unto us and exalte when we require him. Vnde. ioh. xv. Si manseritis in
me et verba mea in vobis manserint: quodcunque volueritis petetis and fiet
vobis That is to say if ye abide or dwell in me that is in my love. and that my
words be abiding in you / that been my commandments / ye shall demand
what so ever thing that ye will and it shall be done to you. Et legitur mathei.
xxi. and marci. xi. Omnia quecunque peneritis in oratione credentes accipietis.
God says you byleuynge in me by faith operant / take ye in orayso^ all
things what so ever ye demand / and the psalm. says. Occuli domini super
iustos and aures eius ad preces coru^. The eyes of god ben upon the just / and
his eres unto the prayers of them. Et legitur luce. xi. Petite et dabitur
vobis: querite et inuenietis: pulsate et aperietur vobis etc. Example how at
the prayer of a man a mounayne was remeued from one place unto another.
Quere.xli. a. Another example how a good priest catholic entered within the
fire to conferme the faith / and was not burnt. Quere.lxi. b. And in deed
contrary the orayson of him the which will not keep the commandments of god
ne shall be exalted / and ne shall get grant anenste god of that that he
demands. Vnde augu. Qui preceptis auertitur quoth in oratione postulat non
meretur: nec impetrat ab illo bonum quod poscit: cuius legi non obedit.
Example. The request of ye cursed dives was not granted hy^ when he demanded
a drop of water and that the lazar should go unto his brederne. etc.
Quere.lxxxiiii. a. The syxte thing mouynge us to keep the commandments of
god is to the end to have the great benediccyons that god prometteth unto those
the which here with good will and keep his commandments the which ben
written after. Quere.xlv. f. The.vii. to the end to have great reward in
paradyse / whereof it is spoken afterward. Quere.xlvii. a. The.viii. is to have
dread of the maledyccyon and exco^munycacyons the which ben cast upon the
sinners inobedyentes unto god and unto the church. Quere.xlviii b. The.ix. of
dread to have punycyon as pharaon the which had the heart so hard and was so
obstynate in ill yt he would not obey unto god and unto his servant Moses.
And therefore god sent unto him many punycyons and in the end he was drowned
divinely he and his people. Quere in ye exemplayre.liiii. f. Also these dys
obeysantes should dread to be sent in to ye fire of hell ye which is a
torment much cruel in like wise as it is written in ye end of the treatise.
Quere.xlix. b.

B. How many things ben nuysau^tes unto those the which ben inobedyentes and
breketh the commandments of god / the which ben written herafter by psalms.
Capitulo. xliiii
QVi in vno mandato peccauerit multa bona perdet. Ecclesiastisis.ix. ca. Who so
has sinned mortally in one commandment shall lose many of good deeds / That
is to understand that ye transgressyon of every commandment that a man
commytteth in synnynge mortally by dylectacyon and delyberacyon noyeth unto the
soul in many manners yt which shall be herafter declared and put by psalms /
First the fraccyon or brekynge of any commandment puts the soul of the
breker unto pouerte of spyrytuall goods. for it chaseth and makes to be
forgoten his virtues and good operacyons lately gote^ and the which rested in
him. Saint ysydore says. Per vnum enim peccatum multe iustitie pereunt. That
is to say yt by one sin many of justices peryssheth and saint poule says
ad galatas quinto Modicum fermentitotam massam corrumpit. In like wise as a
little of leuayn or sour dough corrupts a great dele of paste / even so the
brekynge of the commandment corrupts a great hepe of fair virtues.
Example how ye angel said to a vyrgyn chaste devout / a gyuer of alms and
charytable that she ne might be in such wise saved if she were not pacyente /
for ye sin of ire abode in her. Que. lxxxxix b. circa finem. Another example
of a monk the which was so much replenysshed with virtues that god sent
unto him every day celestyall bread. And after that he had committed sin
he lost ye said bread. Quere in the exemplayre ad numerum.ci. a. Another
example how the sone of a rich man the which served god in fastings and
oraysons and in doing operacyons was in the end dampened for that that he kept
ire in his heart / and for yt he would be venged. Quere.lxxix. a. Hold thou
for certain that the dysobeysaunce that a man commytteth in sin mortal is
an infeccyon and sekenes mortal the which takes away chaseth and anientith
and makes to be forgoten the virtues and ye goods spyrytuelles that any man
has before gotten and the which rests in hy^ For the scripture says yt
these virtues ne may dwell with the vices. Virtutes cum vitiis remanere no^
possunt. And these logicyens says two things opposytes and contraryes the
one unto the other ne may enhabyte ne dwell togyders in one self subject but
that the one chaseth a way the other. Duo opposita nunquam possunt esse in
eodem subiecto. The sins and the virtues ben contrary the one unto the other
/ than they may not dwell togyders. If I be than in mortal sin / my sin
chaseth away the goods spyrytuelles from and makes it to be forgoten before
god whiles yt it regneth in me / for I ne may be hole and seek togyders / good
and ylle / governed of god and of the devil / of good spyryte and of ylle. In
like manner I ne may be in grace and in sin / for they ben things contraryes
that when the one rules it chaseth and puts away ye other what so ever it
be. Vnde bernardus. Sicut ignis et aqua simul esse non possunt / sic
spirituales et carnelis delitie non se co^patiuntur ad inuicem. In like wise as
ye water quenches ye fire / or bytternes chaseth away swetnes and all things
delycyous / or the traycle the venyme / or the derkenesse the light / or the
hete the cold / In like wise mortal sin chaseth away the virtues and the
goods spyrytuell of the soul. Example also as the water departs it from the
pot the which is perced or holed. In like wise does good operacyons from men
by mortal sin. Quere.cii.x. Also mortal sin is by symylytude as infeccyon
and venym mortell / for in like wise as venym corrupts ye health and the
goods of the body / in like wise sin corrupts the health and goods
spyrytuelles of the soul. And in like wise as those yt which ben inuenymed
ben in danger of death if they ne go to seche of tryacle / so ben they in
mortal sin if they ne goo unto penance. Quere.viii. a which is the tryacle
and the remedy again sin Augustinus dicit. Omne seminarium voluptatum venemim
puta. Et luce.xiii. Nisi penitentiam egeritis omnes simul peribitis. Also
mortal sin is a rotennesse the which corrupts the beauty of the soul the
end of virtues / the odor of good renomme and the sauoure of glory. And in
like wise as rote^nesse gothe unto naught and leseth all beauty and bounte of
an apple so does mortal sin of the soul. vnde job. xiii. Qui quasi putredo
consumendus sum: et quasi vestimentum quod comeditur a tinea. Example how an
earl was dampened for an heritage ylle witholden albe it that he had done of
good operacyons. Quere.lxxxii. a. Another example how a woman the which fasted
and excercysed her in oraysons and good operacyons was dampened for the keeping
of Ire without being in will to pardon. Quere lxviii. d. Also a man may say by
symylytude that mortal sin noyeth unto the soul / in like wise as epedyme
or pestylence: or other sekenes mortal noyeth unto the body. For in like wise
as the sekenes corporal takes away the health and all the goods of the body.
In like manner ye dy^^beysaunce the which is ^^^hin mortal sin is so great a
sekenes unto the ^^u^e that it takes away and chaseth^ virtues and good
spyrytuelles the which rest^th in her. Vnde ezechielis.xxxiii. Inqua^tur que
die peccaue^it iustus omnes iustitie ^ius obliuioni tradentur. In what hour
that the just has sinned all his justices ben forgoten. Also when one membre
is seek / all the body feleth it and playneth. Cum patitur vnum membrum
co^patiuntur oi^a membra. Also when a man co^mytteth one mortal sin in
brekynge one of ye commandments of god a man dampneth the body and the soul
/ he leseth god / he leseth paradyse and all good spyrytuell / the which ben
forgoten as unto salvation. Vnde iacobi.ii. ca. Quicunque totam lege^
obseruauerit offendat autem in vno factus est omniu^ reus. Qui enim dicit non

tra^gressor legis. Example how a woman a great gyuer of alms the which wend

sin brings unto naught all virtues and good spyrytuell. Vn^ magister
nicholaus de lyra dicit super illud ad galla. Modicum fermenti totam massam
corrumpit. Malum enim consistit ex singulis defectibus ita quod in
congregatione fidelium vnus peruersus in fide corrumpit alios per suam
malitiam. E alibi. Vnica sola pecus inficit omne pecus. When that a town is
taken with assault those the which takes it puts unto death and chaseth
away those the which it possedeth. In like wise done the sins and deuylles
when they have possessyon of a person / and that they rulen / they slay the

peccato mortuus est semel. He the which is deed by sy^ne / is one time deed /
that is to understand of death of gylte / for grace and virtues ben departed
from him. etc. Also when ye jews / sarazyns / or payny^s have the dominacion
of christian men they slay them and take from them their goods / in like wise

lose all her spyrytual goods and puts her in dampnacyon and perdycyon.
quere.lxvi. a. For to rehearse in partyculer upon the sin of lecherye. A man
should understand that in committing lecherye a man breketh the
commandment of god / and also a man synneth mortally / and such sin
makes the virtues and good operacyons gotten before to be forgoten. In like
wise as a man may say by symylytude / as if they were burnt / broyled / lost
and brought unto naught. For in like wise as ye fire of ye world brenneth /
consumes and puts in to ashes and unto nothing these words and these
other materes combustybles that a man gives unto it. In like manner yt body the
which is chauffed to do the operacyon of lecherye that god defends brenneth
and brings unto naught the good operacyons and virtues of the soul / if ye
said fire be not put out by penance. Of the which it is written job. xxx.
Crimen luxury fax est et iniquitas maxima ignis est deuorans vsque ad
perditionem et omnia eradicans gemmina virtutum. Wha^ a house is enbraced
strongly with fire / if the said fire be not quenched by water i^ brenneth and
consumes all the goods and materes combustybles till unto the earth and unto
the stones / in like manner the fire and embracement of lecherye brenneth and
dystroyeth all ye goods spyrytuelles of the soul of the lecherous man / or
woman / in such wise that the germe and engendrement of virtues ben taken
away and enrached / and it is understand by ye words before spoken.
Eradica^s omnia gemmina virtutum gemmen geminis id est germen: vel genero
generas. Also the blyssed and holy man saint Jerome says Gladius igneus e^
species mulieris. The glayue of fire is the beauty corporal of a woman. Vnde

Colloquium mulieris quasi ignis exardescet. The which is for to say / who so
will keep him from brennynge / draw he a far from the fire / that is from

ferther let them draw back / from the company of evil women. For a bronde

qui ignem in propria domo ponit. And the moo of sins that he co^mytteth he is

yt she conceived a child and deyed impenytent without confessyo^
Quere.lxxxxiii. h. Another example of a woman the which was a great gyuer of

C. Secondly inobedience the which is mortal sin lets and keeps for to
get virtues and goods spyrytuelles / the which ben merytoryous unto the
(...) Capitulo. x^^ii^^
PEccatum meum contra me est se^per. Dicit david i^ psalm. Miserere. After that
the king Dauyd had committed mortal sin / he said that his sin was
evermore again him. Also thou man reasonable know thou and hold thou for
certain that if thou be in any sin mortal thy sin shall be ever more
again the and noyeth unto the soul in all manners and sorts that a man can
tell it the. For if thou will get paradyse and to possede the joys the
which there ben thy sin shall keep the from going theder any sin mortal
what so ever it be. And if thou will not have of pain / ne punycyon temporal
/ or dampnacyon eternell / thy sin shall make the to have in this world
punycyon. And if thou have not by penance / correccyon and amendment / thou
shalt have dampnacyon eternal and shall be constrained to be in ye fire and
torments of hell will thou or not. And if thou have gotten of virtues yt time
that thou commytte in will or deed any mortal sin / incontinent without any
delay as thou haste committed it / it brings to naught all the good deeds
yt thou have done before / as it is specifyed above. And if it so be that thou
will purchase here in this valeye of myserye of virtues and of goods

would get as thou shalt here herafter so that thou sinner may say with
dauyd the prophet. Peccatu^ meum contra me e^ semper. Sin is said mortal
because it mortefieth good deeds acquired And also it sleeth the merit and the
reward eternell of the good deeds that a man would get. And therefore a man
may say by symylytude that mortal sin is a sekenes spyrytuel unto the soul
the which lets all his good deeds as the sekenes corporell lets all the
goods of the body Verbi gratia. If a seek body drink or ete also the sekenes
lets / that thing that he takes that it ne gothe unto ye nouryture of the
body. Also the sin lets the taste / the appetite / the sauoure and the
odoure and takes away the strength / ye beauty and courage of the body. Also
it lets to say his matynes / his service / to go unto ye church / to
labor / and to work. In like wise does the sekenes and infeccyon of mortal
sin to speak spyrytually. For if mortal sin regne in a person it takes
away the taste / the appetyte / the savor / and the odoure of glory / and
draws back the will for to do good deeds. Also it takes away all strength
/ and devotion to do good operacyons / and keeps that they ne prouffyte unto
merit and unto the nourysshynge of the soul in like wise as says these
scryptures. Vnde papius dicit de consecratione. v. Nichil prodest ieiunare scz
quantum ad meruum et orare et alia religionis opera argere: nisi men's ab
iniquitate reuodetur. That is to say that it prouffyteth nothing to fast as
unto merit and reward eternel / and to pray unto god and to do other

si distribuero i^ cibos pauperum omnes facultates meas. etc. Caritatem aute^

First mortal sin and the devil lets to get science / and sapyence

sapie^tia: ne chabitabit in corpore subdito peccatis. Example also how the

cuicunque his delectatur non erit sapiens. Secondly mortal sin and the

ne may labor study / walk / and fast? or do such operacyon. And if ye
person young be in mortal sin it lets and keeps that it be not
merytoryous unto him in deed. How men find by example in the bible yt sy^ne
let that the fasting of the people was not agreeable unto god whereof it is
wryte^ ysaye. lviii. Quare ieiunauimus et non aspexisti humiliauimus animas
nostras and nescisti. etc. Sequitur. Ecce ad lites et co^tentiones ieiunatis

us / we have humbled our souls and thou haste nothing known us. And the
answer unto them was given. You do your fastings in hates / stryfes /
contencyons / sins / and ylles / and therefore your betynges and torments be
as nothing. For god will that the good deed be done in the estate of grace.
Example how a religyous was dampened for his glotonye / for he ete in secret
when men wend that he had fasted. Quere ad numerum. cv. e. Thyrdly mortal
sin lets penance and confession / for he puts before the person shame
and horroure to committee such sin / or dread to have great penance / or
fere to lose his good renomme. And if the person has done penance he

unto the salvation if ye sins be again reco^menced / and he the which

Fourthly mortal sin lets and keeps to do almesdede to less his bread /

D. Thyrdly inobedyence the which is mortal sin noyeth / for it dyffameth
ye person the which it co^mytteth. ca. xliiii.
PEccator transgrediens ma^data dn^i incidit in promissionem nequam. Ecclesi.
xxix. The sinner trespassynge or offendynge the commandments of god shall

Mortal sin is so great vice the which so much noyeth unto the persons the

world as in the other. We read luce xvi. De villico qui diffamatus est apud

eternum: esuriui et non dedistis michi ma^ducare. etc. I have had hongre and ye
have not given me to eat. etc. Many sy^nes regneth the which dyffameth the

us. A man knows openly that the sin of lechery is a dishonor before the

do it and reproach unto the lygnee the which of it proceeds Example the
sin of the sodomytes dyffamed them before god and ye world ineternum and

and unto all those ye which follow them in co^myttynge their sin. legi. eccl
xli. Cu^ semi^e pcto^rum assiduitas opprobrii erit. That is to say. With ye
sede of sy^ners accustomaunce of reproach shall be. It is a thing manyfeste yt

children which bears the rebukes of their sins and crimes / And those
children ben pryued of goods and heritages of both the fader and also of the

Another example of a sone the which had in his foreheed a tode.xiiii. year

E. Fourthly inobedyence the which is mortal sin noyeth. For it aueugleth
and derketh the inward eyes of the soul. ca. xliiii.
QVi odit fratrem suu^ in tenebris est et in tenebris ambulat and nescit quo
eat quonia^ tenebre obce caueru^t oculos eius. vt dicitur ioh. i. c. He the

herytages / or the ylle of his body / or ye da^pnacyon of his soul again that

The reason is so abused and made derke by hate or other mortal sin that the

which is in him / and the which shall come unto him if he persevere in such
estate. vn^ david in psalm. Homo cum in honor esset no^ intellexit comparatus

it not. Example the sage salamon says in the.vii. chapitre of his proverbs
yt he saw by the wyndowe of his house a yongman walking by a way / and when
he came unto a tornynge back there was a woman acurned and appareylled with
the habyte of a strompet for to take the souls the which came to her / and
she began to laugh and to flater with him and spoke unto him ydell words and
kissed him and handeled him / and incontinent reason was so overcome and the
soul auengled of the said young man that salamon has written in ye said
chapter. Et ecce iuuenis statim sequitur ea^: quasi bos ductus ad victimam: et
quasi agnus lasciuiens and ignora^s and nescit quod ad vincula stultus trahitur
velut si auis festinet ad laqueu^. And therefore mortal sin is to flee the
which puts out his eyes within forth of the soul as it is said / and
abuses the entendement and makes him to be bestiall. Vnd david in psalm.
Nolite fieri sicut equus and mulus quibus non est intellectus Also mortal
sin is so great a sickness fylthynes and infeccyon unto the soul yt it

malo scz ai^a in peccato perseuerans q^ nigrior est corno: dyaboli qui eam
rapiunt et locus in quo ducitur. Saint Austyn says that three things ben wors
than al ill / that is to understand the soul perseueraunt in sin ye which

wise as Lucyfer became black / derke / and vyllayn / and abhomynable and lost

virtues and good operacyons the which give light unto man and is in derkenes
as he that is blind ye which has lost his eyes his clarte and the joy of
this world. And if the blind man leseth his conductoure he falls and
tombleth in inconuenyence / as in water / dytche / or mire / and if he be
soylled yet sees he nothing. In like wise the soul yt which is in mortal
sin she has her inward eyes put out / made dy^me in derkenes she sees not
where she gothe / nor she sees the good that she loses / ne the ill wherein
she falls / she has lost her conductour the which is god / and also she
sees not how she is soyled / albeit yt the body live in the world. Vn^ psalm.
Co^prehe^deru^t me iniqitate me and no^ potui vt videre^. Also these sinners
as thieves / robbers. etc. ye which ben in such wise blinded leueth to do
their operacyon by night in derkenes pryuely as beestes and birds that goo by
night for dread yt they ne be rebuked and sharped as it is written. John. iii.
ca. Dilexerunt homines magis tenebras quam luce^ era^t eni^ eorum mala opera.
etc. And therefore god shall punysshe them in hell by derkenes in ye land of
mysery / of ye which it is written. Job ^. ca. Verra^ misery et tn^braru^ vbi
vmbra mortis et nullus ordo sed sempiternus horror inhabita^s. The remedy for
to give sight unto blind syn^ers is pride. Vn^ paul. ad to. xiiij. Abuciamus

F. Fyfthly inobedyence yt is mortal syn^e noyeth / for it is that / yt holds
ye souls of the person yt it commytteth. xliiii.
INiquitates capiu^t i^piu^ et funibus peccatorum suorum vnusquisque
co^stringitur vt habetur prouer. v. c. That is to say. These i^iquytees takes

in the seruytude of the devil. In likewise as the ox is bound by the horns
with ye lain / or the birds taken with snares and gre^nes and put unto death and
perdycyon / or as these yrens or fetres holds ye prisoners in prison and
captyuyte. We find in writing yt such puyssaunce as a man has in his propre

etc. Et legitur ioh. viii. ca. Oi^s qui facit pctm^ seruus est peccati. He that
does sin is servant unto sin / so as a servant / a page / or a maiden do
not their wylles but ye wylles of their master / who so puts him in
service leueth his frewyll and fredome. Example how the devil gave in charge
to a woman four things after that he had surmounted her / the which was

which was never ryden for to be overcome and put under a sadle shall serve will
he or not. Also if the devil vaynquysshe the by his temptacions and yt thou be
fallen in mortal sin thou shall obey him and serve him. That is to
understand when he shall say unto ye / serve me. where thou have the company
of such a woman The lecherous shall obey unto his power / and shall do as the
servant unto ye master Vn^ paul. in epi. ad to. Nescitis qm^ cui exhibuistis
vos seruos ad obediendum serui estis eius cui obedistis sieve peccati in mortem
sieve obeditionis ad iusticia^. When oni man of war is beten down /
vaynquysshed / and overcome his master takes from him his harneys and all the
goods the which ben upon him / after he puts him in lokkes and feters.
More over he his obedyent and servant of his master / so that he ne main
dare go in to place what so it be but by ye leave of his master. At the last he
is put to raunsom and he must needs pay it before that he may escape. In
likewise is it in this purpose when any man is vaynquysshed and surmounted of
the devil by mortal sin First he loses his virtues and gods espy
rytualles of his soul as it is said here before. Eccle. ix. Qui in vno peccato
peccau^^^ multa bona perdet. Secondly he is put in yrons and bonds and holden

place what so it be but by his commaundeme^te / but understand well how. Wha^
a be is drawn he gooth no ferder than the length of his draught / no more
does he the which is in the bonds of the devil. But note well that the
devil alyeneth the in thy draught for to goo unto fornycacyon / or for to do
theft / or for to pleed falsely / or to bear falls witness / (...) or to haunte
tauernes / or to work on the feestes / or for to do homycyde / strive /
deu^syon / and all euylles and sins / or for to go unto ye church / not for
to pray to god / but for to speak there evil words / and to pertourbe and
trouble the deuocyons of other And if the devil se that there be predycation
or fervent orayson he shall draw out of the church his servant and prisoner.
Example of one of the monks of the order of saint Benet that the devil drew
out of ye church when ye other prayed. Que. lxv. g. Another example how the
deuylles held a man bound in a chain and led him with great Joy. Quere. C. ii.
z. Another example how a man being in mortal sin is lo bound that he ne
may do any good operacyon that is merytoryous to him. Quere. C. ii. and. And

the ox by ye horns with a cord for to kyl hy^. Example of auaryous usurers
hanged in hell. Quere in the examplarye. lxxxvi. A. Other examples of people
hanged in hell. Quere. lxxxi. g. and. lxxxxiiii. d. Moreover a man should know
that the devil has throughout the world so many coltrappes / instruments
and baytes for to take the souls in his gynnes / snares / and strings as
there ben delectable things thorowout the world by the which men commytte
mortal sins. That is to understand yt as many as there ben delectable
goods throughout ye world that man takes or coueyteth to take unjustly by
theft or pyllery. etc. The devil has in the world as many instruments
caltroppes and snares for to take and led ye souls in cords and bonds / and
every theft or mortal sin yt a man co^mytteth ben as many of snares as it is
said. Or a man may say that as many of beautes as men and women have throughout
the world so many instruments and slings has the devil for to take the
souls. Example how the devil said unto a fair daughter pompeously arrayed the
which daunsed on the sondaye-Thou art our arms and our daughter for to take
souls. etc. Quere. lxviii. c. Unto purpose of this matter the sage says in
the.ix. chapter of the ecclesyastes. Inueni mulierem morte amariorem que
laqueus venatoru^ est / sagena cor eius vincula sunt manus eius / qui placet
deo fugiet eam qui peccator est capietur ab ea. That is to say. I have found a
woman more bitter than the death ye which is the threde and lease of hunters /

oi^ vi^culo peccatorum. For to be short the soul is unbound from sin by

nostra sicut passer erepta est de laqueo venantium / laqueus contritus est et

G. Syxtely Inobedyence noyeth for it sleeth the soul spyrytually of the death

QVi odit fratrum suum homicida est Primo Iohannis. iii. capitu. He the which

I. Eyghtly inobedie^ce noyeth / for it pryueth from paradyse. xliiii.

quere. liiii. A. Five things lets to mount in to paradyse. The first is

The aungelles and saints of paradyse mount and descend in one only moment.

Also between this and paradyse there ben many heuens after scryptures. There is

Si vis ad vitam in gredi serua mandata. Examples Judas was priued from paradyse

Nec fecit proximo suo malum et opprobriu^ non accepit aduersos proximos suos.

Example of a charytable man yt yode unto heaven at his death or that his body
