from clymbynge / but more sooner vylaynsly to fail. Example of a bird the
which has the bec / the heart / the wings seek he forces not to fle / but
more sooner to fall. In likewise the man the which has the heart seek and
undone by ill thoughts / ye mouth enuenymed of ill words / the hands
scabbed / crooked / and undone by ill operacions he ne is able to fle in to
paradise. Saint Poule says yt they the which do the operacio^s of the body
the which ben of syn^e shall not mount in to paradyse. Vn^ ad gal. v.
Manifesta su^t opera carnis q^ sunt fornicatio / immundicia / impudicitia /
luxuria / ydolorum seruus / veneficia / iimicitie / co^te^tiones / emulationes
/ ire / rixe / dissentionis / sect / i^uidie: homicidia / ebrietates /
co^messationes / and his similia qm^ qui talia agunt regnu^ celorum non
co^sequentur. Also saint Poule says. i. ad co. vi. Nolite errare' qr neque
fornicaru / neque ydolis seruie^tis / neque adulteri / neque molles / neque
masculorum co^cubitores / neque fures / neque auari / neque ebriosi / neque
maledici / neque rapaces regnu^ dei possidebu^t. Example of a woman yt used her
life in lecheryes / glotonyes and pleasaunces carnal that was dampened / and
her husband was saved yt lived so brely and well. Quere. lxxxxii. A. Another
example yt ye body of a fool pryued his soul from paradyse. Quere. xlvi. A.
Also we appetyte to be well heryted / and well lodged in a fair house / and by
mortal sin who so deyeth impenytentes leseth the fair heritage of paradyse
and the fair lodgings the which there be^. He is a fool yt shytteth his house
so strongly that he may no more enter therein / or who so sells or gives his
heritage for nothing. In likewise does he the which commytteth mortal sin
/ he him closes or shytteth from paradyse / and if he sell it and give it for
nothing / that is for sin. And there is no person in all the world so
evil but that right gladly he would have paradyse / ne the which would lose
his part. And for certain they the which commytteth mortal sin and if in
such wise they deye they lose it as it is said before. Quia deus non saluat
impios. Vt legitur Job. xxxvi. Et etiam legitur ysaie. xxvi. Tollatur impius ne
videat gloriam dei. Also we appetyte to be fair / clear / shyninge well clothed
be seen and aorned. Also we desire to have rychesses and honors / also health
agylyte and all other things delectables / and by mortal sin all is lost
unto them the which deye Impenytentes as it is said before. etc.

K. Nynthly inobedyence the which is mortal sin noyeth / for it byndeth
unto pain and punycyon. xliiii.
Iniusti punitur vt dicit david in psalm. The unjust shall be punysshed. Every
person ye which will not have pain and punycyon let him keep him from
dysobeynge unto god / unto the church / and unto his superyours in committing
mortal sin. For from the time that any man has committed mortal sin he
is so bound unto pain and punycyon that he may never escape but that he have
punycyon corporal the which is transitory in this world / or punycyon and
dampnacyon eternal in the other world. For it is written. Nullu^ malu^
remanebit impunitu^. That is to say / yt none evil shall abide unpunished.
And it is written in the gospel yt god shall lose ye ill euylly. Vn^ math. xxi.
Malos male perdet. Iteru^ dd dicit. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua.
Example how god made to rain fire and sulfre upon them of Sodom for to
punysshe the^ for their sins. Quere. lxxxxv. a. Another example how Pharaon
and his people had many punicyons for yt they ne would obey unto god. Quere.
liiii. F. Another example of the punycyon of Chore. liiii. H. When any has
committed blaspheme / homycide / theft / fornycacyon / or any mortal sin /
he is bound body and soul to receive pain and punycyon before god for his
sins. And as if he were bound before ye notaryes to pay any sum of money /
so that he shall never escape without hauy^ge punycyon as it is said Dauyd the
prophet says in the psalter ye words of god. Si iusticias meas prophana
uerint ipit et mandata mea non custodieri^t visitabo in virga iniquitate eoru^.
That is to say. If the cursed inobedyentes have taken in scorn my Justices and
take no head to my commandments / I shall vysyte in a rod the inyquytees
of them in strykynge their sins. Also a man should understand after the
scryptures that god punyssheth the sinners for their Inobedyences and
cursednesses. Quicqid patimur peccata nostra merueru^t. And yet they apperceyue
not from whens proceeds such punycyon / as it is declared before where is
treated that they the which breketh the festes oen punysshed. Quere ad
numeru^. xix. A. Also god punyssheth ye sins in this world by famyne / war
/ and mortalyte. By famyne for he makes the corns to fail / apples / vynes
and other fruytes and labors / by frost / mist / heet / air corrupt. etc.
Vnde deutero. xi. Cauete ne forte decipiatur corvestru^ et recedatis a domino
et mandata eius / iracusque dn^s claudat celum and pluuio no^ descendant / nec
terra det germen suu^ pere atisque velocitur. etc. Example how the sons of
Jacob were punysshed by famyne / for that they sold their brother Joseph and
made their fader to believe yt a be had devoured him / and that be was
envy. Vn^ gene. xxxvii. Fera pissima deuorauit filium meum joseph dicit jacob.
etc. Another example written in the third book of kings how great dryness and
famyne came unto ye people for ye ydolatryes and sins the which reigned in ye
time of ye cursed king Achab and of his wife Iesabell yt made to sle the good
man Naboth / and it was at the prayer of ye prophet Helye. Vn^ iacobi. v.
Multum valet deprecatio iusti assiduo / helyas erat homo passibilis similis
nobis / et oratione orauit vt non pluerit super terra^ / and no^ pluit annos
tres et menses sex / et rursum orauit et celum dedit pluuia^ et terra dedit
frutum suu^. Secondly god punyssheth ye sinners inobedyentes by mortalyte / as
he did unto the people of Rome the which people after Eester went to play /
to be drunk to excercyse lecheryes / sins / and euylles in such manner yt
god wrothed him against the said people / and made to come great waters and
great multitude of serpents and snakes the which deyed and enfected the air
After there was so great mortalyte yt innumerable people deyed / and many deyed
in yanynge suddenly. After that saint Gregory was pope yt institued the
processyon and fast on saint Marks day. Another examp^e of ye punycyon of some
yt returned after ester to their ylles and sins. Cu. t. Also of them yt brake
gods commandments. lxiiii. k Another example written in the last chapter of
the second book of kings how after yt Dauyd had vyctory of his enemies he
made to nombre his people by vain glory god sent unto him the prophet Gad yt
said unto him yt he should chose of three ylle things one which he would / yt
is to have. vii years famyne and honger in his land / or.iii. mo^thes so
strong war yt he should fle before his adversaries yt should persecute hy^ /
or three days of mortalytee in his people. Than Dauyd said. I am anguysshed and
hard beten on all sides. He took mortalyte yt was so great yt in. iii days
there dyed of his people.lxx. M. men by sekenes of pestelence. And Dauyd said
unto god. Ego su^ qi peccaui ego iiqui egi. Isti qi oues su^t qid fecer^t /
vertatur obsecro manus tuas co^tra me and co^tra domu^ mea^. Another example
written in the book of Moses how the children of Israel had punycyon by
mortalyte for their murmr. etc. Thyrdly god does punysshe the inobedyent
sinners by war as we have by example how by the proud answer yt king
Roboam gave unto the people of Israel they raised another king and the said
Roboam had war all his life. Que. lxxxxix. m. Another example written in
the.xix. chapter of the book of Iuges yt mo than.lx. M men were slain in
battle of the people of Beniamyn for to punysshe them of the sin of lechery
yt they committed in the wife of Leuyte. que. lxxx^^. b For to be short god
punyssheth the inobebyent sinners in many manners / for they be^ bound to
punycyon by sin as it is said Example written in ye third book of Jonas how
god sent unto ye people of Nynyue yt they should be dystroyed / they and their
cite wtin xl. days for their sins. Adhuc xl. dies et nyniue subuertetur.
etc. They did penance and god had mercy on them. The punycyon of sinners is
sometime temporal and transytorye. And sometime it is eternal. The punycyon
temporal is sometime voluntary / as that the which is done by penance the
which is merytoryous. Sometime it is done by constraynte as ye thieves the
which ben punysshed and hanged against their will / this punycyon and pain is
not merytoryous. Vn^ legitur. quod oi^s actus meritorius oportet quoth sit
volu^tate i^peratus. But if a thief bear with good will the death and such pain
for his own sins as yt good thief yt was put to death when our lord deyed /
such pain and death should serve for penance / ye which is greter than to
fast. etc. The good thief said. Illud luce. xxii. Na^ digna tactis recipimus
morte^ / hic au^t nichil malifecit / and for that: yt god knew and saw his
faith / his contrycyon and the death that he bare so wyllyngly for his sins
of good right he said unto him. Hodie mecum ens in paradiso. etc. Of the
punycyon eternal that the sinners Inobedyentes shall have it is written
herafter. Quere ad numerum xlix. a. Examples shall be written toward the end
of the book. Quere in penis inferni.

A. The co^dycyons yt the pilgrim of paradyse should have touching yt a man
should apply his.v. wits of nature upon the commandments of god / as a
good pilgrim does on his way.xlv.
IT is written in ye.xix. cha. of saint matthew how a man axed of christ what good
deeds he should do to get eternal life. And he answered. If you wylt enter in
to eternal life keep the commandments. Si vis ad vita^ ingredi serua ma^data.
For the obseruacion ye co^mau^dements is the right way without going by in any
wise. you art here living as a pilgrim yt te^deth to go to heaven or in to hell
/ for thy life is but a pilgrimage of little during. And therefore if you wylt go
to se god / the vyrgyn Mary / the aungelles and holy places of paradyse / and
to have heritage in that contree there and not in hell / employe thy five
wits of nature upon ye commandments of god / and take the condycyons of
the good pilgrim. It is written. eccl. xxix. Pone the saurum tuu^ i^ preceptis
altissimi / et proderit tibi magis quam auru^. Put thy treasour in the
commandments of god / and it shall prouffyte the more than gold. Also
follow the life of god / his manners and condycyons. He appeared unto two of his
dyscyples in semblaunce of a pylgrime. Vn^ luce. xxiiij. T'u solus peregrinus
es in inthrlm et non cognouisti ea q^ facta su^t in ea his diebus. etc. He
descended from paradyse for to accomplysshe the pilgrimage of the world / he
was borne of the vyrgyn Mary and lived in the state of grace without any sin
xxxii. years and an half / and at his death his pilgrimage was accomplisshed /
and after returned in to paradyse his contree. He showed unto us by example and
by word how we should live in this world. Cepit dn^s facere et docere. to
the end yt we be pilgrims of paradyse / and that we goo to dwell with him in his
glory: A good pilgrim should have many condycions for to make his pilgrimage
of the which we shall tell. viii.

B. First a good pilgrim should confess him and put him in thestate of grace
and so to do his said pilgrimage. Also in doing ye pilgrimage of this world
we should confess us often times / and we should live in thestate of grace to
the end yt the good deeds yt we do be unto god agreeable and to us proufytable.
For mortal syn^e is an infeccyon and sekenes unto ye soul so ill yt it
lets all spyrytual good deeds yt it unto hy^ ne may profit as a man sees
by symilytude how bodily sekenes lets to labor / to walk. etc. and that
meet and drink in no wise can profit unto the body / so yt a man seek
corporally and spyritually ne may do his pilgrimage till he have health / yt is
to be well confessed and yt he have charity without the which no good deed ne may
prouffyte / as is declared in ye chapter of charity. que. iiii. c. and in ye
fourth thing yt moeueth to keep ye commandments of god. que. xliiii. a. Vn^
aug. in libro de natura and gr^a. Nullu^ opus qua^tu^cu^que de se bonu^ su^mo
opifici est acceptu^ / nisi agatur i^ gr^a. No work how good so ever it be of
it self it is not agreeable unto the sovereign werker if it be not done in
grace. And saint Thomas says. Nullus ho^ po^t mereri nisi media^te gr^a. No
man may deserve to have reward eternal but by ye merit of grace And howbeit
yt good works done in sin ben not merytoryous unto eternyte yet a man should
not let to do them as it is declared here before. Of this matter example of a
pilgrim yt lived in this world in the state of grace after ye commandments
of god / and he was conforted of aungelles of paradyse the which bare his
soul in to heaven. And of an ypocrite that pleased to the world and did
sins secretly / the devil drew his soul from h^s body with an hoke and bare
it in to hell. For he was pilgrim. Quere in thexam. C. iiii. C. Another example
of a wydowe that was comforted and vysyted at her death of the vyrgyn Mary. And
of a rich man yt was vesyted of deuylles in lykenes of black cattes. etc.
Quere. C. v. A.

C. Secondly ye good pilgryme should take clothynges the which ne may grieve
hy^ in his vyage. And should take away from him al weight or heaviness of burden
/ and al thing yt might let him to walk well. Also in doing ye pilgrimage
of this world a man should not take vestyments / gyrdylles shoes. etc. full of
pompes / fro whens does proceed pride and elacion the which lets to goo in
to the realm of paradyse as says saint Poule in his epy. ad thy. No^ i^
tortis crinibus aut auro / margaritis / vl vesta preciosa. Et psalm. No^hi^tabit
i^ medio domus me qui facit superbiu^. He yt commytteth pride shall not
enhabyte in the myddle of my house. Example how a woman pompeously arrayed and
clothed was enuyroned and set about with deuylles / and she bare many upon her
tail. Quere. lxv. D. Another example how the cursed dyues clothed in purple
was the pilgrim of hell / and there is buried. Quere in thexa^plary. lxxxiiii.
A. Another example how saint Johan baptyst yt was clothed with sharp vestements
is in paradyse for he was a pilgrim. etc. And a man should understand that ye
noblesse of habyllementes is not defended unto every man after his estate. But
the superfluyte and pride is defended the which may be taken in those
habylleme^ts. Also thieves the which ben charged of ye gods of their
neighbors ne may well walk ne mou^te into paradyse. Vn^. pau. i. ad cori^.
vi. Neque fures / neque auari regnum dei possidebunt. Example in Achar ye
which was a thief and therefore he was stoned and all his goods brent by the
commandment of god. Quere. lxxx. a. Another example how ye thief zacheus was
a pilgrim of paradyse and is saved / for he dyscharged him and restored the
theftes that he had done. Vnd luce. xix. zacheus dixit ad jesus / ecce dimidiu^
bonorum meorum dn^e do pauperibus / and si quid aliquem defraudaui reddo
quadruplu^. etc. Also glotons / dronkerdes / the which eats and drinks
unto excess walks not into paradyse / but falls in to hell. Saint Poule
says. i. ad cori^. vi. Ebriosi regnu^ dei no^ possidebu^t. Example of a
pilgrym yt sold his gown for to drink wine. Quere. xci^i. G Another example
how a friar was a pilgrim of hell for that he wont him to drink and ete when
the other occupied they mat the service of the church / at his death he saw
hell open / and the tourmentes. etc. Quere lxvii. C. A man yt is to much fed
may not well walk / nor he mounteth not in to paradyse. Also these mortal
sins ben burde^s much heavy the which greueth the soul and keeps it from
mountynge in to paradyse Men knows by experyence how a heavy burden greueth ye
body / in likewise does sin the soul. Vn^ da. Iniquitates me supergressu^t
caput meu^ and sicut ouus grave grauate sunt super me. Put away the sins ye
which ben in ye for to walk well. The pilgrim of paradyse should put from
above him all things the which lets to do ye commandments of god the
which ben the way of the said paradyse as it is said / to the end yt he may
well prouffyte. When a man cutteth the superflue of the vine / or ye burgeons
of the tree they increase / grow and fructyfye the better. In likewise does a
man spyrytuall for to put from above hy^ all vestementes and array replete of
pride and of vanyte. etc.

D. Thyrdly the good pilgrim should often times with his mouth demand ye way
for dread to go out of it. Also the pilgrim of paradyse should demand and
learn ye commandments of god and the salutary things / as did a man the
which demanded of our lord Ihesu crist. Good master what good deeds shall I
do to the end that I have eternal life. And he answered. If thou will enter in
to life eternal keep ye commandments. etc. as it is said before. Also Dauyd
the prophet axed of god yt he would teache him his Iustyfycacyons to ye end yt
he him self were Iustyfyed. Vnde psalm. Doce me iustificatio^es tuas. Thou art
not so great a lord as Dauyd / for he was king of Israel. Thou art not so
wise ne so learned ne so holy as he / and he demanded for to be instruct for
to have salvation and therefore demand ye commandments. And I tell the for
certain the way for to fle right in to paradyse is obedyence the which is ye
ladder for to mount thither and the ten commandments ben the pynnes of
steps as it is declared in ye beginning of thexamplary where it speaks of
ye obedyence of Abraham. Que^. li. a Also every person yt comes to the aege
of dyscrecyo^ should hold / keep / and acco^plysshe the commandments of god
upon pain of eternal dampnacyon. And therefore every man and woman should learn
them for dread to break them. Vn^ ligitur in scdo libro sente^ci. di. xvii.
Stati^ ei^ cu^ quis sit capax precepti dei tenetur ad noticia^ et obserua^tia^.
The poet says. Serua mandata / si tu vis regna beata. Qui non obedit: celesti
cede care bit, Keep ye commandments if you will have the blyssed realms. He
yt obeys not shall not have a syege celestyall in paradyse Example how the
devil slew a child of.v. year old in his faders lap for that yt he was a
blasphematour. Quere in thexa^plary. lxii B. If the fader had correcked his
child / and also if he had taught him the commandments of god ye deuylles
had not slain him. And therefore a man should demand and learn. When a
pilgrim will not demand ne learn his way he often times swerueth and gooth out
of the way. Also good pilgrims should speak of god and of good words in
making their vyage / and god abides and is among them as it is written.
Mathei. xviii. Vbi duo vel tres co^gregati sunt in noi^e meo: ibi su^ in medio
eoru^. Example how god appeared unto Cleophas and unto saint Mark in speaking
of hy^ as they yode unto Emaus. As it is written. Lu. xxiiii. Another example
how god was in ye mids of two relygious at crystmas in speky^ge of his
natyuyte. lxxxxiiii. b And to the contrary when ye pilgrims of hell speaks
detraccyons / mockes / and ylles the devil their master is by them yt shall
led them in to hell that is their cite and country to dwell in. Example how a
detractour was sent thither and had cruel Judgment Quere. lxxxxviii. Also the
gospel of saint Matthew takes the way for to go in to paradyse and says.
Illud. math^. vii. Intrate per angustia^ porta^ qr lata portat et spreosa via
e^que ducit ad perditione^ / et multi su^t qui i^trat per ea^: qua^ angusta
porta et arcta via est q^ ducit ad vita^ et pauci su^t qui i^ueniu^t eam. That
is to say. Enter ye by the strayte gate for ye large gate and spacyous is that
yt ledeth unto perdycyon / and many there ben the which enters by yt. The
anguysshous gate and strayte way is that yt ledeth unto life. And few people
enters by yt. For to understand well this strayte gate / it is to lead a life
of austeryte and hardness in fasty^ges / abstynences / sobrenes / chastyte / and
penance. And the large way is to live in all voluptuousnes / carnalytees /
lecheryes / glotonies / daunses. etc. Example of a fool and a wise man which
took the way in to hell. lxvi. A Other examples yt it is well taken unto many
for to demand ye word of god / and first How a woman demanded of a
relygyous a good exhortacyon yt prouffyted so much yt her husband yt was of
ill conscience converted him. Que. lv. B. Another example of a relygyous yt
asked often times the faders to tell unto hy^ some admonycyo^. q^re lvi. C.
Another example how he the which techeth ye word of god shall have great
reward in paradyse. lvi. G. Another example of a monk the which reknowleged
his sins in showing them to another. Quere. C. i. A.

E. Fourthly the good pilgrim should evermore take heed if he be well in the
way ye is taught him. Also the pilgrims of paradyse should evermore take heed
if they accomplysshe well the commandments of god the which ben their right
way and conductour the which shall conduyte them and the which shall enlumyne
their eyes to walk well. Vn^ dd. Preceptu^ dn^i lucidu^ illumina^s oclos. Also
the word of god is ye lantern yt shyneth and gives light unto ye fete for to
go well. Vn^ dd. Lucerna pedibus meis verbu^ tuu^. Et legitur pro. vi. Ma^datu^
lucerna est et lex lux. What thing that a man does in this world he should
evermore take heed if he do that yt god commands. For they ye which thereto
takes head shall not be confounded / thus says Dauyd Vn^ psalm. Tu^c non
co^fu^dar cu^ perspexero in oi^bus ma^datis tuis. Et eccl. xxiii. Nichil est
dulaus quam respice in ma^datis dn^i. That is to say. Nothy^ge is more sweter
than to take heed unto the commandments of god They the which take heed
thereunto and abuses them in worldly vanytees and pleasaunces / as daunces /
plays / and folyes / lightly gone out of the way and leueth the way of
paradyse. Example Eve our first mother took none head on ye commandment yt
unto her was given and was deceived by te^tacion / and for the beholdy^ge of ye
fair fruit And therefore she was put out of paradyse terrester. liiii. A. Also
they the which ben lecherous and abuses them to behold the beauty of women (
vl eco^uerso) or the women ye beauty of the men swerueth and leueth the way to
paradyse. It is written. ec. ix. Nec aspicias muliere^ mltiuola^ ne forte i^
laque os eius. Cu^ sallatrice ne assiduus sit nec audias illa^. That is to
say. Behold not yt woman the which will many things that you fall not in her
laces / ne accustom the to be with a woman yt is a daunser / or leper / ne
here her not sing. etc. Example by that that Synchem beheld the beauty of
Dyne the daughter of / Jacob / he coueyted her and slepte with her as it is
written gen^. xxxiiii. Que^ in thexamplary. lxxxx. d. Another example by that yt
the wife of Pharaon beheld the beauty of Joseph / she prayed him of dyshonoure
as it is written. gene. xxix. Saint Gregory says. No^ licet i^tueri quoth non
licet co^cupisci. And therefore Dauyd required of god that he would torn his
eyes from prosperytees yt he beheld not the vanytees of the world by the
which he should be abused. Vn^ david. Auerte oclos meos ne videa^t vanitate^.
etc. The appostles and saints of paradyse have so well looked on the
commandments of god that they have not ben abused and yt they ben gone all
right in to paradyse / and in likewise should we do.

F. Fyfthly the good pilgrim should take pain to here / to understand / and
to retain those the which techeth him his way. Also the pilgrim of paradyse
should with good will here ye commandments of god* the prechynges / and them
the which unto them shows it / for all benedyccyon and salvation thereof
proceeds. In likewise as says these scryptures. Vn^ luce. xi. Bean qui
audiu^t verbu^ dei and custodiu^t illd. That is to say. Those the which
hereth the word of god and keeps it ben blyssed. Et legitur deute. xxviii. Si
audieris voce^ dn^i dei tui / vt facias atque custodias oi^a mandata eius
venie^t super te universe bn^dictiones iste et apprehendent te. Bn^dictus eris
in ciuitate et benedictus in agro / bn^dictus fructus ventris tui / et fructus
terris tue / fructusque iumentorum tuorum / greges armentorum tuorum / et caul
ouiu^ tuaru^ / bn^dicta horrera tua / and bn^dicte tue reliquie / bn^dictus
eris and ingredie^s et egredie^s. That is to say. If you here ye voice of thy
lord god to the end yt thou do and keep al his commandments his benediccyons
vnyuarsalles shall come upon the and shall apprehende the / thou shalt be
blyssed in the / thou shall be blyssed in the field / the fruit of thy womb
shall be blyssed / and the fruit of the earth / and ye fruit of thy mares /
of thy bestyall / and of thy sheep / thy garners shall be blyssed / and thy
relykes shall be blyssed / you shall be blyssed in entering and going forth of
al places. Many other gods shall be written in the said chapter yt abides
because of shortness. Et le. pro. xxix. Qui custodit lege^ beatus est. He yt
keeps ye law is blyssed and that dredeth god / and excercyseth him in his
commandments ye sede of him shall be puyssaunt in the earth / the generacyon
of the good shall be blyssed. Vn^ dd i^ psalm. Beatus vir qi tunet dn^m in
ma^datis eius volet nimis. Pote^s in terra erit seme^ eius gn^atio rectoru^
bn^dicetur. Example in ye blyssed Magdaleyne yt took great pleasure to here ye
word of god and set her at his fete by humylyte for to here him speak. Vn^
luce. x. Maria sede^s secus pedes dn^i audiebat verbu^ illius. Also it is
written ioha^. viii. Qui ex deo est vba dei audit. He yt is of god hereth his
word and it follows of them yt will not here it. Propterea vos non auditis
qr ex deo non estis. Ye here not the word of god / for ye be not of his party.
Et legitur io x Oues me voce^ mea^ audiunt. My sheep / those ben ye good
persons the which here my voice. etc. Of this matter it is written in the
third commandment. Quere. xv. c. All salvation proceeds to here the word
of god and many persons has been saved for herynge of it. In likewise as men
find many examples. First how a great syn^er repented and was saved for to
here a predycacion. Quere. lv. a. Another example of an earl yt converted him
by the herynge of the word of god. Quere. lv. e. Another example of a rich
man yt served the devil. xl: years and in a sermon he repented him. Que^ lvi.
k. Those the which have shame to here speak of god / our savior Ihesus shall
have shame of him at the day of Judgment. Vn^ luce. ix. Qui me erubuerit and
sermones meos / hu^c filius hoi^s erubescet cu^ venerit in maiestate sua. Also
he yt will not here the faith and the commandments his orayson shall be
execrable / and unto him it ne shall be accorded. Vn^ prouer. xxviii. Qui
declinat aures suas vt no^ audiat lege^ or^o eius erit execrabilis. Example of
a carle yt would not here the word of god in his life / and the crucyfyxe
stopped his eres unto the service that men did for him in his buryenge in
betokenynge yt he ne would here ye oraysons that men made for him. Quere. lv.
f. The said carle and all those the which will not here to speak of god / but
ben ready to here of detraccyons and ill should understand yt they sin gretely
/ and ben worthy to have great punycyon if they deye Impenyte^tes Example
written in the sermons of the dysciple of a bishop yt was borne in to purgatory
after his death for to do his penance and he was there gretely tourmented of
the stynke of his clerk being in hell the which mounted unto him for that he
herd sometime his detraccyons and had not eygrely enough correcked him /
howbeit yt above al other things the said bishop had be good. Another example
of a man that was tourme^ted in hell within his eeres for that yt he had
folysshely herd of symphonies and Instruments. Quere. Cvii. d. Another
example of a man yt was terrybly tormented for ye vain songs and syngynges yt
he had herd in the world. Cvii. d. All ill proceeds to speak and to here ill
words. And all goodness proceeds of the word of god as thou may here in
the camplary. Que^ lv. a. b. c.

G. Syxtely ye good pilgrim should thy^ke upon his way till that his pilgrimage
be accomplysshed. Also the pylgryms of paradyse should think upon the
commandments of god and them should plant and root in their hertes without
forgetynge them / whereof it is written i^ deuteronomu. Audi israel precepta dn^i
et ea in cord tuo quasi in libro scribe / et dabo tibi terra^ fluentem lac et
mel. O Israhel here ye commandments of god and write them in thyn heart as
in a book / and I shall give unto the ye land / flowynge milk and honey. These
words spoken touches three things. The first is that men should here gladly
the commandments of god. Audi israel. The second is yt men should put them
in my^de Et ea in cord. The third is yt the reward follows. Et dabo tibi
terra^. etc. Of ye which reward shall be here afterward spoken. xlvii. a.
And it is written eccl. Que precepit deus illa cogita sper. Think evermore upon
those things yt god has commanded. Example in the blyssed vyrgyn Mary the
which held all the words of god and kept them in her heart. Vn^ luce. ii.
Maria autem conseruabat oi^a verba hec co^ferens in cord suo. They the which
have ye heart and the thought to break the commandments of god be not the
pylgryms of paradyse / but of hell / the which shall go to se lucyfer / the
deuylles / and the dampened / and shall have heritage in that country there / if
they deye impenytentes without correccyon and amendment. This matter is declared
in the nynth commandment and in the tenthe.

H. Seventhly the good pilgrim should walk on his fete and do the operacyon
of his way in trauaylynge his body. Also the pilgrims of paradyse should live
in this world in doing the operacyon of the commandments of god and they
shall have benedyccyon and salvation. Vn^ psalm. Beati qui a^bulant i^ lege tua
dn^e. They the which walk in thy law be^ blyssed. Iterum pres. Bti
i^maculati in via qi a^bula^t in lege tua dn^e. Blyssed ben they not soyled in
the way yt walks in ye law of our lord. Example in Dauyd yt ran in the

tuorum cucurri. and lege^ tua^ dilexi. Another example in Abraham that did in
operacyon ye will of god and he had his blyssynge. li. a. Another example of
the good man of an house yt received the pilgrims and set them at his table
received god. Quere i^ q^rto precepto. in ye works of mercy. Another example
of a monk yt bare god upon his sholdres in semblau^ce of a mesell or lepre.
Que. xxiii. e. Many examples shall be found in thexamplary of people the
which have done in operacyon the will of god and of their superyours / as saint
Mor. Joseph. Thobye. Quere. lii. c. d. e. f. etc Also for to be saved and
Iustyfyed it suffices not to here the commandments but it behooves to
fulfill them in operacyon. Vn^ ad to. ii. No^ ei^ auditores legis iusti su^t
apd deu^ sed factores iustificabu^tur. Saint James says in his.ii. cha. In
likewise as the body is deed without soul / even so faith is deed without

audit^res tm^ fallentes vosmetipres. Iterum di. Ex operibus legis ho^
iustificatur et non ex fide tm^. That is to say. Be ye the doers of ye word
of god and not alonely the herers deceyuinge your self. Example of a wrothfull
lady that yode often to here ye sermons and she ne correcked her for thither
going. Also example of her maiden yt desired thither to go and god appeared unto
her. Quere. lxxxxix. b. Also each man yt calls god lord and master shall
not enter in to heaven / but he yt does in operacyon his will there shall enter
/ as it is wryte^ in ye.vii. cha. of saint math. The pilgrim of paradyse yt
loves god keeps and does his word / and he yt loves hy^ not does the^
not. io. xiiii. si qis diligit me sermone^ meu^ seruabit / qui no^ diligit me
sermones meos non seruat. Example how Mathatias yt kept the law of god
persecuted the sy^ners the which brake it. Quere. lii. a. Those the which ne
will do the operacyon of the co^mau^dements of god ben pilgrims of hell and
thither shall be sent for too dwell will they or not / if they deye without
correccyon and amendment. Example in cayn yt slew his brother Abell.

I. Eyghtly the condycion of a good pilgrim is to bear a bordon or a staff
for too defend him from dogs and from his enmyes. Also the good pilgrim of
paradise should have a good staff yt is steadfast faith for to defend him from
deuylles. Vnd. i. petri. v. ca. Aduersarius vester diabolus ta^quam leo rugie^s
circuit quere^s que^ deuoret cui resistite fortes in fide. Example how saint
Anthony was strongly tourmented and beten of deuyls / but he had vyctory
against them by the great faith yt he had in god. Also he had in him all the
condycyons of a good pilgrim / wherefore he is in the glory of paradyse. Unto
the which we may goo cum illo qui est benedictus in secula seculorum. Amen.

A. Example how the body the which is a fool draws the soul in to the way
of hell. xlvi
IT is written eccle. xxxvii. A consiliario malo serua ai^am tua^. Keep thy
soul from an ill councelour for if you believe ill counceyle thou shalt be
deceived and in danger of perdycyon. Et legitur. i. io. iiii. No^ oi^
spu^icrede^du^ est. A man should not believe ne give credence unto every
spyryte. For the ill person ne counceyleth but ill the which in hy^ rests.
Example of a fool and a sage yt made a vyage togyders / the which yode unto a
cite wherein men said yt many goods unto them were promised / and in going in
the said vyage came to demand ye way of pastures or herdmen the which to
them said. Ye shall find.ii. ways the one much large / the other right
strayte. If ye go ye strayte way anon ye shall be at your cite. And if ye go
by the other large way it is way full of bypathes the which shall bring you
out of your way / and also it is full of thieves the which shall take from you
your gods and peradventure shall make you deye and ye shall not go unto your
cite / how so ever it be go ye not that way. Than said the sage unto the fool.
Go we by this streyte way. The fool said yt will we not do / here is a fair
way and a large it is better to believe that yt we se than that yt men tell us.
And the sage said / thou see how ye pastoures says. Than said the fool / fie
/ fie on these pastors they wot not what they say / thou art more fool than I
come on / come on thy way. And the said fool drew the sage and went the large
way. And anon they were out of the way and fell among thieves the which took
from them al their gods / held them prisoners and put them in their bonds /
service and captyuyte. And they were so long yt the fool deyed / and in
contynent the cause was put in Judgment before the Judge / and was declared as
it is said that for as much as the sage believed the fool / and yt they would
not believe ye pastoures yt they were fallen in such inconuenyent. Than the
Judge gave sentence yt the said fool and the sage were cast together in to the
fire to be burnt and broyled without mercy / and it was done. Here is the
example but it behooves to expound it. By the fool is understand the body of
every of us / by the sage is understand the soul / ye vyage is this world
the which is but a pilgrimage / the cite is paradyse / the Judge yt condempneth
them is god. The pastoures ben these bysshoppes curates / prelates / and
prechours the streyte way is to lead a life of austeryte in fastings /
abstynences / so bryete / chastyte / and penance. The large way is to live in
all voluptuosytees / and carnalytees / of lechery / glotony / daunses. etc.
that the body appetyteth / the enmyes ben the deuylles / the world / and the
flesh / the thieves ben the.vii. deedly sins the which takes from them al
their goods / yt is all good virtues and paradyse / the Judge the which them
condampneth is god yt shall condampne the body and the soul at ye Judgment to
be brent togyders. etc. More openly it behooves to expound it. That yt these
prelates counceyleth the strayte way / is yt thing that ye gospel of Matthew
speaks vii. Arecta et angusta est via que ducit ad vitam / lata et spaciosa
est via que ducit ad perditione^ / vt dcm^ est. Et prouer. xii. Iter impiorum
decipiet eos. Sequitur. Iter au^t deuiu^ ducit ad mortem. A fool ne will believe
till that he receive. In likewise these folysshe sinners will not believe the
clerks and prechers till that they be in the fire of hell in dampnacyon. By that
yt is the sage yt is the soul the which would go by the streyte way / and the
body the which is a fool gaynsayeth it. It is yt the which is written ad gall.
v. ca. Caro co^cupiscit aduersus sprem. etc. and illd roma. viii. Sisecundu^
carne^ vixe ritis moriemini. By that ye the thieves yt sins take a way the
virtues / it is that yt is written ecclesiastes.ix. Qui in vno peccato
peccauerit multa bona perdet. By that that they were put in seruytude is yt
that is written. John. viii. Oi^s qui facit pctm^ seruus est peccati. Et.ii.
petri. ii. A quo ei^ quis superatus est eius seruus est. And that yt god shall
Judge it is written. Marci. xvi. Qui crediderit / and baptizatus fuerit saluus
erit / qui vero non crediderit condempnabitur.

B. How the pilgrim of paradyse should consider.iiii. things. xlvi.
DAuyd the prophet says in ye psalter. In cord meo abscondi eloquia tua / vt
non peccem tibi. I have hid thy words that been thy co^mau^dements in my
heart to the end that I syn^e not against thy will. Thou sinner for to keep the
from sin and for to bear lightly all the labors / pains / trybulacions /
sekenesses / and aduersytees the which comes unto the in doing the
pilgrimage of the world. Consider.iiii. things. First consider ye shortenes
of thy life / and how at thy death all ends. That is to understand all
fastinges wakynges / erly rysynge / sekenesses / aduersytees and tourmentes
that thy body has borne and endured. What thing is it as of thy life / it is
a vapor apperinge in a little thing. Vn^ iacobi. iiii. Queest vita vestra /
vapor est ad modicu^ parens. And to^ said. Remember the how life is wy^de. Vn^
job. vii. Memento qr ventus est vita mea. For in likewise as a blaste of wind
is soon paste / so is our life in regard of eternyte. Ite^ job. vii. Parce
michi dn^e nichil su^t enim dies mei. Good lord spare me my days ben nothing
/ they ben right short. Breues dies hominis sunt. etc. Thou man labor
strongly while that thy life dureth and bear all sekenesses and trybulacyons
pacyently / for you shall have the reward eternal of yt that you have labored
and borne for ye love of god. Secondly consider ye labors / pains /
trybulaclons / and death yt Jesus for to again bye the and us all. He yt is ye
sone of god eternal / king of aungelles / and of saints of paradyse. If a
great king bear for thy sake a great weight or burden / you outest to bear for
his sake a straw. And ye king celestyall has borne for the ye cross /
fasted labored / preched / and suffered death. Tha^ sholdest you endure evil for
the love of him. Thyrdly consider the pains / labors and trybulacyons yt the
dampened bears in hell / for the which pains we may be delivered for to
labor and to endure aduersyte in this world for gods love. Vn^. ec. xxix
Minimu^ pro magno placeat tibi. Little thing the pleases for a great thing.
For all ye pains of this world be nothing in regard of them unto ye dampened
the which be^ eternalles. Example of a man dampened yt spoke of the fire of
hell and of the dampened the which ben brent and broyled. lvii. Another example
of tourments yt a woman had that was dampened. lxxxx. a. Fourthly consider the
great Joys that been prepared in paradyse unto those the which labor well in
this world for the love of god. Whereof speaks saint Isidore in the book of
sovereign goodness and says. Qui vite future premia diligentur excogitat mala
oi^a pn^tis vite equanimitur portat qm^ ex illius dulcidi^e huius amaritudine^
te^perat. That is to say. He that thinks dylygently on the rewards of the
life to come bears egally in his courage all the ylles of this present life.
For it attempereth the bytternes of yt by ye swetenes of paradyse. And saint
Poule says Ad romanos. viii. Non sunt condign passiones huius te^poris ad
futuram gloriam. The passions of this time be not co^dygne unto the glory to
come / of the which is spokene hre after.

A. Of ye reward eternal that they shall have the which keep the
commandments of god. xlvii
IT is written in the.xliiii. chapter of Ysaie. And in the second chapitre of
ye first epistle of saint Poule ad co. Quod oculus no^ vidit nec auris audiuit
/ nec in cor hoi^s ascendit q^ pre parauit deus dilige^tibus se. This auctoryte
speaks great things. First it says that never eye ne saw in the world so
much good as god has prepared unto those yt love him. That is to say. if it
were possible yt any had been in the popes court / and of all ye patryarches /
cardynalles / archebisshops bishops / and of all the kings / dukes / earls
queen's / ladies / and gentylwomen of all ye world / and that he had seen their
treasours honors and goods yt they have and that unto them is done / it
should be but shame to have al those goods in regard to have one day in
paradyse of the leest Joy that is in it. There is. Quoth oculos non vidit / after
follows. Nec auris audiuit. If it were possible yt thou were as fair as was
Absalon ye sone of Dauyd the which had not in all his body one spotte ne foul
thing / but was all white / sanguyne / tender / and laughing / and his heeres
were so fair that when they were shorn they were sold for an hundred cicles
of gold. And if thou were as swyft as was Absael the which was so swyfte to
run that he passed an heart to course in plain country. And if thou were
also strong as Sampson fortyn the which at one time overcame a. M. men of
arms. And if thou were also doubted as Augustus Caesar unto whom all the
world obeyed. Of whom it is written (no^ habemus rege^ nisi cesarem) said the
Jews And if thou were also rich as was king Alexander the which was much
rich. And also wise as Salamon yt which was the wysest of the earth when he
lived. And also hole as Moses the which never lost one tothe / ne his sight
waxed derke. And if thou sholdest live as long as Matussa le the which lived.
ix. hundred years / or as Enoch and Helye the which ben in paradyse terrestre
/ and shall not deye unto the end of the world / and if all the world loved yt
as much as did Dauyd Ionathas whom he loved as him self. And if yt all were
accorded unto the in likewise as Helyseus and Cypre accorded togider / for that
yt the one would the other would. And if thou were lord of all and loved as
Joseph was in Egypt. If all that yt I have spoken were in the as yet as much
as a man might tell unto the / yet should it be but a thing of no valor in
regard to be one hour in the Joys of paradyse. Vn^ psalm. Melius est dies vna
i^ atriis tuis super milia. After follows. Nec cor hoi^s ascendit. That is to
say. If all the wysest clerks and people that ever reigned in the world
ymagyned the gretest Joys that they might they ne could comprehend ye leest
Joy of paradyse yt the saved have Also those the which in this world has
done and accomplysshed the commandments of god shall have consolacyon at
their death of god and his saints as it is written in thexamplary and approved
by many examples. And first of an holy fader that saw as his death the
prophets and Ihesu christ. Quere. Ciiii. a. And a man should understand yt the
reward of the saved shall not be egall / for every man shall have after his
desert. Appoc. xiiii. O pera ei^ illorum sequu^tur illos. Et paul. i. ad co.
xv. Alia est claritas solis / alia est claritas lune / alia est claritas
stellarum. Stella enim a stella differt claritate / sic et resurrectio
mortuorum. In likewise as in the fyrmament there is a clerenes of the son and
another of the moon and one of the sterres the which differreth the one from
the other in clerenes / in likewise shall dyfferre the resurreccyon of the
saved. That is to say. That so much the more as they have obeyed unto god /
and endured aduersyte for the love of him / of so much the more shall they be
in paradyse fair / clear / and nere unto god / and the more clearly shall they
se him and have of scy^ce and of retrybucyo^. And therefore says our lord.
John. xiiii. In domo pr^is mei mansiones multe sunt / scz pro diuersitate
virtutu^. Many mansyons ben in the house of my fader for the dyuersyte of
virtues And how be it yt god us gives by word in ye gospel Math. xx. that he
repreued the idle people and that he sent them at diverse hours to work in the
vine. The one in ye morning the other at tyerce / mydday / and even / and in
the end of the Journey every of them had a penny / as well those of the
euentyde as they of the morning. Of yt a man should not murmr if god give
paradyse unto sinners at all aeges when they will repent them / to leave their
sins and to put them to do well. This penny that they all had was paradyse /
they all had Ihesu christ yt which was crucyfyed in their possessyon / as well
those of the euentyde as those of the morning. In likewise as says saint
Austy^ But they had retrybucyon in beauty / clerenes / bounte / science. etc.
but unto the egalite of the good deeds that they had done in the world as it
is said / and as the scryptures declares. Vnde daniel. xii. Qui docti fuerint
fulgebu^t sicut firmame^tum / et qui ad iusticiam erudiu^t multos: quasi stelle
in perpetuas eternitates. They the which have been sage and wise shall shine in
likewise as the fyrmament / and they the which techeth any unto Justice as ye
sterres in perpetual eternytees. Et legitur ezechiel. xviii. Iusticia iusti
erit super eum / et impietas impu super eum erit. The Justice of ye just shall
be upon him / and the sin of ye wicked shall be upon hy^. Also every man
shall bear his charge. Thus Ezechyell says in his. vi. chapter. Et legitur
Ihe. xxv. Reddam eis secundum opera eorum et secundum facta manuum suarum. I
shall yield unto the saved and dampened after the operacyons of them / and after
the deeds of their hands. Et psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua. Thou
shall yield unto every man after his operacyons. The saved shall have Joy on
all parts. First they shall have Joy above them of god yt they shall behold
/ and of the great glory that shall proceed of hy^. For Dauyd says in the
psalter. Excelsus dn^s et super celos gloria eius. Et appocali. vii. Iusti su^t
an^ thronum dei / et seruiu^t ei. etc. Sequitur. Qui sedet in throno habitat
super illos. The lord is lift up and the glory of him is above the heuens.
Also the Just ben before ye throne of god and serve hy^. And it follows. He
the which sytteth on the throne abides upon them. Also the saved shall fe god
clearly face to face in his great honor and in his great glory infynyte /
whereby they shall be replenysshed with all Joys. Ysaie. xxiii. Begem in decore
suo videbu^t. It is written. i. ad corin. xiii. Videmus nu^c per speculu^ et in
enigmata / tu^c autem facie ad faciem videbimus. Also in seeing him clearly
there they shall take parfyte delectacyon and love / and they shall love him so
perfytely yt they shall never leave hy^ and they shall not go against his will /
in such wise that they shall have sure holding. Augustinus dicit. Videbimus /
amabimus / et laudabimus. Also in beholdynge this fair myroure the which is
god they shall se all them of paradyse / and of hell / and so they shall draw
and take of the fountain of science and sapyence so strongely that they shall
know the things past / present and some to come. And also they shall know
all the persons of paradyse / those the which they never saw as the other
and their name / and what they were / and of what operacyons and merytes. etc.
Too speak of this matter to much forth it is not good. And for because that
the wise Salamon says proverb. xxv. Sicut qui comedit mel multu^ non est ei
bonu^ sic qui scrutator est maiestatis opprimetur a gloria. In likewise as it
is not good unto him yt eteth much honey / in likewise to him the which is to
inquire of the mageste shall be put from ye glory. And said Poule yt was
rauisshed unto the third heaven and in paradyse as it is written ii. ad corint.
xii. Audiuit archana verba que non licet homini loqui. And also he says ad to.
xii. Dico oi^bus qui sunt intur vos non plus sapere quam oportet sapere / sed
sapere ad sobrietate^ et vnicuique sicut deus diuisit mansura^ fidei. I say
unto al them the which ben among you / ne savor ye no more than it needs
to savor / but savor ye unto sobrenes / and unto every one as god has
devised the measure of ye faith. And Cathon says. Mitte archana dei celumque
inquirere quid sit. Cu^ sis mortalis que sunt mortalia cura. That is to say.
Leave to inquire the secrets of god / as what thing is the heaven / sith thou
art mortal have in thyn heart those things that been mortalles. Also the
saved shall have Joy under them to se the tourmentes and pains of hell from
the which they shall be preserved and kept / and in such wise to have passed
and avoided the danger of the world wherein they were when they lived. Also
they shall have Joy by them to be assocyate with so great noble / and amyable
company / as in the company of aungelles and saints of paradyse / the which
shall be so fair / clear / shynynge / a ourned / elegaunt / and amyables /
than there ne is tongue yt it may declare ne entendeme^t comprehend. It is
wryte^ apo. vii. Vidit turba^ magnam qua^ dinumerare nemo poterat ex omnibus
tribubus populus et linguis. etcetera. Saint Johan in the appocalypse says. I
saw a great turbe or multitude of people the which no man might esteem ne
nombre of all lygnages / peoples and tongues. Also more over we find yt it is
written in the gospel yt they shall be semblables unto aungelles. Vn^ mar. xii.
Cum a mortuis resurrexerint neque nubent / neque nubentur sed su^t sicut angeli
dei in celo. Also the place of paradyse is so fair pure / and clean / and
delectable yt a man ne may take symylytude ne co^parayson: ne yt entendeme^t
may comprehend / wherefore it is better to hold my peace than to speak unduly.
The good Thoby says in his.xiii. chapy. Beatus ero si fueri^t reliquie seminis
mei ad videndu^ claritatem iherusale^. I shall be blyssed upon the relykes of
my sede when they shall se the clerenes of Iherusalem / that is paradyse. And
in the said place of paradise the which is pure and clean there shall no
person enter if he be not well purged and made clean from all spotte of sin
/ as it is written apoca. xxi. Non intrabit aliquid coinqi natu^ et faciens
mendatiu^ et abhominationem: Also the saved shall have Joy much meruaylous in
themself that they shall se themself so fair / bright / and shynynge. Also
of that yt they shall be so swyft / subtylles / immortalles / and impassybles.
etc. Also they shall be in the place of peace / bounte / beauty / love / honor
/ life / light / franchyse / suerte / swetenes / richesse / health / concord
dysporte / wisdom / rest / glory / Joy / gladness / they shall have peace
without war ne dyuisyon. Vn^ ysaie. xxii. Sedebit pplus meus in pulchritudine

B. Example of a man saved the which spoke and declared of the Joys of
paradyse. It is recyted in the promptuary of the dyscyple that there were two
monks the which spoke together of the life eternal / and they agreed between
them yt the first the which deyed of them should come again to notyfy unto
the other of his estate if it pleased unto god. When the one was deed he that
lived sorowed and was heavy / and the deed appeared to him clerer than the son
and he salued him benygnely. And when the quycke monk axed him of the life
eternal He answered. Sicut audiuimus sic vidimus quod oculis no^ vidit nec auris
auditut. etc. In likewise as we herd so have we seen. Never eye in the world
ne saw / ne ere herd / ne in the heart of man ascended ye great Joys yt god
has prepayred unto them ye which love him / when he had spoken these words
he departed.

C. Another example of a relygious that was.CCC. year to here a bird sing.
The dyscyple recyteth in his sermons that it is wryte^ how a relygyous man
right devout required of god yt he would show hy^ some sweetness of the Joy
celestyall. And on a day as he was in orayson he herd a little bird sing by
him / so he arose fro his prayer and would have taken her / and ye said bird
flewe unto the forest the which was nere unto the monastery and set her upon a
tree / and the said relygious yode after and rested him under the said tree for
to here the song of the said bird or angel / and after yt he had song as
much as pleased god he flewe away. And the said relygyous returned unto the
said monastery weny^ge to have be under the said tree but the space of an hour
or two / and was all abashed when he found the gate of the monastery masoned
and stopped and another gate on ye other side and that he ne knew the porter
ne the relygyous ne abbot / he was axed of whens he was and what he demanded.
And he said I a am relygyous of this monastery and parted from hens at such an
hour etc. Than they demanded the name of the abbot that reigned in that time.
He answered he had such a name. Tha^ they serched their chronicles and they
found yt he had failed in the said monastery and had been to here the song
of the said bird ye space of.CCC.xl. years without having heet ne cold / and
without that his vestyments were worn. etc. What swetnes shall they of
paradyse have when they shall here the song of all the nine ordres of
aungelles about the dyuyne magesty.

D. Another example of the clerenes of god. It is recited in the promptuary of
the dyscyple yt as master Jordan friar of the order of prechours passed by a
town for to go and preche he was prayed of the people yt he would vysyte a
woman posseded of the devil. And when he approached ye devil salued him
literally. And it was so yt the woman had never learned any lettres. And ye
said Jordan questyoned the devil lytterally. Wherefore tormentest you this woman
/ and wherefore delytest thou to dwell in her. The devil answered yt he was
constrained of his creator there to be / and that he ne might be else where.
And ye said Jordan questyoned him of many things among ye which he him
prayed yt he would tell him some thing of the clerenes of the face of god for
yt he had been in paradyse and had seen it clearly. The devil answered Neither
I ne all the aungelles the which it beholds and ben in paradyse / if they
were here in earth ne could tell any thing that might suffyse / but I shall
tell the some symylytude by the which thou may understand that his face is
clear. And he said understand. If all the flowers of all the herbs and trees
of times past and to come / and all grenenes of all graynes and herbs / and
all the colors of all the precious stones / and of all metalles / and the
shynynges of the son and of the moon / of the sterres / and all the clerenes
of all lyghtes ye which ever did shine to give light in the earth / all that
clerenes should be but a derke night in regard of the clerenes of the true
son the which is god. Than master jordan said. O how unhappy is that man yt
loses that / and yt geteth not that great Joy. etc.

A. Also the reward of them the which well or ill has enployed their.v.

ALso it is written. Eccle. xv. Si voluetis ma^data conseruare conseruabunt te.

tua. And you dampened shall have honger and thyrste of my glory. My servants

Tortiones and dolores tn^bunt / quali perturiens dolebunt. Example of Tongdalus

In quo me^bro creator plus offe^ditur in eode^ pcto^r grauius punietur. The
eeres of the good the which with good will has herd the word and ye

B The eyes of the good the which has beholden to do and accomplysshe the said

de^tiu^. Example of a soul yt bewept the time yt it had lost. It is written in

answer was given yt said. I am a soul damned / and he demanded. Wherefore

all the dampened wayle most for is for that yt they have lost and wasted
vnprouffytably the time of grace in sin where in one hour by repentance

quod meus aut aliud dirigi non poterit / nisi ad quoth vis doloris i^pulerit. The
fete the hands / and the body of the good shall have lyberte and fraunchyse to
run by the cleme^tes and places where it shall seem them good and unto gods

aru^d^neto discurre^t. And those of the ill shall be in the derkenesses of hell

to aid / ne to avoid ye place for to go from one place to another Vn^ math^.

B. The maledyccyons and excommunycacions of those yt which have dysobeyed
unto god and the church. xlviii
IT is written eccle. xli. ca. Ve vobis viri impii qui dereliquistis lege^ dei
altissimi. Ye men yt which have forsaken and left the law of the right hye
god maledyccyon is unto you. And it is written in ye first of the prophet
Ysaie. Ve genti peccatrici pplo graui iniqitate / semini nequam / filiis
celaritatis. That is to say. Maledyccyon unto people syn^ers / unto people
grievous of inyquyte / unto the cursed sede / unto the children sinners. What is
that maledyccyon. Maledyccyon is pryuacyon from benedyccyon / and from all
spyrytuall goodness and assocyacyon with all ill. And when a person loves /
serves and obeys more sooner unto the devil than unto god he is much
acursed / or when he leueth god for to follow ye devil / or when he has loved
ye euyls / the sins / and the cursednesses / and that he leueth the good
deeds / the virtues / and operacions Vn^ psalm. Dilexit maledictione^ and veniet
ei et noluit bn^dictione^ et elo^gabitur ab eo. The person yt dyobeyeth unto
the commandments of god loves maledyccyon and it shall come unto him. And
he has not wylled to have benedyccyon and it is elonged from him and shall be
pryued from paradyse and from the company of the blyssed saints of paradyse.
Vn^. i. ad cori^thios. vi. Neque maledicti regnu^ dei possidebu^t. For to speak
of excommunicacion and of malediccyon it behooves to se four things. The
first is wherefore a man is excommunicate The second the manners how any renneth
in the less excommunycacion. The third how he renneth in the great
excommunycacion by sentence of the Judge. The fourth by sentence of right written.

C. As unto the first. If thou demand wherefore a person is exco^munycate.
The answer. It is written in the droit that exco^munycacyo^ ne should be brought
in but for mortal sin. Exco^municati no^ nisi pro mortali culpa affligi
debet. Vt habetur. xi. d. iii. ca. Nemo episcoru^. And when any is cyted of
office and that he is excomunyed by the defaute of none apparaunce at a day
that is for the sin of inobedyence / for he should obey unto ye church and
there answer We ben all members unto the church unto the which we should
obey. Also when any is a thief / fornicatour or sinner and yt he ne dredeth to
offend god by sin he is excommunycate by medycyne for to give him shame and
dread / that is yt he knowledge his fault and yt he have so great shame to be
separate that he him corrects and amendeth. Exco^munycacyon cast of wrong or
of right is to dread / for such weneth not to be accursed yt is. Example of
two me^ the which gelded them at their advise in good intencyon / for the
which thing they were excommunicate / as it is written in thexamplary. lxxxix.
F.

D. As unto the second thing a man should understand that some run in the
less excommunycacyon incontinent that he companyeth wytyngly with one
excommunyed against the defense the which is made openly of the church / as
for to speak to drink to ete / to come too chapter. etc. This excommunycacion
separateth from the sacraments of the church. For ye person exco^munycate of
this exco^munycacio^ ne should in such estate receive none of ye sacraments
and the defaute not first assoyled in confession of that exco^munycacyon as of
other sins in saying. Absoluote a sententia minoris exco^municationis. But
the priest that has puyssaunce to assoyle that person of mortal sin a man
may assoyle. It is said the less / for how be it that it pryuateth from the
sacraments it ne separateth from entering into ye church / and to company with
other persons.

E. As to the third a man should know that the great excommunycacyon the
which is of the sentence of the Judge written and sealed separateth the person
excommunycate from the sacraments / from entry^ge in to the church / and from
the company of al faithful christian people. It is much to dread for many
things. First for that / yt these exco^munyed ben cursed of god the fader / yt
sone / and ye holy ghost. For that / yt the church mylytaunt curses and
byndeth it is also cursed and bound of all the blyssed trynyte. Vn^ math^.
xvi. Quodcu^que ligaueris super terra^ / exit ligatu^ and in celis. Also they
ben taken and delivered unto the devil as saint Poule betoke a fornycatour /
and as men find in writing. Also they shall be separate from the company and
co^munycacyon of the faithful christian people as lazers / or lepres infecte and
corrupt not worthy to be among the other / and pryuate from the partycypacio^
of all the masses / prayers / oraysons / alms deeds / and from all the other
good deeds of ye church without power in such estate to receive any of the
sacraments / ne to be buried in holy ground the which is a great infame / to
be buried as a dombe be / without solempnyte / without prayer / and oraysons /
not worthy to e^habyte ne to be in holy ground and blyssed. Also they ben as a
membre cut and separate from the body yt takes no part of the good of yt said
body. Where they ben as a bough or a branch cut from the tree the which
dries and is no more worth for nothing than to brenne. Vn^ io. xv. Ego sum
vitis vos palmites / sicut palms non potest far fructu^ a semetipso nisi
manserit in vite sic nec vos nisi in me manseritis Also a man may well speak
with a lepre without any sin ne danger / the which thing a man may not do
with one that is exco^munyed / his company is more dangerous than that of a
serpent. For as to company and habyte with a serpent a man synneth not mortally
ne dampneth his soul / as he does with a person excommunyed. Also one
excommunyed dysobeysaunt unto god and unto the church is cursed in his body /
in his members / and in his goods and fruytes and he bears maledyccion with him
in all places / and in all stedes where he enters and abides. Understand the
scryptures and go seche them in the chapytres the which follow. It is written
deutero. xxviii. ca. Si audire nolueritis verbum domini dei tui vt custodias et
facias omnia mandata eius / venient super te om^s maledictiones iste and
apprehendent te. Maledictus eris in ciuitate maledictus eris in agro /
maledictu^ horreu^ tuum / et maledicte reliquie tue / maledictus fructus
ventris tui / et fructus terretue / ar menta boum tuoru^ / et greges ouiu^
tuarum maledictus eris ingrediens / et maledictus egrediens / mittet dominus
super te famen et esuriem / and increpatione^ in oi^a opera tua que facies
d^nec conterat te and perdat te velociter propter adinuentiones tuas pessimus
in quibus reliquisti me / plura alia mala ponuntur ibi. etc. That is to say. If
thou wylt not here the voice of thy lord god to the end that thou do and keep
all his co^mmaundementes all these maledyccyons the which follows shall come
upon the and shall take yt Thou shall be cursed in the cite / thou shall be
cursed in the field / thy garner shall be cursed / thy relykes shall be cursed /
the fruit of thy womb shall be cursed / and the fruit of thy earth shall be
cursed / and the fruit of thy kyen / sheep / and bestyall / thou shall be
cursed in going in / and in going out of all places. God shall send upon the
hongre pouerte / blame / reproach in all thyn operacions that thou shall do
till unto that that he put the out hastily for the sins that thou have
found / for the which thou haste left god. Example how the flower of an
apple tree falls / dries / and leseth the beauty incontinent that it is
exco^munyed for a portous the which was in the said apple tree. Quere. lxxxix.
D. By this example a man should understand that ye soul of ye thief
excommunicate the which had stolen ye said portous was in ill point when the
flowers took part of his malediccyon. Another example of breed fair and white
the which was incontinent black and musty as it was excommunyed. Quere.
lxxxix. A. In showing the ill yt is wtin the person excommunycate. Dauyd the
prophet says in the psalm. Increpasti superbos maledicti qui declinant a
mandatis tuis. thou have blamed those yt ben proud / they ben cursed the
which declyneth from thy commandments. And it is written in the second
chapter of the prophet Malchyas. If thou wylt not here my commandments
says god / and also if ye will not put in your heart yt ye give glory unto my
name I shall send you honger / pouerte / and curse unto your benedyccyons. And
it is written Ysaie. iii. ca. Ve impio in malum. Maledyccyon unto the cursed
sin in ill And it is written in the.x. chapter of Job If I be ill maledyccion
is unto me. Example of a fader and of his sone the which curied each other in
hell. Quere in the exa^plarye. lxxi. Also thieves / coueytous / auarycyous /
pyllers / and false tythers / and many other people dysobeyeng unto god ben
cursed and excommunyed in likewise as these scryptu^es sayen. It is written in
the second chapter of the prophet Abacuch. Maledyccion unto him the which
assembleth cursed auaryce in to his house / to the end yt his nest be on hy / and
he weneth to be delivered from the hand of evil. And it is written in the.v
chapter of Ysaie. Maledyccyon unto youth which assembleth house with house / and
couple field with field. Ye should not enhabyte you all alone in the myddle of
the earth. And it is written in the.xxiiii. chapter of Ysaie. Maledyccyon unto
ye that pyllest / for thou shall be pylled. And it is written in ye.vi. chapter
of the gospels of saint Luke. Maledyccyon unto you yt be rich the which have
in this world consolacion for if ye deye in such wise without co^trycyon and
amendment the end shall be ill in desolacyon. Example how the devil drew the
soul from ye body of a cursed rich man with an hoke. Quere. C. v. a. Another
example how Chore. Dathan. and Abiron descended into hell hosed and cladde for

dysobeyed unto god the earth was cursed in his operacyon Quere. liiii. a.

F. As unto the fourth thing that speaks of persons exco^munyed by sentence
of right. A man should understand not al only those the which ben denounced
by ye commandment of the bysshoppes / prelates / and Iuges ben exco^munyed
of ye great excommunicacion / but also in many cases after the droit canon some
fall in the great excommunycacyon. Also many sentences ben written in droit
canon the which has been ordained by popes and counceyloures upon them the
which co^mytteth any sins determined. And the persons yt which commytteth
the sins ben excommunyed ipso facto / but the curates should not put them out
of the church till that they ben declared of the Judge for some causes ye
which ben not here wryte^. And for as much as those sentences the which ben
written in droit canon should be to long to write / many shall abide for to fle
the length and some the which has been drawn fro the said ryghtes here
follows. First these heretykes and lollers ye which believe / sustain / and
touch any thing against the artycles of the faith ben exco^munyed by
sentence of right. Also al those the which puts faith and credence unto
the said heretykes in reputing them to be good and to have good faith. Also
those the which defend them in word and in deed ben also excommunied. Also
those the which puts in holy ground the said heretykes and their alies by
credence / or those the which them has received and defended ben also
excomunyed / and should not not have the benetyce of absolucyon / if they ne
vnbury them with their own hands. Also if any say that the church of Rome is
not ye heed and that he will not obey it / or if he say yt it ne may ordeyne
the canons / such is an heretyke exco^munyed by sentence of right. Also those
the which false or make to false yt lettres of the pope / and those the which
them sustain and defend ben excommunyed. Also those the which falseth the
lettre or seal of a cardynall is exco^munyed. Also those ye which gives
lettynge unto messagers and ambassadors of the holy syege appostolycal ben
excommunyed (ipree facto). Also ydolatres / wytches / inuocatours of the devil
/ and they the which him demands his help and will have his aliaunce / or
the which makes covenant with him / or those the which unto him do sacryfyce /
or yt worship him And those the which unto him does homage or honor / or
that demands answer of any demand / such people ben excommunyed of deed
by sentence of right Of this matter thou shalt find many examples in the
nombre.lviii. and.lix. Also they the which puts vyolently the hands on
prestes / relygyous / and clerks ben excommunyed. And if there be (atroci) yt
is hurt enorme it is a case reserved unto the pope. Also those they the which
stryketh no clerk / but by their commandment be stryken and with holden ben
also exco^munyed Also those the which ben ye cause or ye which give the
counceyle to aid or put ye hands on clerks ben exco^munyed. Also those the
which ne counceyleth ne commands but after that the deed is done ben
agreables ben excommunyed. Also a relygyous that leueth folysshely the habyte
of his relygyon is exco^munyed and apostate. Also ye monks and chanons and
regulers the which has not of admynystracion the which go and give them unto
courts of pry^ces without having any license especyall of their prelates / if
they do any domages unto their said prelates and monasteryes in the said
courts where they ben betaken / the text says that in yt deed they run in
sentence of excommunycacion. Also all relygyous yt which bring forth
wytyngly any things in their predycacyons or elleswhere to the end that they
withdraw the auditors and herers to pay the tithes ben exco^munied And those
relygyous the which says unto them that go to confession unto those yt should
make conscience to have paid the tithe should be suspended from the office of
predycacyon till yt they have made conscience and that they have said unto
those confessed yt they have not well counceyled not for to pay the said tithes
if they may find them ne to have the oportunyte. And afterward if they were
without repentance and that they presume to preche the said neclygence / they
ben exco^munyed by sentence of right (ipse facto). Also a clerk ye which
knows carnally his concubine that is openly exco^munyed / for that yt he
departs not from the said concubyne is exco^munycate. Vt habetur extra de
sen. ex. ca. Si concubine. Also those the which makes fraccyo^ in a church /
or the which it brenneth ben excommunyed. Also those the which draws any
person vyolently out of the church the which thither was come^ for to waraunt
him ben exco^munyed. Also those the which gone against the lybertees of ye
church / or the which mak^th to keep oni customs against the said lyberte
ben exco^munyed. Also the rectours of the chyrches the which takes away such
customs against the said lyberte / and it may defend abate and do it not ben
excommunyed. Also the lords temporalles which constreyne any to sing the
things dyuynes in places interdyted / or the which dyffendeth that the
persons exco^munyed openly go not forth of the church when he that syngeth
mass them commands or makes to tell them ben exco^munycate. And those the
which be^ named exco^munyed if they go not out of ye church aggreueth them in
greter exco^munycacyon. Also those the which steleth the oblacyons from the
auter / some say yt they ben to be exco^munyed. Also those the which buryeth
in a chyrchyarde enterdited / or the which buryeth those yt ben exco^munyed
openly or inderdyted named by word express. Or those the which buryeth
usurers the which ben open and the which will not restore the vsuryes / such
people ben excommunyed. Also false makers of money the which falseth the king
coin of England / or those the which bears false money for to deceive other
ben exco^munycates in that deed. For to short this matter al persons the
which ben cursed and excommunyed shall be dampened and sent in to the fire and
tourment of hell if they so deye without absolucyon / correccyon / and amendeme^t
Thou art cursed and excommunyed I put the case / than thou shall be dampened
and sent in to the fire of hell if you correct the not. Vn^ athana. Qui mala
egeru^t ibu^t i^ igne^ eturnu^. vel sic. They shall be strongly cursed yt shall
have like sentence / punycion: and da^pnacion as the devil of hell. They the
which break the commandments of god shall have like sentence and punycion
as ye deuyls if they deye impenytentes. Than they shall be much accursed. Vn^
mat. xxv. Discedite a me maled: cti in igne^ eturnu^ qui paratus est dyabolo et
angelus eius. This sentence that god shall cast at the day of Judgment upon the
damned co^teyneth.vi. clauses. The first clause is understand by (discedite a
me) ye which is that god shall depart and shall send ye evil out of his
company / the which shall be unto them a terryble thing for to here For after
yt they shall be departed they shall be put from the vysyon of god / yt is yt
they shall never se him ne his saints. The second clause is to understand by
this word (maledicti) the which is yt god shall cast his great fulmynacyon /
exco^munycacion / and maledyccion upon the dampened. The third is understand
by this preposicion (in) the which god shall assygne / lodge / and put ye
sinners wtin the prysons of hell. The fourth clause is understand by this
word (ignem) the which is ye god shall put them in possession of a terryble
tourment that is the fire that shall brenne them for the ylles that they have
done. The.v. is understand by (eternu^) the which shall make the ill to
dyspayre / for after yt they ben entered in to hell they shall never go forth /
ne never have grace / mercy / help / socoures / ne comfort For in hell shall
be their bed / house / and dwelling. The.vi. is (qui paratus est diabolo et
angelis eius). That is yt the dampened shall be assocyate and assembled to be in
hell punysshed with the deuylles. Example of a cursed rich man that burnt in
the fire of hell.lxxxiiii. A. Other examples of people exco^munyed
Quere.lxxxix. f. g. h.

A. Of the punycyon eternal that those the which have broken the
commandments of god shall have. xlix.
DAuyd the prophet says in the psalter the words of god. Si iusticias meas
prophanaueri^t impii et mandata mea non custodierint vilitabo in virga
iniquitates eorum et in verberibus peccata eorum. If the cursed sinners has
taken in scorn my Justices and that they have not kept my commandments I
shall vesyte their inyquytees in a rod and in strykynge their sins.
Creatures reasonables we should obey to do that yt god wylleth and commands
for the love him the which is full of bounte infynyte / and of dread to have
punycyon and dampnacyon eternal. For it is a thing certain that every man yt
synneth mortally in brekynge one or many of the commandments of god by
delyberacyon. And if in such wise he deye impenytent / obstynate and arested
that he shall be put from paradyse and sent in to the fire and tourments of hell
without any remyssyon as is beforesayd. Thou have commyted theft or lechery / or
broken any co^mau^demente / I put the case and so thou deyest impenytent Than
thou shall be brought in to the fire of hell the which is a tourment much cruel
Vnde appo. xx. Qui non est inuentus i^ libro vite scriptus missus est in
stagnum ignis. He that is not found written in ye book of life is sent in to
the ponde of fire brennynge. And Athanaise in the psalm of qui cu^que. Qui
mala egeru^t ibunt in ignem eturnum. Those the which have done evil and
sin in their lives shall go in to the fire eternal if they deyen
impenytentes. Vn^ luce. xiii. Nisi penitenciam habueritis omnes simul
peribitis. None of us ne would be brent / ne broyled / ne cast in a fire
brennynge there for to dwell / and so to abide without ever going forth. And
it is a thing certain that all those and they ye which deye in mortal sin
impenytentes / obstynate and arested shall be sent in to the fire of hell by
the sentence before written. Ite maledicti in ignem eternum. And shall be
constrained there for to dwell and there to hold them will they or not. God
shall not spare them at the day of vengeance the prayers shall do nothing /
ne the wrath / ne the gold ne the silver / ne gifts / ne promysses. Vnde
prouerbio. vi. Zelus et furor viri non parcit dominus in die vindicte nec
acquiescet cuiusquam precibus nec suscipiet pro redemptione dona plurima. Also
he yt which has broken one of the commandments of god shall be dampened and
put from paradyse / for it as for many if he be deed impenytent without
correccion and amendment / for he has be transgressoure of ye law. And god
would that that the which he has broken were as well kept as all ye other.
Vnde iacobi. ii. Quicunque autem totam legem seruauerit offendat autem in vno
factum est omnium reus. Qui enim dicit. Non mechaberis / dixit et non occides:
quod si non mechaberis occides autem / factus es transgressor legis. etc. Also
he the which has broken the commandment of god shall feel terryble dolours
at his death in likewise as a man shall find in the examplary where it speaks
of the death of evil persons. And first. Example how ye devil drew the
soul from the body of a cursed rich man with an hoke. Quere in the examplary.
C.v. A.

B. A questyon. Who so should demand what is or shall be the fire of hell
where unto the said inobedyentes shall be al sent The answer is after the holy
scryptures that it does defer in many of manners unto that fire of this
present world here. Primo that of this present world does give clerenes ^
and that the which is of hell is black / obscure / and tenebrous the which
gives no light unto no consolacyo^. And by sometimes it casts light but it is
for to give more greter tourmentes / pain / dread / and desolacyon. Saint
Gregory says in his moralles. Hic flamma que succendet illuminat illic / ignis
qi cruciat obscurat. The flambe the which brenneth in this world gives light
/ and the fire that tourmenteth in hell waxes derke. Secundo the fire of this
world quenches / and it must be holden togyders with wood and with matters
combustybles to blow and to kyndle. And ye fire of hell is unto the contrary /
for evermore it dureth without quenchinge / without wood and without to be blown
ne to be kyndeled / and the matter combustible of the said fire of hell where it
takes and where it brenneth cruelly / yt is all sin / all ill / and
inobedyence. It is written Ysaie vlti^o. ca. and mar. ix. Quoth vermis eoru^
scilicet da^natoru^ non monetur / et ignis non extinguiter. That is to say The
remors of the conscience and the worm of the dampened deyeth not / and the fire
ne quenches nor gooth out / that is incessably it dureth and it holds in
estate / and evermore it brenneth. The gospel of saint mathewe says that god
shall send them in to ye fire of hell that is inextynguyble. Also it is written
Job. xx. Demorauit illu^ scilicet i^pium ignis qui non succenditur / super quod
ait gregorius. Gehenne ignis cu^ sit corporeus et in se missos reprobos
corporaliter exurat nec humano studio succe^ditur / nec lignis nutritur / sed
semel creatus duratinextinguibilis / nec ardore caret. The fire the which is
not light shall devour the cursed dampened Saint Gregory expounds this ye
which says. The fire of hell as it is of body and bre^neth corporally the
dampened sent in to it is not lyghted by study humanye / nor nourysshed by wood
/ but ones created inexty^guyble has not of indygence successively to be
holden togyders / and it is not without heet. Et math. iii. dicitur paleas.i.
peccatores co^buret igni inextinguibili. Tercio the fire of this world
co^sumeth / puts in to ashes makes to dye and to defayle. And that of hell
is unto the contrary / for though that it be much cruel / eygre / sharp /
and hot yet consumes it not / ne makes too defayle ne to deye the dampened.
