Saint Johan Crysostome de reparatione lapsi. Ignis iste qui in presenti vita
est consumit cuncra que recipit / ille vero quos suscipit semper cruciat et
pene sue semper integros reseruat. For the soul is immortal the which shall be
clothed with a body uncorruptyble and immortal at the resurreccyon of the
great Judgment / not unto the honor of life but to ye great langour of
tourme^t. The psalm. says. Sicut oues in inferno positi sunt / mors de pascet
eos. And sayni Gregory says how the dampened shall have death without dyenge /
end without endyng / defaute without defaylynge. The death evermore shall live
The end evermore shall begin. The defaute ne may defayle. And evermore in
dyenge they shall live / and in living they shall dye / and dye may they never.
Grego. Sit miseris sine morte / finis sine fine / defectus sine defectu / quia
mors semper viuit / finis semper incipit / et defectus deficere nescit. Quarto
the fire of hell is so brennynge ho to the regard of that in this world and
above it that our entendement ne may co^prehende and esteem it / the which
shall broyle the cursed dampened / not egally / but as every one of them has
of sin with him the which sin is matter combustyble whereof the said fire
holds as it said is / and in likewise as it shall be declared here
afterward. Quinto the fire of hell is stynkynge / and so is not that of this
present world. Examples. Primo how one of the dampened told unto saint
Machayre the gretenes of the fire of hell / and the dyfference of tourmentes of
them the which there do brenne. Quere.lvii. A. Another example of the cursed
Dyues ye brenneth in the fire of hell. Quere.lxxxiiii. a. Another example.C.vii.
A. Another example how a priest saw his mother that was dampened and tourmented
cruelly for arayenge and making gay atyre upon her heed / for shewy^ge her
breasts / for daunsynge / lepynges / and vnshamefull enbrasynges. Quere.lxxxx.c
Another example of a woman aduoutres damned and cruelly brenned and
tourmented.lxxxx. A. And the dampened endures will they or not ye said fire of
hell / so have they many tourmentes. They shall have with the said fire
derkenes / stynke / smoke / tempest / honger / thyrste / cold / and froste.
They shall have foulenes / horror / heaviness / weykenes / dread / and fere. They
shall have terreur of deuylles / serpents / and foul company whereof the soul
shall be enuyroned and set about. They shall have dyffame / shame reproach /
euilles innombrables without end They shall cry and bray / they shall deye
without deyenge. They shall have ire / dyscorde hate / cofusion / they shall
blaspheme and curse for the punycyon / they shall have seruytude dolor /
bytternes / desolacyon / they shall be sorry / enraged / out of wit / and
despayred. Also the said dampened shall never have peace for all euylles shall
run and war upon the^ They shall never have bounte / for they shall be cursed
and evil / they shall never have beauty / but ever hydeous / vylanous / black
/ and horrybles. They shall never have force ne virtue / but evermore weyke and
feeble / they shall never have love / but evermore shall be in hate / ne honor
but dishonor. They shall never have Joyous life / for they shall have death
without deyenge as it is said / ne light for they shall be in derkenes the^
shall never have lyberte to go ne to do they^ will / for they shall be at the
subgeccyon* obedyence of all euylles and aduersytees unto the which they must
obey will they or not. They shall never have suerte / but be in dread and fere
/ ne swetenes for they shall be in bytternesse / ne richesse but evermore in
pouerte. They shall never have health / but evermore sekenes / ne concord but
evermore discord / ne dysporte but evermore enoy ne wisdom but evermore folly
/ they shall never have swyftnesse / but always shall be weyghty and heavy / ne
subtylyte / but always evil subtylles. Also they shall be evermore passybles /
immortalles howbeit yt they desire death it flees fro them. Also they shall
never have paradyse / rest / glory / joy / gladness / but evil and
heaviness. Who so should speak of every of the euylles yt they shall have in
pertyculer as the scryptures determyneth it should be to long a thing to
write And therefore this suffyseth of things thee be spoken in general.

C. Here follows a questyo^ for to understand if those the which commytteth
in this world many sins in dyspysynge ye commandments of god if they shall
have punycyo^ eternal in hell for each of those sins / by such wise yt if
they deye imponytentes without contrycyon ne confession. The scripture gives the
answer yt says Quoth nullum malu^ remanebit ipunitu^. Et legit. i. ad co. iii.
Vnusqque au^t propria^ mercedem accipiet scdm suu^ labore^. And ye psalmist
says. Vureddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua. Whereby it follows yt all sin
shall be punysshed. And for to dyscerne of the punycyon how great it shall be it
passes our wit but god in whom all the treasour of science and sapyence
rests and that is full of bounte infynyte ye which is Just and the fou^tayne
of all Justice the which sees and knows the hertes and operacyons of every
one and in what intencyon they ben made shall yield unto every man after his
labor be it in well or in ill. That is to say. that in such measure yt any
has sinned that is to commytte of great sins and of great nombre and taken
delectacyon and is long time in such measure he shall be punysshed without that
he fail any thing. Vn^ luce. vi. Eade^ mensura qua messi fueritis remitietur
vobis. Vbi dicit basil. Qua mensura vnusquisque peccat aut bn^ agit / eade^
premia aut penam sumet. Example a man yt has done an hundred sins shall
feel an hundred times more great pain than he that has done but one. Vn^
deuteronomy. xxv. Pro me^sura peccati erit et plagaru^ modus. After the measure and
quantyte of the sin shall be the manner of ye wounds. Also of as more as the
sin shall be done in the greter degrees of persons they shall be the more
grievously punysshed. Vn^ Ihero. In maio u gradi / mayor sieve dubio pena. As he
that is married or priest synneth more in co^mittynge lechery than other
persons. Also of as much more as they have taking more greter delectacyon /
or that they shall gloryfye them in their sins and vanytees / or of as much
more that they therein have be^ more longly / of as much more shall they have
in hell more great pain and tourmentes. Vn^ appoc. xvii.. Qua^tum glorificauit
se scilicet peccator in peto^ and in deliciis fuit i^ diurnitate tm^ date illi
torme^tum and luctu^. Also of as much more as they have sought new
delectacyons not accustomed of as much shall they be tourmented. Vn^ job. xx
Iuxta multitudine^ adiuentionu^ suarum sic et sustinebit. Also those members ye
which has most habounded in sin most shall habounde in tourmentes as
says ye scripture. Vn^ Isodorus. In membro quo quis amplius peccauit / in
illo amplius tormenta patietur. Et ber. dicit. In quo me^bro creator plus
offendit / in eode^ peccator grauius pumetur. And every man shall be punysshed
(per pena^ talionis) for his offense to the end that he there have evermore
reemors in his conscience that he endures so much evil by his own
operacyon. Vnde sapi. xi. 'Per que peccat quis / per hec et torquetur. And in
the person in whom there is most of sins and of cursednesses ye fire of
hell most terrybly shall take and cruelly shall bren^e and tourment. For as
it is said the matter combustyble of the fire of hell / and wherefore it is
create: and where it takes for to do ill / that is for to brenne sin and
the person yt it commytteth. Also we se by experyence that the fire of this
world is more great and sharper where as is most of fagottes and of matters
combustybles. In likewise is it of the said fire of hell where there is most of
sins and great sharpenes of fire / wherefore the great sinners ben more burnt
and tourmented than they in whom there is less of sins. And if saint Peter
were within the fire of hell even by Lucyfer he should have none harm / for in
him there is no matter combustible / yt is no syn^e And therefore if any person
were all assured and certain too be dampened yet should he cease to do ill and
sin / and should do the most of good deeds that he might to the end that he
have the less of pain in the tourmentes of hell. He the which thathe no
moo but one sore / botche / or sickness has not to suffer so much of pain
and anguysshe as he the which has on him x. or.xx.

D. A questyon. What dyfference is there between the fire of helland that of
purgatory / and of the souls the which there ben burnt / broyled and cruelly
tourmented. The answer after some scryptures is in this manner of wise. The
said fire is egally hot ye one as ye other / but it has a dyfference in as
much as the one is eternal and the other is but for a time. And they yt ben
in purgatory go in to paradyse after yt their penance is ended / but they of
hell go not out of the said fire. And wherefore abide they and the other gone
forth. The reason is such yt those that been in purgatory has gotten grace or
they departed fro this world / and have taken away ye culpe or gylt of sin
by contrycyon and confession / and for that they have not done the pain yt
they have deserved after penance thider they go to do it in the said fire of
purgatory. And when they ben wtin it ye fire takes and begins to brenne the
delectacyon and spot of sin the which is his matter combustyble as it is said
/ and never shall cease to bren^e and to broyle till yt it find no more matter
of sin. As a man may se how the fire of this world well kyndled brenneth ye
wood and all the matter combustyble that unto it is admynystred till yt the matter
be consumed and brent and yt al be purged. And when the said fire of purgatory
has consumed and purged all the matter of sin the person is delivered / and
so gooth in to paradyse pure and clean. And it is to be noted that it behooves
to pass through the fire / and that the fire shall prove what the operacyon of
every man is. And if the operacyon yt he has edyfyed abide without brennynge /
he shall have reward. And if the operacyon that he has edyfyed brenne he shall
suffer tourme^t He shall be saved also as the fire. Vn^. pau. i. ad cori^. ii.
Vnusqsque opus quale sit ignis probabit / si cuius opus manserit quod
superedificauit mercede^ accipiet: si cuius opus arserit detrimentu^ patietur:
ipse aute^ saluus erit sic tamen quasi per ignem. The dampened ben unto the
contrary of them of purgatory. for when they deye they ben impenytentes /
obstynate / and abides in their sins / and bears them with them without
taking away the gylte of the said sins by co^trycyon and penance ne without
getynge any grace ne mercy whiles that they lived in this world and that they
have the time and the place for to do it. And for as much as the soul is
eternal and immortal the which shall be sent unto the fire eternal / and
that it shall have with it evermore sin that the said fire shall brenne. In
likewise ye soul evermore shall suffer pain / and evermore shall brenne with
ye said sin the which never shall have mercy. By these things the which
ben written in this book it appears that we should love god chyldely and
perfytely more than al things for ye great good Infynyte the which is in him
/ and to love our neighbor as our self in god / and for the love of him.
Morouer it appears that we should do and accomplysshe the commandments of
god for to escape ye tourmentes of hell / and to the end to possede the Joys of
paradyse. Unto the which we may go and us to enjoy cum illo qui est
benedictus in secula seculorum. Amen.

Here is the end of the book the which is called the flower of the
commandments of god.
Here begins the exemplayre of the commandments of god. ii.
Almighty god the fader / the sone and the holy ghost / the which is but one
only god in trynyte / pleases it hy^ to enlumyne the hearts and thoughts of
all those the which shall study this book the which is called the exemplayre
of the commandments of god / for it is all of examples. The which examples
has be extracted and gadered in many books / in likewise as bears wytnes
every example. And has be transmuted and changed first from laten in to
Frensshe / and from Frensshe now lately in to English tongue. To the end that
ye simple people the which know no laten them may understand. And if any
say that there are of examples ye which ne ben holy scryptures I confess it
well. But I say that they ben vysyons or miracles that some persons credybles
has seen ryally / or known by experyence the which has be put in writing.
For asmoche as they have consonance to approve the holy scryptures. etc. And
for that that many examples ben put in the book of the dyscyple it is not for
to alegge it as holy person / or holy scripture / but for that / that it was
a great clerk the which found the said examples in books the which we
have not studied. etc.

Obedientia.
A. Examples of those the which has obeyed to the will of god and of their
superyours. And first example how Abraham was obedyent unto god. Ca. li.
IT is written in the.xvii. chapter of gene. how Abraham was obedyent unto god
when he hy^ commanded the cyrcumsycion the which was a thing much hard and
cruel. Also he was obedyente when god said unto him that he should leave his
friends and his country. Egredere deterra tua et de cognatione tua. etc For
his obedyence god appeared unto him in an evening and said unto him. It is I
that has made the heaven and ye earth etc. I am appeared unto the for that /
that you dredest my name. And therefore I shall give the benedyccyon and unto thy
lynce Again god said unto him. Behold the earth on the one side and on the
other. I shall give the all the countrees that thou beholdest unto the and unto
thy lygnee. / More over god said unto him. Behold ye sterres of the sky and
nombre them. Than Abraham said that there were so many that he ne might nombre
them. And god said unto him. In like wise shall be thy sede upon the earth. Of
the and of thy wife shall come forth a sone the which shall have my
benedyccyon and those of his lygnee. Abraham and his wife Sarra were ancient /
yt wend little to have had lygnee because of their aege. After that the said
Abraham had a sone named ysaac the which he loved so much that he nese him
half / for that that he had but him legytyme / and for that that he had him in
his aege. Also for that that god unto him had promised benedyccyon. More over
for that that he was of great beauty and full of bou^te. Also it is written in
the.xvii. chapter of genese how god would assaye Abraham and he appeared unto
him and said unto him. Abraham thou ne may have no mo children I have given
ye one the which thou love much. I will that thou go in to a mountain yt I
shall show the and that thou make unto me sacrefyce of thy sone. The manner to
make sacrefyce in that time there was that they had a lamb or a got and did
cut his throat and burnt him / the which thing was commanded unto Abraham.
Than Abraham would obey unto god albeit that in his heart he was right pyteous
to slay his sone for the love that he had unto him And he took him and his
ass and two of his servants and so yede unto the said place that god unto
him had commanded How be it that they had the space of three days Journey to
walk. When they came unto the foot of the said mountain / the said Abraham
left his ass and his two servants and yede he and his sone. And took a
burden of wodde / a sword and of fire. And in going up the said mountain
Ysaac demanded of his fader where the said sacrefyce was. He answered yt god
should provide. And when they were at the place Abraham said unto his sone in
weeping that god him had commanded that he should make sacrefyce of him Than
the sone the which was good and benyngne answered in willing to obey unto
god and unto his said fader. My sweet and amiable fader it is reason that I
submytte me and obey unto you / and that the will of god be accomplysshed: /
Than they began for to wepree. And Ysaac said unto his fader. Alas my fader
wherefore had ye not told me / to the end that I had said farewell my mother. I
pray you my fader yt ye reco^maunde me unto her / And also I pray you that ye
bind me / for that yt I am young and strong and yt ye be ancient and feeble /
to the end yt wha^ ye shall come for to sleeme that I ne do unto you thing the
which is not good. / Than Abraham with great teres bound his hands. And
left him on hye upon the fagotte of byllettes / and drew his sword for to
stryke of his heed. And when he had lift up his stroke for to stryke ye
angel cried and said. Abraham / abraham stryke not thy child / now god
knows that thou dredest him. And Abraham cast his syghte aside and saw a
lamb by hy^ among the thorns the which was teyde by the horns in the said
thorns. He thanked god with great joy. etc. And took the said lamb and made
sacrefice in steed of his sone / in like wise as it is written in gene.xxii. ca.
This example ought to move us for to obey unto god and unto fader / and unto
mother. If Abraham were obedyent unto so cruel a commandment as to slay his
child / by more strong reason we should obey unto things the which ben
light to do. etc. Obedyence is certain life and way for to go unto life
eternell And also as Adam was forclosed from ye realm of paradyse by inobence.
In like wise Abraham has had beatytude and life eternell by obedyence. Also
obedyence is the laddre by the which men mouu^t on hye in to paradyse / in
like wise as men may se by figure. For it is written how Jacob saw in his
sleep a laddre the which touched the heaven with the one end / by the which
the aungelles ascended and dyscended and Ihesus was there intremedled. Vnde
gene.xxviii. Jacob v^dit in so^nis scalam stantem super terram atm cacumen
illius tangens celum: angelos quo que dei ascendentes et descendentes per ea^
et dominus innixum scale dicentem sibi ego sum deus Abraham. etc. This laddre
is obedyence. For without obeynge unto the commandments of god a man ne
may mount in to paradyse as says ye gospel. Vnde mathei.xix. Si vis ad
vita^ ingredi serua mandata. That is to say / Yt thou will enter in to life
eternell keep the commandments of our lord Ihesu christ. The staves of this
laddre ben ye ten commandments / unto the which a man should obey redely
without dylacyon devoutly without dysdeyne / wyllyngly without contradyccyon /
ioyously without heaviness / virtuously without feebleness ne weykenes /
perseuerauntly without ceasynge ne ennoye. Also obedyence is ye keye the
which opens paradise / and inobedience is that that shytteth it. Saint poule
says of those the which ne will obey. Illud ad thessal.iii. Si quis non
obedierit verbo nostro per epistolam hunc notate et ne commiseamini cum eo vt
confundatur. That is to say. If there be any that will not obey unto our word
by epystyll note ye him / and acompany ye not with him / to the end that he be
confounded / For to be short / obedyence is requysyte of necessyte of health.
And therefore it is in such wise dyffynyed after master Hyonde foliot.
Obedientia est salus omnium fidelium genitrix omnium virtutum: inue^trix regni
celorum: virtus celos aperiens et hominem in de eleuans cohabitatrix angelorum:
cibus omnium sanctorum ex hac enim letati sunt: et per hanc ad perfectionem
venerunt. The which is as much for to say. Obedyence is the health of all
those that be faithful / the engendresse of all virtues / the fynderesse of
the realm of heuens / the virtue opening ye heuens lyftynge up man from the
earth / the dweller or nere enhabytaunt of aungelles / the vyande of all
saints / by her they ben given souke / and by her they ben come unto
perfeccyon. Without obedyence no man may have salvation nor escape
dampnacyon. And therefore if thou will have of good and not to have none ylle /
it behooves that thou be obedient unto the commandments of god and of the
superyoures in things the which ben after god and good maneres as was Abraham
and as has be the saints of paradyse.

B. Another example of a monk ye which cast his sone in to a brennynge oven
by obedyence / yet was he not brende. li.
IT is written in the life of faders how a seculer man renounced ye world and
made him a monk And afterward by leave he yede to seche a little sone that he
had left in a cite / and bare him unto the monastery. And the abbot took him
between his arms and kyssed him. After said unto his fader. Love thou this
child (he answered ye) After the abbot demanded loueste thou him. And the
fader yet answered him ye. After the abbot said unto hy^ If thou love him take
him and cast him in to this brennynge fire. At ye hour they were at the oven
where men make bread. and ye oven was enbrased with fire / and the fader cast
him within the oven. And incontinent ye said oven was in like wise as it had
be roused with water and ye fire ne did no hurt unto the child. In that deed
he gate glory in that time / as did Abraham the preatryarke by the great
faith that he had in god and obedyence unto his abbot.

C. Another example of the obedyence of Noe. li.
IT is written the.vii. chapter of genese that Noe was obedyent unto god in all
things that he him commanded. Facit noe omnia que mandauerat ei dn^s. And for
yt that he was a good man Just and obedyent he ne was taken in the deluge with
the ylle. For god him commanded that he should make an arche in ye which he
should enter himself / his wife / his three sons / and their wives. And they
were saved and preserved from the great haboundaunce of waters the which
drowned all the world.

D. Another example of the obedyence of Joseph. li.
YT is written in the.xxxvii. chapter of genese how Ioyeth was prepared to
obey unto his fader when he would send him unto his brederne the which kest
him in to an old cysterne and sold him unto strange people. In the end and
conclusyon for yt that he was a good man Just and chaste not willing to
committee lecherye with the wife of Pharaon the which required him and that he
was obedyent unto god and unto his said fader he had domynacion above his
brederne. Albeit yt he was the youngest.

E. Another example of the obedyence of young Thobie. li.
IT is written in the.v. chapitre of the book of Thobye that after yt the young
Thobye had be well instruct of his fader that he ne should committee mortal
sin / and that in his life he should do many almesdedes and good operacyons /
and more over that he him had commanded that he should go in to a place far
from his worldly besynesses. The good child answerde illud thobie. v.c. Oi^a
quecu^que precepisti pater faciam. That is to say fader I shall do all things
that thou co^maundest me By his obedyence the angel was assocyate with him /
and led him unto the place where his fader had sent him and after brought
him again without having any ylle.

A. Another example of matathias. lii
IT is written in the.ii. cha. of ye first of Machabees that a man of ye lygnee
of Israhell named Matathias was so obedyent unto god in keeping ye law of his
faders that the messagers of ye king of Anthyoche ne might make him to do
sacrefyce unto the ydolles and to leave his law. Unto the which messengers he
answered. Et si oe^s ge^res regi anthioco obediu^t and disceda^t vnusqsque a
seruitute legis patru^ suoru^ and co^sentia^t ma^datis eius: ego et filii mei
and fratres met obediemus legi patru^ nostroru^. That is to say if the people
of Anthyoche leave ye law of their faders to obey unto the king / yet I my
sons and my brederne shall obey unto the law of our faders. This matathias
was so wroth to se the people err and goo against the law of god yt he slew
the messenger of ye king of Anthyoche as he constrained the people to do
sacrefyce / and did cast horrybly a Jew upon the altar as he sacryfyced.
Afterward dystroyed the ydoles and fled he and his children in to the
mountains and called with them all those yt had zele of the law and
persecuted the sinners / This matathias the which loved god and obeyed unto
his commandment more sooner than unto the commandment of a te^porall king
he is to love / to praise / and to love. For a man should keep the law and
the commandments of god as it is said and to persecute the sins / and
those the which them commytte.

B. Another example of the obedyence of our lord Ihesus and of his
appostylles. Capitulo. lii.
IT is written in the.ii. chapitre of ye gospelles of saint luke that our lord
Ihesus was cyrcumcysed and would be presented in the temple with oblacyons in
showing yt he would obey unto ye law / And when he had.xxii. years it is
written that he was submytte and obeyssaunt unto the parents. Vn^luce.ii. Erat
subditis illis. Also it is written yt he was obedyente unto god till unto the
death for us. Vn^ pa. ad phi. ii. Xpres factus e^ pro nobis obediens deo patri
vsque ad morte^: morte^ au^t crucis And of the appostles it is written yt
incontinent yt our lord them called they were obedyent and yode after him.
Vnde mat. ix and.iiii. Relictis oibus secutisu^t eu^. Also wha^ the appostylles
were reproved of ye princes of ye priests yt they ne kept their
commandment. they answered illud actuu^. iiii. Obedire oportet ded magis quam
hoi^bus That is to say that it behooves to obey unto god more sooner than
unto the will of princes / in like wise should we do and we shall have paradyse.

C. Another example of the obedyence of saint Mor. lii.
IT is written in the legende of saint Mor how saint benoyst knew in spyryte
yt the water of a river bare away a child yt was fallen in it / he called one
of his dyscyples named Mor and commanded him to run after ye child / which
was obedyente and yode above the water after it He found him and brought him
by the here hole and sound. And when he was out of the water he looked behind
him / he meruaylled and apperceyued ye miracle that he granted unto the
merytes of his master And saint benoist said that it was by the obedyence of
saint Mor.

D. Another example of a relygyous the which bound a lion. lii
IT is written in the life of faders yt an abbot commanded his relygyous y he
should go seche him a lion the which was a much cruel be / he theder yode
by obedyence / he found him / and bound hy^ and led him unto ye said abbot
as a man would have do a simple and sweet be / When he ran after him and
that he had said unto him. Mine abbot has commanded me yt I should bind yt
and bring yt unto him. When the said abbot saw the beast would humble him
unto his relygyous said unto him. Baneur unbind hy^ wherefore have you brought
him. In this deed here all relygyous may know that it is a great thing of ye
virtue of obedyence Also it is to be noted that ye good abbot ne praised his
relygyous of dread of vayn glory / but blamed him for to meke him.

E. Another example of a relygyous the which watered a dry busshe. lii.
Written it is in the life of faders how an abbot set a dry busshe and
commanded unto his relygyous yt he should water it every day till that it bare
fruit. And yt he should go seche of water in such a fou^tayne ye which was so
far of that when he parted in the morning: it was night when he came again.
The said relygyous was obedient unto his abbot / and watered it by the space of
three year every day. And by his obedyence ye logge waxed grene and bare fruit
/ was given to the freres saying yt they should ete of the fruit of obedyence.
By this example it behooves to understand yt it is a great thing of the
virtue of obedyence sith yt a dry logge bare fruit. For it is a thing
contrary unto nature.

F. Another example of a religious writer
IT is written in the life of faders yt an abbot had a dyscyple named marc yt
he loved for his obedyence / he had of other dyscyples yt were sorry yt the
abbot loved better marc than them. After yt these other au^cyentes herd this
thing they came unto him to show how the freres yt were with him were sorry /
and before yt he unto them confessed any thing led him into the chambres of
every of them and called the^ by their propre names / and said unto them
brederne come ye forth / for I have to be besy with you / and none of them ne
would come out forth. After they yode unto ye door of marc and incontynente yt
the abbot had stryken and called him by his propre name he came forth without
taryeng and the abbot entered and demanded what he made / and he said yt he
wrote / and had left his lettre imparfayte when he herd him call. And the
other auncyentes said unto him. Truly we love him in the thing yt thou
loueste him / and also god loves him for his obedyence. This example denotes
yt all good relygyous should obey unto their prelates redely without heaviness /
or dilacyon / they shall have praysyng before god and ye world.

G. Another example how obedyence proceeds the other virtues in heaven.
IT is written in ye life of faders how four brederne came unto ye abbot pambo
with robes of skins / and every of the^ showed ye virtue yt one of the other in
the abscence of him of the which men spoke and the one of them fasted much /
the other ne posseded nothing / the third had great charity. Of the.iiii.
they said yt he had be xxii. years in great obedyence. The abbot pambo answered
them. I say you yt the virtue of this here yt has had obedyence is more
great than the other. For every of you has retained his propre will with the
virtue the which possedeth / and this here renounceth unto his propre will and
makes himself servant of a strange will. Unto a relygyous it apperteyneth
great reward / for at every hour his will is broken. When he is laid in his
bed and well at ease / also it behooves yt he arise to go to matynes by
obedyence / and that his will be broke. And also of ye mass and of other
hours him behooves to leave all other wylles for to go theder. And also these
relygyous may not go in no place without license / of the prelate / for they
ben dyspoylled of their propre wills so yt they ne have. neque velle: neque
nolie And therefore they ne may leave more great thing than their propre wylles.
etc. Also it appears yt unto a good religious obedyence it apperteyneth to
have great reward in paradyse. The which reward unto them is kept after
the death. Of the which speaks saint poule in his epistle ad co. quam oculos
no^ vidit: nec auris audiuit: nec i^ cor hoi^s asce^dit q^ preperauit deus
diligentibus se.

H. Another example how relygyous obedience have great reward in paradise.
IT is written in the life of faders yt how a holy fader saw in heaven. iiii
ordres of people. The first was of seek me^ which yield thanks unto god in
their sekenes. The second was of men hospytalers yt lodged the poor and
mynystred unto them their necessites. The third order of people were
solytayres yt lived without seeing any person. The.iiii. order was of people
submytte to obey unto the people spyrytuell for the love of god. This.iiii.
order yt was obeyssaunce had in heaven more great merit and reward than ye
other. For these obedyentes have crown and ceptre of gold. And ye holy fader
ye which saw these said things demanded of him that showed them unto him.
How has this order more great reward ye which me seems to be more little
than the other. He answerde those yt ben hospytalers live after their propre
will / in like wise those ye ben hermites solitayre they live in ye world of
their propre will / but they yt ben in obedyence take away their own wylles yt
depend unto god and unto ye commandment of ye fader spyrytuel / and therefore
they have more great glory than these other / and therefore obedyence is good
when it is done for the love of god.

I. Another example of a religyous obedyent and of an abstynent. lii.
IT is written in the life of faders / how two brethren carnalles came to
dwell in a monastery. The one was of right clear contynence and the other of
great obedyence. When the fader of the monastery said unto the obedyent / do
this thing / he did it / do that there / he obeyde / ete in the morning / he
ete / upon this thing he had great opinion. And his brother contynent was
punysshed for the envy that he had ayenste his brother / the which thought
unto him that he should prove him for to understand if he were obedyent / and
he came unto the fader of the monastery and said unto him. Send my brother with
me for to go by ye country. The abbot suffered them to go. And ye friar
contynent would prove him. When they came unto a great water wherein there was
of terryble beestes the which ben called cocodrylles / he said. Go down into
the water and pass. And incontynente he dyscended / and the said beestes came
unto him the which did him none ill / but they licked his body. And when his
brother saw it he bad him come out of the water And as they yede they found a
body deed in the way / and the abstynent said. If we had any thing to cast
upon this body / and the obedyent said let us more sooner pray unto god and
parauenture he shall arise / and as they were in orayson ye said deed body
arose / and the brother abstynent gloryfyed himself and said yt by his
abstynence the deed body was raised. God showed al unto the fader of the
monastery. And how he tempted his brother of ye beestes. And how the deed man
was raised. When they were come again unto the monastery ye abbot said unto ye
abstynent. Wherefore have you done so unto thy brother. Know you that by his
obedyence the deed body has be raised.

A. Another example of an abbot ye which called his relygyous deed ye which
came again and was obedyent and spoke of the Joys of paradyse.
THe disciple reherceth in his sermon yt the which is written in libro cesaru
and says yt there was a relygyous named menigotm a man simple and good / that
was so seek yt he had the sacrament of vnccyon. And in yt time as ye abbot
would depart to go unto the chapter general he said unto him. Brother you
shalt deye but tarry at thy departing till I come agay^ He answered. If I may
I shall do it / and the abbot commanded him to do it. The abbot yede unto ye
chapter and tarried long / he comen again being at ye gate ye belles range.
He demanded the cave of ye ryngynge. It is for menygotm yt is departed / The
abbot said I should have spoke with him. Than he hasted him and found him deed
/ and cried unto him. My brother menygotz. He ne had in hy^ voice ne wit /
and secondly he repeted his name / and the pryour badde him torment him no
more. The abbot said in his eere. I commanded ye not to deye till I came
again. And yet said / I command the yt thou answer me. And in wayllynge
opened his eyes as if he awoke from sleep and said. O fader what have you do /
wherefore have thou called me again / The abbot said where was you. I was in
paradyse in a syege of gold nere ye fete of our lady and as you caldest me
again Ysambart our secretayn drew me from ye sege and said unto me. Thou
shall not be here thou art hither comen inobedyently / return to thine abbot
/ so am I come agay^ And how be it / it is promised me that yt syege and place
is kept for me where I have seen the secretayn in great Joy.

B. Another example how a serpent was obedyent to a friar iardiner. Also of
theft And to do good unto his enemies. liii.
Saint Gregorye says in the book of his dyalogue that there was a monk
gardyner in a monasterye of good life. And a thief had of custom to stele of
herbs of the garden and lepte upon a hedge. For the said monk planted many
herbs and he found but little. And some were fouled and the other broken / he
yede about the said garden and found whereby the thief passed / as he walked
he found a serpente unto whom he commanded and said. Follow me. He yode
after him. And when he was in the place whereby the thief passed / he commanded
unto the serpent in the name of Ihesus that he should keep the enter / and that
he ne should suffer ye thief to enter. The serpente abode ouerthwarte the way.
And the monk returned unto his monasterye. When it came unto the time of the
myddaye that ye brederen had of custom for to rest / yt thief came as he
had accustomed and lept upon the hedge. And as he set his foot in the
garden he saw suddenly that the serpente closed the way / and in trembling
drew back his fore so it took through ye hedge and he abode hanged bakwarde
in the said hedge till that ye gardyner came And when he was in such wise
found he said unto the serpent. Thou haste accomplysshed my commandment / go
thy ways now. And forthwith the serpent departed. And he came unto the thief
and said unto him / how is this brother god has given the in to my hands /
wherefore have thou presumed to do so many of times theft unto the labor of
monks. Than took he the foot from the hedge and said unto him. Come thou after
me in to the garden. And he gave unto him these herbs that he had appetyted
to stele with great Joy. And said unto him. Goo and do thou no more theft /
and that thing yt thou shall appetyte come unto me and I shall give it the
without that that thou take it in co^myttynge sin. In this example two
things be to be noted. The first is that sith a serpent was obedyent unto the
said relygyous / by more great reason we the which ben reosonable should obey
unto our superyoures. The second thing is that sith that the said relygyous
gave of herbs unto the said thief the which did unto him ill. It is to
understand that we should do the good again the ylle unto our enemies. etc.

C. Another example of him the which commanded unto two dragons yt they
should keep the door of his house. liiii.
IT is written in ye life of the faders that a holy fader dwelled in an
hermytage and the thieves came often unto him the which ete his bread and his
substance whereof he lived. After that ye said fader had much endured of the
said thieves he yode in to the feldes and found two dragons the which he led
with him to whom he commanded in the name of our lord Ihesu christ that they
should keep them still at his door / and that they should keep the enter
against ye forsaid theuis When the thieves came as they had of custom and
that they found the said dragons the which kept the enter they had right
great dread and fell down as deed to ye earth without speech When the ancient
apperceyued it he came unto them and found them as half deed. And he lift
them up and blamed in saying. Look you and behold that ye are more hard than
these beestes here / they obey unto us for the love of god / and ye ne dread
god and also ye have no shame of the servant of god. Allbeit the said fader
made them enter in to the monasterye and set them at the table / and commanded
them that they should ete. Than they repented them did penance and converted
them unto god and so much they prouffyted by penance that in short time
after they did miracles.

D. Another example how the water o^f a flode obeyed unto a bishop. Ca. liii.
IT is written in the book of ye dialogue of saint Gregorye how a flode or a
streme ran nere unto the walls of a cite and by the dysriuasyons ye water
made his course to shede through the field and took ye that it found sown and
set. After that ye water had done of great ylles and that the necessyte
constrained the people of god / ye men began to study by great labors to make
torn the said dysriuasio^s by other places / but they ne might. Albeit that
there they labored longly. Than the bishop yt was a devout man made a little
rake afterward put him in orayson and came unto the last end of the streme
and commanded unto the water that it should follow him by the places that he
should show it and he drew the rake above upon ye earth The which water left
hastily his propre course. And all the water followed him till that it left the
place accustomed. And made his course where ye said bishop drew his rake. And
more over the said water ne hurted more that the which was sown and planted.
Sins that the water obeyde unto the said bishop wherefore shall not thou obey
unto god and unto thy supery dures. Cesse thou of doing ill as ye said water
and obey unto god and unto his commandments or thou ne shalt be saved / so
says the gospel. mathei. xix. Sivis ad vitam ingredi serua mandata. etc.

E. Another example how the fire yt which burnt a house was obedient unto a
freer the which prayed god. Ca. lii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows that the dyscyple recites in
his prompt^arye and says how a devout friar precher and lectour was one time
in a house of a knight of England and the fire took suddenly in the house
where they souped / the water to fayll and all the counsayll humayne. And as
the fire grew more and more the compaignon ran and cried with the household.
And the said relygyous fell prostrate in orayso^ and chased the fire in such
manner yt there abode none apperceuaunce / the said frerene lift himself up
in vaynglorye ne yet told it unto no person / but wrote it unto the master
of the order of prechers unto the edyfycacyon of other.

F. Another example how the rain touched not unto two freres prechers in wall
king on their way. Ca. liii.
IT is written in some books this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his promptuarye and says ye two freres of the order of prechers were sent
by obedyence unto a convert and as they accomplysshed Ioyously ye said
obedyence it befell that great impetuosyte of rain began to sourde / the
which fered them gretely. And they began to say the one unto the other.
Parauenture god has not agreeable our obedyence. And wha^ they see no place
where they might hyde them / the one thought on a miracle that god did unto
saint domynyke in taking away the rain from above him and above his
compaygnon. And he was moved in hope and put him in orayson / he made the token
of the cross again the tempeste and impetuosyte ye which came unto them /
and forthwith the water of the rain divided it on the right hand and on the
left hand and suffered that they ye de without being wete so that there ne
fell one drop of water upon them / albeit that they saw on the one part
and on the other fall rain. By these examples before said and many other the
which tarry because of shortenes / it appears that for to obey unto god and
unto our superyoures a man does miracles. A man geteth also the love of god /
paradyse and Joy eternel. And unto the contrary by inobedyence a man byndeth
unto punycyon and dampnacyon. Also a man leseth al goods and purchases all
ill. In like wise as men shall here herafter. etc.

G. Of the obedyence of a relygyous named Pol: iiii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt there was a man simple named pol among
the dyscyples of saint Anthonye The beginning of his conuersyon was that he
saw a rybaulde lyenge upon his wife / than he was sorry in heart departed from
his house and yede unto the monasterye of saint Anthonye and demanded to speak
with him / when saint Anthony understood yt he asked the way of health he
considered that he was a simple man of nature and answered him that he might
be saved if he obeyed unto the things the which should be spoken unto him And
the said Pol said unto him that he would do all things that he should
commau^de him. And to the entente saint anthony might prouue if he would
accomplysshe his promesses said unto him. Hold the here before this gate and
pray unto god till that I come again unto the. And he entered in to his
chamber / and pol abode in the place and was so obedyente that he yode not
forth all the day and the night from the said place / where he prayed god. And
saint Anthony beheld him often by a wyndowe secretly / the which knew that
he remeued not / ne in the hete of the day / ne at the dewynge of ye night and
held him without mouynge in orayson as it is said. The other day after saint
Anthony yede for the and taught him of every thing how he should live. And
among other things he commanded him that he should take his refeccyon at the
even tide / and that he should take heed yt he ne took so much whereby he
might be full fed / Pryncypally in drink and affermed that the fantasyes of
the soul were made never less for to drink haboundaunce of water / than of
hot wine. And after that saint Anthony had well enstructed him and largely of
every thing. And commanded how he should live / he builded a little habytacle
three mile from him where he dwelled. And saint Anthony vysyted him often and
enjoyed him for that yt he found him accomplysshynge tho things the which
had be taught unto him and commanded. Also of the obedyence of the said Pol It
befell that many freres parfyte men came unto saint Anthony with whom came the
said poule. And as they drew many things parfounde and spoke of prophets and
of the savior. Pol them axed by symplenes of courage if Ihesu christ were
first or the prophets. When saint Anthony had understand the folysshe
questyon / he had shame and by sweet words said unto him. Hold thy peace and
goo thy way. And incontynente Pol parted / and yede unto his little chamber
and kept scylence: In like wise as if he had be commanded from heaven so that
word he ne spoke in the world. When saint anthony had apperceyued that in no
wise he ne spoke / he commanded him to tell the cause wherefore he kept
scylence. Pol answerde. Thou saydest unto me that I should go my way and hold
my peace. Than saint Anthony meruayled him that he kept ye said word that he
had brought forth neclygently. And said. This here us condamneth all / we have
not accomplysshed thoo things the which ben commanded us from heaven / and
this here keeps every word the which proceeds from our mouth Afterward
saint Anthony commanded him of things the which were without cause and
rayson to the end that his obedyence were proved and said unto him. draw of the
water of this well and cease not to cast it about all this day upon the earth
and he was obedyent. Also he him commanded that he should undo all the rods
of a basket and afterward that he should tie them togyders and make them
again / he was obedyent. Also he him commanded that he should cloute or
patche his vestyment / and afterward that he should vncloute it and cloute it
again. These things here ben again reason commanded the which pol ne
agaynsayd. And shortly he came unto perfeccyon. At the example of pol saint
Anthony taught that if any would come hastily unto perfeccyon / that he should
be master of himself. And that he ne obeyde unto his propre wylles / albeit
that the thing seemed unto him to be good and just so that he keep the
commandment of the savior the which is that before all things every man
also should deny unto himself and renounce unto his propre wylles. Vt ante
omnia vnusquisque abneger semetipsum sibi: et reemmiciet propriis voluntatibus.
The blyssed savior did this thing in like wise as it is written in the
gospel. Ego veni non vt faciam voluntatem meam: sed eius qmisit me. And in
like wise should we do for to come unto perfeccyon. etc.

H. Of the obedyence of a man ye which bare of the flesh al naked upon his
body Capitulo. liii.
IT is written in the life of the faders how saint Anthony would prouue a man ye
which demanded to enter in to religyon. Unto whom he said that he should go
to bye of flesh in such a market / and yt he should bring it unto him all
naked / ye which was obedyent. And as he bare in such wise the said flesh /
the birds came from ye sky unto him the which rent and brake all his body /
and he bare the said flesh unto saint Anthony as he had commanded him unto
whom he told ye case. And saint Anthony said unto him Those the which
renou^ceth unto ye world ben in such wise punysshed and assailed / but they
should be ferme and constant in the faith of god for to resyste against them.
etc. By this yt Anthony proved those the which yielded them unto him to be
relygyous. It is well to be noted that in likewise should do these prelates
before as to clothe and to receive of nouyces. For many there ben received the
which receive ill knaves. They make many dyuysyons sclaundres and desolucyons
/ and breketh the scylences / ceremonies / and constytucyons / whereby relygyon
is lost. Vnica so la pecus. Also as a seek be vndoth many other / in
likewise in a congregacyon when one relygyous is ylle inobedyent and rebel he
makes many ylle. Master Hugues of saint vyctor declares the life of the
sayll ill relygyous at the beginning of the rewle of chanons and says. Sunt
quidem in congregatione obstinati in suo sen^u sapientes in suis oculis. hu hoc
quodin in animo conceperunt qua^i ex ratione defendu^t. nec se aliis sed alios
sibi aplicari contendunt. Et si viderint sibi non obtemptari: statim
commouentur et alios perturbant. Tales solent esse rebels mandatis senioru^
plurunumque regnat in eis passio inobedientie et impatientie: isti no^ su^t
ydonei ad concordiam. etc.

Inobedientia.
E. Examples of inobedyence / and first example how Adam and Eve dysobeyed unto
god. liiii.
IT is written in the third chapter of genese how the serpente tempted Eve to
ete of the fruit that god her had defended / and eve said unto the serpente.
God has said unto us that one what day yt we ete of it we shall deye / that
is to say / we shall be bond unto the death. And the serpente said unto them
that they should not dye and that god knew well that on any day that they
should eat of the fruit their eyes should be open and they should be as
gods knowing the good and the ylle. Than eve byleued the persuacyon and
temptacyon of the devil / and ete of the fruit defended. And also made adam
to ete. And afterward god demanded of Adam wherefore he had broken his
commandment. He excused him upon eve that she had counsaylled him / but his
excusacyon vaylled him nothing. And god said unto him illud genesis.iii. Eo
quod obedisti voci vxoris tue plusquam michi: maledicta erit terra i^ opere
tuo: in laboribus comedes eam cuntis diebus vite tue spinas et tribulos
germinabit tibi: et comedes herbas terre: In sudore vultus tui vesceris pane
tuo donec reuerraris in terra^ That is to say for asmoche as thou haste obeyde
unto ye voice of thy wife more sooner than unto mine ye earth shall be cursed in
thy operacyon. Thou shalt ete y^ earth by labors all the days of thy life.
The earth shall bring forth thorns and thy stylles. And than thou shalt ere
the herbs of the earth. Thou shalt get thy bread in ye sweet of thy face
till unto that that you shalt return unto earth whereof thou art come. For
thou art poudre and ashes / and unto poudre thou shalt return. And god axed
Eve of her inobedyence ye which excused her upon the serpente that tempted her
but her excusacyon vaylled nothing / For god said to her illud genesis.iii.
Multiplicabo erumnas tuas et conceptus tuos. In dolor peries filios tuos et
sub viri potestate eris and ipse dn^abitur tui. That is to say / I shall
multeplye thy poorenes / myseryes / and thy conceyuynges. Thou shall child thy
sons in sorrow and thou shall be under the puyssau^ce of the man. etc. By this
example a man should understand that those the which synneth mortally in
brekynge the commandments of god and in obeyenge unto the temptacyons of the
devil / of the world and of the flesh shall not have of execusyo^ before god
for to say I have be tempted but that they shall be put from paradyse and lent
unto the fire of hell / by the dysobeyssaunce of the bytynge of an apple the
which is a little thing as unto the bytynge / but a great thing to do again
god the which it had defended. Paradyse celestyall was close / and adam and
eve were put out of paradise terrestre and put in to this world full of
myserie. And by their sin it behooves that we all ben baptized or put from
paradyse. Vnde ioha^.iiii. Nisi quis renatus fuerit ex aqua et spyrytu scto^
no^ potest i^troire in regnu^ dei. Who so well should consider this example he
should keep him to offend again the commandments of god

B. Another example how by the dysobeysaunce of the man of god a lion
strau^gled him in the way. liiii
IT is written in the.xiii. chapter of the third book of kings that at the
prayer of a man of god ye kings hand was heled ye which was dry. When he
had done this miracle the king prayed him to go dyne with him and that he
should give him of gifts. He answered / If thou would give me the half of thy
house yet would I not ete of bread ne I shall drink of water in this place /
it is in such wise sent me in the word of god the which it commanded.
Vnde.iii. regu^. Nec comedes panem neque bibes aqua^ nec reuerteris per via^
qua venisti. Than he yode by another way. And the prophet ancyen the which
dwelled in Bethell there as the king had be heled herd the said words that
ye man of god had no will ne to etene to dry^ke mounted upon his ass and yode
after him / and prayed him to go in to his house and to drink and to eat. He
excused him and said that god him had defended, and he said unto him. I am a
prophet as you art / and the aungel told me bring him again in to thy house
to the end that he ete of bread and drink of water / he did so much that he
brought him with him and ete of bread and drank of the water / And as they
sat at the table the word of god was brought forth in this manner. Quia no^
obedie^s fiusti ori dn^i: and no^ custodisti mandatu^ quod precepit tibi dn^s
deus et reuersus es: et comedisti pane^ et bibisti aquam non inferetur cadauer
tuum in sepulchrum patrum tuorum. That is to say for asmoche as thou haste not
ben obedyent unto the mouth of thy lord and have not kept his commandment.
etc. Thy body shall not be borne to be buried in the sepulcre of thy faders.
After that they had ete and drunk the man of god mounted upon his ass and
departed for to go / and found a lion in the way the whithe slew him the body
deed abode in ye way and the ass by. And the lion ne ete of the said body and
did none ill unto the ass but sat by him. etc. By this example we should
understand yt if god punysshed so holy a man for the fraccyon of so little a
commandment that he shall punysshe of great obedyences. And for asmoche as the
lion ne ete of the body it is to understand yt the said man of god is not
dampened and that his inobedye^ce was pardoned him / but he was punysshed for
that yt he was not obedient he byleued to lightly unto ye temptacyon of the
other man. Non oi^ spu^i credendum est. A man should believe unto every
spirit.

C. Another example of the disobeyssau^ce of two nonnes the which demanded of
the pope that they should confess each other. Ca. liiii.
IT is written in some books this yt follows the which the discyple recyteth
in his sermons and says yt the nonnes of a monastery were dysposed one time
that two amongst them should go unto the pope to get yt they might confess
each other. For they estymed that it was a thing unlawful yt they should
declare their sins and sekenesses unto a man / yt is unto a priest. When they
came unto ye pope and that he had understand their symplesse and the fraud of
the devil he took unto them a box shitte and closed and said unto them yt
they should bear it with them unto their lodging / and that they should
bring it him again in the mornyge with our opening it and that they should
obteyn that / yt they demanded. When they were at their lodginge they beheld
it dylygently and had great will to open it and the one of them said unto the
other open w^^ it let us se what is within it. The other said we dare not / for
the pope has defended it us. In the end by temptacyons they opened the said
box and thought to have shytte it again as it was. And a bird ye which was
within enclosed took her flyghte and fled / than they had dread. And in the
morning when they returned unto the pope and that he had known their
inobedyence / he said unto them. In this thing men know your instabylyte and
sekenes. In like wise should ye do the one with the other if ye should confess
each other / when the one should offend the other / she should hyde her sin
/ and so the pope sent them again without granting unto them their
demand.

D. Another example how the king Amaleche resysted again ye will of god / and
ill came unto him. Ca. liiii.
IT is written in the.vii. chapter of exode how the king amalech fought
meruaylously again the people of Israhell / and resysted again him as he
mounted into Egypt / and ylle came unto him the which shall be declared
herafter. Also god told it unto Moses. Delebo enim memoriam amalech sub celo.
etc.

E. Another example of the obeyssaunce of king Saul. liiii.
IT is written in the.xv. chapter of the first book of kings how god sent
unto king saul by the prophet Samuel that he and his army should go to
slay and to dystroye the king sinner Amaleche and all his people / and all his
beestes / and that al were dystroyed and lost without taking any unto
mercy. And without coueytynge ne taking any thing.vi regum. xv. Vade and
percute amalech and demolire vniuersa eius et non concupisces ex ipsius ali
quid no^ parcas ei: sed interfice a viro vsque ad mulierem and paruulu^ atque
lactante^ bouem and oue^ and asinu^. etc. Than Saul yode he and his army the
which was great and accomplysshed not the commandment of god / for he took
the king Gag quycke / and slew Amalech / and the good bestyall was spared.
Also they took the precious vestymentes and clothes / and the best of the
goods And slew the wulgarye people and bestyall and dystroyed all that ye
which was not good and precious against the will and commandment of our
lord Ihesu christ by his prophet. etc. This thing dyspleased unto god for
that yt Saul was inobedye^t where as he punysshed not the sinners as it was
commanded him. And for as much that he pylled and took their goods the
which was defended him. etc. After yt that the prophet samuel had spoken
unto god / and knew that he was wroth of the said inobedyence. He came unto
Saul and demanded him werfore he had not obeyed unto god / and that he was
gone unto ye pyll erye. Saul answered unto Samuel and said unto him. So have I
obeyed unto god. I have brought Gag the king and also Amalech have I slain /
ye people has be pylled and brought of fair sheep and of oxes to the end that
he did sacryfyce unto god. Meliore^ eni^ obedie^tia quam victime / That is to
say obedyence is better than sacryfyce. Also the prophet Samuel reproved
another time the said saul for his inobedyence and said unto him. illud. i.
regu^ xiii. Stulte egisti nec custodisti mandaradn^i dei tui q^ precepit tibi:
quod si no^ egisses iam nu^c preparasset dn^s regnu^ tuu^ super israhel in
se^piternu^: sed nequaquam consurget etc. Thou haste done folysshely and haste
not kept ye commandments of thy lord god the which he command the. If
you had not done it our lord had prepared thy realm upon the people of
Israhell in eternyte. But from hensforth he ne shall lift him up. For as much
as the said saul left god and did the will of the devil / the devil him
posseded and tormented gretely as it is written in the books of the kings / and
the end of hy^ was right ill / for he drew his sword and slew himself.
Saul arripuit gladiu^ suu^ and irruit super eu^. etc.

F. Another example of the dysobeyssau^ce of Pharaon and of his punycyon. liiii.
IT is written in exodi in the.vii. viii. chapitre. etc. How the king Pharaon
had the heart so enha^ded / rebelle and inobedyent yt he ne would obey unto god
/ and unto his servant. For he ne would let go the chyldre and people of
Israhell by many times in likewise as god him commanded. And therefore at every
time that he dysobeyed unto our lord Ihesu christ he sent a punycyon. The
first punycyon that our lord sent them was that all the waters and ryuers of
the kingdom of Egypt was changed and turned unto blood. The second that
god sent them so many of frogs yt they spradde over all egypt. The third
god sent so many of gnattes and flies upon bestes and people that they ne
might defend them. The fourth other flies and more terryble or al sorts.
The.v. was mortalyte upon all the beestes of egipte. The.vi. was wou^des and
bladders upon the beestes and people The.vii. was thondres and lyghteny^ges
hayle and fire in the mids. The.viii was grasseloppes and other ye which ete
all the verdure and grenesse of egypt. The ix. was derkenes. The.x. was
mortalyte upon ye first borne / and for that yt he had the heart so hard that
he ne would obey to god ne by word ne by punycyon moses stroke the water of
the sea the which departed on the one side and on the other And six hundred
thousand men of the children of Israhell without the women passed with dry
foot. And pharaon and all his army entered afterward and all we redrowned. Vn^
exo.xv. Curus pharaonis and excertitus eius proiecit in mare. Et electi
principes eius sub mersi sunt in mari rubro: abyssi operuerant eos descenderu^t
in profundu^ quasi lapis. Filii au^t israel ambulauerunt per siccu^ in medio
mari. By Pharaon the which was so obstynate yt he ne would never obey unto
the servants of god / ne him correct for plage nor punycyon yt god sent
unto hy^ ben understand ye sinners obstynate the which ne correct them for
prechynges ne wrytynges yt a man unto them might tell / ne for sekenes of
fortune what so ever ye god unto them sent. And for asmoche as they be in
danger to have in the end and conclusyon as pharaon had / yt is yt god shall
punysshe them and make to deye myscheuously and yt they shall descend in to
dampnacyon in to hell. etc.

G. Another example of the inobedyence of the prophet jonas. liiii.
IT is written in the first chapter of Jonas how god him commanded yt he
should go to preche in the cite of Nynyues / the which obeyed not redely and
fled from the face of our lord / mounted upon the sea in a ship and
incontinent these began to move for ye tempest of the time. For to make short
Jonas was cast into the sea / and a fisshe named a whale him swalowed / and
was in his womb three days and three nyghtes. And in the womb of ye said
fysshe made his orayson unto god. Afterward god commanded unto the fysshe yt
he should vomete Jonas. He was obedyent and vometed him and cast him on dry
land. And when Jonas came forth of the womb of the whale / god him
commanded secondly that he should go to preche in the cite of Nynyue / and he
was obedyent forthwith.

H. Another example how chore: dathan and abyron / and their alyes dyscended in
to hell for their inobedyence and murmr. Also how the children of Israhell
gadred of the manna again the commandment of Moses. Ca. liiii.
IT is written in the.xvi. chapter of the book of nombres / how chore / dathan
and abyron and two. C. and. l men murmured against god and Moses and ylle
came unto them. For ye earth opened under them. And they dyscended all quycke
in to hell hosed shod and clothed / and in such wise they perysshed. Vnde
numeri.xvi. Dirupta est tra sub pedibus eorum: et aper^es os suum de uorauit
eos cum tabernaculis suis: and vniuersa substantia eorum descenderumque vi ni
in infernum operti et perierunt. etc. Also it is written in the.xvi. chapitre of
ye book of exodi how ye children of Israhel murmured that they had not of
flesh and of bread. And god sent unto them of ye manna the which dyscended
from heaven / and Moses commanded them that they ne should gadre ne keep but
that the which should suffyse them for the day without keeping it till unto
the morrow. And many were inobedyentes and kept it till unto the morrow / the
which manna stanke and therein gadred the worms. These examples here show
that inobedyence and murmr makes to have punycyon and dampnacyon temporell
and eternell and therefore it behooves to obey unto god and unto his servants.

I. Another example of a friar ye which was punysshed dyuynely for the murmr
that he made again god. liiii.
IT is written in ye life of faders that there was a friar honest and verytable
/ after that he had served god long time in the order of prechours / and that
he ne had apperceyued any thing of consolacyons and swetnes of god the which
read and that he had herd how these other had tasted often times. In a night
they were before the crucyfyxe and lamentably began to inquire before god in
saying these words here. My lord I have herd of the ye thou procedest al
creatures in bounte and mansuetude. And I have served the by many of years in
keeping hard things for the words of thy lips / and wyllyngly I am all
mortefyed for the love of the And my lord I know that if I had done as much
of service unto a tyrant he would have showed me some sign of benyuolence
either in speaking swetely / or in gyuynge me some thing / or in co^myttynge
me to do some secret / or at ye leest in laughyng on me. And certainly my
lord thou haste not shed in me any doulsour / thou haste not showed in me
any benyuolence. Thou lord the which prechest swetnes thou art in me cruel.
Thou art more hard than if thou were to me a tyrant / you lord what thing
is it or wherefore do thou it. Than as he said these words and began again
and many other semblables / he herd one time and two great tremblynges / in
like wise as the church had threted ruin / and above the covering of the
church he herd sco much of tredynge as and if many dogs there had grated
with their nails and gnawen with their tethe. When he herd that he was a ferde
hugely and all his body trembled / and suddenly he saw behind him an horrible
vysage. And with a thing that he held in his hands stroke it and fell
prostrate unto the earth. And as he would have risen / he ne might in no manner
/ and in brekynge he drew him toward an altar / And more over he ne might
ferther proceed for the great dolor that he had. When the freres arose at
pryme and that they found him replenysshed with dolours / they bare him in to
the fermerye and knew not the cause of his maladye. He lay the space of three
wekes / and unto himself and unto other he stanke so much that with great
pain might they serve him if they did not stop their nosethrylles. After
that he had recovered his strength and that he was corrected of his
presumpcion returned unto the place where he had be stryken and where he had
deserved the wrath and ire of god / to the end that he should get mercy. And
he said. My lord I have sinned in heaven and before the I am the leest of all
those of whom you haste pytye / and am indygne of thy great graces. My lord
thou haste beten me justly. but debonayrly thou have heled me. Than he fell
prostrate on his face and required pardon many times of things that he had
folysshely thought and lightly spoken again god / and a voice unto him was
made. Yt thou will have ye consolacyons that thou have made. And these
doulicurs of the holy ghost it behooves that thou the repute vile in like wise
as a worm and as the mire where upon you tredest. When he herd that he was
strongly comforted he rose him up and yielded graces unto god / And afterward
did the said things humbly brennyngly / and lyberally he showed this thing
the which happened him unto the master of the order of prechours / and men
believe that it came unto him as it is before rehearsed in the life of the faders
/ and therefore inobedyence makes to have punycyon. etc.

VErbum dei.
A. Examples for the word of god and the prechynges. And first. A. Example
how a great sinner repented him and was saved by the herynge of a predycacyon
or a sermon. lv.
MEn find by writing in many books this the which follows the which the
dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that as saint Bernarde preched
in the churcheyarde in a cite / ii. rybauldes were nere. Of the which the one
theder would go as the other people / the which yede theder. And ye other
mocked him and said unto him. How ledeth the theder now the devil the which
nededyste in all thy life any good deed. And now thou wylt go unto the
predycacyon And he took no head of the rebukes that he said unto him and theder
yode. And saint Bernarde preched again those the which spoke cursed words
and the which led an ill life. The sinner began to have contrycyon and
doloure for his sins / and he began for to weep. And saint Bernard saw that
he had about his neck a great chain the which had more than an hondreth
linkes / but at every iere that he wept there fell a lynke from the said
chain Than saint bernarde began to preche more strongely and ardauntly and to
deteste his sins. And the sinner more strongly wept. In the end the chain
was al undone and broken. After the said predycacyon saint bernarde called him
and comforted him. And by his admonycion he confessed all his sins and
afterward lived holyly and his compaignon abode in sy^ne and bond with a more
cheyne than was the other. By this example a man should understand that
mortal sin is a bond or a chain by the which the soul of sinners is
bound and holden in the hands of the devil of hell. In like wise as
approves the scripture in many places / Vnde david in psalm. Funes peccatorum
circumplexi su^t me. The cords of my sins has beset me about and
compassed in all things. Et legitur prouerbioru^.v. Iniquitates sue capiunt
impium et funibus peccatorum suorum vnusquisque constringitur. The iniquytes
happen the sinner. And every one is constrained by the cords of his sins.
And saint Austyn says in his confessionayr. Ligatus eram non ferro alieno:
sed ferra mea voluntate / I was bound not with strange iron / but by my
thought hard as iron.

B. Another example how a relygyous converted in few words a man of gross
conscience. lv.
MEn find by writing in the promptuarye of the dyscyple and of other books
that a rich man puyssaunt had a wife devout / and he himself lived seculerly
and without devotion and it befell that a relygyous the which passed ye
country yode unto their house / and they sitting at the table / the wife
prayed the relygyous that he would say before her husband some good
exhortacyon / he answered so shall I do if he will. Than the husband said I
shall here it with good will so that it be short. And he said. So shall I do
but understand it well and put it in effect. I say that it is written mathei
xii. Oi^a quecu^que vultis vt vobis faciant hoi^es: and vos eade^ facite illis.
That is to say. The good that thou wylt that men do to the / do it unto thy
neighbor. If thou keep these words here without forgetynge them and that
thou accomplysshe them you shalt be saved. Than he began to think yt he would
keep them and he did it / afterward sometime as he passed by a way he found a
mylle yt he had made to dystroy he recorded him of the words of the said
relygyous / he sent his procurour to compounde with him unto whom it
apperteyned. Semblably these other yt he had offended / he them appaysed and
satysfied them unto his power. It befell also that he found a poor man in the
way as he came again he led him in to his house he refresshed him and made
him to sytte by him at the table / and gave him of his metes. After souper he
brought him for to sleep in a place where he and his wife slepte yt was nere
the yates of the door. and when the poor man had a little while slepte he had
thurst. For he had taken good refeccyon not accustomed and when he had not to
dry^ke he cried importunatly yt he was tormented by great thirst / and for
asmoche as the household slepte and was in a place on ye side far of the
host all only he herd hy^ cry the which was moved unto mercy he rose him
up and demanded him what he neded / and he said unto him. My lord I lose by
thirst. Than the master would have brought him of water of the cysterne. And
as he drew he fell within it and was drowned. Afterward long time when the
servants sought him they found him within the said cysterne / the which had
about his neck a cercle of gold in the which there was in writing that his
soul was borne in to heaven before yt his body was cold after yt he was deed.
/ By this man the which was converted from ylle unto good for to here one
good word it is to understand that it is a great thing to preche and to
show ye word of god. And for that yt he restored ye things ill done and that
he was mercyful it is to understand that he had contrycyon and purpose to live
well and that he changed the ylle in to good. And by that that men found the
lettre of gold written and that he was saved. It is to understand that he
deyed in good consummacyon as very repentaunte and good catholyque.

C. Another example of a master delycatife the which ne would here the word
of god ne do of penance and was converted in few words. lv.
IT is written in the book of dread of a master delycatyf / the which refused
so much the estate of penance that hene would goo unto sermons. And also hene
would here speak word of god lest that he were moved to enter in to relygyo^
And it befell one time yt a precher of his parentage came to vysyte him in his
house. And when he was in his chamber he dreded that he came to him to preche /
unto whom he said. Friar wherefore are ye come / if ye will speak unto me of
god I care not of it / and if ye speak of other besynesses ye are welcome. And
he said unto him master I have to speak with you of other things / and sithe
that ye will not here speak of god I purpose not to speak unto you of him / but
by your leave and license. Than he received him to speak of other besynesses.
And after that these rumors were fined when the friar would go said unto him.
Master give me leave to speak one word of god / with great dyffyculte he
granted it him. And the said friar said to him. Master I pray you yt when ye
be laid this night in your bed that ye remember you of the bed yt these
slothful men and women have in hell the which ne do of penance in this
world. And ye said man said unto him. What bed have they / and the said
friar said / The prophet Ysaye says in the.xiiii. chapter. Subter te
sternetur tinea et operi mentum tuum erunt vermes. The (...) as much for to
say that thy fire shall (...) strewed under the with mouths and thy couerture
shall be worms. After these words the said friar departed. And the said
master thought so much of the said word of the bed of hell that all the
night he ne might sleep. And the said word had so great effect and so much
vaylled it unto him that within a right little time after he entered in to
relygyon and corrected him. Wherefore it is a great thing to here the word of
god.

D. Another example of an ill knight the which in his life was confessed but
one time / and at one sule predycacyon he corrected himself and converted. lv.
MEn find by writing in the sermons of the dyscyple and many other books of
a knight replenysshed with many sins. The which ye devil had so strongly
blinded his heart yt in all his life he had not be confessed but one time. And
it befell that he came reverently unto the church on the day of pentecoste /
and not for because of devotion / that he had unto our lord Ihesu christ nor
unto his saints / but to the intent for to show himself. For upon that day
he had be clothed with.ix. vestymentes the which were right precious. And on
the said day he herd speak unto prosne the priest of the said parysshe the
which showed of the solempnyte and virtue of the holy ghost. And when the said
knight herd that unto those what so ever they were either men or women the
which have committed sin that would repent them that god should send the
holy ghost ye which should make clean their hearts and al sins. And
afterward should enhabyte in them. Incontinent that the priest had spoken this
thing the said knight yode in to a place secret to pray unto god and said. O
lord god I am a sinner / I have gotten many of sins / of the which I sorrow
and repent me gretely. I pray the by thy great mercy that thou send me on
this day the holy ghoost the which shall make me clean and enlumyne mine heart
And incontinent god exalted him and sent unto him the holy ghost the which
made clean his heart by verey contrycyon and after by pure confession. And so
ye holy ghost came unto him and abode with him: and after sinned he no more
mortally and did penance dygne and satisfaccyon and ended his life in good
conso^macyon. This example denotes that it is a great thing to here the word
of god / for all benedyecyon and salvation proceeds of it. Another example it
is written in the deed of ye appostles that as saint peter preched the holy
ghost dyscended upon all those yt herd the word of god. Vn^ actuu^.x. Adhuc
loque^te petro cecidit spiritussa^ctus super oe^s qi audiebant vbu^ dei.

E. Another example of a count ye which converted hy^ in hery^ge ye word of
god
IT is written in ye sermons of ye dyscyple and in other books yt there was an
earl lecherous / proud / and malycyous ye which lived longly in many sins
and so it befell one time yt he entered in to ye church and there herd a
sermon. And when he herd preche yt / yt is written eze.xviii. In quacu^que hora
i^gemuerit pcto^r oi^m i^iqitatu^ eius no^ recordabor. That is to say / in what
hour the sinner shall wayle and weep his sins I shall not remember of al his
iniquytes. He took this auctoryte in himself he repented hy^ bytterly and
required of god his grace and his mercy and that he would pardon him his sins
/ and confessed and said yt he ne would do more other thing till unto the
death than to serve god / he left the world / he entered in to relygion and
there served god deuoutely. And after his death men found in writing upon his
sepulture in lettres of gold the words of the psalmyste. Misit dn^s vbu^ suu^
and sanau^t epos. That is to say yt our lord sent his words and heled him /
yt is yt he converted him from ylle in good by the herynge of ye word of god.
and therefore it is a great thing as to preche and to teache. Another example of
a carle ye which would not here the word of god / and the crucyfyxe stopped
his eres in sygnefyenge yt he ne would here ye prayers that men made for him.

Master Jacques of Vitre says in his book yt there was a carlysshe man yt
would never in his life here ye word of god / and when the priest began for to
preche he yode out of ye church and went in to the chircheyarde to talk and
to detracte with other carles ye which was repreued many times of his said
priest for yt that he and the other let to speak the word of god / but he
ne corrected hy^ and abode in his obstinacyon. The which was afterward seek
grievously / and called his said priest and confessed him for dread of death /
and not for the charity of god / ne for his health / and of the said sekenes
shortly he deyed. And when his body was borne unto the chirch and that the
said priest and clergy song the dyryge and the office of the deed bodies the
image of ye crucifixe stopped his eres with ye fyngers of his hands taken from
the crrosse before all the people. Than as all they meruaylled to se yt / the
priest said unto ye people. Know ye what token this is here. They answered
that nay. And ye said priest said. Ye shall understand that the soul of this
carle whose body lies here is now between the hands of the deuylles. For in
likewise as he stopped his eres that he herd not the word of god / In like
wise god closes his eres that he ne here ye prayers and oraysons that we make
for him. And the said priest defended unto all the presence yt they ne should
pray more for his soul. Than they ceased to pray for him. And his body was
taken from the holy place and was buried in a field. For as for the soul of
one dampened a man should not pray. Quia in inferno nulla est redemptio. After
that a person is iuged and sent unto the pains of hell for to suffer pain /
he shall never come again unto light ne never shall he have mercy. Wherefore
it behooves no more pray for it. Vnde gregorius vndecimo. Quis quis ad inferna
mala tollera^da semel decenderit: nequaquam vlterius mia^ parcentis liberat
quos semel in locis penalibus iustitia iudicantis damnat.

A. Another example of ye paroyssyens of a curate the which ne would here ye
predycacyon and the commandments of ye church.
IT is wryte^ how a curate reproved many times his paroyssyens for yt that they
yede in to ye chircheyarde when he preched and made his antetyme. Also when any
other made predycacyon / and for asmoche as he knew not how to remedy it for
ye health of their souls. For they dyuysed of their occupacyons seculers in
the said chircheyarde when he diuysed of feestes / fastings. And other
co^maundentes of the church. What did he / he made to bring him a little
