stole in the mids of them in the chircheyarde and so set him down / and
beheld them there. And he herd their langayges. And when he ennoyde them
they demanded what he did there. He answerde. Vbi sunt ciues ibi debet esse
episcopus. That is to say. That ye bishop should be where his cytezyns ben
Also a curate should be where his paroyssyens is / and you are here / wherefore
I should be with you. And for asmoche that at ye first time they correct them
not / yet theder did he goo afterward the second time. And when it came unto
the third time they all had so great shame that afterward they yede theder no
more. And so he correct them / and unto them it prouffyted more than all the
langayges yt he had spoken to them before. And therefore when a man may not
correct his paroyssyens in one manner him behooves to assaye in another.

B. Another example how a herdeman was saved and correct himself by the
herynge of one predycacyon. lvi.
THe dysciple recyteth in his tromptuary how that a pastor or herd man yede
late unto ye church unto mass and sermons for the keeping of his bestyall And
one time he passed by a cite and entered into ye church and herd preche yt
every creature is taught to fle sy^ne and to love god / by this prechynge he
was edefyed. And in beholdynge ye creatures he said to himself Such a
creature serves unto god and obeys unto him. The water in rennynge ye birds
in singing the herbs in rysynge up and growing and in like wise of other
creatures. And he saw a toode one time and said / the creatoure might have
create me as this tode if he had would / and I offend him contynuelly by
sins and am unkind. For he has made me and create unto his image for to
have beatytude and me has redeemed by his passyo^ etc. For to be short he
converted him and did penance / and was suffycyently instruct of a holy man
and perseuered louably in the service of god. etc.

C. Another example. That to here the word of god it is prouffytable albeit
that a man hold it not.
IT is written in the life of the faders yt a friar said unto a good fader
abbot. I have axed questyons oftymes that they would tell me ammonycyon for the
health of my soul. And of all that that they tell me I reteyne nothing. The
auncyente said unto the friar I have two vessels void goo fetch me one and
wasshe it with water / and afterward cast it and put ye said pot in his
place. And the said friar did so one time two times / and the au^cyente said
unto him. Bring me ye two vessels heder / when that he had brought them
the auncyente said unto him / Which of the two pottes is most moist and also
clean. The friar said unto him. It is that wherein I have put my water that I
have washed. Than the ancient said unto him. Sone in like wise is it of the
soul the which hereth often the word of god / albeit that he reteyne
nothing of the things that he axeth / notwithstondynge he is more clean than
he the which demau^deth nothing and also hereth not any thing.

D. Another example how some freres slepte in herynge the word of god and in
herynge the ydell words they were much waking. Ca. lvi
IT is written in the life of the faders that an au^cyent the which set him in
hermytage for to pray unto god that he would give hy^ grace yt he slepte not
when men should speak of spyrytuell things. And when men should speak of
detraccyon or of hate that he might sleep incontynente that the eres ne token
the venyme of that sin. He said that the devil studied hy^ to admoneste
these men in ydell words for to impugn doctrine and thing spyrytuell. And he
told this example. When I spoke some time unto some freres of the vtylyte of
souls / they slepte so profou^dely that they ne might meue the eye lyd of
their eyes. And I would show that it was a thing dyabolyke. And I yode to
speak things ydell. And they were incontinent waking and enjoyed them and I
took me to wayle and to say. I spoke till unto now of things celestyall /
and all your eyes were holden by grefe to sleep and when an ydell word has
be brought forth / ye have be all prompte and ready to here. For the which
thing I pray you right dear brethern that ye know that it is the work of
the cursed devil / take heed to your self and keep you from slepynge when ye
do or here any thing spyrytuell. etc. By this example a man may understand
that the devil brings a sleep his servants of dread that they ne here the
word of god / and that they ne should leave their sins. And also he waketh
the^for to here ylle / to the end that they fall in to sin and dampnacyon. etc.

E. Another example again those the which flees the sermons. lvi.
IT is written that as saint martyn yode from town to town prechinge and
doing miracles one Cayment impotente fled evermore before him from town to
town / and from cite to cite / and fered that he should hele him / of dread
that he ne lost to get and to demand his living. In like wise the
rauysshers / ye the uys / the lechoures / and sinners flees the sermons and
they ne will here them / of dread lest that they leave their sins / and they
ne amend them. etc.

F. Another example how the case of a prechoure was borne at the death / and
how Ihesu christ aided him and chased away the deuylles. lvi.
SOme masters has written this ye which follows how ye dyscyple recyteth
in his pro^tuarye and says that it was commanded unto a relygious priest of
the order of the prechers that he should go to preche again the sarazyns / ye
cross he theder yode and so deyed. And he appeared unto one of his compaygnons
ye which axed him of his estate. He answered in this. It seemed me that my
pain was to long. And when that I deyed I ne saw by me but the deuylles the
which began to say unto me. Thou keptest never well thy professyon ne the
obedyence that thou have promised unto thyn abbot And also thou ne preched
never unto any clearly thy lord god. And as the said deuylles preposed against
me diverse things in the said manner and that there ne was person the which
answerde for me Ihesu christ came and said. Come after me / for thou haste
preched me. And incontinent all the company of deuylles departed as a smoke and
I followed Ihesu christ in to glory and I ne felt any other pain except the
said fere. etc.

G. Another example how he the which precheth the word of god shall have great
reward in heaven.
MEn find by writing in some books / also the dyscyple it recyteth in his
promptuarye that as a good priest precher approached unto his death one of his
good friends made him swear in our lord that he should come to certefy him of
his estate.xxx. days after his death. After that he was deed the said priest
appeared unto him as he had required hy^ in a meruayllous fair chapel al
replenysshed with ouches of gold that is to say of Iewelles rich / noble
good and precious / among the which there was one upon the breast dyffered /
and was more fair without comparyson than the other. And as he inquired of his
estate / he said unto him that it was well. After he him demanded wherefore he
was so cladde. He answered I have this vestyment for the great zele and love
that I have had unto my neighbors. And as many as I have converted of sinners
there are in my vesture of ouches. And I have received the ouche that thou
see on my breast / for that that I have converted a sinner of whom no man had
any hope of health. And he asked him of the estate of those the which have
cure and charge of soul and of people / as the curates the which have
parysshynges. He answered right few shall be saved. For they walk in the
large way ye which ledeth unto hell. And show evil examples unto their
subgectes they be so much habandoned in couetyse that they care not of souls
so that they have the gods of their subgectes. And enioyneth yt is yet more
peryllous / that / yt they should convert unto the usage of ye poores / they
dyspende it with vile persons. When he had spoken these words he departed.
/ These curates and those the which have cure of souls should well note this
example. For great reward follows unto those ye which well show unto their
paroyssye^s. And also dampnacyon unto those ye which use ill of the office and
charges yt they have. etc.

H. Another example how the devil ne might strangle a knight / for that / yt
he salued the vyrgyn Marye every day / and for the good will that he had to
here a predycacyon he was saved. lvi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye this the which follows / the which
is also written in other books and says. That there was a knight lord of a
castle whoo had under him many tyrauntes. And this said knight dyspoylled all
the goers by without mercy / but he had of custom that every day he salued
the vyrgyn Marye. And one day there passed thereby an holy monk that ye said
knight commanded he were dyspoyled / and the holy man prayed the pyllers that
they would bring him unto their master and that he had a secret thing to
tell to him when he was led he prayed the lord yt he would make al his
servants to come forth to the end yt they should here a predycacion. And he
commanded that they should come al. When it was done he said They ne ben all
here there wants one. and some said ye chamberer defayleth / he was made to
come. The holy man said. It is this here that I demanded. And he said unto
him. I the adjure and command yt in the name of the fader / of the sone / and
of the holy ghost that thou tell what thou art / and wherefore thou art heder
come. He answered. Alas I am constrained to declare my secret. I am not a man
but a devil / and I have dwelled with this knight.xiiii. years / for our
prince sent me hither for to look the day that this unhappy said not the
salutacyon accustomed to the end that I should strangle him. For I have the
puyssau^ce of god for ye sins that he has co^myted / to the end that he
were our compaygnon in hell / when the knight herd these words he was
abashed. And he fell prostrate at the fete of ye said monk / required him
pardon. And amended his life in to better. It is a great thing to here a
predycacyon and to serve the vyrgyn Marye. And in like wise as the devil of
hell flees / and renneth from the predycacyon / because yt he would not find
himself there / denote yt those yt flee the sermons follows ye devil of hell
And as now there are many of his party the which ne will here predycacyon.

I. Another example how men shall forgete the commandments of god in the
last or latter generacyon.
IT is written in ye life of the faders that one time the holy faders assembled
them together and prophetyzed of ye last generacyon. Amongst whom one
pryncypall named querimus said. We accomplysshe the commandments of god. And
these other faders shall ask it in demanding. And those that shall come
after us what shall they do. He answered and said unto them. They shall
accomplysshe parauenture the half of the commandments and shall require the
good eternell. And the faders demanded after these people where shall become
these other. In answering he said. The men of that generacyon shall not have
the operacyon of that / yt god wylleth that be do. And they shall forgete the
commandments of god. Also in that time sin above shall habounde / and
charity shall were cold / and great temptacyon shall come upon them / but
those ye which shall be in bounte proved they shall be better / more blyssed and
proved than we and or our faders.

K. Another example of a rich man ye which served the devil.xl. year. And in
a s^^mon repented him.
LEgitur in dyalogo cesarii. It is written that a rich man and puyssaunt full
of vices and cursydnesses was in such estate.xl. years. And afterward
repented him in a sermon / confessed him / changed his life / entered in to
relygyon / and prouffyted so gretely yt he was in the grace of god / and that
he made reuelacyon of ye hour of his death. And when he was seek he said unto
his friends yt he should deye the third day and so he did. etc. By these
examples beforsayd it appears yt all godenes / all salvation / and benedyccyon
proceeds to here and to keep the word of god / and therefore it is written in
the gospel. luce. xi Beati q audiu^t vbu^ dei and custodiu^t illd.

first A. Another example of a priest prince of the ydoles of the people yt
burnt in the fire of hell / and how these without believe shall be found
there.
WE find in the life of faders yt a good abbot named machaire found in his
way in ye deserte a head dry of a man deed / whom he co^iured and demanded
him what he was / and he answered. I am the prince of the prestes of Ydoles of
the people ye enhabyted in this place here. And the abbot asked him of ye pain
yt he endured / and in wayllyng on hye he said. Qua^tu^ distat celu^ a tra:
ta^tu^ ignis altus e^ i^ quo medio positi sumus. That is to say / yt of
asmoche as there is of dystau^ce from heaven unto earth of asmoche is ye fire of
hell great in the myddest whereof we ben put when ye holy Machayre herd this
word he began to weep and say. Ve hoi^ il li q ma^data dei tra^sgressus e^.
Malediccion is unto yt man ye which has transgressed the commandments of
god. And he asked him again if there were more great pain / and he answerde
yes. And yt the jews were more strongly brent and tormented / and lower than
they / for that yt they had gretter knowledge of god and of ye faith than they
have had. And after said yt ill christian men and women ye which live in sy^ne
mortal ben yet more bas brent and tormented / For as much that of certain
science they offend god and had more great knowledge of him and of the faith
than the Jews and paynemes ye which offended by ygnoraunce and enfermete and
unsteadfastness. And therefore they ben in the botome of hell / ye which of
asmoche as it mounteth hye / and it is the less hot. And therefore we ne ben
so much tormented as ye said crystyens / and when the said Machayre herd the
said words he asked hy^ no more / and in wepy^g so departed. This example
shows yt all sorts of people incredules and unfaithful yt go against the
faith / and deye impenytentes shall be punysshed in ye fire of hell after
their deserte. Unto ye purpose the psalm. says. Pones eos vt clibanu^ ignis i^
te^pore vultus tui dn^e: dn^s i^ ira sua conturbabit eos et deuorabit eos
ignis. That is to say O you lord you haste put the ylle in like wise as an oven
of fire in ye time of thy face / yt is of thy judgment / the lord shall
trouble them in his ire / and the fire shall devour the^. And again ye psalmyst
says. Cade^t super eos carbones: scz i^ die iuditii: i^ ignem deucies eos i^
miseris no^ subsiste^t. That is to understand. The coals shall fall upon them
at ye day of judgment yt shall brenne where ye sy^nes has been made / you shall
cast them in ye fire / they ne may be but in my seryes. Et le. job. xx.
Deuorabit eu^. s. i^piu^ ignis q no^ succendit. That is to say. The fire yt is
not light shall devour the cursed dampened.

B. Another example of the ydolatrie of Nabugodonosor when he made the three
children to be put in ye furnayse. lvii.
IT is written in the third chapitre of the book of Danyell how the king
Nabugodonosor did make an ydole of gold of.lx. cubytes in heyght / and six of
largenes / and made to bear it in to a great field and caused all the people to
come theder. More over he sent a commandment yt all the people should worship
the image when they should here the instruments melodious sou^de / and that al
those yt would not prostrate them or fall unto ye earth and worship the said
ydole yt they were taken and cast in to the furnayse light and embraced. And as
the people worshypped in such wise the said ydole there were three children
called sydrac / Mysac / and Abdenago yt would not worship it ne prostrate
them. Than the king made them to come before him to whom he demanded.
Which is the god that may deliver you fro my hand. And the said children said
unto the king nabugodonosor. Of that thing it needs ye none answer. The god
that we worship has puyssaunce to deliver us from the furnayse brennynge and
from thy hands. / Than ye said king was replete of furour and commanded yt
the said furnayse were.vii times more strongly embraced than had be accustomed
/ and the most strongest men of his host bound their fete and their hands
and cast them within the said furnayse The which was done / and the fire
burnt those yt cast them in / but it did none ill unto ye said children /
the which walked within the myddest of ye said furneyse in lauding and
blissynge god. And the fire ne did them never ill. Than the king was much
meruaylled to se them in such wise to walk through the fire / and to give
louynges unto god the which made them for to to go out of the furneyse. And ye
great and puyssaunce of the king beheld them gretely / but they found that
the said fire had not had any puyssaunce to touch the^ nor never here of
their hedes nor vestymentes were burnt. Than the king nabugodonosor began to
cry yt their god were blyssed the which sent his angel / and delivered his
servants the which byleued in him. And they changed the word of the king
the which made a decrete that all the people of what lygnee and tongue that he
were ye which had made blaspheme again the god of sydrac / mysaac / and
abdenago / should perisshe / and his house be wasted. etc. In this example a
man may understand yt all blasphematours ben reprehend and punisshed grievously
be it in confession or otherwise / sith yt the king the which was ydolatre
and peruers knew manyfestly the puyssaunce of god / and that he offended
again him in doing him such dyshonoure / rebuke and blaspheme to give the
divine honor unto an ydole ye which apperteyneth to god And therefore of good
right he made to punysshe the blasphematoures after that he had known his
health.

C. Another example how Egeas ydolatre was slain of the devil. lvii
IT is written in the legende of saint andrewe how the king egeas constrained
the crystyens to do sacryfyce to ye ydoles. Again whom came saint Andrewe to
reprehende him and they dysputed longly togyders of the passion and redempcyon
of our sauyoure. And for asmoche as the said saint Andrewe was ferme in ye
faith And the said egeas ne might put hy^ out he him iuged and condampned to be
crucyfyed and put in the torment of the cross the fete upward to the end yt he
had ye more long and gretter torment. And to be short in such wise was it
done. And the said andrewe was two days in ye said torment where he preched
and showed unto the people the which were present by estymacyon. a.xx. M. the
which people yode unto the said egeas cryenge yt unjustly he had condampned
him to death. etc. The said egeas came unto the said saint for to satysfye unto
ye people and to take him from the cross. And the light dyscended unto the
said saint. And as the said egeas returned him the devil entered in to his body
the which slew him in the said way and so euylly fined he his days.

D. Another example of the death of simon magus and of other myscreau^tes. lvii.
IT is written in the deed of ye appostles yt the enchauntour symo^ magus
deceived ye people by false art magyk in many manners the which abide because
of shortness / in the end of his days he vaunted hy^ to flee in the air. And in
deed mounted in to a toure and took him to flee before ye people / but they
were the deuylles the which bare him through the air / the which let him
fall by the commandment of saint peter / and fell upon the stones ye which
brake his body. And right shortly after yield up his spyryte / and so deyed
myscheuously. / Another example of two enchauntoures / zaroes and arphasat ye
which deceived ye people in many maneres. And they were burnt and bruyled of
the fire and of the lightening the which dyscended from heaven. When saint
simon and saint Jude should be martred in like wise as we read in the legende
of those appostles. Another example how he the which slew saint leodegayre
yede out of his wit and cast himself in ye fire / and so was brent as it is
written in ye legende of saint leodegayre. Another example how the priest of the
ydoles the which cou^saylled that men should sle saint Vital / yede out of
wit / and by seven days was posseded of the devil / and drowned himself as
it is written in the legende of the said Vytall. Another example how the
emperor domycyen ye which put saint Johan the euangelyst to death and made
him to be put in a to^ne of oil was slain yt year. And all his deeds were
reproved ill of ye senators as it is written in the legende of the said Johan.

E. Another example how dyascorus ye which was ydolatre deyed euylly. lvii.
IT is written how dyascorus was fader unto saint Barbara / ye which was a
great lord (but ydolatre) And for as much as the said daughter saint barbara
made her to be baptized and ne would believe ne worship the ydoles / ye said
dyascorus betoke her unto the judge marcyen / for to torment her and to punysshe
by martyrdom / and so was it done. And after that she had endured many
martyrdoms and yt the said marcyen was confused he sent her again unto
dyascorus / ye which led her on a hye mountain / and to make short there
byheded her with his own hands. And afterward as he came again in dyscendynge
the said mountain vengeance and punycyon dyuyne followed / for fire /
lightening / and tempeste dyscended upon him and was burnt and consumed in
such wise yt of his body there ne abode poudre / ne ashes / ne other thing of
him / and so mischeuously he ended his days as reason was / and as done people
of ill life.

F. Another example how the prouoste Tarquyn the which was ydolatre deyed
myscheuously. lvii
IT is written in the legende of saint syluester / yt after yt the provost
tarquyne had made saint thymothee to deye by martyrdom for that / yt he
preched fermely the faith of Ihesu christ / he commanded unto saint syluester
to do sacryfyce unto the ydoles / or he would make him in the morning to be
tormented by diverse torments. And syluester said unto him Fool thou shalt
deye this night and thou shalt receive torments perdurables / and will thou
or not you shalt know the god the which we believe to be true / and in eatinge
at dynere the bone of a fysshe abode in his throat the which he ne might cast
ne swalowe down / so dyed he at mydnyght and was led unto ye tomb with
great wepynges and lamentacyons / and saint syluester was delivered from prison
with great Joy. So it appears that people ydolatres and myscreauntes deye
myscheuously.

G. Another example how the king of perse quosdros the which would be of all
folks praised and worshypped as god / had the heed stryten of.
IT is written in ye exultacyon of the cross / that the king of perse quosdros
put under his empire many realms of the world After he did make a toure of
silver and gold where the precious stones did shine / and made ye images of
the son and of the moon and of the sterres in semblau^ce of an heaven. And a
precious sege wherein he sat / and made him to be worshypped as god. More over
he had a sone much or guyllous / great and puyssaunt the which made the
war / the which fought upon a bridge again the humble prince eraclius. For
to be short god gave grace unto the said prince eraclius in such manner yt he
dyscomfyte the orguyllous in fighting. And after yode unto the said toure and
stroke of the heed of the said king quosdrus for that yt he ne would believe in
god So it appears that the proud men and mysbyleuers fined their days
myscheuously.

H. Another example of the death of the ydolatres dacyen and Valeryen. lvii.
IT is written in the legende of saint Ypolyte that dacyen and valeryen
emperors deyed myscheuously / for after that they had made to sle by
martyrdom saint laurens / saint Ypolyte and many cristiens / he mounted in to
a chair for to goo to tormente of other crystyens / and dacyen was rauysshed
of ye devil / cried. O Ypolyte has rauysshed me / and holds me with great
chains. And valeryen cries. O Laurens you drawest me bound with chains and
deyed incontinent. And Dacyen returned unto the house / and was three days
tormented of the devil / and deyed euylly.

I. Another example of the death of king Yrache ydolatre. lvii.
IT is written in the legende of saint mathieu yt after yt the king Yrach had
made to sle saint Mathieu ye fire took in his palace ye brent and wasted all /
and none ne escaped but only ye king / and one of his sons was rauysshed of
the devil / and began to cry the sins of his fader and so yode unto ye
sepulcre of saint mathieu And his fader was a foul lepre ye which slew
himself with his sword when he saw he ne might be hole.

H. Another example of the ydolatrye of Quincien. lvii.
THe legende of saint Agathe specyfyeth yt after that Quyncyen had made to
cut the breasts of the said saint Agathe and to deye by martyrdom / he
entered in to a boat and his two horses began to greune togyders / and the one
of them bote him / and the other stroke him with his fete and cast him to a water
in such wise that ye body of him ne might never be found.

L. Another example of the death of neron. lvii.
AFter yt Neron had made to crucyfye saint peter and to beheed saint poule /
and that he had committee many other euylles for to make short he slew himself
with a sharp staff.

M. Another example of the death of Maximien. lvii.
AFter that maximien had made to sle and to martyr many crystyens toward
the end of his days he dysguysed him and would command to tyrannyse as a
tyrant. And he was pursued of constancyen his sone in law the which made him
to be taken hastily / and so fined his days as it is written in the legende of
saint Mauryce. By these examples beforsayd it appears that the people of ill
life defyneth their days cursedly. Also those the which has dispysed and
persecuted god and his servants / god them shall punysshe and persecute at the
hour of their death. And shall be iuged and punysshed after that that they
have deserved. Vn^ psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua.

Apostasia.
A. Examples of people apostates. And first how Iulyen apostat the which
left the crystyente and persecuted the church / deyed by punycyon dyuyne.
lviii.
IT is written how Iulyen the apostat was in his chyldhode instruct in art
magyk and afterward was monk. And stole and took away from a woman three
pottes full of gold as tells master Johan beleth. More over he left the
relygyo^ and yode unto Rome. And in the end did so much that he was emperor
of ye cite of rome / as well by money as otherwise he did many ylles and
persecuted the church. Also he fined his days ylle. For as he yode in arms
in battle he sent unto saint Basylle bishop yt he should provide him of his
necessytees unto him and unto his host. He answerde that ye things of the
church was not his: but gods. Than ye said Iulyen was angrye and swore yt at
his return he should dystroye his church. and the said bishop trusted in the
keeping of our lord Ihesu crist and of the vyrgyn Marye put him in fastings /
oraysons and almesdedes himself his clerks and his people in requyrynge their
aid. And as the said bishop was in orayson in his church requyringe aid of
our lady / he was rauisshed in spyryte before ye trone of god / where he herd
ye vyrgyn Marye yt complained her unto her sone of ye dystruccyon of her
church. And god demanded which was he yt would venge the iniurye of his
mother. And incontinent saint Mercure martyr yt was buried in ye church offrid
hy^ to do the said vengeance. Than he rose him from his tomb and armed him
and came in to the place where every man made him way / and with his axe of
arms stroke the said Iulyen apostat ye which took of his blood himself and
cast it toward ye sky and said. Thou have vaynquysshed me nazareth / you
haste vaynquysshed me. And so deyed myscheuously / and his host fled The
said bishop told by order ye said vysyon unto his people and for token of
troth they ne found saint mercure in his sepulcre the which was open / ne
his armoure the which hang in ye church. And after three days all was found
in their places And those the which came again from battle told the truth
of the deed. And they all yielded thanks unto god the which delyuereth all
those yt have trust in hy^ as it is written. eccle.ii. quod nullus sperauit i^
dn^o and confusus e^. and david says. In te speraueru^t patres nostri
speraueru^t and liberalti eos. That is to say there is none yt has hoped in
god yt is confused. Also for trust you haste delivered our faders.

B. Another example of Theophylle ye which was apostat / worshypped the devil
renounced unto god and unto ye vyrgyn Marye / but he repented him and after was
saved. lviii.
IT is written in the legende of our lady that Theophylle desired to be vycayre
and rectoure of a bishop / and for to come unto his entencyon he yede to seche
the counsayll and aid of a cursed Jew hebrewe sorcyer the which led him
unto the sabbat of the devil. And so much ill he counsaylled him that he
drew him to do ye will of the enemy / and that he was apostate / worshypped
the devil / renounced god and the vyrgyn Marye / and betoke hy^ a lettre of
his hand. After yt the bishop found him so much tempted and prycked that he
constytuted ye said Theophylle to be his vycayre general. And when he had
reigned an espace of time by the grace of god he reknowleged his fault /
repented him and did penance / and came before the image of our lady and
wept and waylled his sin by day and by night / and continued in fasting and
oraysons to require the aid of the glorious vyrgyn Marye / the which appeared
unto him / that should be a long thing to tell / but for to be short she
gate his grace and was mean yt all was pardoned him. And yt the lettre wherein
he was bound unto the devil unto him was restored. Also yt he showed before
the said bishop in great congregacyon of people al ye case by order how it was
done. And anon after he deyed in good consummacion and is of the nombre of ye
saved. By this example is to be understand yt there nys in the world so great
sinner but yt he may have salvation if he will come again unto god and do
penance here. Vn^ ysaie. lv. Dereli^quat impius via^ sua^: and vir n^quus
cogitaciones suas and reuertat ad du^m and miserebit eius.

C. Another example of a monk ye which renyed god / his baptysme / and
purpose of monk / after he repented him / did penance and was saved. lviii
IT is written in ye life of faders how a relygyous was tempted of fornycacyon /
ye which loved to much ye daughter of a priest of ye ydoles yt he demanded
herto wife / which priest gaynsayd him till he had spoken with his gods. Then
he spoke to the devil yt told him if he would renye his god / his baptysme /
and the purpose of monk than give her unto him. / The said priest told it to
ye monk yt was content to renounce unto ye three things beforsayd. And
inco^tynent he saw a white douue going from his mouth ye which flewe into
heaven. And the priest returned to ye devil and told him he had promised him
to renounce / shall I give her unto him / and he said nay / for his god is not
yet departed from hy^ but him aydeth. When the said relygyous herd yt he had
great repentance / and told his case unto a good fader yt bad him fast three
wekes contynually / and he should pray for him. At the end of the first weke
the good fader him demanded. Have thou any thing seen. and he answerde I have
seen in ye sky a douue fle over me / and at the end of the second weke. He
said he had seen the douue fle after him. And at the end of the third weke he
saw her come over him and entered in to his mouth / the which denotes yt he
had done all his penance for the renyenge of god / and yt god hy^ had
pardoned. By this example a man may understand that grace and virtue depart
them from the person the which renyeth god. or synneth mortally. Also a man
may know that grace comes again unto sinners / when they repent them and do
penance. etc.

D. Another example of a bisshoppe the which renyed god for to escape ye
torments of the incredules / the which repented him afterward did penance
and was saved. lviii.
IT is written in ye life of faders how a good fader walked.xvii. days by a
country of desert for to se if he should find any the which served god. And
he found a little habytacle. And by it a tree of palm. And a man being there
the which had great here / and the berde white of age the which covered him.
And he was poorly clothed. Also he was of terryble look. When he saw me he
yode in orayson / and when his orayson was fined he did know that I was a man
took me by the hand and axed me how I was comen theder / and whether the
persecucyons were yet in the world. I answered him that I was comen theder
unto him ye which served god for the grace of him. And how the persecusyons
were ceased by the puyssaunce of god. And I prayed him that he would tell me
how he was comen theder. And in weeping said unto me. I was a bishop / and of
the myscreauntes I had of persecusyons and torments. And for asmoche as I ne
might bear the said torments I renyed god and did sacrefyce unto ye falls
gods. After yt I reknowleged my sin and gave me in to this hermytage to
deye and do penance. And it is.xlix. year sith that I have been here in
confession and prayer yt god me would pardon my sin. I have lived of the
fruit of this tree ye god has given me. And I have not had of consolacyon of
my said sin till unto. / xlviii. years. In this year here I have had
consolacyon. When he had said these words here / he rose up and yode out /
and there was in prayer a long space of time. And when his orayson was ended
he came unto me / and when I beheld him I had fere / for he was as tire. And
he said unto me dread not god has sent the heder to the end that thou bery my
body. And wha^ he had spoken these words / he stretched out his hands and so
deyed. And I dyspoylled my robe I cut the half / and with the one party I
covered wrapped / and beryed the holy body and with the other half I covered my
body. And incontinent the said tree waxed dry. And his habytable fell down.
Than I wept strongly and prayed god that he would lend me the said palm.
And how in yt place I should persevere ye remenau^t of my life. And I knew that
it was not the will of god I returned in to the world and showed this thing.
Many things be to consider in this example. First a man should understood
that if the said bishop had not repented him correct and amend he had be
dampened. Secondly a man should consider ye by penance he was saved. Thyrdly it
is to consider the great austeryte of life / as to ete but one fruit / and
not to lie in bed / ne to have of clothing ne co^solacyon of person / and
to be so long time as is.xlviii. years without having reuelacyon ne
consolacyon of his sin. etc.

E. How a christian man lost the crown of glory by that that he renounced ye
crystendome. And a paynym wanne it. lviii.
THe disciple says in his sermons yt it is written how one time.xl. cristyens
were take of the myscreau^tes. The which crystyens were put in the time of
winter in a tonne of cold water there to suffer martyrdom. And as they were
in the said torment a paynyme saw by the suffraunce of god.xl. aungelles the
which held.xl. crowns over their hedes And in the end one of the said
crystyens said yt he renounced unto the crystendome by such condycyon that men
should take him out from the vessel. And incontynente yt he was taken out one
of the said au^gelles flewe in to heaven with one crown. And ye said paynym the
which saw this thing said. And I believe in him for whom these here suffer
pain. And he was put wtin the said tonne of water to suffer. And he the which
was taken out demanded hy^ who it was the which converted him so soon. Than
he told him by order that / yt he had seen. So he that which ne perseuered as
the other lost the crown of glory all be it that he had well begone. And ye
paynym the which perseuered with yt other had the crown eternell For to be
saved it suffyseth not to begin well / but it behooves to persevere. Vnde mathei
decimo. Qui perseuerauerit vsque i^ finem: hic saluus erit. Saint bernarde
says. I we ne that it is a good life to suffer ill / and to do good
operacyons. And so to persevere till unto the death.

F. Another example of a man yt gave ill counsayll for to make martyr ye
crystiens and make them renye their faith / and that cou^sayll redounded first
upon him. lviii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promtuarye how a master werker gave folysshe
counsayll unto a tyrant called Valeryen the which did do make a great bulle
of brass holowe within / and that the crystyens were put in that bulle and of
fire under for to torment them. And said ye their voices should resounde not as
men but they should below as bulls. The tyrant did do make it / but of the
ordonau^ce dyuyne the said werker the which had given the counsayl there was
first punysshed and put in by the said Valeryen for to here his voice how he
should below and braye. So the cursed counsayll that he gave came first unto
him before other as reason was after god and the scryptures Vnde eccle. xxvii.
Qui fodit fouea^ vt noceat proximo in illam decidet. Et qui statuit lapidem
proximo offendet in co: et q laqueu^ alio ponit peribit in illo facienti ne
quissimu^ consilium super illud deuoluetur et non agnoscet. Vnde veniat illi.
Et david in psalm. Lacu^ aparuit et effodit eum: et i^ cidit in foueam quam
fecit.

Exempla contra hereticos.
A Examples to confou^de heretykes / and first example how the deuylles kept
from brennynge an heretyke / but when ye hosty was there they might not keep
him. etc.
MEn find by writing in some books. Also ye dyscyple recyteth it in his
promptuarye and says / that as an heretyke the which should be brenned / ye
When he was cast in the fire he cried. / Help me / aid me. And incontinent
the deuylles drew him out of the fire. And he therein was cast again / and
the deuylles drew him out again. And in this hanging the good catholyckes
dysputed of the faith. And a good predycatour said unto the bishop. Make ye
body of Ihesu christ to be brought. When it was brought the said heretyke was
cast in the fire as before. He cried help me. And the deuylles answerde
appertly / we ne may: for a more great master than we is comen / and so was he
burnt / they ne might resyste again god almighty. Quia non erit impossible
apud deum omne verbum. Vt dicitur luce. i. ca. Also god is the strength of all
his people that says david. Vnde psalm Dominus fortitudo plebis sue. etc.

B. Another example how an heretyke was dombe by the virtue of ye faith. lix.
IT is written in the promptuary by the dyscyple this yt follows / There was a
faithful and devout christian man albeit that he was an ydiot. And an herytyke
mocked him of the faith yt he held. And wend to have beten him down / but
the said faithful christian man put him in oraison And lift up his eyes and
said before all unto the heretyke. I command in the virtue of the faith
crystyen that thou ne declare ne blaspheme any thing again it that is again
the faith. And forthwith he was dombe before all. And ye crystyens reioysed
them and the herytykes were all confounded.

B. Another example how a cautellous heretyke was brende of a fool demonyacle
MEn find by writing this the which follows how ye dyscyple recyteth in his
tro^ptuarye and says that there was an herytyke right cautellous the which
dredde to be sought and burnt for that that he yode again god and the faith.
And one demonyacle him vay^quysshed / and was led in to a church and bound.
And in that church was there a clerk posseded of the devil and bound / The
which clerk by the will dyuyne unbound himself in the night following And
when he was vnbou^de he assembled the mattes / the strawes and benches of ye
said church. And put them in a hepe upon the said heretyke. And the said
herytyke wend that yt woodman had played / and endured / and dyssymuled to
call aid unto yt that the said clerk demonyacle took of fire of a lamp / and
lyghted the said heepe of straw. Than when the fire was taken the said
heretyke began to cry. And at yt voice the gardyens of the church ran all
abashed / the which would quench the said fire. But the said clerk found a
glayue in the said church / and vyolentely chased the said gardyens out and
burnt ye said heretyke without any taryeng. And indede by ye judgment dyuine
that clerk was delivered of the devil. And appeared play^ly all hole heled.

D. Another example how the bishop of heretykes feigned to give light unto one
that was blind. lix.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says that a bishop of Arryens
named Cerula seeing that he was confounded by the reasons and dysputacyons of
the good catholyques he gave unto a man of his sect fyftye pieces of gold by
such couenaunte that he should feign to be blind and heled of the said
bishop. And Cerula passed in great company and excercyte of people of arms
and of bysshoppes good catholykes prisoners The said man took him to cry and
to say O ye my right verytable Cerula behold my blyndenes / and give me the
experyence of thy virtue. For thou gyuest the sight to the blind / the herynge
unto ye defe / thou helest ye lepres / and reysest the deed. Than Cerula drew
him a part / touched his eyes and said. After our faith that we believe
ryghtfully thyn eyes ben open and you see clear. Forthwith that he had spoke his
said words the eyes of the said accursed took them to swelle so horrybly that
they would out by great dolor / the which in cryenge dyscouered ye malice.
And he cried in casting the pieces of gold and said Here is thy gold and
yield me again my sight. Than the man used of good counsayll / and prosterned
him before the bysshoppes catholykes in weeping and denyenge the envy of the
arryens. Than saint Eugenye bishop made ye cross upon his eyes gave him
health and received his sight When the king saw this thing noted that his
sect was confounded / and that ye faith catholyke was exalted / made to
torment ye saints of god in diverse manners and incontinent the son wexed
derke / And the said king was posseded of the devil in such manner that he
tere him with his own tethe. And so fined his days by dygne torment. Chaton
says. Te^poribus peccata late^t and tpree parent. The sy^nes some times hyde
them but in time and place they appear. Also the gospel says that there nys
thing so bestowed and hid but that it be wyste and known / and that it ne
come manyfestly before all Nichil occultu^ est quoth no^ sciat: nec absco^ditu^
quod non agnoscat et in pala^ veniat. etc.

E. Another example how a simple bishop vaynquysshed an heretyke right great
phylosophre.
IT is written in the hystorye ecclesyastyke that many phylosophres gadred them
together to the end yt they should war again the faith of Ihesu christ. / And
among those philosophres there was one unto whom none ne might resyste / For
he soylled lightly all the arguments Than a simple bishop was moved agay^ him
and demanded audience. And these other crystyens the which knew his
symplenes dred yt he ne should fayll unto purpose / but for his holiness they ne
durst defend hyme. The which in arguyng with that phylosophre purposed yt
Ihesu christ had taught to eschew the fallaces dyabolykes and to believe in one
god / and in Ihesu christ his sone / and in saying all the symbol said unto
the phylosphre. Tell me if thou bileue so. Than incontinent as he herd the
faith coming out of his mouth he was enlumyned and bileued and said unto
those yt which were present. When I have herd ye words of the one and of the
other I have yielded word for word But when the dyuyne virtue was approached I
ne might ferthermore answer ne more again say unto the faith cristien but I
me consent I am enlumyned of ye faith.

F. Another example how by the penance and good example of saint domynyke he
converted an heretyke. lxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptu arye this the which follows / the
which is written in other books and says that as saint domynyk yode to
dispute again the heretykes with many relygyous and priests. And for as much
as they ne knew the way they demand it of a man and wend that he had be a
good catholyke / but he was an heretyke. The which said with good will I shall
show you the way / and so I shall led you till unto the place. Than he them
led through a forest / and malycyously them made so much to swerue and to go
out of the way / that he them led through the thorns and breres / so yt
their fete and thyes were fulfilled with blood. And saint domynyk bare it
pacyently and said unto them. And by a great ioyousnes admonested them to
praise god and to bear all pacyently / and said unto them. Right dear friends
trust ye in god that we shall have vyctorye / our sins ben now purged by
the effusyon of our blood. And that heretic the which regarded the joyous
and meruaylous pacyence of them. And the good words of the man of god repented
him and unto them declared the venim of his fraulde / renou^ced unto ye said
heresye and revoked himself afterward and demanded life louable.

Exempla contra fidem.
A. Examples of people yt have not ben steadfast in ye faith / and first example
of charmers yt in maste time charmed their hogs. lx
MEn find by wrytinge this yt w^^che follows / how ye disciple recyteth in
his book and says yt a man devout found the devil in a forest in man's
lykenes / he asked him what he did there He answerde I keep the hogs here
that has been charmed yt the wulues and cruel beestes ne devour them. And to
the end ye men put to faith unto ye said charmours and that they abide in their
erroures. I keep them in all dylygence.

B. Another example how a devil lied unto a noble man / and put him in error
wenynge to deceive hy^ in his death. lx.
SOme masters has written this ye which follows how the disciple recites
in his pro^tuarye and says that a man noble and puyssau^t with his people
passed through a forest by night. And he herd the voice of a woman singing in
like wise as she had be nere by him / and he said unto his servants / is
there any of you that will se this woman the which syngeth. And they ne would
go. and they said unto him that they ne would go. He theder yode all alone and
found her under a tree. The which was also as a black nonne the which song
holdyng ye hands toward heaven. And the said noble asked her what she did
there. She answered. I praise here my god / he byleued yt she was one of ye
holy women. He prayed her in saying. I pray the tell me what thing is to come
unto me. She answered thou haste done many ylles and yet shall do And after that
thou haste overcome thyn enemies / thou shalt pass the sea and thou shalt go
in to the vyage of Iherusalem / And thou shalt receive the cross and so
shalt thou deye in the service of thy lord Ihesu crist. When he had herd
these words he departed with great Joy. And as it was told him he
vaynquysshed his enmyes. And in awaytynge to goo over the sea he fell in to a
grievous sickness. Than his friends and the physicyens prayed hy^ that he would
confess him and repent him of his sins and to receive the sacraments for
the peril of death. He ne would in no manner. And said that he ne should die
yet. And as the physyens meruaylled the^ of this thing they called his brother
carnal the which was a great clerk / and told him ye peril of death and
that he should warn him of his health. When the said clerk had argued ye
seek. He answerde. Thou art also a fool as these other / for I know well that
I shall not deye now. And the clerk in weeping him demanded how he knew it.
Than he declared unto him that that the said woman had said unto him in the
wodde. And ye clerk was stryken of dolor in heart / said unto him. my dear
brother it was the devil ye which lied unto the ye which watches the and
taryeth to have the and to dysceyue ye now at thy death. Repent the think of
thy health and receive the sacraments. And without taryenge he repented him
demanded ye priest required pardon / confessed his sins / and the error
wherein he was / and establysshed his testamente / took the body of our lord /
was anointed and in good estate he deyed. And so men believe that he was
delivered from ye malice of deuylles And the said clerk brother of the deed
knew the bounte of Ihesu christ / entered in to relygyon in to the order of
prechers. And left in the world many of goods. etc.

C. Another example how a woman in error byleued in a bird the which is
called a cuckowe. lx
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says yt a woman was seek till unto ye death / and her daughter
said unto her. My mother send to seche the priest and confess thy sins. Unto
whom the mother said. What needs it I shall be hole to morrow. And when ye
daughter saw how she empayred she made ye neighbors to come theder / warned
her to confess. Unto whom she said. I shall not dye before.xii. years. for yt
cokow told it me. In the end she was dombe in such peril. And her daughter
made the priest to come with the body of god. And the priest demanded her if
she would any thing confess / she said alonely cokow cokowe. And so the
priest returned / and she so deyed. etc.

D. Another example how a relygyous in error byleued that he should live.
xxii year / and he ne lived but two year. lx
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye how yt a relygyous co^uers herd
sing a bird the which is called a cokowe. He nombred the times yt she sange
without ceasynge / and he found.xxii. the which he counted for as many of
years as he should live in this world. And said for certain putting to faith
yt he should live yet.xxii. years. More over he said wherefore shall I make me
leave in relygyon so long time. I shall return in to ye world xx. years. And
I shall repent me ye other two years the which ben yet to come. but our lord
Ihesus ye hates all deuyninges dysposed it otherwise / for he lived but.ii.
year / and was deceived. Saint poule says in his epystylles. It is impossible
to please god without steadfast faith. Sine fide i^ possibile e^ placere deo.
And therefore men should put to of faith in such things incredybles.

E. Another example how that there is mo of women than of men dampened.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary that one deuyne converted unto the
faith coniured one time the devil that he should show him of the which was
more either of men or of women dampened. The devil answerde that mo of women.
And ye deuyne said. How may yt be / for there ben many vsureres / rauysshers /
players / rybauldes / blasphematoures. etc. The devil answerde. It is as I
have said. And the deuyn constrained hy^ to tell the cause. He answerde that it
was for the sorceryes / and deuynynges / and how ye lightly they falsed their
faith catholyque Eve our first mother byleued more sooner unto the devil the
which spoke by ye serpent than unto god the which defended that they ne
should eat of the tree of ^ience of good and of ill. And by yt these women the
which believe to lightly go again ye faith and commandments of god. And by
that they go unto dampnacyon.

F. Another example how some prepayred the table unto deuylles because yt they
would enryche. lx.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that as saint germayn yode
to lodge in an ynne / he saw yt after souper men prepayred again the table and
he meruayled. And he demanded unto whom men prepayred such things. His
hostess told him yt good things sa^ there by night / to the end that they
should enryche them in temporal goods. And ye holy man waked by night. When
the deuylles were come in manes lykenes / and that they were set at ye table /
ye holy man suffered not that they yode cut of the house and yode to wake them
of the house and demanded them if they knew those persons there. They
answered that ye. And that they ben such and such. Than the holy man sent
them unto the houses of their neighbors for to seyf they were there and they
found them in their houses. When they had reported it unto the holy man / he
constrained the deuylles to tell what they were. And they confessed that they
were deuylles and that they deceived in such wise the men. etc.

G. Another example of a king ye which sent to seche counsayll of beelzebub /
and his messengers were burnt of the fire celestyall. And he deyed
myscheuously. lx.
IT is written in the first chapter of the.iiii. book of kings how the king
Ozochias was seek in bed. The which sent for messengers for to take
cou^sayll of belzabub god of Acharon. That is to understand if he should live
or dye of the sekenes. And the angel of god came unto the prophet Helye /
unto whom he said. Arise and goo thou before the messengers of ye king of
Samarye and thou shall say unto him. Is it not the god of Israel yt is to
understand unto whom ye should go to take counsayll / and not unto beelzebub
god of acharon. For this thing our lord has said from thens that thou art
mounted you shall not dyscende / but you shalt deye The said prophet made his
message: and the said messengers returned to tell it unto the king. And ye
said king said. why are ye come again. And they told how a man herye cladde
unto the raynes with a skin is comen again us. etc. ye which said it is
Helye. Than ye said king sent unto the said prophet a Capytayne and fyfty men
under him / ye which capitayn came unto him and said. Gods man ye king has
commanded that you dyscende. Homo dei. Rex precepit vt disce^das. And Helye
answerde. If I be gods man dyscende the fire from heaven and the devour and thy
fyfty men. And incontinent the fire dyscended from heaven and him devoured with
his.l. men And again the said king sent another capytayne with fifty men ye
which were burnt as the other in the same manner / and yet again the said
king sent another capytayne and fyftye men under him / ye which came before
ye said helye / yode on knees and prayed humbly / not as the two other ye spoke
proudely / and said. Man of god ne dyspreyse thou my soul / ye fire is
dyscended from heaven yt has devoured those yt have been sent toward ye before
me / and I pray the have mercy on my soul / and the angel of god spoke unto
the said prophet and said. Dyscende with him and dread thou not. Than he came
unto the said king with him / unto whom he said. For yt that thou have sent
messengers to take thy cou^sayll with beelzebub god of Acharon / as and if there
ne had be of god in Israhell of whom thou may axe a word. And therefore
from the bed wherein thou art mounted thou shall not dyscende but thou shall
deye of death. Than he deyed alter ye word of ye prophet. This example
denotes manyfestly how a man should evermore seche counsayll after god and
good maneres And so men should take heed to believe ylle counsayll in like wise
as says the saige Vnde ecclesiastici.xxxvii. A co^si^io malo serua ai^am
tua^. And by that yt these two first capytaynes the which spoke proudely in
saying / the king has commanded yt thou dyscende / is here to be noted yt
god punyssheth boweth down and dystroyeth the proud men. And exalts and
preserves the humbles as he bide the third capytayne the which humbled him
on knees and spoke humbly. etc.

H. Another example of a man the which gave himself unto the devil because
that he should enryche him. lx
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says yt a rich man came unto
pouerte and afterward submytted him of his good will unto the devil to the end
that he should enriche him. And the devil took him and baptized him in
saying. I baptyse the in the name of Lucyfer and of all the deuylles that thou
be ours in body and soul. Afterward the devil took him many rychesses and
said unto hy^ For as much as thou art ours you sholdest bear our token the
which is pride in clothyng and in all thy members. After that he had be in
such estate by some years it befell that he entered in to the church and herd
a predycacyon of the mercy of god / And afterward abode in the church
contryte and sorrowful of his sins. He fell prostrate unto the earth and
prayed god lyenge that he unto him would yield his grace / and that he would
correct all that that he had done. When our lord had seen his humylyte / his
teres / and his will that he would correct and amend his life / proffered from
ye altar and said. Arise thou up thy sins be pardoned the. Go and sin thou
no more. The which arose and with the great contrycyon that he had he was
changed that is as an ancient man so yt right few of his household knew him
more. The which did afterward so great penance and tormented his body by
correccyon that it was known that he had the life eternal. Our lord shows
his mercy unto sinners whiles that they benlyuynge in this world and shall
show till unto the judgment / but when ye said Judgment shall be come. He
shall show and do Justice unto the good and unto the ill.

I. Another example of a woman the which renyed the faith / slew her child
and betoke herself unto the devil / and after had mercy. lx.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promuarye how a woman had a husband the which
unto her was much contrary. For when he came fro the mass / From the market
/ from the tavern / he bet her evermore. And she took cou^sayl of an old
woman what she should do to the end yt her husband should love her. She
promised her to find the mean / and led her in to a garnyer When she was
there ye old woman called the devil the which was present incontinent. Unto
whom ye old woman said. This woman would serve you so yt ye make yt her
husband love her. He said yt he should do it with good will so yt first she
must slay her child yt she had. When she had slain it she returned unto him.
Ye shall do yet a thing / ye which is that ye shall renye the faith and ye
aid of god and of all the saints. And she said that she consented / and that
she committed her unto him both body and soul. And the devil said unto her.
Go ye now al assured unto your house / than she theder yo de Joyous. And her
husband came to beat her yt came from the tavern. And as he had be before
ylle and cursed / he was now more cursed. When she se that she was co^fused /
she took her to flee. And as she fled the devil ran after her in semblaunce
of her husband and in semblable habyte / and on horsbacke / unto whom he
said. And accursed whether go thou. She answered I fle before you. Unto whom
ye devil said / return anon unto thy house. For I promise the I will beat
the no more / nor do the ill. And so she lepte behind hy^ upon the horse / and
wend it had be her husbonde. When they were before the house / the devil
vanysshed away so yt she wist not where he was become. And her husband came
for to beat her. Unto whom she said. How fled I before you this day / and
that ye have brought me again. Ye have promised to beat me no more. When he
herd that she had fled before him he began again to beat her. And so bet
her so much / yt she was as at ye death. And as she lay half deed in wou^des
said. bring me a confessor / unto whom her husband said / she will now
confound me and say yt I have slain her / and defended yt none should goo
for ye priest. She ceased not to cry bring me a confessoure. In the end one of
her servants went pryuely to fetch the priest / ye which came at night
with ye body of our lord. But her husband locked ye door against him. And as
he was before the house ye woman cried unto him sayng. My lord at ye leest
here me thorowethe wall (and thus she cried) My lord I confess yt I have
slain my child / and have committed me unto the devil in body and soul / and
renyed the faith of Ihesu christ. And in great contrycyon of her sins yielded
up her spyrite. And incontyne^t god ye which is debonayre pardoned her all her
sins / and received her to grace / and made to bear her soul in to heaven by
his au^gelles. Her husband se that and the pressed and the presence by the
permyssyon dyuyne. And therefore these sinners should have ye eye to require god
the which is fader of pity / mercy and forgyuenes. etc.

Fides.
A. Examples of the faith / and first example how a mountain was put from one
place into another for to conferme ye faith catholyque. lxi
SOme doctors has written this the which follows how the disciple recyteth
in his sermons and says how in the town of a king infydele myscreaunte ill
and peruers came.v. bysshoppes cristyens the which assembled them therefore to
make a consystorye. For one party of ye people of ye town were crystyens And
by the counsayll of an infydele ye said king made to come before him the said
bysshoppes unto whom he said. Nere to this cite there is a mountain ye
lets ye the sea comes not nere / the which should be a great good deed if
the said mountain were taken away. And I can not find the mean to make it
to be take away. And I have understand yt it is written in your law that if
any has faith in your god as the sede of mustarde and that he say unto a
mountain yt it remeue in to another place yt it shall be done incontinent and
for asmoche as ye be the masters of the law I command you yt ye do make to
be take away yt mountain from thens it is / between this and such a day /
or I shall make you to deye. Than the said bysshoppes were sorry in saying
among them that better it was to deye than to make ye said request unto god
for to obey unto the commandment of the said infydele / and that he ne was
dygne that men unto him should obeyene do the said pleasure. And as they
waylled in awaytynge the death and the day and the hour that they should be
trod underfoot. A good crystyen simple man and shomaker demanded ye cause of
their heuynesses. Answer was given as it is said yt / that the king unto them
had spoken. And the said shomaker said Alas and shall our pastors and
bysshoppes dye the which unto us precheth / techeth keeps and susteyneth our
law. And he yode to make request unto god / and said in this wise. My god / my
lord / and my master if it be so yt I have faith in the in like wise as a
sede of mustarde after yt / that ye scripture speaks. I require the that the
said mountain be changed in to another place / and that our bysshoppes ben
kept from death. And incontinent ye said mountain was found in another place
than it was accustomed to be. And the said bishops were kept from death. It
is that ye which is written mathei. xxi. Amen dico vobis sihabueritis fide^ et
non hesitaueritis / and simo^ti huic dixeritis toll and iactate mare cito fiet
et oi^a quecu^que petieritis in oratione credentes accipietis. etc.

B. Another example of a priest a good catholyque the which entered within the
fire for to approve the faith / and he was not burnt.
MEn find by writing in the life of faders this ye which follows how the
dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt there was a devout pressed
the which found a great doctoure heretyke of the manychees the which
deceived the simple people. And for asmoche as that doctoure was strong to
turn and to take in words the devout priest said in herynge of all. Light a
great fire of wodde in the mids of the place. And enter we both within the
flambe. And he ye which of us both shall not be brent. men shall believe that
he has the better faith This thing pleased unto the people. and forthwith a
great fire was made. Than the priest took the heretyke and drew hy^ with him
for to enter into the fire. And the said heretyke said. It shall not be so but
every of us syngulerly therm shall enter. Thou shalt enter in to it first
said the heretyke / for thou have first imposed it. And he blyssed him and
entered in ye name of Ihesu christ in ye mids of ye flambe / and was there
half an hour / and there yode on the one side and on the other. And the fire
never hurt him. When the good christian people saw yt / they took them to cry
in great admyracyon and said. Mirabi^is deus i^ sa^ctis suis. That is to say
yt god is meruaylous / yt is in doing meruayles in his saints. Afterward
they began to co^strayne ye heretyke yt he should enter in to the fire / and he
began to resyst and to wtdrawe himself. Than the people took him and cast him
wtin the fire. And incontinent the flambe of the fire beset him about and
burnt him. And yielded him so half brent And the people cast out of their cite
the said heretyke with confusyon / and said ye seductoure brenneth living. And
they took the priest with them in blyssynge god / led him unto the church
with honor And so the crystyens were joyful / and the heretykes confounded.
etc. This example denotes that by the bounte and great faith yt the said
priest had he was preserved and kept from brennynge. And so had honor before
god and the world for puttyng him in danger of death for to defend ye faith
/ and so should we do. etc.

Humilitas contra superbia^.
C. Examples of humylyte of a holy no^ne the which feigned to be a fool / and
was scolyon of the kechyn.
Saint Basyll tells that in a monasterye of women / there was a vyrgyn the
which for the love of god feigned to be a fool. And where the other vyrgyns
were old and well ioconde / she lived sobrely. And she served all the other /
never a no^ne of forty ne se her eat / ne never sat she at the table / nor
never took she piece ne party of bread / but gadred the gro^mes yt fell from
the table and made clean ye pottes And of yt she contented her / she never did
ne said iniurye to none / she spoke verily tell / every body she fled as a
fool. And unto a holy man the which dwelled nere unto the said monasterye came
the au^gel of god unto whom he said. Thou wenest to be great / wylt you se a
woman more holy than you. Go unto such a monastery where thou shalt find one
of them the which has a crown upon the heed the which is more holy and
better than thou / the which fights again the people nere unto her and
night and day / and her heart departs not from god. Than he came unto ye
said monasterye and desired to se all the relygyeuses the which came with
great Joy unto the holy man and set them at his fete. And for as much as he
ne saw her for whom he was come / he said bring them all unto me there
lacks one. And they said that they should make the fool of the kechyn to
come. The which ne would come / for she knew the said deed by reuelacyon. And
they said unto her. Sctu^s pirus vocat te. Than she yode theder. And when ye
said saint saw her he fell at her fete and required her benedyccyon. Than she
gave it unto him. And also she required the benedyccyon of him. And the laid
relygyeuses had shame the which said unto him. Abbot do not that thing she
is a fool. And he answered them / ye ben all foles. Please it unto god that I
were found at the day of Judgment also dygne and worthy as she is. And when
they herd these words / they yode on knees to cry her mercy. When the said
saint was parted she might no more bear the glory yt they did unto her. And
she parted and left the house / wheder she yode / and how she ended her days
it came not unto knowledge for to speak of certain. But men presuppose that she
is saved. etc. This example denotes that for to be of the nombre of those the
which ben perfytely good. It behooves to despise the praise and honor of the
world and to have humylyte and pouerte as had the said woman. Unto purpose
of this example the holy scripture puts. Si quis int vos voluerit sapie^s
esse stultus fiat vt sit sapie^s. sequit. Sapie^tia huius mu^di stultia e^ apud
deu^. That is to say if any among you has will to be wise make himself a
scole unto the wisdom of this world the which takes head unto pride /
auaryce and vanytees. And he be sayge as unto god And fulfilled of grace and of
virtues for the gospel says that he ye which humbles him and boweth down
shall be lift up and honored in glory. Vnde mathei. xxiii. Oi^s qui se
humiliat exaltabitur and qui se exaltat humiltabitur. Et legit job. xxii. Qui
eni^ humiliatus fuerit erit in gloria.

Secundu^ preceptu^.
Blasphemia.
A. Examples of those the which has blasphemed and sworn god and his
say^tes vnprouffitably. And first of the sone of a woman of Israhell ye which
was stoned by the commandment of god for his blaspheme. etc.
IT is written in the bible in the.xxiiii. cha. of ye book of nombres that one
of the sons of the women of Israhell took strife and noise with a man of
Israhell / ye which sone blasphemed the name of god and cursed him. And
afterward was led unto Moses. His mother was called salumyth ye which was
proceeded of the ligne of dan. Moises made yt blasphematour to be put in pryso^
/ till men knew what god should command / for in ye time he spoke to moses
and said. Led the blasphematoure without the castelles and put they all their
hands upon his heed ye which has hard ye blaspheme / and all the universal
people cast stones at him and slay hy^ / and so was it done. And more over god
said to moise Say unto the children of Israhel that ye man the which has
said ill of his god shall bear his sin. And he the which has blasphemed
the name of ye lord shall deye of death / the multitude of people rebuke him
and slay with stones. Vnde leuiti. xxiiii. Homo qi maledixerit deo suo:
portabit pcim^ suu^. Et quiblasphemauerit nomen dn^i morte moriat: lapidibus
oprimet eu^ oi^s multitudo populi. Sith yt it is so yt god made to stone and to
sle the blasphematoures yt reigned in this world in the time of Moses. It
follows well that he shall punysshe them terrybly after their death if they
deye impenytentes. If men dread the punycion of this world / a man should yet
more dread the punycyon eternell. The person ye which blasphemeth iniuryeth
and says ill of his god / his king his Judge and master is not wise / ne he
ne may do well. For he deserves to have punycyon and to be pryued as was he ye
which was stoned the which is an example the which should draw back all
persons from blasphemynge god. If all ye blasphematoures the which regneth in
this world were stoned / many should be deed the which ben alive / but they
should dread to be stoned and punysshed in hell.

B. Another example of a child of the aege of five years blasphematour ye
which ye deuylles slew in ye lap of his fader.
IT is written in the fourth book of the dyalogue of saint Gregorye. That in a
cite there was a man known of all / and puyssaunt the which had a sone that
he loved to much carnally / and nourysshed hy^ to much softely without
correccyon. And that sone had of custom a thing ye which is grievous to tell
and to here / the which is that he blasphemed the majesty of god when there
came unto him any thing in courage / he was of the aege of five years. And one
day as his fader held hy^ in his lap / in likewise as many unto saint
Gregorye it wytnessed ye which were present. The said child saw come to him
the ill spyrytes that been the deuylles his eyes wept / he cried unto his fader
/ Help me defend me. And in cryenge he declyned his face and hid him in the
bosom of his fader ye which was abashed to se him in such wise tremble and
cry demanding what he saw. The child said the black men of moryenne ben
come the which will bear me away. And as he blasphemed the name of the
majesty he yielded up his spyryte. Saint Gregory says upon this example that
al little children the which speak ill a man should not believe that they enter
all in ye realm of heaven. For unto some little children the said realm is
closed by their parents / if they ben ill nourysshed. Vnde gregorius Omnes
paruulos qui iam loqui possunt regna celestia ingredi credendum non est quia
nonnullis paruulis regni celestis aditus a parentibus clauditur si male
nutriantur. After the scripture every person is bound to hold and to keep
the commandments of god in that aege that he may them comprehend. Statim
enim cum quis sit capax precepti dei tenetur ad eius noticiam et obseruantia^
distinctione. xvii Some ben more aduysed and sage in the aege of five years
than the other ne ben at.x. And by that that incontynente that the person may
dyscerne that he does good or ylle. And that he has dyscrecion for to
understand the commandments of our blessed lord Ihesu christ clearly / He
should accomplysshe them for that / yt they ben of necessyte of health. etc.

C. Of a player the which blasphemed the womb of the vyrgyn Marye and ill
came unto him.
IT is written in ye book of miracles of cleruaulx of two players after yt that
the one had lost he wrathyd him and had envy upon him the which had won And
for to satysfye unto his wrath / he began to refrain and say / hold thy
peace. Thou ne sholdest say ill. And incontinent he blasphemed god. And after
swore by ye vyrgyn Marye and to swear by her womb And forthwith a voice from
heaven was herd the which said. I have sustained and forborne mine iniurye /
but the iniurye of my mother I ne may forbere in no wise / And ^orthwith this
blasphematoure was stryken upon the table inuysybly of a wound vysyble and
apperynge and in gaspynge yield up his spyryte. Caesar says yt this is true.
This example should draw back al persons from blasphemynge god and the
vyrgyn Marye. For sith that the said man was in such wise punisshed in this
world cruelly. It is to presuppose that he is dampened and punysshed horrybly.
etc. It is written ecclesiastici. xxiii. Vir multum iurans replebit iniquitate:
et no^ discedet a domo eius plaga. That is to say a man swerynge much is
fulfilled with iniquite. And the plage shall not depart from his house. etc.

D. Another example of an earl blasphematoure.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the discyple recyteth in his
promptuarye / and says that an earl brought for the such blaspheme ayenste
god that he said ye would god or not he should have again his land / and
incontinent he fell from his horse upon ye which he was / and was tormented
horrybly. And after that the knights had lift him up again he fell / in
showing the pain of his blaspheme. and when he was brought again in to his
house he was strongly tormented in ye fete and in ye thyes / He dyspraysed
confession and in such wise deyed myscheuously four months after Also in ye
said book of the dyscyple is written of rybauldes ye which dyuyded a he^ne And
afterward by wanto^nes said / neither saint Peter ne Ihesu christ ne can make
it hole again. And forthwith they were lepres. These examples here should
draw back all persons to bring forth words blasphemynge god / for punycyon
and dampnacyon follows.

E. Another example of a burgeis of paris yt had his lips perced for
blasphemy^ge.
IT is written in the legende of saint Lowys yt one of the cytezyns of paris
blasphemed our lord Ihesu crist / but the said saint lowys king of france
made his lyppes to be perced with a hot yro^ by punycyon and for to give
example unto other. And because some pry^ces reproved him for this thing. He
answerde them I would with good will sustain in my lyppes that pain and
vnbesemynge whiles yt I shall live so yt this vice were out of my realm. and
yt no man should offend more. Unto the example of saint Lowys men should
reprehende and punysshe the blasphematours / for it is a sin the which
displeases much unto god and unto his saints. And those the which will go
into paradyse with them should correct the^ of that vice.

F. Another example of a dyse player yt was a blasphemer the which brake ye
arms of the image of the vyrgyn Marye / and he was posseded of the devil.
lxii.
IT is written in the miracles of the vyrgyn Marye yt some men played at the
dyse before the yates of the church of the vyrgyne Marye of ye monastery of
doul. And the one of them was wroth for that that he had lost / and began to
blaspheme the vyrgyn Marye / and to speak foully again her. And in the end he
turned him toward the image of the vyrgyn Marye the which was in stone upon
the yate of the said church / and in his wrath keste again that a stone and
brake the arms of the image. And incontinent the blood sprange out of it
fresshely. And the blasphematoure was posseded of the devil and was tormented
and expyred his days.

G. Another example of a dyse player blasphematoure yt the devil slew. lxii.
SOme masters has written this the which follows how the dysciple recyteth
in his promptuarye / and says that it happened in the realm of Frise in
patria la^ditie of a dyse player blasphematour / and thief the which used his
life in such things. And one time among other to abrege the matere after that
he had committee theft yode unto the tavern to play at ye cards with his
compaygnons and for asmoche as he lost he blasphemed horrybly god and the
vyrgin Marye. And incontinent the devil came unto him to whom he gave such a
stroke upon ye head that all the ioynctes from the members of his body were
dysceuered and departed and he dyed horrybly. Than his compaygnons fled the
which denounced the deed unto his fader / and that he should goo to fetch his
sone in a sack. And as ye said fader theder yode to fetch him / he yode
through the chircheyarde. And one of his neighbors deed seven year before rose
hy^ up and came to mete with him the which he knew and demanded him. Act
not thou such one deed of late / he answered yes. I am sent from god to tell
the that thou burye not thy sone in this chircheyarde with us for his soul is
damned and borne into hell for his sins. And god has suffered that the
devil has killed him. Goo in to such a place where he is / thou shalt find
him by such tokens that all his members ben departed from his body / the
which ben all stynkynge / and burye him in a place profane / and so was it
done. This example denotes three things. The first is that the said
blasphematour deyed myscheuously / and was punysshed corporally for his sins.
The second that his soul is buried in hell with ye dampened of perdycyon in
pains and torments. The third denotes yt the body of one dampened the which
is deed many festly in mortal sin should not be buried in holy ground with
the good christian men that be in paradyse.

H. Another example of a knight with one eye the which was enlumyned for that
that he smote a Jew that blasphemed the vyrgyn Mary. lxii.
MEn find by wryty^ge this yt follows / how ye dysciple recyteth in his book
of a knight with one eye the which with good will herd the mass of ye vyrgyn
Mary. And on a time as he herd salve scta^ pare^s he kneled on his knees. Wha^
(...) Jew saw him he began to mock him and blasphemed the vyrgin Mary. The
said knight ne might bear the injury yt he did unto our lady / but gave him a
buffet and entered into the church and herd mass devoutly. And ye mean time
the Jew yede to compain unto ye Judge / and he ne might tell other token of
him but yt he had but one eye When the people came forth from mass ^he said
knight abode and dredde. The vyrgyn Mary enlumyned him and commaun^ed him yt he
should go forth hardely. Wha^ ^he Jew saw him he said / if this man had ^ot
two eyes I should say yt he were culpa^le. And the knight said. It i^ I yt
smote the love of her that has restored mine eye / for whom I have prepared to
spend my body and my goods. When ye miracle was seen and known great
praysy^ges was there given unto ye vyrgyn Mary / and the knight allowed. etc.

H. Another example of two players at ye dyse unto whom there came ill for
swerynge and blasphemynge. lxii.
IT is written in ye book of honey flies that in a town of the parties of
Champayne a Jew played with a christian man. And after that the said Jew had lost
many penyes he was moeued by impacyence. In the end he recovered his loss and
wroth him against our lord Ihesus and blasphemed and cursed. And as he gadred
the dyse for to cast them his hand closed upon the dyse without being in power
to help himself. And tha^ne by cursed furour he was enbrased and enforced him
to smite the table whereon he had played with the said seek hand. Again he
blasphemed untruly Ihesu christ and his mother and forthwith he turned the eyes
overthwart and fell to the earth all deed. And the christian man yt played with
him for feere lost his wit / la^guysshed afterward and ended his days by
cruel death. etc. By this example a man may se clear that ill comes unto
players blasphemers. Also the death is evil as unto the body / it is to
presuppose that it is right cruel and terryble as unto the soul For in the
fire of hell they ben so much tormented that they have death without deyeng and
