without ending and defaute without defaylynge. And evermore in dye^ge they
shall live / And never dye they may not.

K. Another example how ill came unto king Semacheryb the which sent words
blasphemynges against god unto Ezechyas. lxii.
IT is written in ye.xxxvi. chapter of the book of Ysaie how king semacherib
was meruaylously proud for his great puyssaunce of people of arms and of
rychesses / ye which took many towns and castelles / and after came to
besyege Iherusalem / and king Ezechias was within. Unto the which Ezechias he
sent that he should deliver the town and to say unto him by great pride and
elacion. What is he of all the gods of these lands here the which has power
to deliver his land and his people fro my hand / as if he would say that none
had power to resyst against him and who is so great ye shall deliver Iherusalem
fro mine hand. And when ezechyas herd his words here / he cut his clothes and
clothed him in a sack / yede unto ye house of god / and sent Elyachym and the
ancient prestes clothed with sackes unto the prophet Ysaie to tell ye proud
words full of blaspheme against god yt the king Sennacheryb sent / and that he
was besyeged. etc. And the prophet Ysaie said unto the messageres. Illud
Ysaie.xxxvii. Hec dicitis dn^o vestro / ne timeatis a facie verborum que
audistis quibus blasphema uerunt pueri regis assirioru^. Ecce ego dabo ei
spiritum et audiet nuncium and reuertetur ad terram suam et corruere eum facia^
gladio in terra sua. etc. Say to your master that he dread not the words of
the said king. For to abredge this matter it is written in the said book of
Ysaie that the aungel of god struck and slew.lxxxv. thousand me^ of arms of
the said king Sennacheryb And those of Iherusalem came in the morning and
found the said deed bodies / and the said king Sennacheryb fled in to the
cite of Nynyue. And it was done that as he prayed his god in the temple his two
sons drew their swerdes and slew him in the said temple / and so he was
punysshed of his pride. And the said Ezechyas ye which clad him with a sack /
and the which humbled him was delivered. It is that / yt the gospel of matthew
speaks.xxiii. Oi^s qui se exaltat humiliabitur / et qui se humiliat
exaltabitur.

Periurium.
A. Example how a tauerner lost the use or speaking / for swerynge and
blasphemynge. lxiii
THe dyscyple recites in his book yt it is written how in the town of Cluny
there was a tauerne^ ill and of foul life. For when the people that yede to
dry^ke in his tavern paid not his will he blamed get and the vyrgin Mary and
spoke many vylayne words. So it happened yt a man told hy^ yt he had well
paid him that yt he ought h^^ Than the said tauerner swear by ye tongue of our
lady yt he lied and that he had nothing paid him. And incontinent by the
pun^cyon dyuyne his tongue lept fro his mouth and he lost the use of speaking /
and dyed horybly for the vile words that he had said of god / and of saint
Mary.

B. Another example of some children ye which swear / and in swerynge they
were drowned. lx^^^
IT is written in a book that is called mariall how a good woman instruct her
child to salve ye vyrgyn Mary. The which as he ye de with other children to
play they swear and stryued by a water side. The water flowed up the which
drowned them al in blasphemynge / and reserved him before said that our lady
took from the water and set him on her lap / conforted him and saved. etc. By
these examples a man should understand yt swerynges ben to fle / and that it is
great sin and case too swear vaynely. And to name in such wise god and his
saints vnlefully. Legit ecclesiastice.xxiii. In rationi non assuescat os tuum
/ multus e^^casus in illa sequitur nominatio dei non sit assidua in ore tuo
neque in omnibus factoru^ admiscearis quoniam non eris immunis ab illis / quia
omne iuramentum requitet a te.

C. Another example how the heed of a swerer turned that yt was behind before
/ and the cattes cried upon his grave after his death. lxiii.
MEn find by wryty^ge this the which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in ye
book of his promptuary and says that a young man wrothed him moshe / for that
yt he had lost at the playenge at the tenes. Therefore he began to swear and to
dyspyte god and the vyrgin Mary. And incontinent his heed was turned that / yt
was behind before / and his tongue lepte out of his mouth more than half a
foot / and three days after he deyed / and was buried in an abbaye. But every
night there came so great multitude of cattes the which made there so great
tempest that ye monks ne might take no rest / and this dured long time / so
long that finally it behooves to put him out of the chyrcheyarde / and ^kest
him in a dyche.

Vota.
D. Examples how a man should accomplysshe his vows. And first example how
the children of ysraell accomplysshed their vows after that they had vyctory.
lxiii.
IT is written in the bible in the book of Iudyth yt when the children of
Israel were besyeged of holofernes / and yt they felt great necessyte they
made vows unto god for to go in to Iherusalem for to make gifts and oblacyon
if it pleased him to deliver them. And it is written in.xvi. chapter yt after
yt they had vyctory and that Holofernes was slain all they yode in to
Iherusalem to worship god and fulfill their vows.

E. Another example of a vyrgyn yt vowed chastyte and after would be wedded.
lxiii
SOme masters has written this the which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in ye book of his promptuary / and says how a vyrgyn served faithfully in
chastyte the vyrgyn Mary / and bound herself by vow to serve her and her
sone Jesus christ in chastyte unto her death. And the devil of hell had envy of
her good operacions the which moeued the courage of a rich man in her love
for her beauty / and did so much that he demanded her in marriage / and
offered worldly glory / honor / rychesses / and every day he ceased not by
flateryes and promesses to draw her so to consent what more. The said vyrgyn
was so weary of the temptacyons of the ennemy yt she fell and consented to mary
with the said rich mortal man / and left the espouse of the king eternal
the which is Ihesu christ and the goods perpetualles for to have yt gods
transytoryes. The day of the weddynwas constytute and set. And the night
precedent ye day yt the wedding should be as she rested in the house of her
parents / she saw in her dreme as she slept yt she was rauysshed upon the
mouth of a well / from ye which proceeded so much stynke that it seemed unto
her yt the world was infect and undone. And also kest so great clouds of
smoke yt she thought yt all ye clerenes of the world was driven away / and all
boiled of serpents and worms and of souls tourmented. And as she meruayled
her of the horrible clamours of those the which were wtin ye tourmentes she
saw suddenly go forth of ye said well of these moryens of fire they ben
deuylles the which took without dyffere^ce ye souls deputed to ye tourments and
them plunged and kest wtin it. And as they drew ye said vyrgyn among ye other
for to be plonged there she looked on the one side and on the other as despayred
if there were any aid and saw a far of her ancient lady the glorious
vyrgyn Mary that turned to her ye back. And the which was for yt she might
not draw her back. In the end she converted unto her with all her heart / and
called her name and said. O lady think on thy handemayden constytute in so
great and bitter necessyte. And she approached more nere and said unto her. What
art thou. And she answered I am thyn handmayden / I have be evermore devout in
thy service and in thy memory. And she said / it is not so / thou art not mine /
for thou have dyspised me and my sone / thou art his that thou have chosen /
think on him and he will deliver yt. And she ne might bear the words and
said. O lady far of is he fro me / fro my heart / and fro my mind / deliver
thou thyn handmayde^ and defer it not. O dn^a iam absorbet me profundu^ / iam
vrget super me puteus os suum. And she excused her for to aid her and that the
enemies drew her without gyuynge unto her dylacion. The mother of pity Mary
the mother of god approached unto her / touched with her hand and took her / and
incontinent the enmyes fled far of / and durst no more look when they saw
the help of ye mother of god. Than she spoke and conforted her benygnely and
said. Here ben the fruytes of ye flesh / and the reward of volupt. Thou
know not that thou gyuest the to be cast in this deluge of tourment / fle it
now sith that thou have seen thexperyence / and draw the with all thyn heart
and with al thy might to recover grace and to serve me in time to come chastely /
and I shall help the by my prayers. Than the vyrgyn Mary departed and yielded
the soul / and so she awoke. The friends of the rich man were there the
which demanded what the man should do. And she answered / mynystres of death
depart ye far of / and in great indygnacyon she put them back. The parents
and all were troubled / unto whom and to al together she told all the thing
before said. And they left her fre when they had herd that yt she had showed /
and she returned unto her first purpose And with all her force she excercysed
her in penance and weeping for to recover grace of the glorious vyrgin Mary
and of her dear sone Ihesus. And after ended her days in good purpose. etc.

F. Another example of a man yt had made a vow the which was dampened. Also
example of rauayne and of the pains of hell. lxiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^tuary this the which follows the which is
written in other books and says that as man preched of the cross a carle
usurer bought again a vow yt he made to Iherusalem / and yode to ye
despensatour fraudelently and gave unto him for his said vow.v. li. and he
might well have given.xlviii. without to dysheryte his children. And as this said
carle sat in ye tauernes he said unto other the which had made vows. Ye
foles ye shall pass the sea in peril of your lives / and ye shall spend your
substance. I have again bought my vow for.v.li. And I shall abide sure of my
life in my house / and also I shall have as great mede as you. And on a night as
he was in his bed with his wife he herd in his myll moeuynge tempest as the
wheles gryndynge / and he said unto his sone. God se what is in the myll. The
child yode and returned anon by great dread and horror / of whom the
master demanded / what have thou seen. I have had so great fere at the myll
door yt I durst not tarry. And he said / if the devil be there yet shall I go
and se who it is. Than he kest his clothes upon his sholdres and yode unto ye
myll / he was all naked sauf only of ye said vestement. He opened the door and
looked wtin and saw to black horses / and a black man by them the which said
unto the carle. Haste the / lepe upon this horse the which is to the brought.
The earl feered / and the black man said. Why taryest thou / cast down thy
vestement and come. There was a cross on his garment. He was dyspeyred at ye
voice and calling of the devil and keste of his clothes and lept on the other
horse. and they were inco^tynent brought in diverse places of pains / in the
which ye cursed saw his fader and his mother in many other yt he had known.
And he saw a knight named He lie of the castle horste yt sat strydlynge on a
cow / and the back toward ye horns. The which cow ran on the one side
and on the other / and tourmented terrybly the said knight in smiting him with
her horns in the back. And the carle demanded hy^ wherefore he suffered such
pain. He answered. I have taken away this cow from a woman wydowe without mercy
/ and therefore she me tourme^teth sore. Afterward there was showed unto the
carle a syege of fire / and it was told unto him. Thou shall return now unto
thy house / and after three days you shalt come again in to this place here /
and thou shalt take thy reward in this syege After these words the devil
brought him again in to his mylle / and he found his wife and his meyny as
half deed / unto whom he told that yt he had seen and how it was comen unto
him. The priest was called for to confess him and to styre him to confession
and to have contrycyon. And he answered. What prouffyteth me these words here
I may not repent me / for I se that in vain I should confess me / and I know
that it is of necessyte to accomplysshe in me the thing the which is
dysposed. And the cursed man deyed in such wise without receyuy^ge the
sacraments of ye church. etc. They the which changes their vows should
take heed therein to make fraud as did ye said man and to mock other / for
punycyon and dampnacyon there follows. Also the rauysshers should well note
where punycyon and dampnacyon follows to take and to rauysshe the kyen or
other gods from their neighbors as was punysshed the said knight named
Helye. Also people obstynate ben to be blamed For if ye said carle had repented
him and confessed he had be saved / but for his obstynacyon he was dampened
eternally. etc.

G. Another example how a doctor yt had vowed and dyfferred to accomplysshe
his vow lost his sight. lxiiii.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a doctor greatly lettred and clerk after
that he had vowed to enter in to ye order of freres in the cite of melanke /
and that he unto them had assygned the day he was withdrawn of his scolers and
went into another cite to the end yt he should teache his science / and that he
ne se the said freres. And on that day yt he brake his promise he lost his sight
and abode three days blind At the last he reknowleged his sin and recovered
his sight and entered in to the order / and therein was devout and ended his life
in good consummacyon.

H. Another example yt it is peril to dyfferre to do his vow. lxiii.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a young man named Johan vowed that he
would enter in to the order of Cysterciences / but he was replenysshed with
slouthe and repented him. And instead of that vow he made his pilgrimage unto
saint in galyce James. And wha^ he had accomplysshed it he was received
honorably of his parents. And in his sleep he saw him ascyted before god /
with whom was saint Peter / saint Poule / saint James / saint Johan / and the
other. And it seemed hy^ that saint Peter held in his hand a fair book the
which our lord commanded to open. And he saw that the name of ye said Johan
was written in lettres of gold / and how our lord commanded that it were
scraped out. Than saint James fell prostrate before our lord and required him
that the name of his pilgrim were not put out / and out lord excused him not.
Than our lord reproched hardly unto the said John^ with great Indygnacyon that
he had contempned to accomplysshe his vow / and he commanded unto saint peter
yt he should scrape out his name. And saint James fell prostrate yet again
before god / and prayed him that the name of his pilgrim were not effaced ne
put out / in promyttynge for him that he would accomplysshe his vow wtin.xv.
days. Than the said Johan awoke fro sleep and yielded thanks unto said James /
and promised yt he should begin before the term And before the.xv. days he
entered in to ye order of cystercyences / and was so good afterward that he was
abbot and bishop of Valence where he did many miracles and fynysshed his
life. etc. This example denotes yt those the which repent them to have
vowed or that ne will accomplisshe their vows ne shall be of the nombre of ye
saved / if they in such wise deye without amendment. It is here understand
by yt that god made to efface his name out of the book of life. And that / yt
saint James prayed for him denotes that pilgrimage is agreeable / when any
does in the honor of any saint and remuneracyon there follows For the said
man was saved by the prayer and mean of saint James. etc.

I. Another example how a priest the which would not accomplisshe his vow
ended his days ill. Also of his Judgment and of his punycyon. lxiii.
IT is written in the book of Peter of Cluny yt a priest committed many sins
the which as he was warned many times of ye pryour ot bonneuall that he should
amend his life / yt he should renounce ye world / and that he should enter in
to thordre of relygyon. The which priest vowed yt he therein should enter / but
he accomplysshed not his vow / and suddenly he began to b^ seek / and sent for
the pryour. When he was come he warned him to accomplysshe his vow without more
dyfferrynge / and he began to cry suddenly. O fader pray for me. For two
beres comes to devour me. Than the said pryour with them present prayed for
him and forthwith he was delivered / and yet he accomplysshed not his promise.
And again he began to cry that men should pray for him / for the fire did
run unto him for to devour him / and he was delivered again at the prayers
and requests of the good man. And yet he contempned to accomplysshe his
promise and vow / and as despayred he was rauysshed in the Judgment of god /
and herd that sentence was given against him for his sins / and for the
brekynge of his vow. And he was inco^tynent brought again unto the place fro
whens he had been rauysshed / and told these things the which he had seen
and herd and that he had no more hope of health. And he put to and said. Here
ben to deuylles the which bears a fryenge pan for to have me fried wtin it
by perdurabylyte. And as he said the said word a drop of the fryture fell
upon his hand the which devoured him unto the bones before all yt before him
were the present / and than he said. Believe ye now that here ben the deuylles
the which casts me in to the fryenge pan. And in spekinge these words he
departed and ended his life without correccyon. etc. By this example a man
should denote that he ought too accomplysshe his vows and hy^ correcke and
amend while that he lives for to escape punycyon / and to have saluacyo^. The
said priest was warned of the holy pryour / and for that that he would not
correcke him he was dampened with the deuylles.

K. Another example of a carle the which vowed a cow and her calfe unto saint
Myghell and he accomplysshed not his vow. lxiii.
IT is written in some books. Also the dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary and
says how a carle led his cow and her calfe unto the mountain of saint
Myghell fered of the peril of the sea for the wawes of the water came unto him
/ and in cryenge he said. O saint Myghell help me and deliver me / and I shall
give the my cow and the calfe. And when he was delivered he said. Saint
Myghell was a very fool to wene that I should give him my cow and my ealfe.
And again the wawes of ye water came unto him / and yet he cried and said O
good saint Myghell help me and deliver me / and I shall give the my cow and
my calfe. When he was delivered he said. O saint Myghell thou shall neither
have cow nor calfe. And as he was so as assured the wawes of the sea came
again the which englouted him / and drowned him and his cow and calfe.

L. Another example how some Jews made a folysshe vow for to slay saint
Poule. lxiii.
IT is written in the.xxiiii. chapter of the deed of the appostles that mo
tha^.xl. Jews vowed and made an oath that they should neither eete nor drink
till that they had put saint Poule to death. And they departed and went to
tell unto the prince of the priests that they had vowed by devotion not for
to ete nor drink till that they had put to death ye said saint Poule. And
that he should make the said Poule to come before him for some cause. And ye
sone of the sister of saint Poule the which herd their malycyous counceyle
went and told it unto saint Poule the which found the means for to escape
and eschew ye cursed intencyon that they had conspyred against him. And than
he was led and conduyted by night out of their bounds and frauds. etc.
Almighty god delivered his servant from the hands and touchementes of evil
people / the which had made cursed vow and oath ye which they might not
accomplysshe as reason was. etc By the examples before declared and showed it
euydently appears that all manner of persons ought for too keep them well
from swerynge / from blaspheminge / and fro brekynge the vows justly made for
the love of god for to escape dampnacyon / and also to have salvation.

Tercium preceptum.
Operatio.
A. Examples of the^ the which has broken the festes commanded. And first.
Example of a man yt moses made to be stoned for that yt he gadred wood on the
holy day. lxiiii.
IT is written in the bible in ye.xv. chapter of the book of nombres yt a man
of the children of Israel was found gadrynge wood on the day of the feast
commanded He was taken and given unto Moses and Aaron the which made him to
be put in prison for that yt they knew not what they should do. And god said
unto Moses the words the which follow. Morte moriat homo ista obrua^t eu^
lapidibus oi^s turba extra castra. That is to say / this man shall deye of
death / all the company of the people cast stones at him / and let him be
broken and slain without the castles. And thus was done ye commandment of
god. By this example a man should know ye it dyspleaseth to god to work on
the feast commanded. It was a little thing as to gadre wode / but it is a
great thing as to break the commandments of god yt says. Keep and sanctyfy
the feast without werkynge thereon. By this that god commanded that he were
stoned / slain / and punysshed is to understand that so shall be those the
which break the feestes / in likewise as god says in ye holy scryptures. Vn^
psalm. Si iusticias meas prophanaueri^t et mandata mea non custodieri^t:
visitabo in virga iniquitates illorum. et in verberibus pcta^ eoru^. That is to
say. If the sinners have taken in scorn my Justices / and if they have not
kept my commandments I shall vysyte their iniquytees in rod and betynge
their sins. And the sage says. O ye cursed men maledyccyon unto you the
which have left the law of yt right hye god. Vnde ecclesiastic. xli. Ve vobis
viri impii qui dereliquistis legem dei altissimi.

B. Another example of a woman that was dyuynely punysshed for that yt she
sercled and closed her field on the fest of saint Johan baptyst. lxiiii.
IT is written in the miracles of saint Martin yt as a woman closed her field ye
day of saint john baptist wha^ other were at mass When she began to be besye
her hands were taken incontinent with the fire dyuyne / and her vysage was
enbrased as it had cast flambe of fire / and all her body and her members were
replete with bladders brenny^ge and pryckinge / so that the cursed unhappy was
bound not alonely of dolor of body / but with yt of dolor of shame when it
was so yt she must needs declare her sins This example should withdraw all
persons fro work on the holy day / and ought for to warn too sanctyfye it.
For when a man does thereon operacyon he breketh ye commandment of god / he
synneth mortally / and he byndeth himself unto punycyon and dampnacyon / and
also it puts him from the Joys of paradyse / and from the vysyon of god.

C. Another example of a man yt wrought on the sunday. lxiiii.
IT is wryte^ in ye miracles of saint Martyn how a man made his hedge on ye
sunday / his hands harded them in the wood and he drew back strongly his
right hand / but the fyngers fastened them unto the palm / and was in great
dolor by.xl. days. And afterward by the merytes of saint Martyn he was heled.

D. Another example of a man the which carried hey on the sunday. lxiiii.
IT is written in some books / also ye dyscyple recyteth it in his promptuary
and says ye a man was led to se the pains of hell / and he saw as it had been
a carre full of hey and it was said unto him. There must needs as much hey be
brence on thy back for that / that thou have ladde hey on ye sunday And thou
know well it was defended of the priest. Afterward he was brought again
and did penance / and was confessed of his sins and was of right good life
after.

E. Another example of a man the which bare his whete on the day of the feast
commanded. lxiiii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that a carry led his whete from the feldes in to his
graunge on the day of the feast commanded. And by the suffraunce of god ye
fire brent all the said wheet and the graunge. This said man yede against the
scripture the which defends that a man should not bear charges on the day of
the solempnyte / that is of ye feast commanded. And that a man should put no
charges without his houses. Also that a man ne do operacyon the which should
let the sanctyfycacion of the feast. Vnde hieremie decimoseptimo. Nolite
pondera portare in die sabbati et oe^ opus non facies in eo. etc.

F. Another example of going unto the plough on the day of the feast
commanded. lxiiii.
ALso the dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye how Gregory of tours tells
that as a carle would plowe / that is to ere / he took with his right hand the
hafte or the handle of an axe for to make clean ye plough / but his hand was
nailed and harded in the wood / and two years after was heled in the church of
saint Iulyen by the prayers of the said saint.

G. Another example of two women the which baked their breed in the solempnyte
of the sunday. lxiiii.
IT is written in the miracles of saint Martin of a woman of the parties of
Angyers the which would bake on the saturday after the son going down. And
as she made the breed she was smyten of evil in such manner that her body and
her members became all dry. And in especyall her right hand and her fyngers
were more dry than the other me^bres. And afterward she yode unto the
sepulcre of the holy archebysshop saint Martyn of Tours and fell prostrate in
devotion and prayer. And at the last she had health by the merytes of the said
saint Martyn. By this example a man ought to absteyne him from work on the
holy days.

Another example written in ye said miracles of a woman the which baked on ye
saterdayes at night within the fast of the sunday / and as she put the breed
within the oven her hands were grievously seek / the which claue and took in
the hafte of the pele in setting in the breed. And when the said woman felt
that pain and punycyon took her she would have casten away ye said pele
hastily / but she might not escape the pain. And her said hands were crooked /
and the nails of her fyngers fastened them in the palms of her hands in such
manner that the leches said that she might not be remedyed. Afterward she went
unto the tomb of saint Martyn by great devotion and there was heled / and
vowed unto god and unto saint Martyn that she should goo to serve one weke in
every month in the holy place where the body of the said saint Martyn rested.
And she accomplysshed the said vow one year without faylynge it. And after
that year she left one weke of a month without going thither and doloure took
her in her eyes in such manner that in less than half an hour she was blind
of both the eyes. And afterward she confessed her of her neclygence to have
left the said vow / did penance / returned unto ye tomb of saint Martyn in
orayson and for to accomplysshe her vow / and her eyes keste blood and she was
enlumyned at the end of.viii. days. These examples here denotes that a man
should abstain him from work on the festes commanded / and that a man should
do and accomplysshe his vows / or else he shall be punysshed be it either in
this world or in the other.

I. Another example of baky^ge of breed on the day of the holy feast
commanded. lxiiii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows that the dyscyple recyteth in ye
book of his promptuary and says that a chorle baked his breed on the day of
the feast / and all the said bread was blody in token of offense made / and also
that the feast should be hallowed and kept.

K. Another example that god sends punycion upon those the which breketh his
commandments. lxiiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons that men find by writing that it
happened in ye country of England in a year that the corns came and grew in
great haboundaunce and were much fair. And when ye time to gadre approached
there sprange up a swarm of flies in great haboundaunce the which consumed
those corns in such manner that in five thousand pace of land with great
pain might a man find one quarter of corn. The men of the country took some
of those flies and beheld them dylygently / so that they found lettres written
on their wings. And on the one wynge there was written / ira / that is to say /
ire. And on the other winge was written / dei / that is to say / god. The
which sygnyfyeth that god was wroth against them for their sins and mysse
living and that by vengeance and punycyon all mighty god sent unto them the
said vermyn or flies.

L. Another example of two cordoyners of the which the one kept the festes
commanded / and the other would work always. lxiiii.
IT is written in some books this ye follows the which the dyscyple recyteth
in the book of his sermons wherein he speaks of two cordwyners of the which
the one had great multitude of children the which kept well the festes and
yode unto mass every day and habounded in great goods. And the other ne kept
feast ne work day / and ceased not to work day and night and had no children
and was much poor. And this poor demanded of the other from whens came unto
him his goods. And he answered / come with me in the morning in to the
church and I shall show the where I take them He came and they yede by three
mornings unto the church and unto mass. And after ye rich said unto the
poor. Go do thy work. And the poor said unto him. I wened that you sholdest
have led me unto a great treasour. I have none other place where I get the
treasour of the body and the reward of the life eternal than the church. For
god has said. Illud mathei. vi. Primum querita regnum dei et her oi^a
aducie^tur vobis. Go as I do unto the church and keep the festes and obey unto
god / and he shall give the of his goods. He yode confused / corrected him /
yode unto the church / and afterward had goods.

M. Another example of a mowyer the which ceased of mowynge on a saturday at
euensonge time / and his felawes did not. lxiiii.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuarye and says how that a knight made for to fell his
medowe. When it came unto the euensonge time that the belles range in ye
chyrches for the feast one of the fellers said unto his felawes / leave we work
for they ringe to euensonge it is time to cease. And they would not for him /
but confounded by words him the which them warned / and he left work and
yode unto euensong. On the third day he yode to make an end of fellynge with
his felawes the said meadow And for as much as the other yode before and that
he must needs fell the last all the other mocked him / and he bare pacyently
their mockynges and laughynges. And at the beginning that he put the hand
unto the sithe for to fell after the other he saw before him a great pyece of
gold the which hanged at the stumpe of a felled tree / ye which tree was of
great beauty and largenes / than he bowed his knees and thanked god. When he
cried the master of the medowe and his felawes ran^e and they saw the dyuyne
miracle. The knight the which was a clerk beheld the scripture and found
that there was in writing about the said pyece of gold. The hand of god has
made me and brought me in gift unto the poor the which has not broken the
day of the feast. And the knight bought yt pyece of gold of ye said poor and
showed it unto many in recountynge the said miracle. etc.

D. Another example how the sellers and the buyers on the holy day of the
feestes commanded ben gretely for too be reprehended. lxiiii.
IT it written in the bible. Neemie vltimo capitulo. how the prophet Neemie
repreued vyllanously those the which bare in to Ihesalem of lyuynges or
vytayles and the which there sold and bought on the sabbot day / that is on
the feeste / unto whom he said. Did not our faders this that ye do / and our
lord led upon us and upon this cite all ill / and ye bring again his ire
upon Israel in vylynge this feast. For to cease such marchaundyses and
operacyons the said Neemye made to shytte the gates of Iherusalem the day of
the sabbot / and constytued his servants upon the gates that none should bear
burden on the said day in the cite. And the negociatours and merchants abode
two times before Iherusalem with their marchaundyses wenynge there to enter. But
ye said Neemye thretened to lay hand on them if they came ones again: and so
they came no more on the feast day. This here is a great example for to keep and
to sanctyfy the feestes. Another example. It is written in ye.xvi chapter of
Exodi. how the children of Israel gadred in deserte the.vi. day double manna
by the commandment of god to the end that they should rest them on ye day of
the sabbot in gyuynge example that in ye feast men should cease and do none
operacyon.

Seruicium.
A. Another example of a rich man the which rode and went to worldly
occupacyons when they range to mass. Also he despised for too here the
predycacyons or sermons. lxv
SOme masters has wryte^ this the which follows how the discyple recyteth
in his promptuary and says yt there was a rich man of such condycyon yt wha^
he should go to mass he lept on horsbacke and went to se his manoyrs / his
mylles / and his corns in his feldes. And he was warned by his wife yt was
devout that he ne should do such things / and that he should go unto the
mass on the holy sondayes and solempnytees unto the church to the end yt he
might here some good in predycacyon. He answered. I know what I should do
better tha^ thy prechers. At the last on a time as men range to mass he lepte
on horsbacke / and as he rode in a field the devil ran unto hy^ and said.
Alyght from thy horse and here my mass / and the devil led him in to a great
dyche the which was there and keste hy^ in and descended with the devil in to
hell for to here the service of hell. etc.

B. Another example of a woman ye which would have hanged herself / and as
she herd knyll unto a sakerynge she kneled on her knees and was delivered from
danger. lxv.
THere is found by writing this the which follows how ye dyscyple recyteth
in his book of sermons and says that a woman was one time so heavy and
tempested of the devil that she prepared a cord and a place to hang her
self / and as she made an end of that she had begone she hard ryngynge to a
sacrynge / than she bowed her knees and put her in orayson for she had learned
to do it in her youth / and said. My lord Ihesus sone of the living god
have mercy on me. And incontinent the beme and the cord brake / and the
deuylles fled and said. The virtue of the presence of Ihesu christ has
delivered the from the death present and eternal.

C. Another example how the devil bare a book wherein was written the sins of
men and women / and in especyall a complyn that saint Austyn had forgoten. lxv.
IT is written in ye legende of saint Austyn that as the said saint Austyn
studied he saw the devil go before him berynge a book on his sholdre. And than
he coniured hy^ that he would show that the which was written in it. And he
a^swered that they were the sins of men that he gadered in all places and put
them there. Than saint Austyn commanded him yt if he had any of his sins in
wrytinge that he should give them incontinent unto him to read. And he showed
him ye place where he was / and found nothing in wrytinge but that he had
ones forgoten to say complyn. Than he commanded ye devil that he should tarry
there and he entered in to the church and said complyn devoutly and made an
end of his oraysons accustomed. And aftercame unto the devil whom he
commanded yt he unto him should show again the chapter where ye said complyn
was written. And he turned and returned the said place / and in conclusyon he
found ye said place void where it before was written. Than the said devil was
wroth and said that he had foully mocked hy^ / and yt he repented yt he had
showed him h^s said book. etc By this example men should understand that they
the which forgeteth or leueth to say their service that ye devil does not
forgete their neclygence.

D. Another example how deuyls were seen upon a woman's train pompyously
clothed. lxv.
CEsarius dicit. It is recyted in the book of the discyple how caesar shows in
his wrytynges that as a devout priest keste holy water on the sunday upon ye
people at the church door / there aryued a matron be seen and aorned of diverse
aornementes as a pecocke. And the said priest saw great multitude of deuyls
the which were upon her train the which was long and the said deuylles were
little as dormyse black as ethyopyens / scornynge with their mouths / strykynge
with their hands / and lepynge as fysshes do enclosed in the net. When the
priest saw them he called ye people and adjured the deuylles that they should
not fle. The woman was afraid and stood still. And the good Just man obtained
in orayson that the people might se the vysyon. Than the woman understood that
she was so beset about with deuylles for ye pride of her clothy^ge and returned
in to her house and changed her clothing. This vysyon was occasyon of humylyte
as well to other women as to her.

E. Another example how saint Bryce saw the devil write in the church ye evil
words that were said. lxv.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says how as saint Bryce helped saint Martyn to sing he saw
the devil yt wrote the ill words that two persons spoke in ye church. And
when al his parchemyn was written he drew it with his tethe to length it / the
which escaped him and struck his head against the wall / and the said saint
Bryce began to laugh. And when the mass was ended saint Martyn demanded him
the cause wherefore he laughed. Than he told unto him the deed. And in the end
and conclusyon the said saint Martyn knew that ye said thing was verytable.
Wherefore it follows that evil words ben to fle / in especyall in the church.

F. Another example how the devil encharged a woman for to do four things.
lxv.
MEn find written in the legende of the deed folk that a doctoure tells that
as a woman wydow despayred her lest she should be in pouerte the devil appeared
unto her and said unto her that he would make her rich if that she would do
after his will / and she accorded thereto. And he gave her in charge sour
things. The first was that she should make to do fornycacyon with people of
the church that she should receive in to her house. The second that she should
receive on the day the poor people for to lodge / and that in ye night she
should put them out without doing them any good. The third is that she
should let other of their prayers by her Jangling and talking. The fourth
was yt she should not confess her in none of ye things before said. And in
the end when her death approached her sone warned her that she should confess
her. Unto whom she discovered her deed / and said that she might not confess
her and that her confession ne should nothing prevail. And her sone began to
weep and warned her to repent and too confess her in promising her that he
would do penance for her. Than she had bitter contrycyon and purpose to
confess her and to amend / and sent for to seche ye priest by her said sone /
but or ever that the priest came ye deuyls came unto her / and for the great
horror of them she deyed. Than the sone confessed the sin of his mother unto
the priest / and did.vii. year penance. And when it was accomplysshed his
said mother appeared unto him and thanked hy^ of her delyueraunce and salvation /
and that by him she was saved. This example denotes pryncypally three things.
The first is that the devil counceyleth us to do ill / and to leave the good to
bring us to dampnacyon. The second that a man should correcke and amend him
by contrycycyon and confession how great so ever ye sy^nes be yt a man has
committed / and he shall have grace and mercy. The third is that the penance
and good operacyons that a man does for one that is deed avails to deliver
hy^ fro the pains of purgatory. etc.

G. Another example of a monk that ye devil drew out of the church when y^
other prayed. lxv
Saint Gregory tells in the second book of his dyalogue yt an abbot named
Pompeianus might not correcke one of his monks yt in the time that the other
waked in orayson he went out of the chryche and yede unto vanytees. The which
abbot wrote the case unto saint Benet to the^de yt he should correcke hy^. Than
ye said saint Benet yode unto the monastery and saw vysybly the devil in
lykenes of a black man yt drew out the said monk by ye plytes of his
vestement. And for as much as the other relygyous saw not the said devil the
said saint Benet said unto the^ that they should goo to prayer / and that they
ne should cease to pray god till it pleased hy^ yt some of them might se him
that drew out the said monk. Than they all put the^ in prayer. And when they
had been so by.ii. days saint Mor relygious of the said monastery saw vysybly
the devil the which drew out the said monk with saint Benet. And the said
abbot Pompeianus and the other relygyous might not se the said devil. Than
saint Benet bette the said relygyous / and so he was correct / and the devil
came no more. By this example a man may understand that they the which hold
them not in orayson when they should be bound of necessyte of health / and
have not excusacion but for to go unto vanytees that it is the devil the
which them draws out to the end that they lose the fruit of prayer.

Sompnolentia.
A. Examples of slepynge in herynge the service. And first example of a monk
without devotion the which slepte in orayson. lxvi.
IT is written in the dyalogue Cesaru that there was a monk priest of ye order
of cystercyences called white monks the which lened him upon a syege or
stalle and slepte when the other relygyous were at ye psalmodye and in orayson.
The which thing so much dyspleased unto god that he would show unto him
that in such a place and such an hour he should not sleep. And it befell that
many times when the said relygyous came to pray before the crucyfyxe the image
turned the back unto him / and in denotynge for that yt thou art slouthful
and neclygente in such orayson thou art not worthy to behold my face.
Himself wytnessed that he had seen the experyence of the said thing. Wherefore
men ought to be fervent in prayer.

B. Another example of a monk yt was smyten with the knot of a straw in
slepynge for yt he was without devotion and weyke in spyryte. lxvi.
LEgitur i^ dyalogo cesaru. There was an ancient relygyous the which was
accustomed to sleep in the service time. It befell yt at matynes on a night as
he did sleep at the psalmody he saw in a dreme before him a great man long /
black / and defourmed the which held in his hand a dyrty straw. The which
as he beheld ye said relygyous / and after that he had said wherefore slepest
thou so all ye night he smote him in ye vysage with the said straw. And the said
relygyous the which had so great dread as no marvel was a woke. And to
the end that he might avoid the stroke of him yt smote him he smote his heed
against the hard wall. etc.

C. Another example of a slouthful monk unto whom ye devil gave hot
brennynge pytche for to drink lxvi.
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that a monk had a custom for to sleep. And it befell
that as he slepte in the quere at the lauds he saw in dremynge a devil right
terryble the which had a ladle enbrased with fire and pitche molten within it /
and came to vesyte every monk for to know if he slepte. And unto some yt
slo^bred he offered in a spone of iron of the said pytche. And when the said
devil came unto the said relygyous the which slepte / and that he unto hy^
had offered the sponefull of pytche in fyndy^ge it hot he withdrewe suddenly
his heed and smote himself sore against ye lenyng of the syeges that he found
himself sore hurt. etc. These example here denotes that god would show that
it him dyspleaseth when a man slepeth in the service of god. And those the
which slepeth ben worthy of punycyon. Tempus est orandi / te^pus est
dormiendi. etc. Oi^a tempus habe^t et in suis spacus tra^seunt vniuersa. There
is time to pray / and time to sleep. All things have their times / and al
things also passes in their spaces of times. etc.

D. Another example of a relygyous the which swette in ye morning at the
matyns. lxvi.
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that ye devil made to come unto a monk a sweet
fantastycall in the morning / and counceyled him yt he should not arise. And
many times he lost matyns wenyng that he swette in the morninge by sekenes. And
for as much that one time he would have risen the voice of the devil was
herd all on hye the which said unto him. Rise thou not / break not thy sleep.
So he understood yt the devil made him in such wise sloth full / and to lose
to do ye good deed / and correcked himself. etc.

Oration.
E. Examples of prayer. And first how a man should take heed to the prayer that
he makes. lxvi.
IT is written in the life of the faders that a relygyous complained him one
time unto a good abbot that they were tourmented in their quarter for the
dryenesse for it rayned not there. And the good abbot said. Why goo ye not unto
prayer. And he said / we cease not to pray / and it rayneth not I believe yt ye
pray not ententyuely. That is to say that ye pray not devoutly entendynge unto
your prayers. Wylt you se that it is so / goo we unto prayer. He stretched his
hands unto heaven in orayson / and inco^tynent the rain descended from heaven
his boundau^tly. Than the other had great marvel / and knew yt the prayers
were not made of heart and devotion.

F. Another example of a devout relygyous the which ceased not to be in ye
orayson of the psalmodye / and good odoure issued out of his sepulcre.xiii.
year after yt he was deed. lxvi.
IT is written in the book of the dialogue of saint Gregory that there was a
relygyous named Merry much devout / the which was a gyuer of alms / wept
often / and took head so much unto the psalmodye in orayson that he ceased not
at any time but alonely when he drank and ete / or when he slepte. And this
said relygious had a vysyon in the night the which appeared unto him as a
crown of white flowers descended from heaven on his heed. And hastily sekenes
corporell took him / and with great surete and Ioyousnes of courage he deyed
and was buried. And.xiii. year after as the abbot of the monastery made to
prepayre in that place his sepulture so much of good odoures and swetenes
issued out that it seemed that the odoure of all good flowers were there
assembled / in likewise as that abbot wytnessed to have smelled. etc. This
example denotes that orayson well made much pleases unto god when the deed
body the which naturally should stynke kest good odoure. Dauyd says in the
psalter. Dirigat dn^e ad te oration mea sicut incensum inconspectu tuo. That is
to say. O you my lord dyrect mine orayson and prayer in thy sight in likewise
as ensence. When ensence is put upon the coals of fire it casts a good odoure
and smoke the which mounteth unto heaven toward god. Also orayson and prayer
well made and embrased upon the coals of devotion is a good odor the which
mounteth on high before god the which makes to have great reward in
paradyse. etc.

Gula.
A. Examples of drinking when men should serve god. And first example how a
nonne the which ete letuse before that she served god / and without making ye
sign of the cross was posseded of the devil. lxvii.
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint Gregory that a maiden entered in to a
gardyn the which be held and coueyted a letuse / she forgate to make the
benedyccyon and sign of the cross and ete glotonously ye the said letuse /
and incontinent was posseded of the devil and fell unto the earth in the said
gardyn. And as she was strongely tourmented it was showed unto a holy man named
Equycius the which came to pray for her and to socour her the which ye de
thither and entered in to the gardyn. And the devil the which was in the said
maiden began to cry by her mouth and said What have I done. I set me on a
letuse and she is come and has eten me. And ye man of god commanded him that
he should depart and that he had no more place in the servant of god / and
forthwith he departed without power to do her any more evil and grefe. etc.

B. Another example that evil came unto a conuers the which drank wine in
the cite without license / and without making the sign of the cross. lxvii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book yt it is written in a book how a friar
conuers was right grievously tourmented of the devil in a conuet. The freres of
y^ convent arose them up for they were laid / and called their master saint
Domynycke ye which was at that time in the house / the which sent that he were
brought unto the church. And with great pain.x. freres brought him. And in
entering in to the church with a great blast he put out all the lamps in the
church that there were brennynge. And as the devil tourmented him in many
manners saint Domynycke said unto ye devil. I the conjure from Ihesu christ that
thou you tell wherefore thou tourmentest this friar here. And when and how thou
art entered in to hy^. The which answered I tormente him for he has deserved
it. He drank wine yesterday in the cite without having license / and without
making the token of the cross. And in drinking I entered in him / that is he
drank me with the wine. After these things matynes were ronge. And the devil
said. I may no more tarry here sith that these hoded folk arise to praise god.
And the devil departed fro the friar and left him as deed lyenge upon the
earth. And the freres bare him in to the fermoury. When the morning came he
arose all hole and wist not what was come^ unto him. He the which wrote this
miracle herd it told of one of those the which at that said time was
present there in the abbaye.

C. Another example of a smyth the which waked to drink and to ete when ye
other waked to serve god. lxvii.
THe venerable Bede tells in gestis angeloru^ in libro qui^to how a smyth had
of custom to drink and to ete and to be dronken when the other waked in ye
church at service. And on a time there came unto him a sodeyne sekenes in the
which he was warned to repent him / to confess and to do penance. The which
as dyspeyred began to cry that he might not repent him. For in likewise as
saint Stephen saw heaven open so he said that he saw hell apertly / and a
place of tourmente the which was made ready nygh unto the place where as were
Pylate / cayphas / Judas and ye other the which made our lord Ihesus to deye
/ and afterward told what ye Judgment of him was made / and yt he should never
have hope of health for the great contynuacyon of dronkenes that he had led
And when he had told this he deyed and was put from sepulture ecclesyastycall
and from all prayers. etc. This example here is good for those the which
leseth the masses and the seruyces of the church for to be waiting in
tauernes and potacyons by that yt the said smyth would not wake at ye
sanctyfycacyons of the feestes and in the service of the church / but despised
them. In likewise god would that he were put at his death / and fcom the
prayers of the church and from sepulture ecclesyastycall / and from all good
and honor. And by that yt he said that the Judgment of him was made and that
he saw ye tourments the which was made ready unto him should understand these
dronken and slothful people to go to sanctyfye and to honor god in
solempnytees commanded yt the Judgment partyculer shall be made of those at
their death and that they shall have there punycyon after their deseruynge.
Vnde psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua. And god suffered that he spoke
the said words to the end that his semblables thereby take example and head.

D. Another example of a man yt yede t^ play and to drink at the tavern with
his felawes when he should wake in the service of the church. lxvii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says that in ye time of a devout bishop
named Cyryllus there was a young parent of the said bishop Cyryllus named
Ruffus dwelled with him as a servant. And when the bishop sange mass the
said Ruffus yode unto tauernes to play with his felawes. So it befell that he
was seek and deyed After that he was deed the said cysshop required ye people
the which unto him were subgecte that they would make prayer for him / for he
loved him much and was well loved of the people. And one day after that the
bishop had song for his soul as he was in devotion and orayson the said
deed body appeared unto him all in fire and in great tourment. And he demanded
hy^ what he was. He answered. I am ye soul of thy cosyn for whom thou prayest
god in vain for I am dampened eternally. Than ye said bishop was ferefull and
said. Alas how have thou deserved it the which have lived truly enough / and
I wened that you had be yet in Innocence vyrginal. And he said It is so /
for I am yet vyrgyn. But I am dampened for that yt I had of custom in ye
morning while that ye did sing mass to go and vysyte the tauernes with my
felawes and to play with them at the dyse and cards / and that yt I wanne I
kept to my self without being in will to make restytucyon. And I was the
occasyon sometime yt they swear / wrothed and blasphemed god. And of this I am
not confessed. I ne have done of conscience ne of penance / howbeit that I was
warned in sermons and by good people. Alas I cared not / and therefore I am lost
eternally. This bishop Cyrillus wrote this vysyon unto holy saint Austyn This
example denotes that dampnacion comes upon those the which go to dry^ke and
to ete or to play when they should wake in the service of the church / unto
ye solempnytees and teestes commanded if ye they correcke them not and amend
by penance. Also it is to note that it is offense not being in will to restore
/ or to be the occasyon to swear and to blaspheme god and his saints. etc.

E. Another example of a man named Vodo the which yode unto the tauernes when
he should go unto ye church / what drink / what bayne / and what bed he has
now in hell. lxvii
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that a man named Vodo had of custom to be dronken well
nere every day / and lived after ye voluptuosytees of the body / to drink
wynes and to ete metes gotten right applykes. And for as much as he did good
operacyons god sent first his angel / and secondly warned him yt he should
amend him / and else that he ne might in such wise be saved / thyrdly the
angel warned him and with that said. If thou amend ye not shortly thou
shalt sustain cursed death. and so the angel departed. The which man amended
him not and perceuered in his sy^nes as before. And on a day he laid him
down drunk / and he had a good servant and devout the which saw ye soul
of his master that the deuylles drew from the body in the said night / and
led it unto ye pains of hell. And the prince of the deuylles rose him up and
came before him / and made him sytte upon a seete of fire / and commanded that
deuylles should bring to hy^ to drink of molten brymstone meddled with fire. And
they gave it him to drink in saying. For as much as in the world thou have
made thy self dronken this shall be here thy drink / and parforced him to
drink. After the prince of deuylles made to apparayle him a bayne of fire in
pytche and sulphre meddled / and was put there in ye bayne And the prince of
deuylles said unto him this here shall be thy bayne for thou have offended thy
creator in baynynge the with delytes and draughtes of lechery. etc. Thyr dely
that devil made to prepayre a bed / and than he was casten in to a dyche
right deep the which was full of fire / smoke / sulphre and stynke. And the
pry^ce of the deuylles said unto him. Have thou not herd and read what is
said by the prophet Amos. Ve qui dormitis in lectis eburneis et lesciuitis in
stratis vestris. And for as much as thou shalt be such this shall be here thy
bed and thou shall rest in this dyche of fire for to lay the on. etc. By this
example that this wretched gloton would not leave his sin and believe the
admonycyons of the angel the which gave him warning to correct him all
glotons should understand and other sinners the which will not correct them
and leave their sins by the admonycyons that the holy prechours makes unto
them the which in the end of their days shall be punysshed. And by that yt
he was perforced to drink of sulfre And that he was bayned and laid in bed is
understand that the dampened shall have punycion for every sin that they have
committed in this world. Vnd psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua. And
therefore every man should do the fewest sins that he might so that he may
escape pain and punycyon. etc.

F. Another example of a boucher ye mocked the holy ashes / and drank at the
tavern when the other good folks were at mass. lxvii.
IT is written in dyaloguo Cesarii that there was in ye town of Florence a
boucher the which waked well nere all the night on the shroue tuesday to fill
his belly as many done the which is great dolor. When asshewednesday came he
and mo of his felawes entered in to the tavern for to vngrese their tethe. And
for to wasshe and put away shrouetyde. And when the mass was ronge and the
good crystiens yode unto the holy ashes they abode all alone too drink and to
ete / and the one of them said unto the boucher. We tarry here to long / go we
to ye church to take holy ashes. Unto whom ye boucher said in mocking of ye
holy ashes. Sit thou still and I shall give the ashes and thou shalt give
me. And the other took ashes in the harthe of the fire and kest up on the heed
of the said mocking boucher. And incontinent pain and punycyon followed of his
mockery / for he felt so much dust about his heed and his vysage the which
on him was blown that he was all aferde. And as he began to cry so many
ashes entered in to his mouth that he was well nere choked and his brethe
gone. Tha^ clamor was there / and many came to se the plage of his mockery. He
was led in to a place nere thereunto where as there were none ashes / but it
prouffyted him nothing by the Just Judgment of god / ne in waters / ne in
gardyns / ne among apple trees / ne in no place where so ever it were / he
might never defend him from ye ashes in hepes the which came about him. And
in conclusyon with an hepe of ashes he was choked / and so he ended his days
myserably for his mockery. etc. By this example mockers and glotons ben
rebuked. And also ben those the which gooth-vnto the tavern when men go unto
the service of ye church. If the said mocker were in such wise tourmented in
this world by punycion dyuyne / by more great reason it is to presuppose that
god punyssheth there semblables in hell if they deye impenytentes without
correccyon. etc.

G. Another example of a knight ye yode to vysyte tauernes when he should
vesyte the dedycacyons / and pardons of the church. lxvii.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a knight would be drunk often times. And
one time he yode with the vessel whereof he drank unto the dedycations and
pardons of the chyrches / but he vesyted the tauernes and cared not of
indulgence and chyrches. And afterward as he was seek his daughter the which
was much devout prayed hy^ instauntly yt after his death he would appear unto
her and for to show her of his estate and being. The which appeared after his
death within.xxx. days and held in his hand the vessel infernal the which
was all in fire. And when his said daughter saw hy^ so enbrased she had great
feere / and demanded him what he was / and what he would with that cup. The
which answered. I am thy fader. And this cup is the tourmente wherein I
drink. Whereof speaks the psalmyst. Ignis sulphur et spiritus procellarum pars
calicis eorum And she demanded him secondly if she might help him by prayer
or good deeds And he said nay / ne all the saints of heaven for the sentence of
the gospel was given against him. Ligatis manibus and pedibus proucite eu^ in
tenebras exteriores ibi erit fletus et stridor dentium. Mathei. xxii. Than he
cried with an hye voice three times (ve) in saying. Ve in amaritudine / ve in
multitudine / ve i^ eternitate penarum. And saint Gregory says in his
moralles. Qui nunc se male in voluptatibus dilatat / illum postea in suppliciis
pena angustat. etc.

Venatio.
A. Examples of hunters. And first example how a lord the which hunted on ye
feestes had a child the which had eres like a dog. lxviii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows ye which is
written in libro apu^ and says that a noble man was all given unto hunting in
such wise that he neither herd mass on ye saterdayes ne on the sondayes. And
his wy yt was devout reproved him often / but he took no head. And it befell
that after yt the said wife had many children she chylded an evil shapen
thing the which had the heed as a dog / and the eeres hanging. And when
she saw it she was confused and shamed before many damoysels good matrones the
which were there in presence / the which counceyled all that incontinent it
were covered with earth without being more seen / and it was done. And
forthwith the husband came from hunting ye which demanded where the child:
was and yt he would seit. And for as much as she dyfferred it for shame he
drew his sword and said that he would se it. Than the said woman made to take
out of the earth the heavy and horrible monster: the which said unto her
husband. Behold how the puyssaunt god by showing manifest has venged thyn
vnwytte for that thou have done no good deed ne honor unto the holy days and
festes / and have not given any reverence unto the holy sacraments of the
sacred body of Ihesu christ / but unto vain hunting thou have taken head on
the said holy feast days. etc. Than the said noble man correcked him worthily
and did penance much bitter.

B. Another example ye men knew not where an hunter became in huntinge of a
be. lxviii.
ALso it is written in libro apum this that follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his sermons. And says yt rich lord parforced his me^ and subgectes to go
with him every day to hunte / the which men left to labor and to do their
seculer occupacions till yt they became poor / the^self / their wives / and
children. And it befell one day that the said lord went to ye hunting in a
wood he and his household the hounds raised ye wild be. He was on
horsbacke and followed him / and saw him evermore / but his rennynge prouffyted
him nothy^ge for he might not take him and perceuered to follow him by night
and from that day afterward never man saw him more / ne no man wist what
there was done of hy^ / and he was not found. Some say that in likewise as ye
earth opened the which swalowed Chore. Dathan / and Abyron the which
descended all quycke in to hell that so it might be happened unto the foresaid
hunter.

Chorea.
C. Example of dauncynge on the feestes And first example how the devil would
have borne away a maiden the which daunced on the sunday. lxviii.
IT is written in the miracles of ye blyssed vyrgyn Mary of a fair daughter the
which in her deeds was desolute dauncer and a synger the which would not
correct her for her mother. And her fader loved her for her beauty the which
clothed her pompeously with fair garments. And one day of the sunday after
that she was werye of dauncynge she sat her down under an apple tree for her
recreacyon. And incontinent the devil came unto her the which said unto her.
Arise thou and come with me. And she said. What art thou. He answered I am the
devil unto whom thou enforcest the to do my will / thou art our arms and
our daughter to take the souls And therefore now thou shall receive pains /
not alonely for thy sins / but for all the sins of them the which ben
drawn unto cursed concupyscence for thy clothyn-and aournementes of thy body.
And as ye devil enforced hy^ to rauysshe her vyolently she cried twyes Lady
mary help me. Her mother had taught her in her youth so to call the vyrgyn
Mary and for to salve her And she learned her to say. Auemaria gratia plena.
etc. And the devil said. Cursed be they that taught the yt orayson. If you had
not said it I had borne the now in to hell and he departed. By the example of
the maiden yt was fair / well clothed / of abyte to dance and to sing must
be understand yt she pleased unto the devil and dyspleased god. For such
vanytees draws unto sin / corrupts virtues and good manners and ledeth
unto dampnacyon. Also by that ye she called help of the vyrgyn Mary yt is ye
flower of vyrgynyte is understand yt in likewise should these vyrgyns do in
necessyte / and them conferme unto ye vyrgyn Mary to the end that they may goo
in to paradyse. etc.

D. Another example of men and women the which dau^ced a year without that any
person might socour them. lxvii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt in the year of the incarnacyon of our
lord. M. and.xi. There happened in a cite of ye country of saxonye wherein
there was a curate of ye parisshe church of saint Mayng: the which curate was
called Tulles how in the vygyll of crystmas many of his parysshens men and
women put them to dance in the said chyrcheyarde and to sing in such manner
that they let the said curate in his office of ye church. Wherefore he sent
to them yt they should cease / but they ceased not ne would not obey for him.
Than he cursed them in requyrynge god yt they might not cease all that year.
So by miracle it became and was done that in all the hole year there fell not
one drop of ^ater upon them / nor they suffered honger ^e thyrste / nor their
clothing ne hosen we ^e broken / but by anoye and contynuacion of ^^rnynge
they were much weary within ye ^ercle. And much great nombre of folk of ^ll
estates and of diverse regyons came for to (...) the punycyon of god. When it
came to ^hende of the year the archebysshop of Co^yne named Hebart came thither
for to as^oyle them / and made them to come unto hy^ before the hye awter of
the said church in ^he which place a woman and two men among them yielded up
their spyrytes in yt hou^e. Some of the other slepte three days wt^ut waking.
Of the other the hedes and the members trembled. And so they were dy^ersly
punysshed for too be in example for ^uermore that in the church or chyrchyarde
men neither should ^ynge ne dau^ce worldely. And also of the great ill of those
that dysobey their curates.

E. Another example of the punysshynge of a woman dauncer. lxviii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says how a man named Arnoldus tells of a maiden the which
every holy day occupied herself in plays and daunces without going unto the
sermon the which was made unto the people. And in the even tide she became
weary and slepte at the door. And incontinent that her eyes were close she was
borne by vysyon of two deuylles in to hell / and was so burnt that there ne
abode here in all her body / the which was full of great bladders and kest a
stynke intolerable. And a devil put in her mouth a brenny^ge bro^de and said
unto her / take this bronde for the songs yt thou have song vnshamefully Her
clothing had no token of brennynge. the which awoke in great clamor and
wepy^ge and told unto her mother and unto many other this thing. She was borne
in to the house / the curate was called the which found in her no mortal
sin / but that wylly^gly she went unto plays and daunces. etc.

F. Another example how a mayde^ was rauysshed in the dau^ce and vyoled / and
after hanged her self. lxviii.
SOme masters has wryte^ this the which follows yt the dyscyple recyteth in
his book and says / yt as a yo^ge maiden went to a gaderynge for to dance she
met ye devil in lykenes of a man the which said to her. Whyder go thou.
And she answered and said. I god for to dance in such an assemble. And the
deceyuable devil ye which counceyleth sometime well the more gretely for too
deceive said unto her. If thou will believe me thou shall not go thither ne come
among them. She took no head and yode thither. And at the dance she was
rauysshed of harlots and corrupt at their pleasures. And after as she came
again wepy^ge and dysco^forted she met the devil / but he dyscomforted her so
yt she dyspayred and hanged her self.

Ecclesia.
A. Example how Nychanor was slain after yt he had thretened ye church. lxix.
IT is written in ye.vii. cha. of Machabeus how Nychanor had a great host and
fought with yt children of Israel / and had lost.v. M. men on a day he yode to
the mount of syon and the old prestes came before hy^ to tell him yt they made
sacryfyce for the king. And the said Nychanor mocked them and spoke unto them
proudly and swore if Judas and his host were betaken unto him and that he had
the vyctory that when he came again from battle yt he should dystroy and
brenne their houses and the church / and with great ire he departed. Than the
said prestes yode unto ye church to weep and to require ye aid of god And to
be short when the said Nychanor was at battle he fell the first and was slain
as it is written the said chapter / and also in the second book of Machabeus
in the.xv. chapter. And when the said Nychanor was deed his host fled / and
were pursued and slain yt there was not one left. After they cut of the heed
of the said Nichanor and his right hand yt he had showed proudely in
thretenynge the said prestes. And god was loved and gloryfyed the which
punisshed the proud herted and aided the meke. By this said Nychanor yt spoke
proudely unto the priests and said unto them that he would dystroye them he
was first dystroyed and punysshed. For by pride all the strength and the
goodness of man is dystroyed and lost. Quia deus superbis resistit et humilibus
dat gratiam. vt dicitur iacobi.iiii. ca. Also he moeued not the prestes to pray
with good mind for him / he being in will to dystroye them. Also they prayed
for his dystruccion and confusyon / and they were herd. Also god aydeth not
unto the proud / furyous / and vengeable / but unto the contrary he them
punyssheth and puts from paradyse.

Sepultura.
B. Examples of sepultures. And first. Example of a sinner the which the
deuylles unburied and drew out of the church. lxix.
IT is written in the.iiii. book of the dyalogue of saint Gregory that a
worshypfull bishop and right herytable told unto him yt he knew of truth
and of his people had seen the deed in a cite named valence / h^^ a man bryttle
in his life and in all light thyges occupied. When he was deed his bod^ was
buried in the church. And when it (...) me unto mydnyght great voices were
he^de / as if men had drawn out of ye church some man by vyolence. At these
voices ^^se up the gardyens of the said church / and ran and saw two
terryble spyrytes the which had unburied the said man and had bound his fete
with a string and drew hy^ out of the church incryenge horrybly. Wha^ the
said gardyens saw that they had great dread and returned in to their chamber.
And when the morrow came they opened the sepulcre of the said deed man and they
found not his body. And they yede to seek him out of the church / and found
him in a dyche and his fete bounden where the deuyls had casten him. By this
example a man should understand that holy ground saves not the sinners the
which ben the^ buried. etc. Also after the right written men put out of the
church people exco^m^nyed or acursed / the which ne ben buried till they ben
assoyled / and reabled. Also people the which ben homycides of them self ben
not buried in holy ground / for that yt it appears that they ben dampened.

C. Another example of an usurer buried in the cloister kept the monks from
slepynge. lx^^.
MEn find in writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that an usurer was buried of monks in their cloister /
And in the night he yode out of the pytte in playnynge and cryenge dyscouered
the house and he stroke with his staff meruayllously and woke the monks. In
ye morning the body of the said man was found cast far of in to a field
beyond the cite. And he was again put in to the pyt And after that many times
it was in such wise done / he was coniured of an holy man that he told
wherefore he and his monks had no rest. And he said of me it is to dyspayre.
For in like wise as by my vsuryes I have tormented by night and by day the
poor people. In like wise now shall I not rest. And ye may rest if that ye
cast my body out of the cloister The which thing was done. And afterward
they ne were more of hy^ troubled. Who so well should consider these examples
beforesayd of this third commandment he shall find that a man should keep
honor and sanctyfye the feestes ye which ben of commandment of the church
without being slothful to go to here the service / and not neclygently to
put him in devotion and to do good operacyons. Item without doing worldly
operacyons the which let the sanctyfycacion of the said feestes. And without
co^myttynge sins mortalles ye which ben operacyons not of sanctifycacyons /
but of da^nacyon and perdycyon.

Quartu^ preceptu^.
Filii.
Example of those the which has not borne honor and reverence unto faders
and moders / and the which ne has socoured them in their necessytees after
the commandment of god.

A. And first examples of Absolon the sone of Dauyd the which deyed
myscheuously for that that he made war with his fader. Ca. lxx
IT is written in the xiiii. chapitre of the second book of kings yt in all
the people of Israhel there ne was so fair a man as was Absolon the sone of
king dauyd For from the sole of the foot till unto the heyght of his heed was
there not in all his body and his members any foul spotte. / And also his here
were of great weyghtynes and beauty. And he the which was noble / young /
fair / and strong was so proud and dysobeyssaunt unto his fader Dauyd and
made again hy^ so great war that he fled one time before him. Also he was
lecherous and so fulfilled of couetyse that he would be king and expel his
own fader from his realm / but he abode not unpunished as reason was. For he
deyed myscheuously. In like wise as it is written in the.xviii. chapter of the
second book of kings. It befell that Absolon ran after the servants of
Dauyd in making war again them / and was upon his mule the which yode
under an oak gretely braunched / and his here took and meddled with the
branches of ye said oak. And as he was there hanged between the sky and the
earth / the mule where upon he was rested not but yode forth still And some men
the which saw this thing yode unto ioab the which was Capytayne and led
the war for David / unto whom they said that Absolon was abyden hanged on
the branch of an oak Than the said ioab took in his hand three speres and
festened them in ye heart of absolon. And for as much as he yet removed and
panted ten stryppelynges of the army of the said Ioab went to kill out of
hand the said Absolon / and cast him in to a great dytche / and laid upon
him a great hepe of stones in sign of punycyon and maladyccyon. This is here
the example of all the evil children yt will not bear honor and reverence
unto faders and moders after the commandment of god. By this that he was
hanged by the here myraculously / is to understand that the pride that he
took in his here dyspleased unto god / and by this that his heart was perced
with three speres / is to understand yt it was reason that the proud heart and
inobedyent unto god the which ne did honor unto his fader / but made war
with him was trebly punysshed. For he was replenysshed with three vices / the
which is pride / auaryce / and lecherye. And by that that he was buried in
ground profane without prayers / without honor / ne without solempnyte
ecclesyastycall was in token of maledyccyon. For it is written deutero. xxii.
ca. Maledictus homo qui no^ honorat patrem suu^ et matrem suam: et dicet omnis
populus amen. That is to say that man be cursed the which honors not his
fader and his mother / and al ye people shall say Amen / so be it. etc.

B. Another example of a sone the which defaylled unto fader and mother / and
he bare a tode three year in his vysage. lxx
THe dyscyple recites in his sermons yt it is written in dyalogo cesarii / how
a rich man and his wife left of their goods and herytages unto a sone yt
they had to the end that he were married unto a damoysell. And then to provide
for the^ haboundau^tly whiles they lived. And after that he was married unto the
young damoysell she had the fader and the mother of the said sone in dyspleasure.
And did so much that they were departed and put in to a caban in the which
they had much of defaute. And one time ye ancient woman said unto her
husband. I saw borne from ye market of good mete in our sons house / it is a
great time sith thou etest any flesh / goo thou theder this sunday and in
deed thou shalt find there of good roste and a great dinner. Than at the hour
of dinner the said auncyente came to knock at the door / and incontinent the
ill sone made to hyde the mete roasted And when the fader was entered the evil
sone demanded him what he would / and he said that he was come to dyne with
hy^ hoping that there was some good thing. And the said sone said unto him.
Look what we have / hold here is two pens bye some thing for ye and for my
mother / and go thy way. And when he was gone the said roste was set again
upon the table and a chekyn roasted by the will of god was changed in to a
great tode ye which lept in to the vysage of the ill sone / and took him so
strongly with ye two fete before on his chekes / yt the flesh of the man and
of the tode was one flesh together / without that they might separe them. And
the behind of the said tode hanged before his mouth. The priest was called
that led him to the Archebysshop / unto whom he confessed his sin and the
case by order euenso as it was happened. Then the archebysshop gave him in
penance that he should go through all the great towns and cytees of France /
and that he should call the young children and recounte unto them the case
beforsayd / to the end that none should despise their faders and parents And
the said tode removed not from his vysage. And when ye man ete he ete. And when
men would take away the said tode with instruments he streyned so sore with
his fete yt the face became so blown that the eyes remeued from their place
and he lived so three years without that that a man could take him away. In
that time friar Johan du pont of ye order of prechers saw him at paris with
many men women and children. The said child the which ne did honor unto
his fader and mother / himself was dishonored. quia legit eccle. xxix.
Peccator transgredyens ma^data dn^i: i^cidet i^ promissione^ ne quam. This
example shows yt punycyon shall come be it in this world or in the other
upon ye children the which defaylleth unto fader and mother in their
necessytees. God ye which is all puyssaunt would that this thing were seen and
known over all the country / to the end that all the children meruaylled them.
And knew ye great offense the which is to defayl unto their parents. etc.

C. Another example of Cham the which mocked his fader noe. lxx.
IT is written in genese yt Noe had three sons / yt is to understand / sem Cham
and Iaphet. And it happened one time that after that Noe had strongly
labored at the gaderynge of wine that he was weary and slepte / the which was
uncovered byneth / and one of his sons named Cham came there / the which
