mocked of the things naturell of his fader / which went to seek his two
other brethren for to se it for to mock withal. And the two other when they
saw that covered them and did chyde with Cham / to women they said that it was
not well done to mock with his fader. After this ye said Noe knew it by
reuelacyon and cursed him / not that he was cursed / but al his lynee / not
that ye souls were cursed / but they yt proceeded of him should be subgectes to
great trybulacyons / as of pouerte of gods / or fortunes temporelles. And more
than two thousand year after as our savior and redemptoure preched a wife
issued of the said lynee of Cham came to require our lord to hele her daughter
that was tormented of the devil. Dn^e misere mei filia mea male a demonio
vexatur. etc. And our lord answered to her that it was not good to give the
bread of sons unto dogs. Non est bonu^ sumere pane^ filioru^: et sumere
canibus. He called the said people dogs / because that they were evil / and
issued of the said cursed fader Cham that mocked with his fader as said is.

D. Other example of two sons yt slew their fader. lxx.
IT is written in the.xxxvii. chapitre of the book of Ysaye that the army of
king Sennacheryb was punysshed divinely for their pride and sin / yt should
be a long thing to recounte. And the aungel of god slew in one night. C.
four score and five thousand. And the king Sennacheryb fled in to the cite
of Nynyues / and it was so that as he adoured in ye temple his god / his two
propre sons drew their glayues and slew him in the said temple The which
sons wend to have succeeded and reigned in the realm after him / but the one
nor the other was not king.

E. Other example of a sone the which stroke his mother. lxx.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary how a sone cast down and stroke his
mother with the fete. And of ye permyssyon dyuyne that foot where with he had
stryken her was cut from him. Another example of a sone the which dishonored
his mother / And in short time all his children deyed / without doubt al
children the which done ill unto the fader and unto the mother / or ye which
dyshonoureth them / or the which fayl them in their necessytees shall be
punysshed in this world or in the other. For they dysobeye unto god and ben
vnnaturelles. etc.

F. Another example how ye two sons of Helye would not be corrected for their
fader and they were slain. lxx.
IT is written in the third chapter of the first book of kings how hely was
judge of ye people of Israhell by.xl. years. And he had two sons named ophi^
and phynees the which lived delicyously and prepayred them delycatyuely ye
meats the which came unto ye temple in sacryfyces / and made of sins and
cursydnesses. Their fader hely the which herd the tidings repreued them /
but he punisshed them not. And therefore god suffered yt they deyed myscheuously
/ for the children were slain in battle. And the said hely fell from his
chair and slew himself when men brought him the tidings yt his children
were slain / and that the arc wherein were ye commandments was taken of the
phylystyens. The clerks presuppose their dampnacyon / more sooner than
otherwise / for the sins the which regne in children / and for ye fault of
their correccyon.

G. Another example of the child that the devil bare away. lxx.
IT is written in the dyalogue Cesarii how a devil bare away a child in body
and soul for the malediccion of his parents. In such manner that his
parents saw him no more afterward. And god suffered it to the end that these
other parents have dread how they curse their children / but that more sooner
they correct them with a rod. etc.

A. Another example how a good and true child loved his fader and might not
endure yt a man did unto him any ill.
MEn find by writing how ye dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary and says
how a man had three sons with his wife after the opinion. And it befell yt they
wrathed them one time together / and that the said wife said unto him. Thou
wenest to have three children of me / but ye ne haste but one. And he demanded
her which it was. And she ne would tell him After that that ye said woman was
deed as the fader lay in his death bed / by his testament he left all that
he had unto hy^ ye which was his own sone. And when he was deed they strove
who should have his goods and heritage. And the king commanded that the said
fader deed were bound unto a tree / and that the three sons should shote at
him. And that he the which should shote most str^^^htest should have the
heritage. And af^^^ yt he was bound two of the sons shot ^han the third
saw that they had shot^^ (...) such wise unto his fader he was wroche agay^
them / and said that he ne would in no manner shote unto his fader. Than men
knew truly that he was the very child the which ne would none ill do unto
his fader. And unto him it was iuged that he should have the goods and
herytages. Also al good children should love their fader deed and quycke. A
be loves naturelly her fruit and semblables. Eccle. xiii. Om^e animal
diligit simile sibi. And those ye which love not their faders and parents ben
gretely vnnaturell / worse than a dombe be / and therefore they ben worthy of
punycyon / ye which they shall have if they correct them not whiles that they
ben lyuinge in this world.

B. Another example how the nature of birds techeth us to think and remember
our parents. lxxi.
Written it is in the book of Ysydore of the nature of birds yt the nature of
cranes is such that they withdraw them from mete and endure ho^gre / to the
end yt they puruaye unto their little birds. And after that their little cranes
may fle and take proye if their parents have necessyte / afflyccyon and
lennes they have co^passyon and gadre them in to a neste / and nouryssheth them
whiles yt they have conualescence / and do good ye one unto the other. In like
wise done ye good children unto their parents. These little grypes ne done not
so unto their parents of whom ye naturyens say that after that their
parents have longely labored to nourysshe them / and to go to get them mete
in many places / and that they have kept themself from mete for to give it
unto them. After that those little grypes be great to fle and have puyssaunce.
Than they beat with their wings their parents. / Also they ne give them to
ete of their proye / but with their bylle and with their wy^ges they beat them
out of their nest. The ill children done in like wise unto their parents. etc.

C. Another example of a daughter the which nourysshed her mother the which
was enclosed in a toure / with the milk of her breasts. lxxi.
VAlerian recyteth that for the sins that a noble woman had committed she was
iuged unto the death / but the Judge ne would punysshe her openly / for the
honor of her parents. And she was enclosed in a prison to the end yt she
should deye for hongre. And her daughter the which was married vysyted her
mother every day by the leave of the Judge in such wise that she was serched
before yt she entered for to se if she bare any thing to be eten. And the said
daughter gave unto her / her pappes to souke and nourysshed her. And at the
last the Judge knew of it wherefore he was moved with pity and gave the mother
unto the daughter. etc.

D. Another example of the child yt bote of his faders nose. lxxi.
IT is written in many books this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his book and says that there was a fader the which led his sone with him
in to tauernes and plays. And he learned that in such manner yt when he was
great he ne might keep him from playnge and using the tauernes / and after was
a thief. First unto his fader / and after unto his neighbors / and was so
cursed yt his fader delivered hy^ two times from hanging in gyuy^ge great
money. And thirdly for a theft was led unto ye galowes And there required
that he might kiss his fader / from whom he bote the nose with his tethe. And
as the sone was rebuked of that he answered. I have done well and justly / for
he is cause that I am hanged in asmoche as he correct me not in youth of my
fautes / for if he had correct me I had not be here. This example denotes yt
the sage says prouer. xxix. Puer qi dimittitur volu^tati ^ue: co^fudit matre^
sua^: i^mo patre^ and oe^s cognatos. etc. The child the which is suffered to
do his own will confounds his mother / also his fader and al his kynnesmen.
And therefore a man should punysshe him and correct in youth. Men plye and
bend the rod whiles yt it is young / so does men a child. And who so
taryeth till they be grown men / he ne may aid hy^. If the said fader had
correct his child he had not byte of his nose nor be hanged / he yt well
loves well chastises.

E. Another example of him whose berde grew after he was hanged. lxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says yt there was a cursed child
inobedyent unto fader and mother ye which slew his fellow / and for his
demerytes was hanged in his young aege. And with in three days after yt he was
hanged a great gray berde grew upon him so much that it came till unto his
gyrdyll whereof the people meruayled. And afterward it was reveled unto a holy
man all the deed of it the which said that he should have lived in as great aege
as ye said berde showed if he had be obedyent unto fader and mother. And all
such children abrydge their lives / and ben in the way of dampnacyon if they
have not great and bitter repentance. etc. Et legitur in psalmi. Subito
defecerunt propter iniquitatem ^uam.

F. Another example of a man the which was fell and hard unto his fader and
his young sone repreued him. lxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary that there was a man ill and
vnnaturell unto his fader ancient / For he made him to lie in the stable with
his sheep. And gave unto him a vile vesture the remenaunte whereof men covered
the horses. The said ancient had given unto him his heritage for to lift him
up in great estate. Now it happened yt the sone of the said felon was heavy and
displeased to se his grandfader so entreated: And for this thing he came unto
his fader / and demanded him such another couerture of horse as his said
grandfader had. And his fader asked him what he would do with it. And the child
answerde. I shall keep it till yt thou be auncyente / and than I shall clothe
yt with it in like wise as you do thy fader my grandfader the which begat
ye nourysshed the / and left unto the his heritage. etc. Legitur mathei. xv.
et marci. vii.

Honora patre^ tuu^ and matre^ tua^: and qui maledixerit patri vel matri morte
moriatur The holy scripture proceeds of ye mouth of god commands yt men
honor their fader and their mother. And he says unto the children yt do the
contrary. That is they the which curse their faders or moders / or the which
them dyshonoure or defayle in necessyte that they deye of death And it is to
understand not of death corporell alonely / but of dampnacion and death
eternell the which is death without dyenge if they deye without correccyon
and amendment.

G. Another example how a fader and his sone cursed each other in hell. Also of
a good sone yt blyssed his fader in heaven. lxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says how a holy man desired to
se the pains of hell / and the glory of the blyssed the which was led in
to hell by his angel. And among many other pains he saw a fader strive
with his sone. And the fader said unto his sone. Cursed be the time that ever I
begat the. All that that I have done for yt is cursed. For for yt I was a
cursed usurer / to the end that thou had great haboundaunce of goods in the
world. and he said many other things unto his sone in cursynge him. The sone
said unto the contrary. Cursed be the hour that thou begatest me for thou ne
haste taught me the commandments of god / ne to do penance ne other good
deeds / but thou taught me pride and to make false vendycyons / and he
reproched him many other things because he corrected him not of his ill deeds
Than said the holy man unto his aungel the which led him. It is a cursed
thing to here and to se these things here. Afterward the angel showed him
the glory of the blyssed. And in that he saw a fader and his sone the which
were in great Joy And the sone said unto his fader. Fader be thou blessed of
god. For thou me haste made to learn science. And thou haste led me unto the
church / and unto predycacions thou haste taught me many good things and
haste correct me of the ylles that I did. More over thou haste learned me the
commandments of god and to love and to dread god above all things. And many
other things yt the sone said unto the fader in blyssynge him. For by the said
things he had saved his soul. And the fader blyssed the sone in speaking unto
him se^blable things good and prouffytables by the which they were saved.
etc. This example denotes that god has suffered yt this thing were seen and
known to the end that the faders and moders and children in likewise take heed and do. And yt they correct and learn unto their children the good for
to come unto the glory of heaven. And if they do the contrary that they know yt
they shall have punycyon in hell. Where they shall curse other eternally. etc.

H. Another example of a woman damned which dispreysed those that repreued her
of her sins. Ca. lxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary and says that a woman much devout
and loved of god was right curyous of her mother departed. The which would
know of her moders estate for to help her if she were in purgatory / and it
required of our lord Ihesu christ. / And one time as she was at the church
with teres required god of this thing / she was put in horror and saw by her a
derke spirit. Than she made the token of the cross and demanded who it was.
And the spyryte said I am thy mother. And she her demanded how it was with her
/ and she answered it is with me right ill / thy prayers ne may serve me of
nothing / for I am dampened eternally. Than the daughter with great wayllynge
said. Alas my mother what is the cause of thy dampnacyon And she answered. For
that that I lived and have be nourysshed of things ill gotten by vsuryes and
otherwise / and I culpable took no head to restore unto other. And that the
which was ill done again god of my subgectes in my house I forced not of it /
but I am entered in the ways of ye world ill and unrightful. And also I have
dyspreysed those ye which me have repreued of my sins and ylles. And I ne me
amended ne repented in no manner. And in such wise I deyed. And when the said
mother had said these words she departed / and the said daughter prayed no more
for her Unto this purpose saint Austyn says. Si scire^ patre^ meum in
inferno: non plus orare^ pro eo quam pro dyabolo. That is to say if I knew my
fader were dampened in hell I should pray no more for him than for ye devil.
This example denotes that those the which lives of things ill gotten ben in
the way of dampnacyon / if yt they dye without restitucyon. Also a man should
not dyspreyse one yt repreueth him of his vices and sins.

I. Another example of a tauerner that the devil bare away in body and soul
for that he repreued not those the which did ylle. Ca. lxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons and says that a tauerner received to
ete to drink and to lodge all sorts of people / yt is to understand good and
ill / and suffered to play / to swear / to be drunk / to blaspheme / to
committee baudrye and other sins in his tavern for temporell gain. And one
time on a sunday as he bare of wine from his seller before his yate for that
yt his house was full of other hosts / there arose up a tempeste of wind and
deuylles among it ye which took up vyolently the said tauerner on hye in the
air before all the people. And when he saw himself so lift up and of ye
deuylles borne away cried by great contricion of heart. O deus quid fatiet
ai^a mea. O my god what thing shall be done of my soul. tha^ the deuylles
suffered him to fall in to a field / and they said unto him. For asmoche as thou
haste forgoten all things transytoryes and the life of thyn own body / thy
wife thy children / and thy friends / and that thou haste prayed alonely god
for thy soul by contrycyon of heart we ne may bear the no ferther / for god
ne will suffer us to exercise in the our will. For that that thou haste called
him by contrycyon. And if ye had not done it we had borne the in to hell in
body and in soul. Than the said deuylles yode away / and he was found in the
said field / and borne in to his house. / And he lay in his bed certain
days / and after that he was in conualescence he corrected him and amended /
and put away his tavern. And more over he never suffered in his house to play
/ to blaspheme / ne to do other ylles. All tauerners and hostyllers should well
note this thing yt god ne punysshe them as he did the said ylle tauerner.

K. Another example of a man the which was so ylle instruct and correct that
he sold his soul / and the devil bare it away with the body. lxxi.
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons and says that a man said unto his
compaygnons as they drank at ye tavern if they byleued yt there was of souls
/ and that he byleued nothing / and yt he ne had none seen. And that the
prestes and prechers had found that there was of souls in hell for the gain
temporell And that he byleued nothing. And his compaygnons affermed yt after
the faith catholyke that there was of souls in hell and in heaven / and that
the soul of every person goes unto paradyse or in to hell or in to
purgatory after that it departs from the body. After he demanded if any
would bye his soul. And that he should sell it. And one of his compaygnons said
unto him. I will bye it. And it was sold for a quarte of wine the which was
incontinent drunk. And there came the devil in the form of a man the which
boughte the said soul of him the which sold it / and paid a quarte of wine.
And when ye said wine was drunk the devil said. Give me the soul yt I have
bought / for it is mine. And those the which were present said. It is a thing
just that he the which byeth possede the thing bought. And the accursed the
which had sold his soul said that he had not sold the body. And the
presence said. When yt any sells his horse he gives the coler or halter
withal. And incontinent ye seller was estrangled of the devil. And before the
presence rauisshed the said man and bare him in to hell in body and soul.

A. Another example how ye fader should love more god than his children / and
other parents and friends. lxxii
IT is written how the dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that a man
was one time so much holde^ in the love of his parents and neighbors that
he was let to love god and to follow him. And one time he would therein find
remedy and called them unto a dinner. And in dynynge he prayed one of them the
which unto him after his advise was most faithful. If thou love me put thy
little finger in this fire for the love of me. And he dredde the pain and would
nothing do. So the faith and the love yt he feigned to have in hy^ appeared to
be vain. After he required all the other by order and said unto them as unto
the first / and they would nothing do. Than he declared his purpose unto
them all / and said unto them that only for the love of them he was tarried
for to love parfytely Ihesu christ / but for that that he found no more faith
in them he would no more tarry. And for that they ne would put in ye fire
transytorye ye most little membre that they had one seule hour for the love
of him / he said that in like wise for the love of them he ne should put all
his body and his soul in the fire perpepual of hell. Afterward he said unto
them / take heed to do for your self / and so will I for myself Then within a
while after he restored and paid all his debtes. And after gave and
dystrybuted all his goods unto the poor for the love of god. And put him to
serve our lord Ihesu faithfully and devoutly / and to love him parfytely. etc.
True it is that we should love our parents / friends and kinnesmen naturally
and wyllyngly And for as much as god commands it / Diliges proximu^ tuu^
sicut te ipsu^. math xxii. But we should love our fader celestyall more than
them and above them. Vn^ au. Dilige^dus e^ genitor sed prepone^dus e^ creator.
And if any man love his fader or his children and parents more than god and
above him he shall be sent unto dampnacyo^ And he ne may be saved without
true penance. For it is written mat. x. and luce. xiiii. Qui amat patre^ aut
matre^ plusquam me no^ est me dignus. Et qi amat filiu^ aut filia^ super me:
no^ est me dignus. We be holden unto fader and mother: but yet ben we more
holden unto god the which has fourmed our souls unto his semblau^ce / and
the which has redeemed us by his precious blood / and suffered death for us.
And more over he us puruayeth and nouryssheth by ye goods yt he makes to
grow. And also unto us prometteth paradyse. And therefore no love what so ever
it be ne should draw us back from the parfyte love of god. etc.

B. Another example of a fader yt which said unto his sone that he should
hold his fyngere in the fire till he had said Aue maria. lxxii.
IT is written in some books that ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his sermons and says that a rich man posseded many goods unjustly
gotten. And after that he had herd ye word of god in predycacyon would
experymente ye fidelyte of his sone. Unto who me he said that for the love of
him he would hold his finger in ye fire so long alonely as he should say aue
maria. And the said sone began to assaye / and incontinent that he felt the
brennynge of the fire / he drew back his finger and said unto his fader. What
shall it prouffyte the that all my body shall feel hete and shall be brent And
the fader said unto the sone. What shall it prouffyte yt for the I dampne my
self and put in the fire of hell eternel / And so the said rich man restored
all tho things that he had ylle gotten and changed his life from ill unto good.

C. Another example how a man should do of good deeds while that he lives with
out trusting upon his heirs. lxxii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says that a rich man was in
the article of death / he called his three sons and said unto the most
au^cyente. My dear sone know ye that I leave unto you many possessions and
goods that I have kept for you / the which I should have given unto the
poores / and therefore parauenture I shall go in to purgatory. Tell me what
shalt thou give for my soul. And he said unto him yt he should make to sing
many masses / and also should give of alms. etc. In like wise ye second him
prometted. The fader praised these two sons here. And demanded of the youngest
what he would do for him I promise the nothing not to give one penny. Whiles
that thou lyuest dystrybute thy goods for the health of thy soul with out
co^myttynge it unto us / how shall we aid the by deed when we have thy gods
the which ne will help thy self for the love of us / and every of us shall
love better his own vtylyte than thine. And therefore think first on thyselfe
if thou will / When the said rich man herd this young child considered that
he said unto hy^ veryte and dystrybuted his rychesses unto ye poores for his
own health.

D. Another example how a man should do of good deeds in his life time without
taryenge unto his friends. lxxii
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye yt there was a rich man the which
had a sone / the which rich man when he was in his death bed made his
testament solemply / and left much goods unto the relygyous and unto ye
people / and afterward he deyed After his death the said people and the
relygyous came unto his said sone and demanded him that yt his fader had left
unto them by his testament. Than the sone answered and said. I ne shall give
unto no person that lives / and told ye reason. Ye say in approuynge the
scripture yt if any be in hell yt the suffrages and good deeds ne prouffite to
him. And if he be in heaven yt him needs nothing. I know not now if he be in
paradyse or in hell. And if he be in purgatory he is there purged unto the
last sin / for I ne shall give nothing for his soul. The goods temporelles
that I possede I ne shall shed them. Also I doubt me for his soul / but be he
tormented till that he be purged. This example techeth us to do of good deeds
whiles yt we live without taryenge or trusting unto our parents for to do it
after our death. Vn^. grego. Tutior e^ vita vt bonu^ quoth quisque post morte^
sperat agi per alios: agat du^ viuit ipse per se. Beatius quippe e^ liberu^
exire quam post vi^cula liberante^ q^re. Child unnatural sith yt it is so yt
god commands the to help thy neighbors / the poor / ye hongry / ye
thrusty / ye seek / and if you do it not thou shall yield account before god at
ye day of Judgment. By a more strong reason if thou socour not thy parents of
whom thou haste thy goods the which ben in ye prison of purgatory having
hongre and thurst / and great necessyte thou art worthy of great punycyon. etc.

E. Another example of semblable matere to do of good deeds without taryeng or
trusting unto his children. lxxii.
MEn find by writing yt there was a rich man the which had purchased lo^des
and possessions. And all the country about him was his. It happened that he
fell in a great sekenes and sent for his priest and devised that he had / and
required him to pray for him / and made to pray in every monastery. And
promised that if he might escape yt he should de go unto saint James / unto
saint gyles / unto Rochemador. And yt he should do many of good deeds for the
love of god / It happened that he escaped from ye said sekenes / and became
wors than ever he had be and more unfaithful / and did nothing of all that
he had promised unto the priest. Long time after he fell again in to a
much great sekenes / and sent for his priest as before. And promised to do
many of good deeds / and that he would pray for him. Ha said the priest the
other time thou saydest as much unto me / and nothing have you done of yt that
you promised. I have said he to much good / who shall do it for me. Then he
called his sone and his heir and told him yt he had gotten hy^ great lands
and that he must goo for him unto saint James and unto saint gyles And unto
such pylgrymages if I deye / Fair fader said the sone men say that deed men
go as swyftely as they will. Go you by saint James and unto saint gyles if ye
will / so god help me I shall not put my body in pain. If ye have well do ne
ye shall find it. The said heir yode not / and therefore a good thing it is
not to tarry ne abide unto his heirs. For ye lantern ye which is borne before
gives better light than that the which is borne behind.

F. Another example how a man should do of good deeds whiles that he lives and
that a fool taught well one sage. lxxii.
MEn tell of a great lord the which had of custom as done these great lords
when he will go through ye country to send his coke to prepayre his dinner and
his place. And the said lord had a fool yt had of custom to go after the coke
for the prouffyte that he there had. etc. It befell one time that ye said lord
was seek in his bed of the death. And ye people the which came to se him
said unto each other when they met / ye lord gothe his way. The said fool
herd these said words and said yt shall he not do / for his coke is yet here.
And for yt that ye people perseuered to say yt he gothe his way / ye said fool
entered in to the chamber of ye lord / and said to him. My lord all the people
say yt ye go your way / and because ye have not sent your coke before by
saint Peter ye shall deye of hongre. Than the lord said that the fool said
true / and that a fool has assensed well a saige. Than the lord made all the
prestes of the country to sing and to do in his life the seruyces yt men
should do after his death and to do almesdedes and so he sent the coke before
/ and made his fardell to bear with him as does a bryde the which departs
from the house of her fader. etc.

A. Another example of a fader and of his sone the which were dampened for ye
goods ill begoten and witholden. lxxiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in the book of his sermons and says yt an usurer had
two sons of the which ye one repented him in herynge a sermon / and after
said unto his fader. My fader if we deye in such wise we shall be lost in body
and in soul. Than he said unto him. Pay unto every man that yt thou owe and
return unto god. Unto whom the fader said / and the other brother. Sholdest you
be our confessoure / goo deye where thou will. For we shall abide with our
goods. The which held his peace / left them and yielded himself hermyte /
and lived a poor life in seruy^ge god. And after that this good hermyte herd
speak that his fader and his brother were deed was moved in pity and desired to
know of their estate. And required of god if it were his pleasure that he
might se them. And one day as he was in orayson the angel of our lord came
unto hy^ and said. Thy petycyon is made / come thy way I shall show them the.
And he took him and rauysshed him / and bare him in to hell. And set him upon
a hye mountain. And the said angel said unto him / will thou se and here
thy fader and thy brother and the said hermyte answered yt ye. And he saw a
valeye replenysshed of diverse kinds of torments / and herd a miserable
voice. And he saw first his fader the which boylled in fire as pesen do the
within a great pot ye which said. Maledyccyon / maledyccyon / maledyccyo^ /
cursed be the hour that ever I was conceived. Cursed be the womb that bare me
/ When the said hermyte herd these words he trembled and said. O fader art
you here. The answer. My sone thou art blyst for thou have dredde god and haste
fled this pain right horrible and cruel / but take heed that thou serve
well god. And even in like wise as he spoke these words the sone came and
appeared as the said fader had done with great boylyons of fire: and in
swymmynge on hye and within as a piece in a pot. And the said sone took him to
curse his said fader in pains and said in this manner. Cursed be thou my fader
in pardurabylyte. For by these things yt thou haste ill gotten thou haste
dampened me and lost. And unto the contrary the fader said unto the sone.
Cursed be thou sone / for for the I have gotten such goods and them has
witholden. And so am I put from al good. And therefore I am descended in to this
pain. Unto whom the sone living said. Is there neither prayers ne suffrages
may prouffyte you nor aid. The which said that no. For in hell there is no
redempcyon. And the said angel led again the said hermyte / The which
lived afterward more faithfully and served god deuoutely and he was saved This
example denotes that those ye which takes and witholdeth ye goods of
another unjustly if they dye in such wise with out restitucion and amendment
yt they shall dyscende in to hell in pain and in great torment.

B. Another example of a fader the which put a malet in a cheste / and took ye
keys unto his children. Ca. lxxiii
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says yt a rich man married his children and enryched them of
his goods. And in the end became poor. And his children gave no force. And
afterward he called his children unto whom he gave the keys of a coffre
wherein he had a locket / and within it was a heavy malet / in like wise as and
if it had be money / but he retained one key to the end that they ne might go
unto the cheste. And he said unto his children. You ben mine herytours and
friends / when I shall be deed open ye the cheste / and ye shall find within
it a lettre the which deuyseth how much I have left unto every of you. For
this hope the children the one after the other inuyterent the said ancient /
they honored him and aid. After his death they found within the said loket a
malet and a lettre ye which contained. That man is worthy to be beten on ye
heed with his malet the which has so much given unto his children and
trusts the which nothing reteyneth for hy^ self.

C. Another example of two daughters the which put out their fader in his
old aege. Ca. lxxiii.
IT is written in some books this the which follows how the discyple recyteth
in his promptuarye and says that a man had two daughters unto whom he gave
all his goods and married them. and after that he was poor his daughters and
sons in law would no more reteyne him with them. And the one of the daughters
said unto her fader. Go unto my sister / and the other said in like wise. That
you shalt repast with me one day / and after go another day unto my sister.
And the ancient man was instruct of one of his nere neighbors the which was
sage / which said unto him yt he should take a fair coffre aourned and besene
withouteforth and that he should put of stones within / and he should make to
bear it unto the church on a sunday when the people ran unto the mass / yt
which thing he did. When his daughters and sons in law saw this thing
they strove togyders who should have to keep the said ancient / the which made
bargayne with one that he should have the said coffre after his death / and that
with in it for to nourysshe him. And took a lettre and kept toward himself
three keys When he was deed his sone in law opened the coffre / and when he
found nothing but stones he was confounded. etc.

D. Another example how a good mother loved naturelly her child and might not
endure that he had any yile. lxxiii.
IT is written in the third chapter of the third book of kings that two
harlottes came before king Salamon / and the one said unto him. Sir this woman
here and I dwelled together in one house / and I have chylded by her. And the
third day after she childed also. We were togider And there was but we two /
She has ouerlayne her child in ye night in slepynge and it is deed. And she
arose up softely by night in scylence / and took secretly my sone by my side
and put it between her arms. And hers ye which is deed she put it by my side.
When I rose up in the morning for to give the breast unto my sone it appyered
to be deed. And when that I had right well beholden it on the day I knew
incontinent that it was not my sone the which I had engendered. The other
woman answered that it was not so and that she had lied falsely and untruly
/ and said my child lives and thine is deed. And the two women stryued so
before the king Salamon. And then the king Salamon said unto the
assystence. This woman says my sone lives and thine is deed. And the other
answers nay / but thy sone is deed and mine lives. Bring unto me a sword
said ye king and deuyde ye the child quycke in two parties and give unto
every of them one of the said halues of the said child / And ye woman unto
whom apperteyned the quycke child said unto the king Salamon. My heart and mine
entraylles is all moved upon my child. I pray you give unto her the child
quycke and slay it not. And the other cried unto the contrary. That it ne be
unto me ne unto her but that it be divided. The king answered and said. Give
the quycke child unto this woman here the which will not yt it be slain That
she is his propre mother So the people knew that the king Salamon had given
ryghtwyse Judgment and that a good mother loves naturelly her propre child
and ne may endure that it have ylle.

E. Another example how ten children trembled and were punysshed dyuynely after
that yt their mother them had cursed for that yt they had offended her. Ca.
lxxiii
IT is written in the legende of saint steven yt a noble matrone a wedowe woman
was wroth and tormented of the multitude of ye ten children that she had
whereof there was seven males. And three females And one time they offended their
said mother ye which required of god that maledyccyon should come unto them.
And in contynent they were stryken of divine ve^geaunce. For they all by
semblable pain horrybly tremble in their bodies and by all their members / by
the which thing they were much sorrowful. And for as much as the people of
the country ne might endure them of the horror that they had to se them in
such horrybly to tremble / they departed them through out the world
vacabondes. And over all where they yode every man beheld them. And two of
them were heled a sone and a daughter by the merytes of saint steven in the
presence of saint Austin. This example shows that all children should dread
to offend their faders and moders yt maledyccyon and dampnacyon come not unto
them. Also faders and moders ne should curse their children / but should desire
that they have benedyccyon and salvation / and if they ben as forsaken they
should punysshe them and correct sagely and dyscretely.

F. Another example that it displeases unto god yt a woman aourned her
daughter and clothed pompously. lxxvi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book yt a fader and a mother had a daughter the
which served god deuoutely unto the example of her mother and purposed to abide
in virginite. And the fader commanded unto the mother that she should aourne her
daughter after the course of the world the which dredde her husband and
clothed her daughter pompously and seculerly and aourned her face and her
here. Than ye angel by the commandment of god appeared unto her mother and
said unto her. Wherefore haste thou more dredde thy husband than god to aourne
thy daughter / and to take her from Ihesu christ for to put her in to the
world. For this thing thou shall dye within four wekes / and thou shall be
dampened if thou repent the not with in the said time. And more over within the
said time all thy children shall deye / And this day thy hands shall begin to
dry in pain for that yt thou have aourned the here of thy daughter. Than the
said woman did true penance and all happened in like wise as the other had
said unto her. For she deyed and her children within the said term / and also
her hands dried. etc. Those and they the which ben culpable should look upon
this and take example for to correct them and amend to ye end that our
lord Ihesu christ be not wroth against them / and that they have not
punycyon. etc.

Correctio.
A. Examples of correccyon. And first example how sweet correccyon more
profyteth unto the ill than sharp. lxxiiii.
IT is written in the life of the faders and in many other books that as saint
Machayre walked one time by the country he said unto his dyscyple that he
should go acore. And as he yode he met with ye pressed of the ydoles the which
bare a great staff and the dyscyple said unto hy^ wheder go thou devil yt
thou art. And ye said priest wrathed him against him for his hard words /
and bette him so much yt he left him as for half deed. After ye said priest
yode his way. And as he yode his way he met the said Machayre which said unto
him. Thou art a save walker / thou be saved. And the priest meruaylled and
said unto him. What haste thou seen of goodness in me the wiche salutest me in
such wise. And he said I have behold that you labourest strongly in walking.
And the priest said unto him yt in his salutacyon he has had composycyon /
and he knew ye he was the servant of god and that he had met a cursed monk
yt had iniuried him and that for his iniuryes he had strongly beten him. For to
be short by ye sweet words of the said Machayre the said priest yode with him
/ converted himself / and was relygyous / and many paynyms converted them by
the example of ye said priest. And here ye said Machayre said yt a proud word
and an ill conuerteth sometime ye good unto the ill. And a humble word and good
sometime draws the ill to do good Unto this purpose it is written. prouer. xv.
quod respo^^io mol is fra^git ira^ / sermo durus excitat furore^. Et eccle. vi.
Dulce vbu^ inimicos mitigat et amore^ multiplicat.

B. Another example of ye good correccyon yt was done unto a child. lxxiiii.
THe dysciple recyteth in his promptuarye yt a fair sone noble / was given of
his parents in to a monasterye of the black order / for to be discyplyned
regulerly in good manners / the which was instruct of the pryour and correct
by words / and sometime by rod / in so good manner yt he refrayned him from
all things infancybles and vnnefull / and that he was informed in all goodness.
And the said child took the said correccyon humbly. And in like wise grew he
in good perfeccyon till unto the aege of.xx. years and so deyed / And after his
death appeared the soul of him unto the pryour so clear and fair yt the
chamber was all replenysshed with light and he said. Pryour I yield unto the
thanks of the correccyon that thou have put in me. I am not fallen by little
and by little in to sin by ye which I had be dampened / and by the I am
saved. etc.

C. Another example of the correccyon of two relygyous of the which the abbot
corrected the one and spared ye other. lxxiiii
IT is written in ye book of ye sermons of the dyscyple how there was two freres
in a monasterye / of the which the one was gracious and agreeable unto his
abbot and unto the other relygyous / and therefore he was spared and was not
punysshed of his necligences. And the other was not agreeable. And he was
punysshed incontinent that he did a fault. So they deyed both twain. And he
ye which was gracyous appeared unto his abbot after his de death and said unto
him that he was in great pains. And his said abbot demanded him. Where is the
cursed the which committed more of neclygences than you And he said. O fader he
is not cursed / for he is in the clear vysyon of god. For ye neclygences that
he committed were incontinent punisshed. And by that yt the satisfaccyon of his
sins is made / but for that yt thou sparedest me in my neclygences for my
gracyousnes I am now tormented in purgatory. And therefore my fader I require
the pray unto god for me. And yt ye reco^maunde me unto mine other brethren in
their messes to the end that ye deliver me from the great pains wherein I am.
By this example a man should understand that these sinners the which ben often
times punysshed and corrected or those the which gone often unto confession
and do penance ben more sooner saved than those ye which be not repreued /
and the which go not unto confession but one time in the year. etc.

D. Another example how a man should correct him when a man is warned.
THe discyple recites in his sermons and says that a good relygyous
conceplatyf was rauysshed in judgment ye which saw an earl accused before
god and also a great prelate again whom god was wroth. Albeit at the prayer
of some saints ye which there were present god dyfferred his sentence and
said unto yt relygyous ye he should make them to be warned to correct them by
his abbot. the which thing was done. The earl corrected him by the said
admonycyon for the dread of the said vysyon. And the said prelate contempned
the said visyon and correct him not and he deyed suddenly in his bed

E. Another example how a man should correct and draw back the sinners
swetely as saint Johan the which drew well by swetnes ye prince of ye thieves.
lxxiiii
Saint Clement tells in ye fourth book of the hystorye ecclesyastyce that
saint Johan the euangelyst converted a fair yongman the which was cruel the
which he betoke unto a bishop for to enstructe. And a little while
afterward the said man left the bishop and became prince of thieves. And one
time yt saint Johan came again demanded of the said bishop where he was yt
he had reco^maunded so curyously unto him. He answered. Fader he is deed in
spyrite and dwells in such a mountain with thieves and is their prince. Than
saint Johan was wroth and said unto him. Thou art a good keeper / thou have
suffered to lose the soul of thy brother. And anon he took a horse and yode
surely in to ye mountain. And ye young man saw him and had great shame and
lepte on horsbacke and fled hastily. And than the appostle forgate his aege
and stroke the said horse with the sporres and began strongly to cry after him
the which fled Right sweet sone wherefore fleyst you thy fader sone doubt the
not / for I shall yield ye unto Ihesu christ by reason. And certes I shall deye
with good will for the / in like wise as did Ihesu christ for us / for god has
sent me unto the. And when he herd yt he repented him and wept right
bytterly. And the appostle fell at his fete and began to kiss his hand / as
and if he had be lately purged by penance. Than the said appostle fasted for
him and prayed and gate him pardon. And after the said penitent was ordained a
bishop by ye said appostle and was a good man and a devout. etc. By that / ye
saint Johan kyssed the hand of this sinner and drew him again swetely and
called unto penance. In like wise should those do the which wyldrawe back
these persons from sin and bring them unto salvation.

Caritas.
A. Examples of charity and first example of a clustre of grapes the which
was sent unto many by charity. lxxv
IT is written in the life of faders ye a friar relygyo^us gave a grape unto
saint Machayre / and of his charity he sent it unto the most seek and weyke of
his brethern. And he took it and gave it again unto another unto whom it
seemed as him thought that it should be better employed than unto him. And he
sent it again unto another. And this said grape yode so from one to another
till yt it came again at the last unto ye said Machayre ye which had it
first given. And also they ne knew the one of the other. Than the said
Machayre thanked god of the great charity and abstinence yt he saw in his
bredern relygyous. etc. Unto the example of these good religyous here a man
should give so me noueltees to his neighbors if they ben seek and weyke for
to chere them and comfort them. etc.

B. Another example of the charity of two men the which would deye the one /
for the other. lxxv
PEter Alphons tells in his book that two merchants of diverse countrees
met and accompanied together and loved so much the one the oath that the one
took in marriage the daughter of the other. And after yt the marriage was past
and done the said merchants yode back every of them in to his country. And
it be fell that in short time he yt took ye others daughter in marriage lost
all his gods and came unto so great pouerte yt he begged / He came in to the
town where his said compaygnon dwelled. And it happened yt when he arrived yt
men sought an homycyde the which had slain a man / and on him was this crime
put. And how be it yt he was innocent he confessed it. For unto him it forced
not to dye because of his pouerte. And was Iuged and led unto ye gybet. And
when he was there for to be hanged his compaygnon beforsayd knew him and said.
It is not this here the which has done the homycyde. It is I ye which has
done the deed / and would well dye for his compaygnon so much he loved hy^
Than that last was taken and the first delivered. And the homycyde ye which
had done the deed ye which was present had remors in his conscience cried and
said. He there ne this here has not done the homicyde / it was I. Than the
two first were delivered and the last was taken and holden The Iuges were
meruayled / led unto the king the two first delivered and ye last
retained. And after yt the king had known the truth he pardoned al ye pay^
And this first the which was come unto pouerte was releuid of his compaygno^
the which gave unto him ye half of his goods by love and charity. This
example denotes that it is parfyte love and charity as to put his body ye one
for another / whereof speaks the euangelyst Johan. xv ca. Maiore^ caritate^
nemo habet: vt ai^am suam ponat quis pro amicis suis.

C. Another example how an holy man named sanctulus lyuered himself to be slay^
for the love of his compaygnon. lxxv
IT is written in the dialogue of saint gregorye yt the Lombardes took a deken
for to slay him. And a holy man named sanctulus required them gretely of his
delyueraunce / the which ne would here him / but was betaken unto him to keep
by such law that if he escaped that ye said sanctulus should be slain for
him and were so agreed. When the night came ye they slepte the said sanctulus
said unto ye said deken / rise thou and go thy way / and he said unto him. O
fader if I goo my ways they shall slay the / and he said go thy ways. We ben
all in the hands of god / they ne may nothing do unto us but yt god shall
suffer. Than he fled. And after the Lombardes said unto the said sanctulus.
Chose the of what death thou will deye / for thou shalt deye for the deken /
and he said. Sle me of what death yt god shall suffer. Than they chose a strong
man to stryke of his heed at the first stroke. The said sanctulus fell
prostrate in orayson and required god. And wha^ his orayson was made the
hangman made him to stretche the neck / and he lift up the sword in the air
for to slay him in the presence of much people. And when the said sanctulus
had stratche the neck and seen the sword / he said. O sa^cte ioha^nes suscype
illu^. And incontinent saint Johan vyolently held in the air the arm of the
said hangman and they all thanked god. Some required ye by his prayer the arm
were heled. He answered yt he ne would pray for him / but if he would swear
that he should never kyl christian man. And after yt he had sworn said. Put
down thy hand. And it was taken away and heled. Than the lombardes would give
unto him all the oxen and kyen that they had pylled / but he them refused and
required all the prisoners / and they all were given unto him. So by his
charity he delivered them all. This example should move us to love another /
and to put us in danger corporelly for to save and to deliver our neighbors
from ill and from inco^uenyence as did the said sanctulus the which
delivered the deken from death and the prisoners from captyuyte.

D. Another example how god sent a poor man.xx. s. for one penny ye he gave.
IT is written in the book of the discyple that peter damyen recou^ted ye a
poor man fasted with his wife ye which had not but one penny for to by their
diner and he gave his penny unto a poor man as he yode unto the market. And
after that as he was at his table and that the bread was put upon it there came
in a man unknown hastily the which laid.xx. s. in money upon the said table
in a clothe bound and said. This here my lord has sent you and incontinent
he departed. And men presuppose that it was an angel. This example should
move us to give alms to the poor people. For great retrybucyon follows
thereof. For one penny that the said man gave god sent him twelve score. Al so
if any will have vyctorye and to surmounte his enemies / be he a gyuer of
alms. And if he will regne and to flee in to heaven also give he unto the
poor folk. In like wise as says the scripture. Vn^ poeta. Vincit cu^cta dare:
da sivis superare. Per dare regnare poteris: celosque volare. etc.

E. Another example how the heart of a vyrgyn was cut for the great love that
she had unto god. lxxv.
THe discyple recyteth in his promp tuarie this example the which is written in
many other books and says yt a noble vyrgyn was.xiiii. year much devout
unto ye vyrgyn Marye. And by.vii. years every day she required her yt it would
please her to show unto her her child And it befell as on a crystenmas day
she entered alone in to the chapelle because of orayson the vyrgin Marye appeared
unto her holding a fair sone between her arms and said unto her. Take my
sone and play with him. And she took him with great Joy / reverence and
devotion. And ye said child demanded her / love thou me And she answered /
ye. Whether said he love thou me more than my clothes / and she said. I love
you more than my heart / And ye said child said. How love thou me more than
thy heart. The answer / I ne can tell it / but the same speak. And inco^tynent
the heart of the said vyrgyn for the great love that she had to the said sone
it brake in sondre. And so deyed the said vyrgyn. Than the child took her
soul and so great song and melodye of aungelles was there to bear the said
soul in to heaven / yt the people ran unto the chapel the whic^e were
replenysshed of meruayllous odoure. And they found the said vyrgyn deed. And
her heart cut wherein was wryt^n in lettres of god. I love ye more than myself.
For thou haste create me redeemed and endowed. etc. After the scypture and this
example we should love god more than our self. vn^. math. Diliges dn^m deu^ tuu^
ex toto cord tuo et ex tota ai^a tua.

F. Another example of the charity of him the which did wy^ne his brother the
which was fallen in to fornycacion for to make him self a sinner / and in
doing penance. lxxv.
IT is written in the life of ye faders how two bredren yode to sell in the cite
yt / that they had wrought. And when they were departed in yt cite / one of
them fell in fornycacyon. After that his brother came unto him and said. Brother
return we in to our habytable / he answered I may not return / he demanded
the cause. And he said unto him. After that thou departest fro me I was tempted
and I am fallen in to fornycacyon. And his brother said yt so was he / but
return we together do we penance with great labor. and god shall pardon us
our sy^ne. When they were returned they told it to ye auncyentes. The which
gave them in charge the manner how they should do penance. and the one of them
did penance / but for ye other brother also as he was culpable to have sy^ned.
In few days god showed unto one of the au^cyentes yt the sin of hy^ the
which had done fornycacyon unto him was pardoned by the great charity of
the other the which had not sinned / This example is greatly to be noted /
For for to socoure his brother the which was fallen in to the sin of lecherye
/ and in to the bonds of the devil. And in the way of perdycyon and
da^pnacyon eternell. He made himself a sinner and took labor and penance for
him / yt was charity and great socour did unto his neighbor. In this thing it
appears yt he loved his brother as himself / and that he socoured him in his
necessyte as he wylled yt a man should do unto him / and for the great charity
the sin was pardoned. etc.

G. Another example how one friar wtdrewe another from ill will / not by force
but by charity and pacyence. lxxv
IT is written in the life of faders yt a friar came one time unto a great
ancient and said unto him I have a brother the which goes on the one side and
on the other without holding him with me / and therefore am I tormented. And
the au^cyent said unto him. Bear it pacyently. When god shall se the labor of
thy supporting he shall call him again unto ye ne wene thou not by austeryte
yt any shall withdraw him from his entencyon / for one devil ne expels
another devil / but by benygnyte thou shall make him come again unto the. Our
lord draws unto him many in cherynge them. And he recou^ted to him of two
freres of the which the one was fallen in fornycacyon / the which would
return unto the world and the other wept and said. Brother I shall not suffer
the to return and be lost. And for yt yt he would nothing do / he went to
take cou^sayl of a great ancient which said unto him. Go you with hy^ in to ye
world / god ne shall suffer him to be lost for thy labor than he yode with
him. And when they came in to a street god ye same the charity of ye friar
which yode to save his brother took away ye co^cupyscence of ye friar sy^ner.
Than he said unto his brother yt they should return unto their hermytage. I
wend now to have sinned with the woman but I have no more of will sith yt I
have conquest in such deed. And they retour in to their hermytage in devotion
wtoute co^myttynge sin. By these examples be foresaid it appears that a man
should have love and charity with his faders and neighbors. And as a man
should honor them and socour them in their necessytees.

Qintu^ preceptu^.
Homicidiu^ i^iustu^.
A. Examples of those the which have done homicide iniustely. And first
example of Cayn the which slew abel his brother. Ca. lxxvi
IT is written in the.iiii. chapitre of gene that after that Cayn had slay^ his
brother abell by envy and cursednes god demanded / where is thy brother Abell /
he answered I can not tell / am I the keeper of my brother. And god said unto hy^
what haste thou done / the voice of the blood of thy brother cries unto me from
the earth It is yt that demands vengeance / and incontinent god cast forth
maledyrcyon. Vn^. gene. iiii. Nu^c maledictus eris superira^ cu^ operatus
fueris ea^ no^ dabit tibi fructus suos: spinas and tribulos germinabit tibiva
gus et profugus eris super terram. That is to say thou shalt be cursed above
the earth When thou it shall labor it ne shall give unto his fruytes. It
shall bring forth thorns and thystylles / you shall be wandryng and fugytyue
upon the earth. Cayn saw that his brother Abell was better than he / and more
loved of god because that he paid better his dysmes then he did. / And
therefore god multeplyed his goods and fruytes / and sent unto him
habou^dau^ce. And unto cayn and unto his gifts he regarded nothing. So Cayn
wrathed him hugely and had envy upon his brother and slew hy^. Vn^ ge. iiii.
Propter hoc deus respexit ad abel et ad munera eius: ad cayn et ad munera eius
no^ respexit: iratusque est cayn veheme^ter inuidit super fratre^ suu^ et
occidit. Envy proceeds to se and to consider that his neighbor is better
than himself in any thing be it temporell good or spyrytuell. Vn^ grego. i^
mora. Inuidere eni^ non possumus nisi eis quos nobis in aliquo meliores esse
putamus. That is to say we ne may have envy but unto those yt which we wene
to be better than we in some thing. By this example and by ye scryptures a man
should understand that those the which follows the life of Cayn have
maledyccyon. Vn^ in epi. jude. ii. ca. Ve his qui via cayn abieru^t erroris
ba^aa^ mercede effusi su^t: et contradictione chore perieru^t. For to
understand what maledyccyon is. A man should understand ye maledyccyon is
putting from benedyccyon and from all goods spyrytuel / and assocyacyon with al
ill. And when a person is cursed of god and of the church knowing that he is
pryued from benedyccyon / and from all goods spyrytuelles done in holy church
/ and is assocyate with all ill. And if he deye in such estate impenytent he
shall be put from paradyse / as says saint poule. i. co. vi. Neque maledicti
regnu^ dei possi debu^t. Also when a man obeys sooner to the devil than to
god / he is much cursed or when he leueth god for to follow the devil / or
when he loves sy^nes and leueth virtues. Vn^ psalm. Dilexit maledictione^ and
veniet ei* noluit benedictionem et elongabitur ab eo. etc. That is to say. He
has loved malediccion and it shall come unto him / And he has not wylled to
have benedyccyon / and it shall be lenthed from him.

B. Another example how the king achab and iezabell his wife made to sle
Naboth for to have his vyneyarde. lxvi.
IT is written in the.xxi. chapter of the third book of kings that the king
Achab coueyted to have and to possede ye vyneyard of a good man named Naboth.
And for as much as he ne might have it ne by sale ne by eschaunge was sorry.
And laid him down and would not eat. The said Naboth would not sell the
heritage of his predecessors. And Iesabell wife of the said Achab comforted
her husband. And to be short in the matere she sent lettres unto the
grettest of the cite. And caused to make false wytnes again the said Naboth.
And so made him to be stoned and slain. And when he was deed by the counsayll
of Iesabell Achab went to take possessyon of the said vyneyarde / and the
word of god was made in the prophet Helye in saying. Arise and dyscenbe thou
again the king Achab and thou shall say unto him. Thou have slain Naboth
and possedeth his vyneyard / god has said yt in the place where the dogs
have lycked the blood of Naboth / they shall lycke thy blood. More over god
has said that he shall send ill upon the and upon thy house: as unto
Hieroboam the which was cursed and brought unto naught. etc. Great
thretenynges ben here written. And the said prophet Helye said unto Iezabell yt
god had said yt the dogs should ete Iezabel in such a field. When ye king
Achab herd these words here / he cut his clothes and cladde his flesh with
a sack / fasted and slepte in a sack the heed bowyng down And when god had
seen his humilite said unto the prophet Helye. Haste thou not seen Achab
humble him for because of me I ne shall send him the said ill in his days /
but in ye days of his sone I shall bring in ill unto his house. And so was it
done. And it is written in the.ix. chapter of the.iiii. book of kings that
Iezabell deyed myscheuously. For ye king Cheu made her be cast forth at a
wyndowe in to the street / and the horses of his army yode over her
notwithstondynge that she was a kings daughter. And after the dogs brake her
body and she ne was buried. this example denotes many things The first is the
auaryce and couetyse to have and possede the vine of Naboth yt which is
fraccyon of ye.x. commandment of god. Non ^o^cupisces re^ proximi tui. The
second is false wytnessyng. No^ falsu^ testimontu^ dices. And also homycyde.
No^ sis occisor / ye third is great punycyons temporelles and corporelles
follow after without the punicyon eternell for the fraccyon of ye three
commandments of god. And it is here to be noted that by the penance and
humylyte of the king Achab god spared him in his life / but his sone bare the
punicyon of his said fader the which is great matere to understand and to
moralyze the which shall abide because of shortness. And the false harlot
Iezabell the which humbled her not was slain and eten of dogs the which is
a long thing to declare / in like wise as it is written in the foresaid
chapter. etc.

C. Another example how Ioab slew ye prince Abner malycyously and Amasam and
ill came unto him. lxxvii.
IT is written in the chapter of the second book of kings how Ioab the which
was capytayne and chyef of ye werre of king Dauyd slew malycyously a prince
named Abner for to venge hy^ of his brother that the said Abner had slain in
batayl. And dauyd was gretely wroth of that murdre wept upon his grave and ne
would never in ye day ne ete ne drink till that the sone was gone to rest /
and said unto his servants the which would make him to ete. Ye know not yt
a pry^ce and that right great is fallen this day in Israhell. Our lord grant
unto them the which have done ye ill after their malice. And it is written in
the second chapter of the third book of kings that in contynent that dauyd
was deed the said Ioab fled in to the tabernacle of our lord / and held him
nere the altar for to warraunt him. For the king Salamon commanded that he
were slain / for that yt he had slain two men better than himself without
the consenting of dauyd / yt is to understand Abner prince of the chyualrye
of Israhell / and Amasam prince of the army of Judas. And the said Ioab would
not come forth of the tabernacle / And there was slain by the commandment
of Salamon. Men say inco^une la^gage / he that sleethe with the sword with
the sword shall deye. etc.

D. Another example how herod Ascalonyta made to sle the innocents. lxxvii.
THe euangelyst saint mathieu makes mencyon / yt when god was borne in
bethelem ye three ky^ges came out of orient for to worship him / and demanded
king herod where yt he was borne.: When herodes herd these words he was
greatly troubled / and those of Iherusalem with him. And inquysycyon was made
where it was that Ihesus should be borne / the great clerks said that it
should be in bethleem as it was written by ye prophet mychee. vi. Et tu
bethelem terra judah nequaquam minima as i^ principibus judah: ex te eni^ exi et
dux qi regat populu^ meu^ israel. Than ye king herodes called the other kings
and asked them dylygently in what time the sterre appeared unto them. And sent
them in to bethelem to enquere dylygently where he was borne. And when they had
found hy^ yt they should come again unto hy^ in faynynge to go to worship him
/ but it was for to slay him. When ye kings had found him and worshypped him
it was said unto them in a dreme that they should not return unto herodes /
but goo in to their countrees by another way. And so was it done. Afterward
when herodes saw that ye kings returned not by hy^ and that he was mocked he
sent in to bethelem and made to sle all the children the which were in the
country of the aege of two years and under / wenynge for to slay our
redemptoure Ihesus. And the souls of ye holy innocents cried unto god
vengeance of their blood that herodes had made them to shed. And they had
dyuyne answer that they should tarry yet a little time till that the nombre of
their brethren were accomplysshed. The said herodes ne abode unpunished in
like wise as it is written in the hystorye scolastice. For he began his hell
from this world before that he deyed / he became blown so sty^kynge foul
and vyllayne yt there ne was person yt might approach unto him. and also he
had his guts eten with worms. Legitur etia^ actuu^. xii. By this history it
appears that the said herodes was much cursed where as he would not give
honor unto god as the other kings / but would slay him. And in wenynge to do
him ylle made to sle great nombre of fair children And therefore he had well
deserved punycyon the which came upon him ye which should be to long a thing
to tell. etc.

E. Another example how Herodes Antypas made to slay saint Johan baptyste (ca.
lxxvi.)
IT is written in the.xiiii. chapitre of the gospelles of saint Mathieu yt saint
Johan baptyst reproved herod of his lecherye and said unto him that it was not
lefull to have ye wife of his brother philyppes. By this thing herod was
wroth and by the cou^sayll of his harlot herodien he made saint Johan baptist
to be put in prison for to sle him / but he fered the people for they held him
as a prophet. And Herodes made a great dinner the day of his natyuyte unto the
princes and great of his court. And his daughter daunced at dinner and lepte
and pleased so well Herod the which said unto her with an oath that she should
axe what she would and he would grant it her and if it were half his realm.
This thing was done malycyously for to have the occasyon to make saint Johan
to die Than herodyane counsaylled her daughter. And made her to say unto the
king Give me in a great dysshe right hastily ye heed of saint Johan baptyste.
And ye king feigned to be wroth for the oath and ye prasence the which there
dyned. And sent to behede in prison saint Johan baptyste And ye heed was
brought in a dysshe and presented unto the lepynge wenche. The scripture makes
mencyon that there were three kings herodes. The first had to name Ascolonita
the which slew the innocents. The second antipa / the which made saint
Johan baptyst to be slain / The third Herod had to name Agrippe the which
made to slay saint James the more. And put saint peter in prison. It is written
in speculo historiali yt a doctor named vincent recites in the said book yt a
holy man by vysyon and permyssyon divine saw in hell ye beforsayd kings
herodes the which were hanged in the fire of hell being in great torments.
And the said harlot was hanged under them more cruelly tormented than the said
herodes. For she had two serpents ye which held her by the breasts / and
bote her. And by punycyon and permyssyon dyuyne his said harlot herodes antipa
bote him in the throat often times as if he would have strangled him Also ye said
harlot had in her heed so many of litell bestes as litell serpents that by his
estimacion as she might have of herys. yt which bestes bote her incessably
etc.

F. Another example how judas / pylate / and this other iewys were homicides
of the death of owre blyssyd savior and redemptour Jesus. lxxvi.
IT is written in the gospellys And in many other books yt judas sold our
savior and redemptour jesus crist unto the jews for.xxx. penyes. unto whom he
said. he that I kiss take and bind him for he it is: and after that he had
lyuered him unto them and betaken by ye said toke^ repented him And yielded unto
them the said pence. More over he despeired ha^ge him self and estrangled.
Than the princes of ye prestes: and the cou^seil of ye iewys sought the ways
and the means to make him to day by envy and coursednes For they se the
miracles and predicacions that he made. And the world went after hy^. They
saw that he was just and good: and yt he reproved them of their sins. And
therefore they sought false wytnes for to accuse him / but they found none. and
they accused him of.iiii. things. The first was that they said that they had
a law. after the which he should deye The second that he deceived / and
moved the people unto ill. The third that he deffended to pay ye tribute unto
caesar The.iiii. that he did again ye majesty in as much as he said him self
to be god. Of the three last things pylate knew well that they lied and they
said it by envy Vnde mat. xxvii. Sciebat eni^ quod per inuidia^ tradidissent
eu^ And therefore pylate restyde at the first: and said unto them. Sith that I
have a law after ye which he should dye the^ judge ye hy^ after your law. Than
they answered him that it was not lefull unto them yt they should put any man
unto death. For to be short in the matter Pylate ne found cause of death in
Ihesus. And for to satysfye unto the Jews said yt he should be punysshed for
his fautes. And made him to be bound unto a pyller and to be beten. and so
much was he broken yt al his body was in blood and wounds. And so betoke him
unto the Jews / but yet were they not content they crowned him with thorns
and put it down with staves / and cried unto Pylate that they might crucefye
him. And by cause yt he said yt he ne found in him cause to make him deye /
they cried. Sa^guis eius super nos: et super filios nostros. That is to say.
His blood be upon us and upon our children. And so it was done. For
afterward Vaspasien beseged the cite of Iherusalem. And they were so
affamysshed yt a woman ete her own child. And they ete their treasoures
wenynge for to bear them away. And when the cite was taken / some deyed of
hongre / some other with the sword / and other take prisoners and sold And men
gave.xxx. for a penye. And one of those accused them ye they had eaten their
treasours. So every man yode to sle his prisoners for to have their money. so
their children had for to do. When men led Ihesus to crucefye ye women of
Iherusalem wept. Unto whom Ihesus said weep ye not upon me / but upon your
children. For the days shall come yt the wombes shall be blyssed ye which
has not borne / and the pappes the which has not given souke. The Jews
were homycydes and the cause of the death of our lord ye which was Iuged
unjustly and condampned of Pylate to be crucefyed / and so suffered death and
passion / and had in his body five thousand.CCCClxxvi. wounds for our
redempcyon. Pylate the which Iuged hy^ abode not unpunished / and deyed
myscheuously. For afterward the Emperor caesar would make him to deye. and as
he was in prison he dyspayred him and slew himself with a knyfe. And for as
much as he slew himself Caesar made a stone to be hanged about his neck and
to cast him in to tybre the which ran by the cite of rome. And incontynente
the deuylles and cursed spyrytes there made such a lyghteny^ge and tempest for
the reason of such a cursed body that man ne woman ne might dure / ne bote /
ne ships durst not thereon go. And when the romans saw such tempest they
made him to be drawn out and cast in to the river of Rosne.

A. Another example how Lucrece made to slay saint Beatryce. lxxvii.
IT is written in the legende of saint Beatrice yt a cursed man named lucrece
coueyted to have the heritage of beatryce. And to the end that he might come to
his entencyon accused her that she was crystyenne. And made her to be slain by
martyrdom but he abode not unpunished. For when he had taken the possession
of the said heritage he reioysed him and made a dynere. And a little child at
the pappe cried. Lucrece thou have slain beatryce and possedeth her heritage.
And you art given in to the possessyon of ye devil And incontinent Lucrece
gaped / the devil entered in him the which tormented him three hours and after
slew him. So it appears that homycydes and thieves covetous ben punysshed in
this world or in the other / or in both.

B. Another example of a man yt slew his fader and his mother / when he was
dronken. lxxvii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says that as a dronken man came from the tavern he met his
fader the which blamed him and repreued of his exces of drink / And then
incontinent he drew out his sword and slew his said fader. And as his mother
herd the bruyte and the clamor she ran theder a great pace / and he did
slay her as he had done his beforsayd fader. Incontynente the neighbors came
out and took him / and led him into a prison. And in the morning there was
great marvel of that that he had done.

C. Another example of a servant that served well his master in youth / and
when he was drunk slew him. lxxvii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye of a man yt served a king right
faithfully. And when he was young he governed hy^ well and much pleased his
service unto his master. And he was sent unto a dinner at the which he became
dro^ken and slew the king and his sons. Also when we fast the vices flee
from us and make our service agreeable unto god our king. And when we be
dronken we slay all our virtues / and the king that is our soul and reason.
And the sons they ben his five wits with the which we should govern our
bodies / and do meritoryous deeds.

D. Another example of a daughter the which slew her fader and her mother /
and after had mercy by contrycion and confession. lxxvii.
THe disciple recites in his pro^ptuarye yt Peter says in his second book
de amore that a knight had a fair daughter the which sinned with her. and
her mother knew that they sinned together by euydent signs / of the which men
aduerted her / but they ne would sclau^dre for the confusyon. When ye maid
understood yt her mother knew her sy^ne / by cou^sayll of an old woman she
poisoned her. And the fader had horror of his sin and left her. Wherefore
the daughter poysonned him also. And when she had so slain her fader and mother
she dyspayred thynky^g not to have mercy till unto that she herd preche yt in
contrycyon and confession all sins were pardonned. Albeit that they were the
moo^t grace and fou^^ that man may speak / so m^che is great the b^ounte and
grace of god. Than ye said daughter came to the precher for to confess her /
and for her great dysperacyon ne might declare all her sins in confession.
And after yt he had chered her she confessed truly her sins with so many of
teres and of lamentacyons yt it was meruayll / and said that she was worthy to
have all pain and confusyon. After that she had confessed her and that she had
received penance salutarie she entered in to the church with her chamberere
and fell prostrate in orayson and wept and lamented her sins in so great
dolor and haboundaunce of teres yt she deyed in the place. And afterward as
her confessor preched and desired the people to pray for her he herd a voice
the which said yt he and the people had more great need of great haboundau^ce
of teres she had be puryfyed and washed in like wise as of new baptized and
so flewe in to heaven wtoute the pains of purgatory.

E. Another example how dauyd made to slay Vrye unjustly and committed
aduoutrye. lxxvii
IT is written in the.xi. chapitre of ye second book of kings that dauyd
beheld out at a wyndowe ye wife of vrye as she washed her / and for her
beauty was tempted and deceived. For he her coueyted / loved and slepte with
her. And when her husband Vrye servant of the said dauyd came from the war
to bring tidings to his master / dauyd said unto him that he should go to
lie with his wife And sent after him vyande ryall / but the said Vrye would not
lie with his wife but excused him honestly. Afterward dauyd wrote again unto
his captain a pistyl by Vrye that in the place where the danger of death
should be he should put Vrye in batayl to the end that he were slain / and so
was it done. And it follows incontinent in ye.xii. chapitre ye god sent
nathan unto dauyd unto whom he said. Answer me of a Judgment. Two men were in
one cite one rich and one poor. The rich had oxen and sheep and goods
habou^dau^tly / and the poor ne had but one sheep that he had bought and
nourished. And so much he loved her yt she ete of his bread and drank of his
cup and slept in his bosom And it befell that a pilgrim came unto ye rich
the which spared his sheep and yode to take the sheep of the said poor / and
prepayred of metes unto him / for ye that he was come to him. When david herd
these words here he was much wroth and said unto Nathan. God sees. For he
the which has done this thing is culpable of death / he shall yield the
sheep in four double because he has done this thing. And Nathan said unto
hy^. Thou art he the which has done this thing. god has made the king
and given the of goods yt which has despised his words. Thou haste slain
Vrye by glayue / and also has taken his wife for thyself. For this thing the
glayue shall not depart from thy house. God has said yt he shall send ill
upon the and upon thy house / and shall take thy wives before thyn eyes and give
them unto thy neighbor the which shall sleep with those women. Thou haste
done thy sin secretly / and I shall do all these things before all the
people of Israhell. And dauyd said unto Nathan. Peccaui dn^o. I have sinned
unto my lord. And incontinent as david had reknowleged his fault and that he
had said peccaui / Nathan said unto him. God has translated thy sin thou
shalt not deye / but thy sone yt is proceeded of the shall deye / and so was
it done as it is written in the said chapter. etc.

F. Another example how a knight was strongly tormented in purgatory for that
that he vyoled the chircheyarde / and hurt a man within it. lxxvii
IT is written in ye legende of ye deed that as a knight was laid in his bed
with his wife / and the moon was clear the which entered by the holes / he
meruaylled him much wherefore the man the which is reasonable obeyde not unto
his creator / when the creatures not reasonnables obeyed unto hy^. And began
to missaye of a knight deed the which had be his pryue friend. And the said
knight deed entered in speaking these words in the chamber all suddenly / unto
whom he said Friend have thou none ill suspeccyon of me in any things / but
pardon me if I have any thing sinned in the. And when he demanded him of his
estate he said unto him I am tormented of diverse pains for yt that I have
vyoled the chircheyarde and hurt a man within it / and him dispoylled of his
mauntelles hode / the which is upon me more heuyer than a mountain. And the
said deed man prayed him that he would do make oraysons for him Than he
demanded if such a priest should sing for him. The said deed answered
nothing / yt is he spoke no word / but lift up and shoke his heed in like
wise as he them refused. And afterward him demanded if he would that such an
hermyte prayed for him. And he said I will well that he pray for me. And when
the said knight had promised it him ye deed said unto him. And I say the that
this day two years thou shalt deye. And so was it done. This example denotes
many things. The first is that one man should not say ill of another in as
much as ye deed body repreued him that spoke ill of him. The second is that a
man should keep hy^ to do and to speak ylle in holy ground in as much as the
deed body was in purgatori for that / yt he had vyoled the said church yard.
And also that a man ne should betene do none ill unto his neighbor / for
punycyon follows in this world and in the other. The third thing that the
example denotes is yt the prayers and oraysons of a good person ben more
sooner exalted than those of sinners in sin. It is here understand by that yt
the deed loved the prayer of the hermyte more sooner than of the other
beforsayd. How be it ill priests empayre not the sacrament of the mass / but
