those the which accedeth unworthily is unto their dampnacyon.

G. Another example how the angel showed unto tongdalus a valeye replenisshed
with coals of fire in the which were put the homycydes. lxxvii.
MEn find by writing yt a man amed Tongdalus deyed. And yt the angel led
him to se the torments of hell. And afterward brought him again and put
him in to his body. The which recompted many torments among the which the
angel showed / him unto a valeye much horrible and full of derkenesses the
which was right deep full of coals bre^nynge. And above yt valeye was there a
covering of iron in fire bre^nyng in thyknes as of a six fadom the which was
more hoter than the coals the which brenned under it. From thens yode forth
so great stenche the which grieved more ye souls than all yt that they had
suffered before. Under the said couerture descended many souls ye which were
fried as men frye the bacon in the pan. And afterward they were streyned as men
strain wax through the clothe. And so fell they and dyscended in to the botom
of the said valey / upon the coals brennynge / upon the which they were
tormented of a new torme^te. Than said the angel / this pain suffers those
the which have killed faders or moders / systers or broders or other people.
Also ben in this torment those yt which have had will to sle another by
delyberacyon if they might / albeit that they have not done it / and after that
tormente shall be led in to more great.

Homicidium dubium.
A. Examples of homycyde doubtous / and first example how saint Peter made to
deye Ananye and his wife saphyre for that that they fraulded of the price of a
field. lxxviii.
IT is written in the fifte chapter of the deed of the appostles that a man
named ananie his wife saphyre present sold his field and fraulded of the
price his said wife culpable. And bare away one party and put it under the
fete of the appostles. He should all bear for that he should yield it in the
co^munyte without being propryetayre. And saint Peter said unto ananye.
Ananye wherefore haste you tempted satan thyn heart / thou have lied in ye
holyghoost and fraulded of the price of the field / when thou possedest it you
haste puyssaunce either to hold it / or to sell it / wherefore haste thou put
this thing in thy heart. Thou have not lied unto men but unto god. When ananye
herd this thing he fell and expyred / that is he was deed / and was buried /
within three hours saphyre entered the which knew nothing of the deed. / And
saint Peter said unto her. Tell me woman if thou haste sold the field at such
a price. She answered yt ye. And saint peter said unto her. What needs you to
tempte the spyryte of our lord / here be ye fete of those the which has
buried thy husband / the which shall burye the. And she fell deed before his
fete. And the young men took her / and buried her with her husband. And great
dread was made in the church. And so kept these other for to be propryetayre.
Here is example that all relygyous and other shall be punysshed if they take or
witholde of the goods of ye co^munyte.

B. Another example how dauyd made to slay the young man the which lied to say
that he had slain saul. lxxviii
IT is written in the first chapter of the second book of kings that a young
man came to bring the tydy^ges unto dauyd that he had slain his aduersarye
the king saul and his sone Ionathas in wenynge to be welcome. And albeit he
lied / for he had not slain the said Saul Sothe it was yt he had slain
himself / and dauyd demanded of the yongman how know thou that saul is deed
/ he answered and said. I am come of adventure in the mountain of gelboe / and
saul lened him upon his axe / he called me and said what anguysshes held him
of al parts and desired that I would sle him / and I have slain hy^ For I
knew well that he ne might live after the ruin / for his adversaries
approached unto him. And I have taken the dyademe the which was on his heed and
the aournement of his arm / and have brought them unto the. When dauyd herd
these tydy^ges took his clothes and cut them And all they yt were with him
wept and fasted till unto ye euentyde. He was not joyous of the death of his
aduersarye ye which made war on him. Dauyd came again unto the yongman the
which had brought him ye tidings and said unto hy^. Wherefore have thou not
dredde to put thy hand and to slay a king. And dauyd called one of his
servants and made to sle ye said yongman / and said thy blood be upon thy
heed / thy mouth to speak again them saying I have slain saul. etc. By this
example a man should understand yt ill came unto the yongman the which wend
to be welcome for to tell yt thing that he had not done. Also no good
spyrytuell ne proceeds of lyenge / and to vaunte him to have done ylle. Also
this example denotes yt a man should not enjoy of the death perdycyon and
ruin of his adversaries.

C. Another example how dauyd slew Golyas phylystyen incyrcumsysed. lxxviii
IT is written in the.x. chapter of ye first book of kings that the
phylystyens the which made war with the people of Israhell came one time
again them among the which there was one named Golyas the which was
incyrcu^sysed / proud / reno^med / strong / and puissau^t well armed the
which dysdeyned the sons of Israhell. And for asmoche as he was strong he
ne doubted person / defied the children of Israhel / and said unto them that
ye most strongest of them should come to fight again him and he the which
should have the vyctorye should be master of all the other. And for as much
as he was so strongly armed / redoubted and dredde every man fered to assayl
him. etc For end and conclusyon dauyd the which kept beestes was moved unto
ye zele of the law putting his trust in god offered himself unto ye king
saul for to go fight. And Saul armed him and put an helm on his heed. When
dauyd had assayed it said yt he could not in such wise fight / and that he
had not accustomed to bear armoure / so made to unarm him / and took five
stones / his slynge / and his staff yt he had of custom to have after his
bestes and yode unto Golias. When he saw dauyd with his staff he dyspreysed
him and said unto him. What wenyst thou I am a dog the which come unto me
with a staff. And Golyas cursed dauyd in his goods / and said unto him. Come
unto me and I shall give thy flesh unto the birds of the sky and unto ye
beestes of the earth. And dauyd said unto him. Thou come unto me with glayue
/ axe / and armoure. And I go unto the in the name of god of Israhell and thou
shall be slain / to the end that all earth know that there is one god in
Israhell and that he ne saves in axe and armoures. ^han Golyas herd these
words he lift him up and took him to come again dauyd. And Dauyd hasted him
to fight and took a stone out of his pouche and kest it in the foreheed of
golyas / and made him to fall unto the earth upon his forheed he yode upon him
and for that that he had no sword to draw / he drew the sword and glayue
from golyas and cut of his heed / and so had the vyctorye of the phylystyen /
orguyllous incyrcumsysed that byleued in gods strau^ce and mortal. etc.

Ire.
D Example of a woman dampened for Ire without being in will to pardon and to
forgive. lxxviii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermon that there was a woman right full of Ire
and wrath that with pain any might accord with her. But notwithstondynge she
reputed herself to be holy and devout / for she fasted much and excercysed
in fastings and oraysons and in many good operacyons. But she had
pryncypally this vice yt after that a person had only offended her one time
she never loved him after. And no person ne might put her out of that Ire
and vengeance. When she came unto the death she confessed her of all her
sins except of this Ire. And as the priest would have given her the body of
god / she shyt the mouth and turned her toward the wall and said unto the
priest and unto all the men and women the which were present In like and
semblable wise as I turned me from al those the which has offended and
trespassed against me / And that I ne would pardon them with heart I ne might
love them parfytely. And yt I have hold me in Ire in lettyng other. In like
wise god takes and torneth from and shall never look on me mercyfully / ne I
him Ioyouslye in the realm of heaven for mine Ire / but I shall enter in to
hell with the deuylles and with all Irefull where I shall brenne eternelly. And
so the said Irous departed and deyed. etc. By this yt this said woman ne would
corecte her in her life of the said Ire and vengeance / and that she confessed
her not in her death it is to presuppose that she is dampened to consider the
said words yt she spoke at her departing. And a man should here clearly
understand yt one mortal sin dampneth the person the which co^mytteth it /
what good deed so ever he has done in his life. So deyed she without
penance correccyon and amendment vnde ezechielis xxxiii. Iustitia iusti no^
liberabit eu^ in quacu^que die peccauerit. etc.

Odium.
A. Examples of hate / and first example how the lone of a rich man was
dampened for to keep Ire in his heart and for that he would be venged. lxxix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in the book of his sermons and says that a nobe man
had a sone the which yode unto the church and served god in fastnges /
oraysons and in doing good operacyons. And when the said sone was in the death
bed his fader prayed him that he would pere unto him when he was deed if it
pleased unto god for to show him of his estate / and of the merit of his life
/ the which so appeared and said unto him. Fader pray ye no more for me / for
I am dampened / and in so great pains that if there were as many of tongues as
there are of sterres in the sky ne might express the pains yt I have. And
his fader said unto him. And have not thou ben chaste / abstynent / and
devout. etc. He answered ye / but I have lost all the good deeds that I have
done as unto salvation for Ire and vengeance that I have retained in my heart
again those yt which has offended me After that a person had done me ill
one only time I ne might never love him / and venged me all times when I might
/ and for that only vice I am lost and dampened eternally. When he had spoken
these words he departed. This example denotes and techeth that Ire / hate /
and vengeance ledeth unto dampnacyon. For it is again charity and the
commandment of god the which says. Diliges proximum tuum sicut te ipsum.
Men find by writing that the said boy was one time in a tree / and bette
down and took the apples of his neighbor / and a good man the which paste
by made him to dyscende / showed unto him his case / and by correccyon gave
unto him a buffet. And the said boy thretened him and said unto him that he
should yield it him how be it that he tarried / and after that as often as he se
hy^ he showed him with his finger in saying There is he the which bet me / but
when I am great I shall yield it him. The ylle will that he kept in his courage
made hy^ to be dampmned and lost. And therefore for to have salvation it
behooves to put out all hates and rancoures / and to pardon unto another in
like wise as we require of god that he pardon us our sy^nes Also by this
example is to be noted that good operacions ben put in forgetefulnes as unto
salvation how be it that a man ne should withdraw him to do good deeds as many
as he may in this world. / For it serves unto the dymynycyon of ye pain.

B. Another example how hatours the which slew a man in ye church were
punysshed dyuynely. lxxix.
IT is written in the promptuarye of the miracles of the vyrgyn marye that three
knights hated a man the which sought the opportunyte for to sle him And one
time as they would have slain him he fled in to the church consecrate in
the honor of the vyrgin marye for to escape the peril of death / they yode
after entered into the church irreuently and cruelly slew him before the
altar of the vyrgyn Marye. For this thing the vyrgyn emoued her against them
/ and incontinent vengeance of god came upon them for their presumpcyon /
they were embraced with fyren such manner that ye members of every of them
brenned. When they apperceyued ye dyuyne vengeance to be on them they were
constrained to beseech ye vyrgyn Marye of grace / and returned unto her by
great contrycyon of heart. And she the which is fulfilled with pity delivered
them from the fire by the grace of god: but not full health. After yt they
might go they presented them unto the bishop / requyrynge him of penance. And
he enjoined them to bear upon them ye armoures that they had when they slew
him And that they should repent them evermore till unto that that they had
satysfyed unto god and unto the blessed vyrgyn Marye.

C. Another example how the devil did sle a man for the keeping of hate and
would not pardon it. lxxix.
MEn find by writing ye two men neighbors pleded togiders and hated other
so much that their curates knew not what to do at every ester. and one time
the said curate gave them monycyon to pardon the one the other and to love
togyders / or that they ne should receive their creator in the estate of grace
/ and he that had the leest of wrong pardoned him all and put him in his
deuoyre. And ye other would not pardon. And for as much as his curate menaced
hy^ not to give hy^ his creatoure / for as much as he should tarry / and of
dread / of office said with the mouth and not with the heart that he pardoned.
And they received togider their creatoure. After the mass as they yode together
to their houses / for it was their way He the which had lest of wrong
followed the other to have him to dinner with him and right gretely prayed him
and his wife The which answered yt he loved better to dyne with Satan and to
eat with all ye deuylles in hell than with him. Ha said he wenest thou to
play ye knave with me in such wise / when ye feast is past I shall handle the
well enough. And the other said / my neighbor have ye in such wise received
your creatoure / ye have received him in ill estate. After they departed For he
the which had wrong dwelled ferther of than ye other. And when he was nere
to a wodde ye devil came unto him in lykenes of a black man / the which took
him horrybly and said unto him. Thou ill crystyen wors than a sarazyn / or than
I am yt haste not done honor unto thy creator yt you have received in mortal
sy^ne For as much as thou haste not wylled to pardon unto thy neighbor unto
whom thou haste said that thou love better to dyne with the deuylles than
with him / at this hour thou shall come to dinner with them. I am the devil
the which evermore has stered the to do ill. And I ne had never puyssaunce
to sle the unto this day But thy god has given me leave and license / and it
is suffered that at this hour thou have punycyon and dampnacyon. And therefore
thou woman go tell unto thy curate that I command him to come hastily here for
to take the body of Ihesu christ that this cursed crystyen has received /
For to be short the devil slew the said hater. The curate came with great
company of people the which took the body of our lord in like wise as god it
suffered and wylled. And the devil did him honor and yode on knees. And
after took the body of the said man and bare it away. Alsoo men find many
other Examples of haters the which ne would pardon unto their neighbors. And
therefore they dyffyned ylle their days horrybly and myscheuously. wherefore men
presuppose more sooner that they ben dampened than otherwise. For it is written de
pe. di. i. Omnis qui non diligit manet in morte.

D. Another example how the devil we ned to let saint Thybault to pacyfye ye
barons of the champayne that had dyuysyon together.
IT is written in the legende of saint thybault that great dyuysyon was one time
among the barons of ye champayne in such manner that they were ready to slay
each other. And the tidings came unto saint Thybault the which was far from
the country. And for as much as he ne might ride he made to prepayre him a
charyot / and made him to be borne with in it for to go to pacyfye them. And as
he was in a way the horses yode in to a water for to drink. And the devil
enuyous and wroth of the welfare of the country came in to the said water and
took away one of the wheles of the charyot and cast it in to a dyke right
deep. And in spyryte the said saint Thybault saw this thing yt the devil
did. Unto which devil saint Thybaulte said. I command the in ye name of
our lord Ihesu christ that thou serve to this charyot instead of ye said
whele And the said devil was obedyent and ye said charyot yode upon one whele.
And ye devil bare the other part ye ye which was a thing right meruayllous
unto all those that se it. And when the said saint came unto the place where
they were all appointed to sle other. When the princes and people saw
manyfestly that the charyot yode upon one whele as it is said they were
ameruayled / and came before the said saint and them pacyfyed and put in good
concord. And then returned from whe^s he was comen. And when he was in the
said water saint Thybault said unto the devil. Acursed go fetch ye whele and
put it on again and go thy ways. Thou wendest to have had great prouffyte for
to do me this thing / and it has be unto thy confusyon. And the said devil
it appointed upon the said charyot / and afterward returned him. etc. By
these examples before said in this fyfte commandment it appears that a man ne
should commyt homycyde iniustely. And that a man ne should do none ill unto his
neighbor by Ire / hate / vengeance ne cursydnes. etc.

Sextum preceptum.
Furtum.
A* Examples of people the which have committed theft. And first of a thief
named Achar the which was stoned and his substau e brent by the commandment
of god. nc lxxx.
IT is written in the.vii. chapitre of the book of Iosue that a man named Achar
stole again ye commandment of god. And of his capytayne Iosue a right good
mauntell / two hundred pieces of money / and a rod of gold the which was
worth fyftye pieces of gold in like wise as him self confessed. Vnde Iosue.vii.
Vidi eni^ inter spolia paleu^ cocceneu^ valde bonu^: and duce^tos cieclos
arge^ti. regula^que aurea^ qui^q^ginta sicloru^: and concupisce^s abstuli and
absco^di in tra. And by ye sin of the said theft ye people of Israhell lost
a Iourneye agay^ their adversaries / and fled before them. Than their
capytayne Iosue yode unto the temple / cut his vestimentes / and prostrate
couched him upon the earth before the arche where were the commandments till
unto the euentyde. And all the auncyentes of Israhell with him / the which put
of the poudre upon their hedes and humbled them before god / and him demanded
what was to be done. Quid facies magno nomini tuo. etc. And god said unto
iosue. Arise you up wherefore lie you on ye earth Some of the people of Israhell
has broke my commandment. I shall not help you till he that is culpable be
taken from you. Vnde iosue.vii. Anthema in medio tur e^ israel no^ poteris
stare cora^ hostibus tu is: donec deleatur ex te qi co^taminatus e^ scelere.
Than god commanded yt men should seche after him yt had done the sin. An^ yt
he were slain / and all his substance brent and it was done. For the said
Achar confessed ye said sin as it is said. And it was Iuged of Iosue by the
will of god in the manner the which follows. That is the said Iosue made to
hang the said achar thief and all his bestyall / his house / his beds with
all ye other household stuff / and made all to be borne in to a valeye wtoute
the cite. And all the people of Israhel came theder. And than the said Iosue
spoke and said. For as much as thou haste troubled us all / our lord
troubles ye this day. All the people of Israhell shall stone the. And all yt
the which is thine shall be burnt / and so was it done. And after that al ye
said people of Israhell assembled a great mountain of stones upon ye said
thief the which yet is there. And ye Ire of god was appeased for ye punycyon
of the said thief. Here is an example as unto ye text of the bible the which
is gretely to be noted unto all thieves. For by that yt god made to punysshe the
said thief and to take him from among the good / it is to be understand / yt
in like wise shall god make to be departed all thieves at the Judgment And shall
make them to be broyled and brent Vnde mathei. xiii. Exibunt angeli et
seperabu^t malos de medio iustorum and mittent eos in caminu^ ignis. Also here
is an example of people the which have co^muned goods that they ne should
nothing take unto their partyculyer as people of war the which have made
oath to put all in butyn / or boty fellows as were the children of Israhel. And
as ben many sorts of people with goods comunes. And such people the which
draws and pretends unto their partyculer ben thieves And by that that the
children of Israhel were gretely troubled and in like wise vexed And lost a
Iourneye by the said thief / it is to understand yt by an ill person all a
parysshe / or good company is troubled / and has to suffer. etc.

B. Another example of a thief the which was fastened / and abode with his
theft upon the grave of a deed body. lxxx.
IT is written in ye dyalogue of saint gregorye yt in the prouynce of Valerye
was there a worshypfull priest of holy conuersacyon with his clerks to give
preysynge unto / full of good operacyons and virtues. After his death was
buried before the church. And as the clerks were in orayson in a night there
came a thief ye which stole from them a sheep. And the said thief came to
pass with his proy above the grave of the said priest buried And abode there
all still without power to go / ne power to leave ye said sheep. And in the
morning was found with his proye as the deed body held him. And as he ne might
leave his theft the said clerks yode to prayer. And yt pain obtained they
that the said thief might go without berynge any thing away. etc. For to
moralyze upon this example a man should understand by the thief the which was
arested with his theft without power to remeue ne to go / that these thieves
ye which ben dampened bear upon them ye theftes that they have stolen and shall
bear eternally without power to take them away. and shall be holden in ye fire
of hell. It is written ezechielis.xliiii. quod pcto^res portabu^t co^fusione^
sua^ and scelera sua q^ feceru^t / yt is to say yt the sinners shall bear
their sins in confusyon. And the dampened shall se al their fautes upon them.
As men know a company of people yt such is clothed with gray and such with
white / and such and such have white hodes / or black. Vnde eze xviii.
Impietas impii erit super eu^. Et legittur eccle. xi. In fine hoi^s denudatio
operum illius. etc.

C. Another example how the deuylles slew a thief and bare away his soul for
ye that he had witholden the horse of a deed body the which should have be
given unto poor people. lxxx
IT is written in ye legende of ye deed bodies yt Turpyn Archebysshop of Rayns
said that a knight named charles yode in battle for fo fight in arms. the
which prayed one his cousin yt if he deyed in the said battle yt he should
sell his horse and that he should give the money thereof unto poor people. And
when ye said knight was deed / the other withelde for himself the said horse.
And within little time after the said knight deed appeared unto the other knight
shynynge as the son / and said unto him. Good cosyn thou haste made me to
suffer pains by eight days in purgatory for my horse / the price whereof was
not given unto the poor in like wise as I had dysposed / but thou ne art
quyte / for at this day the deuylles shall bear away thy soul in to hell. And
I goo purged in to heaven. And than a cry was herd suddenly in the air of
deuylles the which bare hpm away from thens. etc. This example denotes that
those ye which witholde the goods of deed bodies / ben thieves and dampne
themself as did he ye which withelde the said horse. etc.

D. Another example how a child the which had stolen an halfpeny from his
cosyn was punysshed in the pyt of hell and afterward brought again in to
his body. lxxx
THe dysciple recites in his sermons this example how a child was pre^ent in
Judgment before god after yt he was deed. And the devil accused him and said.
Dn^e iudica secu^du^ iustitia^. etc. Thou lord judge after justice / this
child has stolen from his cosyn germayn an halfpeny the which he has not
yielded / and is deed without doing penance. Would thou well yt I condampne
this child for so little a thing / my justice is not with out mercy. Than some
saints ye which were than present yt the said child had served prayed the
Judge for him. And the Judge said yt he should have pain for his offense. And
after shall be brought again in to his body. Than by the commandment of the
said Judge he was cast in to a pytte of fire wherein he sustained so much of
pain and dolor yt afterward he ne might express it by word. And at ye
prayer of ye said saints he was drawn out of the said pyt of fire / and the
soul was restored within the body and lived afterward And the said Judge gave
him in charge to yield again the said half penny / and the people meruaylled
them of ye yt he had recounted. And they put to faith unto yt that he had said.
For asmoche as he lived afterward much holyly in the dread of god with out
taking apple ne pere ne any thing of other men's. By this example a man
should understand yt this child was accused before god of ye devil of so
little a thing as is an halfpeny / by a more great reason shall be accused
those the which stele a great thing. And if he had so great punycyon for so
little offense / so shall they have that do the great offenses. And by that that
god him commanded restytucyon so should those do ye which has taken fro
other / or else they may not be saved. For it is written in droit. No^ dimittur
pctm^ nisi restituatur ablatu^. xiiii. q. vi. c. Sires. and saint Thomas says
secu^da secu^de. q. lxii articulo.viii. Who so ever lets iniustely another
neighbor in the usage of ye thing the which unto him apperteyneth he
trespasseth the commandment of charity

A. Another example how churl was punysshed of the devil for that yt he had
stolen a little of a hedge in the field from his neighbor. lxxxi.
IT is written in the dyalogue cesaru^ that a carle was in the death bed and
the devil came unto him ye which held a little of a hedge al in fire / the
which enforced hy^ to put it in his mouth. Than the said carle forgote not
his sin. And understood yt the devil did unto him soche pain for a little
of a hedge yt he had taken and stolen in the field from his neighbor / and
had put it in his field unto himself. And for that yt the devil was evermore
before his face in what place so ever he turned him was constrained to restore
the said little hedge / called his friends sent them to promytte to restore
ye said little and to require pardon / unto whom ye master of the said little
said. I shall not pardon him yet / let him be well tormented. And again the
said devil held the said little hedge embrased / and him tormented as before.
And again sent messengers but they ne might have pardon. thyrdly in weeping
sent them. I unhappy I ne may dye ne live / return ye to demand pardon.
Than the other him pardoned and the devil departed inco^tynent. By this example
a man should understand that all manner of thieves yt steleth or wastes ye
goods of their neighbors iniustely shall be punysshed in this world or in the
other Sith that the devil tormented so this man for so little a thing as is
a little of hedge. By a more stronger reason he shall torment those the which
do ye great theftes. This little of a hedge was not worth no great thing. But
it was a great thing as to take it wyttyngly from his neighbor theuysshely
against the commandment of god wherefore he was digne of punycyon. etc.

B. Another example of a servant the which took and stole from his master
fyggues. lxxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and sermons and says that ye body
of saint Thomas is reverently kept / where god unto him has given such
grace that he is yet entere and hole. And when the time comes to admynystre
unto the people one sytteth in a chayer reverently. When the hostyes are
consecrate ye priest puts them in saint Thomas hand / ye which
admynystreth ye people. And if any of those yt receives their creator be in
any sin ye said saint thomas with draws his hand / and shall not be
admynystred till he be in the state of grace. The scripture speaks of a
servant yt stole fygges from his master and eat them without ye knowledge of
his master / and confessed him not of it. So he came to be admynystred as the
other did. And the said saint thomas withdrewe his hand and would not suffer
him to receive it. Then the servant be thought him of the said theft and was
confessed / and after that was admynystred of ye said saint Thomas and was no
more repulsed. And by this all theft is to fle be it great or little. For for
that man is put out of the company of god.

C. Another example of a baylye judge and thief the which took gifts iniustely
and corructe Justice. lxxxi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt a baylye made a
wedding unto his sone / and a man yt which had a great cause before him gave
unto him an ox / and prayed him that he would do for him in his cause. And
when his aduersarye herd it spoken / he sent a fair cow unto the wife of ye
said baylye and prayed her to speak for him. The which did so much against
the said baylye that he promised that he would do for him yt had sent the
cow. And when they were in judgment and that the said baylye ne spoke for him
the which had given the ox / he said / ox speak. Than ye baylye answered.
The ox may not speak / for the cow will not suffer it. etc. The cause of such
iuges the which corrupts justice by gifts promesses and favors shall be
dyscussed and iuged before god the which is souerain Judge / ye which is not
acceptour of persons / in like wise as says the holy scripture. No^ eni^ e^
acceptio personaru^ apud deum. And in the said judgment of god every man shall
be punysshed after that / that he has deserved as the false Iuges and those
the which wy^ne their causes falsely And those ye which possede herytages ill
begoten / and witholde them without restitucyon. Tu reddes cuique iuxta opera
sua / vt dicit psalm. Also god ne shall spare in Judgment the great lords / ne
prayer ne gold ne silver / ne contrycyon ne wrath ne shall do nothing in
like wise as says the scripture. Vn^. prouer. vi zelus and furor viri no^
parcet dn^s i^ die vi^dicte: nec acquiescet cuiusquam precibus: nec suscipieth
prorede^ptio ne dona plurima. etc.

D. Another example how the king of perse made to fle an ill Judge corrupt by
gifts. etc. lxxxi
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye yt the king of perse repreued a judge
for gyuyng falls judgment and for his iniustyce made him to be flayne and to put
his skin upon a stole. And made to sytte upon the said stole his sone and the
iuges the which came after him to the end that they should remember them of the
said ill Judge. And that they should dread to Judge unjustly. etc.

E. Another example how the devil bare away in body and in soul a thief
covetous advocate.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermon that there was an advocate chief of diverse
towns / auarycyous without mercy yt made of grievous exacions in his subgectes
/ and came one day as he yode in a town for an exaccyon ye devil assocyated
with him in the way in lykenes of a man. And of horroure and of the words yt
they spoke togider he understood yt it was the devil and dredde to go with him
/ but in no manner he ne might depart / neither in praynge / ne in making the
sygn^ of ye cross. And as they yode togider they met a poor man the which
led a hog in a band. And as the hog turned from one side to another /
yt poor man was wroth / and cried the devil take the. When the advocate herd
this word he had hope to depart from him by such occasyon. and said unto the
devil. Friend here yt hog is given unto the / go and take him. The devil
answerde / he is not given me with heart and therefore I ne may take him. And
after they passed by another town / and as a child wept his mother was at the
door wroth / and said the devil take the / wherefore tormentest you me thus with
thy wepynges. Than the advocate said here haste you won a soul / take ye
child / for it is thin Unto whom the devil answerde as before. She has not
given it me with good heart. And when they began to approach unto the place
whether they yode. Then the men of ye town se them far of they knew not the
cause / wherefore they yede all together with one voice cryenge the devil take
the. And said unto the devil you art welcome. When the devil had herd this /
he shoke the heed / and in mockyng said unto the advocate. Those here has
given the unto me with all their hertes. and therefore art thou mine. And the
devil rauysshed him in that hour / and what became of him no man can tell. The
langages yt which were spoken / and the things ye which were done in the
way the servant of the advocate declares yt was with him. / By this example
it appears that cursed Iuges and advocates deye cursedly / and that the gifts
and salayres that they have taken unjustly / has deceived and bly^ded their
souls. Also the scripture speaks it in many places. First gifts blind the
eyes of the wise people yt which have justice to govern For they ne se drope
in the good and just cause of those the which ne give nothing. And look right
clear in the cause of those ye which has made them any gift. Also the
gifts peruerteth the words of the justices as says moses / deuterono.xvi.
Ne acciptas munera: nec persona^ quia munera execant oculos sapientu^: et
muta^t verba iustoru^. And he says in ye book of exode. Exodi. xxiii.
Aduersus impiu^ ne accipias munera q^ execa^t etia^ prude^tes: et subuerte^t
verba iustorum Also the gifts put outethe eyes of ye Iuges / and them make
dombe / and take away correccyon as says the wise. Eccle. xx. Dona
execa^toculos iudicu^: and quasi iu^ctus in ore aduertit correctione^ eoru^. Et
gregorius dicit. Non potest consta^ter argui a quo accipitur. Also the gifts
make malediccyon to come unto those ye which for gifts iustefye the ill / and
make their ill causes good / and take away justice from the just and their
good causes make ill. Vn^. ysay v. Ve qi iustificatis impiu^ pro muneribus et
iusticia^ iusti aufertis ab eo. Iteru^ in eodem capitulo. Ve qui dicitis bonu^
malum et masu^ bonum: ponentes amaru^ in dulce and dulce i^ amaru^. Et
deutero.xxvii. Maledictus qui peruertit iuditiu^ aduene: and pupil li et vidue:
et dicet omnis populus amen. He is acursed the which peruerteth ye judgment of
the man strange / and of the orphelyn / and of the wedowe. And all ye people
shall say amen / that is so be it. Iteru^ deuterono.xvii. Maledictus qui
accipit munera vt pereutiat ai^am sanguinis innocentis: and dicitomnis populus
amen. He is acursed the which takes gifts to the end that he stryke the soul
of the blood i^nocent. Et prouerbiorum.xvii. Qui iustificat impium: et qui
condemnat iustum abhominabilis vt vterque apud dominum. He the which
iustefyeth the wicked sinner / and condampneth the Just / the one and the
other is abominable anenst god. and those the which composeth and makes ill
laws to the end that they eschasen the poores in Judgment. And that they make
force unto the cause of the humbles be cursed. Vn^. ysaie.x. Ve qui co^dunt
leges iniquas vt opprime^t in iuditio pauperes et vim facerent cause humiliu^
populi mei vt essent vidue preda eorum* et populos dirumperent. Also the
person the which takes gifts byndeth himself anenst ye gyuer / or else
vnkyndes follows. Munera alliga^t. Also some cursed officers take of two sides
/ as those ye which fissheth with two nets and flatereth with both parties
/ and say unto every of them he has good right / they do treason /
decepcyon / theft / susurracyon / and in scripture ben called bylyngues. For
their tongue speaks two langages. And ben cursed. iegitur ecclesiastici decimo
octauo. Sufurro et bilinguis maledictus: multos enim turbauit pacem habentes.
Sequitur lingua tercia multos commouit: et dispersit illos a gente in gentem.

F. Another example of a tailor named martyn the which stole the clothe in
cuttynge the robbes. lxxxi.
THere was a tayller named Martyn the which had of custom that when he
cut of clothe for to make of robes / or gowns / or cotes. etc. that he stole
evermore some what of the foresaid clothe as colored clothes or fine whytes.
And him thought that he dremed in one night for that ye he stole of clothe
that the devil bare hy^ away in to hell / he showed unto his wife his dreme.
And his wife ye which would withdraw him from evil counsaylled that he should
never take none. Afterward it happened that this taylour cut a fair blewe in
his shop which was nere unto his wives chamber / and by a hole through the
wall the wife beheld him evermore cuttynge. And in seeing her husband the
which had of custom yt when he would stele he whysteled in loky^ge where it
might be yt he might any thing stele. Than ye wife cried martyn martyn
remember the of the devil. And martyn seeing this stole nothing. Afterward
came a fair scarlet to be cut. And yt wife as is beforsayd cried / martyn
martyn remember the of the devil. And he seeing so fair clothe rubbed his
sholdres and evermore that woman said martyn martyn. etc. And he said / if the
devil should bear me a way yet should I have it. etc.

G. Another example how four men of one lygnage were dampened and hanged in
hell / for yt that they posseded falsely an heritage. lxxxi
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says that a rich man saw by vysyon
four men dampened and tormented in hell the which were under a dry tree and
saw that one of them hang the first / the other the second / and the fourth
the third / the other abode under ye said tree. The angel the which showed
this visyon said unto the rich man that the three hanged were of his lynage /
that is thy grau^d faders fader / and his fader. And he the which abides
under the tree / that is thy fader ye which taryeth till thou be deed for to
hang the for such heritage the which was ill gotten / the which they have
posseded falsely the one after the other without being in will to leave it. And
thou shalt be hanged as they ben if thou leave it not / For they ne have therein
nothing / no more haste thou thyselfe. Than the said rich man left the said
heretage and did penance. This example denotes yt a man ne should possede
gods and herytages wha^ a man has true knowledge that they ben comen of ill
getynge and purchase. For the false geters purchasers and herytours ye which
possede the said things without being in will to leave them. In the which
they ne have nothing dampne their souls to reteyne and take unjustly the
thing the which is not theyrs. And therefore for to save their souls they
should make restitucyon. etc.

Sacrilegium.
A. Examples of sacrylege / and first example how an earl and many of his
lygnage were damned for that yt they posseded unjustly an heritage the which
had be take away from the church. lxxxii.
THe dysciple recites in his sermons that an earl after the opinion of men was
of good life. After his death a relygyous saw him in the flambes of fire of
hell upon a laddre on the last staff the which was lift upward / and
procedyng from the lower part of hell. And much people were upon the laddre
that grynde the tethe of rage of torments. And ye said relygyous demanded
wherefore the said earl was in such torments on ye said laddre consyderyng
that he had lived so well. And it was told him that it was for an heritage yt
his great grandfader had taken from ye church / and that he was now the
tenthe ye which had posseded it. And therefore all those the which shall
possede the said heritage shall be put on the said laddre with the earl This
example should draw back all persons to get and to possede unjustly the
heritages the which be not well gotten. And pryncypally to take from the
church that the which is given unto it. For god is their judge and sufferer with
whom they have to do. And it behooves to pass under his hand / and his
rod. Vn^ scryptura. No^ est qui de manu mea possit eruere. And therefore it is
great folly to take from his judge yt the which apperteyneth unto him. By this
that this said earl dredde not this thing / and ne made of it conscience ne
restytucyon he put himself in dampnacyon and perdycyon what good deed so ever
he had done of the other part And therefore take heed unto him who so loves
himself. etc.

B. Another example how Helyodorus was punysshed dyuynely in taking the
treasours from ye church of Iherusalem.
IT is written in the book of machabee how heliodorus was sent from the king
solencus to take and to bear away the treasours of ye church of Iherusalem In
the which treasours there were four hundred talentes of silver / and two
hundred talentes of gold as it appears in ye said chapter. And as ye said
Heliodorus was in the church with his complyces / god showed unto him yt he
dyspleased him. For all those yt there was entered hardely were cast by the
puyssaunce of god in dyssolucyon and dread. Unto whom it appeared a terryble
horse upon the which was by symylitude a man on horsbacke aourned with right good
enournements. And with great impetuosite came the horse to stryke the said
helyodorus with his fete. He the which was on horsbacke seemed that he was armed
with armours of gold. And there arrived by symylytude two yongmen / and believe
that they were aungelles replenysshed with great virtue and with great beauty
/ and clothed right specially the which set about the said helyodorus / and
hymbet and whypped without cessynge / till yt he was replenysshed with wounds.
Than ye said Helyodorus fell unto the earth as deed in great confusyon. The
which young men took him in to his lodging where he had lain. He ye which
was come on horsbacke with puyssaunce of satyllytes was borne again without
horses / ne without aid humayne by the virtue of god the which appeared
manyfestly. And so lay the said helyodorus by the dyuyne puyssaunce and
pryuate from all hope of health. And the people of Iherusalem blessed / and
thanked god the which had kept his temple to be pylled and was replenysshed
with Joy the which little before was replenysshed with dread. Than the friends
of the said Heliodorus came unto the sovereign priest of Iherusalem named
onias. And him required that he would pray unto god for the said Helyodorus.
Unto whom he obeyed and prayed god for him. And as the said priest onias
prayed god the foresaid young men clothed as they were before came before
helyodorus unto whom they said / yield thanks unto the priest onias / For for
the love of him god has given the thy life. And thou the which have ben
beten by god denounce and show unto all ye puyssaunce and the great things of
him. Than the said Helyodorus was heled yielded thanks unto god and unto the
said onias / returned unto the said king to tell these things beforsaid. And
them manifested over all where he might. By this example a man should note that
no person ne should take ne pylle the goods of the church. For god will yt
they be employed unto that where unto they ben ordained. And if the said
Helyodorus were punysshed in this world of the punycyon dyuyne / by more great
reason shall those be punysshed in ye other world / the which take and pyl
the chirches. The great thing that they will take ne make not the questyon.
For those the which take little things ben thieves and sacryleges and sin
mortally / as those ye which take great things / but every man in his egall
porcyon shall be punysshed after his deserte. Vn^ psalm. Tu reddes vnicuique
iuxta opera sua. etc.

C. Another example of he punycyon of a man the which denied the silver of the
church the which had be lent unto him. lxxxii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says yt the deane of the church of
Couioygne lent unto his brother carnal five mark of gold of his church. And
after the death of the said deane ye chanons demanded ye said money. And for
that yt they had no wytnes the said brother denied it and forswore him. And
afterward as he returned in to his house he abode immovable and was dombe.
Wherefore he auowed in his heart that he should return where he was pariured /
and that he should show his malice / and yield the said money unto the
church. And by contrycion and penance was delivered. All thieves sacryleges /
and pariured persons should c^rrecte them and make restytuco^n if they
consider well this example. For if the said man were punysshed and his case
manyfested / so shall it be to thieves if they repent them not / and that they
ne done also good and true penance.

D. Another example of thieves sacrileges the which were punysshed for that yt
they had stole the cross. And the goods of the church. lxxxii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuary and says ye thieves broke a church
founded of saint martyn. The which took and stole of treasours and the cross
of the church the which was aourned with gold / with precious stones / and
with a porcyon of the very cross of our lord Ihesu And for that yt the said
thieves were many some had the treasours. And two had the said cross and
fled. When the bishop herd the tydinges sent people after them and on al
parts for to seche them. And those the which had the cross ne might goo but
by the great hye way. And god alyened their wits / and made them bide still
in a great way full of mire / and they walked and trod in the said mire without
power to proceed any ferther. And those the which followed them over passed
them first without thinking yt it were they. But wha^ they found them in the
morning there they had suspeccyon / and said in this wise / Good men ye go not
well wherefore go ye not by the hye way. They answered we go well / what have
ye to do with our goy^ge Than the one of them said. I wene that they ben culpable
/ take we them. and they were asked of the theft / they confessed it by
condycyon that they should not deye / and they poynted unto the said cross the
which was in the mire hid / were led unto the bishop / and were let go
for the said promise. But god the which punyssheth the sinners anon after
those thieves broke another church / and were taken and hanged Hec cesarius
dicit.

E. Another example of a relygyous of saint gregorye the which was buried in a
donghyll for that yt he withelde three pieces of gold of the co^munyte. lxxxii
IT is written in the fourth book of ye dyalogue. s. gre. how a monk of ye
relygyous of saint gregorye medecyn hid three pieces of gold / and kept them as
unto his partyculeir without betakynge them unto the communyte. And when it
came unto his death he showed where the said gold was hid / he wept this
thing and so deyed. And when he was deed the said saint gregorye for to show
that he had gretely offended / and for ye example of other made to burye him
and the gold in a donghyll / saying. Thy money be with the in perdycyon.
Albeit after.xxx. days saint gregorye commanded one to sing mass for
him.xxx. days. And he did it. And at the last day the said deed body
appeared unto one of his brederne / the which him demanded of his case. He
answered. I have been ill entreated till unto this day but now am I well. For I
have at this day received communyon. etc. This here is a great example for all
relygyous yt they ne should be propryetayres ne go again the vow of pouerte /
or ill shall come to them And if the said relygyous had not had repentance /
and if he had not manyfested his sin he had be dampened / he was punysshed in
purgatory by penance and by the masses yt were song for him he was delivered.
etc.

F. Another example how a merchant was poor whiles that his brother ye which
was abbot took unto him the goods of the church. lxxxii
SOme masters has written this yt the dyscyple recites in his promtuarye and
says that a monk was abbot of an abbay founded of saint panthaleon The
which abbot had a brother merchant unto whom he gave many times of the
money of his monastery for to increase him in marchaundyse. But ye said
merchant lost all and yode unto naught / how be it that before that he had
received the said money he was a good merchant And also he was right dylygent
in his case. And after that many years he had marchaunded in such wise of the
said gods and that he lost all the said abbot said unto his brother. Wherefore
wastest you so thy substance unto thy confusyon and mine. Unto the which abbot
he said. I live much straytely / and keep my marchaundyse dylygently / but I
can not tell what it ayleth / for my felawes prouffyte and I defayle. Than the
said marchaunte aduysed him and yode to confess him unto a good and wise
priest / yt which told him yt the money yt he had taken was theft by which
al yode to naught. And charged him not to take more ye good of the church /
but that he marchaunded with so little as he had / And that the half of the
gain he should give unto the monasterye for to ful^yl till he had restored. And
that he should live of the other half. And the merchant was obedyent and
accomplysshed the said counsayll. And in short time he became so rich that he
restored all unto ye said abbot And more over he became much rich / and for
as much as the said abbot had meruaylle of the said restytucyon and of ye said
richesse of his brother him demanded from whens came the said rychesses. He
answered when I took ye substance of thy bredern of relygyon yt thou gave me
I ne might nothing get / but was poor / and thou sinned grievously in like
wise as I have found by these clerks. And after yt I have had horror of the
said theft. I have had haboundaunce of goods. etc. by this example all
relygyous should understand yt they offend to give unto their friends of the
goods of the church. The gyuers ben fraulded of their entencyon / for they ne
have given ye said goods for to be employed in such wise / yt is the
substance of the servants of god. And if there be resydue it should be given
again to the poores of Ihesu criste in like wise as says the scripture. Bona
ecclesiaru^ su^t bona pauperu^. etc.

G. Another example how these relygyous ne should give the goods of the
church unto their friends. lxxxii.
IT is written in the life of faders / yt a monk had a poor brother seculer
unto whom he ceased not to give him / so yt he labored not. And the more he
gave him the poorer he was. Than the said monk took counsayll of a good fader
the which cou^saylled him yt he ne should give him no more / and that he
should say unto him. My brother when I had I gave ye go you now to labor / and
of yt that thou shall have give unto me / and all that yt he shall b^^ge unto ye
take it and give it unto pylgry^s / and good auncyentes and them require that
they pray for him. The said monk did this counsayll / and the said seculer
yode heuely to labor. And the first day that ye said seculer came unto the
monk he brought him halpens / the which gave them as it is said. Afterward
he brought unto him of herbs and three loves / the which dystrybute them.
Thyrdly he brought unto him of vytaylles / and of wine and fysshe. / When the
said monk saw it he meruayled / called the pores and fed them. And
demanded of his brother if he had any more need and that he would aid him. He
answered yt nay / and said unto him. All that thou gave me consumed away /
and now I take nothing of the Ihabounde in all goods that god sends me.
Also these seculers shall not be rich for to draw unto them the goods of the
church.

H. Another example of an holy man ye which gave the whyppe unto those that
had taken away his horse. lxxxii
Saint gregorye shows in his dyalogue yt as an holy man named lybertyn was
upon his horse he met an host of men of war yt keste him to the earth / and
took his horse to lead him away / and he said unto them / take this whyppe for
to make him go the better / they departed and lepte upon ye horse / gave him the
sporres impetuously for to make him to goo / but for to be short / they ne
might ferther go / So they byleued that this thing came unto them for the
rauyne that they had done unto gods man / and yielded him his horse again. And
afterward yode their way lightly. etc. This example denotes that the good
lybertyn was right lyberall and pacyent to take unto them the whyppe after that
they had cast him down unto the earth and taken away his horse. And god
showed manyfestly unto the pyllers that they had sy^ned and offended. And that
they ne should trouble ne pyl the people of the church where god them shall
punysshe eternally if they deye without correccyon and amendment. etc.

I. Another example how that thieves sacryleges revoked themself unto penance /
and made restytucyon by the pacyence of an ancient. lxxxii.
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple yt there came thieves to the
monastery of an au^cyent unto whom they said. We are come to bear away all yt
is in thy house. And he said / children bear away what ye will. Than they took
all that they found / and yode their way. And the said ancient found a sack
the which apperteyned unto them / the which they had stolen / he ran after
them and said unto them. Children bear away this yt ye have forgoten in my
house. Than the said thieves were ameruayled of his pacyence revoked them unto
penance / and restored to him all his goods.

Decime.
A. Examples to pay his dysmes. and first example of a lord the which
retained the tenthe of his goods that he gave unto his servant. lxxxiii.
MEn find by writing that a great lord was required of his servant to give
him of his gods. The which lord gave unto him by condycyon to reteyn / yt is
to know / he gave him.x. kye x. sheep.x. geete. etc. and all by tenthes / Unto
whom he said. I give ye these goods here by such condycyon yt I reteyne
the.x. pyece every year. And also I will yt thou them nourysshe in my pasture.
Than he thanked the said lord and took them ioyously / and promised in such
wise to do it. And did it by two or three years / but when he was rich he gave
it with ill will and of ye worst Than the said lord made him come before him and
demanded why he had not given unto him the tenthe of his goods ye which he
had given him / and it was by the admonycyon of his wife. He answered yt it was
by his proprecouetyse and not by his said wife. Than he required pardon and
promised satysfaccyon / and he it pardoned him. etc. By this lord is
understand god the which reteyneth the.x. party of the goods yt he makes
to come / and to grow unto the as you haste herd by ye scryptures. And by that
yt he has paid with ill will denotes unkindness or couetyse. And by this yt he
repented him and promised satysfaccyon is to note yt those the which have ill
paid their dysmes should repent them and reknowlege their fault: and they should
make satysfaccyon / and they shall have pardon of god. Vnde ezechielis.xviii.
Si au^t impius egerit penitencia^ ab oi^bus peccatis q^ operatus e^. etc. vita
viuet et no^ morietur.

B. Another example of a knight ye which dysmed well and his vine bare fruit
two times in the year. lxxxiii
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how ye dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says yt there was a knight replenysshed with so much of
virtues and of Justice yt in payenge his dysmes he had all good condycyons
pleasau^tes unto god / for he them paid without taryenge / without malice / and
of the best / He had a vine that bare again from year to year about ten pypes
of wine. And it befell one year more of the dyspensacion of god than of the
attempraunce of ye air after that the wine was gadred there ne was but one
only pype of wine. And as the said knight had herd yt he said unto his
servant. That the which was mine and that I should live wtall of the vine god
has taken fro me. And I will not take away his porcyon. Goo and give unto
the priest this pype of wine for his dysme. and it was done. And in that time
as the cosyn germayne of the said knight and a priest past by the said vine ye
which was all full of grapes / yode unto the knight / and repreued him of his
neclygence. Wherefore have not you gadered wine. He answered and said / it is
lately gadered. And ye said priest said that it was replenysshed with fruytes.
Than yode men to se it / and they found more grapes and better than ever they
had done before. And therefore it is a good thing to pay well his dismes. The
said knight was lawful and just to pay well that that he should in obeynge
unto god. Also he ne was unkind / for he reknoleged the good ye god to him
had done. And he was much lyberall to give unto god ye said pype of wine.
And god ye which is the rewarder of ye good deeds that men do unto him he him
restores / and shows that he has done thing digne of praise and of
retrybucyon.

C. Another example of a simple man the which dysmed well / and did miracle.
IT is written in the collocucyons of the faders in like wise as recyteth the
dyscyple and says that after that a holy abbot named johan had done many
miracles there was brought unto him a man the which had the devil in the body
And the said Johan was strongly required of many that he should chase ye devil
from the said man. And for to be short yt said Johan commanded unto the
devil from god that he should go out. The which devil answered that he
would not / and that he ne should go out for him. And upon his words there
arrived a good simple man ill clothed the which bare his tithe unto the
priest the which herd how the devil answered that he ne should go out for
the said abbot / yt which simple man said to the devil. And wherefore ne go
thou out (so thou shall) I command the from god that thou go out. Than the
devil yode out the which said that he ne was gone forth for the said Johan
/ but yt he was constrained by god to go forth for the bounte of the said
simple man. and than the good abbot was a meruaylled ye which demanded of the
simple man of what life he was. And how be it yt he drew back to tell it / he
answered yt he paid well his tithes incontinent that they were deu. And them
put unto prouffyte and paid them Ioyously of the best / and bare them unto
the person or unto ye vycayr I go unto the church said he every day And if I
may there I here every day mass. I keep well the feestes and the
commandments of god / at the begy^nyng of my young aege I had will to be
relygyous and for that that my fader had no more children but me / they ne
would that I were relygyous to the end that to possede their heritage I obeyed
unto them and they married me unto a good woman / we keep well our marriage
together. And if she deyed I have yet the will to be relygyous / it is not yet
changed. There is the life that I am of. Than the said Johan fell on knees
before him and required him yt he would pray for him. etc. In this example is
to be noted yt a good simple man labourer is sometime more nerer unto god and
more holy person digne to do miracles than ne ben ye great bysshoppes doctors
and prelates. When the day of Judgment shall come god ne shall demand have
you be doctor or master in such science or in such / but he shall demand
have thou done ye works of mercy / have thou paid thy dysmes / have thou
obeyed unto ye church. etc.

D. Another example of those the which take of dysmes. lxxxiii
MEn find by writing how saint renobert the which was ye second bishop of
bayeux saw one time that a man took a iauel of corn out of a shefe of dysme
for to give it unto his horse / and saint renobert badde him leave it / but he
would not / wherefore his horse enraged. etc

Tenatitas.
A. Other examples of people to much holding and unmercifully. And first
example of the cursed rich man. lxxxiiii.
IT is written in the.xi. chapter of the gospelles of saint luc yt there was a
rich man clothed with purple and with precious vestymentes / yt which ete and
drank every day delycyously. And there was a lazar full of wounds ye which
let him before the yate of ye said rich / which demanded the cro^mes yt fell
from his table but he gave hy^ none but set dogs on hy^ and they lycked his
fete. So he deyed and ye rich man also / the poor man went to heaven and the
rich man to hell. The ill rich lift up his eyes as he was in torment and
saw Abraham a far of and the lepre in his bosom. He made two requests of
ye which he was denied. The first was of one drop of water. The second to
goo tell unto his brederne yt they might correct them. etc. This rich man is
an example unto all cursed rich men the which use ill of their rychesses /
and this poor is example of all good poores yt have pacyence in aduersite. The
rich was dampened for many things pryncypally for four. The first is because
he was without mercy / for he let ye poor deye for hongre at his gate Cupie^s
saturari de micis q^ cadebant de me^sa diuitis. And therefore god sent him in to
ye fire of hell without pite / and shall say to him at ye day of Judgment. I
have had hongre and thurst and thou have not given me mete nor drink. Et ideo.
Ite maledicu i^ igne^ eternu^. math.xv. The second for because he appetyted
the honors of ye world. And he was proud in heart. And therefore the gospel
says sygnantly yt he was clothed in purple and with precious vestymentes the
which denotes vaynglorye. Induebatur pupura et bysso. The third that he was
much lykorous and yt he nourysshed his belly with metes made dylycatyuely the
which draws unto lechery / and makes the man unmercifully. And therefore
says the gospel. Expulebatur cotidie splendide. He lived after the will of
the body the which ledeth unto dampnacyo^. Vn^ ad roma. viii. Si scdm carnem
vixeritis monemini. He ne lived in this world bu^.xl. years to live
delyciously / and he is in ye fire of hell fro the time of Moses two. M. years
past in so great pouerte yt he ne might have one drop of water / so was it
unto him a right cursed market from ye kechyn The fourth is that he declyned
not from evil words the which comynly he spoke in dynynge. And therefore
sygnauntly he playned that he was tourmented in the tongue when he demanded a
drop of water. What prouffyted unto that man ye rychesses / honors / and
meets when he is dampened. The rychesses delyuereth him not from death. The
metes keeps not his body from worms / and the honors from stynke. Vnde
bernardus. O diuites quid prosant vobis diuitie / quid epule / quid honores
diuitie non liberabunt vos a morte / epule a verme / honores a fetore. Et poeta
dicit. Quid tu^c the sauri / qid aceruus proderit auri Quando pcto^res /
mittuntur in inferiores Malet preterite / quod in omni tempore vite. Pauper
vixisset / quam diuitias habuisset. Et math.xvi. Quid prodest homini si mundu^
vniuersum lucretur / anime vero sue detrimentum patiatur. This saved beggar is
ye example of all good poor folk. He is blyssed in as much as he had
pacye^ce in pouerte. Vn^ luce. vi Beati pauperes quia vestru^ est regnum dei.
Also he is blyssed in as much as he had patience in honger and thurst when he
coueyted to have of the crommes Vnde luce. vi. Beati qui esuritis qr satura
bimini. Et apoca.vii. Non esurie^t neque s^tient amplius. Also he had not the
honors of the rich / but was so abject and dishonored that men set at him
the dogs the which did unto him no harm but lycked his sores. Legitur
math.v. Bti^eritis cum maledixerint vobis homines. etc. Also he had no health
as the rich had but was seek / full of sores / and in sekenes he had pacyence
/ and by that was he blyssed. Vn^ ma. v. Beati pacifici qm^ filii dei
vocabuntur. Also he endured pacyently hete and cold and was evil lodged and
lay before the gate of the rich. And he shall never have hete ne cold. Vn^
apoc. vii. Non cadet super illos sol / neque vllus estus. etc. And the rich
lift up his eyes as he was in tourmentes / and saw and knew the bosom of
Abraham and the lazer. The master of the sentences expounds this in
expressing that the dampened sees some manner the saved in glory / and shall se
till the day of Judgment / to ye end that they be the more tourmented to have
lost the Joys of paradyse. And after the Judgment they shall se nothing. And
in this that Abraham and the lepre saw and knew the rich in tourments is to
understand yt the saved sees the dampened in hell and shall se them them
pardurably / that is also after the Judgment of god to the end yt they have the
more greter Joy that they have avoided the said tourmentes. And the rich the
which demanded one drop of water was denied it. And Abraham said unto him.
Inter nos and vos chaos magnu^ firmatu^ est. To bear unto the a drop of water
it may not be done / for between you and us there is great confusyon and
dyscorde. Ye the which ben ever in tourmentes may not come unto us. Vnde psalm.
Spu^s vadens et non radiens. And we may not go unto you / for we ben confermed
in ye Justice that god has made that we may never have pity ne compassyon of
one dampened. Vn^ david i^ psalm. Letabitur iustus cum viderit vindicta^. If the
saved were sorry of th dampnacyon of their friends they should not have parfyte
Joy / and should go against the will of god. And after the rich required that
the lepre might goo in to the house of his fader to tell to his five bredren
that he was in tourments / and that they should do penance of dread yt they
yode not with him in pains. Abraham denied it and said unto him that they had
Moses and other prophets / and that they might here them if they would. And
the rich said. A fader Abraham if one of the deed arose they should believe
more sooner. And Abraham said. If they will not here the quycke they shall not
here the deed.

B. Another example of dur Durant the which lived without having pity nor mercy
of the poor people. lxxxiiiii
IT is written in speculo hystoriali of a man the which was called durant yt
was not surnamed. For he was hard to do well / in especyall to give unto the
poor / and also too excercyse the works of mercy. And his wife was unto the
contrary / for she was much pytefull / a gyuer of alms / and merciful. When
the poor folk demanded alms of the said Durant / right vylanously he
chased them away. And it befell on a time that our lord came unto him to
demand alms in the symylytude of a poor man. And the said Durant took a
mace wenynge for to have smyten him. Tha^ he wist not where he became / quia
euanuit / but he abode not unpunished. For incontinent great multitude of
deuylles in the form of black moryens came unto him and bare him away in
body and in soul hosed and cladde / and made him to pass the row a little
partycyon of the wall with great tourment. And his wife seeing yt was full of
dread / and in trembling as a lefe ran to tell it unto her neighbors. And
ye servants and children seeing their mother and may stresse run in such
wise they ran after her. And incontinent as they were departed / fire /
lyghtnynge / tempest / and punycion descended in the house the which was great
as a palace / and confounded in to depnes his goods and the said house except
yt the portayle before the gate the which abode in wytnes of that thing. And
ye deuylles came and wrote upon the portayle the words the which follow. Here
was the mancyon of dur Durant / whiles that he was living. Of al wretches
most hard and skante / unto the poor in gyuinge. Of their need he gave no
charge. Wherefore in hell is now his dwelling / in perpetual tourme^t and
rage. Unto that purpose saint James says that the Judgment without mercy shall
be done unto him the which does no mercy. Vn^ iacobi.ii. Iuditia sine
misericordia fiet illi qui non fecerit misericordiaz. When god has given
haboundaunce of worldly gods unto any person / and that he is so unkind yt
he will give nothing unto the poor the which demands in ye name of god /
a man should know that god has such a man in hate. And reputeth yt man
denies it unto himself / as says ye gospel of matthew.xxv. Quod vni ex
minimis meis non fecistis / nec michi fecistis. When a master sends to
demand any thing by his servant and yt he is denied the said master
reputeth that him self is denied. In likewise when ye said Dura^t denied the
poor yt axed in the name of god he denied god. And the evil yt he did unto
them god reputed as done unto himself. And for as much as he was unkind and
without mercy he had well deserved to have punycyon corporel / and that yt is
much wors damnacyon eternal. So it appears that he lost his body / his
goods / and his soul. etc.

C. Another example of a rich man unmercifully yt fled in ye time of famyne
of dread to give al mess unto the poor peop.le lxxxiiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermens this the which follows thwehiche is
also written in other books and says that there was a rich man without pity and
mercy the which in the time of famyne and of death fled in to an heritage
that he had by a water side. And it was for to avoid the clamor of the poores
the which him required. And the said poores followed hy^ And for that yt they
demanded alms he said. I shall not endure with these dogs / and made his
table behind a chamber on ye side from whens he ne might here their clamor.
And thither came incontinent an armed man the which smote at the gate saying. I
am the messager of god / and I would speak with your master. And a servant
said by the commandment of his master yt he was not there. He answered thou
lie He is gone unto such a chamber to the end that he here not the clamoures
of ye poores And now fro the party of our lord I cite him that he appear
before god / and that he come to yield reason of all the goods temporelles yt
unto him has be taken. The rich man was hastily seek unto the death / than
his friends and parents came to vysyte him and to move him unto penance and
co^fessyon / the which he would not here / and said unto them. I am cyted unto
the Judgment of god / unto whom I have appeared and am there Iuged unto ye
death eternal without any hope of health For in likewise as I ne have
excercysed mercy ne had co^passyon on the poores of Ihesu christ / also without
any mercy am I sentenced / and so ye accursed deyed / and lost his life / his
b^dy / his goods and his soul.

D. Another example how a monk saw rich men hanged in ye fire of hell.
lxxxiiii
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint Gregory that a monk desired to go in to
an hermytage / and before that he demanded lyce^ce to go thither he was seek
and deyed and was led in to hell / but anon he was brought again and put in
to his body. And he remembered him to have seen the tourmentes of hell and
innombrable places full of fire. And within those flambes of fire he saw some
rich men hanged / ye which he had seen and known in his country / and were
stro^gely tourmented. And as he was led to be put within the said fire there
a ryued an angel fro whom proceeded great clerenes the which defended yt he
ne were put in the fire. The which said unto hy^ return in to thy body and
take good head wisely from hensforthe whiles thou lyuest that you come not
hyder. After this voice he returned in to his body / and little and little
came in to conualescence. And afterward put him in so much fastings /
wakinges oraysons / and good operacyons ye marvel it was / for the tourmentes
yt he had seen yt the sinners sustain. etc. This example should move cursed
rich men to restore ye things evil gotten. etc.

E. Example how two men were lepres for yt they despised lepres. lxxxiiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in ye book of sermons that there was a priest the which
had in so great horror the lepres yt he herd their co^fessyon through a wall
and himself was lepre. Also it is written of a servant the which had in so
great horroure the lepres that he would not bear the^ ne to give the alms /
and he himself became lepre.

Simonia.
A. Examples of people the which have been symonyakes. And first example of
Simon magus. lxxxv
IT is written in the deed of the appostles yt the false and dysloyal simon magus
offered great sum of money unto the apostles wenynge by yt to get the grace
of ye holy ghost yt he saw in them. And understood yt if he might have ye
grace that he should sell it unto other and should receive great fynaunces. But
in figure of all those the which sells or byeth things spyrytualles he and
his money were accursed of god by the mouth of saint Peter. Vn^ actuu^.vii.
Pecunia tua tecum sit in perditio^e. That is to say. Thy money be with the in
perdicion. And for yt he was the first in ye new testament yt would bye
spyrytuall things this espece of theft is named in all holy church symony for
because of ye cursed simon figure of all the dampened symonyakes.

B. Another example of the punycyon of Gyezy yt was symonyake. lxxxv.
IT is written.iiii. regu^.v. ca. how the prophet Helyseus gave health of the
sekenes of lepry to a rich man named Naaman the which offered great gifts
unto ye said prophet after yt he was hole. But for none erthly thing he would
nothing take. Also he knew yt it was symony to sell ye grace of the holy
ghost. And the dyscyple of the said prophet named Giezy was coueytous and
ran after Naaman of whom he demanded money and clothinge. And for to be
short he took two talentes of silver / and two vestementes for ye grace yt his
master had done to him. The which thing dyspleased unto god and his master.
And when the euentyde came ye said prophet demanded of Giezy fro whens he
came. He answered. Thy servant has been nowhere. And the prophet said. My
heart was that you were gone after Naaman and that thou have taken silver and
clothes for to bye oxen and sheep / and for to have servants and maidens.
etc. For as much as you have done this thing ye lepry of Naanam shall draw to
the and to thy sede in perdurabylyte. Lepra naama^ tibi adhereat et semini tuo
in se^piternu^. And so was it done. For he was incontinent mesel / and so he
was punysshed for his symony. This example should wtdrawe each person to bye or
sell spyrytuall things / for it is a great sin yt taryeth not unpunished.

C. Another example of the symonyake Hieroboam the which sold bysshopryches.
lxxxv
IT is written.iii. regu^.xiii. ca. how king Hieroboam took money for to
constytute ye persons to be sovereign bysshoppes. Also it was ydolatry and for
that / yt he was a symonyary and a great sinner for these causes he deyed
myscheuyously and he and all his was put down / degraded / and effaced
Vn^.iii. regu^.xiii. Quicu^que ei^ volebat implebat manu^ hieroboa^ / and
fiebat sacerdos excellorum et propter ha^c causa^ peccauit domus hieroboa^: et
euersa est et deleta de superficie terre. etc. If ye vendycyon of the
prestehode of ydolles was in such wise venged of god that the said Hieroboam
was so punisshed and put down as it is said / it follows well yt they the
which sells the true prestehode shall be cruelly punysshed / for such
people ben thieves. Vn^. johan. x. Qui no^ intrat per hostiu^ i^ ouile ouiu^ /
sed asce^dit aliu^de ille fur e^t et latro. Also they ben sacryleges. For ye
theft yt they done is by vendicyon of holy things. Sacrilegiu^ dicitur quasi
sacru^lede^s vel sacru^ viola^s. It should be a defe thing to say yt he is
sacrylege that steleth a chalyce and yt he is none that steleth the hole
church. Also he that sells a church is a thief / symonyake and sacrylege /
whereby he commytteth great sin. Unto whom it behooves satysfaccyon unto him
yt is culpable / and that desires to be saved.

D. Another example how king Anthiochus was symonyake and proud over
puyssaunce humayne. lxxxv.
IT is written in ye.iiii. chapter of the second book of Machabees / how the
king Anthiochus sold unto Ialon the dygnyte to be sovereign bishop / and
also ill came unto him. He was also proud and lift up over puyssaunce humayne
/ as it is written in the.xvi. cha. of ye said Machabees. And he was punysshed
as he yode he and his army in great pride and furour to sle them of Iherusalem
/ god unto him sent a cruel and right stynkynge sekenes in the guts so yt he
was borne in a lytter / and from that fell in to puddle of mire lyenge on ye
earth. Also he was so stynkynge yt his servants and his host were sore
grieved / and himself ne might endure his own sty^ke. Also he was so seek yt
maugre in his heed he meked hy^ and than deyed in dyspayre.

E. Another example of a man damp^^d yt had many benyfyces. lxxxv.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that one of ye great masters of Paris named
in science was vysyted of ye bishop of paris and admonested at the hour of
his death yt he should leave and resygne many benyfyces that he had vnlefully /
and that he should hold alonely one. And he abode in his opinion full of
error and said. I shall assay if any may be saved with many benefyces. After
his death he appeared unto that bishop at the hour of tyerce as he was in
orayson to pray unto god. And when the said bishop knew yt it was the said
deed body he asked him how it was with him. He answered. I am dampened eternally
without any remyssyon. And he demanded ye cause wherefore. He answered for
elacyon. And ye bishop axed him of the said opinion. He answered that the
pluralyte of his benefyces helped him not / but noyed him. And ye said dampened
him asked if there were mo persons living in ye world. The bishop answered
/ Why demaundest you that / ye which art so great a clerk that thou wenest yt
the world is so sone fynysshed. He answered. Certainly sith yt I deyed there
is dyscended in to hell so great multitude of souls dampened that I would
skantly believe yt there had been so many living in ye world. etc. Unto this
purpose ye prophet Ysaie says / that at the day of Judgment few of the
people shall be saved in regard of al sorts of the ill yt shall be dampened.
And gives this symylytude of raysyns in ye time of their rypenesse and of
olyues in ye time yt they ben gadred. When the grapes and ye olyues have been
assembled and gadered there y^ abides same little thing in the vynes and
olyues forgoten and left. And this little the which there abides is to
compare by symylytude unto the saved / and the great multitude of the raysyns
gadered unto ye dampened. Understand well this the which is here written.
Ysaie.xxiiii. Erunt in medio terre in medio pplorum quo modo si pauce olive q^
rema^seru^t excutiantur ex olera et race^m cu^ fuerit finita vi^demia / huscm
pauci boni saluati lenabu^t voce^ sua^ atque laudabu^t cu^ glorificatus fuerit
dn^s. etc. This man dampened yt had so many benefyces denotes yt the couetyse
of gods and honor of the world deceyueth and dampneth yt people of ye
church. Or cupiditas et radix oi^m maloru^.i. ad thy.vi. ca.

F. Another example that none ought to be constytute in benefyce by prayers
carnalles. lxxxv.
MEn find by wrynge of anabbot when he was in his death bed he made all his
monks to come before hy^. Unto whom he required yt wha^ he should be deed yt
they should choose his neuew for to be abbot after him. The which was done. And
as ye new abbot walked in his gardyn by a well side he herd a voice yt
complained ruthefully. And the said young abbot coniured the said voice in the
name of god yt he should tell him what he was. He answered. I am the soul of
thyn uncle yt am here brent and broyled mestemably in this fountain / for that
yt I have procured carnally yt thou were abbot after me. To whom the neuew
said How may this be that you brennest in a well so cold. Than the voice said.
Go in to the church and fetch ye candelstyckes of copre and cast them in to
this well and you shalt se how I am burnt. Than he did it / and incontinent
ye said candelstyckes were molten as wax within the fire. And when the said
young abbot saw that he called all the monks and renounced unto the dygnyte
and croyse. / and afterward ye said voice was no more herd. By this example a
man should understand that those yt which enters so in benefyces enters not
not by the door / that is Ihesu christ as before is declared. Vnde johan.x. Qui
non intrat per hostium in ouile ouium sed ascender ali unde ille fur est et
latro.
