G. Another example how a man seculer should not do the office of the priest in
ye church. lxxxv.
IT is written in the.xxv. chapter of the second book of paralipomenon how ye
king Ozyas lift up in pride when he was in puyssaunce regal / and dyspraysed
his god. Morouer he presumed to be worthy and to do the office of prestes. And
he entered in to the temple of god and took the ensencer for to do the office of
a priest after as ye custom was to do honor unto god. And the master of the
prestes named Azarias entered in to the temple after with great multitude of
prestes strong. The which resysted against the said king / unto whom they
said that it was not his office to do such thing. Vn^.ii. pa. xxvi. No^ est
tui officu vt adoleas incensu^ dn^o / sed est sacerdotu^ qui consecrati su^t ad
huiusmodi misteriu^ / egredere de sctu^ario ne conte^pseris / qr no^
reputabitur tibi ingliam hoc a dn^o deo. And for as much as the prestes
reprehended the king thereof / he thretened them in great ire. And incontinent
before the prestes in ye temple he was smyten with a lepry / and was so all his
life / and dwelled in an house separated from all other / where he deyed a roten
lepre. And for the said cause he was put out of the temple. etc. By this
example and after scripture the seculer people should not presume to do ye
office of a priest / nor meddle to govern the goos^ly things ne the church.
For such things dyspleaseth god.

H. Another example in Alchinus / how lords should not co^stytute people of ill
life to be benefyced. lxxxv.
IT is written in the.vii. cha. of the first book of Machabees how king
Demetrius consiytuted in sovereign priest / yt is bishop a ill man warryour
named Alchinus the which did many euylles / and also he dyed mischeuously /
and he reigned not long in his bysshopryche / after yt he had of eccysyons he
began to dystroy the operacyons of prophets. And incontinent he was stryke^ of
dyuyne punycyon and cursed sekenes / lost his speech and deyed foully / as it is
written in the foresaid book. Vn^.i. macha. ix. Precepit Alchinus destrui domus
sancte iterioris et destrua opera prophetarum and capit destruere Intempore
illo percussus est alchinus and impedita su^t opera illius et obclusu^ est os
eius et dissolutus e^ paralisi: nec vltra potuit loqui verbu^ et motuus est cu^
tormento magna. etc. Alchinus is interpreted / luctus / weeping / For they the
which se^blably entren in to benefyces should weep their sin by repentance.
For they enter not by ye door yt is Jesus christ. No^ intre^t per hostiu^ in
ouile ouiu^ sed ascendut aliunde / et ideo non saluabuntur. etc.

I. Another example of a man the which was bishop unjustly / and he deyed of a
sudden death. lxxxv
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says yt there was an archedeaken yt coueyted the
bysshopryche / and laid in wait upon his bishop a good man how he might slay
him. And the bishop had of custom to go often times to matynes / and went
before ye other for to great our lady / and he entered by a gate. The cursed
archedeaken put a great stone upon yt said gate. And when the bishop came as
he had of custom and yt he opened ye gate ye stone fell on his heed and
brayned him. And the archedeaken with great labor obtained ye bysshopryche. When
yt he was confermed and that he made his dynera pry^ce served before hy^ at ye
table knelynge. And suddenly the said prince was rauysshed before the chair of
ye sovereign Judge And he saw our blyssed lady with great multitude of saints
and of aungelles bryngy^ge ye said deed bishop / and brought his brain in
their hondes. And ye blyssed virgyn said My right dear sone I show to the / ye
blood broken and the brain of this bishop my friend yt the prodytour has
shed wyllyngly to obtain ye bysshopryche. Our lord answered. Who shall I
send to cite ye said prodytour / and who shall go. Than the blyssed vyrgyn
said. Here is his servant. Unto whom our lord commanded on pain of death yt
he should cite his lord personally to come to answer of so horyble crime. He
returned straight weeping / and trembling / and keste ye keruynge knyfe down
yt he held / and wept sore. He was prayed of the bishop and other for to
tell ye cause / and so he did. And cyted ye bishop as he was charged. And
after that he had brought forth the words / the bishop was smyten
incontinent of sudden death and deyed mischeuously before them al. By this
example a man may understand that he yt sleeth his neighbor iniustly is
homycide of his own soul. For he it da^pneth and byndeth unto punycyon
eternal. If the said archedeaken had not slain the said bishop he had not
deyed in such wise / and he had not be borne in such wise in to perdycyon. He
wened to clymbe hye / but he fell anon. He that cly^beth higher than he should
/ he shall descend more sooner than he would. etc.

K. Another example how a chanon was accused of the patron of ye church. lxxxv.
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that in a night it seemed to a chanon that god had set hy^
in Judgment and that all ye world was called before him for to receive every
man after his merytes. He saw also that every of them led with him some saint
unto whom they had most served to be advocate toward the hye Judge. And this
chanon thought yt he would pray that saint of whom he had be chanon / and that
he had served in singing and redynge / and that he should go in Judgment with
him before Ihesu christ to the end yt he prayed for him in showing him of his
service. That saint answered / I shall goo with the with good will. And he took
another with hy^ as for witness They came unto Judgment togiders. And when they
were before god the saint said. Lord I require Judgment of this vile lechour
yt by.xxx. years and more has eten and dronken his prebe^de of my church /
and has dysposed his time lecherously and foully / and one only day has not
ended his hours as he ought to do. He here is witness of this thing. Ihesu
christ answered. Take and bind him hand and foot and cast him in to hell. The
chanon awoke as if he had be in a great sleep / and wend for to have been than
in hell. And he said unto that saint. My lord take your prebende / for of it I
will ete no more. For this vysion he converted him / entered in to relygyon /
and saved his soul. etc. By this example people benefyced may understand yt
if they use ill the goods of the church they shall answer before god. And
better it is to be abiecte in this world and to live poorly than after the
death to lose paradyse and to be dampened.

L. Another example how a conuers yt would have been bishop by ye induccyon of
the devil / and he stale an horse and was hanged. lxxxv.
CAsarius dicit. It is written how a monk conuers had learned so strongly the
lettres yt he could read the text. And by the occasyon of this thing was wode
and made to write secretly little books deceptyues / and began to delight hy^
in ye vice of propryete. And as that study was defended to the said conuers for
the love of lernyng he ran in apostasy / and prouffyted little for the aege.
Afterward he was moeued unto penance and came again in to the monastery. And
the devil took him matter for to deceive him. For now he went unto ye scole to
the end yt he were a scoler / now he returned to the monastery / and appeared to
hy^ in lykenes of an angel / and said to him. Learn fast / for it is dyffyned
of god yt you be bishop of such a place. And ye unhappy fool euaded not his
fraud / hoped in hy^ to renew ye ancient miracles. What more. On a day he
appeared unto the conuers in clear voice and Joyous face and said unto him /
such a bishop is deed this day / haste the go in to the cite in the which
thou art predestynate of god to be pastor / his cou^ceyle he ne might change.
Incontinent the unhappy yode our secretly of ye monastery and was lodged in
the house of an honest priest. And to the end that he were put in his syege
gloryously he rose up before the day and stale a right good horse from his
host / lepte upon him and yode his way. In ye morning ye household knew the
damage and followed the appostate. They took him and put him in Judgment and was
drawn with his theft / and by sentence condampned. Not to be in ye chair as a
bishop / but he mounted unto the galowes / and there was hanged as a thief
Take heed unto what end the promise of the devil tends. etc. By this
example a man may understand that one ought to keep him to be deceived of
temptacyons / decepcyons / and lesynges of the devil. For yt that ye said
conuers kept him not and wend to be bishop he was hanged / and yt wors is in
way of dampnacyon.

Vsura.
A. Examples of people usurers. And first example of the punycyon and
dampnacyo^ of an auarycious usurer / out of whose belly proceeded a tree. lxxxvi.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a rich auarycyous usurer gate much good
unjustly / and for yt he was dampened / as it was showed unto a man yt was
rauysshed. Quasi i^ extasi. yt saw many torments in hell / and there was yt
said usurer prosterned and stretched allow / and from his belly proceeded an hye
tree full of branches / whereon hynge an horyble sort of men and women. And it
was told to the said ra^ysshed man yt the said usurer fro whom proceeded the
tree was an auarycyous / and they the which hanged were of his household / and
of his kynne the which followed him in syn^e / example / counceyle* and
admonyco^n And the which posseded after him yt things ill gotten without being
in will to yield them ne to leave them. etc. This example denotes that it is
great peril to give gods or herytages unjustly. For the geters and posseders
go unto da^pnacyon if they deye Impenytentes without being in will to restore
them.

B. Another example how an usurer that would not restore cried at his death yt
he brent and broyled. lxxxvi.
IT it is written in the sum of penance how an usurer was warned at his death
to make restytucion. And he answered yt he would not / and yt his wife and his
children had need / and therefore he would not restore. The priest would not
give him yt body of our lord and bare it again. Than by the admonycyon of his
friends for to take away the shame did so much yt he promised with mouth for
to deceive the priest / not of will to come to the operacyon. And when he had
received our lord / he cried yt he brent / and the fire of hell was wtin his
body. And in great clamor said I brenne I broyle in body and members / and so
he deyed myscheuously. By this examples a man may understand yt if ye said
usurer deceived the priest by word / he deceived himself much wors by deed.
And if he brenin body in this world. It is to presuppose that he brenneth
cruelly in hell as unto ye soul. etc.

C. Another example of the myscheuous death of an usurer the which in his
sekenes said that he chawed pence. lxxxvi.
IT is written in the promptuary of the dysciple that in the dyocese of Coleyne
a knight deyed yt was renoumed to be an usurer and auarycious. When he was seek
and yt the matter mounted in to the brain he was frantyke. And as he moved
every day his mouth and the tethe his servants said unto hy^. My lord what
ete you he answered. Iete pence. It seemed unto him yt the deuylles put pence in
his mouth. And he said. I may not bear ne suffer these deuyls bring me unto
the church / for peradventure I shall be delivered by the prayers of good men.
When he was there he cried / bear me again / for I se mo deuyls here tha^ in
mine house. The unhappy man was had home / and as the deuyls tourmented him he
deyed myscheuously. etc.

D. Another example of ye horrible death of an usurer. lxxxvi.
ALso the dyscyple recyteth that there was an usurer in the parties of brabant
right cursed / for he dysheryted many noble and puyssant men / and dyspoyled ye
poor of their goods. This said usurer yede often unto the relygyous and
prayed them as in manner of wepinge yt they would pray for him. But he correcked
not himself in no manner. And it befell that he was seek suddenly / and when he
aproched unto his death two terryble dogs of derkenesse came to his bed. And
he drew out of his mouth his own tongue / the which was stretched out as a
foot / and right horrybly he deyed. This example denotes that people the
which lives in sins of cursed life dies horrybly of cursed death. Also the
scripture speaks it. Vn^ psalm. Mors peccatorum pessima. etc.

E. Another example of a woman usurer the which made too burye with her / her
purse and her gold and silver. lxxxvi.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt two systers departed their gods and
herytages after that their mother was deed. And one of them took her porcyon and
departed it unto usury / and there assembled much gold and silver / and had
no compassion of her sister the which was nedy and poor. It befell that the
sister usurer was seek till unto the death. The which called her other sister
for to admynister unto her her necessytees. She served her in hope to have some
thing. When the sister usurer saw that she might not escape the death sent
her sister aside and took two purses full of gold and of silver / and gyrded
them to her bare belly under her clothes. And when her said sister was comen
again she said unto her. I pray the my sister yt when I am deed that you suffer
not that I be dyspoyled of no person / but that you bury me with the clothes
wherewith I am clad: What more. She deyed and was buried as she required. And it
was told unto the lord to whom the town apperteyned yt such an usurer was
deed / and that her gold and silver apperteyned to hy^. He sent incontinent a
messager to seek the said treasour gotten by usury. When the messager had taken
the keys opened the cofres / and that he had nothing found he began to
tourme^t the sister of the said usurer and to inquire for the said gold and
silver. The which had suspeccion yt it should be buried with her sister And for
the words that she had spoken / and for that her body was so heavy. Wha^ yt
said messager understood this thing he required ye priest yt the body were
unburied for to se the said thing. The priest suffered it and the sepulcher was
opened. Marvel it was / for when the body was all naked the priest and the
messager saw a right great and right meruaylous and ferefull serpent ye which
lift up often her heed / and kest in the mouth of the woman fire and sulphre.
Wha^ they saw that they had so great fere and horror that they fled and
cried to make men to cast again the earth hastily / and that it was the
devil the which punysshed the body and mocked it. The messager returned
hastily the which recounted what he had seen. etc. What prouffyted it unto the
said vsuryesse to get the said gold and silver wha^ her soul is tourmented
and damned. It is written mathei. xvi. ca. Quid prodest homini si vniuersum
mundu^ ^ucretur: anime vero sue detrimentu^ patiatur. She got / posseded / and
bare away the thing whereby she is pryued from paradyse / and is in hell
tourmented. In likewise as it is to presuppose for to consider her life and her
death / and that was found after that she was buried. etc.

F. Another example of an usurer the which demanded help of his gold / of
his silver / and treasoure when as he lay at the point of death / with the
which he was tourmented. lxxxvi.
IT is written in the book of examples of an usurer that as he labored in the
later days of his death was prayed of his tre^des that ^e would confess him
and to restore the vsuryes and brought unto him ye priest by two or three times.
But at every time he said / abide till to morrow / and after yt I shall do it.
And at the last after yt he had be strongly warned to be confessed / and that
he had said tarry till to morrow / when the priest was gone he made to bring
before him all his gold and silver / and said to it My gold and my silver I
never ceased to labor to take pain for the till unto now And therefore socoure
me now at this need. And one time there was herd a voice the which said. Go
in to the place where thou sholdest go and we shall goo after the. And
incontinent he deyed / and great thonder and tempest came thither / and the said
gold and silver vanysshed that it was not known where it became. And
afterward by ye suffraunce of god the soul of the said usurer appeared unto a
holy man as he was in orayson the which said unto him that he was dampened /
and that every day he was perforced to drink of the said gold and silver the
which was in the said fire molten brennynge and decourau^t / whereby men may
say unto this purpose yt the which is written. Sapienc. xi. Per q^ peccat ho^ /
per hec et torquetur. In likewise as the said usurer had offended in getynge
and keeping ye said good also of it he was tourmented. By this example a man
may know yt these auarycyous ben well abused to wene yt their gold and silver
shall socoure them sooner than god at death or in sickness / or that it shall
put them in paradyse and deliver fro hell by yt they have loved / served / and
trusted in the gold and the silver more than in god they shall be Iuged and
condampned and by their gold in hell punysshed and tourme^ted. etc.

G. Another example of an usurer ye which commanded his soul unto the devil
for yt it would not abide no more with his goods. lxxxvi.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons how Hubert says in the treatise of the
triple dread that as an usurer labored in his last days he made to be brought
before him his vessel of gold and of silver as cups. etc. And spoke unto
his soul and them unto it promised and many other goods as feldes / houses /
herytages. etc. and that it should abide yet in the world with his body. And as
he said these words ye doloure of the sekenes gryped him / and than he said.
For as much as thou wylt abide no more with me I command the unto the devil
And in saying these words he deyed / and ended his days evil as right was.
For he required not the help of god / but it was of his gods the which
failed him at his gretest need.

A. Another example of an usurer ye which would not restore / and he was borne
upon an ass unto the galowes and there was buried. lxxxvii.
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that a man an usurer would not restore: howbeit that he
was warned often. And when he was in his death bed he demanded ye
sacraments of ye church of his priest / the which would not give him them if
he would not restore / but he would not. And when he was at the point of death
the said priest was called for to recommaunde the soul unto the aungelles of
god / and yet again he ne would restore. Than the priest said. I recommau^de
him unto all the deuylles of hell / and went fro him. When he was deed his
friends required the said priest to bury him in some corner of ye chyrchyarde
for to save their honor. The which thing he ne would consent / for yt in his
life he would not consent to restore. And the said priest had an ass yt served
for nothing but to bear to and fro the church the books and other things for
the laid priest / and therefore he ne knew none other way. Than the friends of
ye said usurer prayed the priest yt the body might be laid upon the ass and
to let him go where he would / and where the said ass rested the body to be
there buried. And they wened that the said ass would have borne him to the
church or unto the house of the priest / for yt he was acustomed to go to none
other place. This thing was acorded of the priest and of all / and the said
carayne was laid upon the ass / the which bare him all right without
declynynge on any side under the galowes. And there he shaked him so sore yt he
made him to fall before all the people / and there he was buried cu^ patribus
suis. It was no reason that he were in holy earth with good crystyens / for he
had not lived an holy life in obeyeng unto god. And by yt the scripture
approved says yt usurers manyfestes ought to be pryued from sepulture
ecclesyastycall if they deye correccyon and amendment and without restytucyon
made to other. Vt habetur extra de vsuris. capitulo. Quia in omnibus. etcetera.

B. Another example how the ennemy ye devil set him upon the coffre where
the money was of an usurer. lxxxvii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary how an usurer gave in kepy^ge his
money in an abbay and a relygyous saw ye devil the which set him on the
cofre unto whom he demanded what he did there upon the said cofre. And he
answered. I keep my money. Than when ye abbot herd him speak it he sent again
ye said money and the devil yode his way fro that place. etc.

C. Another example how a man should not pray for an usurer deed. lxxxvii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a priest prayed for his fader the which
had been an usurer / and in syngy^ge his hands trembled. And saint Bernarde
prayed god that he would show what ye sygnyfyed. And an angel appeared to him
and said. It is great folly to pray for an usurer the which is dampened. And the
blyssed saint Bernarde defended unto the priest that he should sing no more for
his fader / And after that he had ceased to pray for his said fader his
hands ceased and trembled no more.

D. Another example what became of a church the which was made of vsuries and
extorcyons. lxxxvii
THe dysciple recyteth in his promptuary that after that a man had do make a
church of vsuryes and extorcyons he made the bishop to come for to dedycate
it. And as the bishop accompanied with his clerks did dedycate it he saw
behind ye auter the devil in habyte of a bishop being in a chair the which
said unto ye bishop Wherefore consecratest you my church. Cease the. This
church apperteyneth unto me of good right / for is is edyfyed of vsuryes and
rapynes. Than as the bishop and ye clerks fled the devil dystroyed the
said church with great dau^synge. An almesdede or any thing that a man gives
unto god or unto his church / or unto any of his saints of paradyse should be
of good acquysycyon of good berynge without being made of theft extorcyon or
usury. etc. or it shall not be agreeable unto god. He will not that a man take
away ye goods fro any for to bring them unto him. As the scripture says in
many places. Vn^ eccl. xxxiii. Dona iniquoru^ no^ a probat altissimus / nec
recipit oblatione^ i^i quorum. Et michee. ca. i Intulistis de rapinis claudum
et languidu^ munus / no^ quid suscipiam dn^o debile qr rex magnus ego sum dicit
dn^s. etc.

E. Another example of an usurer yt would not restore. lxxxvii.
IT is written in the book of ye gift of dread how a priest gave warninge of
three things unto an usurer yt deyed. The first was that he should repent him.
The second that he should confess him. The third yt he should make full
restytucion after his puyssaunce. And the said usurer said. I am content to do
the two first things / but ye third how should I do it / for there should
nothing be left unto me / ne unto my children. And the priest said. Without
these.iii things thou may not be saved / as says ye sages and the
scryptures. And he answered I will prove if it be true / for I will nothing
restore. And so he deyed cursedly / and dred more ye pouerte temporal than
dampnacyon eternal.

F. Another example of an usurer ye confessed him / and made restytucyon in ye
end of his days lxxxvii
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that an usurer fell in great sekenes ye which was warned
by his friends to confess hy^ and to receive all the sacraments. And he said.
What shall it serve me yt have so much deferred to confess and amend. And
the fre^des said. A man should evermore confess him / for peradventure god
shall give you his grace. And the confessor was called / unto whom the usurer
said. My fader espyrytuall I will confess me with good will. But I have
committed so many sins / and therein am so bewrapped yt I can not tell how I
may escape. Unto whom the confessor said. Dyspayre ye not / but confess you
/ for confession well made has such virtue that all sins there ben pardoned.
Than he confessed him / and god gave unto him such grace yt he repented him
and wept so strongely his sins that with pain might he speak by force of
wepinge. He made an entyer confession / restored the said vsuryes and things
ill gotten after ye counceyle of the confessor / and ended well his life and his
days.

Restitucio.
A. Examples of restytucyon. And first example of a man named Fryderyke
tormented in purgatory for that he had not restored ill gotten gods. lxxxviii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt after yt a knight was deed he appeared unto
a citezyn his neighbor in such manner yt smoke and flambe issued fro his
nosethrylles / and he was covered with sheep sky^nes / and bare a plotte of earth
upon his sholdres. Unto whom the cytezyn said. Ar ye Fryderyke. And he said /
ye. Fro whens come ye / and what betokens the things yt I se. He answered. I
am in great pains for yt I have taken away sheep skynnes from a wydowe the
which I feel now brenny^ge. Also I have drawn unto me iniustly ye party of a
field yt weyeth sore / and bruseth my sholders. But if my children restore my
pains shall be light / so he departed. And wha^ the sons of ye said knight
herd these words of their fader they loved better that he should abide in
pain than restore ye said things. This example denotes that ye said
Fryderycke had contrycyon and confession / but he did no satysfacco^n. And
therefore he was in purgatory. And by yt / that ye said children would not restore
it is to note yt one ought not to tarry for his parents too do good after his
death / but do it himself.

B. Another example of a child yt was in the pains of purgatory / for yt he
restored not money borrowed. lxxxviii.
MEn find by writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says yt a duchesses sone of.ix. year old was seek and shrone
him and deyed. And after his death he appeared to his mother / and said yt he was
in great pain in purgatory for that yt he had not paid the debtes borrowed of
the servants of his said mother for to go play. And yt at his death he
remembered not to pay them or make to be paid. And the said child required his
mother that she would pay the said debtes / and that his pain should have end
so yt they be paid. The which said yt with good will she would pay them. And
she made inquysycyon of the said servants. And made them al to be paid the
which had send to her said sone. And incontinent that they were all paid the
child appeared to his mother again in great clerete Unto whom he said that he
was delivered from pain and put in great felycyte. etc. By this example a man
should understand that him behooves to be pure and clean for to go in to
paradyse. When the said child was wtholden and carried from glory alonely for
silver borrowed / how shall these thieves and pyllers enter the which will not
restore / when the said child had taken nothing malycyously was carried. It is
written i. ad cori^. vi. Neque fures neque auari regnum dei possidebu^t. etc.

C. Another example of a man tourmented in the pains of purgatory for the
defaute of.vi. penyes that he ought to a woman. lxxxviii.
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple yt a man ought.vi pence to a
wydowe / the which demanded many times her payment. And the said man dyed
without payenge it / howbeit yt he denied not ye debte. After his death he apered
to a devout person and prayed him yt he would pay ye said.vi. pence / and
that he was much tourmented in purgatory / and endured as many strokes as she
had made steps for to axe him the said money / and yet should sustain till
yt she were paid. By this example it is to be noted that by the defaute to pay
that yt a man owes he is let to go in to paradyse / and is bound to
punycyon.

D. Another example of a relygious that was in the pains of purgatory for an
halfpeny that he owed unto a feryman or passager. lxxxviii.
IT is written in dyaloguo cesaru yt a relygyous conuers of the order of
Cystercie^cis was sent of his abbot for a besynes / and he yode. And when he
came to pass over yt water he promised to pay an halfpeny unto ye passager for
his mede / the which he should have sent unto him / and he was neclygent to
send it. When he came unto his death he confessed him of the neclygence of the
halfepeny not paid / for he cared not for so little a thing. After his death
he had ye said halfpeny before his eyes the which halfpeny became so great
that it seemed him that it was greter than all the world. And when he came unto
the Judgment of god there was found none other thing yt let the said
relygyous to go to heaven. And at ye request of some saint he was sent to his
body and confessed it and restored and was saved.

E. Another example how ye devil lets to restore lxxxviii
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that three deuylles came upon a time to a
good holy hermyte. Of whom he axed the names. The first said / close heart For
when any hereth a sermon I close his heart yt he sees not ne repents his
sins The second says. I am called closing ye mouth. For if any would
confess him and avoid our gynnes I close his mouthein lettynge him yt he ne
may confess him. The.iii said. I am called close purs. For I let to restore
the ill gotten goods / and lets to give unto poor of their goods / and so
I close ye purse. We ben assembled togyders to help each other. etc. By this
example it appears yt the deuyls lets a man to repent him / to confess /
and to make restytucion. And it behooves to do the contrary to have salvation.
etc.

F. Another example of an abbot yt sent again money given unto the monastery
/ for yt it was come of usury and cursed acquysycyon. lxxxviii
THe dyscyple recites in his book that an usurer left by testament a great
sum of money about a. M. and. vi.C.li. unto a monastery / whereof many great
possessions were bought. After the death of the abbot was chosen another of
good conscye^ce yt was dyspleasaunt of the said money received. What did he.
He sold his bestyall his moeuables and immouables and sent ye money again to
the executourse to the end yt they should restore to all those the which had been dispoyled and grieved. And for that / yt the said executoures would not take
it but sent it again to the monastery ye good abbot was sorry and made the said
money to be borne to the market before all the cytezyns the which were present
/ and to them said who so will take this money let him take it / yt it is ours
I renounce and refuse it. For I doubt not but yt it be unjustly gotten. When yt
cytezyns saw this thing they were much edyfyed of the deed took counceyle
among them and chose people right faithful the which yielded the said money
pertyculerly to all those yt had been grieved / and of whom the said money was
comen. And in short time god restored unto to the said monastery in double
more of money tha^ they had restored. And where they had but few goods
afterward in great haboundaunce all was replenysshed. A doctor named Wyllyam
witnesses this to be verytable. And yt he saw in the said monastery many of
ye relygyous saints doing miracles and replete with spyryte of prophecy.

Excommunicatio.
A. Examples of exco^munycacyon against the thieves and sinners. And first
example how a white lofe became black and moysty after that it was excommunyed
and accursed. lxxxix
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that there was an earl of Toulouse that
sustained and received heretykes / and every such person is accursed by
sentence of right / ipreo fcto^ / with the heretykes. And an holy abbot was sent
to the said earl to wtdrawe him fro the said deed the which ne might be
converted by word ne deed to dread exco^munycacion. Than ye abbot said to ye
earl. To the end yt you and yours know by deeds how the soul is undone yt is
bound of exco^munycacyon I will yt one bring me a white lofe. And than he
said. O breed albeit that you ne haste deserved cursynge to the end yt ye veryte
of our faith be showed in ye / and the cursednes of ye soul that dredeth not
exco^municacio^. Exco^munico te. I curse ye. And as soon as he had spoken ye
word ye said breed yt was white became black / he made it to be cut in two
parties / and it appeared also black wtin moysty and corrupt. Afterward he
said to the^de that ye know also the virtue of the absolucyon / he took the
said lofe and absoyled it / the which became in his first whytenes and beauty.
By this example a man may understand yt ye souls of people exco^munyed or
accursed ben in horrible and foul estate yt has deserved to have such
maledyccyon / when the white breed became so undone and moysty / If a person
exco^munyed knew the great evil and maledyccyon yt is in it / and the pains
the which ben to him prepayred in hell if he deye in such estate / he should
love better to lose all the world if it were his / and that his body were as
small as flesh to pastees than to abide in it.

B. Another example how yt storkes left their nestes the which were upon a
man's house incontinent that he was accursed. lxxxix.
MEn find by writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that the pope Gregory the saint exco^munyed a new earl.
And for yt he contempned ye said excommunycacyon by miracle the storkes the
which had made their nestes upon his house yede to another place / whereof ye
said man meruayled / and made him to be assoyled. And incontinent the said
storkes came again to make their nest upon the house of the said earl.

C. Another example how the sparowes the which made noise in the church yode
out incontinent that they were accursed. lxxxix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons how in ye church of saint Vyncent the
martyr sparowes and cried and let the dyuyn^ service. And for yt none might
put them out the bishop of ye place cursed the^ and thretened them of death if
they entered after that. And more over if a man took such a bird and bare it
with force in the said church forthwt it deyed.

D. Another example how the flowers of an appletree fell and dried as soon as
the exco^munycacyon was drawn for a portos yt was in it. lxxxix.
MEn find by wrytinge how a thief stole the porthos from a priest And for yt
the said thief was suspended he put ye book in the creues of a young apple tree
full of sweet flowers. The sentence of ye bishop was borne. etc. And the day
that it was cast in going to mass the people saw the said tree floured / and
when they came again from the said mass they found ye said flowers undone.
The tidings came unto the said bishop of this thing / ye said book was
found / and as soon as ye bishop had assoyled the tree ye flowers came again
unto the said apple tree. By this example these excomunyed or cursed may
understand that they lose all the goods spyrytualles the which ben in them /
and also god paradyse / and all good deeds. And also all the consenters and
part takers should dread / sith that the said apple tree the which had not
done the ill lost her flowers. And here a man may understand that the good
deeds lost comes again by the virtue of the absolucyon sith that the apple
tree recovered the flowers.

E. Another example how a raven became hydeous and his feders fell from him
incontinent that ye bishop had cursed for his ring that the said raven had
taken. lxxxix.
MEn find by writing that a bishop drew one time a ring from his finger /
and a raven pryuely took it and bare it upon the house between two tyles And
afterward the said bishop sought his ring and was wroth and accursed him yt
had taken it. And in short time ye feders of the said raven fell from him and
became so hydeous yt it was marvel. And afterward within a little time the
tyler found the said ring / and the truth was known. The said bishop
assoyled and reapelled the said sentence / and incontyne^t the feders came
again unto the raven as before / and was made fair. etc.

F. Another example how excommunycacyon cast Justly or unjustly is too be
dredde as it appeared in two monks the which made the^ to be gelded. lxxxix.
IT is written in vitas patru^ how two seculers made them monks the which had
envy of the voice euangelyst / but not after science They gelded theymselfe
also as for to have the realm of heaven. And when the archebysshop herd of it
he cursed them And they wend to have done well / and they wrothed them against
him saying. We ben gelded for the realm of paradyse / and he has accursed us
/ go we in to Iherusalem to the bishop for to have help against the said
archebysshop. And when they were comen thither and that they unto him had
declared the case he said unto them. And I accurse you of this thing. They
were yet wroth and yode unto tharchebysshop of Anthyoche unto whom they
declared by order all the case. And he them cursed as the foresaid did. And
they said among themself Go we unto rome unto the pope / and he shall venge us
on the said bysshoppes. And thither they yode and said unto ye pope. We ben
comen unto the as chief unto the church and of us all / and they unto him
recompted al unto whom he said. And I you exco^munycate / for ye ben separed.
Than the monks defayled of all excusacyons and reasons. and said unto
themself. These bishops holds together for that they resemble to sennes. But
go we unto such an holy man yt ne takes head unto ye persons. Eamus ad illu^
viru^ dei sctm^ epyphanu^ episcopu^ de cipro qr propheta est et persona^ hoi^s
non accipit. When they approached unto the cite of ye said prophet it was
reveled unto hy^ of their case. And he sent before them and told them that
they ne should enter in to the cite. And than they knew their fault and said
that they were culpable in veryte they repented and would do penance / in
saying they have Justly excommunycate us This man here is a prophet / god has
reveled unto him of us. And they repreued themself right gretely of the gylte
yt they had done. And when god saw their heart repentauntes and knowing their
fault reveled it unto the said bishop. etc. The which made them to enter in
to the cite / comforted them and received unto co^munyon. And wrote again unto
the bishop of Alexandrye that he should receive them and that in veryte they
had done penance and so was it done. By this example a man should understand
that sentence is to be dredde. How be it that they wened to do well and not to
be excommunycate and yet they were. And incontinent they had reknowleged their
fault god would yt they were absoyled and received.

G. Another example how lightnynge consumed one that was excommunyed and
accursed. lxxxix.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuary that one exo^munycate and obstynate
entered in to the church of the virgyn Mary. And in contynent lightening
entered therein the which slew him / and the other had no harm. A man should
here understand that one exco^munyed or accursed yt gooth unto the church and
to speak and to talk with the good against the defense the which is made / and
for to put the other in sin hurts himself / and better it were unto him to
humble himself and to be solytary. etc.

Another example that one excommunyed repented him and afterward deyed before
that he was assoyled his body appeared as black as pytche. And after the
absolucyon he appeared white as snow.

H. Another example how a gardyn exco^munyed bare no fruit that it was
absoyled. lxxxix.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt the mother of the duke of burgoyne bought
of a priest a right fair gardyn planted with fair trees. And for as much as
the said gardyn bare no fruit ye lady demanded the cause. And it was said
unto her / when the priest song mass on ye sunday in the fruit time the
young men left the mass and the church and yode to gader the fruytes and
brake the hedges. After yt they had been repreued and warned too resyst them and
that they ne would obey he cursed ye gardyn yt it bare no more fruit. Tha^ ^he
duchess made to absoyle the said gardyn by the priest. The which commanded
with that yt it should bear fruit as it was accustomed / and in likewise it was
done. Unto purpose of this example it is written marci xi. quod dn^s maledixit
ficulnee / and statim aruit Our lord Ihesus has given his puyssaunce unto
prestes to bind and unbind. Vnde math. xvi. Quodcu^que ligaueris super terram
erit ligatu^ etin celis. etc. Of good right the gardyn bare no fruit / for it
was a curste. And after that it was assoyled ye ire of god was taken away / and
it fructyfyed. Sith yt ye said gardyn yt had not offended was pryued from
fruit and from all goodness by more great reason a person excommunyed is
pryued. etc.

Malediccio.
I. Examples of maledyccion. And first example of four monks the which slew
a bear. lxxxix
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint Gregory how a good relygyous named
Florentius required god yt he would send him some co^solacyon for to keep his
bestes. And when he yode forth of his oratory he found a bear. The which
when he bowed his wist yt he was sort of god / and committed his bestes to ye
said bear to keep as pastor and said. Keep my bestes yt come aye^ always at.
vi. of ye clock. The bear was obedyent and did so / and came sometime at six
or at noone after the commandment of his master in the time of his young
aege. And it befell that.iiii. monks had envy on the said Florentius for yt
their master did not like miracle and slew the said bear as he kept ye
bestes. When the beer came not again to the house at ye hour acustomed
Florentius was sorry in awaytynge for him And yode in the euentyde to the feldes
and found hy^ deed by the sheep. When he was enfourmed of ye case / and that
he knew how the monks had slain him he bewailed ye beer / and the malice of
his bredre^. And in his wrath cursed the homycydes of ye beer / and said. I
hope in god yt those the which has slain my beer yt did none ill shall
have vengeance in this life. And forthwt yt said monks were smyten with
cruel sekenes / scz morbo elepha^tico. and their members sty^kynge so deyed.
Whereof Florentius was ferefull and wroth / for he reputed himself homycyde /
for yt his his orayson was exalted of god. He wept their death all the time of
his life / to the end yt a simple man ne should presume to curse here after. etc.
This example denotes two things. The first yt punycyon and maledycyon came
upon the four monks for yt they slew the said bear by envy. The second yt a
man should more sooner require salvation and benedyccyon for his enemies than
maledyccyon in as the said Florentius was wroth to have required maledyccyon
on the monks. etc.

Septimum preceptum:
Luxuria.
A. Examples of people yt committed lechery. And first of a woman dampened yt
knew lecherously one of her kynnesme^ and did many other sins / of whom
issued two todes and bestes in confessy^ge her. lxxxix.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says ye two freres yode to preche in ye country
about. Of the which the one was au^cyent and penytencer of ye pope. The other
was young / innocent / and debonayre and came unto the castle of a noble woman
sinner. She confessed her unto the penytencer / and at every sin yt she told
the young friar saw a tode or a be issue of her mouth yt lept and ran
out of the church. And at the last as she would confess a great sin a
dragon put out his heed / albeit he drew it in again / for she had shame for
to confess it / and all the said todes and beestes came again in to her
mouth. And after that the said freres were gone ye young friar recou^ted it
unto the penytencer. Than the said penytencer was wroth and came again for to
warn her to confess her entyerly / and found her deed. They put them in
fastings and oraysons. And on the third day the said woman appeared unto them
in a terryble vysyon. For she bestrode a right terryble dragon / and had two
cruel serpents that enbraced / gyrded / stynged / and bote with their tethe
her breasts And had on her eyes two foul todes / and from her mouth issued
fire and sulphre right stynkynge. Her hands were devoured of two dogs yt
bote them Her eres were replete with arowes of fire Her head was full of
venymous lysardes yt bote her sore. And when ye freres saw this woman for
dread they fell unto the earth. Unto whom she said. Friends of god dread you
not. I am the right cursed woman sinner yt ye confessed before yesterdaye. I
made a confession faint and not entyer / for I hyd one sin yt I had committed
with my cosyn. And ye penitencer coniured her in ye name of god almighty that she
should tell the causes of the pains yt she had. And she answered. The lysardes
the which punysshe me in the heed is for the aournementes yt I bare. The todes
the which punysshe me in the eyes is for the lokynges unlawful. The arowes of
mine eeres is for the herynge of folysshe words. The fyry sulphre punyssheth my
mouth for the blasphemes / detraccyons / songs / vain words and kyssynges
yt I made. For the enbracynges and atouchynges unlawful yt I made the serpents
tourmenteth my breasts. The dogs byteth my hands for yt I have given to he^
that yt I should have given unto ye poor Also for yt I have aourned them with
rings and Iewelles. And I ride this dragon for ye pride yt I had in rydy^ge
and lyftynge me up in clothynges and garments above other / and for the
lecherous thynkynges I am brent intollerably in the members femynyne with the
thyghes knees / and legs. And soodaynly ye foresaid dragon terribly tourmented
her and bare her in to hell / and never after she appeared. By this example is
denoted many things / pryncypally how the said women the which bears on
their hedes undue aournementes / and that makes enbracementes shameful and
unlawful / upon their breasts as it is said in ye example shall have strayte
punycyon. Also by that yt she made not entyer confession for shame the todes
and beestes the which were issued returned again in to her body. That is to
say her sy^nes confessed were not pardoned and returned in her. For saint
Bernarde says. quod su^ma dei pietas vinia^ non dimidiabit / aut nichil / aut
totu^ te penitente dabit. And unto purpose that she had todes and bestes yt
tourmented her / and the fire that broyled her. It is written Ysaie vlti^o. and
marci. ix. Vermis eorum non moritur and ignis non exti^guitur. Et legitur
judith.xvi. Dabit ei^ eis deus ignem and vermes i^ carnes vt vrantur and
sentia^t vsque in se^piternu^. This word vermes / sygnyfyeth two things. The
first ben ye worms todes and bestes of the earth as says catholycon. The
second is the remors of the conscience / for the dampened shall evermore have
remembrance and remors of their sins yt they ben tourmented.

Another example of a curyall the which knew lecherously a daughter yt he had
holden upon the ^onte. lxxxx.
IT is written in the.iiii. book of the dyalogue of saint Gregory yt there was a
curyall in the prouynce of valere that made hy^ self dronken the saturday of
Eester after ye fast / and had holden upon the font a daughter the which he
demanded to dwell with hy^ And he knew her and lost her that night ye which is
a thing horrible to tell. When ye morning came yt he should arise he thought
yt he was much culpable / and that needs he must go to wasshe and bathe him in
likewise as he wysshe him in the bayne he washed the soylenes of the gylte of
his sin. Than he yode to wasshe him and dredde too enter in to the church /
but he dredde ye shame of the world / and the language if at such solempnyte
he yode not in to the church. And if he thider yode he dred the Judgment of
god. Than he dredde the shame of the world / but in dredynge held hy^ in
the^de suspect in regarding unto every of his moeuynges at what hour he
should be given unto the devil for to tourment hy^ before all the people. And
albeit that he dred hugely / he ne had none ill on ye said day And yede forth
Joyous of the church. And the monday he entered in to the church surely
without any grefe or harm. And it was so that by six days / he had never
none evil. And he yode in too the church Joyful and assured in wenynge ye
god ne had seen his sin / or if he had seen it yt he had pardoned him
mercyfully. And ye seventh day he deyed in the church of sodayn death
ho^^ib^y. And when he was buried flambe of fire issued out of his sepulcre /
and was so long space in the sight of all people. And there was in such manner
yt he brenned his body and bones / his sepulcre and all the earth yt had been
thrown and put out. etc. By this man that was punysshed is to understand yt
so shall be the lechours impenytentes. Also by that yt he confessed him not /
and that he did no penance / his case ne should be good to bear. For it is
written luce.xiii. Nisi penitentiam habueritis oe^s simul peribitis. Also he ne
might be puryfyed and made clean of his sin but only by true confession as
says saint Ambrose Nullus pcto^ iustificari poterit / nisi prius co^fessus
fuerit. And therefore he was abused to wene to take the culpe of sin away as
in baynynge him or wasshi^ge. Also for that / ye god punysshed him not forthwt
that he had done ye sin / is to understand yt god the which is mercyful
punyssheth not incontinent that we fail for to tarry us / that we should do
penance. etc.

C. Another example of a woman damned for atyrynge and aournynge of her heed /
and for to show her breasts / and for dauncynge / lepynge / and shameful
enbracementes. lxxxx.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says that there was a priest yt put himself
ofttymes in afflyccyons and oraysons / and song mass for his mother deed. And
one time as he song mass for her and desired too know somewhat of her estate
he saw her fast by the auter in a basket of fire holden with two deuylles and
bound. Her heed was replete with serpents small as heeres / and had a tode on
her breast that colled her about the neck with her forefete and vometed flambes
of fire in to her face. And had her hands and fete bound with chains of
fire. The said priest meruayled / and asked her of her estate. And she said
that vnprouffytably he prayed for her and yt she was dampened. She said more
over that the pains yt she had in her heed of serpents of fire was for the
aourneme^tes and heeres that she had borne upon her head. And yt she sustained
the tode on her breast for yt that she had showed her neck bare and her said
breast. And that yt the said tode vomyted the brennyng flambes of tire in her
face was for that she had colored and painted her said face. And for that yt
she had offended our lord by enbracementes shameful of her hands and of her
fete to lepe and to dance she had them bound w chains of fire. Than she
departed and went to hell. By this example is denoted that aournementes and
atyrynge full of pride the which apperteyneth not unto the estate of the
persons ben to fle. And also the dau^ces vnshamefull / for in hell they shall
be kept from lepynge / the fete and the hands shall be bound of the Justice of
god. Vn^ mathei.xxii. Ligatis manibus et pedibus proucite eu^ in tenebras
exteriores. Also by that yt the said woman had punycyon of the rode the which
was on her breasts is example for all good women the which will euade punycyon
/ and have salvation that they should hyde their said breasts and fair
flesh. For it is a bayte and the line whereby the devil deceyueth and takes
the persons. Also by ye beholdynge and regard of such things the persons
appetyteth to do and fulfill the sin of lechery that ledeth to da^pnacyon.
Vnde gregorius. No^ licet i^tueri non licet co^cupisci. And sapyence says.
ecclesi. ix. ca. Propter specie^ mulieres multi perieru^t / and ex hoc
concupisce^tia quasi ignis exardescit. Et hieronimus dicit. quam gladius igneus
est species mulieris quasi ex omni part sui sagittas mittunt / scz ad animas
decipiendas.

D. Another example how.xxiii. thousand men were brent with ye fire celestyall
for the syn^e of lechery. And Balaam gave the counceyle. lxxxx
THe hystory of Balaam is wryte^ in the bible in the.xxii. and.xxiii. chapter
of ye book of nombres. In the beginning of his life he was good and prophesied
ye coming of our redempcyon. For he said yt a sterre should go out of Jacob.
Orietur stella ex jacob / the which denotes the blyssed vyrgyn Mary. etc.
Also he had such gift of god that those yt he blyssed were blyst / and those
that he cursed were cursed. And for yt ye Balaac made war with the children of
ysrael / and yt he might not surmount them he sent to seche the prophet Balaam
for to curse the said people of ysraell. And for the great honors and
rychesses that the king Balaac made to offer him / he was perverted and
overcome so strongly that he demanded of god by two times yt he might go to
curse the said people. And god not so accorded. For his request was unjust and
ill in two manners. Primo. For that he would curse ye people ye good had
blyssed. Secundo. for to to have gold / silver / and honors worldly. Vnde
marci. xxii. dicit dn^s. No^ ire cum eis / neque maledicas populo qr bn^dictus
est And after yt Balaam had excused him to ye messagers of the king / he was
yet so gretely desired and overcome for worldly honors that he lept upon his
ass for to goo and speak with the king. But ye ass yode backewarde and would
not go his way / and yede ouerthwarte the feldes and drew him among breres
and thorns. He bette him / but for nothing he would go forward. And by the
virtue of god the ass spoke and him demanded. Wherefore smytest you me. He
answered. Thou have deserved it / and thou mockest with me. And Balaam aduysed
ye angel ye held a sword all naked. Than Balaam worshypped him upon the
earth hastily. And the angel him demanded wherefore he had beten thyrdely
his ass. I am come for to persecute the. And if thyn ass had not gone back
against thy will I had slain the / and he had lived. And Balaam said. I have
sinned. I knew not that you was against me. And if it dysplease the that I
thither go I shall return. And the angel said unto him. Go with these messagers
/ and keep the that you speak nothing but that yt I shall co^maundethe. Than
Balaam yode. And wha^ he was in the cite the king sent unto hy^ gifts and
princes / and was received in great honor. For to be short Balaam made to
edyfy by three times auters / and in three places for to do sacryfyce to god of
lambs and bulls to know if god should consent more sooner in one place than
in another for to curse ye people of Israel. But god yt is not varyable
consented no more in one place than in another Afterward for to obey to ye
king Balaam counceyled hy^ how he should make to commyt fornycacyon in ye men
of arms of ysraell: whereby god should be wroth with them: and right cruelly
punysshe them. And ye manner of ye counceyle was yt they prepayre all the fair
maidens of the cite assyeged of ye ysraelytes / and that those fair women
should hold them at their doors / and their ydols by them. And yt when the
cite were take ye me^ of arms would go to ye fair women. And so god wrothed
against the^. The ill counsel of the said Balaam was done and the sin
acco^plysshed. And god the creator wrothed him against the said children of
ysrael in such manner that fire celestyall descended upon them the which
bre^ned.xxiii.M. In likewise as expounds Haymo upon the words of saint Poule
the which ben written.i. ad cori^. x. Neque fornicemur sicut quidam eorum
fornicati sunt et cecideru^t vno die viginti tria milia. And yet of the above
said children there was yet a thousand of the princes the which were hanged
by the commandment of god and of Moses as it is written numeri.xxv. And the
Ire of god was appeased by that ye one of the children of Ysraell named Fynees
rose up and slew in the zele of god and of Justice a man and a woman in
co^myttynge fornycicaon. etc. All this said punycyon and this sin was by the
counceyle of the cursed prophet Balaa^ the which required of god that he
might deye as the Just men. Vnde numeri.xxiii. Moriatur ai^a mea morte
iustoru^ / et fiant nouissima mea horu^ similia. He would deye well / but he
would not live well. And therefore his request was not Just for to have well
without deseruynge it..

Stuprum.
A. Examples of deflouringe of vyrgyns And first. Example how a vyrgyn was
corrupt of a young man / and by malice imposed the sin upon saint Machaire yt
was pacyent. lxxxxi.
IT is written in the life of faders how the devil tempted a vyrgin the which
was defloured. And when she was great her friends asked her of whom she had
con^eyued. And she answered. This solytarye has slept with me. And her friends
and men of the street took Machayre / and hanged pottes and kettilles about his
neck / and led him betynge through the streets. And so much they Iniuryed
him / bette and oppressed that he was in likewise as half deed / and he bare
all pacyently. And a seculer man yt had mynystred unto him his necessytees was
also rebuked in saying unto him. Thou said yt he was an holy man / and he has
defloured our daughter. For to be short they would not leave to beat the said
Machayre till yt ye said man had pledged that he should nourysshe the daughter.
And after that he was pledged Machayre said unto himself. I find a woman it
behooves me to nourysshe her. And he put himself to work night and day and
made baskettes. And the price that they were sold for he made to be born unto
the said woman / and he bare all pacye^tly. And when the said woman should
child she was sore seek / and so longly to travail that it was marvel. And
she was demanded ye cause wherefore she chylded not She answered. It is for
that / yt I falsely has imposed the sin unto the solytary the which is
innocent / such a young man has committed the deed. When the man pledge of
Machayre herd the case he bare tidings that the woman might not child for
the false crime that she had imposed and that all the people came unto him to
cry him mercy and to do penance. When Machayre herd these tydy^ges here to
fle vain glory he abode not till the people came unto him for to gloryfye him /
he fled in to another place solytarye. etc. By the said daughter the which
was punysshed for yt yt she had imposed the said sin by lyenge upon saint
Machayre is for to understand that liars and ill sayers shall be punysshed of
god. And that their lesynges shall be dyscouered and showed before all. Vn^ in
euangelio. Nichil occultu^ est quod non manifestetur: nec absco^ditum quod no^
co^gnoscatur and in pala^ veniat. And by that yt Machayre had pacyence when he
was beten and iniuryed denotes yt in aduersyte a man should be pacyent. And
that / yt Machayre dred vaynglory denotes yt we should fle it and not abide to
be honored and praised of ye people. etc.

B. Another example of a knight dampened and tourmented in hell yt took the
maydenhede of a vyrgyn. lxxxxi.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a knight dyspoyled and took the mayde^hede
of a vyrgyn. And after that he was deed she prayed for ye soul of hy^. The
said knight deed appeared unto her vysibly in voice right rough and horrybly.
The which as she demanded the cause of his horsenes / he answered that it was
for that / yt he gloryfyed himself in ye swetenes of his voice in syngy^ge the
songs lecherouses and seculers. And she him demanded wherefore he had in such
wise the thyghes and the legs right black / scalde / scabby and full of
wounds. He answered / for that yt I gloryfyed me in ye beauty of my thyghes
and stretched them out and has enorned them proudely by the custom of a
knight. Now I walked among the thorns and am tourmented and prycked and
fulfilled with wounds. And she asked hy^ of thestate of his body / for he had an
huge tode styckynge on his breast in such manner yt with his two fore fete
strayned his neck and his mouth Joined to his / and his womb stretchynge
upon his womb / and with his hinder fete held and strayned his genytoryes and
wrong him terrybly. He said I suffer the kissing of this tode for the
lecherous kyssynges yt I made upon the and on ye other women. And for the
embracementes this tode enbraceth me. And for the operacyons of lechery I am
tourmented in my genytoryes without ceasynge. And she him demanded if he should
be delivered fro the said pains. And he answered pray ye not for me / for it
shall prouffyte me nothing / for I am dampened eternally / and for that yt I
have despised the medycyne of penance. And when he had spoken these words he
departed. And after this said vysyon ye woman chose to be enclosed and there
wept her sins.

C. Another example how Ammo^ ye sone of Dauyd was slain of Absolon for yt /
that he had defloured his sister named Thamar. lxxxxi.
WE find written in the.xii. chapitre of the second book of kings that Ammon
loved dysordonately his sister Thamar. And for the co^myttyng of the said sin
a man named Ionadab his friend cou^ceyled him yt he should feign hy^ to be seek
in his bed / and that he should demand yt his sister Thamar should visyte
him / and apply him to ete / and so it was done. When Thamar had applied him
to ete he put all the other out of the chamber / and there he prayed her of
dyshonoure. She answered. My brother do not this thing / it shall be a cursed
renown in Israel / do not this folly. I ne may bear this rebuke and thou shall
be as one of the foles of Israel. Ammon would not believe her / and was
stronger than she and took her by force and defiled her. And he hated her more
than he had loved her before and chased her and put her out rygorously. Than
she said. The evil yt thou do me now is more greter than that / yt thou
dydest to me before. And she dispoyled her of her clothes of vgynyte / and took
other and so yode away weeping and cryenge. And her brother Absolon unto whom
she told all ^he deed comforted her / and had Ammon in hate / and said
nothing to him. And two years after Absolon made a great dinner / unto the
which he badde Ammon and at the said dinner made him to be slain. And for
because that he had defloured his said sister Thamar. etc. And therefore many
euylles comes by harlottryses. The said Ammon committed incest to know his
sister / and defloracyon to break her vyrgynyte. These ben two sins reserved
to ye bishop. And the third came after ye was much great that absolon made
to sle his own brother. And the said Absolon was slain and deyed myscheuously
as it is written before in the fourth commandment. And it is to be noted that
yt the said lechery was committed by the cursed counceyle of Ionadab the which
seemed too be the fraud of Ammon. etc.

D: Another example how Sychem the which defloured Dyne the daughter of Jacob
was slain and his fader Emor / and those of the cite. lxxxxii
IT is written in the.xxxiiii. chapter of genesis how Dyne ye daughter of Jacob
yode forth of her faders house to the end that she would se ye women of the
regyon. And when she was in ye town Sychem ye sone of Emor prince of that
land beheld her / and coueyted and took her by force and slepte with her. And
after he loved the vyrgyn so much yt he said unto his fader. Demand this
maiden yt she may be my wife. Than he yede to demand her of Jacob as his
sons came from the feldes / the which were angry of ye defloracyon of their
sister. And the answer under treason was made unto Emor yt they ne might give
their daughter unto a man incyrcu^cysed / but if the males would be cyrcu^cysed
yt they should give together their children in marriage / and they should be one
people. This thing pleased well unto Emor and unto Sychem and to all ye
people. And they made all the males to be cyrcu^cysed. And on the third day
after as their wounds were sore grievous ye two sons of Jacob Symeon and Leuy
entered the cite and drew their glayues and slew Syche^ and Emor and all the
males of the cite yt had be^ cyrcu^cysed. After they took their sister Dyne in
the house of Emor. And the other sons of Jacob yode afterward in to ye said
and dyspoyled it in the vengeance of the said sin / and wasted the sheep /
the asses / and ye bestyall yt were in the houses and feldes / and led the
women and children in captiuyte. When this was done Jacob said to his sons. ye
have troubled me and put me in hate with ye chananyens and e^habytauntes of this
land / we ben few / they shall assemble them and beat me and my house shall be
broken. They answered. Shall we leave our sister a brothell and abused. Than god
spoke to Jacob and said. Arise you up and go in to Bethell and abide there.
Jacob was obedyent and yode in to Bethell and sacrifyed there to god. And the
terror of god beset about so strongly his enemies yt they durst not follow
hy^. By this example is seen yt for to commit the sin of lechery great ill
comes. For a little to have ye company of the said daughter only great murdres
and debates proceeded without the danger of the loss of souls.

E. Another example of him yt kyssed and enbraced the ketles of ye kechyn
weny^ge to enbrace vyrgyns. lxxxxii.
IT is written in the sum of virtues and vices how the provost of the town of
Rome made on a time to take the vyrgyns for that they believed in the christian
faith And the said provost made them to kept in the kechyn to the end yt he
might enough enbrace them. And as by night he entered with them in the said
kechyn he was assotted in his my^de in such wise yt he thought to enbrace them
/ and he enbraced the ketylles and the pottes of the kechyn and kyssed them And
so much he enbraced and kyssed them yt he was filled of lechery and was as
black as coals. Afterward he yode to his servants the which tarried him
without not knowy^ge that he was soyled and affoled. And when they saw him so
black they wend that he had be changed to a devil. So they bette him and
after they fled and left him. And as he meruayled by himself what it was /
he yode unto the emperor to the end yt he should make queremony. And they fled
al as from the face of the devil and bette hy^. And when he had understand of
other what it was he went home and washed him. And after made to bring ye
said vyrgyns before him and commanded to dispoyle them yt he might enough
behold their beauty but by gods power their clothes held so fast to their
bodies yt by no force none might dyspoyle them. And so god kept them from
defame and fro the fylthe of lechery / and the said provost was shamed. And
therefore they yt will live chastely should require the help of god as the
vyrgyns did yt god kept.

Consilium malum.
F. Example how an old bawd cou^ceyled ill and deceived a young woman. lxxxxi
THe dyscyple recyteth in the book of his promptuarye of a man yt had to go to
Rome. When he departed he left the gouernyng of his house unto his wife the
which was young fair and chaste. And as she governed her wisely a young man
beheld her beauty / and coueyted to have her by folysshe love / and her
desired by him and by other But he was despised / and she set naught by all his
gifts. And on a time an old baude him demanded the cause why he languysshed
and wept. He to her declared the cause of the said love / and she him promised
yt she should make him to have her. And for too do that she made a little
bytche yt she had to ere mustarde confycte with breed for to make it weep. And
she yode unto the house of yt said young woman / the which received her
benygnety in weny^ge yt she was a good woman. And the young woman demanded of
the old the cause wherefore the whelpe yt she had brought wept so. And she took
her to weep saying. This little bytche whelpe was my daughter right chaste and
right fair that god has changed in to a little bytche / and it deputed for
to weep so for yt she had let a young man deye yt languysshed of her love. And
the young woman declared unto the old yt such a young man had required her in
likewise as it is said. And the old said / behold how god has done in you
great mercy / ye may know it by ye wound yt he has made unto my daughter.
And take heed yt there ne come unto you se^blable thing. And by the causes of
yt said old woman the young wife consented her unto the love of the young man
and committed ye sin with him. etc. The said old bawd lecherouse in thought
but dyspised by her foulness was wors than yt devil / so ben these other
bawdes / for where the devil might do nothing by his temptacyons the said
old bawdes there works as did the beforesayd. And for that yt they have the
manners and condycyons of the devil the which ne counceyleth but evil they
shall go with h^^ in to dampnacion and perdycyon eternally. etc.

Adulterium.
A. Examples of aduouterers. And first example of a woman dampened the which
used her life in lecheries and glotonyes and her husband was unto the contrary
the which lived sobrely. lxxxxii.
IT is written in the life of faders that there was a man yt besyly labored his
land / he was attemperate / soft / of good manners / weyke / and sekely of his
body holden in his bed by langoure and lived great time / he kept tacyturnyte
and scylence in such manner that they the which knew him not had wend that
he had be dombe. And his wife was unto ye contrary / for her words moeued unto
all persons and unto all purpose that a man had spoken as her body had be a
tongue. Noyses sourded up often times among many for her. And she abode in
dronkenes with lecherous men / and so much was she given unto sin yt few
men of the street might escape her lechery. In her body she had never dolor ne
sickness. It befell on a time yt her husband dyed / and forthwt the air was
moeued by three days so much that it rayned on his bed and thonders and
wyndes were so strong yt he abode unburied those three days. And ye said woman
was unto the contrary / for after that she had lived long time she deyed and
it was fair weder / clear / and peasyble. And they had a fair daughter yt
considered the life of her fader and that of her mother for to choose which she
might take / and to believe that yt she had seen with her own eyes / or to believe
that yt she had herd tell of clerks. Than she slepte and there came before
her as a great man of body and of look terryble the which said unto her. Come
to se thy fader and thy mother and afterward choose to live of whyder thou
will. And led her in to a great field full of many flowers in paradise and of
diverse fruytes / and of diverse trees and of beautees inenarrables the which a
man ne may recompte. And she saw her fader in Joy and spoke unto him and
desired to dwell in that place there with him. Than he that led her took her by
ye hand and said that she should come to se her mother / and led her in to
hell the which is a place much low / dymbe and derke full of brennynge fire
stynkinge as sulphre / and there knew she her mother in the said low place /
and plonged in the fire up to the neck the which cried and wept / strayned
and grynded her teache of rage and of anguysshe / and had worms about her
neck the which bote her. And as she lift her eyes upward she knew her said
daughter and said unto her in cryenge. Alas my daughter for mine own operacyons
I bear these tourmentes. It seemed me that the life of sobrenesse and chastyte
was but mockery. I believed not that ye life of lechery and rybaudry gave such
torments. Lo for the little delectacyon of lechery and of glotony / and for
the delytes and worldely Joy yt I had I suffer so great cruelte of fire and
tourment. And as she required her daughter for help he yt led her took her
and set her there as he had taken her / and said to her. Choose now which life
thou will / either of thy fader or of thy mother. Than she took relygyon and
was saved. By this example it appears yt this woman yt lived after her body
was dampened. For ye little delectacyon yt she took she brenneth and shall brenne
eternally and shall be in so great pains that there is no writer that it ca^
write ne clerk / ne tongue tell it. And her husbonde the which lived sobrely
is in Joy eternal. etc. Tu reddes vnicuique iuxta opera sua: dicit david in
psalm.

B. Another example of the dampnacion of a burgeys aduoutrer and of another
woman married. lxxxxii.
MEn find in writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says that an holy man prayed for his wife departed and deed.
She appeared unto him and led him in to a place obscure. In the which he saw
deuylles horrybles / the which keste in a tonne of fire full of metal
boylynge a burgeys deed being of her town and the wife of another man / and
they were bre^t and bayned in the said metal and they swy^med wtin it as
peasen in the pot boylynge and they cried both twain / maledyccyo^ /
maledyccyon. And the said holy man was admeruayled. The said woman said with
those here I had been bayned if the mercy of god had not called me unto penance
/ and afterward said. These two here has left their propre maryages and has
drawn them unto sin long time togyders. And I have been their example and
mean and unto them I have taught the way to ask pardon of the said sin of
aduoutrye / but they ben deed without penance salutary. For the confession that
they made was without charity and for the dread of death. And my confession was
salutary and agreeable unto god / I made in it charity of the love of him. This
example denotes that punyssyon and dampnacyo^ follows to commit lechery. And
for that yt the confession of the burgeys / and of the woman was not good it is
to understand yt in confession a man should have true co^trycyon and
repentance to have offended god by sin and to be against his commandments
For those the which repent them for ^rede to be dampened / and alonely they
love but them self they ben out of the love and charity of god. For they ben
not wroth ne sorry to have of offended god by sin as the said woman the
which made confession in charity and she was saved. No good deed done is
merytoryous when charity there fails. As it is written.i. ad. cor. xiii. ca.

Another example of an aduoutrer that ye deuylles posseded at the enter of ye
church. lxxxxii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons of a man that after yt he had committed
aduoutry entered in to the church / and forthwith ye deuylles posseded him and
tourmented / and so myscheuously deyed he impenytent before the people.

D. Another example of a woman aduoutres dampened that two dragons tourmented.
lxxxxii.
IT is written in the book of gifts yt an honest man with his wife gave to gods
service any child if it unto them were given of god or sent. And they had a
sone ye which was good and relygyous. Than the fader and the mother did great
almesdedes / but the mother was deceived and chylded.ii. children of other than
her husband yt she slew secretly: and so she deyed without confessyo^. And as
her sone prayed for her in his mass she appeared to hy^ in great tourment and
had two foul drago^s yt bote her pappes. She was required to tell of her
estate. And she said / I am dampened. Than as her sone was heavy she said. I
trusted me in ye almesdedes yt I did and am deed without confession and charyt
These two dragons yt biteth me is for the two children yt I had in aduoutry
which I should have given souke and nourysshed and I slew them. By this
example is denoted yt dampnacyon comes for co^myttinge of aduoutry and bawdry.
And for that the said woman trusted in almesdedes yt she had done a man should
understand yt mortal sin brings to naught and makes to forgete the good
operacions done unto salvation and reward eternal and so dampneth the
persons the which so deyeth without correccyon penance and amendeme^t. Howbeit
that those the which has done in their life of good operacyo^s has not so
many pains in hell as if they had done no good deed And therefore none should
wtdrawe to do good deeds. etc.

E. Another example of ye pain of a man the which knew the wife of his
neighbor. lxxxxii.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that a young man sinned with the wife of his
neighbor / unto whom god sent a plaghe and he deyed of sudden death without
confession and without receyuynge the sacraments. The which by ye suffraunce of
god unto the terror of other aduouterers he appeared unto his rybawde after his
death in great tourment and pain. And ye said woman asked him of his estate.
He answered I am dampened for the aduoutryes yt I committed with the. And he said
after. Wylt you se how I brenne without and within / and keste of his urine ye was
as metal molten in bre^ninge fire. Of this vysyon the woman had so great fere
yt she went to confess / correct / and amended her life.

F. Another example how a man saw a woman punysshed for ye aduoutry yt she had
committed. lxxxxii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons that he has read that a man was
rauysshed before the gates of hell the which saw a woman right grievously
tormented / and a flambe of fire enuyroned her and beset about in all parts.
And the man demanded wherefore yt woman was tormented so grievously. The answer
was given that she suffered such tourmentes for the rybaudryes yt she committed
with strange men.

G. Another example of a young man yt sinned with a wedded woman. lxxxxii.
ALso the dyscyple recyteth in ye book of his promptuarye and says that a
young man sinned with a woman married and perjured himself. The which was seek
/ the body of Ihesu christ was brought unto him / but he would never receive it
till he had made confession verytable of the deed / after he amended him and
correcked his evil life.

H. Another example how two aduouteresses bette each other in the departy^ge of
a pyece of lynnen clothe that was given to them. lxxxxii
ESope says in his book that two harlottes married habandoned them with a man of
auctoryte that governed him not wisely ne holyly. After that he had sinned with
the said women / and with the one more than with the other he gave unto them a
pyce of lynnen clothe to depart between them for their hyre. And when they
were in ye street there was noise between them to depart the said clothe. And
the one of them said yt she should have more than the other / for she had been
there longer. They reuyled each other and called harlottes as they were. And
their husbands the which knew nothing of ye cause of them came to defend
each of them their wife and bette each other strongly. And as they were in
such debate there came one Quidam yt departed them / and said. Syrs it is no
matter here but to depart from hens. It apperteyneth well yt wise men here them
speak / and so they deparded. And the said lynnen clothe was put in hand
sequestered till ye said matter be dyscussed in judgment. etc. By this example a
man should understand yt the matter of them yt co^mytteth lechery shall be
dyscussed and iuged before god if it be not effaced by penance. And in
likewise as the said women were defamed before ye world and openly showed
their sin / all the sins of al sy^ners openly shall be showed in Judgment
before all. And that yt the said harlot said yt she should have more than ye
other for yt she had be^ there longer denotes yt so much more as a person
has done of sins and has lo^gest abyden in them shall have in hell ye mo
torments / and unto him shall be given more punycion than he yt has done but
one syn^e anon past. Vn^ apoc. xviii. Quantu^ glorificauit se pcto^r in pcto^
suo et i^ delicus: ta^tum date illi tormentu^ and luctu^.

I. Another example how a queen rode upon Arystotle yt was wise and a great
clerk. lxxxxii
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary yt James de vitre say^h yt Arystotle
