taught king Alexander that he should refuse to accede often times unto his wife
the which was right fair yt his courage ne were let to puruey unto the
charge of the comune yt he had. And Alexander unto him obeyed. When the queen
knew it she was full of sorrow and began to draw Arystotle unto her love /
for she passed by him often times all alone barefoted and her heeres vntressed
hanging down to the end yt she might draw him to her love. In the end
Arystotle was tempted and began to desire her carnally / the which said. I ne
will do it in no manner what so ever it be if I se not in the some tokens of
love that you tempt me not. Than come in to my chamber rampy^ge with fete and with
hands as an horse in bery^ge me and I shall know if you mockest with me And when
he consented unto the condycio^ she denounced this thing unto Alexander / the
which hyd hy^ and took Arystotle as he bare ye queen. And as he would have
slain him Arystotle said in excusing hy^. If it be so happened unto a wise
ancient yt is to me yt has be so deceived of a woman you may well se and
know yt I have well taught the / how may it come unto the that art young.
When ye king herd these words he spared and made an end of that / that he
had begone after his doctrine. etc. By this example here a man should
understand that ye most wisest ben as soon deceived by lechery as the simple
people. Also it is to be noted that the said Arystotle had offended before
god and was culpable as and if he had accomplysshed the said lechery / for he
had broken the commandment of god. No^ concupisces vxorem proximi tui. etc.

K. Another example of a woman aduoutresse yt bare an hot iron. lxxxxii.
IT is written in the sum of penance yt a woman married aduoutres was
susspeccioned of her husband / the which yode unto confession to weep her
sins / and after her confession bare an yren al reed before her husband for
too show yt she was clean and pure. And after yt she had done the said
miracle she enpryded her and assured returned unto her sysie as before. And
ones her said husband apperceyued her with the said sin / and hete secretly
the said iron and put it in the place where it was. And afterward said unto
his wife. Give me such an iron / where is it. Than she ran to take it with her
hands and she brenned them. etc. By this example is denoted yt by the virtue
of confession her sins were effaced and pardoned and did miracle / and for
to return unto sin she lost all and was wors than before

Peccatum in matrimonio. quere exempla.xxxvi. e. f. g. h. i.
A. Examples that in the solempnytees a man should abstain from operacion of
marriage. lxxxxiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons of a man yt a man knew his wife the
vygyll of Eester. The which when the priest put the body of god in his mouth
on Eester day it lept out. And as the said man saw yt he was confessed / he
repented him / confessed / and was houseled.

B. Another example how the children of a man and of his wife ne might have
baptysme for the sin yt they committed n marriage. lxxxxiii
ALso men find by writing that a man and a wife contempned not honestly in
the operacion of marriage. And they had three children the which could not have
baptysme. And for to find remedy and counceyle they yode unto an holy bishop
to confess them. Unto whom they said that their children might never have
baptysme. And he axed them one after another / each of them by their self if
they made any dyssolucion or dyshoneste in the operacyon of marriage. And they
answered ye one after ye other / ye / thus and thus. Than ye said bishop said
unto them that it was ye cause wherefore their children had not baptysme for
doing that sin. And therefore a man should conte^pne honestly in marriage /
and to accede the one with the other / or to make lygnage / or for too yield the
debte of marriage on her party / or for to fle and avoid sin.

C. Another example how a woman chylded.ix. children at a burden. lxxxxiii.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that there was a clerk a good child
approved of good manners the which converted all unto the praise of our lady.
By ye which he was bishop of coleyne / and ye said bishop arose on a night
for to give lauds to god and our lady. And after yt he had walked through his
hall he beheld out at a wy^dowe women yt bare in a panyer.viii. children borne
in yt night of a noble matrone of the cite. The which for shame retained one
and gave great sum of money unto ye women for to go drown. viii. The said
bishop took the said children / baptized them and made them to be nourysshed
secretly / and made them to be instruct in lettre and in song.x. or.xii.
years. The bishop made his occupacyons with a burgoys yt took the children and
they followed him. In the end ye said bishop reveled ye deed unto the burgoys
and unto ye mother of the children. And by ye grace of god a cloister was
edyfyed / in ye which the bishop and the children yielded them unto god. etc.

Sacrilegium.
D. Examples of men of the church lecherous. And first example how a priest
fornycatour deyed suddenly. lxxxxiii
IT is written in the life of saint Loye bishop how a priest of his
bysshopryche was infamed of fornycacyon for a concubyne yt he held with him.
And after yt the said priest was often times warned to abstain him from yt
sin / and that be would not the said bishop exco^munycate him and defended
him to sing mass. The priest despised the sentence and prepayred him to sing
mass. And when he was at ye auter he fell toward it and was strangled of the
devil and deyed suddenly before al ye people. This example denotes many
things. The first first is yt these lechours yt will not correct the^ and
amend when they ben warned shall be punysshed of god. The second is yt people
of the church ne other should attend to receive their creator in sin / and
without to have will dysposed to abstain them fro ill. For ill came to the
priest. The third is yt exco^munycacyon is much to dread and for as much as
the said priest dredde not ill did come unto him both unto body and unto
soul. etc.

E. Another example how two relygious were appostates / lecherous / and after
did penance. lxxxxiii.
IT is written in the life of faders that two relygyous were tempted of
fornycacyon / they yode in to ye world and took two wives. Afterward they
said togyders. What have we won where as we have left the order angelycke for
to come to this immundycyte and uncleanness / and after these things we shall
come unto the fire of tourmentes Than return we unto our hermytage / and do we
penance of things yt we have presumed. And they went in to ye hermytage and
prayed the faders yt they would receive them confessing and penytentes of
things yt they had committed. They wete tha^ received and enclosed an hole
year. And by penance men gave unto them breed and water by measure. In
beholdynge them they were semblables of one replexym. When ye time of their
penance was accomplysshed they issued. And the one was pale / lene / and
sorrowful / and ye other fair and ruddy. And each had marvel for they had
egally breed and water And they axed hy^ yt was lene and heavy what he did with
the thoughts when he was enclosed. He said I thought yt I should go in to
pains for the euylles yt I have committed and my bones harded them to my
flesh for great fere yt I had. They demanded ye other what he thought when
he was enclosed. He answered I yielded thanks to god yt had wtdrawen from me
the soylenes of ye world and the pains of hell / and called to ye
co^uersacyon angelyke. And I rejoice wha^ I think on my god. And the au^cyents
said yt the penance of both twain was egal toward god. By this example
those the which has committed sin should return unto god and do penance
as did the said relygyous. What shall it prouffyte unto a person to do sin
at his pleasure / and after to be dampened. etc.

F. Another example of the punycyon and dampnacyon of a nonne that committed
lechery. lxxxxiii.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a nonne slew her child in her womb /
and so deyed without co^fessyon Afterward she appeared unto her cosyn yt prayed
for her and held a child of fire in her arms / unto whom she said. I am
dampened / and this child of fire yt I bear I have conceived and slain it. And
I must bear it eternally by punycyon.

G. Another example how a pilgrim saw a prelate cast within the depnesse of
hell. lxxxxiii.
ARnoldus and the discyple recyteth in their books yt there was a pilgrim yt
sold his robe to drink strong wine. And he drank so much yt he was dronken
and lost his wit / and yt men esteemed yt he was deed And that hour his soul
was borne in too hell in the place of tourmentes / and specially in to a pyt
brenny^ge and covered with a lydde of iron enbrased in fire. And there was ye
prince of derkenes / and the pilgrim saw aprelate yt was presented unto y said
devil the which greted him / and him presented to drink of a cup enbrased
full of soulphre in fire molten. And when the prelate had dronken the lydde of
the pytte was taken away: and the prelate was cast within ye pytte of fire. And
when the said pilgrim saw yt he had great fere. And the devil cried on high.
Bring me hyder yt pilgrim yt has sold his vestement and made himself
dro^ken. And when ye said pilgrim herd those words he beheld his good
angel yt had brought him thither / required his aid / and promised unto god
and him that he would neuermore be dronken so yt he would deliver him at that
hour. And forth with his said soul was put in to his body. And the said pilgrim
noted the hour and the day yt it so befell and went in to his country and
found yt the said prelate deyed at ye day and at the hour that he was borne
in to hell. For he was of his country whereby he wist yt it was very table. And
therefore the excess of meet and drink is to fle. etc.

H. Another example of a relygyous woman dampened the which in her life gave
great alms / but she conceived a child and slew it. lxxxxiii.
MEn find by writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that the daughter of a king was so much devout / so
good an almeswoman and chaste yt it was marvel. She nourysshed all ye days
of her life a nombre of poor folk / of wydowes and of orphelyns. And it befell
that by folysshe look that she made upon one of her servants she coueyted to
lie with him / and conceived a child. And by the counceyle of an old woman she
dystroyed and slew it. After that she had no more Joy and required to be put
in relygyon. Her fader put her / and there she was solytary without laughing or
playenge the which was ye example unto other in all bounte and relygyo^
Afterward she deyed without confessyng her of yt sin / and within.xxx. days
she appeared unto her abbess to whom she said yt she was dampened. And the
abbess said. Alas tell me the cause wherefore / for you was so good that you was
our light and our example in all goodness. Than she told yt for ye said syn^e
committed she was dampened. Moreover she said yt if she had be confessed of it
yt she should have had pardon and if she had committed it a.M. times. By this
example a man should understand yt the good operacions saves not the persons
if they deye in mortal sin without confession and correccyon. It is that / yt
the prophet Ysaie says. Iusticia iusti non liberabit eu^ in qua cu^que die
peccauerit. etc. Also note well yt no person ne should draw back to do good
deeds: and also he should do as many as he may and albeit he should dampened for
he shall have the less of tourmentes in hell. etc. as it is declared before.
Quere. xlii. b. Also a man should understand by this example yt by true
co^fessyon all sins ben pardoned. etc.

Castitas et bonitas.
A. Example how a vyrgyn saw a priest chaste / pure / clear and fair in
synginge mass. lxxxxiiii
IT is written in the promptuary of ye dyscyple yt there was a virgyn religyous
named Oda in the town of Benda^ce yt saw yt as a priest of ye vyllage sa^ge
mass his body and his holy vestements were decored honorably. And when he
lift ye hostye and put it on the corporas the angels took ye sleues yt they ne
touched ye said hostye. And lyfted their hands enclinynge their hedes with great
reverence and worshypped ye body of god. When time came to receive the
sacrament the vyrgyn was also rauysshed out of her thought / and saw the body
of the priest so pure and clear that she saw ye body of god as by a fyole of
crystal. When ye mass was ended and that ye priest had put of his clothes the
vyrgyn came again unto her self and saw the body of ye priest little and
little thycken and return in the first form. And ye said maiden had such
grace yt she saw those the which received their creature worthily. And she
saw on an Eester day yt all only.x. persons received their creator worthily
in a church. etc. This example should moeue the prestes to accede in the holy
sacryfyce of ye mass worthily and holyly in estate of grace for to have ye
grace that the said priest had. Also the virgyns should keep holyly their
chastity and maydenheed / and to live devoutly in doing good works as did ye
the said vyrgyn for to get grace toward god. etc.

B. Another example how two relygyouses were from crystmas till unto ye feast
of saint Johan to speak of god / and they wened not to have been but the space
of two hours. lxxxxiiii.
IT is written in the book of ye dyscyple and in many other places approved yt
two young vyrgyns relygyouses felawshypped togyders the night of crystmas after
the mass of mydnyght entered in to an hall deserte nere unto the cloister and
bare with them three pylowes otherwise called cuysshyns. And one of them
demanded of the other wherefore she bare two cuysshyns. I shall sit on the one
and ye other shall be between us yt the child Ihesus also may sit. For he has
said when two or three ben assembled in my name I am in ye myddle of them Vn^
math. xviii. Vbi sunt duo vel tres co^gregati in noi^e meo: ibi su^m medio
illorum. The two vyrgyns sat and spoke of the natyuyte of Ihesus and of good
words / and were in the said place without enoyenge them till unto ye day of
saint Johan baptyst fro ye night of crystmas. And their abbess demanded them
and made to seek them over all. And it befell yt a vacabonde the which walked
by the cloister the vygyll of saint Johan entered in to the said halle and saw
ye two vyrgyns speak / laughe / and enjoy the^ and in the myddle of them there
was a right fair child. The said man bare the tydinges unto the abbess of ye
relygyouses that she demanded. And she came in to ye said hall and saw the
fair child and her relygyouses the which enjoyed them. Than she demanded
them what they did there. They answered yt they tarried till mass were rongen
of the day. And they wened to have be^ there but a little while as two hours.
The child departed and the abbess led them with her. They were demanded
where ye said little child became. And they answered yt they had not seen him.
And ye abbess said. Systers have no dread / in your company has be ye child
Ihesus yt ye have not seen I have seen him. He has holden you in such Joy fro
crystmas till ye vygyll of saint Johan baptyst yt is this day without ho^ger or
thyrste. These relygyouses had great Joy thereof / and of their systers that
they demanded. etc.

C. Another example how a bishop chaste and pure saw on Eester day some men
confessed the which were black and other white. lxxxxiiii
IT is written in the promptuarye of ye dyscyple and in the book of gifts that
an holy bishop prayed god the day of Eester to know ye merytes and the estate
of them yt received their creator. And god exalted his oraysons / and in
beholdynge the people there came some black as pytch / some enbrased as iron
al reed as blood / and the other white and shynynge as the son. And the
angel of god appeared unto him and told him that the black were lecherous
and proud. And they the which were enbrased were auaryous / and the blody
were dyse players and blasphemers. And said unto hy^ yt all they were unworthy
/ and that unworthily they had received their creator / and that all be it yt
they had had contrycyon and made co^fessyon / yet had they no purpose to
abstain them fro sin in time to come. And said afterward yt all the other
the which where white and clear ben those the which had acceded worthily with
ferme purpose to abstain the^ fro sin and to amend their life. etc.

Another example. It is written in the life of faders yt two men were sklaundred
to be aduoutrers and dyshonestes. And for as much as they were of the nombre
of good people the bishop prayed god yt he might know if the sklaunder were
true. And as ye people acceded to receive their creator after the consecracion
the said bishop knew the deeds of one and of every of them / and ye souls in
beholdynge their faces. And he saw the faces of the sinners as black as coals
and their eyes replenysshed with blood He saw the other the which had the
vysages clear and clothed in white. And wha^ they had received the body of god
he saw light in some vysages / and in some flambe. And to the end yt he knew
of those of whom he herd the sklaunder he gave unto them their creator. And
he saw yt the one of the^ had the face clear and honorable / and was clothed
with white clothes. And the other had the face black and horrible. And after
yt they had received the light and the beauty of the one shone clear / and the
other brent as flambe. And the bishop prayed god yt he were ensygned of these
two here. And the angel came unto him the which told him yt the sklaunder
that he herd of ye men was true but the one was yet in sin and in will for to
sin and therefore you have seen him black / and enbrased with flambe: The other
was as you have herd / but for that / yt thou have seen his face shine is for
that he has recorded his sins yt he has done and has renounced unto those
operacyons with waylynges and teeres in requyringe the mercy of god / and in
promysy^ge yt he should not return unto his sins if they unto hy^ were
pardoned And therefore his sins ben effaced and put out / and is comen unto
such grace as you have seen. And as ye said bishop meruayled hy^ of the grace
of god for that / yt he had been so much foul and the man of tourmentes / and
with yt he had cored and besene him with so great honor. The angel
answered hy^. Well may thou marvel for thou art a man / and our lord is
natural god and mercy full. They the which cease of sins and ben penytentes
and truly confessed god the^ shall pardon and leave / not alonely the
tourmentes but he them makes dygne of honor. God has much loved the world
yt he has sent his sone to suffer death for the redemption of sinners yt will
repent. etc. This example denotes yt all they the which has been confessed at
Eester received not their creator in estate of grace / for they have not the
condycyons yt ben requysyte unto true confession. That is contrycyon of heart /
co^fessyon entyer and true / and satysfaccyon of work by doing penance / and
abstynence from sin. etc.

Peccatu^ sodomiticum.
A. Examples of the sin of sodomye. And first example of the lechery and
p^nycyon of those of Sodo^me and of Gommore. lxxxxv.
IT is written in ye.xix. chapter of Genesis that in an evening as Loath sat
in the market of ye cite of sodom he saw two young me^ coming / the which
were two aungelles. He arose and yede before them / he worshypped them and
prayed them for to go lodge in his house / and said to them. Ye shall wasshe
your fete and in the morning ye shall go your way. And for yt they ne would go
and wo^de abide Loath them coged and they yode he washed their fete and
apparayled them well to suppe. And before that they went to bed the men of
sodom came to demand of Loath the two men the which entered into his house
that they might know them lecherously and dyshonestly. The good man Loath would
not deliver them / and was angry because they would committee so great syn^e /
and said unto them. I pray you my bredren yt ye do not this sin here. I had
lever take you my two daughters vyrgyns than ye should committee this evil
sin with these two men the which ben entered under the shadow of mine
assurance. And the said sodomytes would not leave / but said to him Shall thou
be our Judge / we shall torment the more sooner than the men. Than they made
great force unto Loath and almoost had broken his gates. And they ^ut bette so
strongly yt they ne might find ye door. And the two aungelles said to Loath.
Have you here none of thy sons in law / ne sons / ne daughters / take with the
al thy friends from this cite. For we shall dystroye it for that yt their
clamor is before god yt which has sent us for to lose them. And Loath showed
this thing unto his friends the which nothing believed it. When the morning
cam^ ^he angel said unto Loath yt he should depart lest that he perysshed not
with the sy^ners. And for that yt he deferred they took hy^ by ye hand / and his
wife and his two daughters and led them out of the cite for that ye god had
spared them. And the angels said unto him. Save thy self and look not behy^de
the. The wife of Loath had mind upon her goods / and looked behind her / and
forthwt she was changed in to a salt stone. Wha^ Loath was gone forth god made
to rain fire and sulphre from heaven upon Sodom / go more / segor / bom / and
oleale. These ben the.v cytees that he lost / and dystroyed / and the
inhabitauntes the which were within them. etc For yt Loath was merciful god
suffered not yt he perysshed with the ill. And for that ye Loath loved better to
give his daughters than the two men is for the gretenes and horror of the
sin / for it is a sin yt cries vengeance unto god. Vnd gen^. xix. Clamor
sodomorum clamat ad me. And by that yt god them punysshed by fire and sulphre
yt is stynkynge is to understand the vylete of the sin wherein they lived.
The rain yt descended upon them was not water of grace and of nuriture / but
it was of fire and sulphre Whereof says the psalmist. Pluet pcto^res laqueos
ignis sulphre. Their lechery was anon past / but the tourmente is eternal.
Mome^taneu^ est quoth delectat: sed eternu^ quoth cruceat. Iterum psalm. Subito
defeceru^t and perie^u^t propter iniqitatem sua^. They be al perysshed for
their sin. etc.

B. Another example of ye slaughter that was made upon the sodomytes Beniamyn
for the lechery yt they committed in ye wy^e of Leuyte pilgrim. lxxxxv
IT is written in the.xix. chapter of the book of Iuges yt an ancient man of
the cite of Gabaa lift up his eyes in an euentyde / and saw a pilgrym with his
wife and his asses in the place of the cite. He axed him and knew yt he came
from Bedleem and that he ne had found any that would lodge him. Than ye
ancient desired him to lodge in his house and said unto him Pax tecu^ sit ego
preleo oi^a q^ necessaria sunt / tm^ queso me i^ platea maneas. That is to say.
Peace be with the I shall take the all thy necessytees. I pray yt alone ly that you
abide not in the street. He brought in the pilgrim / washed his fete /
applied unto his supper / and all that yt to him was necessary. And as they
took their refeccion ye sons of the cite chy^dren of the devil came cryenge to
the ancient yt he should deliver the man yt was entered in to his house for to
know him lecherously. And the ancient yode unto them and said. My bredren do
not this ill here / for I have lodged him / cease you of this folly I have a
daughter vyrgyn and he has a wife I shall bring them unto you to the end that
ye acco^plisshe your lechery. I pray you do not this syn^e against nature in
man. But for yt they ne would obey unto the ancient in no manner. The pilgrim
betoke them his wife the which abused and committed so strongly their lechery
all the night in the said woman yt in ye morning she came to deye at the door
where her husband was. When he found her deed he charged her upon his ass
and bare her in to his house / and afterward brake her body in.xii. pyeces and
bare them in to all the ends and parties of Israel and told unto them the
case and said that they should make Judgment and sentence. Than.xl. M. men on
foot of the children of Israel ass^mbled them and made recenser to understand
of Leuyte husbonde of the deed woman as ye deed was done And after yt he had
again recounted all ye people of Israel of one accord and will said yt they
should never enter in to their houses till the sinners were punysshed: They
constytued people for to bring them vytayles And sent messagers in to the cite
of Gabaa to ask them wherefore they had committed so great sin / and that
they should betake the^ those the which had committed the syn^e for to take
away the ill from Israel. Those of the cite would not / and made their
alyaunce for to defend them. But to be short great war was made for yt
sin. And they moved the^ in such manner yt great murdre was made on both
parties. But in conclusyon all the harlottes and all those the which sustained
in their quarrel were slain and degraded. In ye first battle there was.xxii.
thousand men. In ye second.xxv. M. and an hundred men. At the third when ye
town of the said harlottes sodomytes was taken there was.xviii. M. slain
and.v. M. of them the which fled. After that as they proceeded ferther they
slew two thousand / and brenned all the towns / streets / and houses of the
said sodomytes. Also they slew bestes and people the which were in them / and
by the will of god / as it is written in the.xix. and.xx. chapter of the said
book of Iuges. By this example men may se that great occysyons came for the
horrible and abhomynable sin that was committed in the said woman. And not al
only were punysshed those the which had committed the said syn^e but with
that all the consenters and alyes. and all that the which unto them apperteyned
was wasted. And so it appears yt great multitude of bodies / of goods / and
of souls yode unto perdycion for sin committed in a woman. etc.

C. Another example of a man ye used his wife sodomytly. lxxxxv
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary yt a man knew his wife sodomytly. And
much it displeased unto his wife. An^ on a time against her will he committed
in her the said sin. And incontinent after he arose from his bed for to go
in to the chambres in the which his guts fell from him and descended by ye
foundeme^t with great tourment. Than he took him to cry. The people came / and
of dolor that he felt showed his sin / and that god venged him / and he
stanke and myscheuously deyed etc. as reason was to commytte so horrible sin
in his own wife / and to soil the holy sacrament of marriage.

D. Another example how a sodomytike deyed impenytent and dyspeyred him / the
which said that he saw hell / ye torments and the deuyls. lxxxxv.
ALso the discyple recites in his promptuary yt a Sodomytyke was stryken of
god / and when he came to the death he was warned to repent him / to confess
and receive the sacraments of ye church. And in dyspayre he answered.
Wherefore shall I call on me the aid dyuyne I se now late ye tourmentes in hell
and the deuylles presents apparayled to rauysshe me. And as ye people present
bad him make the sign of the cross the myscheuous deyed in likewise as he had
given no force / and he turned his face / closed his eyes / and with a great
and horrible clamoure he yielded his ghost and deyed. etc.

E. Another example how a woman Sodomytyke was unburied and drawn horrybly.
lxxxxv.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that a woman culpable of the sin of
sodomye deyed and was buried. And the night following a sow right black with
seven black hogs were seen openly wrote and dyggynge the earth from her
pytte and brake membre after membre of the said woman / and drew the guts
alonge and brake them. When this was done the said sow and her pigs departed
them and kest great stynke.

F. Another example how ye deuyls have horror of yt sin. lxxxxv.
ALso it is written in the book of honey bees yt a woman sodomytike laid her in
her bed / and when she sinned in herself she herd the devil between her and
the wall the which cried fie / fie / fie. And when she herd the devil in such
wise cry she had fere / yode unto confession / did penance more than she had
charge. By these examples it appears yt the sin of lechery is a sin yt
much dyspleaseth unto god the which makes to have great punycion and
dampnacyon eternal. And therefore every person should wtdrawe to do the said
thing and obey to god for to get paradyse and escape punycyon eternal.

Octauum preceptum.
Testimonium.
A. Examples of falls witnesses. And first example of a christian man yt forsware
him cautelously on the awter of saint Nycholas. lxxxxvi.
IT is written in ye legende of saint Nycolas that a Jew lent money unto a
cryste^ man. When ye term came yt he should yield the money the christian man
said yt he had yield it unto hy^. And for yt the Jew ne might prove it he gave
it him upon his oath if he would swear upon the auter of saint Nycolas. Than
the christian man put the said money wtin his staff cloven and perced craftily.
And wha^ he was ready to swear he took his said staff unto the Jew whiles yt
he should swear. And so swear surely yt he had taken him ye said money. His
malice shall be dyscouered. For as he yode in to his house he slepte in the way
/ and a carte passed over him and slew him and brake the said staff whereby
the money and ye malice was known. The deed man was raised by the merit of
saint Nycholas / and the Jew converted him the which had his money. etc. A
man should understand here yt the christian man was perjured and that his
cautele excused not his sin. For god yt knows all took the thing after the
truth and not after the malice and cautele. Legitur math.x. Nichil occultu^
est quod no^ sciatur / neque absco^ditu^ quod no^ manifestetur. There is
nothing so hyd but yt it shall be known / ne nothy^ge hid but yt it shall be
showed. The sins hydeth them in time / and also appear in time. Vnde catho.
Te^poribus pcta^ latent et tpere parent

B. Another example how those the which kept the tomb of Ihesu christ took
money for to witness falls yt the dyscyples had stole his body by night. lxxxxvi
IT is written mathei vlti^o. yt wha^ Ihesu christ arose ye gardyens of ye tomb
had such fere yt they were as deed. Pre ti^ore au^teius exterriti su^t
custodes and fcti^ su^t. etc. And the maryes the which yode unto ye tomb
there found an angel yt had the face as lyghtnynge and his clothes white as
snow the which said unto them. Dread ye not I know that ye seek Ihesus
crucyfyed / he is not here / he is risen / go ye and tell it unto ye dyscyples.
When the maryes were parted some of the gardyens of the tomb yode in to the
cite of Iherusalem and denounced unto the princes of the prestes the things yt
which had been done / and how Ihesus was risen. And they assembled with the
ancients and took counceyle to give great some of money unto the knights the
which kept the tomb for to say and wytnes yt the dyscyples of Ihesus came by
night as they slept and stale from them his body. And if the presedent here
speak of it we shall persuade hy^ of this thing / and we shall do so much yt
ye shall be sure without harm. And ye knights took the money and wytnessed
falsely as they had been taught. And this thing was dyuulgued and is yet among
the Jews / whereby they ben without faith and believe not in Ihesus. And by the
said witnesses ye people is without believe and descend in to hell in
perdycyon. etc. And shall descend till unto the time of Antechryst yt they
shall know yt they have been deceived / and than they shall repent them and be
saved / in likewise as the scripture says. In diebus illis saluabitur judah /
and israel habitabit co^fidenter. etc. A man may than know clearly yt by falls
wytnessy^ge beforesayd innumerable people is gone and gooth to perdycyon and
dampnacyon. Also it happens sometime yt by falls wytnessynge of some a good man
leseth his heritage and his good cause / whereby dampnacyon. etc follows / not
all only to the false witnesses but also to those the which shall possede the
said heritage unjustly yt is not theyrs and know it well and it wtholde without
restoryng.

C. Another example of falls wytnessynge yt two auncyents made against Susanne
and ill came to them. lxxxxvi.
IT is written in the.xiii. chapter of the book of Danyell yt two ancient
prestes in ye time coueyted to commit lechery with the fair Susanne and watched
her and took her on a time al alone in her gardyn under ye foot of an apple tree
/ unto whom they said. Loathe doors of the gardyn ben shytte no person ne may
se us / wherefore consent you unto us yt we may have thy company / and if thou
wylt not we shall make falls wytnes against the yt a young man has had thy
company. Than Susanne wayled and was sorry and said Anguysshes ben to me on all
parts. If I do this that ye say death is unto my soul. Si eni^ hoc egero
mors michi est. And if I obey not unto you I shall not escape your hands that
is your falls wytnessynge and the death corporal. For in yt time ye women the
which commyted lechery were stoned and slain. And Susanne said. Better it is
to me without operacyon to fall in your hands than to syn^e before god. Than she
took her to cry for help. And also the said anncyentes cried against her. And
the servants ran unto the cry. After ye every of them had told their case
/ for to be short ye said Susanne was put in Justice / the which wept lokynge
to heaven and had her heart and her trust in god / the which leueth not his
servants. Than the auncye^ts put their hands on her heed and before all the
people showed yt they saw the said Susanne commyt ye said sin of lechery with
a young man yt was stronger than they and fled. The people believed yt the said
auncyentes said true for they were Iuges. So they co^dampned ye said Susanne
unto death. Than she cried unto god by a great voice and said. God eternal ye
know the things hid and all things before yt they ben made / you know
that they have borne falls witness against me ^ I deye. And so it is yt I have
nothy^ge done of the things that those here has composed malycyously against
me. And god exalted her orayson. For as men led her unto the death y^ holy
ghost spoke by ye mouth of a little child named Danyell and said with an hye
voice. I am clean of this blood. And the people him demanded who it was ye
which spoke. He answered and said to them. The foles of Israel the which has
Iuged and codampned Susanne unto ye death has not known veryte. Return
lightly unto Judgment / for they have spoken falls wytnessynge against her. Than
they returned hastily / and the said falls wytnessers were separate and
conuaynquisshed to have made falls wytnessyngr. For the one of them said yt he
had seen them committee the said sin under an holyn tree. And ye other said
under a plom^e tree. The people blyssed god ye which saves those yt trust in
him / and they took the two falls ancient prestes the which were Iuged unto
death and slain as reason was. For saint Ysydore says. Iudiciu^ quoth aliis
imponis spree portabis. Et pauius ad romanos.ii. In quo ei^ iudicas alteru^
teiprem conde^nas: eade^ eni^ agis q^ iudicas. The said Iuges had iuged Susanne
unto death for the sin of lechery. And for yt it was round that they were
culpables of ye said ^yn^e they also condemned theymselfe to bear and to have
such pain. And therefore of good right they were slain. Also our lord says
in the gospelles of saint mathewe.vii. and iuce. vi. Nolite iudicare scz
unjust and non iudicamini in quo ei^ iudicio iudicaueritis iudi bimini. Iteru^
in eode^ loco. Nolite condemnare scz unjust: and no^ comde^nabimini. That is
to understand. Ne Judge ye iniustly and ye shall not be Iuged. Certainly ye
shall be Iuged in ye Judgment that ye have Iuged And will ye not to condemn
other and ye shall not be condemned. For ye shall be co^dampned of yt
condempnacyon yt ye conde^pne other as y Iuges were. This example denotes yt
the two auncyents were harlottes / falls wytnessers / falls Iuges / and
homycydes. And the blyssed Susanne was chaste / clean / and good / the which
loved better to be dyffamed and slain than to commit lechery and to dysobey
unto god. In likewise should honest women do / and they shall have praise and
reward eternal in paradyse. Susanne was never so much shamed as she is loved
/ praised / and rewarded of the said deed. etc.

Periurium.
A. Examples of people perjured. And first example of three persons the which
perjured them for to impose falls crimes against a patryarke lxxxxvii.
IT is written in thy story ecclesyastycall that in Iherusalem there was a
patryarke right Just and good. And some of his subgectes hated him for yt he
held good justice. And three persons imposed on him falls crime yt they
affermed with oath. And the first said. If it be not so I perysshe by fire For
they were not believed for the excelle^ce of the patryarkes life. And ye second
said I be hurt and seek of a sekenes / scz morbo regio. The third said. I
lose the eyes. And all hapened as they had required for their periury^ge and
lyenge. The first falls wytnes was brent with all his house / progeny / and meyny /
and his goods. The second was consumed of the said sekenes from head to fete.
The third when he herd what was become unto his felawes dredde and showed
all. and wept so much yt he lost his eyes. etc. By this example is denoted yt
the three men beforesayd were detractours and ill spekers to take away the good
renown of the patryarke. Also they were perjured / liars / and falls witnesses
/ and therefore of good right god sent unto them such pain as they had
required / but the punycyon infernal is yet more to dread for it is eternal.
etc.

B. Another example of a man the which perjured him / and he might not draw
back his hand. lxxxxvii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a man perjured him on the sepulcher of
saint Pancrace / and forthwt he ne might draw his hand back. And so appeared
his malice and lyenge before all / and so was co^fused. And as it is said / he
yt lyfteth his hand or that touches the gospel or the holy things and
periureth him the said hand apperteyneth unto the devil till yt he be repented.

C. Another example of a man yt would for were hy^ for borrowed money. lxxxxvii
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple yt a cytezyn lend unto his
neighbor a qua^tyte of money. And when the term came to pay the borower
denied the debt. And for hat he was cyted again in Judgment he denied it and
would swear. And as he bowed the kne he lost speech and might nothing say.
After he was redressed and the speech came to him. Secondly he would swear in
denye^ge it / and as he kneled again he lost the speech / and so it was known
to all that he would pariure hy^. and before god he was pariured as it is written
in ye decrete. Paratus iurare falsu^ ia^ pariurus est.xxii. q. v.

D. Another example of two men ye which pariured them / and the one was lepre
and the other seek of ye fire of saint Anthony. lxxxxvii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says yt an usurer repented in his death and
prayed his fre^des to restore the money yt he had taken of them. And the first
promised and said Else be I stryken with the fire of saint Anthony. The second
promised and prayed / else be I a lepre. They were neclygent to restore after
his death / and would win some thing or they restored and forthwt they were
seek as they had prayed. This example denotes yt a man should hold promise
and restore to other / or punycyon shall follow. And it is to note yt semblably
as ye prayers of the good ben exalted to their honor and praise of god: so
wha^ ill me^ defayle of their promise on pain of punycyon god exalts their
requests to their co^fusyon.

E. Another example of a king and many of his people yt pariured them and
deyed suddenly. lxxxxvii.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that a king of France named Troatarius was
acursed for a sin / and he yode to the pope with many lords and excused him
with oath that he was not culpable. And the pope assoyled them all and them
admynystred by condycyon yt if they had sworn falls and unworthily accede unto
the eucaristie yt they should deye wtin the year. And unto them there came of
vengeance dyuyne. For the said king and the nobles and the part takers in
retournynge from the court of the pope deyed of sudden death wretchedly.

F. Another example of Maryners the which forsware them for dread to give
alms to a poor man. lxxxxvii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary that a poor man demanded alms of
maryners. And yt master of them made an oath that they had not in their ship
but stones / and that he should cease to demand of them. Than the poor man
said. And sith yt ye swear all etynge things be stones. And even forthwith all
yt was to be eaten in the said ship was changed in color and form of
stones / these things abiding as they were before. The said maryner was a
liar / perjured / and evil speaking wout mercy / and therefore the prayer of ye
poor man was herd so that yt the which was to be eaten became stones. etc.

G. Another example of him yt constrained a man to swear and knew well that he
should forswere him. lxxxxvii.
IT is written in the sermons of ye dysciple yt a man made to cite in Judgment
another for money le^de the which he denied. And the lender him constrained
and made him to swear / howbeit that he was certay-yt he should forswere hy^.
And in ye night folowy^ge ye said lender was rauisshed by vysyon in the
Judgment of god / and there saw Ihesu christ yt sat in his syege of mageste yt
which him demanded the reason of the soul of him that he had made to
forswere of his propre soul. The which were both twain to condemn to
perdycyon. And the Judge him demanded wherefore he had received the oath sith yt
he knew well that he should be forsworn. And he said / for he denied me my
thing. And the Judge said Had it not ben better unto the to have lost that
thing than thy soul and his. Than the Judge made to beat him. And he awoke and
recounted and showed his wounds and brusy^ges in his body the which ne might
heel till that he was repentaunt of the deed with confession and penance. This
example denotes yt a man should love the salvation of his neighbor as of
himself. Diliges proximu^ tuu^ sicut teiprem. And that a man should sooner
let to lose any thing temporal tha^ to constrayne any to swear / when he is
certain that he should forswere him and shall be dampened. etc.

H. Another example of a chorle the which gave unto the devil that yt he had
to eat as two clerks him demanded ye alms. lxxxxvii.
MEn find in writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuarye and says that an hermyte dwelled at the foot of a mountain. And
before his wyndowe in a corner the deuyls held their syege and chaptre and
devised of their works / and of the ruynes of persons. And the master devil
asked of a devil if he had brought any thing to ere. And he answered / ye / yt
is of wheet / of breed / of butter / and of meele / and that a chorle had given
hy^. And yt he it brought unto wytnes against his corswery^ge. For as two poor
clerks demanded him asmesse / he swear by the holy charity of god yt he had
nothing to ete yt he might give. And as they again demanded he said. I give
al to ye devil yt I have to ete. And I have brought yt he has given me in the
reprefe of his periurynge. When the deuylles were gone the hermyte made to cast
the said meet in a dyche yt no person should taste it. This example denotes
yt ye said churl was without mercy / he was pariured and a liar / and that the
devil forgeteth not the things ill done and spoken. Also it is danger to give
any thing to the devil / ye gift is soon preferred / but it is not soon
forgoten and effaced.

Mendacium.
A. Examples of lyenge. It is to be noted yt all falls witnesses and pariurers
be liars How saint Iherome made a lie before god the which commanded yt he
were beten / and after the said Iherome did penance. lxxxxviii.
IT is written in ye legende of saint Iherome yt the begynny^ge whereby the said
Iherome studied holy scryptures and took strayte and parfyte life was yt in his
young aege he was seek of a fever and came to the death / his soul was
rauysshed in Judgment before ye chair of the Judge. And in yt place there he
had so much light and clerete of them ye which were present yt he was cast
unto ye earth and durst not look upward in heyght. And he was asked of what
condycyon he was. He answered I am crystyen. And he ye which preceded said to
him. Thou lie / thou art cyceronyen and not cristyen. He held his peace. And
ye said Judge commanded that he were beten. And as they bet him he cried.
Miserere mei dn^e miserere mei. That is to say. Lord have mercy on me. And
those yt which sat with the said Judge yode on knees before him and prayde hy^
yt he would pardon his youth / and that he would give him place of penance
unto his herrour. In yt time he studied the book of Tulye and of Platon / the
books seculers and fables hy^ pleased. And he would not study the books of
prophets And he began to swear and to say to our lord Sir if ever I read
seculer books I shall renye the. And was left in his word by his oath and he
reuyued suddenly. And he found the traces of his betinges yt he had between
his sholdres tyght horrybly. And after he read and estudied the books dyuyne /
he did penance / wept right bytterly / and made so many books yt he is one
of the four doctors of the church. This example denotes that all lyenge or
lesynges ben to flee. for god it sees and knows. Also it denotes that the
clerks should study science dyuyne and not worldly science deceptyble and
those of fables. etc. For such science is folly anenst god this says
scripture. Vnde sapientia huius mundi stulticia est apud deum. Also the amyte
of this world is the enmye of god and those the which it studyeth. Vn^
jacob.iiii. ca. Amicitia huius mundi mimica est deo. Et quicu^que voluerit
amicus esse huius seculuminicus dei constituitur. And for that saint Iherome
was culpable he was reproved of lyenge and beten.

Detractio.
B. Examples of detraccyon. And tyrue example of some relygyous the which made
detraccion of their brother the which deyed. lxxxxviii.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that one of the relygyous of the monastery
of saint Gregory deyed by the sekenes of brennynge ague / and as he was in the
last pange to yield up his spyryte some monks the which were there presents
left to say ye psalmody for to speak and make detraccyon of him. After he
reuyued and said to ye monks. Bredren god pardon you of that yt ye have made
of me detraccyon. Ye have engendered me lettynge / not a little but much great.
For I have been accused as well of you as of the devil all in one time yt I
newyst unto what sklaunder first to answer If ye see any in time to come yt
deyeth make no detraccyon of him / but have ye him in compassyon / for he gooth
in Judgment where he shall have much to a^swere of his accusatours. etc.

C. Another example of a detractour damned for his detraccyons. lxxxxviii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt there was two clerks felawes / whereof the
one was detractour and a liar so ill yt he ne spoke well of no person. As he
came unto the death he was warned of his said felawe to confess him and
amend. The which did not and conte^pned his said admonycyon. And when he
approached the death he promised his felawe if yt it pleased god to appear to
him wtin.xx. days / and so he departed and dyed. And soon after on a day by
the suffrau^ce of god to give example to other he appeared to his felawe black
all enbrased with fire within and without. And wha^ his felawe saw him he defayled
for feere yt he had / unto whom he said. I am the cursed thy felawe for whom
thou prayest vaynely / for I am dampened perpetually. And he axed how it was with
him at the death. He answered. As I was in ye last pange I was brought before
the Judge / and as I held my peace for dread I saw many souls clerer than ye
son the which stretched their hands out against me unto the Judge and cried
Lord venge our blood on this liar detractour the which has us dyffamed by
lesynges before the men. At this voice the Judge beheld me with vysage wroth /
and in beholdy^ge him I was all ferefull and confused of the ylles that men
spoke against me in seeing that I was culpable I forgate my self and dyspayred
me of the mercy of god and was Iuged and am dampened eternally. By this example
a man should understand that detraccyon is a great sin / for ye good
persons detracted demanded vengeance and punycyon and it was done. With
great pain is that sin pardoned / for it behooves to restore the good
renown as after shall be declared. Et ideo hieronimus. Non facilis venia praua
dixisse deiectis ho^mibus To much speech noyeth. For there ensues punycyon
and dampnacyon.

D. Another example of a detractoure yt had his tongue among todes. lxxxxviii.
MEn find by writing this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that there was a man a right great detractour of relygyous
/ clerks / and of other good men he departed and deyed. And after in great
time as a man dug in his sepulcher men found all his body in earth and dust
/ but his venomous tongue was hole among todes the which remoeued it and
would gnawe it but they ne might / in showing yt the tongue was not worthy to
return in to earth for that yt it had hurt many a man / and yt the cursed man
that owed the said tongue was tourmented in soul and after the Judgment shall
be in body and in soul eternally without to be consumed. Vn^ apoc^. ix.
Desiderabunt mori et mors fugiet ab eis.

E. Another example of a detractour yt bote and wasted his tongue. lxxxxviii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his pro^ptuary that a priest was so aba^doned in vice
of the tongue that almoost he made detraccyon of all and infamed grievously other
men. When it came before his death he was furyous / and in his furour bote
himself / brake and wasted his cursed tongue venymous in showing before all
that his tongue had spoken cursed words dygne of punycyon and pain.

F. Another example of a fader yt slept as he herd detraccyon. lxxxxviii.
IT is written in the life of faders of a good ancient fader named machetem the
which was much solytary / unto whom god gave such grace that as often times
as he was in convent with the other bredren for to here the service and collacyon
espyrytuall he never slepte and if he had been there the long day and the
night. But as soon as any spoke word of detraccion / or idle word he was
forthwt aslepe. Unto thexample of this good fader a man should keep hy^ from
slepynge in ye service and predycacyons / and from herynge of evil words.

G. Another example yt as a knight made detraccyon of a deed man he appeared
unto him. lxxxxviii.
IT is written in the legende of ye deed be dies yt as a knight was laid in his
bed by his wife he made detraccyon of another knight deed. The which appeared
to him suddenly and said. Friend pardon me and cease too make detraccyon for I
am in great pains in purgatory. And he him demanded / may a man help ye. He
answered / ye. And he demanded him / wylt thou yt such a priest or such pray
for the. Than he shoke the heed in token yt it pleased him not / for that yt he
was in mortal sin. Afterward he demanded if he would yt such an hermyte
prayed for him. He answered I would well / if he prayed for me lightly I should
be delivered. These examples denotes yt a man should cease hy^ of detraccyo^ /
for it is a vice yt dyspleaseth unto god and unto the saints of paradise. And
in that yt the deed body desired the prayer of ye her myte and not of the other
is to understand yt ye prayer of good folk is exalted and not they of
sinners. But the holy sacrament of the mass enpayreth not for an ill priest.

Loqui.
A. Examples of some the which has vttred cursed words. And first example of
a man letygyous full of strife and dyscorde the which said at his death yt all
those that he had troubled them opposed against him and enforced to sle him.
lxxxxix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book yt Guilliam says yt there was a man so
letygyous full of strife and furyous that from his young aege he ne might live
in rest with his own kynnesmen but dyscorded with all them in his house and
without the which was grievously seek and in ye death bed he took the
sacraments of the church unworthily. And hastily among ye people the which
were present he cried horrybly. Arise ye al and take armoures and keep me for
all them the which I have troubled oppose them against me and enforce them to
sle me. And without taryenge his eyes turned terrybly / and in cryenge
myscheuously he deyed. This example denotes yt the just men and saints of
paradyse arise in Judgment against the sinners the which them has troubled
and that has brought forth cursed words against god and taken away their
goods. Whereof it is written sapientie.v. Stabunt iusti cu^ magna co^stancia
aduersus eos qui se angustiaueru^t / et qi abs^uler^t labores eorum. And by
this a man should keep him from speaking ill of another and to do him ill. For
none ill shall bide wout punysshement.

B. Of a woman full of wrath yt myssayed her maiden. lxxxxix.
IT is written in the promptuarye of the dyscyple and in other books yt there
was a lady yt often times herd the predycacyons / but she was so impacient yt
when she came fro the church she stryued with her maiden that was good and
devout. This said lady wrothed her for nothing and without cause / and
myssayed her said maiden. The which maiden on a time required her lady that
she might go to here the predycacyon that a relygyous well renowned should
make. And she answered by courage wroth and hearty. Abide at home and keep the
house. ^he was obedient and tarried. And as she ^as in the kechyn with great
affection to her^ the word of god she made a request unto our lord in saying.
My lord Ihesu christ teache me to do thy will. And forthwt Ihesu christ appeared
unto her in saying. What coueytest thou. And she answered to here the word of
god. And Ihesus began to preche unto her and said. Keep three things that I
shall tell the and you shalt be saved. Hold thy peace in maledyccyons / be you
pacyent in trybulacyons and aduersytees / ne yield thou evil for evil / but do
good unto those that shall do the evil. She answered I shall do it with a good
will / and incontinent Ihesus departed. And wha^ her maystresse came again
from the church she missayed her. And the said maiden held her peace and gave
her no word to a^swere. And the maystresse was moeued with Ire and bette her.
And the maiden said to her self / in trybulacyons thou sholdest be pacyent.
The lady said. What is that / that thou spekest. She answered. I have kept
better ye sermon yt the man made me this day than ye ne do many where ye have been this year / for ye be not amended. Than ye said maiden showed unto her
maystresse how Ihesu christ had preched unto her and that she would keep his
word all his life. When the lady had herd the said words she thought unto
her self of the case and was afterward pacyent. etc. By this example is much
to be noted in regard to do three things the which god told unto the
maiden. And it behooves to understand that she was so good that she unto him
suffysed to do the said things / for god sees and knows all. Also it is a
great thing of pacyence / and to here the word of god / And to se good
example by the good life of the maiden the maystresse correcked her self and
became humble and pacyent toward echone.

Another example the dyscyple recyteth in his sermons that there was a vyrgyn
so much chaste devout / a gyuer of alms / and charytable that meruaylous
it was to wete / but impacyente she was in things that came unto her. And the
angel appeared unto her and said. Thou labourest much lawfully and do of
good works and operacyons for to possede the Joys eternelles / but thou ne
may be saved for thyn impacyence and thou labourest for naught. And she
required the said angel that he would pray for her yt god would give unto
her patience / and he prayed for her Afterward she corrected herself / and
was so pacyent yt all men meruaylled and well she fined her days. etc.

C. Another example of him the which said unto his servant pull of my hose
devil / and forthwith the devil vnhosed hy^ in his house. lxxxxix
IT is written in the dialogue of saint Gregorye that a man named steue^ weary of
walking came in to his house / and in his we called his servant and said unto
him come devil and vnhose me. And forthwithin haste at that voice the points
began to vnknytte and undo to the end that appertly he appeared as the devil the
which was called was ready to draw of his hoses and that he obeyed him. And in
contynent that the said Steven saw yt he had hugely fere and took him to cry
and to say. Depart thou acursed fro me. It is not unto yt that I spoke it is
unto my servant. And forthwith at the said voice he ceased. And therefore a man
should not call the devil in Ire / for he is not far of he is by the for to
tempte the / for to deceive the / for to counsayll the ylle ^^^d for to draw
the back to do or goo^ d^d^s. Also if thou call him by Ire ^ sin and
cursednes / he is ready and appar^yll^d for to serve the as he vnhosed y said
Steven and incontinent that he sees that a man repents him he draws him
back as he did when Steven had fere and said unto him that it was not he to
whom he spoke and that it was unto his servant. After the examples and
wrytynges that men find it is great danger to speak often of ye devil / or
to call him / or to put in him his faith / his hope and his love / or to give
himself unto him / or to make alyaunce and covenant with him and to byl^ue in
his effects. For in so doing men renounce unto god and unto baptysme that man
h^the received in saying. Abrenuntio sathane et omnibus pompis eius. Also a
man is private from paradyse / from the company of god and from his saints /
and from all things celestyelles and spyrytuelles / and draws to the man
with the devil and with the dampened of maledyccyon and perdycyon. And man
byndeth himself unto pain and punycyon eternell. etc.

D. Another example of a man the which said unto his wife go thou in the
deuylles name. lxxxxix
IT is written in the dialogue cesar^ that a man full of wrath say^ unto his
wife in his Ire / go^ thou in the deuylles name. And forthwith the ^^u^l entered
in to her and tormented her greuou^ly / of the which thing the man was much
wroth / and promised that he sh^^^e never curse / ne his wife ne person / nor
other creature what so ever they were. etc

E. Another example of the woman the which put dyuysyon in a good marriage
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons that a man and his wife lived
togyders.xxx. years in peace without that that the devil might put between them
hate ne dyscorde one only time. And when ye devil saw that he might nothing
do he came unto an old woman unto whom he promised a pair of new shoes so
yt she could find the mean to put dyscord between the said man and his wife.
And she promised to do it. Than she came unto the man unto whom she said that
his wife loved more another man than him And that she should slay him if he
provided not wisely in his case. And the said man ne would believe it. The old
woman yode unto his wife unto whom she said. Thy husband loves another woman
better than the. And when souper time came they beheld other with indygnacyon
Than both tweyne put faith unto the words of the old woman. And the other
day the said old woman gave cou^sayll unto the said wife that she should take
ye great knyfe of her husband and that she should were it in holy water and
after put it under her husbands bedheed and that he should love her as he did
before / so yt he slepte upon it. And afterward ye said old woman yode unto
the husband / unto whom she said that he should wake by night and that he
should take heed unto his case or else his wife should kill him By this token
yt he should find his knyfe under his beds head. And he byleued ye said old
woman / found his knyfe under his beddeshede / and stroke it in his own wife.
Than ye devil put a pair of shoes at the end of a staff / and took them
unto ye said old woman as he had promised her Unto whom he said. I dare not
approach unto the of dread that thou ne deceive me as you have done ye man and
the wife. Such people ben wors than the devil and unto them apperteyneth more
great punycyon. For where the devil ne had power to put dyuysyon and to
trouble the said marriage. The old woman it wrought and more strong was the
homycyde of the said woman. And therefore a man should here note that the said
old woman and her semblables the which in such wise put diuysyon where there
is good love demand penance a man ne should deny it them but a man should
give unto them plain punycyon and penance without any mercy. For it is a
sin the which is again the sin of ye holy ghost. Inuidentia fraterne
dilectionis the which has not of remyssyon as unto the pain ne in this
world ne in the other. Also if such people will go in to paradyse before yt
they there enter it behooves that they have true contrycyon / confession / and
full punycyon for by satysfaccyon by penance in this world / or in purgatory
/ and if they deye without correccyon and amendment they shall have in hell
punycyon and dampnacyon eternell without any mercy.

F. Another example of the woman the which had the party upward brent in the
church after her death for her cursed tongue. lxxxxix
IT is written in ye.iiii. book of ye dialogue of saint Gregorye / how that a
no^ne was chaste in ye law parties / but she had cursed language / when she
was deed she was buried in ye cathedral chirch And in that night the gardyen of
the church saw by vysyon yt she was taken up and borne before the great
altar and cut by the myddell and that the one party was burnt and the other
was not. When the morny^ge came he told the said thing unto his brederne / the
which yode before the said altar in the church / and found the appearance of
the brennynge in the stones as if the said woman there had be burnt corporelly.

G. Another example of an advocate yt which lost his tongue in his death for
he had habounded in ill langages. lxxxxix.
MEn find by writing in the book cesarii this yt which follows how the
disciple recyteth in his promptuarye. And says yt when an advocate was deed /
men ne found of tongue in his mouth. And of good right he lost his tongue in
his dyeng. For in his life he sold it many times in defending causes unjust
and in calling them in wyttyngly by favors and by gifts that he took
unjustly / in like wise as recompteth cesarius. By this example it is to be
noted that a should wtdrawe him from ill speaking. For when a person
haboundeth wyllyngly in his life in cursed languages / in his death he leseth
his speech / and he ne may confess hy^ to cry god mercy and to dispose of
such things as he should do. Also in the membre wherein a person has most
offended / in the same membre shall he suffer the most of torment. That is to
understand if an advocate be dampened for his cursed tongue / he shall feel the
mo of torments in his said tongue than in other members Vn^ ber. In quo au^t
me^bro magis creator offe^ditur: in eo grauius pcto^r torquetur. The cursed
dyues habounded in cursed langages in dyenge. And therefore signantly the
gospel says that he playneth him that his tongue was burnt more sooner than
another membre. And also saint (...) makes mencyon in the appocalypse o^^
dampened tormented for cursed word^s / Et dicit illud apo. xvi Co^manducaueru^t
linguas suas pre dolor: et blasphamaru^t deum pre doloribus suis. etc.

H. Another example how the angels ben present when a man speaks of good
words / and when ill words ben spoken the deuylles ben ready. lxxxxix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in the book of his sermons that a rich man badde one
time many of his parents and neighbors unto dynere with him. The which he
put at one table / and in a second table he set and put many poores. and one
of those poores the which was a holy man saw that they said benedicite / and
as they ete the first two loves / the aungelles were among them the which
enuyronned and beset about at the said dinner / they spoke of god and of all
good words. And afterward they began to speak of worldly things and vycyous
and of detraccyons. And incontinent the said holy man saw that the deuylles
were present by them / and the au^gelles fled fer of and gave place unto the
deuylles the which lepte and enjoyed them and beset them about. Than the
said holy man began to weep bytterly. And after in the end of the dinner they
took them to speak of god and of good manners salutaryes and the said au^gelles
came again right joyous and the deuylles fled. And when the said man devout
saw this thing he began to laugh gretely. And after that graces were said the
said man devout was asked ye questyon wherefore he had wept and afterward
laughed. Than he told them the cause in admonestyng them yt in etynge and
drynky^ge they should speak of god / for god and his au^gelles there ben
present. And unto the contrary ye deuylles ben present in detraccyons and
cursed words. Unto this purpose it is written math. xviii. Vbicu^que fuerint
duo vel tres congregati in noi^e meo / ibi ego su^ in medio eoru^. etc. That is
to say when two or three men ben assembled in ye name of god in spekyng of him /
god is in the medyll of them. etc.

Audire.
I. Example for those the which here cursed words. And how the sister of
saint damyen was tormented for that that she had taken pleasure to here the
song of daunces. lxxxxix
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says / that ye sister of saint damyen
appeared unto him after her death. Unto ye which damyen she said that she was
in great pains in purgatory. And the said Damyen demanded her ye cause. She
answered yt it was for that / yt she being ones in her chamber herd ye song
of those the which daunced. And she therein took pleasure and dylectacyon of
the which dylectacyon she ne did penance in this world / and for that
cause she should be punysshed.xv. days in purgatory. By this example a man
should understand yt it is great danger unto the soul as to here vaynwordes
or ill sith that ye said woman had such punycyon. Vn^ sapiens. ec. ix. Cu^
saltatrice ne assiduus sis nec audias illa^: ne morte pereas and efficatia
eius. etc.

K. Another example how two merchants said unto their curate that they could
nothing sell without oaths and lesynges.
IT is written in the dyalogue cesarii how two merchants of coloyne confessed
them unto their curate yt almoost they ne might sell nothing without lyenge /
swerynge and pariurye / and the priest said unto them. Use ye of my counsayll
and ye shall do the better. Keep you from swerynge and leyenge in selling this
year / and ye shall se how it shall be with you. They promised him and did so
/ And the devil let so the byars that in all the year they sold as
nothing. And afterward said to their curate when they came again unto him
that the obedyence had been unto them right do^mageous / for that yt they had
nothing sold. And the said priest them co^fermed in the faith / and said unto
them Persevere ye in such manner that for none aduersyte ne pouerte ne swear ye
/ nor lie and god shall bliss you. And so they promised to do it. And
incontynente god appesed their temptacion and sold more than all the other /
and in short time they were much rich. etc. This example denotes that the
deuylles ben wroth when any wtdrawe them fro sin as to swear. It is here to
be understand yt by that yt the devil lets the merchants to sell / if
any be ferme in the faith for to resyst well / ye devil is vaynquysshed and he
departs as he did when the said merchants byleued their curate / and swear
not: ne lie more for pouerte the which unto them may come. In like wise should
these merchants withdraw them from swerynge and well shall come unto them /
both temporelly and spyrytuelly.

L. Another example how a bishop was tormented in purgatory for that yt he
had herd detraccyons of his clerk.
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons that a bishop was borne in to purgatory
to do penance / and he was gretely tormented of the stynche of his clerk
bey^ge in hell the which mounted till unto him for that yt he herd sometime
his detraccyons / and had not him enough egrely corrected / how be it that of
other things the said bishop had be good. This example denotes that punycyon
follows unto them the which hereth with good will detraccyons and ill
words. Quia age^tes and co^se^tie^tes pari pena punientur. etc

M. Another example that ill came unto king Roboam ye which gave answer
proud unto the children of Israhel / and byleued ye folysshe cou^sayll of
young men.
IT is written in the.xii. chapter of the third book of ky^ges that after the
death of king salamon the people of Israhell came unto Roboam the sone of the
said Salamon for to constytute him king. And the said people made unto hy^ a
request in saying. Thy fader us has gretely kept under and given us great
charges / now dymynysshe us a little of ye said charges and we shall serve the.
Than the said Roboam said unto them that on the third day he should give them
answer / And first he counsaylled with the a^^cyentes and wise counsayllers of
salamon / yt which said unto him. If thou obey at this day unto the people /
and that thou accord unto their petycyon / and that thou speak sweet words
unto them they shall serve the in all times. Afterward the said Roboam
counsayled him with young men the which had be nourysshed with him / the which
counsaylled him that he should say unto the people. My little finger is more
great than ye back of my fader / my fader has bet them with staves / and I
shall put to above that and shall flayle you with scorpyons. Than when the
third day came he left the cou^sayll of the auncyentes and wise / and gave
unto the people a proud answer of young men folysshe cou^sayllers. And for
this proud answer the people of ye two lygnees of Israhell was moved in ire /
and made another king named Hierobam. And of the said people of Israhell ne
abode with Roboam but the people of the lygnee of judah and of benjamin and
war was between the said Roboam and Hierobam in all their lives. Also it
appears as for to believe the false counsayll of young men the which were
proud / ye said Roboam was not lord of his people and had war all his life.
etc.

N. Another example of an earl replenysshed with many sins that ye devil
bare away. lxxxxix.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuary yt in a solempnyte as the abbot of
Clugny and many other were in the palace of an earl / a man not known on
horsbacke entered suddenly in to ye palace before them all / the which
commanded ye said earl that he should rise up and follow him for he had to
speak with him. The earl ne would resyste rose him up and yode unto the door of
the palace / where at he found an horse ready for to lepe on / then the earl
lepte upon his back / and he that was come took the rain of the brydell and
lift hy^ up in to the air before them all and bare him away. And the said
earl cried myserably. Succurrite ciues succurrite. He byleued in the cytezyns
of the town yt they should socoure him / but they ne might for anon he was
run out of their sight / and borne away of deuylles in body and soul / and
was no more afterward seen ne found. If the deuylles lift him in to the air
it was for to make him fall allow and for to punysshe him in hell for his
sins.

O. Another example of a woman impacyent yt the devil bare away. lxxxxix.
IT is written in the dialogue cesarii of a woman impacyent in her ire / as she
was troubled put her fete in a bacy^ and afterward lepte out bakwarde / and
said I lepe in such wise from the puyssaunce of god in to the puyssaunce of
the devil / and incontinent the devil took her and bare her away through the
air in ye sight of many the which were present and never after was she seen.
etc.

P. Another example of a man the which condampned himself unto the devil for

THe dysciple recites in his sermons that an archedeken and his dyspencer
^^^oue as they yode unto rome for the dyspence of the goods of fortune. And ye

that iourneye as he past the water. the devil drowned hy^. And wtin a little
time after his death he appeared unto a chanoyne his friend unto whom he told
all the case before said / and that he was in great pains and torments for
his impacyence / and also for that yt he was commanded unto ye devil.

Q. Another example of a clerk impacyent yt wrathed hy^ again god. lxxxxix.
THe disciple recites in his sermons that a clerk was four year seek. and in
his sekenes was impacyente / and said unto god. Thou have taken my body and I
shall take the soul and shall give it unto the devil. And in his impacyence
said Devil take my soul. And it was done forthwith by ye dyuyne Judgment of
god

cogitatio mala
A. Examples of ill thoughts / and first how a woman a great gyuer of
alms was dampened for ye delyberacyon of will to commit lecherye. C.
IT is written in the some of penance yt a woman devout and a gyuer of alms
confessed her often unto the bishop of ye cite / and therefore he loved her
much because of her holiness. It happened one day she beheld a young man by
concupyscence carnal and by reason dysposed and fyxed had the will to have his
company without other thing / but by many times that she confessed her / and
also in the death she had it in remembrance / she had shame to tell it and
excused her unto herself saying. Since that I have not done ye deed that it
was nothing / and that she would not speak it. And so she deyed without
confession and contrycyon. After her death ye said bishop made her honorably
to be buried in his chapel where of custom he made his prayers / for asmoch
as she was of great people. And that he loved her for the holiness of her. And
in the night after that she was buried before matyns ye said bishop wend to
make his oraysons in ye said chapel. And as he approached it seemed unto him that
it was full of fire / in likewise as a brennynge oven. Albeit he put his trust
in god and approached and saw upon the tomb of yt woman a gyrdyron of fire and
a body stretched above it and all full of fire and the deuylles with instruments
of iron the which embraced the fire in tornynge her from one side to another.
And when the said bishop saw that it was ye said woman coniured her and her
demanded wherefore she was dampened. And she answered and said yt it was for the
thought of lechery that she had not confessed her of. etc By this example a man
should understand yt god dampneth and punyssheth the persons for the ill
thoughts. And by more great reason for the ill operacyons.

B. Another example how a woman desired a clerk to use of her embracements
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says yt a woman cast her eyes
on a clerk unto whom she said if thou wylt consent to use of mine
em^racementes all my goods shall be thine. by many times he refused her / and
she yode to accuse hy^ before the Iuges of oppressyon done unto her. Than the
judge made him to be put in prison / and the said woman was so prycked with
lecherye yt she mounted upon a wall with a laddre and let herself fall where
the said yongman was and desired him to committee lecherye / the which ne did
it. And the iuges herd tell that ye said woman was in the said prison made the
clerk to go out and wend yt he had be an enchauntour and full of malices /
they made to alyght a great fire / wherein he was cast. And as he brende and
that the sides were than dyscouered and that men might se his lyghtes he cried
aue maria so hye that all herd him. Than one of ye cosynes of ye woman
fastened a staff in his mouth and said unto him. I shall take fro the thy
oraysons / and him strangled in such wise and stopped his brethe. And the
bones were buried in the field / ye wiche did many miracles. And over his tomb
a fair church was made. And by this example a man may understand yt the
said young man was chaste and good the which loved better to be in prison /
dyffamed burnt and to dye a martyr than to break the co^mau^demente of god by
co^myttynge lecherye. / Also it is to be noted yt the said harlot sinned
mortally / and brake the commandment of god. Also she was homycyde of his
death dygne of punycyon and dampnacyon And the yongman gate praise / paradyse
and Joy eternell / ^ so should we do / and the woman deserved shame and
punycyon. etc.

C. Another example how a noble woman brake this commandment when she desired
and required her porter to committee lecherye ^ albeit that she did nothing /
for he would not consent. C.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary that a noble woman as she was a^one
upon a day in the castle where she dwelled was suddenly enflambed with
lecherye that she ne might bear the fire of love. And she dyscended down unto
the porter of the castle and prayed him by great instaunce that he would meddle
with her / unto whom he answered. Madame what is that yt thou spekest / where is
thy wit / behold god and take heed unto thin honor / but of al these
things she forced her nothing. And when she saw herself in such wise
repulsed of the said porter / by inspyracyon of god she issued forth of the
castle and ran unto the water froson under the castle / and therein kept
her so long that all the flambe and embracement of lecherye was quenched / and
afterward came unto the said porter and yielded him thanks and praysynges that
he had in such wise repulsed her and said unto him If you would give me a
thousand mark of gold I ne should suffer now that thing whereof I prayed
the not long ago. and she returned in to her place. The said porter is to be
loved before god and the world / For by his resystence ye lady corrected her
and resysted and loved him after more than if he had committed the sy^ne. This
here is example for to gaynsaye those the which pray to do ylle. Also for to
hold him in coldness for to resyst again ye embrasyng of lecherye as did the
said lady within ye said water. etc.

D. Another example of a friar ye which delyted him in the thought of
fornycacyon without resystyng unto it. And therefore his angel was sorye / and
the orayson of the holy fader was not exalted. C.
IT is written in the life of faders yt as a friar was tempted of the spyryte of
fornycacyon he yode unto a great ancient fader unto whom he said. Fader show
me thy charity and pray for me For I am tempted and solycyted of fornycacyon.
And the said ancient fader prayed for him. And secondly again that friar came
unto the said ancient and repeted ye said words. And the au^cyent ne
dyspraysed him but prayed god for him and said My lord god reuele me of this
thing of fornicacion the which is in this friar / for I have prayed unto the
/ and he ne has of rest ne of aid again the spyryte of fornicacyon. And god
reveled that thing the which was again that brother. And the auncyente saw
ye brother the which was set and the said spyryte by him that played with him
/ and the angel the which was sent unto his aid was there / the which had
indygnacyon against ye said friar / for he ne enclyned him toward god / but
more sooner delyted him in his thoughts / and enclyned all his thought. And by
yt the au^cyent knew that the cause proceeded of ye said friar yt his orayson
was not exalted. And he showed it unto him saying / thou consentest the in thy
