thought. etc. Also he taught him to resyste against those thoughts / and was
delivered thrughe ye doctrine of the said ancient.

E. Another example of a man the which ne resysted again his sy^nes and for yt
an of an hermyte was not herd. C.
IT is written in the life of faders yt a man the which left the world for to
serve god in hermytage was devout and proved a good hermit. And when one
seculer his compaygnon herd the renown of him yode to vysyte him. And bare
unto him bread in a sack. And required him that he would pray for him to
absteyne him from his sins. The which hermyte him promised / but he prayed
hy^ that after.xv. days he would return unto him. And when he was come again
at the said term / the hermyte demanded him if his sy^ne pleased unto him yet
as before. He answered that he was wors than before time. And the said hermyte
prayed him yt he would yet return at ye end of.xv. days / and within the
term the said hermyte put him in great oraysons and afflyccyons more than
before for the said man. And when he returned and yt he told him that he was
yet wors ye said hermyte understood yt for his neclygence and for yt that his
sin pleased unto him without resystynge unto the contrary that his orayson was
not exalted. Than the said hermyte took ye said sack wherein he had brought the
bread / and filled it with grauel and afterward prayed him that he would put
the sack upon his sholders / and that he would bear it. And as he wend to do
it the hermyte drew unto the contrary. And he apperceyued that the hermyte
drew unto the contrary unto him. Than he said unto him I may not lift up the
burden for that that thou drawest it again me / And the hermyte said unto him
/ rise up now and I shall aid the. And when they lift both twain of one
accord they lift it up right easily. Than the hermyte said. In like manner I
ne may aid the to take the away from sin. For thou resystest again me.
Thou have thy desire agreeable and thou resystest not again it. But put thy aid
to resyst again thy sin / and god and I shall help the / For if thou help
not thyselfe we can not aid the nor save the. etc. This example denotes that
ye sinners the which will be saved should do yt that is in them for to take
them from syn and for to resyste again it. For for nothing sets him the
good man in ye arse of his carte all myree if his beestes ne draw hy^ That is
to say thou shall not be saved by another / if thou put not pain of thyselfe

A. Another example of a monk unto whom god sent every day of good bread and
fair / and after that he had of thoughts foul and lecherous / and of elacion
he lost the said bread. C. i.
IT is written in the life of ye faders that there was a monk aourned with so
much of contynence / good operacyons and of virtues that god would send unto
him some remuneracyon in this world. And when he was in oraysons and hymns /
god made to be borne unto him of bread upon his table fulfilled with meruaylous
swetnes / and whytenes / of the which he took his refeccyo^. And after yielded
graces unto god of his bounte / and returned in oraysons and in hymns. This
monk had many reuelacyons of god / and many admonycyons of things to come.
And as he was in such things he began to gloryfye hymself^ of his merytes.
And in contynent neclygence and slouthe entered in to his heart so that he was
slouthefull for to go in orayson as he was acustomed And his soul was weary in
such wise as of to great labor / and would rest him / his thoughts
rauysshed him by diverse things. And one foul and vile thought entered in to
his heart albeit after the oraysons he yode as he had be of custom and found
of bread and took his refeccyon / but he ne cared not to amend his ill
thoughts / and apperceyued not the dommages of his mutacyon. And in that day
he was prycked gretely and embraced by thoughts lecherous and of foul
concupyscence that he rauysed him to return in to the world. And he kept
him that day to return. And as he had be of custom made his oraysons / and
afterward yode to take his refeccyon and found of bread but more soylled and
foul than he had had of custom / than he meruaylled him and was sorry. And he
understood that the lyknes of ye monstre that he had thought beheld him Albeit
he took his refeccyon. Afterward the third day foul thoughts prycked him /
and was in his thought in such wise as with a woman present and lyenge
together. And him thought that he embraced her / and that he was couched for to
commit the operacyon unclean. Albeit he proceeded the day following / and he
yode in orayson / but he had the eyes wandrynge / and the thought chetyue. When
the euentyde came he yode to take his refeccyon / found of bread but soylled
and dry. and in like wise as gnawen with rattes and dogs. Than when he saw
it he took hy^ to wayll and to weep / not as he should do with heart for to
quench the flambe of such lechetye / albeit he ete of the bread / but not so
much as he would / ne so much as he had acustomed. And afterward as the
thoughts prycked him they drew ye che^^^e unto the world departed by night
And after yt he was much weary of walking / would rest him / and found there
dwelling some freres. The which when they saw him / ran before him and
received him in like wise as an angel / washed his fete / linuiterent /
exorted them to go unto orayson set the table and accomplysshed the offices of
charity. After that he had his refeccion and that he was a little rested the
freres demanded him some word of edyfycacyon so as of a great wise fader and
instruct and asked him how any might escape the bands and temptacyons of the
devil / or if there came unto them the thought of foul temptacyons / how they
should call them again. Than he was compulsed to teache them of ye said
temptacyons and thoughts he them instruct and taught suffycyently. And
understood in himself the said temptacyons / and reknowleged his defaute and
said. how I teache the other and am deceived myself / or how shall I correcke
the other and a mende not myself / acursed first do thou that that thou
techest unto other. When he had reknowleged in his heart his fault said adieu
unto the freres and ran hastily in to his de^ne from whens he was departed
and said. If god ne had aided me I had be descended in to hell. By the aid of
god and of the freres the which has made me to reknowlege I am come^ again.
And he abode in his place all his life in wepynges and in wayllynges to do
penance and lost the bread celestyall / and labored ye time of his life for
to have his sustentacion. This example denotes many things. The first that
god gives unto his servants reward / grace / and glory in asmoche as he
sent of bread unto the monk. The second is yt by sin a man leseth the said
reward and the grace of god and all goods. For he lost ye bread. The third
is to instruct other a man saves himself as deed the said monk the which
reknowleged his fault and corrected hy^ by that yt he taught ye said freres and
by penance he saved himself. etc.

B. Another example how a friar ye which was tempted in his thought of the
esperyte of fornycacyon and god suffered that he saw it in a foul woman. C.i.
IT is written in the life of ye faders that a holy man had nourysshed a man
child in a forest. The which when he was grown he was tormented with ye
spyryte of fornycacyon. And would go in to the world for cause of lechery. and
when the holy fader saw that he was wroth and by two years retained him by
fair words in comfortynge hy^. In the end he said that he was prycked that he
ne might no more bear it. And the holy man said unto him. Goo than in to the
world and mary the thou may be saved. Than the young man waxed Joyous / but
ye holy man said unto him I demand the one thing of grace the which is that
thou go first unto a fou^tayn in such a forest / and that you fast there forty
days in requyrynge the aid of god yt thou may chese a good woman For it is
a great cure whereof speaks the wise. eccle. xxviii. Multeris bone beatus vir.
More over the said holy man bad hy^ take of bread as much as he would / than
he was obedyent. And when he had fasted.xx. days as he was in orayson he
felt great stenche. The which as it creased by two hours with great pain
might he bear it. And there came unto him a right foul woman / black / vile /
loathsome / sty^kynge blered / full of scabbes / from whom the said stynche
proceeded / and she came unto the said young man / unto whom she said. Where
art thou my friend / by great time I have sought the. I love ye much. I
appetyte the above all men. And ye said yongman demanded her. What will you
right foul stynkynge intolerable / and she said I would have the to lie with
me Than the said yongman spytte in her face and said be it never so that I have
such a love so loathsome foul and stynkynge. And the said yongman demanded
her / what art thou / from whens come thou / and how do men call the / and
she answered. I am the sin of lecherye. And it is now two years that I ne
cessed to seche the / and it was when thou feltyst first the temptacyons of the
flesh. And ye said yongman said. If I had wist yt the sin of lechery had
be so stynkynge and so much abhomynable I should not have wylled to return in
to the world. And from now forth I shall keep unto god vyrgynyte. And he
returned unto the holy man / unto whom he recompted ye said vysyon. And he
said unto him / if thou had abyden unto forty days / mo great things had
be reveled unto the. And the said yongman served unto god in vyrginyte and
dwelled in relygion. etc. If sorts of people lecherous should consider well
this example / and how lecherye is stynkynge / vile / and abhomynable before
god and the ylle the which thereof proceeds in the end of ye days / they
should correct them as did the said young man. etc.

C. Another example of a young man ye devil walked with because of his thoughts
that were ill. C.i.
MEn find by writing here how that he dyscyple recyteth in his sermons and
says that one time a man had of ill thoughts in walking / and forthwith
the devil assocyate himself with him in semblaunce of a man and yode with him. And
as they yode togyders the said man dred / entered in to a church that they
found he repented him and yode to confession / for it was lent. And when he
yode forth of the church he found the devil at the yate / the which beheld
those that came forth of whom he demanded his compaygnon. And he said loo I
am here the which came hither with the / goo we our way. And the devil
answered him thou art not my fellow that came with me The devil knew him not
for that / that he had confessed him and that god had pardoned him. And by
that confession effaceth the sins and separeth from ye devil. Also ill
thoughts ben to dread / for ye devil is not far of. etc.

D. Another example how it behooves to yield account at ye day of Judgment of
ill thoughts. Ci.
IT is written in the epystyll of a bishop named Cirulius how saint Iherome
areysed a deed man / ye which told that when his soul was separate from the
body it was borne before god in judgment. Also soon as a man may shytte ye
eye / and that all the sins that he had done / spoken / and thought in all
his life appeared clearly unto the Judge and before all / as if they had be
present so that there abode not the most little thought / but that it appeared
clearly in like wise as it had be thought. etc.

Cogitatio bona.
A. Examples of thoughts / and first example that a friar won seven crowns
a night in resystyng again ill thoughts and temptacyons the which came unto
him. Cii
IT is written in the life of the faders that an au^cyent fader had a dyscyple
proved. And this said fader had of custom in ye euentyde to teache his said
dyscyple / and after to give unto him his benedyccyon / and than suffered him to
sleep and it befell one day that some relygyous came unto the said ancient /
and after that he had recom^orted them and instruct they departed. After he
came in the euentyde to teache his said dyscyple as he had accustomed to do. And
for as much as he was weary he slepte. And the said dyscyple sustained and
would not sleep ne leave his said master till that he had had his benedyccyon
and leave of him and that he was waked. And the devil tempted him in his
thought by seven times that he should depart and that he should go to sleep /
but he resysted virtuously unto the said thoughts / and never remeued. And at
mydnyght the ancient awoke and found his said discyple by him / unto whom he
said Sone haste not thou departed till unto this hour. And he answered no /
for thou have not given me leave. And the ancient said / wherefore haste thou
not waked me He answered. I had dread to dystourbe ye The said ancient rose
him up / said matynes and instruct his dyscyple / and afterward gave unto him
leave for to sleep / and as the said ancient satte him alone he was as in a
trance. And he saw an angel the which showed unto him a glorious place and
a syege in yt place / and upon the said syege seven crowns. And ye said
ancient asked him ye which showed unto him that thing in demanding unto
whom the said syege was and ye crowns. He answered unto thy discyple / he
has deserved to have the place and ye syege for the good conuersacyon of him
/ and he has deserved to have the seven crowns in this night. And the said
ancient had meruayll / called his dyscyple and demanded him what he had done
the said night. He answered that he had nothing done. And the ancient wend
that by humylyte he ne would confess unto him / and said unto him. I shall not
be content with the if thou tell me not what thou have done or thought this
night. And ye said dyscyple doubted and thought that he should answer / and
for that that the auncyente had commanded him to tell. He answered I have
done none other thing but that I have thought seven times and was much
impugned in my thought that I should go my way and that I should sleep before
that thou had give me leave / but for that that thou had not give me leave I
yode not but sustained and resysted till that thou were waked and yt thou
had given me thy benedyccyon. When ye said ancient herd these words he
understood that at all the times that he resysted in his thought as many times
he deserved to have crown of god. And therefore a man should resyst unto all
ill thoughts for to have vyctorye again the devil / and for to have reward
in paradyse. etc.

B. Another example how that a relygyous apostate the which repented him it
appears that the will of a body is reputed for the deed. Cii
IT is written in libro cesarii yt s^ynt bernarde had a monk the which left
the habyte of his order by the admonycyon of the devil and took to govern a
parysshe. And engendered a sone and a daughter on a concubyne. Than it befell yt
after that he had dwelled there many years his abbot past by the parysshe
wherein the said monk enhabyted / and came to lodge in his house without that
yt he knew any thing and without knowing him Albeit the monk knew him well
and received him also proprely as his own fader / and unto him he admynystred
and unto his compaygnons and unto their marys all haboundauntly in their
necessytes. Erly in the morning when saint bernarde had said matyns he was
prepared to goo his way. And had not spoken unto the monk for that that he
was gone right erly unto ye church. He said unto ye priests sone. Go and bear
such message unto thy master / and that child was dombe from his natyuyte
the which was obeyssaunte at his commandment and apperceyued in the virtue
of the co^maunder ran unto his fader and brought absolutely the words of
saint bernard and said. The fader abbot commands the such things and
such. When the fader herd the first voice of Joy took him to weep and
secondly and thyrdly made him to repete the words. And inquired dylygently
that yt the abbot had done / unto whom he said / he has done none other
thing to me but yt he said unto me. Go and tell unto thy fader these words.
Than the priest was co^tryte of so great and euydent miracle / and came
hastily unto the holy man and fell prostrate at his fete in weeping and said
unto him. My lord fader I was your relygyous in such wise am I named and I
departed at such a time. Than I pray your good faderheed that I may goo
again with you unto the monastery for god has vysyte mine heart in your
coming unto whom saint bernarde answered and said. Abide me here. And when I
have done my besynesses I shall come anon this way / and I shall led the
with me. And the said monk dredde ye death / the which he had not dredde
before / and said. My lord I dread to deye in the space of this time. And he
him answered. / Know thou for certain that if thou dye in such condycyon and
purpose thou shalt be found to be monk before god. And so he departed. When
yt abbot came he found him deed and newly buried. Than he commanded that men
should open his sepulcre. And those the which present were demanded what he
would do. He answered I will se if he lie in the sepulcre as monk / or as
clerk. They answered we have buried him as a clerk in habyte seculer. Than
the earth was taken away and ye monument open wherein he had be buried. And he
appeared before al in tonsure of monk. And god was magnified of them all the
which reputed and took the will for the deed. etc.

C. Another example how a thief came unto an hermyte in good will to amend him
/ the which hermyte dysdeyned him wherefore evil came unto him. C.ii.
THe dysciple recites in his sermons that a thief was much sorrowful of his
sins and had good will to amend him the which prayed an hermyte that he
would receive him in to his felyshyp / for he purposed never to commit tho
synes and to serve god evermore. And ye hermyte ne would receive him / and
dyspraysed hy^ in his heart and let him go without consolacion. And as the
thief would have made him an hermytage a tree yt he hewed fell upon him and
slew him. And in such wise he deyed in great contrycyon of heart. Than the
said hermyte saw that angels came and bare the thief in to heaven / and was
sorry and said. Wherefore make I my dwelling here in this hermytage. This man
has be a cursed thief / and for his good will he is now mounted in to heaven.
And I have be here so long and I ne may enter. And in that co^mocyon said. I
go in to the world and I shall be a thief / and in the end I shall be saved /
and as he excercysed him to commit theftes he was pursued of the people of the
cite. and in fleing he fell and slew himself and the deuilles came the
which took the soul and bare it in to hell. etc. This example denotes that
by the contrycyon and good will that the said thief had he was saved. Also it
is written ezechielis. xviii. / Inquacu^que die ingemuerit peccator oi^m
iniquitatum eius non recordabor. And ye said hermyte was dampened by that that
he changed his life from good in to ylle Vnde ezechielis. xxxiii. Iustitia
iusti non liberabit eum i^ quacu^que die peccauerit. etc

Eucharistia.
D. Examples of the eucharistie. And first example of an abbot ye which said
that the hostye consecrate was not the very body of our blessed lord Ihesu
christ / but that it was his figure. Cii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt an abbot was great in life actyue / the
which perseuered in great labors / but he was simple in the faith. For he
erred and said that it was not naturelly the body of our lord Ihesu christ
the hostye consecrate in the mass yt we receive / but said yt it was his
figure. And when two auncyentes herd tell that he spoke such words
considering his life and conuersacyon how symply and ygnorantly he spoke the
said word / they came unto him and said. Abbot we have herd tell that an
infydele has said that the bread consecrate in the mass that we receive is
not naturelly ye body of Ihesu christ / but that it is his figure. And he said
it is I ye said it And the said auncyentes gave unto him ensygnementes and
techynges that he said not well. And he said unto them that if he ne might
know manyfestly the said thing that he would nothing believe / and the said
auncyentes said. Pray we unto god this weke and we believe that he will reuele
it unto us. The said abbot was co^tente / and all three yode in to their houses
/ and put them in orayson. And when the said weke was acco^plysshed / these
abouesayd came in to the church on the sunday the which put them in a place
apperynge as in the pulpyt from the which they se al ye secrets of the
priest. And ye eyes of their vnderstondynges were open. And when the loves
consecrates were put upon the altar they saw in like wise as three children
lyenge on the altar. And when the priest put forth his hand for to break the
said bread consecrate the angel of our lord and redemptour dyscended from
heaven upon ye said altar ye which had in his hand a knyfe and cut that
child and ye blood ran in to the chalyce. And when the priest brake the
bread consecrate in little parties. In like wise the angel cut the members of
ye child in little parties And the said abbot approached for to receive the
holy co^munyon. It was given unto him seule in form of flesh soylled with
blood. And when he saw it he dredde and took him for to say and to cry. I
believe my lord that ye bread the which is consecrate on the altar that it is
thy body. And ye wine the which is consecrate in clalyce / that it is thy
blood. And forthwith ye flesh that was in his hand was changed into the
lykenes of bread after ye mystere / and after the said abbot received his
creatoure / and yielded unto him graces and was confermed in the law. By this
example a man should understand that after that ye words sacramentalles ben
pronounced that the hostye is no more bread / and that it is the precious body
of Ihesu christ he ye which is borne of the vyrgyn marye / and the which
has suffered death on ye cross for to redeem us. Before the consecracion the
hostye is bread. And after the consecracyon the said bread is transmuted unto
ye precious body of Ihesu christ. And note well here that thou ne sholdest
worship ye hostye ne join the hands for to do it honor till that the words
sacramentales ben pronounced / that is till that the priest lift up the hostye.
For that should be ydolatrye to worship the bread the which is one of the
creatures of god / and to give unto it the dyuyne honor the which
apperteyneth alonely unto god. Incontynente that the priest has consecrate he
lyfteth up the hostye / and than thou it sholdest worship and believe steadfastly
that it is the precious body of Ihesu christ naturelly not a lonely his figure
as byleued the abbot. It is written ioh. vi. Ego su^ panis viuis qi de celo
desce^di. Si quis ma^ducauerit ex hoc pane viuet i^eternu^. That is to say. I
am the bread of life the which am dyscended from heaven / who so eteth of this
bread / yt is to understand in the estate of grace and that he persevere in
such wise till unto ye death he shall live in perdurabylyte. And that chapter
iohannis.vi. is written. Caro mea vere est cibus et sanguis meus vere est potus.
That is to say certainly my flesh is the viande and nourysshynge of the
soul. And my blood is the drink by the which she is replete* Also we read.
ioh ii. capit. yt god changed the water in to wine at a wedding. He has
also puyssau^ce to change the bread in to his body / and ye wine in to his
blood after that it is his will. When the priest pronounces ye words that he
has instytute ye which ben written in the euangelystes. Hoc est eni^ corpus
meum. Hic est eni^ calix sagui^s mei. etc A man should not abasshe him if ye
hostie change his nature and that it be transmuted unto the precious body of
Ihesu crist We read more strongly. Moses the which was man mortal changed
many times his rod in to a serpent before pharaon. And when he would the
serpent became a rod. Also we read that moses made great haboundaunce of
water to issue out of a roche for to give unto the people of Israhell the
which murmured. also the waters of the children of Israhell were so bitter
that beestes ne people ne might drink it. And at the commandment of moyse ye
which put his rod with in the waters they became sweet and changed their
natures Also we read yt an axe ye which was without hafte and fell in to deep
see came again unto the hafte and swa^me again nature at the voice and at the
commandment of ye prophet helyseus the which held the said haft of wodde.
The iron of his nature is heavy. And albeit at the commandment of a mortal
man it swa^me upward on the water. Since that it is so yt mortal men ye which
ben ye creatures of god has done the said things it follows well that god
the which is ye creator of all things may change ye bread in to his
precious body. It is more great thing to create than to change. Also
notwithstondynge yt there ne is but one god / so is he entyer^y in all the
hostyes with out dymynucion. verbi gratia. When any man speaks his voice is
hard and enters in every of the auditors. Also when the priest brings
forth the words of god it enters and extends in to all the hostyes and ben
consecrate / and god is entyerly in every of them without any dymynucyon. Also
if all the men of the world held every of them a glass in their hand when
the sone shyneth every man should se the sone in his glass / and it ne is but
one son. Also it ne is but one god the which is verytably in all the hostyes
consecrate. Sithe yt the hostye is the very body of Ihesu christ the sone of god
celestyall and borne of ye vyrgyn marye a man should receive him honorably and
holyly / and him behooves to purge his conscience of sin. Vnde paulus.
Expurgate vetus fermentu^ vt sitis noua co^spersio. That is to say. Take away
ye old leuayne / that is sin to the end that ye be newely spryncled. Et
legitur ad romanos.xiiii. Abiiciamus opera tenebraru^ and induamur arma lucis.
Put we out ye operacyons of derkenesses tho ben of sins And put we out the
arms of light tho ben of virtues and charity. etc. Men put not of wine in a
foul vessel to the end yt it be not lost / ne of roses / ne of fair flowers
in the trough before the hogs to the end that they ne be soylled ne wasted.
also a man ne should put the precious body of Ihesu christ in a body fulfilled
with sins. etc. vnde mathei.vii. Neque mittatis margaritas ante porcos ne forte
co^culce^t eas pedibus suis. Ite^ in code^ capitulo. No lite setm^ dare
canibus. When a lord temporell comes to lodge in thy house / thou make it
clean / prepayrest it and take away all immu^dicites and things fylthy and
unclean. In like wise sholdest thou do when thou will receive thy creatoure.
/ For if thou receive him in mortal sin unworthily that is unto thy
dampnacion Thou receyuest him the which shall judge the and condemn the. Vnde
pauius. i co xi. ca. Qui eni^ ma^ducat and bibit i^digne iuditiu^ sibi ma^ducat
et bibit. sequitur. Reus erit corporis and sa^guinis dn^i. And therefore prove
well thy conscience to know if it be well made clean by confession before that
thou receive thy creatoure. Vn^. i. ad co. v. Probat au^t seipsu^ homo: and sic
de pane illo edat: et de calice bibat. The good and ye ylle receive him / but
dyfferently. For the good receives him unto their salvation And the ill unto
their dampnacyon. Sumu^t boni sumu^t mali sort tame^ inequali vite vel
i^teritus. Example yt judas ye which received his creator in mortal sin And
incontinent yt he had received him ye devil entered in to his body. And he had
more great puyssaunce in him than before. Vn^. ioha^nis. xiii. Cu^ jesus
inti^xisset pane^ dedit jude and post bucella^ tu^c introiuit i^ illu^
sathanas. etc. And incontinent judas rose him up and yode unto the Jews for to
take and deliver our lord the which was great maledyccyon for him. Vn^ luce.
xxii. Te homini illi per que^ filius hominis tradetur Our lord said unto his
dyscyples. I have ch^se you twelve and one of you is a devil Vnde ioh. vi. Ego
vos duodeci^ elegi: et vnus ex vobis diabolus est. That was judas that our
lord called the devil / he was his dysciple. And for his couetyse to have. xxx
pence he was perverted he was traitor thief / fayntyf and betoke and delivered
his own master in the hands of his enmyes the which was innocent and just
for to put him unto death. And therefore in the end and conclusyon all
maladyccyon / da^nacyon / and perdycyon / came upon the said judas. Vnde
mathei. xxvi. Melius esset illisi natus no^ fuisset homo ille. Quia dixit. Quid
vultis michi dare et ego eum vobis trada^. Et legitur mathei. xvii. Peccaui
tradens sa^guine^ iustu^. Sequitur. Proiectis arge^teis in te^plo recessit and
abieno laque se suspe^dit. It had be better unto him that he had never be borne
/ for he hanged him self / his entraylles fell out of his belly / and is
dampened. legitur actuum. i. De judah qui suspensus crepuit medius and diffusa
su^t oi^a viscera eius. By his sin he slew himself as it is said / and was
deposed of his prelature of his office and sent into hell in to ye place yt he
had deserved to have. And another had his said prelature. And in likewise shall
it be done of the ylle the which follow his life / his manners and condycions
Legitur in actibus apostoloru^. Fiat habitatio eius desserta and episcopatu^
eius accipiet alter. Et david i^ psalm. Fia^t dies eius pauci et episcopatu^
eius accipiat alter. etc.

F. Another example of a woman ye which took her to laughe as saint Gregorye
admynystred unto her on Ester day. Cii
IT is written in the legende of saint Gregorye / yt on an ester day as the said
saint Gregorye admynystred ye people / when he came unto a woman and that he
said / corpus dn^i nostri jesus christi. etc. she began to laughe. When saint
gregory saw ye said thing he withdrewe his hand and put the hostye on the
altar. And after that the other were admynystred he called the said woman and
demanded her wherefore she had laughed. She answered I laughe for yt that thou
have said yt this little portion of bread that thou would give me that it is
the body of Ihesu christ / Than the holy man made a sermon unto the people /
and warned them to go in orayson and to pray that it would please unto god to
show the truth of this thing and for to take away the error from ye said
woman. And when ye orayson was accomplysshed saint gregorye yode unto the
altar and the said hostye appeared vysybly before all to be corporell in
flesh. and the party of the little finger was blody / Than saint gregorye
said unto the woman. From now forth believe thou truly the words of god. Panis
que^ ego dabo raro mea est pro mundi vita. That is for to say. The bread that
I shall give unto the it is my flesh for the life and redemcyon of the
world. After that at the prayer of the said saint and people the hostie came
again in symylytude of bread / and the said woman was confermed / and byleued
in the sacrament. etc. God will yt ye hostye appear unto us in lykenes of bread
for two causes. The first is to have retrybucyon to believe yt that we se not.
The second because it should be unto us cruelte to ete uncouth mete / as raw
flesh. and therefore we should believe without doubt in the consecrate hostye.
etc.

G. Another example of a cursed priest yt received ye hostye wrongfully. Cii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that as a seculer priest
sange one time mass / another stondynge by saw in the patent in the time to
receive not ye lykenes of bread / but of a child / the which when ye priest
would have received him he turned his face and resysted with his fete and his
hands yt he should not enter in to the mouth of the said priest. And this
devout man saw this thing not alonely one time but many. Unto whom the
cursed priest one time among other said. All times when I take the body of
Ihesu christ I take it with so great dyffyculte that I meruayll thereof. And ye
devout man said unto hy^ I cou^sayll the that thou correct the / and I have
seen that of the. Than the priest corrected him. And as he song afterward the
said devout man saw the child the which joined the hands / assembled the
fete and entered in to the mouth of ye priest hastily and easily etc. By this
example a man may understand yt god dwells not ne yet will dwell by grace
with ye sinners in the sin / but will dwell and enhabite with the good the
which ben in ye estate of grace. And therefore every man should correct
himself and amend. etc.

H. Another example of a child of.ix. years the which was admynystred at his
death. Cii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says that as a young child seek
replenysshed with the holy ghost required that the body of Ihesu christ should
be brought unto him. And as his friends refrayned it he cried strongly. Give me
the body of our lord / give me the body of our lord. When this thing was
spoken unto the priest he answered. That it was no sure thing to give ye body
of Ihesu crist unto such a child the which knew not what it was. And the
priest took an hosty vnsacred and bare it unto him and said. Here is the body
of our lord. And god inspyred the child for to dystroye the falsnes and
infydelyte of many the which use them ill. And answered. Wherefore will thou
deceive me this is not the body of our lord that ye offer me. Than the priest
was meruaylled of this thing and ymagyned yt this child was enspyred dyuynely
/ yode to fetch unto him the holy co^munyon / and that child received it
enough devoutly.

I. Another example how that a horse / an ox / and an ass knew Ihesu christ
with in the sacrament and did him honor. Cii
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple yt a devout bishop and an
herytyke strove togyders of the veryte of the body of Ihesu christ. And for to
prove this thing they put of otes in a vessel and put the eucharystye upon ye
otes by cautell. And afterward led theder a horse an ox and an ass the
which ne touched unto the prouende / but bowed the knees and worshypped our
lord. In likewise as if they had used of reason. When the said heretyke had
seen that he converted him and after was faithful / unto purpose of this
example it is written ysaie.i. Cognouit bos possessore^ suu^: and asinus presepe
dn^i sui: israhell au^t me no^ cognouit et populus meus no^ intellexit. That is
to say. The ox has kowen his possessour. And the ass the crache of his
master. Certainly Israhell has not known me / and my people has not
understand me. That is to understood that the beestes irreasonables known
their master. And the men reasonables ne know their god lord and master. etc.

K. Another example of the horse of a Jew the which knew Ihesucryst in ye
sacrament of the eucarystye. Cii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye that as a good priest bare the body
of Ihesu crist for to admynystre unto a seek body he met a Jew upon a fair
horse / and the said horse bowed ye knees before ye body of Ihesu christ. And ye
jew ne might make him to pass for the strykynge with the sporres till that
the body of Ihesucryst was paste. And a voice from heaven was hard. Know thy
creatoure yt thou denyest to be borne of ye vyrgyn marye. And when the Jew
saw that he repented him byleued in Ihesu christ and received baptysme. Also
you infydele when thou see these examples here thou sholdest believe steadfastly
in ye holy sacrament to worship it and to convert ye unto god as did the
Jew. etc.

L. Another example of a woman the which put the body of Ihesu christ before
the hogs. Cii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book and says that in the time that alberte
reigned in his bysshopryche a woman came unto him to confess that the devil ne
would suffer yt she should believe in the sacrament of the altar yt it was the
body of Ihesu crist: and put it before hogs For all the hogs bowed ye knees
and worshypped the sacrament. And ye cursed woman would se the experyence and
put the body of Ihesu christ upon the broche and roast it afterward with fire as
roste. And afterward ye drops of blood began to drop / This thing done she
was not yet content She took the body of Ihesu christ and buried it in the earth
/ and much of blood issued above the pit / in like wise as in boyllynge out
of the earth. At this thing ye said woman repented her and byleued the very
body of Ihesu crist to be in the sacrament of the altar and confessed this
thing unto the said bishop and her sy^ne / and received perpetual penance
of him. This example should withdraw al unfaithful from error / and should
worship their creator / or they shall be wors than hogs the which yode on
knees. Be ye not so incredule and without believe as was the said woman the
which would nothing believe till that she had seen the experyence of the
deed. etc.

T. Another example of a maiden the which shed ye body of Ihesu crist upon
the cabysshe and cole wortes. Cii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that it happened in the isle
of saint James that a maiden seculer was posseded of ye devil. And a pressed
demanded of the devil the which was in her wherefore he tormented her so
cruelly and so longly the said woman. He answered by the mouth of the maiden /
she had well deserved it. And ye priest demanded him wherefore. He answered for
that that she has laid the right hye god on the cabysshe herbs. And because
that he understood not this thing and that the devil ne would expound it to
him. He demanded of the woman if she had understand that yt the devil had
spoken yt she would expound it to him / and incontinent she confessed her
sin and said. When I was young. I entered in to a little gardyn to gadre
cabysshe herbs that ye little worms ete. And I loged a woman tourmented on
night unto whom I expounded ye do^mage of my gardyn yt these little worms ete
my cabysshe herbs. She answered that she should teache me a good medecyne. Take
the body of Ihesu crist and afterward break it in little parties and shed them
upon the cabysshe herbs / and incontinent they shall cease them. And I
myscheuous has had more curyosyte of my little court and gardyn than of ye
sacrament and byleued the woman. And when ester came I drew ye body of Ihesus
from my mouth / and did as I had be taught. And the said thing that I did
made me to be put in torment in like wise as witnesses the devil. etc. A man
may here under stand that ye said old woman gave cursed counsayll the which
a man should fle And the young woman was infydele and right ill to do the said
cou^sayll. And therefore she had deserved to have punycyon and torment / and so
done all unfaithful people And therefore they should dread punycyon and
dampnacyon eternell. etc.

N. Another example yt the oxen knew Ihesu christ in the sacrament in ye field.
THe dysciple recites in his sermons how thieves brake a church and took the
shryne the which is called custodye and ye body of Ihesu christ and yode their
way And when they ne found but relyques with in it and the body of Ihesu christ
they gave no force / and left it in their neighbors field. When the morning
came the labourer with his oxen came to labor his land. And when the oxen
came nere unto ye said cheste or pyxe / as all abashed houed still in such
manner that for pryckynge ne for strykynge ne would they go no ferther so much
yt the labourer wrathed him again them and said the devil was in his oxen.
He ne saw clear for it was right erly. and auysed the box or pyxe before ye
fete of his oxen. Than he understood the cause of his rebellyon / left all in
the field / yode unto his town to tell the case unto the priest and unto
other. They came unto the said field with the cross / encenser / and tapres
and brought again the body of Ihesu christ. etc. Thou infydele if thou ne do
honor unto thy savior the which is in ye sacrament thou art wors than the
oxen / and beestes dombe the which ne would go no ferther for betynge ne
otherwise agay^ their creatoure.

O. Another example how ye honey bees made unto Ihesu christ a chapel and an
altar in doing him honor. Cii
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says that as a woman nourysshed
many bees that deyed and prouffyted nothing / she sought of remedy / and it
was told her that if she put by them ye body of Ihesu christ that they should
prouffyte without death. Than she yode unto the church and feigned that she
would be admynystred / took the body of Ihesu christ bare it and put it in a
hyue of bees. Understand the great meruayl and puyssaunce of god. The bees
knew their creatoure / the which made him a right fair chapel about him of
the swetnes of wax and honey that they gadred. And in that chapel made an
altar of the self matere and ^ut above it ye holy body of Ihesu christ. God
blyssed their operacyons. And at ye time when the said woman opened the hyue /
and that she had seen so fair enoratorye she had shame / ran unto the priest
and confessed unto him all that yt she had done and seen. Than the priest took
the parysshynge with him came unto the vessel / ye bees flewe away and in
lauding their creator keste a cry. They found a fair little chapel made
of the matere made with the bees the which was of great artyfyce and craft. For
it had of fair little walls and covering / wyndowe / door / alter They
meruaylled them and bare it with the body of Ihesu christ unto their church
with great loving and praysynge. etc. if the said bees did honor unto their
creator / so sholdest thou do or thou sholdest be more insensyble than they.
etc.

P. Another example of ye sone of a Jew the which was preserved from
brennynge / for that that he had received the body of god. Cii.
MEn find by writing that in the town of cerram there was two Jews the
which dwelled among the crystyens in a street. And the day of ester the
sone of one of the Jews was moved in great devotion unto the sacrament / The
curate seeing his steadfast purpose / gave unto him his sauyoure. And when the
fader of ye said child herd tell what his sone had done he was wroth and bet
hy^ And at that hour the Jew baked of bread. And the oven was all embrased
with great fire / took his child and kest him with in the oven. The mother of the
child the wh^che saw the said thing ran unto the said oven / and many
other looked with in it and saw the child the which played without having
ill within the said fire. The miracle was incontinent showed over all the town.
The people ran theder the child was drawn out without having ill. And in no
manner of ye world the Jew would not convert him. And for his infydelyte they
took him and was cast within the oven / and he was forthwt burnt.

Q. Another example of a man the which ne would leave his sin / who came to
receive his creatoure again the defense of the priest. Cii.
THe discyple recyteth in his promptuary that a priest knew in confes^yon how
a sy^ner was not contryte / for he had no will to absteyne him from his sin.
And therefore he defended hy^ to receive his creatoure. And upon this thing
trembly^ge he thereto acceded. And ye pressed said unto him. God be Judge between
the and me / and gave unto him the body of god. And incontinent that he had it
in his mouth his throat brake and the body of ihesu christ yode forth and
suddenly he deyed.

R. Another example of the punycyon of one of the relygyous of saint bernarde
ye which received his creatoure in mortal sin. Cii.
MEn find by writing how saint bernarde knew that one of his relygyous was
in mortal sin / whom he admonested gretely in confession to put him in the
estate of grace etc. but the sinner ne would confess him. And at ester he
presented him at the table of our lord as the other did. When it came to
receive him in his order the said saint bernarde said generally that none ne
should receive his creator in mortal sin. And ye sinner said appertly give
me that the which is mine. Than saint bernarde understood that he was
obstynate and steadfast in his sin made the cross before him and said. God
be Judge between the and me. / And when he had received the body of Ihesu
christ in the mouth fell deed before all suddenly. This example here should
move the sinners to purge their consciences of sy^ne before that they receive
their creatoure. etc.

S. Another example of a holy fader ye which drew back the sinners to
receive their creator in sin. Cii.
IT is written in the life of ye faders that god gave so great grace unto a holy
fader named Eulogium that he apperceyued the merytes and the sins of those ye
which came to receive their creatoure. And he withelde some monks the which
would accede unto the table of our lord to whom he said. How are you so hardy
to come unto gods board. First he said unto one. Thou have had thought of
fornycacyon this night / and said in thy heart there is no dyfference between
the just and the sinner to accede unto the sacrament. And said to another thou
have made a doubt in thy heart how a man may sanctefye the co^munyon. And the
said holy man put a part those the which were in sin / and said that they
should repent them and do penance or that they were acceded. etc.

T. Another example of the punycyon of some the which returned unto their
glotonyes and sins after ester. Cii.
THe dysciple recyteth that it is written in the book of the sovereign
bysshoppes ye some men after the feast of ester that they had received their
creatoure returned unto dronkennes / plays / folyes / and sins / but they
ne abode unpunished. For from their mouths there ra^ne stynkynge blood the
which entered with in their bodies and choked and drowned them. Also suddenly
water and rain descended from heaven the which them moysted and marde / and
dystroyed all the corns and fruytes of their possessions / and with yt water
proceeded dragons so venymous yt the people ne might go ne come / but that they
were in danger of death. For to take away the said punycyon an holy man
prayed for them deuoutely. Unto whom the angel of god appeared and said. I
pray the tell me what should a man do with those the which enclose the sone of
ye emperor in a right dark prison and stynkyng for to waste him. The man of
god answered yt a man should undo those the which do such thing. And the
angel said unto hy^ What should a man do with him the which puts the body
of god in the stynkinge mire. And the man of god said unto him ye men should
brenne him. And ye au^gel said unto him. Those for whom thou prayest have not
they done such a thing on the holy day of ester. They received the holy
co^munyon and afterward yode to daunces and dronkenesses again the holy
sacrament that they had received / and th^rfore god is wroth again them.
When they herd this thing many repented the^ and appesed the ire of god. Unto
the purpose of this example a man may take the words of the gospel the which
ben written mathei. xii. Cu^ immu^dus spiritus exierit ab homine: scz per
co^fessione^ ambulat perloca arida quere^s requie^ and no^ i^uenit: tu^c dicit.
Reuertar in domu^ mea^ vn^ exiui vadit and assumit septe^ alios spu^s secu^
nequio res se et i^trantes habitant: ibi: and fiu^t nouissima hoi^s illius
peiora prioribus. That is to understand when ye ill spyryte is issued from the
man by confession he walks on ye one side and on the other for to deceive hy^
And if the said man return unto sy^ne or if he delight him / or if any sin
be not well confessed / the ill spyryte says. I shall return in to my house
from whens I came. Therder he gothe and takes seven other spyrytes wors than
he / and they enter and dwell there and the last things of ye said man ben
made wors than the first. So took it unto the said people the which returned
unto sin after ester. etc.

V. Another example how the eucharistie prouffyteth unto those that been deed /
and first example of a man the which was delivered from purgatory by the
sainge of three masses. Cii.
IT is written in dialogo cesarii that a young man was received in ye relygyon
of cleruaulx / which kept sheep / and as he was in the field with his sheep,
one of his parents lately deed appyered unto him. And ye said yongman him
demanded from whens he came. He answered I am deed and tormented in great
pains. And the conuers him demanded if a man might help him. He answered if
I might have three masses in your order I should be delivered. And ye said
conuers yode to tell the pryour of the house yt that he had seen and herd.
When the pryour had herd this thing with good will he said a mass and also
commanded to two of his brethren. And incontinent after ye deed body appeared
unto ye said young man yielded him thanks and said yt by ye benefyce of three
masses he was delivered from purgatory.

X. Another example of a friar the which should be.xv. years in purgatory and
he was delivered by one mass. Cii.
IT is written in the life of faders of the order of prechers this the which
follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his sermons and says that there was a
fader pryour prouyncyall in the holy land / humble / gracyous / and devout.
And as he was one time in orayson in the church of the freres after matyns he
lift up his eyes again the wall with heart / and he saw in like wise as the
shadow of a friar in being and had habyte black and soylled. And as he
demanded what he was he answered I am such a friar the which of late deyed.
And when I lived I loved the much. And he demanded of the said friar how it
was with hy^. He answered ill and hardly. For I should be in hard pain till
unto.xv. years. And he him demanded wherefore he should so hardly and longly be
punysshed the which had lived so relygyously and devoutly. He answered / ne
demand that / for after the just judgment of god the creator I have well
deserved such pain / but I pray the aid me. And he him promised that so he
should do unto his power. When it was day the prouyncyall began to sing
mass for the deed body And after ye ostye was consecrate and lift up in
holding it in his hands began to pray god so as in this wise saying these
words. My lord Ihesu christ if the soudan the which is king of paynyms
held a prisoner in bonds and that his chamberere the which had served him
twenty years demanded him the said prisoner for his service the said soudan ne
should hyde him lyghtely My lord be no more hard than the soudan of ye
sarazyns. I am thy chamberier and have served the by many years. thou hold
this friar my friend in captyuyte and bonds I pray the yt thou give him me of
thy great debonayrte for my service. And in great teres and lamentacyons in
repetynge ye said words many times ended his mass / and the night following
after matynes he saw the deed friar before him being in habyte white and
right clear. And he hy^ demanded what he was he answered I am the friar ye
which appeared yesterdaye unto the. And he him demanded how it was with hy^.
He answered well by the grace of god. Thou haste demanded me of god and he
has given me unto the. And I am delivered from purgatory. I yield ye graces
and louynges and I go with the felysshyp of saints / and forthwith he
departed. etc.

Another example is written in dialogo cesarii of a man ye which should be in
purgatory two thousand years and was delivered in two years by the suffrages
/ masses / and good operacyons of a bishop / and of other good men.

Perditio bonorum.
Y. Example yt in like wise as water departs from ye pot perced or broken.
In like wise does the virtues of a man by mortal sin. Cii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt that a good fader named arreneus would
se the operacyons of the world / and as he was in his oratorye he herd a
voice the which said unto him. Arreneus go by the country to the end yt thou
behold the operacyons of the world. And when he was gone forth of his
oratorye he saw a man the which drew water of a well and put it in a vessel
perced and holed from the which it ran incontinent. And therein ne abode
nothing. And the said arreneus passed ferthermore and saw a man ye which
made and assembled a burden of wodde / and when he had made it he assayed to
lift it and to lie it on his sholdres / but for that yt he ne might lift it
and that he found it much heavy he yode yet to assemble of wodde / and put it
yet within that burden or faggot / and made it in such wise two or three times /
and the less might lift it on his sholdres. Afterward ye said arreneus yode
ferthermore and saw two young men upon two horses before ye gate of the cite
the which bare before them alonge logge ouerthwarte / and wend to enter in to
the cite by the said gate / but they ne might for the said logge / for they ne
obeyde the one unto the other for to enter within. And after yt the angel
came unto the said arreneus / unto whom he demanded what he had seen. And he
answered as it said is of the man the which drew of water. And the angel
expounded unto him the said things / and said unto him. By the man the which
drew of water is to understand that the man the which does almesdedes and
good operacyons in mortal sin / anon it departs from him for the sin as
does the water from the vessel perced. And the second man the which thou
haste seen the which assembled of wodde / that is to say that the man the
which assembleth and co^mytteth sy^ne upon sin ne may mount in heyght for
the weight of ye sins. and by those the which ne might enter in to the cite
that bare the wodde overthwart ben understand proud people and hateful the
which ne will humble them and to concord togyders ne shall enter in to the
cite of paradyse. This example denotes three things. The first that mortal
syn chaseth away the good operacyons from ye persons. The second is that
sin is of itself so heavy that it lets to mount in to paradyse and makes
to fall in to the pyt of hell as did satan ye which fell from paradyse. Vn^
luce. x. Videba^ sathana^ sicut fulgur de celo cadente^. And that that a man
puts yet more wodde in his burden and yet the more heavy he fyndeth it and
more ill to lift upon his sholdres denotes yt when a man co^mytteth sy^ne
upon sin. And more shyftly a man falls in basse / and the less a man
mou^teth in paradyse. The third is that hatred and discord the which is
between neighbors lets to enter in to the cite of paradyse.

Finis iniquorum est peccatum.
z. Examples that mortal sin is a line by the which the devil holds ye
sinners. And first how the deuylles held a man bound with a chain and led
him with great joy. Cii
A Doctor named Vyrydarias says in a sermon this the which follows how the
dyscyple recyteth in his book / and says that god gave unto an hermyte this
gift to know the hertes of men the which came one time unto the church where
the priest confessed. And ye said hermyte saw that the men entered in to the
said church black and horrible / ye which were accompanied with deuylles the
which were joyous. And the angels the which them kept were sorry and
separate ferof. And as they returned from confession than ye deuylles were
sorry and departed from them / and the angels were joyous the which approached.
And among the other ye said hermyte saw a man the which was bound by the
neck with a chain that the deuylles led with great joy. And his angel
followed far of And this said man yode unto confession as ye other / but he
came again more blacker than before. And the deuylles bound him more strongly
than he was And wha^ the said hermyte saw that approached unto the said man /
and told unto him that yt he had seen. And the said sinner had great dread and
said. I have offended god in many manners. And also I have hid a great sin.
He returned unto confessyo^ and came again clear / and the deuylles were sorry
and the aungelles joyous. So by true confession and repentau^c^ he was
unbound of his sins and of the deuylles / and was assocyate with the good.
etc.

and Another example that a man being in mortal sin is so bound that he
may not do no good operacyon the which unto him is merytoryous. Cii
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that as master thomas
theologycyen should deye he being in his bed he saw the devil fast by him
/ unto whom he said / What do you here blody be. Tell me what thing it
is the which noyeth you most. And as he held his peace he adioygned and said.
I conjure the by the god living the which shall come to judge the quycke and
the deed yt thou tell me the truth. And the devil answered and said. There is
nothing the which takes away so much our force as contrycyon and
confession oftentimes made. For when a man is in mortal sy^ne all his members
ben so bound that he ne may move him for to do good operacyo^ the which unto
him is merytoryous / and when he confesses his sins he is afterward franc
mouable and unbound for to do all good operacyons. This example denotes two
things. The first is that by mortal sin a man is terrybly bound with the
hands of the devil. The second is that by confession a man is vnbou^de as it
is said. etc.

r. Another example how the devil lies out his snares for to deceive us. Cii
IT is written in the life of faders yt as saint Anthony was in orayson upon a
hye mountain he saw al ye world replenysshed with halters of the enmy of
hell. And he took him to weep and said / what shall that man be yt may pass
and escape the snares here. And a voice from heaven came unto him ye which said
/ anthony seule humylite passes and escapes these laces. Here when a man
has humylyte the snares ne may touch him for his humylyte. This example
denotes two things that the snares of the devil ben cast out for to deceive
us. And therefore him behooves to keep him from falling in to sin that a man
ne be taken The second is that a man escapes over all in having humylyte.
etc.

Mors bonorum.
A. Examples that those which has acomplysshed the will and the
co^mae^dementes of god and ben departed of good death / has had consolacyon
of god and of ye saints of paradyse. And first example how a holy fader saw
in his death ye prophets and Ihesu christ. Ciii.
IT is written in the life of faders of a holy fader the which at the hour of
his death his dyscyples present began to enjoy him and appeared fair and
white and spoke joyous words. Than his discyples him demanded unto whom he
spoke. he an^wered. Ne se you not the holy patryarkes and again as he spoke
ioyously was asked unto whom it was. He answered. Ne se you not the holy
prophets. Thyrdly he said. The holy appostles come. Fourthly he said the
aungelles come. And lastely he said. Rise ye up for Ihesus is come / and in
saying these words he deyed. The death of this good man was right glorious
and blyssed. And also such is it of al those the which deye in the estate of
grace. Vn^ apo. xiiii. Beati mortui qui in dn^o moriu^tur. Also his death was
much precious before god / and so is that of the just persons. Vn^ psalm.
Preciosa e^ in co^spectu ^n^i. The just persons the which has lived well in
this world / and also perseuered till unto the death has three joys at their
departing. The first is that they se all the good deeds that they did ever in
ye state of grace / that is to understand all the almesdedes / oraysons / and
works of mercy And all the trybulacyons yt the body has borne pacyently in
doing fastings / abstinences / to wake late / to rise erly / to lie hard /
to be poorly clothed and such other things. etc. Vn^ ezechi. xviii. Iustitia
iusti erit super eu^: and impietas impii super eu^ erit et ysaie.xxix. Erit
nobis visio oi^m quasi verba libri signati. Examples of some the which has
seen the good and the ylle that they have done. Quere post. c. xxii. d. The
second joy is that they se the deuylles co^fused degetted and also to depart
as wroth In like wise the just love and praise god / Vn^ psalm. Benedictus deus
qui non dedit nos in captione^ dentibus eoru^. Example. Quere. lvi. f. The
third joy that the just shall have at their death is yt they shall se Ihesu
christ yt they have received worthily in the sacrament. And the aungelles
assystentes to comfort them and aid them and for to present them before god
the which unto them is great joy. Also often times they have of the saints of
paradyse after ye will of god / as had the good man beforsayd. Innocent says
in his third book of the vylyte of humayne condycyon that the good and the ill
se Ihesu crist as he was put on the cross before that the soul parted from ye
body / ye good unto their consolacyon / and the ill unto their confusyo^ to the
end they have shame yt they be not redeemed and part takers unto the merit of
his passion. Vn^ legitur apo. i. Videru^t in que^ pupugeru^t. And a man ne
should understand that if a just man dye soday^ly tha^ the sudden death
takes away his merytes and his bounte / and that he ne may be saved. Vnde
poeta. Mors iusti subita qua^ precessit bona vita. No^ tollit merita: si
moriatur.

B. Another example how the saints of paradyse and the au^gelles and god came
unto the departing of a holy fader. Ciiii.
IT is written in the life of ye faders that when the time came that the abbot
Sysois should deye many au^cyentes came to vysyte him / the which saw him
shine in the face / and he said unto the^ Brederne comfort you here is the
abbot anthony the which is come unto us here and a little while after said.
Here is the company of prophets. And again his face shone more clear than the
day / and he said. The blyssed appostles ben present / and the auncyentes the
which present were beheld and understood that he spoke unto some body. The
which said unto him that he should declare with whom he spoke. And he said
the aungelles be come to fetch my soul / and I them supply that they tarry a
while for to do penance. And the faders said unto him. Abbot thou ne haste of
indygence to do penance. And he answered them. I say you in veryte yt I ne
remember me yet to have take ye beginning of penance. They apperceyued by his
speaking that he was perfyte in ye love of god. Than his fa^e shone as the sone
and said unto them. Behold behold for our lord is come. In this word he
died And all the place was replenysshed with good odor. By this example a man
should understand that the death of the good is much precious before god /
after the saying of the psalmyst. Preciosa est inco^spectu dn^i mors scto^rum
eius. And also that they ben comforted and received swetely of aungelles and
saints of paradyse / and set in Joy eternell. etc.

C. Another example how a woman saw Ihesu christ in her death. Ciiii.
Saint gregorye recompteth yt wha^ a woman named tarcille came to ye ^aite day
of her death she looked upward and saw Ihesu christ come. And with a great
courage she began to cry to them ye were by her / depart ye depart for
Ihesus is come. And as she understood in hy^ that she see / her holy soul
part from her body. And so great swetnes of odor meruayllous there followed
that that odoure showed unto all that Ihesu christ was come theder. etc.

D. Another example how a friar showed Ihesu christ with the fyngre at his death
in singing. Ciiii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt there was a friar of the order of
prechers grievously seek and for that yt he approached unto ye death / and that
he had a joyous face a friar him required that if he had / had any consolacyon
spyrytuell in heart yt he would tell it him. He answered. For ye great Joy yt
I have I ne may hyde it / this day I have taken it for my lord jesus christ
has promised me to be in presence at my death. And ye friar him required in
the name of Ihesu christ that when he should se him that he would show him by
some tokens or with the finger. He answered that so should he do if it
pleased god. The three days after the sekenes groged him men stroke on the
table for to assemble the freres as it was of a custom / And the freres ran
in to the fermery / and as they were in orayson in abiding his death the seek
man stretched forth his fyngre in a certain place. And as his eyes were
confused at the death he took him to sing and to say in singing joyous. In
galilea^ jesus videbitis sicut dixivobis. that is to say yt ye shall se Ihesus
in galilee / yt is in paradyse as he has told you / wha^ he had fined these
words he deyed in good consu^macyon / for he had lived in this world of a
holy life. And by that reason it was yt he dyffyned well his days / unto this
purpose saint austyn says. Morte mala mori no^ potest qui bona^ ante duxerit
vita^. Et iheronimus dixit. No^ memi ni me mala morte vidisse homine^ qui bonam
ante duxerit vita^.

E. Another example how a good relygyous woman was comforted of saints of
paradyse the which were at her death
IT is written in the fourth book of ye dyalogue of saint gregorye that a good
relygyous woman named rachetee had two relygyeuses of her habyte with her her
dyscyples of the which the one had to name romula. These three religiouses
woman dwelled togyders the which lived of a holy life replenysshed with good
manners and with virtues / but a poor life corporell they led. And ye said
romula was replenysshed with great pacyence / of sovereign obedyence / kept
scilence of her mouth and took head much unto the usage of orayson the which
was seek in bedd^ by many years / and in a night the said romula called her
said maystresse rachetee and said unto her. Matter veni. Matter veni The which
came with the other sister / and at the hour of the very mydnyghte as they
were in one bed / light celestyal descended in to their house ye which it
replenysshed all. And the said light was so great yt the presents had great
dread And as they were in that dread and light they herd noise as many men
entering in the house. But for the great fere and light they ne might se those
the which entered in to the said house with the said light. And there entered so
sweet odoure yt it was meruayl And the said Romula began to comfort her said
maystresse and her sister ye which were in fere and said. Noli timere matter
no^ morior modo. And after yt she had said that she should not deye at that
hour the said light dymysshed little and little but the great odoure abode. And
so it passed the second and the third day that the said odor abode. And
the.iiii. night the said romula called her said maystresse / and when she was
come she demanded ye body of god and received it. And before yt they parted
from bed there arrived before the door of the house two companyes / the one
of men / yt the other of women ye which song melodyously. The men song ye
psalmodie. And the woman answered in doing the service celestyall of exeq^yes
of the said romula she deyed. And her soul yode with the aungelles and saints
the which came to fetch it. And of asmoche more as they mounted in to the
sky / so much the less herd they of the song of the psalmodie. And the
said odor also departed. etc.

F Another example how a holy bishop was comforted at his death of the saints
of paradyse. Ciii.
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint gregory of a good holy bishop named
probus. When it came unto his death his fader assembled many physycyens for to
hele him. The which said after that they had vysyte him that he should deye.
And than the good bishop said unto al those that they should go with his fader
to take their refeccyon after their labor. The which theder yode / and
there ne abode with him but one young child / and after that the said child
saw some come enter clothed with white and their faces clear and shynynge as
the son. The which child after that he was stryken with the great light the
which proceeded of them he took him to cry and demanded of them what they
were. At the which voice the said bishop was moved / beheld them ye which
entered / he knew them and began to comfort the child the which trembled for
fere and said unto him. My sone dread the not for saint Iuuenall and saint
Eleuthere martyrs ben come unto me. And ye said child ferefull of that vysyon
ran out and told to the physycyens and to the fader the said vysyon. The
which ran and found the bishop deed. For his soul yode with those that
the said child had seen* etc.

G Another example how a maiden named gelyne was comforted at her death of
saint peter. Ciii.
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint gregorye of a good noble maiden named
Gelyne / the which was married / and was one year with her husband the which
deyed. And when she was wedowe she put her unto ye service of god in the
church and monastery of saint Peter. And there lived holyly in all symplesse in
making oraysons and great almesdedes. When it came to the end of her days that
she was weary of sekenes in a night as she had two candelles light by her bed
saint peter appeared unto her between ye two foresaid candelles. And she enjoyed
her and said unto him. Who is there my lord ben my sy^nes pardoned. Unto whom
he said benyngly in bowynge down the heed. They ben pardoned ye / come thy
way. And for as much as in ye said monasterye there was a holy relygyous that
she loved before the other she required unto holy peter in saying. I pray the
that my sister named benet come with me. and he answered ye shall not be so /
but such one in this wise named shall come with the And she that thou
requyrest shall come after the / the thyrty day. Than the said appostle
departed. And her mother abbess was called: unto her she recompted ye said
vysyon. And she deyed the.xxx. day with her that the appostle had said. And
ye.xxx day after she yt she had required followed her and also deyed. etc.

A. Another example how a priest fled ye company of a woman yt was comforted at
his death of saints of paradyse. ciiii.
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint gregory of a good priest ye which i^
the dread of god governed a church fl^dde the famylyaryte of a woman / and
would not yt the woman of his house should admynystre any thing unto hy^ / And
absteyned him from all thing unlawful / and also lived of a holy life. When it
came that he labored at the death / and that he ne might almoost speak he
apperceyued yt the said woman of his house put her hand unto his nose for to
know if he were deed / and his spyryte fervently came again and began to say.
Recede a me mulier: ad huc igniculus viuit. Depart thou fro me woman yet a
little fire lives take away the straw. Than the woman departed. / And ye
virtue of his body all grew / and with great gladness and Joy he took hy^ to
cry / ye ben welcome my lords. Wherefore have ye wylled to come unto one so
little your servant. I come. I come / I yield you thanks. And for that ye he
repeted ye said words his friends were by hy^ demanded him unto whom he
spoke: Unto whom he said as in meruayllyng And se you not the appostles saint
peter and saint poule ye which ben here come / And he turned toward them
and began to say. I go. I go. And as he spoke these words he yield up his
spyryte.

B. Another example how a friar fled in to heaven as soon as an arowe. Ciiii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye that a friar of the order of prechers
appeared with great Joy after his death unto another monk the which was his
friend famylyer. And as he was asked of his estate among other things he said
/ that never arowe shot out of a great bow fled so sone in to a place as
my soul fled before god when to departed from the body. For I had lived
fyfty years in the order to serve Ihesu cryst^ in good conuersacyon. etc.

C. Another example of the death of a pilgrim the which was comforted of ye
aungelles of paradyse. Cii i
IT is written in the life of faders of a holy man relygyous so much loved of
god that yt the which he required in orayson unto him was granted. And he
prayed god that he might se the soul of a sinner and of a just man how they
ben drawn from their bodies at their death And as he was in his oratorie there
entered a wulfe the which took his vestyment with his mouth and drew it. Than
the said friar rose him up and yode after the said wulfe / the which led him
fast by a cite and left him there by a monasterye. In the which was a man
that had a great name and was reputed solytayre and good of the worldy people
but he was an ypocryte / ye which was at deyenge. And the fader ye which was
theder come beheld yt men made unto him great lyghtes of tapres and lamps
for his buryenge. And at ye hour of the said death he saw the devil the
which held a brased hoke and put it in his mouth and tormented him long and
said / In like wise as this soul has not suffered me to rest one hour. In
like wise ne shall I have of mercy of it till that I have seized it horrybly.
And he seaced it and bare it away. Afterward the said fader yode in to ye
cite and found a pilgrim seek / and laid on the earth of whom no man took
head / and there was one day to behold him. And when the hour of death came
he saw saint Myghell and saint gabryel ye which dyscended by the said soul
ye one on the right hand and the other on the left hand and prayed the said
soul yt she would come forth of ye body and she came not forth so as she ne
would leave her body. And gabryell said unto Myghell. Take this soul that we
may be gone. And myghel answered. God us has commanded that it go forth
without dolor. And therefore we ne may take it forth by force. And mighel cried
with a great voice unto our lord and said unto him. What will thou that we do
with this soul / for she ne will come forth to go with us. And a voice came
theder the which said. I send unto you dauyd with his harp / and all those
the which sing the salmodye of Iherusalem to the end that at the sweet song
she come forth of ye body. And incontinent they dyscended by the said soul /
and at the sweet song she came forth in to ye hand of saint mighell / and
they yode their way with great joy

D. Another example how a knight saw ye death of an ill man. And more over the
death of a good man that the angels bare in to heaven. C.iiii
IT is written in the book of the dyscyple that a noble knight would enter in to
relygyon. The which sent his servant to tell unto the abbot yt he would be
relygyous in his abbay. And gave him in charge that he should say that he was
dombe / but ready to obey unto al things And thought that if he held not peace
his tongue should lose him all the good deeds that he should do. And that
knight there was received. And men wend yt he had be dombe. And one time he
yode with the abbot unto a knight the which labored unto ye death. And he
saw yt the deuylles drew the soul out of the body of him ye which deyed
horrybly / and he had pity and wept. And as they came again from thens
another knight came unto ye abbot the which him promised that he would
renounce the world and that he should be a monk. And as he yode before the
said abbot on an ill bridge for to prove ye way he fell before ye said abbot
and was drowned. And the said knight saw his soul in habyte of monk that the
aungelles came to fetch and to bear in to heaven he was all replenysshed with
joy. And when the abbot was in the cloystre he said unto the knight that he
commanded him in ye virtue of obedyence that he should tell him if he might
speak / wherefore at the death of the two said men he had in such wise
co^tempned / unto whom the said knight said. Thou have done ill. For again
my purpose thou have made me speak / but I shall tell it the. And he unto him
recompted all by order how he had seen the soul of the one that the deuylles
had taken horrybly from the body and bare it away and that the aungelles had
borne the other. Than the abbot fell at his fete on knees. etc. And the said
knight refused his promesses and good deeds yt he unto him would do / but he
would be enclosed in some place to the end that he might keep his purpose yt he
had to keep taciturnyte and scylence.

E. Another example of a holy fader the which deyed in the dread of god. Ciiii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt a holy fader was seek ye which as he
was seen to dread the death / the freres him demanded wherefore he dredde. and
he answered in this manner. Brederne I have kept the commandments of god
after my puyssaunce / but I am a man and I know not if my operacions has
pleased unto god or nay. And therefore I ne am sure till unto that that I come
unto him. etc.

F. Another example of a pryour relygyous that said that he dyed lawfully
faithfully / amyably and ioyously.
IT is written in the life of faders yt the pryour of a covent was in a grievous
sekenes replenysshed with meruayllous pacyence. And he said oftentimes one
thing the which is written in ye cantycles with great dolor of devotion.
Dilectus meus michi and ego illi donec aspiret di es and i^clinentur vmbre.
Also he said unto his brederne.xv. days before his death that he should deye
of that sekenes in ye solempnyte of the feast of the vyrgyn Marye the which
thing was done. For at the first even song of the natyuyte of the vyrgyn
Marye he deyed / and was buried that day He had song the last mass of the
vyrgyn Marye. And also of her he had made his last predycacyon. When he should
deye anon he made to assemble before him his brederne unto whom he said.
Know ye my brederne yt I deye lawfully / amyably faithfully and ioyously. And
expounded it in this wise. I deye lawfully. For I deye in the faith of Ihesu
christ and of the sacraments of the church. Amyably / for I have perseuered in
the dyleccyon of god unto mine advise sith that I entered in to ye order. And I
have studied how I might best please him. Faithfully for I know well that I go
unto god. Ioyously for I go from one land replenysshed with myserye unto a
good country. I pass from wepynges unto Joy sempyternell. etc.

G. Another example of a monk the which was chosen to be bishop and he
refused it and deyed well. Ciiii.
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple that Arnoldus says that a
monk of cleruaulx was chosen to be bishop / the which refused it against the
will of his abbot / and of ye bishop / and sone after he deyed. And he appeared
after his death unto his famylyer / ye which demanded him if the
dysobeyssau^ce beforsayd had noyed him. He answered yt nay and afterward said.
If I had taken the bysshopryche I had be dampened. And said more over an
horrible word. The estate of the church is come unto that yt she is not dygne
to be governed but of ill bysshoppes. etc.

H. Another example of the death of many holy persons of the which the Bible
makes mencyon. Ciiii.
THe holy scryptures makes mencyon of the death of many holy faders that it
should be long thing and confuse for to write. And for to be short who so
will se in the bible let him study in the chapytres the which follows
here. / First it is written of the death of abel genesis.iiii. cap. Of ye death
of abraham. ge. xxv. of the death of Ysaac genesis.xxxv. of the death of jacob
gene. xlix. of the death of Joseph gene. l. Of the death of Aaron numeri.xx. Of
moses the which deyed in the land of Moab yt our lord buried / and never
man ne knew his sepulcre. In like wise as it is written deuterono. xxxiiii. Of
the death of david it is written primo paralipo. xxix. of the death of zachary
it is written secu^do. paralipo. xxiiii. of the death of Thobye it is written
thobie.xiiii. of the death of his sone it is written thobie vltimo / of ye death
of job / it is written job. xlii. of the death of mathathias.i. machabioru^ ii.
of the death of saint Johan baptist mathei xiiii. Of the death of the poor
lazar beggar yt the au^gelles bare in to Abraha^s bosom it is written luce.
xvi. of the good thief the which deyed when our lord deyed it is written
luce. xxiiii. of the death of saint Steven the which was stoned / it is written
actuum.vii. etc.

Mors malorum.
A. Examples of those the which has not wylled to do the will of god ne to
acco^plysshe his commandments ben deed of an ill death in pains and dolours
/ and first example / how the devil drew the soul of a cursed rich man
with a crochet and a woman wedowe was comforted of the vyrgyn marye and of the
vyrgyns. Cv.
VYcent says in the.viii. book of ye myrrour hystoryall yt there was a rich
curate vycyous in a parysshe ye which had under his cure a noble rich man and
a poor woman wedowe / the which deyed in one time. When ye said rich man was
seek he sent to seche the curate to vysyte him and to admynystre the
sacraments the which curate theder yode quykly and was much more curyous to
have ye said rich man couched on feders in a fair bed covered with purple
with precious vestymentes / and aourned with gold and with precious stones. And
also he found many seductoures the which gave unto him consolacyons of
