flateryes / and his wife / his children / and household the which lied. And in
this thing hanging there came a messenger unto the said curate from the said
wedowe strongly seek for to confess her and to vysyte. And the said pressed the
which put all his entente for to sowke the rich sinner ne answerde nothing
And a deacon ye which was present had pity of the poor wedowe and dredde yt
she should deye without receyuynge the sacraments / spoke unto the curate the
which answered by great furoure. O that thou art of little counsayll ye
which wylt that we leave this noble man our patron for to go unto ye old
wedowe. And the deacon answered. Ne trouble you not / if you command me I
shall vysyte her. And the deacon yode theder by his commandment And bare the
body of Ihesu christ. The wedowe was gretely poor of worldly gods / but full
of good operacyons. She was prostrate upon the earth / and a little of straw
under her. When the deacon was at the door he was meruaylled and rested him.
For he saw there the vyrgin marye / and great company of vyrgyns standing by
the wedowe / and marye chered her / vysyted and with a clothe wyped the
swetynge from her vysage. And when ye queen of heaven and the vyrgyns saw the
body of our lord Ihesus they yode on their knees and worshyppeth the
sacrament / When they were redressed they assured affably the deacon that he
should enter. and the vyrgyn mary said that he should not dread. And that he
should confess and admynystre the said wedowe and so he did / And afterward
he said of the psalms to command the soul with great joy to depart. After
came in to the house of ye said rich man. When he was at the door he saw of
black cattes by the bed of the said rich man ye which cried take away
these cattes comen to this wretch. And in the end a devil black as an
ethyopien horrible of face and of voice menassable held in his hand a hoke
the which he put in the throat bolle of ye sinner for to draw out his soul.
The which ne found in all his vysytacyon of refresshynge in his conscience.
Than the death occupied him he had fere and trembled / and the devil iuryous
drew hugely the soul out of the throat bolle with his crochet. And the
caytyf kest an horrible sygh and so deyed / and the other deuylles stroke upon
ye soul / and bare it unto the place of derkeres and of death eternell. And as
the deacon beheld and saw this thing by the suffrau^ce of god he had so
great fere that he fell unto the earth and was as half deed. And incontynente
the vyrgyn marye appeared unto him ye which laid unto him. Right dear friend
dread the not / for ye cursednes byabolyque ne shall noye the / beatytude
celestyall is apparaylled unto the / and he him redressed in yeldynge graces
unto the vyrgyn marye and afterward prouffited much for ye said reuelacyons.
By this example a man should understand yt the death is much cruel and ill
unto sinners in like wise as says the scryptures. Vn^ psalm. Mors pcto^rum
pessima. O mors quam amarae^ memoria tua homini i^iusto. O death how bitter is
the remembrance of ye unto the man v^ius^e / These sinners inobedyentes shall
have pryncypally four dolours at their death the which also may be taken upon
ye words of dauyd yt says in psalm. Circu^^ederunt me dolores mortis et
torre^tes i^iqitatis conturbaueru^t me: dolores i^ferni circu^deder^t me:
preoccupauer^t me laquet mortis. That is to say the dolours of ye death has
me enuyronned and beset about and the ryuers of iniquyte me has troubled the
doloures of hell has me compassed about / ye panges of death has me
usurped. The first dolor yt these sinners inobedyentes shall have at their
death is sekenes corporell yt shall be so cruel yt it shall perturbe all his
members / and shall separate ye soul from ye body ye which shall be so great
doloure and bytternes yt the heart of man ne may think it. There was never man
in this world endured so horrible dolor as is the death / and the soul shall
draw all his strengthes not thinking of his nourryture bodyly but on his
doloures as it is said. Circu^deder^t me dolores mortis. Also great doloure
shall be at the departing of the body and of ye soul. For they were gretely
delected and enjoyed togiders Also it shall be great dolor to leave the wife /
the children / the gold the silver / the herytages / manors / houses / rentes
/ lands and possessions. Also to leave the wine / ye ale / the flesh / and
the other lyuynges for to go dwell in a place where no good is sowe^ gadred ne
found / not so much as one drop of water. Example of the cursed rich man
the which was denied of one drop of water. For to be short it shall be
dolor to leave the pleasau^ces and dylectacyons of the body and of the world.
Catho^ says. Non eodem cursuco respondent vltima primis. The last things ne
answers unto the first in one self course / Also the euangelyst says yt
the last things of a man ben made wors than ye first Vnde mathei. xii. luce.
xi. Fiunt nouissima hominis illius peiora prioribus. The se^^nde dolor that
the sinners shall have in their death is to understand by that yt dauyd says.
Torentes iniquitatis conturbauerunt me. That is to say that they shall se and
know in them and upon the^ all ye sins that they have commit and done for
the which they shall be punysshed iuged and condampned / the which shall be
unto them dread and doloure. It is written luce. viii. Nichil est occultu^ quod
non manifestetur: nec absconditum quod non cognoscatur et i^ palam veniat.
There is nothing so secret but that it shall be manifest / ne hid but that
it shall be known and that it shall come openly and appear before all. Also in
the end of the man all shall be discovered so that a man shall se appertly
all his operacyons good and ill Vnde eccle. xi. In fine hominis denudatio
operum ulius. In beholdynge a multitude of people a man knows that such one
is clothed with gray / with black / and with white. etc. Also at the judgment
and when the soul shall be separate from the body a man shall know yt such
one was lecherous / thief / or murdrer. etc. as if the sins were painted upon
the person. / Vnde ezechielis.xviii. Iustitia iusti erit super eum and
impietas impii super eu^ erit The justice of the just shall be upon him and
the sin of wicked shall be upon hy^ Also the sinners shall bear their
confusyo^ and their sins that they have done. vn^ ez^. xliiii Peccatores
portabu^t confusionem suam et scelera sua que fecerunt. Et ysaie.xxix. Erit
nobis visio omnium quasi verba libri signati. And when ye sy^ners shall se that
they have not done of penance / and that they shall have no more no time nor
place to do it / their sins shall trouble them and give great bytternes /
The third doloure is to understand by dolores inferni circumdederunt me. For
the unjust sinners shall se the pains the which unto them ben prepayred for
to punysshe them and torment. And for to sustain pain corespondent unto
every sin commit. Example of a mad man the which in his death saw hell
open / and the fire and the torments the which unto him were prepayred for to
punysshe hy^ and said that his judgment was then made. Quere. lxvii. ca.
Another example of a sodomytycque the which said at his death that he saw
hell open appertely and the torments and ye deuylles present for to rauysshe
him. Que. lxxxxv. d. The.iiii. dolor is to understand by preoccupauerunt me
laquei mortis. That is that these sinners shall se at their death ye deuylles /
in their foul figure the which shall be to them an horrible torment. Example
of a sone the which saw them at his death. Quere. lxii. b. Also the sinners
shall have another great dolor at their death / in like wise as says some
doctors. For they shall se Ihesu christ in like wise as he was crucefyed unto
their confusyon to the end that they have shame that they ne be redeemed and
partakers unto the merytes of his passion for their sins committee. Vn^ apo.
i. ca. Videru^t in quem pupugerunt. And ye blessed Ihesu shall demand them
reason of their operacyons. And by that they shall have great dolor at their
death when they shall se and know their damnacyon and perdycyon eternell. etc.

B. Another example how a rich sone deyed impenytent ye which said that his
judgment was made / and that he saw the deuylles. Cv.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons that there was a young man the which
lift him up against god and against his own health the which committed many
euylles in saying / in playnge / in co^myttynge lechery / and in living after
the voluptuosytees of his body. Afterward he fell in to a grievous sekenes / and
as he lay and that men apperceyued in him no contrycyo^ his cousyn that satte
by him said to hy^. Thou art sore seek prepayre the unto god by true contrycyon
/ confession / and in receyuynge ye sacraments / and call him the which has
suffered for the on the cross yt he will pardon the thy sins. And he answered
in dispayrynge hy^. What tellest you me of confession and to receive the
sacraments. I never in my life received god verytably / but I have al way lived
against god / and also I have called god in ire. Than am I now left of him so yt
I never may find grace / for I am setenced eternally unto the fire pardurable
/ and unto the death eternal. And I am now in the puyssaunce of all the
deuylles / and afterward said. See you this great garner of wheet / I tell
the yt there are mo deuylles assembled about me that there ben corns in ye
said garner. Than he deyed and yielded his soul to the deuyls the which carried
him.

C. Another example of a monk ypocrite yt eat in secret and feigned to fast /
and the infernal dragon choked him. Cv
IT is written in the dyalogue of saint Gregory that a monk was by estymacyon a
good relygyous For men wened yt he was replete with virtues and good manners but
in the end he showed that he was none such. When his bredren wend yt he had
fasted he eat secretly and also showed wtoutforthe other than he was within.
When it came unto his death his bredren of his relygyon came thither wenynge yt
he had said good words and salutaryes / but he took him to tremble and to be
in great confusyon and to say. When I was with you and that ye wend yt I
fasted I eat secretly / and I am now given unto a dragon for to devour me the
which byndeth my knees and fete with his tail / and puts his heed in my
mouth and draws my spyrite out. And after yt he had spoken these words he
deyed / and the dragon gave him neither time ne space to do penance. God
suffered that this thing was manyfestly showed to the end yt al ypocrytes
fayntyues know that they shall be dampened if they correct them not in time and
in place.

Iudicia dei:
A. Example how a monk required of god yt he might se his Iugementes / the
which saw them and knew them that they were Just and hard to know. Cvi
IT is written in the life of ye faders that a monk solytary of the parties of
egypt required of god too show him his Iugements. And for as much as he
continued to beseech god to se this thing / god sent unto him an angel in
semblaunce of an au^cyent fader the which said to him. Come go we se the holy
faders and require we them the holy word and their benedyccyon. And after that
they had sore labored and walked they came to knock at the door of an holy
fader the which received them benygnely and after orayson washed their fete /
them refeccyoned and gave of that yt he had charitably. And in the morning in
great Joy gave them license. And when they departed the aungel took and hid
a platter wherein they had eaten and bare it away. And the monk began to
murmr against the angel wherefore he had taken the platter of so good a man
the which had done to them so much goodness. And as they walked ye sone of ye
good man came after the^ to demand the said platter. And the angel slew hy^
When the said monk saw yt he was sorry and said. Maledyccyon is with me that
such a thing is done unto so good a man. It suffysed not to take from him his
platter / but more his sone has be slain. And after that they had walked yet
three days they came to the door of an ancient the which had two dyscyples
and struck at the door. And the ancient sent one of his dyscyples demau^dynge
them what they would and what they were. They answered / we ben of labor and
would have thy benedyccyon / and to here thy word. And the said ancient sent
them word yt he might not entende and that they should go their ways. And
they him prayed yt he would lodge them to pass yt night for they were weri.
And he sent unto them that they should go their way / and asked why they held
the^ not in their place and that they should go as vacabondes. And they prayed
him again yt he would lodge them for the night alonely. And said it is night
and yt they dredde to be devoured of evil beestes. And he commanded his
dyscyple that he should put them in the stable. And in ye even tide they ne
might have no light ne other thing of the said master. But one of the
dyscyples bare unto them a little breed and water / and prayed them that they
should say nothing unto his master. And they abode so all the night. And when
the morning came the angel of god said unto the said dyscyples. Pray ye unto
your master that he give us orayson / and that we have a gift to give him.
And when that he herd that he should have a gift he descended. And the said
angel gave unto him ye platter that he had taken of the good man And when he
had taken it he returned in to his chamber and shytte the door unto him. And
when the said monk saw yt he was indygne toward him that yode with him and
knew not that he was an angel / unto whom he said. Depart thou fro me / for
I shall goo no more with the. Thou have taken ye platter of a good man the which
has done unto us so much of goodness and have given it unto so ill a man. And
morouer thou have slain the son of the good man that did to us so much
charity. And the angel answered. Thou have prayed god that he would show the
his Iugementes / and he has sent me to show them the. The platter yt I have
taken from the good man was not comen of good inquysycyon / and it was not
conuenable that so good an holy man had in his house any evil thing. But that
the which is comen of evil is comen to him yt is unto his ruin. And I have
slain the sone of the good man / for if I had not slain him he ha^ slain his
fader this night And when the monk herd those words he yode on knees before
the said angel / and knew that it was the angel of god / the which
departed incontinent from him. And he knew that the Iugements of god ben
just. etc.

B. Another example that an hermyte murmured against god for his diverse
Iugementes. Cvii
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt an hermit murmured in his heart of the
diverse Iugementes of god for that / yt those the which lived ill had gods And
unto the contrary those the which lived well had of trybulacions / and sometime
those the which had led a good life had in the end death abiecte the ill the
fair end. And the good lost often the temporal gods / and ill had
prosperyte. And as the said hermyte thought much on the said things he prayed
god yt he would show hy^ his Iugementes. Than an angel came unto him and
said that he was sent from god for to show them unto him / and that he should
come after him. The said angel was in form of an hermyte pilgrym. When they
had walked they came first to the house of an hermyte the which they found
broken and wasted with wolves. Of this thing the said hermyte was much
admeruayled and said. This here was an holy man the which lived here
solytaryly fyfty years to serve god. And god has suffered yt he has be broken
with beestes. And the angel of god said unto him. Thou see here one of the
Iugementes of god. Secondly they came unto another yt had his house set on an
high roche above these / unto whom the aungel preched of pacyence against
aduersytees and trybulacyons against impacyence. And in weeping and great
contrycyon he confessed yt as he had been there by the space of.xl. years with
great afflyccyon of penance at the last he was vaynquysshed so strongly in
his my^de that he would leave his good life and return in to the world. And
when the said angel saw him very contryte he took him and kest him in to
the sea and drowned hy^ And when the hermyte saw this he was in great fere and
fled / but the angel called him again and said to him. Dread thou not god
had showed the here his second Judgment. Thyrdly they came in to the house of
the third hermyte yt received them gladly and gave them drink in a cup of
silver yt he had. And ye aungel took the said cup secretly and put it in his
bosom and bare it away Afterward they came by night to ye house of a knight
robber and with great pain they were received to lodge and evil entreated and
tourmented of reproaches and rebukes / and notwithstanding men gave them
somewhat and a bed ill apparayled. In the morning ye angel would not depart
till he had spoken with his host. And he drew out the said cup and gave it
him. When thermyte saw yt he was admeruayled and murmured in his heart of yt
he had seen. After in another night they came to ye house of another knight yt
received them right well / albeit he treated them right meanly. And in the
morny^ge wha^ they should part he was prayed of the angel yt his only sone
engendered shol conduyte them on the way. And as ye child led them he took
and slew him and kest him in to a dyche. When the hermyte saw that he fled
and said. Thou art none au^gel thou art a devil. And the angel said to hy^.
These things that you have seen ben ye Iugements of god occulte and hyd that you
required too know. Understand you the causes. The first hermyte that we found
devoured know you that it was comen unto him in crown of martyrdom yt he has
deserved to have by long time and required of god by great prayers. The
second hermyte yt I kest in to the sea after yt he was converted unto god and
that he had contrycyon and good repentance / so he is well deed and is gone to
god without hauy^ge other pain but only ye death yt I have given him. And if he
had not be slain when the temptacion was to men again he had accomplysshed
that / yt he had conceived and had been lost. The third hermyte is a
contemplatyfe and of good prayers. But the devil by his cautele had procured
hy^ lettinge in his oraysons and has ordained yt a rich man gave unto him ye
cup of silver for to pray for him. And I have taken it from him / for when he
would pray there came unto him of thought what he might do with the said cup
that ye thieves ne should stele it from him / so the thought of the said cup
let his heart to pray god. And by that he shall return in to oraysons
accustomed without hauy^ge any lettynge. The first knight where we yode is an ill
man yt is not worthy to have remuneracyon celestyall / and for a little goodness
yt he did unto us we gave unto him remuneracyon temporal in gyuynge him ye
said cup. The second knight was a good hospytaller yt did great almesses /
and for that he had none heir he prayed the relygyous men yt they would pray
unto god for him yt he might have lygnage. And god has given unto him this
sone yt thou have seen yt I have slain / he is returned to do ye works of
mercy that he had left to do unto ye poores / and also he has left to do many
ylles that he did for to assemble te^porall goods unto his said sone. Also we
have procured their health that they should convert them unto god and shall do
good deeds after the death of their said sone. By these things before said a
man may know yt the Iugements of god ben Just and hard to know as unto us.
And therefore it needs us not to inquire forther ne to know than our
entendement ne may comprehend. Non oportet sapere plusquam sapere oportet. etc.

C. Another example how a holy bishop was punisshed by the Judgment occulte
and hid of god for that / yt he received a vestyment of an usurer. Cvi.
IT is written in ye legende of saints that after yt saint Fortyn bishop was
deed he saw two angels yt came unto him to bear his soul / and the third
angel came with a white bokeler and with a sword shyny^ge yt yode before. And
afterward he saw the deuylles the which cried / and herd that they said. Go
we before and make we battle before hy^. And when they were before they keste
brennynge darts / but the angel yt yode before received them on his bokeler.
Than the deuylles put them against ye au^gelles and said. This man spoke often
of idle words / and he ne should without having pain a blyssed life. And the
aungel said unto them. If ye ne bring forth the pryncypal vices against him
he ne shall perysshe for the small. And the devil said. If god be ryghfull
this man shall not be saved / for it is written. If ye be not converted and do
in likewise as one of my little ye shall not enter in to ye kingdom of heaven.
Vn^ math. xviii Nisi co^uersi et efficiamini sicut peruuli no^ intrabitis in
regnu^ celorum. And the au^gel in excusing him said. He had indulgence in his
heart but the customaunce of men co^tynueth. And the devil said. In likewise
as he took ill by custom so shall he receive vengeance by the sovereign Judge.
And ye angel said that he was Iuged before god And than the angel began to
fight and the adversaries were confused. And the devil said. The servant the
which knows ye will of his master and lord and does it not shall be by
many wou^des and plages / as it is wryted. Luce. xii. Seruus sciens volu^ tatem
domini sui et non faciens plagis vapulabitur multis. And the angel said. What
thing has not this man accomplysshed of the will of his lord. And the devil
said. He has received gifts of an evil man. And the aungel said. He believed
that each one had done penance. And the ennemy said / he should have proved the
perceueraunce of penance before yt he had taken ye gift The angel said / go
we before god / but the devil was vaynquysshed. And the devil again came to
fight and said. Wene ye yt the Judge be very god the which promised yt all
sin that is not punysshed in this world shall be punysshed in perdurabylyte.
This man had a robe of an usurer and he was never punysshed / where is than ye
ryghtwysnes of god. And the angel said Hold thy peace / for thou know not
the secret Iugementes of god / evermore when the soul will do penance ye
mercy of god is with him. And the devil answered / there ne is here no place
of penance. Unto whom ye angel said. Thou know not the profundyte of the
Iugementes of god. And than the devil smote the said bishop so hard yt after
that he was restablysshed to life the trace of ye stroke abode still. And the
deuyls took one of the dampened yt they tourmented in the fire of hell and kest
him against ye said bishop in such manner that he had the cheke and the
sholder brent. Than the said bishop knew yt it was that man the which had
given unto him the said vestement. And the angel said unto him. If thou
had not take ye gift of this man the which is deed in sin this pain had
not burnt in the / and thou have this pain of bren^ynge to suffer for that yt
thou received the gift of the vestement of the said usurer And the devil said.
Yet he rests to pass by the strayte gate / whereby we may hy^ surmount / and
the devil said unto the angel. God commands to love his neighbor as
himself. And the aungel answered. This man has done many good works unto
his neighbors. And the aduersarye said. It suffyseth not if he has loved the^
as him self. Unto whom the angel said. The fruit of love is also well to be
done / for god shall yield unto eueryche after his operacyons. And the ennemy
said. But he shall be dampened for that / yt he has not accomplysshed the
tokens of love. Than the company of the deuylles the which fought with the
aungelles were vaynquysshed. etc. In the end the said bishop was brought again
in to his own body / and his neighbors wept the which wend that he had been
deed. After that he ouerlyued by sometime and fined his days in good rest /
peace / and manners.

D. Another example of the Judgment and horrible punycyon the which was done
of an archebysshoppe that was named Vdo. Cvi.
MEn find by wrytinge this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt it is all known and manifest in the
country where is happened / how in the country of Saxony there was an
archebisshoppe Metropolytayne named Maydenburc founded of saint Mauryce. In
that cite studied a scoler named Vdo the which had hard engyn and wit / and
might nothing learn / and therefore was he beten and much tourmented of his
masters of the scole. And on a time that he had be much beten he went out of
the scole and entered in to the church of saint Mauryce in the which he fell
prostrate and put him in great devotion to require the debonayrte of ye queen
of heaven and the aid of saint Mauryce for to enlumyne his entendement. And as
he was there in prayers he slept somewhat / unto whom appeared the mother of
mercy and said unto him. I have herd thyn orayson I give unto the not alonely
the gift of science / but with that you shalt be archebisshop of my prince
Mauryce after that ye archebysshop that is shall deye. And if thou govern well
the church you shalt have great reward. And if thou do unto the contrary you
shall deye in body and in soul. When these things were spoken the vyrgyn Mary
departed. And the young man arose up and yode to study the lesson yt he had
accustomed. And when he came to speak and to dyspute he surmounted the other
and appeared right sage and expert in all science / and they all meruayled that
herd him and said. How this man here is enspyred in all scyences / is not this
Vdo the which was beten yesterday as a be / and this day he is approved to
be even as a phylozophre. Two years afterward ye archebysshop deyed / and Vdo
was elect of all to be metropolitayne. After yt he was confermed and put in
honor he lived well some little time. And for as much as honors change the
manners he was neclygent to perceuer and to live after the counceyle of the
vyrgyn Mary / and forgate his health. Morouer he habandoned his body unto
voluptees / and wasted the goods of his church / and vyoled not alonely the
women seculers but those of relygyon. And morouer ye which is worse he suffered
those of his dycc to commyt all vices without any dread / so yt his life was in
hate and unto al detestable. And many years after yt the said archebysshop had
broken the air by his sins / in a night as he had in his bed with him an
abesse relygyouse of the order of Cystercienses issued of the castle ryall /
he herd a voice yt vttred terrybly the words the which follows. Fac finem
ludo / qr lusisti satis voo. That is to say. Vdo make an end of thy play / for
thou have played enough. These thing herd Vdo had suspycyon yt they were
mockynges fayntyfes. And in ye morning in perseueringe he returned unto
delyces / so that he was hard and durate as a stone without correccyon / without
having compunccyon ne dread for the voices thretenynge that he had herd. The
night following he herd a semblable voice. And the fool was persevering in
his malice as before. The third night he lay with the said abbess / and as he
excercysed ye foul and stynkynge work of lechery the words beforesayd were
brought forth in great terroure Facfinem ludo / qr lusisti satis vdo. When he
had herd this third voice he was abashed and wayled a little / but he
refused not. Certainly the acursed was nere his da^pnacyon and he hasted him
not to go unto penance. I will tell a thing meruaylous / and but words
verytable. And if all the people of Saxonye where this thing was done held
their peace / all the elements would cry that these things here after ben
manyfested. Three months after one of the chanones of the said church
metropolytayne named Frederycus much venerable and of great holiness / in a
night as he was in ye quere of the church of saint Mauryce fervently in
oray^on and besought god the creator for the holy church universal / and
pryncypally for his own metropolytayne yt the conductour of all and the Just
Judge either yt soon he would make to deye their chyef archebisshop Vdo / or
that he would change him to better. His prayer and his word had effect / for
a vysyon terryble followed. He saw that a great wind came in to the church yt
blewe out all the lamps of the same. So he took a place / his heeres stood up
/ the voice was enclosed in the faucettes of his throat. Afterward came two
young men ye which bare two tapres the which set them on the corners of the
great auter. And all ye place was replenysshed of their light. After them
entered two other / and one of them bare tapytes the which they spread honestly
before the auter. And the other set thereon two chayres of gold. After them
came one alone ye held in his hand a sword al naked And he standing in the
mids of ye church cried strongly in sayng. All the saints of whom the
relykes ben here arise ye up and come unto the Judgment of god. These things
spoken there appeared right great multitude of the one sex and of the other
right clear. Some ordained in habytes as knights. Other in pontyfycall vesture
of chasubles / and they all entered in to the quere and set them there on the
one side and on the other by order after their merytes. Afterward there
appeared.xii. men and in the mids of them there went one clerer than the sone
/ the which had the crown of a king and scepter ryall. When the saints saw
hy^ they worshypped him hastily and made him to sytte in the chair. And ye
queen of heaven aryued more clerer than the moon and the sterres after whom
followed a clear turbe of vyrgyns. All the saints worshypped ye mother of god.
And Ihesu christ came before her / took her by ye hand / and set her
honorably by him. Finally saint Mauryce glorious duke appeared with his
legyon.vi. M vi. C. lx. and. vi. the which of one courage prostrate them and
worshypped our lord saying O rightwyse Judge and conduter of the heue^s give
Judgment. These things spoken they stood up and him required reverently. Unto
whom our lord Ihesu christ said. I know well what ye require give unto us the
archebysshop Vdo. And incontinent some of the presents departed and drew the
cursed Vdo from the bed of the said abbess a led him myserably. When saint
Mauryce saw him he said. My lord ryghtwyse judge / Judge justly / here is Vdo he
is no bishop but a wulfe / no pastoure but a rauyssher / a sleer / and
deuourer of thy flock. This here is also he unto whom thy lady mother has
given science to whom she has reco^maunded this church made in thonour of
thy name and of me and of my felawes: and him before warned and said. If thou
govern the well thou shalt have life pardurable. And if you govern the ill you
shalt deye in body and in soul. Morouer he has be warned three times and he
would not correcke him / and he has profaned and brought unto naught not all
only this church but himself and the souls the which were unto him
committed / and with that has vyoled folyly and foully thyn espouses. Than you
ryghtwyse judge / Judge justly. These things spoken our lord yt preceded in
Judgment in beholdynge ye saints said What think you of this to be done. The
champyon yt held the sword al naked cried with an hye voice saying. He is
culpable of death. And the Judge and all the saints the which were present
concorded in sentence and treated togyders what manner of death he should
suffer. Than ye judge said / he has deserved to lose his heed. That is to have
it smyten of. When these words were spoken the champyon bad Vdo hastily to
stretche out his neck. When Vdo had stretched it and yt the champyon had lift
up the sword to give ye stroke one cried and said. Hold thyn hand till the
relykes ben taken from him Than one Quida^ came unto Vdo holdy^ge a chalyce.
And the champyon smote many strokes with his fyst upon the neck of Vdo / and at
each stroke an hostye soyled issued out by ye mouth of Vdo and fell in to the
chalyce. The which hostyes our lord took reuere^tly and washed them for to
take away ye fylth Afterward he put them wtin the chalyce upon the auter /
and enclyned him besemyngly with his company and yode his way and departed. And
after that the said champion took the myscheuous Vdo and beheeded him. And than
all that company departed. Certainly the beforesayd chanone a Just man the
which saw this thing / not in dreme but with eyes open abashed trembling
found fire in the place of the relykary and lyghted again the lamps of the
church. And as he was yet abashed of the deed and admeruayled him / little and
little he took hardynes / approached al in peace unto the place of Judgment / and
saw upon the awter ye chalyce with the hostyes and the heed cast far from the
body and the pauement wette of ye blood Than he began to cry and to say. O
traytre behold. O great miracle. O that ye Judgment of god is to dread. O yt
it is a thing horrible as to fall in to the hands of the lyuy^ge god. For of
those the which endures longly to the end that they convert them when they
will not convert them they da^pne themself more hardely. After all ye things
beforesayd the said chanone shytte the gates with the keys. And suffered not in
any wise that none entered till unto the time of the rysynge of the son that he
called all ye clerks and lay men. Than he opened ye gates and shew^d unto all
the meruaylous and cruel vengeance how god ye creator had Iuged and
punysshed the archebysshop Vdo And recounted by order all the deed in likewise
as it is before written / how it was done. And the same day one of ye chapelayns
of ye said archebisshop named Brunet wha^ he had made parfayte and
accomplysshed his lygacyon co^mysed by the prouynce sent his servants before
/ and he was oppressed grievously to sleep. He auysed a tree well shadowed and
derke descended from his horse and teyed fast the rain of his bridle unto his
arm and slept. When he was in rest he saw in vysyon a gadery^ge of horrible
black spyrites with busynes / trompets / tympanes / speres / glayues / and axes
/ the which hasted the^ to come unto the place. When they were altogyder there
was one of the^ prince and most horrible of stature. And they made a chair and
set him in it. And without long tarienge an other multitude of spyrites as great
as the other appeared cryenge / mocking / and dauncynge / whereof one came
hastily cryenge. Give place / give place here is our pry^ce Vdo yt approaches.
After this saying ye satalytes of Satan led unto their pry^ce the soul of
the cursed Vdo in semblaunce corporal having a chain of fire strayte about
his neck / against whom Satan arose and salued him by words peasybles in
ill and treason. Thou art right welcome O prince aydour and delatatour of our
realm / here we ben ready to yield unto the ye reward equyualent for thy
deservings / and also unto all our faithful friends. And as Vdo held his
peace Satan said to ye presents. Our friend is right weary in his cominge hyder
/ and therefore it pleases unto us yt he be chered / give unto than to ete / he
refused it and turned his heed. And his mynysters constrained him vyolently to
ete of todes and serpents / and after they made him to drink of ye lycoure of
sulphre / yet he spoke not. And Satan commanded him saying. Such a prince be
led to be bayned and incontinent brought again. And there was a well not
far of that had a coueringe on the mouth. When it was uncovered flambe
devouring lept up unto the heaven The which wasted noc all only the trees and
mountains and stones / but the water being nere unto it dried and consumed.
The deuyls kest the soul of the said Vdo wtin the laid well / and afterward
drew him out ye which was all on fire as iron enbrased and reed / and bare
him unto their prince / ye which laughed and said. Have you not had a soft
bayne as a prince. Than Vdo saw himself dampened. And began to blaspheme and
say. Satan cursed be you / thy felawes / and thy subgectio^ and thy reame.
Cursed be god yt has created me. Cursed be the earth the which bare me:
Cursed be my parents that begat me and cursed be all creatures in heaven and in
earth. Than all the deuylles with their pry^ce clapped their hands and said.
Truly this man here is worthy too dwell with us / for he can well our cantycle and
our office. Than be he put to our pryncypall scole of the dampened to the end yt
he se / here / learn / feel / and frothensforthe never to issue. Scantly had he
ended his words yt the deuylles took that cursed soul and kest it and plonged
in to hell with so great shoutes and noise as if ye heaven and the earth and all
the mountains of the world were moeued to smite together When the chapelayne
beforesayd had seen and herd the said things he dredde hugely Than the prince
of derkenes showed him with the finger and said. Take heed that ye clerk the
which beholds us fle not the which has been evermore defensour / messager
and currour of his euylles. Than in likewise as he has been encreaser of his
sin so let him be partener of the vengeance / and therefore be he plonged in
the well with his lord. When he had spoken that as the deuylles would rauysshe
him he enforced him to fle and awok suddenly / and his horse was so aferde yt he
lepte hyder and thither and ran drawing the meschaunt man till that he was
unbound of the rain yt was about his arm. And with great dyffyculte he lepte
upon his horse and came to the cite metropolytayne And when he knew yt his
lord was deed he approved the vysyon to be true / and recou^ted all the things
the which unto him were comen in the way / and all that / yt he had seen and
herd. So they knew the thing to be veritable. When the cytezyns had seen and
herd this terryble thing they drew ye carayne of the body far fro the cite
in a place full of fylthe. And for ye in the said place bestes infernalles were
by wise counceyle ye cursed body was brent and the ashes casten in to a water.
A thing meruaylous men tell yt all the fysshes left the place and yode in to ye
see and were there till god was apeased by fastings and letanyes. Ten years
after scantely came they again. The demonstr^u^ce of the said horrible thing
appears on ye white pauement where the said Vdo was beheded. For the cruour of
the effusyon of ye blood enharded so strongly in the stones of the pauement yt
it seems that the said blood be of thessence of ye stones the which ben there
yet. And over yt place where the decollacyon ben always tapytes spread. And wha^
they sing (Te deu^ laudamus) upon a bishop chosen he is borne unto the said
place and there they prosterne them in orayson to ye end yt the bishop that
is chosen behold ye said thing / and also to keep hy^ yt he perysshe not as
did the other. This thing was done of our lord to the terror of bisshops
and ill prelates to the end that they tremble to here the terryble Judgment and
the cruel vengeance of god. This example denotes many things. First yt the
said Vdo used ill the science and the counceyle yt he had of the vyrgyn Mary.
Also those the which use ill the science that they have of god be^ to punyshe
and sin gretely. Vn^ jacob. iiii Scienti bonu^ facere and non facienti pctm^
e^ illi. Also he used ill of the prelature and of the goods of the church yt
god had given unto him. He should be the light of virtues and of bounte / and
he was the sklaunder of ye people / and the example of derkenesses and of
sin. Also he used his life in lecheryes and was corrupter of vyrgynyte and
chastyte / and therefore he was worthy of punycyon. Also he would not correke
him and yet he was warned from god. And for yt he was so obstynate and harded
in sin and replete of carnal pleasaunces yt he would not correcke hy^ of
good right he was iuged and punisshed in body and in soul as it is said. This
here is the example of all prelates / curates / and people of the church /
they should understand here if they use ill of the dygnyte and charge that
they have yt god shall punysshe them cruelly more than these simple persons
ye which ne knows / a / ne / b. And therefore who so loves him keep him from
doing ill. Another example in mani books how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says yt in the dyoc and archebysshopryche of Maydenburgh /
there was an archebisshop named Loye / the which was in a dance the which
was in a town of his said dioc and of his sygnoury of women vyrgyns and of
other of masculyn sex. And by ye suffraunce of god as men said the fire took
in ye base court of the house where the dance was / and the said fire brent it
and no person ne deyed among so great nombre of men and women the which were
there / but ye archebysshop and a maiden yt he had led in the dance And
albeit some persons fell by the wyndowes and ne ran in point of death.

Peni inferni.
A. Examples how mortal syn^e makes the sinners inobedyentes to have many
pains and doloures wtin the fire of hell. And first example of a fader of an
household the which saw two pondes and the tourmentes of hell. Cvii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says that ye fader of a household yielded his soul
to god / and all his household watched him and kept his body by night / by the
dyuyne mercy he reuyued and yode unto ye church to yield thanks unto god. And
al yt he had he gave to the church and to the poores. Afterward he yode unto
an hermytage / and by a water made his dwelling / and entered wtin ye said
water and let his clothes to be ysy and frosen nere unto his flesh. And
after yt he entered in to a bayne right hot / and sustained such pain till
unto the death. And when he was repreued to endure such pain he said. If ye
had seen that yt I have seen ye should do with me that I do / or more greter
thing. And he recounted terryble things of the pains of hell in saying yt
when his soul departed fro his body an angel led him in to a valey of
infynyte gretenes. In the which there were two pondes / the one was full of
worms and of flambes of fire eygrely brennynge and hot. And the other ponde
was frosen / and there was terrible coldness of snow and of hayle. And these
two pondes were full of souls terrybly tourmented / ye which when they might
no more sustain the great cruelte of the fire they passed in to the cold. And
they yt might not sustain ye coldenes passed in to the hot. etc. Afterward
the angel led him by derkenes right thycke and there saw little flambes
and little hepes and assemblementes of fire the which proceeded from ^he
furneys of hell and mounted as hye as sperkles of fire and men of fire through
them proceeded / and there felt stynke intolerable / and there herd wepynges
/ waylynges / and howlings incomperables and saw the deuylles right terrybles
yt held hokes of fire / the which coueyted to catch ye fader of the
household to cast him in ye furneys / but ye angel defended yt they should
not touch hy^. For ye judge had commanded yt he should return in to his body
for to do penance. And there he did such penance yt it passed man's
reason. After he deyed ioyously. etc. To ye purpose of this example yt speaks
of ye fyry ponde saint John^ says apo. Qui no^ est i^ue^tus i^ libro vite
scriptus missus e^ i^ stagnu^ ignis arde^tis and sulphuris. He the which is
not found written in ye book of life when he is deed is sent in to a ponde of
fire brennynge and of sulphre. This ponde here whereof speaks saint Johan is
not of cold water or boylynge wherein the sinners ben plonged / drowned / or
boiled / as falls money makers / but it is by symylitude as a ponde or a cawdron
of fire and of sulpre molten brennynge and boylynge wherein the dampened ben sent
there to be plonged / smored / brent and broyled the which is the second
death that comes after the death corporel / whereof speaks saint Gregory in
his moralles. Fit miseris mors sine morte / finis sine fine / defectus sine
defectu. etc. Example of a fader and his sone the which were seen in hell in
tourmente of fire brennynge boylynge as does the peason in a pot on the
fire. Quere.lxxiii. Also saint Johan says in the appocalyps that the
homycydes fornycatours / enuenymours / ydolatres / and all liars shall be sent
in to a ponde brennynge of fire and sulphre the which is the second death.
Vn^ appoca. xxi. Pars illoru^ erit i^ stagno ardenti igne et sulphur quod est
mors secunda. Unto ye purpose of the second po^de the which was frosen and
that the dampened passed from the ponde of fire in to that of the cold. It is
written job. xxiiii. Ad calorem nimium transiet ab aquis niuiu^. And from the
great cruelte of cold and of torments that the dampened have god says in ye
gospelles yt they shall weep and grynde their tethe of great pain yt they shall
endure. Vnde math. viii. xxiiii. Et luc. xiii Ibi erit fletus et stridor
dentium.

B. Another example how a rich man was put in a chyare of fire. Cvii
THe dyscyple recyteth how a devout man saw by vysyon a rich man led in to
hell yt had been much honored in this world and exceded in worldly glory / in
glotony / lechery / in songs / and in diverse solaces. And the prince of the
deuylles rose up from his chair / came before him / and made him to sytte in a
chair all of fy^^ / and said unto him. Sit you here for the honor that thou
have had in the world. And was constrained to drink of lycour right bitter /
stynkynge / and foul. And they said to hy that it was for yt he had dronken in
ye world the drynkes full of swetenesses / and two deuylles were there with
trompettes the which blewe in his eeres yt the flambes of fire yode out by the
eyes / nosethrylles / mouth / and eres. And it was said unto him yt it was for
the bayne / and songs that he had herd in ye world. And they put serpents
about his neck and unto his arms / and said unto him yt it was for the
embracements of women that he had had in living lecherously. etc.

C. Another example of a woman that saw ye pains of her husbonde and of other
dampened. Cvii
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says yt a knight right puyssaunt was abandoned
in tourneyments the which lived myserably / and myscheuously deyed. His wife
the which abode wydowe was right devout and holy. The which recompted unto
her brother Albert master of the order of the prechours that after ye death of
her said husband she was rauisshed in spyryte and saw by the soul of her
said husband great multitude of deuylles assembled. And the one of them the
which appeared to be master commanded unto his companyons and felawes yt they
should put a pair of hosen on his fete of the which the pryckes otherwise
called darts perced him from the plant of the feet till unto the brain.
Afterward he made him to be clothed in a haubergyon whereof the pryckinges
perced all his body on all parts before and behind Afterward he made to put
on his heed an helm of the which the pryckes in descendynge perced him till
unto the plant of ye foot. Afterward he made to put upon his sholder a shield
otherwise called a mark or token the which was so heavy that al his members
were frusshed. After yt the prince of the deuylles had made all these things
to be done to the said cursed soul he said again unto the said deuilles. The
custom of this man was yt after his tourneyme^ts that he used baynes / and
after his baynes that he was laid in his bed and by him a tender maiden the
which he enbraced and with her meddled / appropre ye him semblable things. And
without taryeng the said soul was much tourmented bayned in a bayne of fire /
and afterward laid in a bed of fire brennynge and fast by him a tode of the
gretenes of ye bed the which was so horrible and had so terryble eyes yt of
the enbrasynge and of the atouchynge and of the kissynge that the said tode
made and of the horrible lokes he was more brent and tourmented than he ne had
be before of the said armoures / of the bayne / and of the bed. Alas what
pains have those the which in such wise ben tourmented. That blyssed woman
yt saw by the dyspensacyon of god the things before said vnte ye soul of her
said husband was so much tourmented that marvel it was all the days of her
life of the recordacyon of the vysyon before reherced of her husband.

D. Another example how a servant saw his master the which was led in to
pains. Cvii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that there was a noble man oppressor and persecutour of
poor people and loved the world. The which as he rested him in his bed his
servant the which lay before his chamber was rauysshed by vysyon before yt
throne of god. And there saw his said master yt was accused of all ye things
yt he had done / and for them sentence of dampnacyon was given and was led of
deuylles before Lucyfer with great dauncynge. Unto whom Lucyfer said. Approach
unto me mine own faithful servant yt I may kiss hy^ And when he was before
hy^ Lucyfer said Peace be not with the in eternyte. Again Lucyfer said. He had
of custom too bathe him / led him unto the bayne. Than was he bayned of a
bayne infernal and much tormented with the nails of the deuylles / and some
kest fire upon him. After he was laid in a bed infernal. And Lucyfer
commanded that after the bayne men should give him to drink in the chalyce of
ye ire of god. And he was constrained to drink of fire and sulphre molten
togyders. And as he cried it suffysed Lucyfer said. He had of custom to here
symphonyes. So there arose up two symphonyatours the which were two deuylles
with instruments full of fire the which blewe against him in such manner that
from his eyes and his mouth and fro his nose the flambes of fire yode out.
After Lucyfer made him to be brought and said to him. Thou have song of so^ges
sing me one. And he said. What shall I sing / but that cursed be the day yt I
was borne. And Lucyfer said unto him. Sing a better song. And he answered.
What shall I sing / but cursed be the fader that begat me And lucyfer said
unto hy^ / sing yet a better. And the accursed said / but that cursed be that
god the which has suffered that I was borne upon ye earth / unto this purpose
says the psalmyst. No^ mortui laudabunt te dn^e: neque oe^s qui desce^dunt in
i^fernu^. And lucyfer said / here is the song that I would have / led him
unto the place yt he has deserved. And he was cast in to a pytte of fire.
Than ye deuylles made so great daunsynge that it seemed that all should fall.
And at the said daunsynge the servant of the said man awoke. The which ran
unto ye chamber of his said master and found him deed. Than he told the said
vysyon. etc.

A. Another example of a scoler of Paris the which appeared unto his master
after his death in great torments. Cviii
IT is written in ye legende of ye deed that one of the masters of Paris named
scilo prayed right gretely his scoler that if he deyed that he would appear
unto him after his death for to denounce unto him of his estate if it pleased
unto god. And one time after he appeared / the which was clothed with a cloak
of parchemente all written withouteforth of sophyms / and within enflambed with
fire / and the said master demanded him what he was He answered I am he the
which has promised to come again unto the and he was axed of his estate he
said. This cloak weyeth more on me than a great toure / the which is given me
to bear for the vaynglorye yt I took in the arguments / of sophistrye / yt is
to say fallacyous. And the flambe of fire ye which brenneth me is given for
the furs delicyeuses that I wore. And as the said master said that such
pain was light to bear. The deed body said unto him that he should s^retche
out his hand and that he should feel the lyghtnes of his pain. And when he
had stretched out his hand ye said deed body let fall a drop of his sweet
the which perced the said hand more sooner then should do an arowe / and
said unto him. I am all such. And the said master felt so horrible torment
that he was so ferde that he left the world and entered in to relygyon. In
like wise as tells the chaunter of paris. etc.

B. Another example of the soul dampened yt wept the time yt he had lost.
IT is written in the book of dread yt as a holy man was in orayson he herd by
the will of god a voice horrible weeping. He demanded who it was yt in such
wise wept. Answer was made the which said. I am a soul dampened. And he
demanded wherefore wepest thou so bytterly. He answered and said that one of
the things wherefore he and all the dampened sorrow most fore is that yt they
have lost and consumed the time of grace vnprouffytably in synnynge / where in
an hour by repentance they might have gotten grace and escaped the torments
wherein they be and shall be eternally. By this example these sinners should
understand that it is the most great good deed that may be in them as to be
in the state of grace well confessed / and repentaunte of their sins. Also by
that that this soul wept in hell is unto the purpose of that that the
euangylles say that the dampened weep in hell Vnde mathei.viii. Et luce.xiiii.
Ibi erit flet^s et stridor dentiu^. Unto this purpose tongdalus ye which saw
the torments of hell and afterward was brought again told yt he saw in
hell a torment of an yzy ponde where the souls the which therein were
tormented cried so horrybly that they were herd unto heaven. And after where
the said tongdalus spoke of the pytte of hell he herd great cries and
howlinges of souls and thondre so horrible that no man ne might think ne
tongue declare the horrible cry and the noise ye which was in the said
torment. etc.

C. Another example of two men ye which were in pains when saint taurayn
areysed them. Cviii
IT is written in the legende of saint taurayn ye tidings were brought unto a
right honorable man that his sone and his squyere were deed. And for to
abredge the matere saint taurayne areysed the said sone. The which yode
incontinent on knees before saint taurayne and required him to be baptized. And
after that he was baptized said unto his fader Halas fader thou know what
miserable life we led and what pains those sustain the which ben semblables
unto us And what glory is unto those ye which love and serve unto that god
the which is to be honored of man. Certay^ly I have seen him to be in the
company of aungelles and to pray unto god for us. And when ye said sone
arey^ed had spoken these words and many other unto his fader he yode on knees
before saint tauryn and caused him to baptyze him. And also his wife mother of
the said raised. And for to be short in that day so many of great lords as
of little people a thousand and two hundred persons were baptized. And
afterward at the request of the said sone areysed saint tauryn areysed also
afterward the squire ye which wytnessed that he was in great pains when a
messengere came to tell him of the sovereign master that he were brought
again and taken unto saint tauryn. And this said squire areysed said unto the
said sone. He the which has brought me again heder commands the that
thou dispose the to return unto him. And incontinent a fever took him / and
after the commandment deyed.

D. Another example of.iii. deed men areysed the which recompted of ye pains
of purgatory and of hell / and how they were in judgment before god. Cviii
IT is written in the epystyll of ye holy bishop named sirillus that by ye
merytes of saint Iherome the which appeared unto saint eusebe three deed bodies
were areysed for to take away a great error the which reigned in ye time
among the greeks yt it came in the latyns of ye heretykes yt said that the
ylle persons ne should have of torments in hell till unto ye day of Judgment
yt the body and the soul should be remyt togyders. The three deed bodies yt were
areysed lived.xx. days / ye which were demanded why they wept so sore. And
the one of them said unto hy^ yt asked it. If thou knew the pains the which
before yesterday I endured thou sholdest have evermore cause to weep. and he
was required to tell what pains he had endured and suffered within hell. /
He said that the dampened and those in purgatory have so great pains yt if a
person should endure in this world all ye pains / torments / and
afflyccions that a man may think / that ne should be but consolacyon to endure
all that / in regard of the leest pain of purgatory / or of hell. Also he
said / if any living had felt the experyence of the dolor the which is in
hell or in purgatory / that he should love better to endure till unto the end
of ye world without any remedy togyders all the pains and torments that all
the men and women has endured one after another sith Adam unto now / than to
be tormented one day in the leest pain that is in hell or in purgatory. And
therefore if ye axe me what ye cause is wherefore I weep. It is for that yt I
knowledge me to have sinned against god / and that justly he punyssheth the
sy^ners. Wherefore I weep to have deserved such punycyon. Afterward he was
axed wherein dyffereth ye pains / and torments of purgatory / and those of
hell. He answered that they ne dyffere as unto ye qualyte and quantyte of
pains they ben of one self gretenes / but they differe in asmoche as the
pains of hell have none end. And also the dampened shall have augmentacyon of
torments in Judgment when they shall there be tormented in body and in soul.
And the pains of purgatory shall have an end. For wha^ the penance is
accomplysshed / those of purgatory ben delivered. Also he was asked if those
the which ben in purgatory and in hell have egalle torments or diverse. He
answered that the one have more great torments and diverse than the other
after the quantyte and gretenes of sins that they have committed. And also
the dampened albeit that they ben in a place of pains / yet feel they more
great torments the one than ye other / after the quantyte / and qualytees of
sins that they have committed. For in the person where there is more of
matere of sin / and more strongly the fire him takes and bre^neth more
cruelly. Also he was demanded how he bare the deed when the soul^ issued out
from the body. He answered / When mine hour of death came in place where I
was he found so many of deuylles that a man ne might nombre the^ for the
great multitude the which were so horrybles to behold that a man ne can
think more great pain than it is. Any man had lever cast himself more sooner
in a fire flambynge and brennynge than to behold them with the eye / the
which deuylles came unto me and brought again unto my mind all ye cursed
operacyons that I had done again god esmouynge that I ne had more of
esperaunce of ye dyuyne mercy the which I have gretely offended. And certes
know ye yt if ye mercy of god ne had aided me I ne might have resysted unto
them. For when my spyryte was destytute of all force little and little I me
consented unto their words / and saint Iherome arrived more clear than the
son with great multitude of angels the which came unto mine aid. And the
said saint Iherome blamed them / and they departed with great howlings and
clamours. etc. For to abrydge this matter the said areysed said that his soul
was borne before god in judgment in like wise as a man may shyrte the eye /
but how ne of whom he ne knew. More over he said all the sins that he had
done / spoken / and thought in all his life appeared clearly unto the judge and
before al in like wise as they had been present / so that there ne abode ye
most little thought but that it appeared / so it had be thought. Also he said
that he was replenysshed with so great fere that meruayll it was. And that
great multitude of deuylles were there present the which witness the ylles
that we have done in declarynge the place / the manner and ye time and the ylles
that men spoke against us / we ne may again say them in no manner. For the
judge knows and sees al Also the iustes and presents it seen and know. Alas
what shall I say / we ne abide more than the sentence to be brought forth
again us. For all the presents cry unto the judge yt we ben dygne of
torments. And almoost no good deed appeared wherein we had esperaunce to have
the mercy of god. And when he ne resysted more as to bryngforth the sentence
ye which is justly given again the sinners ye blyssed saint Iherome was
present. Also were present saint Johan baptyst saint peter / and great
multitude of aungelles the which required of the Judge that our sentence were
yet dyfferred a little of time for ye reverence and devotion that we had made
unto the said saint Iherome / And for to destroy the error the which reigned
in the world. And he was accorded unto the said saint Iherome that yt he
required. The which led us with hy^ And showed us the glory of ye blyssed
souls and the pains of hell and of purgatory / to the end that we might
wytnes certain that thing yt we have seen. The which things be not here
written for because of shortness. And would that we were put within the pains of
purgatory to the end that we should prove the experyence of the pains the
which there ben in ye which we were put. For to abrydge the said saint
Iherome us commanded that we should come again in to our bodies And that we
should wytnes that that we had seen / and us promised that on the.xx day if we
did dygne penance of ye sins that we had committed that we should deye
again with saint Eusebe the which should deye on the said day and we should
have glory. And so our souls were in contynent within their bodies. etc.

E. Another example how a devil said that the soul of the earl Guyllaume was
in horrible pain. Cviii.
IT is written in dialogo cesarii this the which follows how the dyscyple
recyteth in his book and says that as a knight was at the death in his bed
all alone the devil appeared unto him vysybly in form and semblaunce of a she
ape the which had the horns of a got. And when he se hy^ there in such wise
he had fere and him demanded what art thou and what sekest thou. He answered I
am a devil the which am come for to fetch thy soul. Unto whom the said
knight said depart thou fro me cursed there / I have commanded it unto Ihesu
christ that I have received in the sacrament. And ye devil said. Varlet if
thou will do me homage I shall yield unto the health and I shall enryche the
above all thy parents And the knight him demanded where ben thy tresours. He
answered treasours infynyte ben hid nere unto thy court / And the said
knight asked him / tell me where is the soul of the earl guyllaume ye which
is lately deed. He answered. It is in hell in so great fire that if the most
great mountain were there it should be consumed in less of time than to close
ye eye. And that pain there is but a bayne of milk in the regard of the day
of Judgment where he shall receive the pain And he asked him of another man.
And he answered he has be.xxxi. years in pains / but a monk and a mynchen
has delivered him by good deeds. And again he demanded the devil. From whens
came thou when thou came to me. He answered. I and my fellows were at the
death of an abbess awaytynge her soul. And ye knight him demanded. How many
ben ye. He answered that the most great forest of the world has not so many
of leaves as we were. And the knight demanded him. What have ye done. He
answered Alas nothing / she was a good relygyous / and saint Myghell came
theder the which beat us and departed in like wise as departs the poudre
before the wind / and he was axed if he were at the death of such an abbot.
He answered yt there is not so much of gravel in the sea as there was of
deuylles / but we ne did nothing / for the vyllaynes monks ye which there
were and groned as hogs ne would let us to approach. And the said knight
said. how dare ye go unto the death of so holy a man And the devil said I was
at the death of the sone of god / and set me on the arm of ye cross /
wherefore dare I not than go unto the death of such a man. etc.

F. Another example how a relygyous would more sooner enter in to a fire than
to behold the devil. Cviii
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt one time a relygyous
came unto ye death ye which cried horrybly / cursed be the hour that ever I
was relygyous / and after held his peace And within a little while afterward
he began to laugh with a Joyous face and said Nay. But blessed be the time
that I entered in to the order. And blyssed be the glorious mother of Ihesu
christ that I love and again held his peace. The freres ye which were by him
and herd these words wept and prayed for him. Two hours after he said unto
a friar the which was by him / call my bredern. For god has exalted their
prayers. And he said unto them when they were entered. My bredren ye were
troubled of the first word I said unto you / but the cause of ye word was
for that that the deuylles horrible appeared unto me / the which would rauysshe
my soul. And for the dread I was rauysshed out of my self and cursed ye hour
that I entered in to relygyon I tell you yt if a great fire were here melled with
brymstone / and that I had to chose to put me within it or else to behold
again ye deuylles in ye form that I have seen them I should chose more
sooner to put me in the fire than to behold them afterward the queen of heaven
and of mercy came the which chased away the deuylles. And when I se her I
conceived esperaunce / and for the great joy that I had I have laughed and
blyssed the hour that I entered in to relygyon and the vyrgyn mary When he had
spoken these words he deyed debonayrly. etc.

A. Another example how the vysyon of the devil is horrible. Cix.
IT is written in some books this ye which follows that the dyscyple recyteth
in his promptuarye and says yt the abbot of saint agathe came unto coleyne
with one of his monks and a conuers with a woman demonyacle. And when ye abbot
asked the devil of some things he ne would an^wer. The abbot said afterward.
I conjure the by him that I have trayted in the mass that thou answer me. And
incontinent the devil answered unto tho things yt men demanded hy^ After the
abbot coniured him yt he should go forth of the woman. The devil answerde.
And wheder shall I go. The abbot said I have opened my mouth to ye end that
thou there enter. The devil said I ne may there enter / for this day the right
hault god there entered. Than ye abbot said. Lepe upon my two fyngers / my
thombe and that next it. The devil answered I will not for you have this day
trayeted the right hault with them. And he said unto him that he should go forth.
The devil said the right haulte ne will it not / I shall be yet two years in
her / and than she shall be delivered. And so was it done. / Than the monk
and the conuers prayed ye abbot that he would show himself unto them in form
naturell. And he first refused it afterward he would it and said unto the
devil. I command the in ye virtue of Ihesu christ that thou appyere unto us
in thy natural kind. And the devil said And will ye not depart if ye se me
not / and the abbot said nay. Than the devil showed himself so horrible
within ye body of the woman that it was meruayll to se / his eyes sparcled as a
furnayse embrased in fire smokynge. When ye said monk and conuers saw yt they
fell unto ye earth as deed for fere / you abbot had also fallen if he had not
commanded ye devil to take his first form. The which things he did and
the devil said. Thou never commanded me so folysshe a thing / know thou
for certain yt if you had not received this day the dyuyne things / none
of you ne had reported unto any man that ye I have showed / wenest thou that a
man may seem and live / nay. In the end the monk and the conuers were reuyued
by cold water. etc.

B. Another example how a man considered if after a hondreth thousand years
the dampened should be delivered from hell. Cix.
THe dysciple recites in his promptuarye and says that as a man much
seculer and delycatyf thought one time unto himself if after a hundred
thousand years the souls of ye dampened should be delivered from pains. And
his thought answered him that nay And after a hundred thousand years nay.
And if after as many of years as there are of drops of water in the sea nay.
And in thinking such things he was much troubled. And as he was ferfull he
began to understand and to apperceyue that the lovers of ye world acursed and
in derkenes the which run in pains eternelles for a little of time that
they live in this world in joys transytoryes in the will of the flesh. A
man should here understand yt when the sinners deye impenytentes / obstynate /
and abide in their sins and them bear with them with taking away the gylte
of the said sins by contrycyon and penance ne without asking any grace ne
mercy of as much as when they live in this world and that they have the time
and the place that to do. And for as much as the soul is eternell and
immortal the which shall be sent in to the fire of hell there for to abide /
and that she shall have with her evermore sin the which is ye matere of the
fire that it shall brenne. In like wise the soul shall evermore suffer pain
and evermore shall brenne with ye said fire the which never shall have mercy
nor grace. etc.

C. Another example that it enjoyed unto a person to be in a good bed wtoute
departing. Cix
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple yt the bishop of marseylle
said unto himself. When I was a lover of the world / and had given me unto
worldly vanytes I began to think one time of the eternyte of the pains of
hell. And I said in my heart. If thou were establed to lie the evermore in a
bed soft and delycatyf in such manner that you sholdest not depart for any
occasyon so ever it should be / with great pain sholdest thou sustain that.
How may thou than lie and brenne in such pain eternell / intolerable in
hell if it fall that thou be theder sent. By this occasyon I left all and
made me monk. etc.

D. Another example how a yongman made him relygyous for to think if his fair
members should be the pasture and the matere of the fire of hell. Cix
IT is written in some books this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his promptuarye and says that one time as master iordayn persewaded a
young man noble fair of members that he should enter in to the order of
prechers / he found him that he was not prompte that to do. And he said unto
hy^ in the end of ye words. I pray the that thou do it incontinent for the
love of god or behold thy hands and the other fair members / what do^mage
shall that be if so fair members shall be the pasture of ye fire eternell. And
he did it. For for this thing he entered in to ye order and so contemned
himself for the love of god.

Rapina.
E. Another example of ye punycyon of a knight the which took away ye cow
of a woman wedowe. Cix.
SOme masters has written this the which follows how the dyscyple recyteth
in his book of sermons and says that one time a knight took away the cow of a
woman wedowe / and as she wept and prayed him to restore it for to nourysshe
her children. The knight answered. If I took her not another after me should
come the which should take her After her death by the suffraunce of god the
said knight was seen that first many great deuylles hedeous and black hy^
tormented right cruelly and horrybly / and specially one amongst all the
other ceased not to beat him and to torment hy^ with out being weary / or
without leuyng him Than the said knight him demanded Wherefore tormentest thou
me more than all the other deuylles the which ben here He answered / if I
tormented the not another should the torment as thou saydest to the good woman
of her cow that thou tokest away / if thou tokest her not another should take
her. etc. By this example it is to understand that the said knight was right
dygne of pain and punycyon For he did unto the good woman that yt he ^e would
a man should do him again the commandment of god the which is love thy
neighbor as thyselfe / ne do unto another no more than thou woldeste a man
should do the. Vnde leuitici.xix. and ma. xxii. Diliges proximu^ tuu^ sicut
teipsum Et thobie.iiii. Quod ad alio tibiodis fieri. vide ne tu aliqn^ alteri
facias. Et ysido. Quod non vis pati no^ facias quod no^ vis tibi fieri alteri
nu^quam i^feras. Non inferas alii mala ne patiaris similia. The said knight had
no will that a man should take away his cow as he did unto ye said wedowe.
And for yt was he punysshed etc.

F. Another example of a rauyssher in pain the which took ye got of a woman
wedowe / and did of great oppressyons unto his subgectes. Cix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt a relygyous of the
order of cysternencis labored unto ye death / he saw saint benet the which
came unto the seperacyon of his soul / the which showed unto him many houses
of the saved and of the torments of ye damned. And among ye other he saw a
great prince borne brennynge and resydente in a chayer of fire. And before him
there was of fair women ye which put their faces of fire in his mouth / and
he brenned till unto the nombryll / and he was bette horrybly. This said man
had be a puyssaunt princes lecherous. After ye said lecherous he saw another
that ye deuylles did fle / And afterward they cast and spryncled of salt
upon him. And upon a gyrdyron of fire burnt him and roasted. This said man had
be a lord cruel the which made of great oppressyons unto his subgectes /
and made of demau^des unjust unto ye poores Afterward ye said relygyous saw
another the which rode a horse of fire and had a token of fire the which
otherwise men call a bokelet / and bare a got of fire. And after the tail of
the got he bare an habyte of a monk. This said man was a rauyssher the which
took the got of a woman wedowe. And when he was seek he received ye habyte of
a monk / not by charity ne by will to abide in the order if he might be hole.
But by theadmonycyon of his friends / and for that he drew the habyte of a
monk after him. Afterward ye said relygyous saw many other people the which
sustained many other pains after the symylytude of the manners that they had
sinned in this world. It is that whereof the sage speak. Sapie^.xi. Per q^
peccat homo: per hec et torquetur. By ye thing that a man synneth by that shall
he be tormented to the end that he have evermore remors in his conscience that
ylle that he endures its given unto him for his propre sins. Vnde Ysaye
vltimo: et marci. ix. Vernus eoru^. s. morsus conscie^tie non moritur and ignis
no^ extinguitur.

A. Another example how a myller was borne to se the torments of hell and
after was brought again in to his body.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in his
promptuary and says that as a man preched of the cross a carle usurer bought
again a vow for money that he had made unto ye sepulcre of iherusale^ And
yode unto the dyspensatour fraudelently / and gave unto him for his said vow an
hundred shelynges as he might well give xlviii.li. without dysherytynge his
children. And as this said carle sat at the tauernes he said unto the other the
which had made of vows. Ye foles shall pass the sea in peril of your
lives and shall dyspende your substance I have bought my vow for five pound /
saved my life and dwell sure in my house. And also I shall have semblable
reward as you. And in a night as he was in his bed with his wife he herd in
his mylle mouynge tempeste In like wise as the wheles gryndynge / And he said
unto his sone goo se who is in the mylle He yode and returned anon with great
fere. Of whom the master demanded. What have thou seen. He answered I had so
great fere at the door of the mylle / that I must nedely come again. And he
said if the devil were there yet should I go to see what it is. Than he cast
his vestiment upon his sholdres and yode unto the myll / he was all naked but
of the said vestyment. He opened the door and looked within / and saw two
horses right black / and a black man by them and said unto ye carle have the
lepe upon this horse the which is brought unto the. That carle had fere / and
the black man said unto him / what taryest thou / cast away thy vestymente
and come / there was on the vestyment a cross. He was dyspeyred at ye voice
and calling of the devil kest away his vestyment and lepte upon the horse.
And ye black man lepte upon the other horse / and they were led incontinent
in diverse places of pains. In the which ye acursed saw his fader and his
mother. And many other yt he had known. And he saw a knight named Helye of the
castle Horst the which was mounted upon a cow his back toward the horns.
The which cow ran on the one side and on the other and tormented horrybly the
said knight in strykyng him with her horns on the back. And ye carle him
demanded wherefore he sustained such pain / and he answered. I have rauysshed
this cow and taken away from a woman wedowe without mercy. And therefore she
me tormenteth without mercy. Afterward there was showed unto ye said carle a
sege of fire and it was said unto him. Thou shall return even now in to thy
house. And after three days thou shalt come again in to this place here / and
thou shalt take thy reward in this syege. After these words here the devil
brought him again in to his mylle And he found his wife and his household as
half deed / unto whom he told that / that he had seen. And how it happened.
The priest was called for to chere him and to counsayll him to confess him /
and to have contrycyon. And he answere^ what proffyte me these words here I ne
may repent me. For I se that in vain I should confess me. And I know that
of necessyte it is to accomplysshe in me yt the which is dysposed. And the
acursed deyed so without receyuynge the sacraments of the church. etc.

B. Another example that a knight deyed / and after was brought again in to
his body / the which recompted of a bridge right strayte upon a water by ye
which him behooves to pass. Cx.
IT is written in ye dyalogue of saint gregorye that a knight deyed and within a
little after came again in to his body ye which told yt he had seen a bridge
under the which bridge ran a water stynkynge and dark. And on the other
side of the bridge there was meadows smelly^ge sweet and aourned with all
flowers And in those meadows were assembled of people clothed in white the
which were fulfilled of swetnes and odor of the said flowers. And at the said
bridge there was such probacyon that when any of ye unjust there passed he
fell in to the black water stynkynge / and the just passed till unto the
place delectable. And ye said knight saw there without the bridge a man named
peter bound with great weight of iron / And he demanded wherefore he suffered
such pain. Answer was given yt when men gave him any for to do vengeance he
desired it more to do by cruelte than by obedyence. Also the said knight said
that he saw a pilgrim ye which passed upon the bridge all over of also great
auctoryte as he had lived in the world clenely. and he saw another named
steven ye which as he passed the said bridge his foot slode in such wise that
he than fell of the said bridge in like as half. And then some men right
black lift them up from the said water the which drew him downwarde by the
thyes. And some men right fair clothed in white took him by the arms and they
drew him upward / and as this strife was ye said knight was put agay^ in to
his body. And he ne knew which of them should vaynquysshe / but saint
Gregorye says that it is to understand that the ylles that he had done strove
again the almesdedes. And by the other the whithe drew him downwarde appeared
yt he had not parfytely resisted unto the sy^nes of the flesh. This example
ought to draw all persons to live clenely / purely / and holyly to the end
that they may pass ye said bridge unto the place delectable without falling
in to the torment beforsaid. And the sinners should also correct them of ill
and to do penance / or they shall fall of the said bridge in to the said
water / wherein they shall be punysshed.

A. Another example of the vysyon of Tongdalus ye which suffered many pains in
purgatory and saw of the torments of hell and after was brought again in
to his body. Cxi.
