IN the years of our lord a thousand.xlix. There was a man named Tongdalus in
a cite of the land of Irlo^de. This said tongdalus was noble of lynage / a
fair man young of age / curteys of all goodness and of great honor. He was
great and right appert of the art of chyualrye. Also he was well speaking /
and good in dysportynge / and of asmoche more as he trusted in his beauty and
his force of asmoche the less was it unto him of the health of his soul And
if any man said any thing to him for ye health of his soul he was greuid with
hy^ / he dyspyted the holy church / he ne daygned to behold the poores in
their indygence. More over he gave that yt was his in plays for to have the
preyse of the world and many he had of friends and of compaygnyons. And it
came one day that he sat at table with one of his compaygnyons for to eat. And
incontinent that he had taken of the mete he deyed of death sudden and the
body fell unto the earth / In like wise as it never had had soul. The
servants ran unto him / the meet was taken away / wepynges / and
lamentacyons were made / men range the belles The people was much ameruaylled
of the death the which had taken this noble man so suddenly. He dyed the
wednesday about ye hour of none. And from that hour till unto ye saterdaye at
none he abode so the body without buryenge for that that in the left party he
had a little of hete. And on the saterdaye at none the soul came again unto
the body. And so by the space of an hour he beheld those the which were by
him / unto whom he made a token that he would have the body of god. And after
that he had received it he began to praise god and to yield unto him graces and
said. Sir all puyssau^t more great is thy mercy than all my sins. And
afterward said this word the which is written in the psalter That is to say.
How many trybulacions and ylles have thou showed unto me / and I being
converted thou have quyckened me. And have brought me again from ye depnesse
of the earth. And incontynente yt he had spoken tho words he departed / and
gave unto ye poores that that he had and promised above all things to leave the
life that he had before led / and all that he had seen and suffered he
recompted it unto us and said. When my soul issued out of my body she knew
and saw ye sins that she had done. And so began she to doubt. But she
knew not what it was yt she should do. And she would rentre within my body /
but she might not / But she ne durst goo out / for she dredde her sins of
al parts / and she ne had trust in nothing but unto the great mercy of god.
And so began to weep and to tremble / and she knew not what she should do /
and anon after / she saw come unto her so great nombre and multitude of
deuylles that all the house streets and places of ye cite were full the which
enuyro^ned her on all parts / the which deuylles said. Singe we unto this
soul the song of death / that we unto her should sing / for she is the
daughter of the death pardurable and the vyande of the fire extynguyble enemy
of the light and friend of derkenesses. And afterward and again her they
grynned and whetted their tethe and said unto her. Unhappy soul here is ye
people that thou haste chosen with whom thou shalt enter in to hell in
pardurabylyte / Thou haste ben a nouryce of sclaundre / a lover of dyscorde
that we love. Wherefore art you not proud / wherefore ne know you not thy
lecherye / where is thy vanite and vain gladness / where ben thy laughynges
right vntempred / where is thy force wherein thou trustedest so much. Wherefore
ne shyttest thou not the eye / wherefore ne tryppest thou with thy foot.
Wherefore ne thynkest thou the great malice that you were wont to do in
vanytees and sins. And as these foresaid deuylles said these words I looked
toward the heaven and saw a far of a light ^^scende in like wise as it had been a sterre right clear and shynynge In the which I had esperaunce that
there was some aid that god sent unto me. And as it approached unto me I
apperceyued well that it was the angel of god the which had kept me in this
world. And when he approached unto me he also greted me swetely and said. God
the salve Tongdalus. And when I saw so fair a yongman ye which greted me so
swetely by my propre name / by great Joy I answered. Alas my lord the dolours
of hell has besette me about. And the panges of death has occupied me /
as it is written. Dolores inferni circumdederunt me: preoccupauer^t me laquei
mortis. And the angel answered. Thou call me now lord and I have be
evermore with the / but Judge you not that I were dygne of such great honor.
The soul answered. Sir I never se the before. And the aungel said. From ye
hour that thou were borne I have evermore be with the in all places where thou
were And thou ne would never bileue my cou^sayll. Than the angel lift up
his hand among the deuylles and showed unto him one the which did unto him
wors than the other and said unto him that is he the which cou^saylled the
which thou byleued and did his will / but be thou sure that thou shall have
the mercy of god / and thou shall suffer a little of torments that thou have
deserved. Come thou after me / and that yt I shall show the so keep thou it
and put thou it in thy memory / for thou shall return again within thy
body. / When the soul had herd this she was much ferefull and she
approached unto the angel. When ye deuylles herd this word they were mad.
For they saw that they ne had of puyssaunce to do ill unto the soul an^
blasphemed god in sayng yt he was not ryghtfull / for he yielded not unto every
man after his deserte. And of the great woodnes whereof they were full they bet
each other. And they departed from thens sorye and heuye as enraged. Than the
angel said unto the said soul. Come after me. A sir thou go before /
these deuylles shall take me behind and shall led me in to hell. The angel
answerde / Have thou no fere for we have more great aid than they ne have. Si
deus pro nobis qis co^tra nos. If god be for us there is none that may noye
us. It is written by ye prophet david Cade^t a latere tuo mill et dece^ millia
a dextris tuis: ad te au^t non appropi^quabit. veru^tame^ occulis tuis
co^siderabis et retributione^ pcto^rum videbis. / That is to say a thousand
shall fall on thy left side / and ten thousand on thy right side. Certainly
they shall not approach unto the. Albeit thou shall consider by thyn eyes and
thou shalt see the retrybucyon of thy sins. And when he had said these
words they yode forth.

B. Of the valeye.
When they were gone longlye togyders by so great derkenesses yt they had no
light / but yt the which proceeded of the angel / they came in to a valeye
much horrible / ye which was right deep and full of brennynge coals. And above
that valeye there was a covering of iron brennynge of thyknes six fadome the
which was more hot than yt which burnt underneath. From thens issued so
great strenche the which grieved more ye soul than all that yt he had before
suffered Above the said covering dyscended many chetyues souls the which
there were fried as a man fryeth bacon in the pan And afterward they were
strayned through the coueryng as wax / and fell and dyscended in to the well
of the said valeye / upon the brennynge coals where they were tormented of a
new torment / thus said the angel. This pain suffers those the which have
killed faders or moders / or other people by delyberacyon or deed. and after
this tormente they shall be led in to more great: but thou ne shall suffer
this said torment albeit that thou have well deserved it.

C. Of the beast horrible.
AFter they entered in to a way much horrible crooked and hard. And when they
had gone long in derkenes / ye soul saw a far a be much horrible and
ferefull of ye gretenes incredyble / more great than all the mountains yt he
had before seen. She had the eyes as great fyres brenny^ge / and had the mouth
so great yt it seemed unto him yt there might well enter.x. M. men of arms.
There issued out of his mouth fire inextynguyble / and stynke incomparable.
Great multitude of souls entered by ye mouth in to the womb of the said be
the which souls cried horrybly of torments that they were in. And before the
said be there was great multitude of deuyls the which bette and tourmented
the said souls and after put them within ye said be And when the soul had
long beholden ye said be she was much ferefull and said to the angel.
Sir wherefore approach we unto this tourment. The angel answered. We may not
go by other way / for none escapes this tourment but those that god has
chosen to be in his company. This be that you see is called Acherons the
which tourmenteth all the auarycyous. Of this be it is written. Absorbebit
fluuiu^ et non mirabitur / and habet fuditiam quod influat iordanis in os eius.
That is to say. He shall swalowe a streme or water and it shall be no marvel
/ and also have affyaunce that the water of Jordan renneth yet through her
mouth And when they had spoken this they came before the said be / and the
angel departed and left the soul among the deuylles. And incontinent the
deuylles beset her about and there tourmented her with great tourmentes as
wood dogs. And afterward they led her with them in to ye womb of the said
be. Therein she suffered many bytynges of dogs / of beres / of lions / of
serpents / and of other beestes that she had never seen ne known before / and
there had of great tourmentes of deuylles / brennynge of fire / sharpenes of
sulphre / derkenesse wounds / to plundge / to cry / and great habondaunce of
disease and of trybulacyon. There was the said soul accused of her sy^nes yt
she had committed. And for the great heaviness whereof she was full she struck her
self on ye chekes tare them with ye nails of her own hands / and wend
there to be dampened pardurably. And anon she found her self out of the said
be / but she wist not how she came out / and she was laid far of much
feeble. Afterward wtin a while of time she opened her eyes and saw her aungel
by her. Than had she great Joy albeit that she was much tourmented / and
began to give praysynges unto our lord of his mercy And the angel touched
her and comforted her. etc.

D. Of the oven with the flambe.
Afterward they yode another way / and when they were gone longely by
derkenes they saw an house much high the which was round as an oven. In the
said house there was well a thousand wyndowes / from the which issued fire
strong / sharp and much hot. When the soul saw ye said house she had great
feere and said unto the angel. A sir we approach to the gates of death Alas
caytyfe who shall deliver me fro this tourment. The angel answered. From ye
fire the which yssueth out by these wyndowes thou shall be delivered / but in
to the house it behooves to enter. When they were approached they saw wtin the
said house in the mids of the fire great multitude of deuylles the which
held axes / knyues / hachettes and other instruments of iron sharp for to
tourment the souls yt were there of the which souls there was great
multitude. Than said the soul unto the aungel Sir I pray the if it please the
yt thou deliver me fro this tourment / and in all the other where thou shall
led me I grant me to be there tourmented. And the angel said This tourment
is greter than al those that thou have seen / but yet shalt thou se greter Now
enter here for the devils tarry for ye as dogs enraged. Than the soul began
to quake and to tremble of ye great feere yt she had and prayed the angel
much yt he would make him to pass the said tourment / but it vayled him
nothing. And when the deuylles herd yt she was granted unto the^ for to
tourment they took her with their instruments and tormented her sharply. The
master of this house had to name Phisternus. His house was full of fire brennynge
in the which souls strayned their tethe and wayled for the great doloures
that the suffered. And there were men and women / not al only of people of the
wor^de / but also of relygyon. There was this soul tourmented the which said
yt she had well deserved that yt she had suffered. But when it pleased god she
found herself out of the said tourme^t and she wist not in what manner. Th^n
she aduysed her angel by her to whom she said A sir where is the word that
the prophet Dauyd spe^^th. Mia dn^i plena est terra. That is to say. The earth
is full of the mercy of god. Than the angel answered and said. By those
words many souls ben deceived. God is ryghtwyse though that he be full of
mercy / and many sins he vengeth and punissheth / and also he pardons. If
god pardoned all the sins wherefore should ye man be Just. And if a man ne
dredde ye torments wherefore should he dread to do syn^e and his will. And what
should it need yt these sinners should repent them and confess them of their
sins if they ne dread god. God by his great mercy spares ye sinners in their
life and tarieth them for that they should do penance. But if they ben
obstynate in their sins and will not reuerte he them punyssheth for their
sins after their death. And god sometime takes away the goods temporelles
from the Just for to punysshe them temporally of some outrages that they have
done / and also to the end that they enpryde them not. But he keeps unto them
the goods perdurables of his glory.

E. Of the cruel be and of the ysy ponde.
After the angel led ye soul in to another place wherein they saw a be
much meruaylous the which had two fete and two wings and the neck right
long. And his neb and his nails were as yren / and from his said neb issued a
flambe a fire by right great sharpenes and force. And the said be was upon a
ponde full of strong yse. The which be devoured ye souls within his womb
in such manner yt they became as unto nothing by the tourmentes yt they
suffered. Afterward he put them out of his womb wtin the yse of the said
ponde. And there were they tourmented of new tourment. And all the souls the
which into ye ponde descended were in throws in likewise as women with
child. And not alonely the women / but also the men as the women. And within
their belyes they felt the sharp bytynges that the serpents made / of the
which they were engryped. And there were the caytyues souls tourmented. And
when ye time came and approached that they should child they cried so horrybly
yt they filled hell of noise and of howlings. Than they chylded serpents as
well the men as the women. And the said serpents issued not only by the
members whereby ye women child naturally. But also by the arms / the fete /
and all the other members issued out the horrible beestes ye which had hedes
of fire brennynge much sharp / wherewith they tourmented right cruelly the
said souls from whens they issued. And the said beestes had horrible tails
and nedles about their tails made as they were crochettes and hokes made as if
they were crochettes. And when they issued from ye said caytyues souls if they
might not draw their tails after them for the hokes they returned they nebbes
and smote the souls and gnawed them unto the synewes and bones / and of the
great pain and tourment that they suffered they keste so great and horrible
cries that they were herd unto the heaven. Morouer ye said souls were
replenysshed of diverse manners of beestes on their members the which did them
ete and gnawe unto the bones. And they had tongues the which fastened wtin ye
said souls till unto the lyghtes. This pain sustain the false monks /
chanons / the false nonnes and these other benefyced of holy church the which
have not well kept their bodies from evil doyenge / ne their mouths from
evil saying and speaking. Also those the which has used lechery sustain
this pain and tourment. And for that / yt thou art culpable it behooves the
to sustain this said tourment. When the deuylles herd this word they took
the said soul and gave it unto the said be to torment and to devour. And
when she was in tourme^t as the other souls and yt she was engriped with
serpents as the other / and when the time came yt she should child the
angel came unto her and touched her / and she was incontinent hole / and said
unto her / come after me.

F. Of the valey of smythes.
Afterward they yode in to another way much horrible and dyseasefull full of
so great derkenes that they had no light but of the clerenes of the angel.
And it seemed yt they descended from a right high mountain in to a great and
deep valey. And the more that they yode the less had the soul of esperaunce
for to return unto life. Than the soul said unto the angel. Sir whyder go
we. The angel answered. This way ledeth unto death. And ye soul said. What
is that than that the scripture says. Lata est via que ducit ad mortem et
multi su^t quuntrant per ea^. That is to say that the way the which is large
ledeth unto death: and many there ben the which enter and go by that way. The
angel said. Of this speaks not the scripture / but of the cursed way of the
world whereby men comen (...) to this way. And when they were descended in to
the said valey much deep they saw there of forges. Than the angel said unto
ye soul. The master of this valey is called Vulcain the which by his engine
and falsenes has casten many souls in to pains and tourmentes. Than said the
soul unto the angel. Sir shall I suffer this torment The angel answered /
ye / thou shalt suffer this tourment. And when the deuylles herd that word
they beset the soul about and took it with their Instruments of yren that they
held / and said unto the holy angel none harm / and keste it in to a
chymney full of fire brennynge. And began too blow the fire of their furneys
in likewise as men blow when the yren is in the furneyse. And so they
tourmented the souls yt which were there till that they came as to nothing.
And when they were so brent and tourmented they took the said souls with their
Instruments of yren.xx. an ho^dred or two hundred and laid them on an hepe
upon an anuelde of yren / and the deuylles the which were in other forges
said. Cast unto us these caytyues souls we shall yet tourment them again.
Than the deuilles kest them unto them again the which werein the other forges.
And after that they had been there st^ongly payned and tourme^ted they kest
them vyolently unto thosof the first forges. And before that they came to the
ground they were taken again and so they keste them from one unto another
and tourmented till unto that / yt the skins / the flesh / and the bones
came as unto nothing. Of this matter is written. Prouerbioru^.ix. Parata sunt
derisoribus supplicia / et mallei percutientes stultorum corporibus. After that
the caytyues souls were so tourmented as it is said they desired the death but
they might not deye. Unto this purpose it is written. Apocalipsis.ix. In diebus
illis querent homines mortem et non inuenient eam / et desiderabunt mori et
mors fugiet ab eis. And when the said soul had suffered longly these tourmentes
the aungel came unto her and took her and had her out of the fire where she was
/ and said unto her. How felest you thy self now Remember the that for as much
as thou have done thy will and the delight of thy body thou have suffered so
great tourmentes. But the soul had not so much force that she might answer
one word for the great tourment that she had souffred. Than the angel said
unto the soul. Illud psalmi. Dominus mortificat et viuificat deducit ad
inferos et reducit. Comfort the / for our lord quyckeneth and mortifyeth /
ledeth in to helles and brings again. And al be it that the tourmentes that
thou haste seen ben much great yet shalt thou se much more greter from the
which thou shall be delivered by the mercy of god. And know thou that al
those souls that thou have seen here abides the Judgment of god. But those
the which thou shalt se from hensforthe ben all ready Iuged. Goo we now
forward for thou arre not yet comen unto ye pains of hell. And the aungel
touched her and heled as he had been accustomed for to do. etc.

G. Of the pytte of hell.
After that they entered in to a way / and when they were a little gone
forward in speaking one unto the other there came to the soul sudden horror
and cold intolerable and stynke and derkenes more thycket than those before /
trybulacyon and anguysshe so great that it seemed unto ye soul that all the
foundementes of the earth trembled under her fete and said unto the angel.
Sir wherefore is it that I ne may hold me on my fete as I have acustomed to do.
And when she had said this she ne might remeue from the place for the great
feere that she had / and incontinent the angel departed in such manner that
she might no morese him / and forthwith she began to dyspayre For she found
that the which is written. Ecclesiastes.ix. Nec opus / nec ratio / nec
sapientia / nec scientia erunt apud inferos que tu properas. That is to say
that in hell there ne is operacion / ne reason / ne wisdom / ne conny^ge
whereby man may aid him. The caytyf soul was in likewise / for she might not
help herself / the which herd terryble cries and howlings of souls / and
thonder so horrible that no man may think it ne tongue declare the horrible
cry and the noise that there was. Unto this purpose god speaks in the
gospel. Illud math.xxii and.xxiii. Ibi erit fletus et stridor dentium. Than ye
soul looked about her for to know if she might se the way whereby they were
comen / and she saw a great square dyche in likewise as a cysterne. And from
that dyche issued out a pyler of flambe and of smoke togyders much horrible
and stynkynge. And that pyler of fire was so high that it stretched unto the
heuens. And in yt flambe there was great multitude of souls and of deuylles
togyders the which mounted with the said flambe in high in likewise as little
flambes. And of tourmentes the which they suffered they came as unto nothing /
and after that they fell again in to the dyche till unto the botome. Unto the
purpose of this says the psalmyste. Tu vero reduces me in puteu^ interitus.
And when the soul had beholden this she would have drawn her abacke / but she
ne might lift her fete from the ground. And when she had assayed many times to
remoeue her and that she might not she was much ferefull / and of the great
wodenes yt she had she tare and rent her chekes with her own hands and
nails and cried. Alas caytyfe wherefore may not I deye. And the deuylles the
which mounted with ye said flambe herd ye said soul in such wise cry so
they be set her about with their instruments of iron wherewith they tourme^ted
the souls and said in this wise. Caytyfe soul worthy of pain and tourment
from whens art thou comen hyder / thou ne have yet nothing felt ne suffered /
thou shall endure now that yt thou art worthy by ye sins that thou have
committed. From the which tourment thou ne may never depart ne within it
deye / but evermore thou shall live and brenne in tourment without light /
conforte ne help. And from now forth thou ne may have mercy. For thou art
comen unto the gates of death / and thou shalt be borne straight in to the
tourments of hell. He that has brought the hyder has deceived the / now let
him deliver the from our hands if he can / for thou shall se him no more. And
they said the one unto the other. Wherefore tarry we so long that we ne ne give
this soul unto Lucyfer for to devour it / and so they thretened it of death
pardurable. And these deuylles above said were black as coals with horrible
lokes / and their eyes were as the lamps brennynge. And their tethe as white
as the snow / and they had tails like as scorpyons / and their claws of
yren and great large wings. And when they had said these words the holy
angel appeared unto the said soul and said unto her. Enjoy ye daughter of
light for thou shalt have mercy and not Judgment. Thou shall se of great
tourmentes and pains / but thou shalt suffer none. Come than after me and I
shall show unto the the right cursed enemy of humayne lygnage. Those the
which ben there have no light and they shall not se the / but thou shalt se
them well and their tourmentes.

H. Of the princes of derkenes and of their cursed felawes the which ben in
pains.
After these things spoken and seen the the soul approached unto him and saw
the prince of derkenes in the botome of hell. and what and how great
tourmentes she saw there the entendement ne may comprehend it / and a man ne
may express it ne declare. That is to say if he had an hundred hedes / and
that every heed had an hundred tongues yet they might not recompte the pains
of hell. There was one the right worste devil the which was more greter than
all the beestes that he had seen before. The which was black as a raven. He
had the form of the body of a man from the fete unto the heed except that
he had well a thousand hands. And he had a tail well an.C. cubytes long /
and.x. of gretenes. And he had nails of yren great and long as well on the
fete as on ye hands longer and greter than the speres of knights. His nebbe
was much long and great. His tail was right long and sharp all full of
pryckles sharp poynted for to grieve and tourment the myserables souls. And
that most horrible devil lay upon a gredyron of yren / under the which
there was great habundaunce of brennynge soles. Also there was great multitude
of deuylles the which blewe and kyndeled the fire. About that ennemy there
were so many deuylles and of cursed and miserable souls that no man might
believe that of all ye world from the beginning might be issued and brought
forth so many souls. And that devil was bound by every Ioynture of al his
members with great chains of yren and of copre brennynge. And of the great
tourment and vehement woodnesse whereof he was full he turned him from ye one
side unto the other / and stretched out his hands in the multitude of the said
souls and took them and streyned them in likewise as men may do a clustre of
grapes in their hands for to make the wine come forth. And in such manner he
strayned the^ that he either brake their heedes / or their fete / or hands /
or some other members. Afterward he syghed and blewe and dysperpeled the said
souls in to many of ye tourmentes of the fire of hell. And incontinent that
pytte or well whereof we have before spoken kest stynke and horrible flambe.
And when that cruel be drew again unto him his brethe all the said
soulles that he had shed with flambes and sulphre fell and entered in to his
mouth / the which he devoured. And when some souls escaped him by adventure
between his hands he smote them with his tail. And that devil the which in
such wise tourmented ye souls horrybly was tourmented above all other. Than
the angel said unto the soul This devil that thou see here is called
Lucyfer the which is the first creature that god made the which was in the
delyces of paradyse before that he descended from heaven / and if he were not
bound he would do many euylles and perturbacyo^s. And they the which thou
see the which ben with him there are a party of the aungelles of derkenesse.
And the other party ben men and women the which ben descended from Adam the
which ben all ready Iuged the which abide many the which have renyed Ihesu
christ / or does the operacyons of them the which renye him. Here ben the ill
prelates and princes of whom it is written sapientie.vi. Potentes potenter
tormenta patie^tur / fortioribus aute^ fortior instat cruciatio That is to say
that those that been mighty in dygnyte and in power shall suffer tourmentes with
great puyssau^ce. That is where as they have myscheuously used the puyssaunce
that god has given unto them. All the other tourmentes that thou have seen al
be it that they ben right great yet are they nothing to compte in regard of
this here And the soul said. Certes sir thou say true / for I am more
grieved and tourmented to se alonely the tourment and to feel ye stynke the
which is there than all the tourmentes that I have suffered hyder to. Wherefore
I pray the if it please the that thou take me from hens. Also I se many of my
felawes that I loved much and held their company much dear where as I have
now great horror for to se them. And certainly I understand and know that if
the great grace and mercy of god were not my socour that I have deserved for my
sins to be punysshed and tourmented eternally as they ben. And the angel
said unto him. O my blyssed come and convert the in thy rest / for god has
done well unto the / thou shall not suffer these tourments here. And thou shall
se them no more if thou forgete not the things that thou have seen / and if
thou deserve them not again. The soul of the said Tongdalus saw many other
tourmentes / and of the Joys of the saved the which has be left because of
shortness for they ben much long to recounte and write. By the scriptures and
examples before said it does appear that the sinners inobedyentes unto god
should correcke the^ and amend whiles that they live in this world if that
they will escape and eschew the inestymable tourmentes of hell and get the
realm and the glory eternal. Unto the which glory we may goo cum illo qui
est benedictus in infinita secula seculorum. Amen.

Ihesus.
A. Examples that the name of Ihesus does many goodnesses. And how it
delivered a man fro many perils and tourmentes. Cxii
IT is written in many books that as saint Patryke preched in Irlonde he prayed
god devoutly that he would show him some token by the which the wicked ill
men might have feere and also repent them. And suddenly a right great hole or
pyt appeared / and it was reveled unto him that ye place of purgatory was there.
In the which place if any would descend he should have none other pain. Many
the which herd this thing therein entered the which came never again. And a
man named Nycolas the which had committed many sins there descended too
the end that he might repent him of his sins. And he found first an oratory
and white monks the which said unto him. Be thou steadfast and co^staunt. For
it behooves the to sustain many temptacyons. And he them demanded what
remedy he might have against the said temptacyons. They answered when thou
felest thyselfe tourmented with pains cry hastily. O jesus christ adiuua me.
That is to say. O Ihesu christ help me. And wha^ that he was departed from them
the deuylles ran suddenly upon hy^ in likewise as wild beestes famysshed.
And as they did in this wise unto him he recorded him of his counceyle and
said. O jesus christ adiuua me. And incontinent he ne wist where the beestes
became. He yode ferdermore and found a right great fire / in to the which the
deuylles kest him. And incontinent that he had said. Jesus christ adiuua me /
forthwith the fire was put out and quenched. He walked yet ferder and saw a
well right deep from the which issued smoke and great clamor of souls the
which were tourmented. And wha^ the deuylles had casten him within it he
cried Jesus christ adiuua me. That is too say. Ihesu christ help me / and
forthwith he was delivered. At the last he saw a bridge that was right narowe
and strayte. And there he had great terroure / the which bridge him behooved
too pass / but he might not. And he set one of his fete upon ye bridge and
said. Jesus christ adiuua me. And so he said at every step till that he had
passed the bridge on the other side. And wha^ that he was past he came unto a
fair medowe wherein grew many fair and delectable flowers / of the which
flowers and me dowe proceeded good odoures and smelles. And afterward he came
again unto life and.xxx. days passed he came unto paradyse by the inuocacyon
of our blyssed savior and redemptour Ihesu christ. Unto the example of the
abouesayd man the which was delivered from all tourmentes and pains
incontinent that he had called ye help of Ihesus. In likewise thou man and
woman call devoutly the name of ye blyssed lamb Ihesus in all aduersytees /
fortunes tourmentes / losses / temptacyons / sekenesses / necessytees /
anguisshes / perils / infyrmytees / and things doubtables and well shall
come unto the. This name Ihesus is interpret savior. Jesus i^terpretatur
sa^uator. For by ye merit of his passion he saved al ^he world. He brake hell
/ saved and delivered all the good persons the which were in the lymbe of the
holy faders and opened paradyse unto all good crystyens. Also Ihesus is the
king of kings / the Judge of Iuges / and of all great and little. It is he
that gives Joy and beatytude eternal unto the good / and that punyssheth and
damneth the evil. Ihesus is holy and debonayre unto the good / and also he is
terryble and ^ruell unto the evil. And therefore says ye psalmyst. Sanctu^ et
terribile nomen eius initium sapientie timor domini. Also the name of Ihesus is
in excelle^ce above all other Vn^ paul. ad phyl. Vocatu^ est nomen eius super
oe^ nomen. Also the name of Ihesus is loved and dredde above all names / and in
namynge him all creatures reasonables should bow the knee / be it in paradyse
/ in this world / or in hell. Vn^ paul. ad phi. In nomine jesus omne genu
flectatur celestrium / terrestrium / et infernorum. The men and women of this
world call him in their besynesses and necessytees / and the deuylles of hell
dread him. For to be short the name of Ihesus ought to be loved / honored /
called / dredde / and redouted / for it is replenysshed with bounte / beauty /
and holiness infinyte and inenarrable. That is the which passes all
entendementes. etc.

B. Another example how the devil was chased from a woman in ye name of Ihesus.
Cxii.
MEn find by writing this ye which follows how the dycyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says that a woman demonyacle was on a time brought
unto saint Bernarde unto the end that he should hele her. And the devil before
many the which were present said. O that I would goo out with good will from
my little lamb here. My lord will not that I go out. And saint Bernarde said.
Which is that lord. He answered The creator of all. And saint Bernarde said.
Saw thou him ever. And ye devil said. I have seen him in glory. And ye saint
said. Thither thou would return. And he said in mocking. The hour is to
late for to go thither. Than saint Bernarde commanded him in the name of Ihesu
christ that he should go out. And the devil said. O name terryble thou me
constraynest to goo forth / and incontinent he went out and the woman was
heled of her infyrmytee. etc.

C. Another example how that the name of Ihesus vaynquyssheth ye te^ptacyons of
the devil. Cxii
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says that a man was meke and had of custom
that every time yt the devil gave unto hy^ any temptacyons he yode unto prayer
and called god in say^ge. Jesus dulcis miserere mei. Sweet Ihesus have mercy on
me and help me. And forthwith the devil departed from him. And on a time a
holy fader herd that the devil said that the deuylles were repelled by the
virtue of this word Ihesus.

D. Another example how ye name of Ihesus gives many virtues. Cxii.
SOme masters writes this the which follows how ye discyple recites in the
book of his promptuarye and says that a young man much devout and Innocent
made orayson and prayer in demanding that he might have ye love of god. And
the angel of god gave unto him a little scrolle written in this manner. Jesus
christ fili dei viui propitius esto michi pcto^ri. And said unto him. Open thy
mouth and eat this writing / by ye virtue whereof the deuylles shall be
vaynquysshed / the heuens ben opened / the sins be^ taken away / the trynyte
is drawn to / and the aungelles serves him devoutly. When the young man had
eten the said writing he had in him all tho things as he was informed.

E. Another example how by the name of Ihesus a clerk was delivered and a
thief converted him. Cxii.
IT is written in the promptuary of the dyscyple that there was a clerk
lecherous and vycyous ye which as he would go to commyt his sin it befell
that as he passed by a forest wherein there was hid a thief ye which spared
no person but yt he slew hy^ or dyspoyled him. And when the said thief herd
him pass he said. What art thou yt passest here by. The clerk answered. I am
the poor servant of Ihesu christ for dread that he ne knew what to answer.
Than the said thief said. I demand the what thou art. The clerk answered. I
am the indygne servant of Ihesu christ. The thief demanded him thyrdly / what
art thou. And the clerk said again. I am the vnprouffytable servant of
Ihesu christ. And ye thief thought unto him self / of whom art thou servant
/ and he said unto the clerk. For the love of Ihesus goo thou in peace. And the
thief in mummelynge said unto himself. Ihesus. Ihesus. Ihesus. And by the
virtue and power of the holy name Ihesus the thief was converted. And after
that he never committed theft ne homycyde. In the morning he yode to
confession and said that for heryng the name Ihesus he was converted / and the
clerk in the namynge of Ihesus was preserved. The which said blyssed be ye
name of Ihesus / for by ye name of him I shall absteyne me from sin.

F. Another example how a relygyous was heled of the fevers by the virtue of ye
name Ihesus. Cxii
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a friar mynour had herd many miracles of
the name of Ihesus. And as this said relygyous was tourmented of ye evil of
fevers he wrote this name Ihesus within the water and after drank it and
incontinent the fever left him. This thing happened in Irlonde

G. Another example how by the name of Ihesus a woman pardoned unto her
enemies. Cxii
IT is written in the book of gifts that a woman ne might be apeased. And her
husband wrote in her forhede the name of Ihesus / and in contynent she forgave
all.

H. Another example ye one would not pardon for the love of Ihesus. Cxii
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuary yt there was a man obstynate unto
whom men said on a time. Pardon thy rancoures / and enmytees for ye love of
Jesus He answered. Neither for god ne for ye devil I ne may pardon them though
that I should enter in to hell perpetually. And a friar approached unto him with
devotion and wrote in his forhede with his finger Ihesus nazarenus / and
incontinent the sinner began to weep and said. For the love of Ihesus I pardon
all.

I. Another example how the temptacio^ of the devil was taken away with ye
token of the cross / and in ^amynge ye blyssed Ihesus. Cix.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is
also written in other books and says that the devil tempted a man and his wife
so terrybly yt they would hang themself to the end that they should euade the
miseryes of this world. And as they were heavy of their temptacyons of the
devil yt they ne might sleep ne ete the one demanded of ye other the causes
of their heuynesses. And they said each to other yt they would hang themself.
And after yt they appointed their cords for to hang them the woman counceyled
her husbonde yt they should drink of good wine yt they had before their death
to the end yt they might deye the easelyer. And so they agreed / and as they
would drink made the sign of the cross in ye name of Ihesus. The devil
fled and the temptacyons were taken away. After contrycyon they did
penance / and well they ended their days.

K Another example that in namynge ye name of Ihesus the devil is repelled and
his temptacyons and persuacions taken a way. Cxii.
MEn find by writing that ye devil tempted often times a man the which by
ye counceyle of sages yode in orayson and call ed the name of Ihesus as soon as
had perceived the temptacion and said. O sweet Ihesu have mercy on me and help
me and forthwith the devil departed and the temptacyon left him.

L. Another example of a noble man the which pardoned ye homycyde of his
brother. And the crucyfyx enclyned his heed in the church Cxii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book that it is written that a man slew the
brother of a noble man and afterward fled and left the country. And it befell
that as ye noble man yode through the country with great company of people
without thinking on the said deed met in a field the homycyde the which had
slain his brother. He drew his sword hastily for to sle him. And ye said
homycyde fell prostrate unto the earth and cried. Right noble man have mercy on
me for the love of Ihesus the which is pyteable and has redeemed the world by
his death. Hastily the said noble man took him to weep and withdrewe his hand
and his sword without strykynge him. And as he was reproved of his taryeng and
folly of the people again he stretched out his hand for to smite him the
which was prostrate / and the culpable demanded pardon and remissyon of his
mysdede in the name of Ihesus And secondly he withdrewe his hands. Thyrdly he
was blamed of his people for yt he had not slain him. And ye unhappy dredynge
yt death humbly required pardon again. And ye noble man of war and nobler of
heart said. I pardon the the death of my brode^. And without tarienge he herd
ring to a mass yt day and entered in to ye church And the times he bowed his
knees before the crucyfyxe. And an holy man yt was in the church saw yt the
crucyfyxe enclyned the heed humbly at every of the said times yt the said noble
man bowed ye knees. Tha^ he that had seen alonely the said thing called and
drew aside the said noble man and demanded him what he was. I am borne in the
land / and said a noble knight. And the holy man said. Dear friend hyde you
nothing fro me. Wherein trustest thou most to have deserved unto the dyuyne
mercy. Than the knight said. I am a sinner and have given me to the world /
and nothing is aduysed in me but yt such a case happened me this day. And he
it unto him declared. Also the holy man told unto him that yt he had seen /
and exhorted him to be pyteous / merciful / and good. Her Guillermus dicit.

M. Another example how Ihesu christ would not pardon one deed till that he had
demanded pardon of his brother yt he had offended. Cxii.
IT is written in the life of faders that the prouyncyall of the prouy^ce of
Rome of ye order of prechers admonested the treers that they should keep them
dylygently fro troubly^ge one another / and unto them recou^ted this example
the which was comen in this wise. A friar troubled me on a time iniustly / and
afterward within a few days he deyed from this present world with out
being at peace with me. And in a night in slepy^ge he appeared unto me for to be
pardoned. And as he demanded me pardon I me aduysed that he was deed / and I
said unto him. Go brother and demand pardon of our savior and redemptour
Ihe^u christ in whose hand thou art. The which departed fro me. And as he
demanded pardon of Ihesu christ in likewise as I said to him. Our lord Ihesu
christ answered unto him. I shall not grant the pardon but if thou demand
pardon first of him that thou have offended. And in that night the said body
came again unto me and brought me again the words of Ihesu and again
demanded me pardon and had it. Afterward he said unto me. Brother Nycolas
behold what ill it is as to offend his brother / and that it is a grievous
thing as not to be at peace and faithful accordau^ce with him. etc.:

Natiuitas christi.
Examples of ye natyuyte of Ihesu christ And first example how that a nonne yt
which habandoned herself unto sin had mercy in requyrynge the sone of the
blyssed vyrgyn Mary on ye day of Crystmas. Cxiii.
MEn find by wrytinge this yt which follows how the dyscyple recyteth in the
book of his promptuary and says yt a nonne left her order and was an open
harlotte. And many years afterward she came again unto her monastery and gave
herself unto penance. And as she thought on the Judgment and on ye Justice of
god and on the horrible pains of hell she despayred / as who says that she was
not worthy to have pardon for ye multitude and greten^s of her sins. And as
she thought on the Joys of heaven she defied herself that no soylenes ne
corrupcyon of syn^e there should enter. And as she thought on ye passion of god
she regarded how many of pains he had suffered for her in wepy^ge she cried and
said. Quid retribua^ dn^o pro oi^bus que retribuit michi. What thing shall I
grant unto god for all the things yt he has given unto me. And in one of
the solempnytees of the natyuyte of our savior she wept and thought Quod puer
natus est pro nobis. That is to say yt the child is borne for us. And that a
child is appeased with a little thing when he is offended. Than she yode before
the image of the vyrgyn Mary the which held her child between her arms and
thought on the chyldhode of our sauyoure / and there was moeued in great teeres
by bitter contrycyon of heart that god gave unto her. And with all her heart
and might in weeping required pardon of our lord for his benygne chyldhode
that he came in to this world to save the syn^ers Than she herd a voice the
which said unto her yt for the benygnyte of his infancy yt she alleged she

B. Another example how the chyldehode of Ihesu christ delivered a relygious

THe dyscyple recyteth in his sermons this the which follows the which is

apostasye. / Than he worshypped the enfance of god on our ladies lap / and
required him that he would aid him / or give him license to go in to another
relygyon. And in weeping and wayllynge he kyssed devoutly the fete of the
image. And hastily he apperceyued such consolacyon that he perseuered in the
service of god in relygyon.

Passio christi.
A. Examples of the passion of our savior and redemptour Ihesus. And first
example of a great sinner the which bare unto his death sekenes for his sy^nes
in the remembrance of the passion of our lord Ihesu christ. Cxiiii
THe disciple recites in his sermons and says that a great sinner was
constytute unto the death / and he took his sykenes in reparcussyon of his
sins as he said. It is good reason that I endure ill in all my members yt
which has offended god by sin. And in such anguisshe he gave him to
think on the passion of our lord Ihesus. That is to understand if he endured
in his heed and here it was of good right / for he had aourned his said here
and offended god the which for to redeem him had endured ye crown of thorns.
And also his eyes the which had made the false lokes were derked and suffered
and that was of good right. For our lord endured for to redeem him that his
eyes were bended with a kerchyef / and his face stryken and buffeted. And if
his body yt which had committee the lecheryes pleasau^ces carnalles and sins
suffered it was good reason. For our lord endured for to redeem him that his
body was rent beten and hewn. And also his mouth the which had spoken ill
words and dronken to exces suffered pain it was of good right. For our lord
endured for to redeem him to drink vynagre and gall. And so of ye other
members as the hands yt which had done of cursed operacyons. And the fete the
which walked ill ways and he bare ye said sekenes wyllyngly for his own
sins in thinking that god had had the fete and the hands perced and endured
death for to redeem him. And it is not to doubt but yt he had health with ye
good thief when his soul parted from this world. etc. This here is a great
example to instruct al persons for to do penance as did the said man when
they shall come unto ye bed of death. For if they take patiently ye said
sekenes and the death for their own sy^nes in sayng yt they have well deserved
punycyon and their me^bres yt have offended god as it is said in the example.
Such punycyon corporell by sykenes shall serve for penance for the sins
committee after confession / and shall be agreeable unto god. saint gregorye
says. Si passio christi ad memorie^ reducitur nihil e^ quod no^ equo ai^o
telleretur. If ye passion of Ihesu christ be brought unto mind / yt is to
understand yt he has endured for to redeem the from hell with much pains.
There is none aduersyte so hard but yt thou shall endure it with good courage.
If the king bear a great maste for the love of the / thou sholdest bear for
the love of him a straw. The good thief yt was hanged on the right hand of
Ihesu christ bare the death agreably and blamed the ill thief. vnde luce.xxii.
Nos quide^ just: na^ digna factis recipimus morte^: hic vero: scilicet xpu^s
nichil mali gessit He said that he received the death Justly / and that he
had well deserved it for his propre deeds. In so saying he confessed that he
was a sinner and that he took it wyllyngly in gre by penance and punycyo^ for
his own sins / so he had confession and did penance. It is gretter
penance to endure the death for his sins / than it is to fast and to say
oraysons. Also when a man confesses openly in judgment his sin as did the
good thief / it is more great thing than to confess it unto one only / but
the custom is to be absoyled of him the which has auctoryte. God absoylled
ye said thief and gave unto him pardon of his sins in considering ye great
contrycyon / confession / and faith that he had in saying unto the ill thief.
No^ times deu^ et meme^to mei du^ veneris in regnu^ tuu^. Also it was great
penance as it is said yt he took the death for the punycyon of his sins. And
therefore of good right god said unto him. Thou shall be with me this day in
paradyse. Hodie mecumeris in paradyso. Before that a man dies him behooves to
demand grace and pardon. For it should be to late after ye death. Vn^ eccle.
xviii. Ante la^gore^ adhibe medicina^: et ante iuditiu^ i^terroga te ipsu^ et
in co^spectu dei i^uenies propitiatione^. That is to understand / take
medecyne / that is penance before that thou fall in to langour in hell and
ask thy conscience before yt the Judgment be made of ye. And you shall find of
debonayrte and mercy before god and saint gregorye says. Qui tpres age^di
penite^tia^ perdit: frustra ante ianua^ paradisi cu^ precibus venit. He the
which leseth the time to do penance / comes as void and for naught before
the yate of paradyse with prayers to demand life eternell. etc.

B. Another example of the swetnes of the passion yt a man had yt said five
times pater noster. Cxiiii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his book of sermons and says yt there was a man the
which loved much god for ye reverence of the five wou^des of Ihesu crist he
said every day five pater nosters / and one time our lord appeared to hy^ and
gave him five meruayllous swetnesses / so that he studied alonely for to serve
god: / And he prouffyted gretely in good operacions and virtues / and in the end
he fined well his days / and yode in to paradyse. etc.

C. Another example of a knight ye which ne might deye on the gybet for that
yt he said every day three pater nosters in the honor of ye passion of Ihesus.
Cxiiii
IT is written in the dyalogue cesarii yt a knight was accused unto the emperor
yt he dyspoyled and wasted his land ye which knighte was taken and hanged by
the commandment of the said emperor / and on the third day ye cosyn of
the said knighte hanged passed thereby with his servant the which had co^passyon
of him / for he was a fair man and a noble approached unto the gybet for to
vnhange him and to burye him. And he spoke unto them on the gybet and said /
vnhange me for I am yet alive. They wend yt it had be a fantasye And he the
which hang again said / ne doubt you not / certainly I live yet by ye grace
of Ihesu christ and by the aid of the vyrgyn Marye. The which was vnhanged
and led in to the cite / at whom ye people meruaylled. And the said knight
vnhanged demanded the priest and the sacrament of the altar. And in great
contrycyon of heart and of teres he confessed him and after received the
creator. More over ye priest demanded him before the people yt he should tell
the cause wherefore god had done unto him such grace to hang three days
without deyenge / he answerde / because yt I did unto god a little service /
yt was / to say every day five times pater noster / and five aue maria before
yt I did any other thing / in the honor of ye passion and of the five
wounds of Ihesu christ. And one pater noster in the honor of the sacrament
of the hostye the which is the very body of Ihesu christ yt the people
receives every day in requyrynge of god that in the end of my days I might
receive him / the which thing our lord Ihesus gave me by his mercy* and that
I ne might deye till that I had received him. After that this said knight had
said thus and that he had true contrycyon of his sins made confession and
received his creator as it is said he deyed and ended well his days. Wherefore
it is a good thing as to serve god and to have in remembrance his blyssed
passion. etc.

D. Another example ye it took well unto a man the which made memory of ye
passion of our lord in his lyenge down and rysynge from his bed. Cxiiii
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons yt a man was accustomed as often times as
he laid him down and rose from his bed he prayed god yt when he should dye
he might have true confession and said this title. Jesus nazarenus rex iudeorum
miserere mei / and made the token of the cross with his thombe upon his heed /
his face and his breast in saying In noi^e patris and filii and spu^ssancti
amen. And god suffered that he deyed suddenly / and as the deuylles would
rauysshe him there came a man shynynge and clear the which chased them And as
he led him through the derkenesses suddenly he departed / and there proceeded
great light from thens as he was wont to make the crosses. Afterward there
came deuylles yt would take him / but they durst not for because of the
crosses on hy^ Than the said man bright and shynynge suddenly appeared unto him
and said. Albeit that thou have well won to be Iuged and condampmed after the
exigence of thy sy^nes nevertheless the sovereign Judge spares the and wylleth
that thou return in to thy body for the devotion yt thou haddeste toward
his passion and that you caldeste his name tryumphall in the said title and for
the impressyon of the cross. And the said Judge wylleth yt thou confess thy
sins and that thou amend thy life / and so he did For after he lived and
ended well his days. By this example a man should understand that the cross
makes ye deuylles to dread / it chaseth them / it takes away their force /
and sets them at naught. etc.

E. Another example of a woman the which loved the passion of Ihesu christ the
which deyed on the good friday and was saved. Cxiiii
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons that it is written that a noble woman
matrone loved the passion of Ihesu christ / and for the honor of him and of
his passion she took afflyccyo^ on her body on the frydaye / desiring to goo
bare foted but because she was noble for to keep honor she yode not / but put
bygge gravel in her shoes in the honor and reverence of ye passion. Also
when her husband was out by any days she lay not on no feder bed. And
among the prayers that she made to god / she required him yt he would give
her grace yt she might dye on yt day and in that hour yt Ihesu christ was
crucefyed / to the end yt in the honor of his passion her body had
afflyccyon on yt day / and so it happened. For at ye same hour she chylded a
sone the which lived after / but the said matrone deyed of the great pain.
And as a friar precher the which had confessed her prepayre him to sing ye
mass of requyem for her the saturday afterward the vygyle of eester / he was
weary of the service and slepte. And in slepynge she appeared unto him and said.
Thou shall not sing mass of requyem for me / but you shalt sing gloria in
excelsis / for I am in the glory of the saints of paradyse / When the said
relygyous was waked he ne would put no faith unto his dreme / and the pryour
sent unto hy^ forthwith a messenger that he should sing for her mass of the
day. The said relygyous wend to have excused him and prayed yt it were
reco^maunded unto another but ye pryour would not / and said that in that day
he should sing the mass of the day unto ye covent And it was done after ye
word of ye said matrone ye which had appeared in slepynge. etc.

F. Another example that oraysons the which ben made in the remembrance of
the cross and of the passion of our lord ihesus pleases him much. Cxiiii.
THe disciple recites in his sermons that it is written that an hermyte of a

orayson of one Just is much worth in like wise as says the scripture.
Multu^ valet deprecatio iusti assidua. It befell one time that as the said

meruaylled / for he was as a poor man all naked ye which trembled for cold /
and bare a great cross on his sholdres / and the said hermyte him demanded
what he was / and from whens he came / he answered I am come from heaven / and
am Ihesu christ the sone of mary / Then the hermyte said. O good Ihesus what
do thou here before me cursed sinner / he answered thou have made me to come
heder by thy prayers / you haste prayed unto me longly yt I should show unto
the what service I had agreeable among al seruyces / and I am come to show it
unto ye. See thou this great cross that I bear upon my sholders it is the
service the which unto me is most agreeable yt thou and every man ne may do /
that thou bear my cross upon ye in remembrance every day of my passion. For
it is the service most agreeable unto me. etc. This example ought to draw unto
us to remember the blyssed savior Ihesus yt endured to redeem us. five.
M.CCCC.lxxv. wounds and the death. Vnde versus. Septuagi^ta qui^^quatur centu^
millia quinque: tot fertur xpres pro nobis vulnera passus. etc.

A. Another example that ye passion of Ihesus moves to have ye virtues and to

B. Another example that the token of the cross was found in ye heart of a

THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary yt as men led a holy man to be
martred / he was asked of ye tyrante wherefore these christian men and women
desired to receive martyrdom with Joy / He answerde for the token of the
cross i^ prynted in their hertes. And therefore it is no meruayll though they
follow Ihesu christ crucyfyed with Joy. The tyrant answerde. I shall prove yt
which you say of mouth. And when the saint was slain he found the prynte
of the cross in his h^ert And when the tyrant saw that miracle he made him to
be crystened.

C. Another example yt a conuers had the life and passion of Ihesu christ for a

THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says yt a conuers was required

because he took no head unto the lesson that was read at the table. He
answerde and said. I have read a right good lesson at the table. When I begin
to ete I think how the sone of god was anounced of ye angel for me and
conceived of ye holy ghost in the womb of the vyrgyn marye in entreatynge that
in my thought I found the first little lefe. Afterward I thought how he was
borne / how he was wrapped in little clothes and cloutes and laid upon a
little of hey in the crache. And how ye au^gelles enjoyed them and sange

thought that is the second lefe. In this manner I run unto the cyrcumsycyon
and coming of the kings / unto the oblacion made in the temple / unto the
baptysme / unto the fasting / unto the passion / resurreccyon assencyon / unto
the sendynge of the holy ghost / and in the end on the Judgment. this is my
daily lesson and the end of my dinner. Unto the purpose of this relygyous the
which thought the mysteryes of god. david in psalm. Beati qi scrutantur

D. Another example of a relygyous yt which learned three lettres yt which he
recorded often. Cxv
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says yt there were two germayns
in one monasterye of the which the one was a clerk and the other lay / The
clerk applied his time to read and to write the which asked one time his
brother lay how he wasted his time. The which answerde I have learned three
lettres on the which I think every day / and return them. The first is
black. The second is read. And the third is white / Then he axed him their
names / and he said The first is of the recordacyon of my sins the which is
so heavy and grievous that I am gretely tormented. The second lettre is the
recordacyon of the precious blood of Ihesu christ yt he has shed
haboundauntly and mercyfully by his wounds / and the death yt he has endured
on ye cross for to redeem me. The third is the desire of the Joys celestyall
and of those the which follow the lamb in aubes yt is of the saints yt
follow Ihesu christ. When the friar the which was clerk herd these things he
had shame / wayled and reputed all his science as naught. And afterward
employed his days in devotion.

E. Another example of an abbess ye which when she should deye she caused ye

ciuitate dn^i virtutu^. and she said nothing more but departed before the eyes
