F. Another example how Ihesu christ showed unto a yongman his hands and his
side perced. Cxv.
THe discyple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt a young man lecherous in
cursed entencyon entered in to a wodde in the which were of harlottes / and the
devil met him and demanded him whether he yode / and he told him his
entencyon / unto whom the devil said go before me and I shall pay the well in
time And as he entered more forward he met Ihesu christ in habyte of a monk
which demanded him in like wise. Wheder g^ ye my sone. He answerde and said
unto him ye be not my fader. Unto whom ye monk said. Certes thou art my
sone. He answered with indignacyon that he was not his sone. And the monk
opened his habyte and showed unto him his hands and his side perced / and in
bledynge as men paynt the crucyfyxe. Byleuest thou now that I am thy fader /
the which cried and said / you art my lord and my god. Than Ihesu crist said
unto him / goo thy ways and confess the. For he yt thou have met before me is
ye devil the which abides the to the end yt he break thy neck. And as he
yode forth of the wodde with purpose to confess hy^ the devil knew him not.
And he axed ye devil whom he tarried after. The devil answered / certes it is
not thou. He that I tarry fore was all ours. And puyssaunce has be given unto
me upon him / that I might sle him. Thou art another / and the yongman
understood the grace and mercy that god had done unto him entered in the
cloister and confessed him / and fined his life in goodness. etc.

G. Another example yt Ihesu christ revoked a postate for to show hy^ his
wounds. Cxv.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuary yt a young man delycious entered in to
relygyon / and for the hard life the bread seemed unto him black and hard and
the wine sour. And he demanded of his prelate license to return in to ye
world / unto whom the pralate said. Brother ye ne may return for ye be
profeste in this relygyon / but have ye affiau^ce in god and require ye him
that ye may bear ye burden with the other / and he did so / but after he was
tempted of the devil on new / he changed his habyte and yode in to the world
And as he yode his way Ihesus appyered unto hy^ in semblaunce of a yongman and
followed him by that way he hasted him in such wise as dyspeyred / and knew
not wheder he should go. And Ihesus the which followed him cried / tarry me /
and he ran more strongly. And Ihesus called him by his name and said unto him
Brother tarry me and I shall go with the / The yongman wrathed him the which was
called brother and monk and had shame and meruaylled that he called hy^ by his
propre name. Than he tarried / and Ihesus asked him wheder he yode. He answered
yt he had left his relygyon and that he should return in to the world. Than
he lift up his vestyment and his arms. And he saw the blood the which
issued out of his side perced and said unto him. Return in to thy monasterye
/ and when you shalt find the bread to hard and the other things grievous
touch them with my side perced and all shall be soft to the and good to
bear. Than he returned and lived afterward holyly. Vn^ grego. Si passio
christi ad memoriam reducitur: nichil est quod non equo animo tolleretur.

H. Another example of a thief murde. rer yt repented hy^ made confession and
had penance a pat nr^ to say before ye cross. cxv
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons that it is written of an hermyte ye which
led a sharp life by long time And one time a thief came unto him the which
had dyspoyled the men by long time and had gotten many theftes / he repented him
/ made confession / but he ne would have but short penance. And the hermyte
charged him that all times that he found any cross in the way yt he should
say a pater noster knelyng on his knees The thief said that he would do that
penance with good will. And after that he had taken his penance / and that he
was departed a little from the hermyte he saw his enemies yt sought him of
whom he had slain the parent. Incontinent that he saw them he took him to
fle. And as he fled he saw a cross lift up in the way. And he bowed the
knees and said his pater noster. And how be it that he had right little to
fle and escape the death. Nevertheless he had lever to deye than to leave to do
his penance yt was enjoined to him. So he gave his life unto god / and unto
him reco^maunded his soul / and prayed yt he might have the said penance
exceptable for all his sins. And as he was slain of his enemies in yt place.
Than ye hermyte saw yt the au^gelles took ye soul of the said thief and with
great Joy they bare it in to heaven. etc.

Signum crucis.
A. Examples of the cross / and first how it was showed to Constantyn / and
raised a deed man and heled a woman. Cxvi.
IT is written in ye hysto. eccle / and in ye inuencyon of ye cross yt maxence
assembled an host of the empire of Rome And the emperor Constantyn with his
army came nere unto the bridge of the water of Anubie for to fight with ye
said maxence. And as he fered / he lift up his eyes toward heaven and saw the
sign of the cross resplendysshe in semblaunce of fire / and he saw after the
angel that said to him. Constantyn thou shall vaynquysshe by this sign. And
the night following our lord appeared unto him with the sign yt he had seen
in the sky and commanded him that he should do make the figure of the said
sign and that he should have aid against his enemies. Then constantyn was
joyous and assured to have vyctorye / made him to be marked in the forhede with
the sign of the cross. And made to change all his baners of war in to ye
sign of the cross. And required god that he might have vyctorye without
effusion of blood. And so was it done. For maxence commanded them of his
ships to go saw the posts of the said bridge. He forgate the thing that he
had made to make and ran hastily against constantyn with few folk / but he
commanded yt the other should follow him. Then he mounted on the said bridge /
fell in to ye water and was drowned before his host wtoute any might socoure
him. And the ylle yt he would have done unto constantyn came on him self. Then
ye said constantyn was received lord of all / and had thus the vyctorye. After
constantyn sent his mother Helene in to Iherusalem for to seek the cross of our
lord. When she was gone theder she made to come all the wise jews of ye
regyon / for to inquire of the place of caluarye and of the cross of Ihesu
christ. And because yt they would tell nothing / she commanded yt they should
be burnt. For to a bridge they gave a man named judas yt in the end showed
the place of caluarye / and made to dygge in the earth / in ye which was
found the crosses / ye which were borne in to the place of the cite. And
because yt he could not chose the cr^sse o^ ihesus from them of the thieves /
Judas put the first and the second upon a deed body and it remeued not. And
incontynente yt he had touched the cross of Ihesus he rose him up all on live.
Another example / Men read in the historye ecclesiastice that a woman the
which was lady of the cite of Iherusalem was syke and as half deed And the
bishop of Iherusalem took the first and the second cross and laid them
upon the syke body and they prouffyted nothing. And incontynente that the
cross of christ touched her she was hole. By these examples here a man may
^now that ye cross of Ihesus is much dygne yt w^iche reyseth in such wise
the deed and heleth the syke. And we should praise it / love it / and honor it.
For by the cross ye deuylles ben vaynquysshed / and by the ^^ecyous blood of
Ihesus the which was shed on ye cross we have been redeemed. And therefore we
should enjoy us to se the cross. vn^ canitur i^ vna. an^. Nos au^t gloriari
oportet i^ cruce dn^i nr^i thu^ christi. etc. Also the cross makes ye
deuylles to fere / chaseth them away / it takes away their force and
sets them at naught. And when any person is tempted of the devil or that
he has fere or dread / or that he find himself in any danger. etc. He
should make the token of the cross and call deuoutely the aid of Ihesus and
of ye vyrgyn marye and he shall have incontynente socours / in likewise as men
shall fyn^e here after by examples Also men should make ye token of ye cross
when they lie down and rise or whan^y men would ete or drink / or do any
operacyon. For the token of the cross is prouffytable ouerall again all
inconuenyences the which may come unto ye body or unto the soul. etc.

B. Another example how saint Iustine resysted and had vyctorye again the
devil by the token of the cross. Cxvi
IT is written in the legende of saint Iustyne that ye devil tempted her by
many times to love vnlefully a man named Cypryen. By two times he tempted her
inuysybly of love unlawful. And in contynent yt she perceived the said
temptacyon she commanded her unto god devoutly and made the token of the
cross / And the d^^yll was so aferde that he fled Also the devil tempted her
another time vysybly in semblaunce of a vyrgyn / And when she had made the
token of ye cross and blewe against him he departed and had no more
puyssaunce. Also the devil transformed him in a yongmans lykenes and entered in
to her chamber / lepte upon her dyshonestly as she lay in bed / and would
have had to do with her. And when she saw that she considered yt they were
ylle spyrytes / she marked her with the cross and the devil departed. and.

C. Another example of a man of war penytent yt resysted again the
temptacions of devil by making ye cross. Cxvi
MEn find by writing yt after yt a man of war had done many ylles and
sins / he repented him confessed / and had in penance to be one night in
the church without drink / and should say. My redemptour Ihesus have mercy on
me / and in that night the deuylles tempted him in guyse of merchants / but
he overcame them with his prayer and in making ye cross. Afterward two
deuylles came unto him in semblaunce of the woman and her child / and tempted
him strongly / but he had the victory by the token of ye cross and in saying
the words beforsayd. Thyrdly the deuylles tempted him in guyse of a bishop
the which had confessed hy^. etc And he had vyctorye as it is said before by
the tokyn of the cross and in saying. My redemptour Ihesus have mercy on me. /
Lastly the deuylles in guyse of beestes bet him and he was pacyent without
remeuynge And after he was a good man and a holy.

D. Another example how the token of the cross served unto a Jew again the
deuylles yt held their chapter. Cxvi.
IT is written in ye dyalogue of saint Gregorye yt as a Jew yode by the
country in defaute of hospytall yode for to lie in the temple of ye ydoles /
and made ye token of the cross. And by night the deuylles came to hold their
chapter in the said temple. And there devised of the ylles yt they had done.
And as the said jew was in a corner and herd them in trembling of dread the
prince of deuylles commanded unto the other yt they should go to se him that
had presumed to lie there. They yode and afterward said unto him Ve ve vas
vacuu^ sed signatu^. maledictu^ It is a vessel yt is a man void of virtues
and of goods spyrytuel / but he has the token of the cross. Than all the
deuylles departed without doing any ill unto ye said jew / because he made
the sign of the cross. etc.

E. Another example how a man showed at his death that he had received ye
cross and the devil fled. Cxvi.
THe disciple recyteth in his promptuary yt a knight a great sinner would have
remyssyon of his sins / received the cross. And the devil appeared unto him
in his sykenes and said unto him thou art mine. Unto whom the knight said / yt
am I not / for I have confessed me and have received the cross / the which he
uncovered and showed him saying / here is the token that I have received unto
the defense of the faith. When ye devil saw that he vanysshed away.

Aqua benedicta.
A. Examples of holy water / and first example yt the deuylles ye were in the
house of a syke man were chased away by holy water. Cxvii.
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons and says yt as a man lay mad of new
a conuers was in a monastery in the article of death he saw all the house
replenysshed with deuylles as persons with long nebbes. And when the said syke
body had sygnyfyed it unto his gardyen he understood that they were foul
spyrytes he made to bring of holy water in a vessel and bespryncled all the
place. And as he did that the syke man took him to cry that he should cast
strongly / and that the deuylles fled so hastily yt they strove who should
first goo forth and that for haste one fell over another. Than the said
gardyen more strongly cast the holy water. So ye sykeman was delivered of the
deuylles / the which wend to deceive him for to dampne him. Unto this purpose
a man should understand yt the holy water is much dygne and prouffytable. For
it puts away sins venyelles / and chaseth away the deuylles and
fantasyes dyabolyques / and therefore many has of custom to have of holy
water by their beds / and also to cast holywater at their lyenge down / and
arysynge / and when they ben syke to the end that they ben puryfyed / made clean
and kept from temptacyons and fantasyes dyabolyques as it is said. Vnde dauyd
in psalmo. Asperges me dn^e ysopo and mu^dabor lauabis me and super niue^
dealbabor. That is to say. O thou lord thou shalt besprynkyl me with the
holywater styk^ and I shall be made clean / thou shall wasshe me / and I shall
be more white than ye snow / yet again says dauyd. Thou have in likewise
troubled the heedes of the dragons tho ben of the deaylles in the waters.
Iteru^ psalm. Cotribuiasti capita drachonu^ in aquis. etc. Item it is good to
sprynkyll with holy water a woman when she trauaylleth of child Also when a man
receives the holy water devoutly it dysposeth the persons to devotion and to
do well. For to be short it is a great thing as to receive the holy water. And
those that refuse it or fle it / they ne ben good catholyques / for they done
in like wise as did ye deuylles yt fled from the house of the syke man for
the holy water. etc.

B. Another example how the devil ne might enter in to the mouth of a
dronkenman for a drop of holy water that therein fell. Cxviii.
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye and says yt a drunk n man met in
his way a demonyacle. And the said dronkenman said unto ye devil enter in to
me and leave this man. And the said devil answered. I may not / wherefore said the
dronkenman. For thou haste ben this day in ye church and one drop of
holywater is fallen in thy mouth. etc.

C. Another example that as a knight bespryncled him with holy water the devil
cried touch me not. Cxviii.
ARnoldus recounteth in his book and says yt as a knight strong in arms
would approach unto a place where a maiden demonyacle lay the devil began to
cry. Here is my friend come. And as he was entered said. Go ye back let my
friend approach. Thou devil thou art a fool / wherefore tormentest thou this
maid innocent / come with me unto the turneymentes. And the devil answered and
said. I shall go with the with good will / if thou suffer me yt I enter in to
thy body or that I be in the sadell or brydell / or in any party of thy body.
And the knight had compassyon of the noble maid / and said if thou will go
forth of this maid I shall grant the one party of my mau^tell by such
condycyon that thou hurt me not / and that you shalt depart incontynente that
I shall tell the. And he promised hy^. Than he yode forth of the maid / and
yode in to the oylet hole of the mauntell. From that hour so much of glory
came unto the knight that those yt he would he them surmounted and wasted and
those yt he would he took. And one day as ye knight prayed longely ye devil
said unto him / thou murmurest to much. And as he spry^cled him with holy
water he said unto him / take heed yt thou touch me not. And one time when the
knight yode unto a place where a man preched of the holy cross ye devil said
what do thou here. The knighte answered I will leave the and serve god And ye
devil said what thing has dyspleased the in me I never hurt the / but I
have enryched the and thou art become much glorious. And the knight said
depart thou and come thou no more again to me I command the in the name of
ihesus. Than ye devil left him and the knight marked him with the cross /
and served Ihesu christ two years beyond the sea / and when he was comen
again he made to edefye an hospytall / in the which he admynystred unto syke
bodies their necessytees and well defyned his days. etc.

D. Another example that when a sinner obstynate had drunk of holy water / he
repented him and confessed and changed him from ill unto good. Cxviii
THe dysciple recites in his promptuarye that a knight did many ylles and in
the end fell seek and his priest warned him to confess him / and to receive the
sacraments as a good catholyque / and he ne might enclyne him neither by
prayers ne by menaces. And reputed his words vain / and that he ne forced ne
cared. And as he demanded of water for to drink the priest yode to bliss the
water without that yt the seek body knew any thing of it and gave it him to
drink. When he had drunk incontynente by the aid of the holy ghost he cried
unto ye priest in requyryng him that he were confessed. And he confessed him
purely he was admynystred and ended his days well.

Maria.
A. Examples of the vyrgyn Marye / and first example how the vyrgyn Marye
delivered an abbot and many other from peril of death for to say this
responce. Felix namque. Cxv^ii
VIncent says in the.xviii. book of the myrroure hystoryall in the lxxxix.
chapitre. That an abbot with many other were in the myddest of the sea of
Brytayne in so great tempest of time oppressed that they all dyspeyred of life
/ so ye some called saint Nycholas unto their aid / and the other saint
Andrewe. And every of them called the saint yt most famylyerly he called unto
his necessyte. And when the abbot saw that none of them called the blyssed
vyrgyn marye mother of mercy yt has puyssaunce above ye heaven and the earth he
said. Brederne what do ye to call any saints and leave ye mother of god yt has
puyssaunce above all tho saints ye ye call. I say not that ye do ill / but
call we all with one voice the mother of mercy. Than all togyders called and
reclamed ye blyssed vyrgyn Marye. And the said abbot the which had not ete in
two days and in two nyghtes but one apple / and the which was at low that he
ne might syghe / he sange with his monks this responce. Helix na^que. And ye
verse Ora pro populo And before yt they had ended their song and devotion /
there arrived a great light in the heyghte of the maste as a tapre the which
chased away all the derkenesses of the night and enlumyned the presence / and
all the tempest so ceased at the commandment of the queen of heaven and had
great transquylyte. And right anon after the day clear and fair shone / and
the ship applied it self unto the land where as they entented. And so had
they aid of the vyrgyn Marye. By this example and by many other a man should
know that all persons the which serve the vyrgyn marye and her ^equyre by
devotion and with good heart / they have aid and socours in all necessytees
that they find themself in / be it in earth or in the sea / be it at the death
or in the life. And by that yt the abbot said unto his compaygnons yt they
should call the aid of ye vyrgyn Marye more sooner than all the saints of
paradyse / he spoke it of good right. For she is more noble dygne / and holy of
the creatures that god create ever. Vnde scryptura dicit. Sicut sol luci dior
est quam luna: et luna quam syderibus: sic maria dignior e^ creaturis oi^bus.
She is more digne than the aungelles / for she is mother of the king of
aungelles. Vn^. a^. Ipsu^ rege^ angelorum sola virgo lactabat. And she led a
life au^gelyke and more then au^gelyke. Vnde hieronimus. In carne preter carne^
viuere no^ terrena vita e^: sed angelica Also she lived without any sin in
her body corruptyble. Vn^ ca^t. iiii. Tota pulcra es amica mea and macule non
est in te / She is more dynge than the prophets / for they prophetysed of her.
Vnde scriptura. Prophet predicaueru^t christu^ nasciturum de virgin maria.
Vnde ysaye. vii. Ecce virgo co^cipiet and pariet filiu^. She is more digne than
the appostles / for she is mother of the king of the appostles / ^ she is their
maystres the which taught them. Quomodo co^cepit de spu^ scto^ and peperit
sine dolor. Also she was more ferme in the faith at the passion than the
appostles. Vn^ scriptura. Beata q^ credidit qm^ perficientur ea q^ dicca era^t
ei a dn^o. She is more dygne than the martyrs. For she suffered in the soul at
the passion more of dolor than all the martyrs. Vnde luce. ^ Et tua^ ipsius
ai^am pertra^sibit gladius. Also she was more dygne than ye confessors for she
was sanctified in ye womb of her mother / and put in to the temple to serve god
in the age of three year yt the confessors has not done. Also she is more
dygne shan the women. vnde luce. i. ca. Bn^dicta tu i^ mulieribus. Et cant. ii.
Sicut liliu^ i^ter spinassic amica mea inter filias.

B Another example how salve regina vayleth much to deye well. Cxviii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye of the vyrgyn marye that as a
chanoyne regulyer labored unto ye death he dredde that the which is written
ecclesiastices none. Nescit homo vtru^ amore vel odio dignus sit. Albeit he
dyspeyred him not. And the vyrgin marye appeared unto him in form vysyble / and
in sweet words said unto hy^. Dread thou not thou shalt not be dampened. But
in likewise as thou have honored me oftymes with this antem. Salve regina. In
likewise shall thou be crowned by me in the realm of my sone. When he had
recompted this thing ioyously unto his bredern he deyed. etc.

C. Another example how ye vyrgy^ marye appesed the thondres and tempests of
ye time for to say salve regina. Cxviii.
IT is written in the book cesarii that a priest had of custom to say at al his
hours this ante^. Salve regina. And one time as he walked through ye feldes
and that he yode to vysyte a recluse ye which was by ye church great thondres
and horrible tempests sourded up yt he lost his force to walk. And in the end
by great labor he entered in to the church and fell prostrate before the
altar and required the vyrgyn Marye to appese ye said tempest And there
appeared unto him a woman with vysage of a vyrgyn replenysshed with great beauty
yt said unto him. For asmoche as thou say and syngest oftymes this antem.
Salve regina matter mi^e. the tempeste shall hurt nor fere ye no more. when she
had spoken these words she vanysshed away / and he understood yt it was the
vyrgyn marye. Another example of salve regina written in the promptuary of the
dyscyple. It happened one time yt in two towns the freres of the order of
prechers were by night so tormented with fantasyes and yllusyons dyabolyques yt
it neded yt one of them must watch and keep by night those that slepte and
rested. And they did put all their esperaunces in the aid of ye vyrgyn marye
/ and made solemnel professyon after complyn in singing Salve regyna / and
incontinent all was appesed / by these examples here it behooves to understand
that the said antem pleases unto our lady. Also marie is queen of heaven of the
aungelles / and saints of paradyse of whom we sing regina celi letare. Also
marye is the queen of all queen's. Also marye is queen of mercy in like wise as
notyfyeth this ante^ Salve regina. Also this queen is dygne / noble / holy /
blyssed / fair pure / clean / clear / gyuyng light / shynyng that she
surmounteth al creatures in bou^te / / dignyte / and clarte / and therefore is
she lift up and set by god her sone. Vn^. psalm. Astitit regina a dextris tuis
i^ vestitu deaurato circu^data varietate / It is good to love serve and honor
this vyrgyn the which is so great a lady / for that yt she requires is done
/ and that yt she refuses is not done Love we than the vyrgyn Marye / serve we
and honor we her / in keeping her feestes and well shall come unto us.

D. Another example how the vyrgin Marye restored the hand of Johan Damascene
yt made salve scta^ pare^s. Cxvii
THe dyscyple recites in his promptuarye yt at rome there was a valyau^t
doctor named Johan damascene The which had of enmyes yt accused hy^ falsely
that he had written with his proprehande of lettres again the empire and
romans. So it happened yt he was led before the emperor / ye which made his
hand to be cut of / which thing he bare patiently. And afterward he
considered yt our lady had none introyte propre as some other saints / and
that it was not an honest thing yt she yt was queen of heaven had not also well
a propre introite as the other. Then he made salve scta^ parens. and then when
he had made it he doubted lest he should forgete it / and incontinent called
his clerk for to give him his ynkorne / and remembered not yt he had his hand
cut so he reched forth the stompt for to take ye pe^ne / and incontinent he
was heled through the vyrgyn marye / and had his hand agay^ also fair and
fresshe as ever it had been. etc.

A. Another example of ye salutacyo^ angelyke how a religious made the chaplet
of the vyrgyn marye. Cxix
MEn find by writing that a relygyous demanded of his abbot how he might do
thing that might please unto ye vyrgyn marye. And he gave him to answer. Make
unto her every da^^ a chaplet of roses He demanded how / he answered. Say
every day fyfty aues a pater noster at every tenth. Than he did it. And a
great time after he was sent for a n^cessite unto another abbaye / and passed
through a wodde and was taken with thieves in saying his aue marye. And as the
capytayne of the said thieves beheld him he saw a white dove the which took
of roses out of his mouth. And demanded him what it was that he said / and
from whens proceeded the said roses. The said relygyous showed how ye said abbot
had instruct him to serve the vyrgyn Marye as it is said. And the said thieves
converted them / restored the others goods and were relygyous in the abbaye of
the said monk and defyned well their days. etc. Another example semblable. It
is written in the promptuarye of the dyscyple yt a relygyous had of custom to
make the chaplet unto the vyrgyn marye in saying a hondreth times aue maria.
etc. And as he yode by the country when he came unto a wodde a thief the
which would slay him saw that a fair child took the roses in his mouth and
made of them a chaplet. The said thief was ameruaylled to se that demanded of
ye said relygyous ye cause and what it was that he said. He said that he salued
the vyrgyn marye in saying aue maria. For to be short the thief corrected hy^
of his ^^rsed life. etc. By these examples here a man should understand yt aue
maria the which is the salutacyon angelyke p^easeth much unto the vyrgyn
marye / and for as much as it is often said and comune it behooves to declare
it in right ample wise.

B. First the angel said unto the vyrgyn marye. Aue. That is for to say god
the salueth. He gives us example yt we should salve the persons when we
arryue upon them in sayng. God ye salve. god save you / or bliss you. Maria.
God ye salve marie. This name marye is interpreted maris stella / sterre of the sea. Of this sterre spoke the prophet balaa^ that ^^aid Orietur stella ex
jacob. And also a sterre appeared to the kings on crystenmas day toward
oryent that conduyted them to Ihesus / and to the vyrgyn marye. And by this
the angel salued the vyrgyn marie in saying unto her aue maria. God salueth
the sterre of the sea / fair / clear / and shynyng^ / For also as the maryners
have a sterre in the fyrmament much clear and fair and verytable that
conduyteth them by night and redresseth them when they are wrong and ledeth
them unto good port. Semblably marye ye which is interpreted sterre of y see
/ is she that conduyteth all the errau^tes and strayers / and ledeth them unto
the port of salute. And for this says saint bernarde. Si i^^urgu^t ve^ti
te^ptationu^ etc respice stella^ voca maria^. In periculis: i^ angustiis: i^
rebus diebus: maria^ i^uoca: no^ recedat ab ore: non recedat a cord: vt
i^petres eius auxiliu^: ipsa^ seque^s no^ deuias: ipsa^ roga^s no^ desperas:
ipsa^ cogitans no^ erras: ipsa tene^te no^ corruis: ipsa protege^te ^o^ metuis:

words of the said saint bernarde / in all ^ekenesses necessytees / and
aduersytees / and in all temptacyons and dangers what so ever they be that a
man fyndeth him in / him behooves to have his recours of heart and of mouth
unto this ster^e yt is marye / and a man shall have all that yt he requires
Example of a man yt as he fell in to the sea he called the vyrgyn marye the
which brought him safe unto land. And because that marye socoureth in such
wise the creatures in all necessytees call ye marye serve ye marye / honor ye
marye / keep ye the feestes of marye and well shall hap you. Gratia plena. The
angel said unto the vyrgyn marye. God the salve full of grace. Marye was

He was in her in her womb.ix. months. He was in her in chyldynge and

shall hap us. Bn^dicta tu i^ mu^ieribus. The angel said unto the vyrgyn

She was the very mother of Ihe^us for three things. Prima because that ye body

Secunda he had place and rest in her precious womb. Tertia he had nourysshyng

A. Another example of him yt knew no good but aue maria. Cxx.
MEn find by writing that a man of arms renou^ced unto all ill / and made
him relygyous of the order of chartreux the which in his life ne might learn
no good thing but these two words aue maria / but he said them right devoutly
of heart and of mouth together / and of time he repeted them / and so used his
life. After his departing there ^prange from his grave a fair flourdelys
white. And on ye leaves of ye flower was written in lettres of gold aue maria.
The people meruayled of this thing. For to be short it was found yt the said
flouredelys proceeded from his mouth / and that it was for that that he had
honored the vyrgyn marye with those words aue maria.

B. Another example of him yt which kneled at the name of our lady. Cxx.
IT is written yt there was a relygyous yt loved so much the vyrgyn marye yt
when h^ herd her name spoken of he kneled down / and wrote it wi^h gold azure
or yelowe. At the last he was seek / and another relygyous yt lay nere unto
his bed herd on a night how the vyrgyn marye with great light and company of
aungelles came to fetch him and said unto hy^ for as much as thou have written
my name / and had it in so great reverence I shall make thyn to be written in
the book of life and so he deyed. etc.

C. Another example of the mother the whi^he taught unto her child to salve ye
vyrgyn marye. Cxx.
MEn find by writing yt a good mother taught well her child / and learned him
to salve the vyrgyn marye and to go every day on his knees to say aue maria
before her image that was in her chamber. The said child was so accustomed and
loved so much the vyrgyn marye that when he was beten he yode to complain him
to the said image / and also he bare often a party of his porcyon that he ete
and put it before ye child of ye vyrgyn marye. And it fortuned one day that
he fell in the water before his said mother / and was drowned / she ran to
fetch people to draw him out all dyscomforted. and when she came again /
she found him where he yode out of the water and played him with two apples.
He was demanded how he came out / he answered that ye vyrgyn marye yt he
saluted / had drawn him out and had given him ye two apples.

D. Another example how the vyrgyn marye aided a woman to child in ye see of
the mount of saint myghell. Cxx.
VIncent says in the myrrour hystoryall in the first party of the eight
book yt a woman with child the time comen for to child put herself on the
way to the mount of saint myghell in one of the solempnytees with diverse
persons. And when they were on ye sands the signs appeared that ye see came.
The people had fere and took them for to cry inferinge the death / and began
for to run toward the mount of saint myghell. The woman with child might
not flee / but abode in great fere and trauayll / and wist not what to do save
for to call the aid of the vyrgyn marye and saint myghell. And great multitude
of people lamented her on the ryuage of the see cryenge toward heaven for the
help of the vyrgyn marye. for to abredge the vyrgyn marye came to ye aid of
the said woman / covered he^ and was as in a sure place / and kept her from
the water in such manner yt never drop of water touched her / and also she
was delivered of a sone in the mids of the sea / without having fere / for
she was well kept. When yt the sea was withdrawn / the vyrgyn marye showed
her the way / And after the said woman came to the ryuage with her child /
and found the people to whom she recounted ye miracle. etc.

E. Another example of a ^ayn^er that the vyrgyn marye defended / and kept
from having ylle. Cxx
THe disciple recyteth in his promptuarye of the vyrgyn marye that there was a
paynter yt painted in a church the image of the devil ye most horryblest that
he might / and also painted the image of our lady the most fairest and with
the fairest colors yt he might find And ye devil him demanded why he made
yt / and he answerde because it was so as the payntynge showed. And then the
devil by envy made ye tymbre to fall yt he stood on because he should fall
down / and as he began to fall the image of our lady painted took him by the
hand so that he might not fall / and kept him from the malice of the d^uyll.
And the ^ynners wtdrewe them from ill doing in beholdy^g the said images / the
one horrible and ye other fair. and^.

F. Another example of the good and honor yt the vyrgyn marye did unto a
thief the which fasted the saterdayes in her honor and absteyned him from
ylle saying. Cxx.
IT is written in dyalogo cesarii As men say yt there was a thief in a forest
reno^med right ill for yt that he pylled slew and did many ylles with many
compaignons. And he found a monk precher in the way unto whom he said that
he should sle him if he yode not after him And in walking ye said monk
demanded him what he was / and what operacyo^ he did. He answerde I am a
thief so gretely reno^m^d ye which has so to name And the said monk said
unto him / thou wakest much dredest thou not the peril of thy soul. He
answered no / no more than a be. And the said monk asked him what had been
his life / he answered when I was a child I stryued with my felawes and after I
was a thief / and to be short I never did no good deed / but ever did ylle
and now am I the master of thieves / and the monk said unto him. Dredyst thou
the pains of hell the which ben made ready for ye for thy cursed deeds / he
answered. Of ye soul without doubt she is lost And the monk the which would
convert him said unto him. If I show unto the how thou shalt be saved will
you do it He said ye. And the monk counsayled hy^ that he should fast every
saterdaye in the honor of our lady / in doing none ylle yt day / and that
the vyrgyn marye should be the mean yt he should be saved. And ye said thief
thereto consented and vowed. He kept yt vow and let his fellows also to do
ylle And the people that his fellows took on that day he delivered them in ye
honor of the vyrgyn marye. Also on ye saturday he ne armed him ne bare staff
of defense. And on a saterdaye his enemies found him and his fellows dysarmed
for the saterdaye he was taken and never would defend him / albeit he had be
more strong Also he ne excused hy^. When he was led in to the cite and that he
was known he was Iuged to be hanged. How be it afterward the Iuges were moved
with pite as men believe by the vyrgyn marye and took their counsayll togyders /
and would yt he ne should deye. But he said that he would nothing so / and
that he loved better yt he should weep his sy^nes here than in hell And the
Iuges said to him will thou be byhedede. He answerde and said I care not what
ye pain be so that I deye. And they said unto him / wylt you have a priest He
answered ye ben al christian men. I confess unto you my sins I ne did never no
good deed. etc. but only yt I have fasted the saterdayes there needs no
priest Than he repented him right bytterly in confessing openly his sins.
And bare and endured the pain and dolor of the death wyllyngly for his sy^nes
ye which was unto him hard penance. To be short he was byheded without the
cite. And the night following the watch men watchynge in the cite saw in the
place where he was buried lights celestielles / and five fair matrones the
which unburied hy^ the which set his heed upon his body the which there took
again / and laid it honorably in a coffyn and bare it in to the cite unto
the church door / of the which matrones there were four the which bare the
said coffyn and had candelles in their hands / and the.v. was more fayrer
than ye other the which yode by with candelles / When the gardiens of the
church saw yt they dredde and wend it had been a fantasye unto whom one of
them said. Say unto your bishop that he burye honorably my servant in the
church in such place the which has be byheded without ye cite. And if he
were neclygent yt to do she menaceth him. More over she named the vyrgyn marye.
When the bishop herd the said thing and saw the head to be taken unto ye
body dredde and called ye clergy and buried him honorably / not as a thief but
as a martyr the which endured the death for his sins. After that the said
deed was known all the men of ye prouy^ce fasted the saterdaye in the honor of
ye vyrgyn marye.

G. Another example how a thief beheded ne might deye without confession for yt
that he had fasted the saterdayes in ye honor of ye glorious vyrgyn marye. Cxx.
IT is written in the promptuarye of the miracles of our lady that a thief the
which pylled a poor woman and he found that she fasted the saturday from her
enfance / and demanded her the cause / She answerde that those the which fast
the saterdayes in the honor of ye blyssed vyrgyn marye ne should deye wtoute
true penance. And ye said thief took this thing agreably and fasted them. In
the end he had the heed stryken of / the which cried confession confession /
those ye which present were meruaylled and got him a priest for to confess
him. After yt the heed had be put again unto ye body and that he had made true
confession he said. I had this gift of grace to confess me by the glorious
vyrgyn marye for ye which I fasted the saterdayes. The deuylles were about me
but they ne might nothing do unto me for the presence of the vyrgyn Marye and
ben fled for the holy confession. Wha^ he had spoken these words he deyed.
etc.

H. Another example how the vyrgyn marye aided unto a thief in his death
because he had fasted on ye saterdaye. cxx.
IT is written in the promptuary o^ the dyscyple yt there was a great thief yt
never had done good deed / but only that he had fast a saturday and made to
sing a mass to the end yt the vyrgyn marye should convert him before his
death And the said mass and fast were so much agreeable unto the vyrgyn m^rye
that she appeared unto the said thief unto whom she said. I have prayed my sone
Ihesu christ for the that thou sholdest convert the and also repent the of
thy sins. He has given unto the such grace that before thy death you shalt
speak five words that shall deliver thy sins. Afterward this thief was taken
and holden in bands / and on the third day was led to be hanged / and in
the way god gave unto him great contrycyon / and in that true contrycyo^ he
said ye.v. words following. Deus propitius esto michi peccatori. yt is to say.
God be merciful unto me sinner.

I. Another example how a thief hanged might not deye without receyuynge of his
ryghtes thrughe our lady. Cxx.
IT is written in the promptuary of the miracles of our lady / yt there was a
thef yt fasted only bread and water the vygylles of the feestes of our lady. /
And when he yode in theft he saluted her and prayed her yt he ne should deye in
mortal sin. And it befell that he was taken and hanged / but he ne might deye
by three days. He called those yt which passed by and prayed them that they
would bring a priest unto him / yt which came with the Judge and with the
people / he was vnhanged / unto whom he said yt the vyrgyn marye sustained him
on the gybet / and so was let go / and lived after holyly. etc.

K. Another example how a thief was bruised and might not deye without
confession / for he had fasted the vygyles of our lady. Cxx.
IT is written in the promptuary of the miracles of our lady yt three bredern
were dysheryted of a knight castyllan. And after that they watched the ways in
the next woddes and did many ylles. And that knight took two yt he made to
hang. The third dredde and confessed him unto a relygyous ye which warned
him to cease of doing ill. He answerde I ne may cease till that I have stryken
the knight with sword or arowe yt has slay^ my bredern. More over he said he
would fast bread and water the four euens of our lady / to the end he deyed not
without confession. The relygyous said yt it was well done to fast / but it
should not prouffyte if he ceased not his sy^ne. He yode forth and after was
taken of the knight yt broke al his members. And as he was full of wou^des he
said he should not deye till he were confessed and received his cre^tour. Than
when he had his ryghtes he deyed. etc.

A. Another example of a monk dyspenser the which was drunk unto whom ye
enemy appeared for to slay him / And the vyrgyn marye kept him. Cxxi.
IT is written in the promptuary in ye miracles of our lady yt in an abbaye
there was a dyspenser ye loved perfytely the vyrgyn marye. So it happened one
time that he was so drunk yt he reled in the cloystre and ne might find the
way to the church. Than the devil came unto him in lykenes of an horrible
bolle which would have stryken him with his horns / but a right fair
damoysell put her between them holdy^ge a rod in her hand / and rebuked him
and put him forth right strongly for that yt he would do ylle unto her
servant / and him commanded that he should go his way. Than he departed and
the vyrgyn. And the said monk put him self in the way again for to go unto
ye church. And the enmye appeared unto hy^ in semblaunce of a dog enraged yt
would lepe in his face. And the fair vyrgyn came yet again and put her
between them the which devil fled all confused / and ye monk entered in to
ye monastery: Than the enmye came in semblaunce of a lion enraged the which
would devour him / but ye blyssed vyrgyn forgate not her friend came before
that the enmye grieved hy^ and stroke him hard with her rod / and commanded
him to come no more again. And the enmye departed all confused / and the
vyrgyn took the monk by the hand and led him in to the dortour and laid
him in his bed / and put his pelowe under his heed / and made the token of
the cross upon him. And when ye monk awoke he was well. Our lady commanded
him yt he should confess him and acco^plysshe his penance And that afterward
he should keep him from falling again in to sin. And ye monk her demanded
what she was / she answerde I am the mother of Ihesu crist And when he herd
that he fell unto her fete and yielded unto her graces / and she mounted in to
heaven.

B. Another example how the vyrgyne Marye delivered from dampnacyon a clerk
lecherous. Cxxi.
THe dysciple recites in ye miracles of our lady yt there was a vicious clerk
yt had alonely this good deed that he said devoutly the matyns of our lady And
one day as he passed through a water for to accomplysshe his lecherye / he
began to say his matyns / and when he had said aue maria gratia plena / he
fell in to the water in sayng dn^s tecu^ / and was drowned / the deuylles took
his soul / but ye vyrgyn Marye came to defend it / and because ye deuylles
had dyuysyon with her for the said clerk they yode in Judgment before god. And
our lady said yt the clerk had ended his days in her service and spoke so yt
Ihesus commanded yt the soul should return unto the body. etc. Men find
another example semblable of a monk secretayne yt was drowned in serving the
vyrgin marie as he yode to accomplysshe his lecherye / and the vyrgyn marye
delivered ye soul in to ye body to amend hy^. etc.

C. Another example how the vyrgyn marye and saint peter delivered a monk from
dampnacyon. Cxxi.
IT is written in the promptuary of the miracles of our lady that there was a
relygyous in the monastery of saint peter the which lived ill / which took
one time a plaster medeynail for the health of body with some freres. And after
he deyed incontinent without confession and without the other sacraments. And
as the deuylles led his soul in to hell saint peter had pity of his monk /
and yode to pray our lord Ihesu christ for his soul And our lord said unto
him how may he be saved the which is deed in sin without doing Justice. When
saint Peter herd his words he yode unto the blyssed vyrgyn marye to the end yt
she should pray for yt soul. And when the vyrgyn marye was before her sone /
he said / Mother what ask ye. And wha^ she had required for the soul of the
said relygyous Ihesus answerde. Sith that it pleases you that he have pardon I
grant for your prayers that the soul return unto his body for to do
penance yt he may be saved. Than saint peter chased away the deuylles / and
commanded two au^gelles to bear the soul in to the body / the which lived
well after and recounted all the deed.

D. Another example of monks yt rose and brake their license. Cxxi
MEn find by writing yt there were of monks yt rose before day and yode in
sporting by a river side / speaking fables and vayn words. And forthwith they
herd a great tempest of ores / and the monks demanded what they were /
which answered we ben enemies of hell yt bear ye soul of ye provost to ye
king of france apostate / for he was in relygyon and left it. Than ye monks
had great fere and said Vyrgyn marye pray for us unto your sone Ihesus. And
the enemies answered ye have done as wise men to call the aid of the vyrgyn
marye. For that yt ye have broken your lycences and are out of your church at
an hour not dew we had put you unto death and borne you with this soul here
in to hell if ye had not called the aid of the vyrgyn marye. And incontynen^
ye monks returned unto their monastery And ye deuylles bare away ye said
soul. etc

E. Another example how he the which brake the arm of the image of ye vyrgyn
marye was strangled of the devil. cxxii
IT is written in the promptuary of the miracles of our lady yt a woman was
pursewed of thieves / and she hid her behind a pyller where the image was of

stroke with a stone the image of ye enfent of the vyrgin marie and brake it.
And incontinent great habou^daunce of blood yode ^ute. Of the which thing all
those that saw this thy^g were a meruayled in praysynge god. And he that
stroke that stroke was strangled of ye devil before al. Another example written
in the miracles of ye vyrgyn marye that a Jew cast an image of the vyrgyn
marye within ye draught And forthwith he was strangled. etc.

A. Another example that a woman ye which deyed in sin was borne again in to
her body for to do penance at the request of the vyrgyn marye for that that ye
said woman had served her. Cxxii
THe disciple recyteth in his promptuarye and says that a woman of honest
conuersacyon commit a sy^ne in you the / the which she ne durst never to
confess / yet was she axed many times / but she had of custom to go as every
day before the image of the vyrgyn marye and there weep her sin unto
herself. And in the end she deyed so / and before yt she was buried her spyryte
came again unto her body / by the merit of the blyssed vyrgyn Marye / and
after yt she had confessed her sin unto the priest she deyed and was saved.
etc.

B. Another example how a man should be dampened and sentencyed unto dampnacyon
he was delivered at the request of the vyrgyn marye and borne again in his
body. Cxxii.
THe dyscyple recyteth in his promptuarye yt as a man should be damned / ye
