that he should yet give him life for to confeffe him. And he accorded unto her
/ but he sentencyed that he should be. xl years in purgatory for to make
satysfaccyon of his sloth / yt is for his penance.

C. Another example how the vyrgyne marye aided unto a friar yt which was
enflambed in hate again the procurour of the covent. Cxxii.
IT is written in the life of faders yt there was at Rome a friar of the order
of prechers the which right hardly treated the procuroure of the couente /
When the pryour had understand this thing he enjoined unto the said hater to
say every day seven pater nosters / ye which hater was more strongly
troubled and enfla^med again the said procuroure / And one day he was seek
and as deed / and he vnpuruayed of wit / began to curse unto his said brother
and unto his order. In the end he said as the freres were in orayson. Mother of
god / mother of god help me. It seemed unto him as he recompted that he was in
brennynge fire for his hate and his Ire / and said yt for the pains
intollerables he had dyspeyred and blasphemed / And at the prayers of the
freres and in calling the aid of the vyrgyn marye was restored unto the
first life / and in probacyon of truth he was all flayne.

D. Another example how the vyrgyn marye aided in Judgment a man yt was
merciful and voluptuous. Cxxii.
THe dysciple recites that it is written yt there was a man full of mercy he
was rauysshed and the Iugementes were showed unto him. In the which he saw
that many were presented unto the Judge. And one presented the almesdedes yt he
had done for the love of god. And another the oraysons yt he had done and said
for the love of god. Another presented the clothes wherewith he had clothed the
^oores. Another the works of mercy that he had done to the poores yt he had
lodged And the said man the which saw ye said things thought unto himself.
Thou haste done more of the works of mercy than those here. Now thou shall
have well before this Judge. So when it came unto his course the Judge ne
demaun^ed hy^ how many works of mercy have thou done / but he him demanded /
what delyces and what voluptuosytees have you wtdrawen from the for the love of
me. And he held his peace / for he had evermore lived in delyces. And the Judge
said unto him / have thou not seen yt I have said in the gospel math. vii.
Arcta e^ via q^ ducit ad vita^ / yt is to say strayte is the way yt ledeth
unto life / yt is unto the realm of heaven. and incontinent the said man turned
hy^ unto the vyrgy mary^ / and unto the saints yt he had served most special
/ and r^quyred them yt they would pray for him / and that in time to come he
should amend his life and purposed to weyke his body in f^stynges and
abstynences and to serve god in time coming. And it was so done. For at the
prayer of the vyrgyn marye and of saints he came to life again / and weyked
his body all the days of his life and lived in great abstynences / and was
more mercyful unto the poor than he ne had be and fined his days in good
consu^macyon. etc.

E. Another example of a relygyous yt which was in his death in Judgment
before god. and the vyrgyn marye and the say^tes of paradyse did aid him.
Cxxii.
THe disciple recyteth in his sermons that there was a young friar relygyous in
ye realm of england in ye coue^^ of bery right devout the which relygyous
was seek to the death / and in the presence of ye suppryour and of five of his
bredern he shytte his eyes with his hand and with full mouth began to laugh.
Unto whom the said suppryour said. Wherefore laugh ye / and he said. That our
king saint Edmonde martyris come / and here all ye house is replenysshed with
aungelles. And he laughed again more ententyfly and said / Our lady is come
salute we her. And after that that they had all said salve regina. etc. The
seek man said. O how agreably has ye vyrgyn marye taken this salutacyon and
in reioysyng made laughyng After that the said seek friar adressed his eyes
toward the door. And his color changed and said unto them. Now is Ihesu
christ comen to judge me. His members were as deed / and he trembled so yt he
swet out of mesure. And as he was constytute before the Judge in all dread he
said sometime ye / nay. And sometime he prayed ye vyrgyn marye yt she ne would
depart from him / sometime he reproved all his accusers / and among other he
began to say. / O Ihesus gy^e me this little. Unto who^ the suppryoure said.
What is yt dear brother / these little sins ben they compted among ye great.
And he said right grievously. Alas ye. And the said suppryour warned him yt he
should not dyspeyre for our lord is merciful. The said seek answered with a
Joyous face. It is a thing verytable yt he is full of mercy / and I yield
thanks unto ye blyssed vyrgyn marye ^ unto the saints the which assyst with
her and the which has made intercession faithfully for me unto Ihesu crist
And after a little of time he deyed and rested in peace. etc.

Innocenti^*
A. Examples of people Innocents and first example. Of a child innocente the
which kept the order of the myneurs relygyous and ne would touch no money /
and deyed well. Cxxiii
IT is written in ye book of honey bees that there was a child the which was
borne of honest parents / when he was five year old / and that he had seen
the order of the freres myneurs he required of his parents yt he might receive
ye habyte / and as they estymed yt his words were childysshe / they knew
after verytably yt the child took him to keep ye customs of the freres
myneurs / for he yode barefoted and gyrde with a hard cord and kept himself
in all manners to touch silver or gold. And in this thing there happened a
meruayllous case. For there came merchants to lodge in his faders house the
which meruayled them to se such a child in such habyte / and to know if he
touched no money one of them cast a penny in to the cup wherein they drank
secretly / and with a little wine gave the cup unto ye child to dry^ke /
which as he had drunk and saw the penny he began to cry horrybly / and cast
away the cup / and said with eyes eleuate. God all puyssau^t thou have known
yt I not known has violed mine order. Afterward he trembled and was pale as
tendynge to ye death. When his fader saw yt he ran for the priest yt
absoyled him / and shortly ye dolor passed / The said child on ye holy days
gadred children and taught them their paturnoster / and aue maria. And if he
saw in them yt they were proud or vycyous he repreued them / in bidding
them serve god. In the conuocacyons of this child the auncyentes ran with
the little child / and also delyted them right much in his prudence and in
his answers and documentes When he saw his fader yt swore or was drunk he had
compassyon and in weeping said unto him. Fader our priest says in the church
yt those ye which do those things ne shall possede paradyse. And in a
solempnyte he repreued his mother in weeping before her pewe felawes because she
was pompously arrayed / and said. My mother right dear fle ye precious clothynges
that thou deserve not the pains eternelles. And without taryeng by the words
of the child his mother had horror of such clothes / and would no more use
them / The manners and the gestes of yt child showed the perfeccyon of virtues
/ and the grace of god being in him. The child had not yet seven years
accomplysshed when he deyed. When death approached he confessed him and required
of the priest the sacrament of ye altar / but ye priest denied it him for his
youth. And ye child with great grace of orayson stratched out his hands
unto the heaven and said. My lord Ihesu christ thou have known that my
sovereign desire is to have ye. I have demanded the / and also I have done
that yt I should do. And I hope that I shall not be void of thy presence. These
things spoken the child cherid his parents weeping yt present were and them
provoked to live better. And among these words of exhortacyon / of orayson
and of lauding he yielded his spirit unto god impolluted And incontinent the
habyte of the order of the freres myneurs yt was cast upon him ne appeared more
/ yt is they were never more seen after. And after his death in his buryeng
some of ye freres myneurs were^ the which ne might never say this psalm
deprofu^dis / albeit they forced the^ and began again many times / the which
gave to understand yt that holy soul ne had indygence of orayson. After the
death of the child the fader and the mother prouffited so much in ye example
of their sone that they left al delyces of ye world And the fader was
relygyous in ye ^rdre of prechers and the mother in the order of women. And so
they entered in to relygyon and served debonayrly. etc. Unto the example of this
innocent we should live well to y end that we may deye well / he was innocent
yt is without sin / and without ill will / he taught to do the good and to
flethe ill. And so should we do to the end that we may escape dampnacyon. For
innocence and virtue keep a man from peril of dampnacyon eternell. Also god
says in ye gospel that if any man keep his commandment without co^myttynge
sin yt he ne shall be dampened. Vn^ john.viii. Si qis sermone^ meu^ seruauerit
morte^ no^ videbit i^eternu^. The said child kept the word of god. Than he
ne ran in to dampnacyon eternell. Also saint gregorye says. Nulla nocebit
aduersitas si nulla dominei^ iniquitas. That is to say none aduersytee shall
noye the as unto the soul if no sy^ne have domynyon in the / no sin ne had
domynyon in the said innocent: ergo. etc Also the holy ysydore says. Nec
plaga: nec mors te trebitur si been vixeris. That is to say / yt neither ye
plage / ne death shall fere the. If you have well lived. The said child lived
well without sin than the death ne noyed him and by the consequent he is
saved. And so shall be those the which lived in innocence without sin. etc.

B. Another example of a scoler innocent the which chased the devil from ^
maiden. Cxxiii.
THe disciple recyteth in his promptuarye yt certain relacyon was made of
those the which were present and the which had seen yt a maiden right much
daunced on a sunday with many young men. When she was weary she returned unto
the house / slepte and was posseded of the devil. She cried the household arose
and she was bound for her woodnes. In the morning she was borne into the
oratorye founded of the vyrgyn marye where many miracles were done. as the
little scolers apperceyued her they ran after where she was tormented. Of the
which children one of the aege of.xii. years ye which was m^re hardy and wise
than the other began to expelle the devil that h^ should issue out of the
maiden. It was showed yt the devil was beside the nau^l. The said child made
with his thombe the sign of the cross under / and so by little and little
thrughe the sign of the cross he chaced the ^euyll upward and made hy^ to
come in to her mouth / in ye which all saw it in the guyse of a grene orchyn
pylled and foul. A meruayllous thing / ye people cried yt he forced to
reentre in again And the child opposed in making the sign of the cross /
and constrained him to issue with great vyolence. When he was out as said is in
lykenes of an orchyn / he took it hardely in his right hand and keste it in ^
dytche where the rain dyscended The which departed before all ye people The
hand of the child was black with tou^hynge of the maiden / but by the
washing of holy water it was made clean / By this child innocent without
sy^ne that did this miracle is to understand that ye estate of innocencye is
much vtyle and agreeable to god / but they must have symplesse and wisdom as
the said child had. And by that yt the maid was a dau^ceresse and the
daughter of the devil for to take and deceive souls for her beauty and by her
manners / the said devil had puyssaunce to enter in to her and tormente her /
wherefore all daunceresses beware by her lest that the devil tormente you in
hell / withouten end. etc.

C. Another example that a little innocent impetred of Ihesu christ pardon for an
apostate. Cxxiii
THe disciple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt a little monk innocent
spoke with Ihesu christ a little child in namynge him his little brother / and was
before the image of the vyrgyn marye that held her sone in her arms. And
Ihesu christ answered and spoke to him amyably as brother to brother. And an
ancient monk yt had be long in apostasye herd this thing / supplied the
little monk that he would pray his little brother yt he would forgive him his
sins / and yt he would receive him to mercy. And the little young Innocent
obtained of his little brother that request / and the auncyente was much
Joyous. etc.

D. Another example that the orayson of children innocents auaylleth much for
the quycke and the deed. Cxxiii.
THe disciple recites in his sermons that it is written in many passages that a
devout bishop saw in his sleep a child fysshynge in a well with a hoke of
gold and with a line of silver / and from the well drew a fair woman When he
was waked he saw yt child in the chircheyarde the which prayed on a tomb /
and he him demanded what he did there. He answerde I say pater noster / and
myserere for the soul of my mother And the holy man understand yt the soul of
that woman was delivered from purgatory by the prayers of that child
innocent / and that pater noster was ye hoke of gold / and miserere was ye
line of silver.

E. Another example of a child innocent ye touched a hot horse shoe. Cxxiiii
THe dysciple recites yt it is written in the book of honey bees that there was a
child in the monastery of ye order of saint benet Innocent and right simple in
his young aege. And one time his abbot led him with him for recreacyon / and
for cause to shoe his horses / the said abbot descended before the door of a
smyth / the which abbot meruaylled him of the simplesse of the said child y
took a hot shoe in his naked hand and lift it up without brennynge him. Then
the abbot and they yt were present were abashed and honored the innocence of
ye said child / and that thing they proved often. After yt the abbot and his
people were occupied in other things / and the said child entered within the
house. The wife of the smyth set him on her knees in meruayllynge her of ye
deed / and in playenge with him. And the wife intysed the child in expert of
malice / and demanded him if he would have such a wife as she was / and he
said ye. The which led hy^ hastily unto bed as not knowinge and instruct
him. He promised to do it / After the lyenge the child was dyspoylled of
innocence / came to the forge and took the hot shoe as he was accustomed but
he was grievously burnt / and ^^yed / of which thing the abbot was much
troubled and thought in his courage yt the soul ^as hurt within sith yt he
was hurt without and that innocence yt had kept him before was no more in him.
Then the abbot led him again in to the abbaye / and inquired him dylygently
for to tell the truth. He confessed the said deed symply. And after by great
teres trembled his do^mage and did repent him. etc.

F. Another example that the devil vnknewe ye sins of ^ synneres after true
confession / and said that she was a good woman. ^xxiii.
MEn find by writing yt god gave diverse goods unto a man and his wife beyng^
in ye cite of ^ome / yt which might have no children / and therefore they
prayed god that they might have some / and he gave them a sone / yt which was
so much beloved of the mother yt she held him often between her arms and
slepte / and the fader of the said sone had a vyage to go to Iherusalem / and
said unto his wife when he should depart yt she should do alms
haboundau^tly / and that she should keep well their sone. And she laid him with
her / and by the admonycyon of ye devil had his company and was with child. Then
she was much angrye and fered the sin and the dishonor of the world and of
her husband / and by the entysemente of the devil yt admonesteth to do ill:
qr peccatu^ peccatu^ atrahit / killed her child when he was borne / without
that any body knew it save only god. Then the devil would that ye sin were
manifest for to lose the wife came unto rome in guyse of a doctor dyuyne
astronomyer / ye which devil told many th^^ges to ye romans yt should
happen. And among the other things said that there was in rome a wife yt had
conceived of her sone her husband being out the which had slain her said
child / And that if the said sy^ne were not avenged yt god should make the
cite perysshe and all they. Then ye romans were much abashed and might not
believe yt the said woman had done the sin for her holly life that she led
and her alms / was made to come before the said deuyne or doctor / the which
accused her to have done the said sy^ne before al. The said woman yt had done
ye said day service to ye vyrgyn marye was suddenly provided of yt that she
should answer and said. Sir ye accuse me of a great thing. And for to give
answer I demand three days of term and I shall answer you. It was granted.
And the mean while she yode to confess her to the pope / the which gave her
in penance to serve the vyrgyn marye / And when it came unto ye term
establysshed the said woman was presented before the senators of Rome / and
before ye said devil in guyse of a doctor / ye which senators said unto the
devil in guyse of a great doctoure. Thou haste accused this woman unto us to
have conceived of her sone and to have slain her child / here she is what
say thou. And ye devil answered it is not this woman here. I never said ill of
^er / this here is a good woman ye which does many good deeds. And also she
has in her company marye ye mother of god ye which makes me to fere. And for
her it behooves me depart / for I am a devil ready to deceive folks.

Virtus.
A. Examples of people virtuous / and first example of vtues of.v. bredern.
cxxiiii
THe dysciple recyteth in his promptuarye and says yt a holy abbot demanded
of five of his brederne / which ben ye virtues yt pleases you before other
and how have ye lived sith that ye were relygyous. The first said I have in
such wise lived yt I remember every day my sins with dolor of heart / and
I am confessed of all yt which I have done to day The second said I have
devised all my time in two parties the one to be employed in devotion and
oraysons / ye other in labors and in seruyces of the freres. And I have
dystrybute faithfully where I have might unto little and great. The third said
I am all given unto the works of mercy and unto compassyon / in such wise
that I weep with those yt weep / and I am Joyful with them yt are Joyous.
The.iiii. said I have evermore gone and adjoined where I was dyspreysed. And I
have in such wise governed me to the end yt I may come to plain humylyte and
pacyence. The v. said I have lived in such manner that I never troubled no man
and I was never troubled of any. The said abbot required of god yt these
things here were unto hy^ reveled. And a voice came fro heaven that said unto
him. I give me. I suffer yt I be found. I sell me. I suffer yt I be stole^ I
suffer yt I be surmou^ted of man. And the abbot yet prayed god to know them
more euydently. Than he herd a voice yt said. I give me unto ye repentau^t. I
suffered me to be found in oraysons and labors I sell me unto him yt has
compassyon on his neighbors / and that enjoys them of their good and well. I
suffer yt I be stolen of ye humble and dyspreysed. And I suffer that I be
surmounted of man the which ne troubles none and holds him in peace. Than
the abbot required to know which was ye best among them. Than a voice came
fro heaven ye said. It is he yt troubles no man / and is not troubled. etc.
For to know what virtue is understand the scryptures of saint Austyn yt says.
quod virtus e^ queda^ equalitas vite: vndique consonans rationi. That is ye
virtue is an equalyte of life the which always sounds and conformeth unto
reason. Et crisos. dicit. quod virtus animi e^ recto de deo sentire et recte
i^ter homines agere. That is to say / the virtue of courage is felyng of god
ryghtfully / and do well right among ye men Et hieronimus dicit quod sola apud
deu^ libertas e^ non seruire peccatis: su^ma apud deu^ nobilitas est clarere
virtutibus. That is to say / only lyberte toward god is / serve not unto
sins / and sovereign noblesse toward god is resplendysshe by virtues / Et
legitur in quarto ethicoru^ quod virtuosus been vtitur qibu^cu^que. The
virtuous use well in all things. Et i^ nono ethicorum dr^ quod virtuosoru^
beatissimae^ vita. The life is right blyssed of the virtuous. Et legi. i^.ii.
ethicoru^. Virtus certior e^: et melior oi^ art. Virtue is more certain and
better than all art and craft. And one ought here to note that one should not
be to Just / nor to unjust for to fle the inconuenyentes yt thereafter may
follow / but one ought to take ye mean. For it is written in.ii. ethico. quod
oi^s virtus co^sistit i^ medio: in oi^bus medium est laudabile. etc.

B. Another example that four virtues were in four hermytes. cxxiiii.
IT is written in the life of faders ye four hermytes were in one house / the
which hermytes one time inquired each other of their virtues and for to show
the most special. One said yt he was so humble yt it seemed him yt none was
wors than he in all the world. The other said that he was pacyente. The third
said ^ he herd gladly speak of god. The fourth said yt he prayed gladly. And
with one assent prayed god to give them knowledge wh^che was most agreeable to hy^
/ and they herd a voice yt said to them. The first has take me / the second
holds me / ye third byndeth me / and the fourth bears me where he will. etc.

C. Another example of the excercyte of five sreres. Cxxiiii
THe dys^yple recyte^^ in his promptuarye and says yt an abbot had.v. freres /
which he commanded to tell their virtues. The first said I have made
general confession every day this ten year The second said I have studied to
have good entencyon in orayson every day by xx. years. The third said I have been meserycordyous asmoche as I might.xxx. years. The fourth said I have
troubled no person by.xl. years / and have sustained al things pacyently.
The.v. said I have sought dyspreysynge by.l. years and have found none
semblable to me in humylyte. Then the abbot prayed god yt he would show which
o^ them were the best. and a voice said to him. The first gives hy^ self to
our lord. The second fy^deth our lord. The.iii bears our lord. The.iiii.
byeth our lord. The.v. vaynquyssheth our lord. etc.

D. Another example how a man and his wife were in like in merit unto saint
pafuncius. Cxxiiii
IT is written in the life of faders yt a holy fader named pafuncius required of
god that he would show unto him upon the earth unto whom he should be
semblable. And a voice came unto hy^ the which said. Know thou yt thou art
like unto the first man of such a street next. When pafuncius herd these
words he yode to knock at ye door of his house. And the man ran before him
as he had of custom to receive his gestes / and washed his fete and set him
to dinner. And between ye metes pafuncius required his host what his deeds were
/ what he studied and unto what operacyons he excersysed him in. He answerde
him of things humbles. For he loved better yt his good deeds were hid than
publysshed. And the said pafuncius said unto him that it was reveled unto him
of god yt he was dygne to be in the company of monks / Than his thought was
yet more humble and said yt he ne was culpable of few good deeds / but sith yt
the word of god has be spoken unto ye from him a man may nothing hyde. I
shall tell than what I have done among many the which ben in vs^ge. Thyrty
years ben now accomplysshed yt I have had consentemente with my wife to keep
chastyte and contynence / and tha^ none of us has had ado with other I have
had three sons of her / and that has because wherefore I have known her to
have lygnee. I never cease to receive gestes / in refusing no body but
gyuynge them their necessytees. I have sytte in judgment. I have not accepted
the person of my sone again Justice. The fruytes of labors of other never
entered in to my house. In all noyses I have put peace / no persons took never
my servants in culpe / nor my beestes never hurt the fruytes of another. I
never defended to labor in my field those yt would saw therein / and also I
never took of the better for to harm the worste / nor never suffered the rich
to ouergo ye poor. I have studied all my life yt I ne should wrath no man. If
I have had Judgment to do yet have I not condampned person but I have studied
me to make peace. The instytucyon of my life has be in these things by the
grace and gift of god. When pafu^cius had herd these words here he kissed
his heed and blyssed him. Bn^dicat tibi du^s ex syon vt videas bona que fecisti
in iherusalem Thou haste well and conuenably done these things beforsayd / but
there faylleth one sovereign good deed / yt is that thou leave all / and that
thou follow the true sapyence of god / the which thou ne may come to if thou
abiecte not thyselfe and deny thyself as ye gospel tells. Nisi abneges temet
ipsu^ et tollas cruce^ tua^ and sequaris xprem. When the said man had herd
these words here without taryenge and without to order any of ye things of his
house followed the man of god and yode with him in to deserte. In the which he
gave unto him ye order of conuersacyon spyrytuel and taught him the excercytes
of the parfyte studyentes and he gave himself unto the science secret. etc.

E. Another example that a mynstrell was semblable in merit unto saint
pafuncius. Cxxiiii
IT is written in the life of faders ye one time saint pafuncius required of god
that he would show him unto whom he were semblable in the world. The answer
was given unto him yt he was semblable unto a mynstrel yt sought his living in
such a town. Than he was abashed of the answer and in dylygence yode unto
the town to seche the man And when he had found him he asked hy^ much what
holy things and relygyeuses he had done / and how he had led his life. / He
answerde yt he had be a man sinner and of cursed life. It is not long time
sith yt I was a thief / and have put me to mayntene this excercitude
myscheuous. and pafu^cyus asked him if among the theftes if he had any good
operacions. He answered I ne feel me culpable of no good deed but as I was
among the theuys there was taken a vyrgyn consecrate unto god that my felawes
would deflore / and I put me in the meddle and took her away fro them / and by
night led her in to the street of her house without having any atouchement
dyshonest. And in another time I found a woman of honest form strayed in
hermytage. I demanded her fro whens / or wherefore / or how she was come in to
that place. And she answerde ne demanded me not I unhappy wife and questyon me
not of those causes / but and it please the to have me for maid / led me
where thou wylt. I woman perverse and ill have had a good husband / the which
is oftentimes beten traylled and put in torments / and is kept in a dongeon
because of dettes yt he owes. We have had three sons together that are also
withdrawn for because of the said debt. And I right unhappy yt am sought for
to be put in se^blable pains / fle from place to place / and of pouerte and
myserye am all abyden / and yet have I ben three days without etyng When I
herd ye said woman I had pity / led her in to our den and gave her to ete
/ for she de^ed for hongre. I gave her also three hondreth shely^ges for to
deliver her out of pain and seruytude / her husband and her sons. When ye
said woman had the money she yode in to the cite and delyuerd them from pains.
Then pafu^cius said yt he never did such things. God has showed me of the
that thou have not less of merit toward him than I and therefore dysprayse
not thy soul that shall have such merit. When the mynstrell herd these
words of pafuncius he cast away his pypes and went with him into his
hermytage / and changed his song seculer in to spyrytuell / and excercysed
him in fastings / oraysons / afflyccyons / and to live straytly. And at the
end o^ three years he yielded up his spyryte unto god. etc.

F. Another example that a provost and his wife were se^blables to an hermyte.
cxxiiii
IT is written in the life of faders yt an hermyte was full of great abstinences
so yt he ete but rotes and pouertees / made request to god yt it pleased him
to show if there were any man in the world that were of strayter life than he.
Then god reveled him yt he should go se the life of the provost of such a
town. Th^rmyte yode. And when he approached the said town he found ye provost
on a fair horse clothe with fair clothes / and in his company many ryders and
notable folk / so he was much abashed (...) se so great pompes. Told to ye
provost how god commanded him to se his life. And the provost badde him go to
his wife which should show him their lives. Then he yode to her the which
showed him the state of the house And she made to preprayre unto dynere of
precious metes as she had accustomed And when they were set at dinner men
brought the first metes of good vyandes before them. And incontynente that they
had be set upon the table they were borne away again without any thing etyng
of chem After men brought the second metes / and the third / and every of
thyem better than other / and were borne away without any thing etynge. The
hermyte seeing so good mete taken away fro before hy^ demanded them / but it
was told him that he should live yt day after the life of them. And at the
last men brought of musty bread all knaw^n with myse. And the wife of the
provost ete a little / and she ne ete of other / but al was given and
dystrybuted unto the poor. After when yt even tide came to go to bed ye wife
of ye provost said unto the hermyte yt they should goo to bed together / the
hermyte would not / but the wife said unto him that he should / and that it
behooved yt he saw how they lived. Than when they were laid and warm the
hermyte was tempted of ye sin of the flesh to have so fair a woman by him
and would have delte with her. Than she said / up up rise we and do we as we
have accustomed my husband and I And when they were up they yode in to a tubbe
of cold water yt was by the beds side. And they were there so long yt they
trembled of cold. Afterward they yode to bed / and when they were hot
again the hermyte was tempted of lecherye / and would have had her company.
Than returned they again in to ye tubbe of col^^ water. All the night ne
cessed they to do so. And the hermyte seeing that said unto himself yt they
led a more straytter life than he far / and that it was reason that they
had more great merit than he And the provost that was so well clothed was also
a man of good Justice to punysshe the malefactors and to yield unto every man
that the which was his. etc.

G. Of fastings / and abstynences of saint Germayn. Cxxiiii.
IT is written ye saint germain was noble / for he was duke of Burgundye / and
after was bishop. He tormented his body by.xxx. year so that he ne ete of
bread of whete / ne yet drank of wine but two times in the year yt is to say
at crystenmas and Eester. And it was meddled so much with water yt it ne had
but a little taste of wine. Also in the.xxx. years he ne ete of pese ne of
benes / ne salt for to have savor in his mouth. For his refeccyo^ he ete
first of the ashes / and after of barley bread. In winter ne yet in somer he
had none other clothing but only the here his robe and his rochet yt is his
habit ye which he ne put of / but only when he gave it unto any poor / or
that he ne brake it. / His bed was of ashes and besen with here and with a
sack / he ne had never under his heed ne under his sholdres feder / but waylled
and bare the relyques of his saints about his neck. He ne vngyrded him but
seldom. That yt he bare of abstynence in this present life was above man. And
after he did so many of miracles yt if the merytes ne had proceeded men would
hane wend that it had be a fantasye. etc.

H. Of the great austeryte of two women. Cxxiiii.
IT is written in ye book of honey bees that there was a woman in ye parties of
barba^ce recluse in a little tabernacle yt ware next unto her flesh an
haubergon of mayle / and above the said haubergon she had an here made of
hogs brystilles ye which prycked her flesh through the maylles of the said
haubergon. She lay upon the earth naked and among the stones / and ete three
times alonely in the weke. And she put of ashes in her bread and ne ete but by
weight and mesure:

I. Another example. Cxxiiii.
THe disciple recites in his sermons that a vyrgyn was in her
hermytage.xxxviii. years the which dwelled in a dytche and served god
deuoutely. And she never ete in the said hermytage but herbs fruytes and rotes
/ and in all that time she ne saw no man. And afterward two hermytes passed
by her entered into ye dytche there they found her d^ed and put her in
sepulcre. etc. By these examples of this book a man may know by experyence
that it is ill taken unto sinners dysobeyssau^tes unto god / and that it is
well taken unto the obedyentes. And therefore thou the which art in this world
living myrre thy self in the example of thy neighbor and know thou yt it
shall take ye in like wise as it is done unto him if thou dysobey unto god.
When thou have seen thy neighbor fall in to an ylle passage and that it is
inconuenyente of body or of soul / or to fall in to hell by his folly thou
sholdest keep the for to do as he did / or thou sh^lte not be wise / but thou
sholdest learn ye manners and condycyons of those ye which has lived holyly
and virtuously in obeyeng unto the commandments of god to the end to go with
him in to the glory of paradyse unto the which we may go cu^ illo qui est
benedictus i^ secula seculoru^. amen.

Here ends the book intytuled the flower of the commandments of god with
many examples and auctorytes extr^cte as well of the holy scryptures as of other
doctors and good ancient faders the which is much prouffytable and vtyle
unto all people / lately translated out of Frensshe in to English in the
years of our lord. M.CCCCCix. Enprynted at London in Fleet street at the sign
of the son by Wynkynde Word. The second year of ye reygne of our most
naturell sovereign lord king Henry the eight of that name. Fynysshed the year
of our lord. M.CCCCC.x. the.xiiii. day of Septembre.
